But no matter how effusively the dinner speakers echo the Carter tribute, a hollow quality will be imparted to their praise by organized labor's current charge that all the legal guarantees for employee freedom of choice and goodfaith bargaining are a delusion where employers are bent on unionbusting.

title: Living Abroad: Rome
description: WHEN I leave my apartment each morning at 7:30 on the daily search for a blade of Roman grass for my dog, our maid, Marisa, is across the street shaking carpets from a neighbor's balcony.

title: For theYoung Audience at a Spelling Bee, TV Reporters and Not Words, Cast a Spell
description: When one considers the kinds of battles that have taken place under the roof of Madison Square GardenJoe Frazier vs. Muhammad Ali, the Knicks vs the Celtics, the Ringling Brothers lion trainer vs the Ringling Brothers lionsthe competition waged there yesterday morning might, at first, have seemed tame.

title: $96 Million N.Y. State Bond Issue Is Sold at Yields as High as 6%
description: New York State sold a $96 million bond issue yesterday and  thanks to some support from President Carterappeared to be making progress toward more normal acceptance in the bond market. Although once again the state re

title: Pamela Harriman's Role: Hostess to the Powerful
description: WASHINGTONThc Geergetown mansion is filled with French and Englisl, antiques. Impressionist paintings, Chinese porcelain, memorabilia a the famous zinc! great. It bespeaks wealth and quiet, flawless good taste.

title: Putting the Heat on Seoul
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Can South Korea's dictatorial President, Park Chung Hee, breathe a sigh of relief now that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has announced that the new Administration will not be cutting military and economic aid to his Government? Has the threat from the North, which Mr. Park has so long invoked as justification for his repression, won out again over what Mr. Vance called our great concern about the human rights situation in that country?

title: A Western Cruise Ship Ends First Visit to China
description: HONG KONG, March 1The first Western cruise liner permitted to dock in China since 1949 returned to Hong Kong from Canton today after three days that included free acupuncture treatment for its passengers, a visit to a commune and a recital of political songs by Chinese schoolchildren.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 2, 1977

title: WarnerLambert Net Drops 31.6%; A Series of Misfortunes Are Cited
description: Fourthquarter earnings of the Warner Lambert Company, a producer of drugs and optical and scientific products, fell by 31.6 percent to $21 million, or 27 cents a share, from $30.7 million, or 39 cents a share, for 1975's final quarter.

title: 75 Years of Jungle Survival
description: What's 75 years old, has 60, 70 or 80 legs and weighs slightly more than 2 ounces?

title: Washington Pleased As Amin Lifts Ban On Americans
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Preiident Idi Amin of Uganda today dropped his demand that all Americans in Uganda remain in the country notii they meet with him, and the Carter Administration looked baci't with F. satisfaction over its handling of the case, its first international crisis.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Enid Nemy

title: Raw Fish and Colt's Meat Grace Siberian Picnic in Snow at 20
description: IN THE SIBERIAN TAIGAWhat do Siberians do when they are sitting around bored and it's 58 below outside? Go on a picnic, naturally.

title: Wife of Senile Coast Judge Is Named His Conservator
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1 (AP)Margaret McComb, wife of Marshall McComb California Supreme Court Justice, has been named conservator for her husband. giving her the right to make nonjudicial decisions for the 82yearold judge. Mrs. McComb said that the judge could no longer care for himself or his property.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO PERMIT CREDIT UNION MORTGAGES
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)The House voted today to allow credit unions to make home mortgage interest loans and also voted to extend Regulation Q, which regulates interest ceilings on time and savings deposits.

title: Bus Strike Affects 10,000 City Riders
description: Drivers and maintenance employes of the Pioneer Bus Corporation went on strike yesterday, halting express bus service between Brooklyn and Manhattan for about 10,000 daily riders.

title: LIEUT. COL. YOSSI YAFEH
description: TEL AVIV, March 1 (AP)Lieut. Col. Yossi dell, a hero of the capture of East Jerusalem in the 1967 ArabIsraeli war, was killed yesterday when his jeep accidentally hit a land mine, the Israeli military command announced today. He was 42. In the battle for the Arab sector or Jerusalem, he commanded the paratrooper force that captured a Jordanian police station on Ammunition Hill on the approaches to the Old City.

title: About Real Estate
description: BALDWINSVILLE, N.Y.The name Pierre Esprit Radisson is considerably less than a household word even in these parts, which he explored in the 16th century in the company first of his Mohawk Indian captors, and then on his own. Later he went West, still exploring.

title: Young Is Security Council President, and U. N. Waits for CloseUp Look
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1Andrew Young began a monthlong term today as president of the Security Council and a curious United Nations waited to get a closeup look at the man whom President Carter calls one of the best personal friends I have in the world.

title: People and Business
description: It was reminiscent of the garbledsyntax Eisenhower days. The United States Steel Corporation yesterday issued a clarifying statement for its chairman, Edgar B. Speer, who was quoted on Monday as saying that while the winter's natural gas shortages certainly will affect the company's firstquarter results, the effects would be very limited.

title: Study Minimizes Effects Of Oil Spills Off Coast
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 (AP)The longrange effects of major oil spills may not he as damaging as feared, according to a study by three oceanographers of World War II tanker sinkings off the East Coast.

title: Governors Back StripMine Curb, But Ask to Be Consulted on a Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The nation's governors endorsed today Federal legislation that would impose environmental standards on strip mining.

title: S.C.C.A. Head Resigns, Hurting CanAm Series
description: DENVER, March 1Tom Duval, who was appointed to the post only nine days ago, submitted his resignation today as director of professional racing of the Sports Car Club of America (S.C.C.A.) in an apparent split between the club's board of governors and the Held staff over how pro racing should be conducted.

title: Deaths
description: alLERSTEINMildred. Beloved wife of Morris, devoted mother of Rosalie Fossel, Sylvia Bohm, Nat, Rachel Manoogian. Darling grandmother of Steven Lawrence Russel, Anita Gott. Neb. Kenneth Bobrow, Kathy Miller, Brad Adlerstein and grealerandmother of Katie Bobrow. Dear sister of Herbert Hanover and Dr. Irwin Hanover. Services 1 P.M. Thursday at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial, 1283 Coney Island Ave. (Ave. it Brooklyn.

title: Husband Held as Wife's Slayer
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 1 (AP) The estranged husband of a mother of 10 children found shot to death in hen home Sunday has been arrested and charged with murder, the police said. Victor Davila, 39 years old, of Nev./ Brunswick, was arraigned yesterday and remanded without bail to the Middlesex County Jail for the murder of his wife, Rosario Davila, 35, the police said.

title: 2 Disease Center Aides Killed by Mystery Ailment
description: ATLANTA, March 1 (AP)The Center for Disease Control, which has frequently been asked to investigate mysterious ailments throughout the world, began today to try to solve the mystery of a disease that killed two of its own employees.

title: Books of The Times
description: The land use in the title of this useful book, prepared by the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private citizens environmentalaction group, embraces a broad range of human activities, from manufacturing to highway building, from sewage disposal to speculative sales. In the beginning of this country, land was the most alluring resourceonce tales of gold and Edenic plenty were discounted by actual experience.

title: A 1986 Rendezvous Awaiting Halley's Cornet
description: People used to view the appearance of a great comet, particularly Halley's, with fear and trembling. In 1910, during the last appearance of Halley's comet, patent medicine hawkers enriched themselves by selling comet pills to ward off any evil influences that the dreaded star may import.

title: Financing Medical Care
description: MEDICARE has proved to be something of a Catch22 for people over age 65. It was originally designed to help take up some of the slack left by private healthinsurance plans. Rising medical costs have so eroded the value of Medicare, however, that private health insurance has become more important than ever.

title: Coffee and Cocoa Prices Advance to Records Again As Futures Rise the Limit
description: Record prices were again posted in the coffee and cocoa futures markets yester. day as both commodities were locked into limit gains for most of the day.

title: Carter Sends Congress Bill For an Energy Department
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)President Carter today sent to Congress his proposal to create a Department of Energy that would combine all or part of at least nine existing agencies with manpower totaling nearly 20,000.

title: Where Have All The Reruns Gone?
description: March, in normal times, would mark the start of the television rerun season. The series that had their premieres in September would have run their sixmonth course just in time for the networks to put their schedules on automatic pilotby repeating the episodes while drafting plans for the campaign next fall.

title: British Seamen Capture StrikeBound Tanker
description: LE HAVRE, France, Wednesday. March 2 (Reuters)More than 30 British seamen stormed the strikebound tanker Globtik Venus early today to end a twoweek occupation of the vessel by its Philippine crew.

title: Dow Up 8.31 for Year's Best Gain Despite Adverse Economic News
description: The stock market, continuing to shrug off negative economic news, advanced along a wide front yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Survey Finds That Most Children Are Happy at Home but Fear World
description: Most of the nation's grammar schoolage children are happy with their family lives but fearful of the world at largetwothirds are afraid that somebody bad might get into their houses; a quarter are afraid that when they go outside somebody might hurt them.

title: Knicks Bow To Spurs By 132127
description: Remember when the cry of DEFENSE, DEFENSE rang through Madison Square Garden meaningfully and when 127 points were more than enough for the Knicks to win with ease?

description: International

title: A Tastier Chunk of Beef Is More Than Pot Luck
description: Among the best and most frequently offered meat specials these days are boneless beef roasts, an allinclusive term that covers such cuts as top and bottom round, eye round, top sirloin, rump, brisket and chuck.

title: College Basketball
description: By The Associated Prees

title: Adult Learning Center in Hackensack Beset by Deteriorating Facilities
description: HACKENSACK, March 1Just behind the tables crowded with students study ing for their high school equivalency diploma was a cluster of 11 plastic buckets, strategically placed to catch the water that has been leaking through the ceilings since early last month.

title: Bar Inspector Indicted
description: Alphonso L. Santoro, 37 years old, of Beechwood in Ocean County, an inspector for the Division of Alcohol Beverage Control, has been indicted on charges of taking a fee from a Lakewood bar owner in return for faking a report. The director of criminal justice, Robert J. Del Tufo, said that Mr. Santoro would be suspended immediately from his job as senior inspector.

title: 65th Appeal for Neediest Marks Record With $1,069,034.03 in Gifts
description: The 65th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended yesterday with a record total of 51.069,034.03 in contributions from 10.232 donors.

title: Business Records
description: Tuesday, March 1. 1977

title: Edison Police Sick
description: Police sergeants and detectives joined a contractrelated sickout in Edison, leaving the township of 70,000 residents with only 15 or its 130 police officers reporting for duly.

title: Frame Before Picture
description: BRUSSELSAlready prior to the 1967 SixDay War, which dramatically altered the Middle East balance in Israel's favor, it was possible to discern important changes in the frame enclosing the picture of continuing Palestine conflict.

title: The Producer Who Didn't Want Robert Redford..
description: HOLLYWOOD JOHN BECK, Susan Sarandon, and MarieFrance Pisierhardly names to conjure withare, at the moment, starring in flossy $8.5 million movie whose producer insists he would not have wanted Robert Redford even if the latter had asked for John Beck's part.

title: Technology
description: At the end of this week, representatives of selected potential customers will gather at the Intel Corporation in Santa Clara, Calif., to observe the latest turn in the war of memory technologies that continually shakes the semiconductor industry.

title: Beame and Sutton Call on Carey To Sign Bill Setting June Primary
description: Mayor Beame and Borough President Percy E. Sutton a Manhattan urged Governor Carey yesterday to sign a Juneprimary billa decision the Governor said he was still weighing.

title: Escapee Arraigned
description: Raymond Alves, a 34yearold convicted rapist who escaped from the Bergen County Jail Jan. 10 and was recaptured by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last Saturday in Woodbridge, was arraigned on escape charges in Superior Court in Hackensack. A plea of not guilty was entered for Mr. Alves, who was then remanded to a maximumsecurity cell in the jail. He now awaits evaluation at the state's sexoffender treatment program at Avenel and eventual sentencing for raping a 16yearold Clifton girl in February 1975. He was convicted of that crime on Dec. 22.

title: New York Plans 10% Reduction In Bus Service
description: The city's bus service is to be reduced by 207 runs, or 10 percent, on March 20, it was announced yesterday, but transit agencies and the transit unions are deadlocked over how it should be done.

title: Technology
description: The latest turn in the war of memory technologies is a tiny chip that can yield information stored in one of its 4.096 microscopic memory cells in about 45 billionths of a second. It uses an advanced form of metal oxide conductor technology. Page 138.

title: Junketeering as an Art: Act as if You Paid for the Ride
description: New Yorkers, etc.

title: City Record to Shrink
description: Apparently prodded by an audit by the New York City Comptroller, John T. Carroll, administrator of Municipal Services, announced that the page size of the City Record would be reduced to 8 by 11 inches for an annual saving of $250,000, Sealed bids for a new printing contract for the Record are now being accepted by the Department of Purchase. Two hours before Mr. Carroll made his announcement, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin released an audit recommending changes in the Record's operations that he said would reduce the current annual cost of publication of $1.7 million by $450,000.

title: Montclair School Plan for Racial Balance Challenged
description: M0NTCLAIR. March 1This Essex County community is once again embroiled in a dispute over how best to achieve racial balance in its public schols.

title: BanCal's Directors Reject Britons Bid
description: Plans for a foreign takeover of one of America's largest banks collapsed yesterday when directors of the BanCal TriState Corporation, a major California banking concern, rejected an offer by the Standard Chartered Bank of London.

title: Green Acres Grant
description: The state announced a $124,500 Green Acres grant to Rochelle Park to develop a park. The Department of Environmental Protection said the Bergen County town would match the state grant for the development of William Carlock Park.

title: OFFER TO AMERICAN U. BY KOREAN REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, March1The South Korean Government tried to set up an academic listening and lobbying post at American University here last year through a special agent, Hancho C. Kim, according to university officials and Koreans aware of the plan.

title: Gen. Haig Urges Congress to End ArmsSale Embargo Against Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, urged today that the Congress end its twoyearold embargo on arms deliveries to Turkey.

title: Woman Surrenders To Federal Officers In Terrorism Case
description: With one last smile to a friend, Raisa Nemikin, a 27yearold secretary who works for the Episcopal Church, walked toward the glass doors of the Metropolitan Correctional Center here yesterday afternoon and surrendered herself to Federal marshals.

title: Breakup Won't Help Prices, Oil Group Says
description: A study by the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation has concluded, that, contrary to some contentions, breaking up the major oil companies would not increase pressure on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to moderate prices.

title: Court Bars Papers From Owning Radio Or TV in Same City
description: WASHINGTON, March 1A threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals here today voided a rule by the Federal Communications Commission that allows newspapers to own broadcasting stations in the same city where they publish.

title: U.S. HIGH COURT BACKS USE OF RACIAL QUOTAS FOR VOTING DISTRICTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The Supreme Court ruled 7 to 1 today that a state drawing up a reapportionment plan may sometimes use racial quotas that are designed to assure that blacks and other nonwhites have majorities in certain legislative districts.

title: Senate in North Carolina Rejects Rights Amendment
description: RALEIGH, N. C., March 1 (UPI)The North Carolina Senate, despite the urging of President Carter and his wife, defeated the equal rights amendment today, leaving the measure three states short of becoming the 27th amendment to the Constitution.

title: CARTER SEEKS CURBS ON MILITARY PENSIONS
description: WASHINGTON. March 1President Carter said today that ha expected to name a blue ribbon commission to study ways of curbing the rising and almost uncontrollable costs of military retirement pensions and other manpower costs in the defense establishment.

title: High Court Overturns Film Dealer's Conviction In a 73 Obscenity Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)The Supreme Court said today that prosecutors could not seek obscenity convictions using standards set up by a high court decision in 1973 if the alleged offense occurred before that ruling.

title: CORRESPONDENTS
description: VIENNA, March 1The Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry today gave the United States Embassy in Prague some of the papers that the police had seized from two reporters in recent incidents. The authorities kept personal notes and other material, described as objectionable.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Garramone Enters the Race for Governor
description: HACKENSACK, March 1State Senator Raymond Garramone of Haworth became today the fifth announced Democratic candidate for Governor. He pledged to run a people's campaign, and announced his support for keeping the present

title: On Losing a Friend Your Private World Can Least Afford
description: Private Lives

title: A Little Zoning Is a Good Thing
description: Zoning Is often interpreted by builders as a challenge to see how minimal their compliance with the regulations can be. In the case of incentive zoning, in which the builder is allowed bonus space in exchange for providing desirable public features, the assumption is that a bigger building will be offset by environmental benefits. Openspace zoning, in particular, has given builders 20 percent more floor area in return for a streetlevel plaza.

title: In Aemoriam
description: DE NAPOLIPeter. March 2, 1970. In loving memory of our dear brother.

title: Engel, a Liberal, Barely Wins Race for Assembly
description: Patrick J. Cunningham. the Bronx Democratic leader, appeared to suffer political blow last night as Elliot Engel, a Liberal, was declared a narrow victor over Theodore Weinstein, the regular Democrat candidate in a race for Assembly in the Bronx.

title: Toll in Moscow Hotel Fire Put at 45
description: MOSCOW, March 1  A wellplaced Soviet medical source said today that at least 45 lives were lost in the Rossiya Hotel fire on Friday. The count was reportedly made by the central statistical office of the Moscow ambulance service, but it may not represent the full scope of the catastrophe.

title: Letters
description: A Proud Cook Boils Over

title: Record of the Annual Appeals Back to 1912
description: The fund for The New York Times Neediest Cases was started in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was publisher of The New York Times until his death in 1935. Contributions to the 66th annual appeal can he sent to he New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. P.O. Box 5193. Church Street Station, New York, N.Y. 10249.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LEAVE EM LAUGHING New York is wellblessed with places where budding comics and singers can bloom in front of live paying audiences, which are the toughest kind. We've had the Improvisation, Catch a Rising Star andin Sheepshead BayPip's. Now the Comic Strip has come along, hi cozy quarters at 1156 Second Avenue, near 81st Street (8619386).

title: TALKS IN SCHOOL STRIKE ORDERED IN WATERBURY
description: WATERBURY. Conn., March 1A Superior Court judge today directed the leaders of the teachers union and the Board of Education to hold nonstop negotiations in the courthouse to settle the fivedayold strike that has closed the 29 public schools here.

description: While horseplayers continue risking their money on Steve Cauthen, the 16yearold apprentice jockey has been looking for safer investments.
