title: ENFORCEMENT OF NEW FISHING ZONE BEGINS: A Coast Guard cutter, foreground, keeping a Soviet fishing boat under surveillance yesterday
description: Off Cape Cod, Mass., as the United States began enforcing its new 200mile fishing limit on foreign fleets. An article will be found on page D14.

title: JERSEY DEFENDANT CALLED NO ASSASSIN
description: CAMDEN, N.J., March 1 (AP)Robert W. Dufala, charged with threatening to assassinate Vice President Rockefeller last year, is a daydreamer and a small man with illusions of grandeur caught up in a plot made up by the Secret Service the defense contended today.

title: REP. BROOKS ASSAILS REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, March IRepresentative Jack Brooks, chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, began today his lonely stand against President Carter's request for authority from Congress to reorganize the Government by calling the Carter proposal not in any shape, form or fashion constitutional.

title: Hispanic Group Asks Carter for More Jobs
description: The recently founded Congressional Hispanic Caucus expressed concern to President Carter yesterday over the number of Hispanic appointments by the Administration and urged support for legislation that would benefit the nation's growing Spanishspeaking population.

title: Advertising
description: BristolMyers does care about the consumer because the consumer is why we're here today, said Bruce S. Gelb, executive vice president, as he explained a company program intended to make better and safer consumers.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: ALTHOUGH the best cuts of veal most assuredly rest in the luxury category where meats are concerned, they are difficult to ignore when it is a question of cooking gourmetstyle within an hour's time. This article then is for those times when you wish to stretch the budget bit for a hurried but special occasion.

title: Kazuko Hayami at Piano
description: Kazuko Hayami, a young pianist from Tokyo who made her formal New York debut last spring, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall late Sunday afternoon. Miss Hayami is a painstakingly precise technician and an orderly musical thinker. Her rather literal, almost petitpoint style would not appear to be suitable to everything in the repertory, the Romantics, for instance, but in the music that she did choose to play such an approach had its strong points.

title: Boy in Newark Crushed to Death. _ While Playing on Elevator Roof
description: NEWARK, March 1 (AP)A 14yearold boy was crushed to death while playing on the roof of an elevator in a city housing project here, the police said.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: A Federal Court order requiring the Cities Service Oil Company of Lake Charles, La., to pay $1.7 million to compensate 374 black workers for economic losses sustained as a result of racial discrimination was announced yesterday by the Legal Defense and Education Fund of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: MONTH'S U.S. AUTO OUTPUT UP DESPITE COLD WEATHER
description: DETROIT, March 1The United States automobile industry reported today that it built 697,118 cars in February, up 2.3 percent from the yearearlier 681,704 but nearly 84,000 below the number scheduled to he produced.

title: Carter Asks Governors To Help Him Organize Foreign Exchange Project
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)President Carter asked the nation's governors tonight to join him in establishing a volunteer exchange program that would send Americans abroad and bring foreign citizens to the United States to promote common understanding.

title: Soviet Dissenters Vow to Fight On
description: MOSCOW, March 1Soviet dissidents who formed a group last May to monitor Soviet compliance with the human rights provisions of the Helsinki agreement say they intend to keep collecting information about violations despite pressure from authorities, including the arrest of four members last month.

title: Andrus Asks Appeal On Atlantic Drilling
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI) Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus, disputing a ruling that his predecessor acted illegally, asked the Justice Department today to appeal a Federal court order blocking the first effort to tap Atlantic Ocean oil and gas riches.

title: Physicist Denies Teriorist Links
description: BONN, March. 1A West German atomic physicist accused by the Government of having close relations with international terrorists and their sympathizers denied it today and demanded a formal exoneration from the Interior Ministry.

title: Education Lobby Girding to Fight Cuts in School Impact Aid Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The nation's education lobby is gearing up for its perennial battle to restore cuts planned in the program for education aid to federally affected areas.

title: The Chocolate Doughnut With a Dial Tone
description: See Page C10

title: Argentina and Uruguay Reject U.S. Assistance Linked to Human Rights
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 1The military regimes of Argentina and Uruguay today spurned United States foreign aid linked to respect for human rights.

title: $175 Million Bonds Sold By Quebec in First Issue Since Separatist Victory
description: MONTREAL, March 1Quebec concluded successfully today its first sale of bonds on the Canadian market since the separatist government came into power last November.

title: The FleetFooted Athlete's Delight: Sneakers Page C11
description: Pamela Harriman: A Life In The Political Shadows Page C14

title: Carter Policy and Clifford Visit Seem to Ease Cyprus Crisis
description: ATHENS, March 1Now that Clark M. Clifford has completed his factfinding mission in the eastern Mediterranean, the outline of President Carter's policy toward this region is starting to become clear. In several important ways it de

title: Stevens Labor Policies Assailed at Annual Meeting
description: Union representatives and a broad spectrum of religious groups leveled repeated attacks and criticism at the labor and hiring policies of J. P. Stevens & Company at a crowded annual stockholders meetina yesterday.

title: Let's Have an Election
description: Now it is Governor Carey who is being asked to join the shoddy election game by vetoing this week the rules for the New York primary elections that the Legislature delivered to him last week. Indeed, the case for continued fiddling with the rules of government is cast now as a case for good governmentthe sudden discovery that a September primary for Mayor of New York would produce so many more worthy candidates than a primary in June. With this sort of juggling, New Yorkers may wake up one morning to be told that the primary was actually held yesterday.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 1, 1977

title: If It Really Takes All Kinds, Queens Certainly Has What It Takes
description: Queens has supplanted Manhattan. Brooklyn and the Bronx as the city's most bubbly melting pot, with a strong middleclass flavor. The borough may also be the most varied ethnic mixture in the nation.

title: Summonses Audited
description: The City's Parking Violations Bureau had 7.3 million uncollected summonses with a potential value of $247 million outstanding in June 1976, according to an audit released by State Comptroller Arthur Levitt. The audit found that 4.2 million more summons (value about

title: Hofstra Is a 21Victory Team Seeking Recognition
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 1Today's college basketball quiz asks for the name of the first team with 20 victories in the metropolitan area this season.

title: Certificates of High School Proficiency Stir Controversy
description: What is the purpose of high school? Some cynics say it is simply a holding institution, a place for keeping youths off the streets and out of the labor markets.

title: If It Really Takes All Kinds, Queens Certainly Has That It Takes
description: Queens has supplanted Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx as the city's most bubbly melting pot, with a strong middleclass flavor. The borough may also be the most varied ethnic mixture in the nation.

title: Newborn Baby Saved From a Shopping Bag
description: The plastic shopping bag pushed up against a hedge bordering a sidewalk near Prospect Park in Brooklyn looked empty. But when a woman walking her dogs looked inside she found newborn baby boy.

title: Colleges Are Lagging In Enrollments
description: In an effort to reverse lagging registrationswhich would endanger the university's futurethe City University has begun a wideranging program of inducements to make enrollment more attractive.

title: ENFORCEMENT OF NEW FISHING ZONE BEGINS: A Coast Guard cutter, foreground, keeping a Soviet fishing vessel under surveillance yesterday
Swiss National Bank Sells Dollars in a Move to Halt Slide of Country's Franc
description: ZURICH, March 1 (Reuters)The Swiss National Bank sold dollars on the foreign exchange market here today in a rare intervention to check the slide of the Swiss franc, dealers said.

title: The Paris Reunion
description: The Paris Reunion concert, which took place at Environ on Sunday evening, had neither the organizational coherence nor the compositional variety to which followers of new jozz in New York have become accustomed. The individual players  Steve Potts and Oliver Lake on saxophones, Peter Warren on bass and Oliver Johnson on drums  were accomplished and resourceful. Bright moments were abundant, But overall the music sprawled.

title: FRED PABST, PIONEER IN SKI INDUSTRY, DIES
description: MANCHESTER, Vt., March 1 (AP)Fred Pabst, founder of the Bromley Ski Area here and a pioneer in many aspects of the ski industry, died last night at his home. He was 78 years old and a member of the National Ski Hall of Fame.

title: 12 BIG U.S. CONCERNS IN SOUTH AFRICA SET EQUALITY IN PLANTS
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 1  Twelve major United States corporations, including the General Motors Corporation, International Business Machines Corporation and Citicorp, have agreed to support a set of six principles aimed to end segregation and to promote fair employment practices at their plants and other facilities in South Africa.

title: Grant Hurt by Beaver s Griping to Press
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1The New York Mets worked on two front s today to repair relations with their sulking stars: they made a slightly new offer to Dave Kingman, their million holdout, and they said that they were hurt and disappointed by Tom Seaver's recent attack on the frontoffice management.

title: People in Sports
description: Nadia Comaneci, the tiny. 15yearold Rumanian gymnast, is reported ill and has been advised not to perform, the United States Gymnastics Federation announced last night. Miss Comaneci's illness has caused the cancellation of a fivecity American tour by five Rumanian gymnasts, slated to begin March 15.

title: Bishops in Nicaragua Say Troops Kill Civilians in Fighting Leftists
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 1Nicaragua's Roman Catholic bishops have accused government forces of resorting to widespread torture, rape and summary executions of civilians in their battle against leftist guerrillas in this impoverished Central American republic.

title: Eritrean Guerrillas Wearing Down Ethiopian Troops
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Feb. 28Guerrillas fighting for the independence of the northernmost province of Eritrea reportedly are wearing down the morale of 20,000 Ethiopian troops, whose hold on the hot and rugged territory is apparently slipping.

title: EthnicReligious Data
description: According to the 1970 Census figures, there were 1,695.288 whites in Queens and 258,006 blacks. Other categories were: Chinese, 12,855; Japanese, 6,100; unclassified whites, 9,399; American Indians, 1,840. There were 153,691. people of Hispanic origin, of whom 33,141 were Puerto Rican.

title: From Prison To Exile Role Vladimir K. Bukovsky
description: MOSCOW, March 1Two and a half months after he was freed in a surprise exchange for the Chilean Communist Party's leader, Luis Corvalan Lepe, Vladimir K. Bukovsky remains a hero of almost legendary proportion among the Soviet dissident movement.

title: Dr. Adele Franklin Dies at Age 80; Began AllDay Schools Program
description: Dr. Adele Franklin, founder of an innovative and influential program for elementary school children in underprivileged areas of New York City, died Monday in South Bend, Ind., where she had been hospitalized for two years. She was 80 years old and had lived at 470 West 24th Street.

title: A Correction
description: An item in the New Jersey Briefs yesterday said that the head of the Opticon Hearing Aid Company on Academy Street in Newark had lost his license under the state's consumerfraud law. The correct name of the company is Academy Hearing Aid Centers of Newark and Livingston.

title: ... He Wanted John Beck. John Beck?
description: HOLLYWOOD

title: Chilean Economics
description: The economic life of a country the product of many factors, past and present, whose complex interaction cannot he ignored if a fair analysis is to be made. Chile is a case in point. Much has been written about its current situation, ignoring historical perspective.

title: U.S. Delays Dam Project After Plea From Ottawa
description: OTTAWA, March 1The State Department has advised Canada that the construction of a controversial dam and reservoir in North Dakota will be held up pending a report on whether the project might pollute Canadian rivers.

title: Jazz:
description: The Thad JonesNiel Lewis Band, moving into its 12th year of Monday evening performances at the Village Vanguard, has been joined by Aura Urziceanu, a singer from Rumania who made a memorable impression at her only previous New York appearance. with Duke Ellington's orchestra at the 1972 Newport Jazz Festival. On that occasion she gave a remarkable demonstration of the range, purity, control and rich colors of her voice in a magnificent and highly original vocalized version of Mood Indigo.

title: Chemical in River Called Exaggerated
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., March 1 (AP)The threat posed by carbon tetrachloride in the Kanawha and Ohio Rivers has been vastly exaggerated by the Environmental Protection Agency, an FMC Corporation officer contends.

title: Court Bars Papers From Owning Radio Or TV in Same City
description: WASHINGTON, March 1A threejudge panel of the United States Court of Appeals here voided today a rule by the Federal Communications Commission that allows newspapers to own broadcasting stations in the same city where they publish.

title: Gas Companies Admit Overcharges And Will Give Customers Rebates
description: CAMDEN, March 1A State Senate hearing on the recent natural gas crisis elicited testimony today that New Jersey utilities overcharged their gas customers last year and will make rebates.

title: Ribicoff's Choices
description: Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff announced that he had recommended T. F. Gilroy Daly, Connecticut's Insurance Commissioner, to be United States District Court judge for Connecticut. The Connecticut Democrat said he also had recommended Richard Blumenthal, his former administrative assistant, to be United States Attorney for Connecticut and Anthony G. Dirienzo Jr., to be United States marshal. Mr. Dirienzo has been chief deputy marshal since May 1967.

title: Chess:
description: For the first time in 20 years, a United States player, Mark Diesen, 19 years old, of Potomac, Md., has won the world junior championship. In the tournament held in Groningen, the Netherlands, Diesen posted seven victories and six draws for a total of 103.

title: Gordie Howe Gets No. 900
description: HOUSTON, March 1 (AP)Gordie Howe scored the 900th goal of his 29year professional hockey career tonight as the Houston Aeros beat the Phoenix Roadrunners, 83, in a World Hockey Association contest.

title: U.S. HIGH COURT BACKS USE OF RACIAL QUOTAS FOR VOTING MIMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The Supreme Court rued 7 to 1 today that a stare drawing up a reapportionment plan may sometimes use racial quotas that are designed to assure that blacks and other nonwhites have majorities in certain leRislative districts.

title: Carter and Mondale See Bukovsky, a Soviet Dissident
description: WASHINGTON, March 1President Carter met with the outspoken Soviet dissident Vladimir K. Bukovsky at the White House today and told him that his Administration's commitment to human rights was permanent and that I don't intend to be timid in my public statements and positions.

title: $10 Million Is Asked to Maintain Quality
description: Governor Carey's commission on postsecondary education has asked the state to give an additional $10 million next year to the senior colleges of the City University of New York to avoid further budget cuts that, the panel feels, could do permanent damage to the quality and integrity of these colleges.

title: Net Advances 15.6% As Macy's Reports 2d Successive Gain
description: R. H. Macy & Co. Inc.. the New York area's largest retailer, reported yesterday a strong profit improvement in its second fiscal quarter ended Jan. 29. It was the second consecutive quarterly improvement for the Manhattan  based department store chain.

title: Tennis
description: AT MEMPHIS

title: Nureyev and Friends
description: FOR THE THIRD year, the dancer Rudolf Nureycv has given a solo season with his friends at the Uris Theater. The pattern remains constant, only the program varies. And the present program is possibly the most interesting of the three. While it does not show Mr. Nureyev as a pure classicist, it does offer most aspects of his dramatic persona.

title: Open Interest
description: Wednesday, March 2, 1977

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 2, 1977

title: CARTER PROPOSES STUDY OF PUERTO RICO PROBLEMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)  President Carter proposed today creation of an informal, toplevel study group to assist Puerto Rico in solving its economic problems.

title: HOUSE CODE OF ETHICS APPROVED WITH CURB ON MEMBERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  The House of Representatives overwhelmingly adopted tonight a stringent code of ethics, including a limitation on outside earned income, in an effort to restore public confidence in Congress.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM IMPORTS SET A RECORD LAST WEEK
description: The nation imported a record amount of petroleum again last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: ASSEMBLY APPROVES NEW COUNCIL LINES
description: ALBANY, March 2  Arnid denunciations of the leadership of the New York City Council, the State Assembly voted reluctantly today to make it possible for Council members to run in next November's election from the slightly modified district lines they adopted last weekend.

title: Edward C. Mattes Jr., at 72; Former Guaranty Trust Officer
description: Mr. Mattes, who attended the United iStates Military Academy at West Point, was with the Guaranty Trust Company and the CentralHanover Bank and Trust Company before retiring to look after his private investments.

title: U.S. Urban Bank Called Possibility For LongRange Assistance to City
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal said today that a Federal urban bank was one possibility for effective longrange aid to New York City and other economically strapped lame cities.

title: Jazz: Unorthodox Quintet at Ali's
description: hluhall Richard Abrams, the versatile pianist from Chicago who is revered as a musical guru by ninny younger jazz men, is leading a quintet of gifted iconoclasts at Ali's Alley, 77 Greene Street, through tonight.

title: Rhodesia's Insurgency Has Spread Like Brush Fire, but Rebel Control Fails to Follow
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 2  The tall blond trooper with the flashes of the Rhodesian Light Infantry on his uniform sat in a mountain hotel along the Mozambique border nursing a beer and reflecting on the Government's successes in the struggle against black insurgents.

title: Top U.S. Arbitrators In Labor Strife Turn To Marriage Wars
description: After 50 years of grappling with disputes in labor, commerce, insurance and consumerism, the American Arbitration Association is stepping into the ring with husbands and wives.

title: CAREY VETOES BILL FOR A JUNE PRIMARY, SAYING IT'S TOO SOON
description: Governor Carey vetoed the June primary election bill yesterday, delaying the political calendar and thoroughly scrambling the mayoral race in New York City.

title: Theater: Why?
description: Once in a while, less now than in former times, you simply have to wonder why. Why should such futility as Unexpected Guests, which turned up at the Little Theater last night, have turned up? Even expected. It makes no sense at all.

title: Events Today
description: Film

title: The Program
description: NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Leonard Bernstein, con. tuztor; Lazar Berman, pianist. At Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Rightist Revolt Imperils Rhodesia Liberalization Plan
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 2 revolt by rightwingers against Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's bill to reduce racial discrimination appeared today to have jeopardized the measure in Parliament and undermined Mr. Smith's plan to seek coristitutional settlement with this country's 6.3 million blacks.

title: President Carter's First CoverUp
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  If any Carter appointee should be nonpolitical and nobody's business associate, that man should be the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Criminal Division,

title: Social Club Set on Fire
description: An unoccupied upper Manhattan social club was set on fire last night with a can of alcohol, according to the Fire Department. The club, which according to fire officials consisted of a bar and several tables, is located on the ground floor of a fivestory apartment house at 518 West 166th Street. The fire did not spread to the floors above, and there were no in juries.

title: BUKOVSKY SEES GAIN IN CARTER MEETING
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  Vladimir K. Bukovsky, the deported Russian rights activist, said today that his meeting with President Carter might cause worse treatment for dissidents in the Soviet Union for a time, but that continuing American commitment on the issue could only bring improvement S in the long run.

title: Books of The Times
description: After a first reading of John Cheever's extraordinary new novel, Falconer, I could report that I had devoured it hungrily, marveled at the grace of its prose, been given nightmares by its early passages, and come away from it with a sense of a world set right. Yet for the life of me, I could not recall it in detail. Beyond its

title: Inventors With Some Varied Ideas Gather for Their Expo
description: John Vaslas of Staten Island was worried about his wife's back because she was shoveling so much snow, and Margaret Guffin of Montauk, L.I., was bothered by her own back, not to mention her feet.

title: Pollution Still Major State Problem Despite Progress, Bardin Reports
description: TRENTON, March 2  The State Department of Environmental Protection said today that air and water pollution continued to be a major problem in New Jersey, despite some progress.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday it had purchased an additional 448.9 acres of land in Danbury. Conn., adjacent to property it bought a year ago for a new corporate headquarters. The tract was purchased for $9.49 million.

title: Dislocated Right Knee Fails To Halt a Dog Show Handler
description: The mediumsized, sandyhaired fellow hobbling around the show ring Sunday with a cast on his right leg will be Mike Wolf. Even a dislocated knee doesn't keep the ownerhandler from showing Ch. Ouilkin the Stringman at the Pekingese Club of America specialty in the Sheraton Motor Inn. Wolf, one of the nation's leading Pekingese fanciers, had speciallymade, removable cast prepared so he could return with the 10pound, 3yearold toy champion. The injury resulted when Wolf fell ever a small gate at home.

title: FEAR OF PBB IN FOOD SPREADS IN MICHIGAN
description: DETROIT, March 2  Shoppers at the Great Scott! supermarket on Livernois on this city's west side cannot miss the huge signs when they pass through the store's meat section:

title: BRAZIL, U.S. AT AN IMPASSE ON GERMAN NUCLEAR DEAL
description: RIO DE JANEIRO. March 2 (Reuters)Brazil and the United States appear to have made no progress in highlevel talks on the problem of Brazil's controversial nuclear agreement with West Germany.

title: Trade Between Germanys Up
description: BONN, March 2, (UFI)  Trade between East and West Germany increased by 13.3 percent in 1976 over the previous year; the Ministry of Economics said today.

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTON  The highly charged and often unfocused argument over whether the United States can finance future prosperity without major policy changes seems suddenly to have vanished.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 3, 1977

title: FREED TOURIST TELLS OF JAILING IN UGANDA
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 2  An American tourist from New York who spent two days in jail in the Uganda capital said here tonight that he had been very frightened and at times thought it was the end.

title: BBC Comedy Series
description: Commercial broadcasters who have seen Fawlty Towers, a British situation comedy, concede that it is funny and that its slapstick style would probably appeal to American audiences, but none have bought it for their television stations. Instead, the series will play in this country on at least six public television stations, including WNET/13 in New York.

title: Jazz: Quartet With Keen Pianist
description: Harold Mabern. the pianist in the quartet that Milt Jackson. the jazz braharpist, is leading at Hopper's. Avenue of the Americas at llth Street, this week and next, plays at a totally opposite extreme from John Lewis, the pianist in the Modern Jazz Quartet, the group with which Mr. Jackson had been associated for 22 years.

title: Small Fields Continue To Be a Big A Headache
description: The days are growing longer, but the fields are growing shorter at Aqueduct, a sure sign that winter is still here.

title: India's Congress Party, With Voting Two Weeks Off, Is Widely Believed to Be in Serious Political Trouble
description: NEW DELHI, March 2  With the Indian parliamentary election just two weeks away, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party is widely believed to be in serious political trouble.

title: Feldman Rebuffed In a Move to Keep His Trial in Bergen
description: HACKENSACK, March 2  A move by Matthew Feldman to have action on suit seeking his removal as President of the State Senate remain in Bergen County, the site of his home and his Senate district, was rejected today in Superior Court.

title: Braves Try to Woo Reed
description: The Buffalo Braves are continuing to pursue Willis Reed as their coach, but Reed has resisted in hopes that he will be the next Knick coach when Red Holzman steps down.

title: Lag in Spending Likely to Shrink Federal Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today that the Federal Government was continuing to spend less than its budget calls for, a phenomenon that will probably reduce the projected size of the fiscal deficit this year. He said the reasons for the underspending were not fully understood.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: OFF OFF GARDE The Open Space in SoHo, 64 Wooster Street (9663729) is an avantgarde company that performs original works by new writersusually. Its secondfloor quarters these days are jammed with actors preparing for Playwright's Group Festival 3, a series of six plays, all but one premieres, that starts tonight at 8 and runs through March 26. Each play gets several performances and usually goes on at 8 P.M., with shows also at 10 on Fridays and Saturdays and at 3:30 on Sundays.

title: Nazareth and Power Memorial Reach Catholic Schools Final
description: Kevin Dunleavy watches his opponents stomachs while playing defense for Nazareth High School. Last night at Fordham University, he watched so well that his team defeated Carclinal Hayes, 5141, and gained the final of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: Nursing Home Accepts Woman After Protests
description: GUTTENBERG, March 2  Hanna Gunning, an 8Gyearold widow, returned today to the nursing home where she had lived for three years but that had refused to accept her following a brief hospital stay because her Medicaid bed had been filled in the interim.

title: Rowdies to Face Soviet Team
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 2 (AP)  The Tampa Bay Rowdies will be the host team Saturday to the Soviet Union's ZenitLeningrad soccer club in the first catch of an outdoorindoor international doubleheader. Zenit is fifth in the 18team Soviet first division. The club is led by Alexander Markin, the Soviet 1976 player of the year and leading scorer so far this season with 13 field goals in 13 games. The Rowdies, North American Soccer League champions in 1975, are expected to be at full strength.

title: Kuhn, Finley Meet
description: DALLAS, March 2 (AP)  Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn met with the Oakland A's owner, Charles Finley, for almost three hours today to determine whether the sale of Paul Lindblad, Oakland relief pitcher, to the Texas Rangers was part of Finley's plan to liquidate his assets.

title: Nader Group Urges A Curb on Drug Ads At Safety Hearing
description: WASHINGTON. March 2  All advertising for some of the most widely sold nonprescription drugs should be stopped Untilquestions about their safety and effectiveness are resolved, the Federal Trade Commission was told today.

title: 600 Who Visited Nigeria Warned of Malaria Peril
description: ATLANTA, March 2 (AP)  The national Center for Disease Control issued a warning today that at least 600 Americans who attended an arts festival in Lagos, Nigeria, may have been exposed to a particularly severe form of malaria.

title: Bridge
description: A player in a team match who reaches an optimistic slam and brings it home by good play is entitled to expect that he has gained heavily. It is distinctly deflating to find that there has been no swing.

title: POLICEMAN KILLS MAN LUNGING AT HIM WITH AX
description: A police officer fatally shot a 29yearold former mental patient last night after he lunged at him and another officer with an ax, a police spokesman reported.

title: Moscow, Criticized On Dissidents, Cites U.S. Shortcomings
description: MOSCOW, March 2  In response to the Carter Administration's complaints about Soviet violations of human rights, the official press has been counterattacking the United States as a land of political arrests and naper freedoms.

title: Takeover of a Garbage Collector Charged to 2 Reputed Mafia Men
description: Two reputed Mafia associates were arrested yesterday and charged with using extortion and violence to extend their control of private garbage collecting in the Bronx

title: F.B.I. Studying Report Of Oswald Letter to Hunt
description: DALLAS, March 2 (AP)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating letter reportedly written by Lee Harvey Oswald to the late Dallas billionaire H. L. Hunt asking about Oswald's position on Nov. 8, 1963, two weeks before President Kennedy was assassinated.

title: New York Planning Agency Clears Housing Project
description: The City Planning Commission unanimously approved a permit yesterday for a $39 million federally financed housing project on a site first chosen in 1971a platform over railroad tracks in the South Bronx.

title: Companies Go Underground To Increase Profits and Save Energy
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan.  The offices of the Consolidated Meat Distribution Center here seemed no different from hundreds of similar ones on the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan, with bright colors and modern furnishings.

title: Moscow, Criticized On Dissidents, Cites U.S. Shortcomings
description: MOSCOW, March 2  In response to the Carter Administration's complaints about Soviet violations of human rights, the official press has been counterattacking the lin:ted States as a land of political arrests and paper freedoms.

title: Notes on People
description: After Joseph Maxwell Cleland, Vietnam War amputee, and Sam Brown, a resister in the same war, were sworn, in to Administration positions yasterday, President Carter observed, I don't think we could have two more stark contrasts in two young men, each deeply patriotic, each committed to preserving our nation's character in his own special way. Mr. Cleland was sworn in as Veterans Administrator andMr. Brown became director of the Federal volunteer agency ACTION. They are 34 and 33 years old, respectively. Sworn in at the same ceremony in the White House Oval Office was Evan Dobelle, 31, former mayor of Pittsfield, Mass., who is now chief of protocol in the State Department.

title: Industry Group Joins Oil Appeal
description: WASHINGTON. March 2 (UPI)  An industry group said today that it would join in the Government's appeal of a court decision voiding the $1.1 billion sale of offshore oil and gas drilling rights off Long Island and New Jersey. A spokesman said the National Ocean Industries Association, representing more than 300 companies involved in offshore oil and gas activities, planned to file as an intervenor in the case in the United States Second Court of Appeals in New York in the next few days.

title: Atomic Waste might Be Safe In Seabed, Researchers Find
description: A group of marine scientists have determined that the ocean floor may be a safe place to dispose of the evergrowing quantities of toxic and longlived radioactive nuclear wastes.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 3, 1977

title: 3 Businessmen Arrested on Heroin Charges
description: Three businessmen were arrested yesterday on an indictment charging them with conspiracy to possess and sell 40 to 60 kilograms of heroin and attempting to purchase 20 kilograms of heroin in what District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau called one of the biggest narcotics cases in recent years. A kilogram is 2.2 mounds.

title: GROSSET TO ISSUE BOOK BY NIXON IN HARDCOVER
description: After a search of more than a year, hardcover publisher for North America has been found for the not yet finished memoirs of Richard M. Nixon. Grosset & Dunlap, best known for its picture books, adult and juvenile original books and reprints, has made an agreement with Warner Books, which owns worldwide print rights and will issue the paperback, to bring out the memoirs in the early spring of 1978.

title: WHITE HOUSE ASKS 450,000 FOR IDEAS ON ENERGY POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  In an unusual effort to wed policy to public opinion; the White House asked the public today to offer suggestions on the new national energy policy that President Carter will submit to Congress by April 20.

title: Cold Stems a Surge In Building Awards
description: The upward surge of construction contracts was temporarily halted in January by severe winter weather, the F. W.. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Inforl mation Systems Company reported. Construction awards at $6.47 billion rose by a scant 3 percentover the level of January 1976, although residential building was ahead by 35 percent.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk reports that apprehension remains over a potential clash between the Carter Administration and the Federal Reserve System, with a possible credit crunch. Page 49.

title: All's Right in Colorado With Snow on Rockies
description: DENVER, March 1  Colorado's Rockies have just disappeared (under whole lot of snow). An advertising campaign with that message, backed by Gov. Richard D. Lamm, was sanctioned today by the state with a $27.000 an propriation. The reason? Almost all the state's ski areas were buzzing again. Suddenly the heavens are cooperating, said Tim Lynch, communications di rector of Colorado Ski Country, U.S.A. As many as 23 inches of snow dropped on most of our resorts last week. Snow kept falling all day today and into the night.

title: Miss Rodnina, Zaitsev Win Fifth Straight Skating Title
description: TOKYO, March 2 (AP)  Irina Rodnina and Aleksandr Zaitsev of the Soviet Union presented a nearly perfect freeskating program today and won their fifth straight pairs title in the world figureskating championships.

title: Now Pitching: Randy Jones
description: YUMA. Ariz., March 1  For a pitcher his arm is his career. And for two months, Randy Jones's left arm was dead.

title: Carter, Looking to a Lid On Federal Employees, Orders Limit on Hiring
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (A4)  President Carter ordered all Federal departments and agencies today to fill no more than 75 percent of their civilian job vacancies pending the establishment of new employment ceilings.

title: Navy, Faced by Court Suit, Seeks To Expand Sea Duty for Women
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)  Faced by a court suit, the Navy is moving to give women wider opportunities for sea duty.

title: The Long And The Short
description: WASHINGTON  In politics as in so many other aspects of contemporary life, we demand instant gratification. People are already heard to express impatience with Jimmy Carter, to wonder where his new programs are. And it is just six weeks since the inauguration.

title: S. E.C. Is Focusing On Boeing's Moves In Four Countries
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)  The Securities and Exchange Commission investigating the Boeing Company for alleged payoffs to high government officials in Canada, Japan, Portugal and Egypt, according to court records made public today.

title: Gonzalez, Assailing His Committee, Quits as Assassination Inquiry Head
description: WASHINGTON March 2  Representative Henry B. Gonzalez submitted his resignation as chairman of the House Committee on Assassinations today after accusing other committee members of trying to usurp his powers and charging the Democratic leadership with failure to support him in his dispute with Richard A. Sprague, the committee's chief counsel.

title: Growing Bahamian Loan Activity By U.S. Banks Causes Concern
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas  For years this string of sunblessed islands off the coast of Florida has enjoyed a lucrative, if slightly dubious, reputation as a tax havena pleasant locale where individual and corporate wealth finds refuge from income taxes, gains taxes, inheritance taxes, or any direct taxes at all.

title: Top French and Italian Reds Meet In Spain With Madrid Party Chief
description: MADRID, March 2  The leaders of the French and Italian Communist parties met here this afternoon with Santiago Carrillo, secretary general of the Spanish party, in a conference intended to advance the legalization of the Spanish Communists.

title: Claim Paid in Tanker Sinking
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 (UPI) The Fireman's Fund Insurance Companies said today that it had paid a $12 million claim on the cargo of the tanker Hawaiian Patriot, which sank last week in the Pacific Ocean 340 miles from Hawaii. The payment covered the loss of 714,000 barrels of Indonesian crude oil and was made to Pacific Resources Inc., owner a the oil. An explosion and fire destroyed the ship after it developed a leak.

title: Three Inquiries Are Set on Metropolitan Museum's Annenberg Center
description: Amid mounting controversy over the proposed establishment of the Annenberg Fine Arts Center at the Metropolitan Museum, three separate inquiries were announced yesterday. They will be conducted by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, by the Manhattan Borough Board and by Martin E. Segal, chairman of the city's Advisory Commission on Cultural Affairs.

title: Tennis
description: Associated Press

title: U.S. Reviews Missile Sale to Saudis
description: WASHINGTON. March 2  State Department officials said today that the Carter Administration was undertaking a detailed review of the previously approved sale of $1.14 billion in new antiaircraft missiles to Saudi Arabia to decide if the export would be permitted.

title: CocaCola's Profits Set Records in 76; Dividend Increased
description: The CocaCola Company, the world's largest soft drink producer, reported yesterday a 23.9 percent gain in fourthquarter earnings and a 19.1 percent increase for all of 1976. Sales exceeded the $3 billion mark for the first time last year.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Eastern Tennis Group Gains a Windfall of $33,000
description: Stranger things may have happened but the Eastern Tennis Association finds itself now in the uncommon position of looking for ways to spend money. It has been given $33,000 as its share of the surplus revenue earned by the parent United States Tennis Association in 1976. The E.T.A. ranks third in size among the 17 sections making up the U.S.T.A.

title: U.S. and Canada Agree On Prisoner Transfers
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (Reuters)Americans in Canadian prisons and Canadian prisoners in the United States will be able to transfer to institutions in their own countries under a treaty signed here today.

title: U.S. Report Urges Preparations For Possible Recurrence of Riots
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)  A Government advisory group today urged the police to prepare for a possible recurrence of urban riots and increasing terrorism. But officials said the immediate outlook for continued tranquility was good.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY RULE UPSET OVER SEX BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  The Supreme Court struck down today a requirement that made it more difficult for widowers than it was for widows to collect Social Security survivors benefits. That provision of the Social Security Act is unconstitutional sex discrimination the Court said.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 53311 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES AM. TO 4.30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY, NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 33900: WESTCHESTER CO. AND (JORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 9.5300; NASSAU CO. (1116) 7470500; SUFFOLK CO. (516) 1800; CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767.

title: UMass Ends Rutgers Hopes In 7874 Upset
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 2  This the place where it all fell apart for Rutgers last year. The Spectrum proved to be the chamber of horrors, the gym where the flame went out on Rutgers's hopes for an unbeaten national championship team, crushing team pride like a stale cigarette butt.

title: Banks Propose Stiffer Controls; City Is Resisting
description: The major New York City banks have informally submitted stringent new proposals for an independent agency to control city budgets, but City Hall aides said the proposals were stiffer than what had been offered so far and were very likely unacceptable to Mayor Beame.

title: Nicaragua Groups Looking to Carter For Help on Rights
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 1Church groups and opposition politicians are looking to the Carter Administration! to help end a wave of fierce repression; by a Nicaraguan dictatorship that has traditionally enjoyed the political, economic and military support of the United States.

title: It's a Chill Wind That Makes the Hand Lotion Business Brisk
description: The wind chill factor is doing some people a lot of good. The manufacturers of potions that help keep hands smooth are rubbing their own soft hands with pleasure as they contemplate what one of them calls an explosion in the hand care market.

title: Growing Bahamian Loan Activity By U.S. Banks Causes Concern
description: NASSAU, the BahamasFor years this string of sunblessed islands off the coast of Florida has enjoyed a lucrative, if slightly dubious, reputation, as a tax havena pleasant locale where individual and corporate wealth finds refuge from income taxes, gains taxes, inheritance taxes, or any direct taxes at all.

title: Guilty Plea in Brinks Robbery
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 (AP) Richard Charles Rees, a former Brinks guard charged with taking more than $400,000 in stolen bank money on an 11; month spending spree, changed his plea to guilty in Federal district court today.

title: ExLoan Officer Indicted in Chemical Bank Fraud
description: A former loan officer of a Brooklyn branch of the Chemical Bank was indicted with two other men yesterday on charges of having bilked $1.3 million from the bank in the early part of 1974 through a bogus loan scheme.

title: WILMINGTON 10 GAIN IN HOPE FOR FREEDOM
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C.  A hearing on new trial for the socalled Wilmington 10, civil rights activists serving prison terms for the burning of a grocery store in. Wilmington, N.C., during the height of racial tensions in 1971, is expected to begin in early May amid prospects that the granting of a new trial could mean permanent freedom for the defendants.

title: Spectrum Again Haunts Rutgers As UMass Posts a 7874 Upset
description: playoff was played today, divided into an afternoon and an evening session. In the afternoon, fornlheld up as West Virginia, the class of the Western Division, improved its record to 189 by beating Pitt, 6654, and Duquesne eliminated Penn State, 6555.

title: Indictment Says Lefkowitz Aide Accepted Bribe
description: A top aide to Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz was arraigned in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday on charges cf accepting a bribea trip to Las Vegasin exchange for letting himself be influenced in a State Department of Mental Hygiene investigation of school for the mentally retarded.

title: Dean of Orthodox Rabbis
description: A 66yearold rabbi who gave up the law for the synagogue and eventually became the dean of the modern Orthodox rabbinate in the United States has been chosen for still another honor. He is Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, who yesterday was elected president of BarBan University in Israel at a meeting of the school's board of trustees on its campus at Ramat Gan. He is the first American to hold the post.

title: BLACKS WIN A MAJORITY ON COUNCIL IN RICHMOND
description: RICHMOND. March 2 (AP)  The first municipal election here in seven years has given blacks their first majority on the ninemember city council.

title: Lebanese Villagers Cross Into Israel to Seek Help
description: TEL AVIV, March 2Elders of Dibel, a Lebanese Christian village, crossed the frontier today to plead for Israeli help and said that their village of 4,500 would be doomed without it.

title: VENEZUELAN GOVERNMENT DENIES IT GOT C.I.A. MONEY
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 2 Venezuela last night denied that the Government here had received money from the Central Intelligence Agency early in the 1960's for joint intelligence activities.

title: Czechoslovakia Arrests 2 French Journalists
description: PRAGUE, March 2 (Reuters)Czechoslovak authorities have arrested two French journalists and intend to deport them, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: City College Five Added To E.C.A.C. Tournament
description: City College, which won the City University of New York basketball tournament for the second straight year has been added to the field for the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metropolitan Regionals for Divisions II and III. Play starts tomorrow night at Kean College in Union. N.J.

title: Swiss Order Lugano Bank Shut Because of Bankrupt Subsidiary
description: BERN, March 2 (UPI)  The Swiss Federal Banking, Commission has ordered the closing of a small bank in Lugano because a financial subsidiary is bankrupt.

title: U. N. Rights Group Rules Out Inquiry Into Uganda Case
description: LONDON, March 2  Foreign Secretary David Owen said today that the United Nations Human Rights Commission had turned down a British proposal for an investigation of developments in Uganda hut that Britain would continue to press for an inquiry.

title: Recruiting Puzzle at City U.
description: Disclosure that the City University of New York has decided to combat lagging registration through more systematic promotional and recruiting efforts points up how complex and interlocking the problems are that New York State faces in higher education. It also raises News the obvious question: Why Analysis should the City University be going out of its way to attract students at a time when the city and state are, locked in a, battle of nerves to find a way of financing the university's senior colleges?

title: BONN SNUBS U.S. BID TO PROD ITS ECONOMY
description: PARIS, March 2  West Germany has firmly rejected a renewed effort by the Carter Administration to persuade it to stimulate the German, economy with expansionary, shortterm measures.

title: WBAI Denied Tax Exemption On Its Building on East Side
description: Nonprofit radio station WBAIFM, after nearly three weeks off the air following seizure by a disgruntled staff, was denied taxexempt status by the City Tax Commission yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Bell Asks Court to Allow PurseSeining for Tuna
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)  The Justice Department asked the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia today for an immediate order allowing the American tuna fleet to resume using the purseseine method of tuna fishing near porpoises, even though it endangers the porpoises.

title: Companies Go Underground To Increase Profits and Save Energy
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan.  The offices of the Consolidated Meat Distribution Center here seemed no different from hundreds of similar ones on the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan, with bright colors and modern furnishings.

title: Iran's Oil Exports in February Rose 30.4% After January Drop
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 2 (Reuters)Iran's oil exports rose 30.4 percent in February to an average of 5.7 million barrels a day from the January slump that followed a 10 percent rise in oil prices, the stateowned National Iranian Oil Company said.

title: Market Place
description: When the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, a wholesale drug distributor, took on a $405 million contract last year to administer North Carolina's Medicaid Program through computerized processing methods, some investors assumed that the company would soon teach the bureaucrats a lesson in efficiency.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Mike Marshall Sues Michigan State Paper
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., March (AP)  The Atlanta Braves relief pitcher, Mike Marshall, is suing the Michigan State University student newspaper for $2.5 million.

title: C. A. B. Orders Airlines To Post Notices Warning About Bumping Passengers
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)  Airline must post warnings next month that passengers may be bumped trom confirmed reservations because airlines deliberately sell more tickets than there are seats available.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: In Bahamas, Banking Is Second Only to Tourism
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas  Towering over the Nassau airport customs area, side by side with the ads for Coppertone and beachfront hotels, are the banners of the banks: the Bank of Montreal, the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce and Citibank  the right bank in the right place.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 3, 1977

title: Frazier Seeks a Hitter Who Can Also Field
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2  As the Los Angeles Dodgers opened baseball's 26th and last training camp today, there were 120 players in the big leagues making $100,000 a year, and 10 of them belonged to the New York Mets. The only problem was that none of them could do what the Mets needed most: play center field and hit with power.

title: Nassau Republican Party Chooses Purcell; Caso Promises Fight in Primary Election
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 2  Nassau County Republicans tonight designated the Hempstead Town Presiding Supervisor Francis T. Purcell, for County Executive. But the incumbent, Ralph G. Caso, immediately said he would challenge Mr. Purcell in the primary election.

title: Serkin Plays All Beethoven With Ormandy
description: Going to hear Rudolf Serkin play the Emperor Concerto yet again is a curiously mixed experience, exciting and soothing at the same time. It is something like watching the world's greatest tightrope walker teeter across Niagara Falls: You know he is going to make it, because he is famous for doing it successfully, but that still is Niagara Falls down there beneath him.

title: Colorado Is Ahead In N.C.A.A. Skiing
description: WINTER PARK, Colo., March 2 Competing in an allday snowstorm, the University of Colorado gained 10point lead today as the National Collegiate Athletic Association ski championships opened a fourday run.

title: Puerto Rican Theater Finds a Home
description: The Puerto Rican Traveling Theater has found a permanent home in the Broadway area. The fivestory building at 304 West 47th Street, a former firehouse, will be converted into a modern plant for the group, now celebrating its 10th anniversary. The company, directed by Miriam Colon, performs in English and Spanish.

title: Westchester G.O.P. Hopes Dashed as Flynn Rules Out Contest Against DelBello
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 2Republican hopes to unseat Alfred B. DelBello, Westchester's first Democratic County Executive, were diminished today when State Senator John E. Flynn announced that he would not run against him in the November election.

title: Experts on Aztecs Deny Withholding Cannibalism Facts
description: A New York anthoropologist's theory that the Aztecs practiced human sacrifice and cannibalism because they needed to supplement a marginal diet has been sharply criticized by a number of authorities on Aztec life.

title: AntiImperialism Is Parade Theme Of Ethiopia Fete
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 2Ethiopia celebrated one of its proudest national holidays today, the anniversary of the 1896 Battle of Aduwa, when a poorly equipped army routed Italian invaders, making the country the only one in Africa to repulse colonialism on the battlefield.

title: Carey Panel May Urge Stripping Regents of Noneducation Powers
description: Governor Carey's commission on higher eduCation is considering a proposal that would strip the State Board of Regents of its power to license the professions and of other functions not chiefly concerned with education.

title: After a Summer When It Sizzled Paris Endures Month of Drizzle.
description: PARIS, March 2  The French are being drenched.

title: Notes on People
description: After Joseph Maxwell Cleland, a Vietnam War amputee, and Sam Brown, a resister in the same war, were sworn, in to Administration positions yasterday, President Carter observed, I don't think we could have two more stark contrasts in two young men, each deeply patriotic, each committed to preserving our nation's character in his own special way. Mr. Cleland was sworn in as Veterans Administrator andMr. Brown became director of the Federal volunteer agency ACTION. They are 34 and 33 years old, respectively. Sworn in at the same ceremony in the White House Oval Office was Evan Dobelle, 31, former mayor of Pittsfield, Mass., who is now chief of protocol in the State Department.

title: Business Records
description: Wednesday, March 2, 1977

title: Rites for Daniel P. O'Connell, 91, Draw Key New York Democrats
description: ALBANY, March 2  Daniel Peter O'Connell, for 55 years the boss of Albany's Democratic political machine, was buried today, and many of the state's most powerful Democrats came to pay their respects,

title: Film Institute Honors Bette Davis
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., March 2  Bette Davis, whose movie career began almost 50 years ago and spans more than 80 films, was honored by Hollywood last night when she became the first woman to receive the Life Achievement Award of the Ameritan Film Institute.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Associated Press

title: Croat Suspect in Skyjacking Pleads Guilty to an Attempted Kidnapping
description: One of the five Croat nationalists accused of hijacking a Chicagobound jet to Paris and planting a bomb in Manhattan that killed a New York policeman last September pleaded guilty yesterday to a lesser charge, attempted kidnapping.

title: PRICES RISE IN RALLY OF BONDS AND NOTES
description: The credit markets rallied yesterday, with yields declining to the lowest level since January as the Treasury conducted its monthly sale of oneyear bills and with notes and bonds rising as much as half a point. Sales of the Indiana Bell Telephone Company debentures yielding 8.18 percent that were originally offered to investors on Feb. 23 picked up speed late in the day, enabling the underwrit ers to estimate the $130 million issue to be twothirds sold.

title: CAREY VETOES BILL FOR A JUNE PRIMARY, SAYING IT'S TOO SOON
description: Governor Carey vetoed the June primary election bill yesterday, delaying the political calendar and thoroughly scrambling the mayoral race in New York City.

title: Carey Explains Veto's Reasons
description: It is plain that this measure, which was passed by the Legislature only few days ago, provides very little time for prospective candidates to take the necessary steps to qualify to run in this year's primary elections.

title: Tolls Are Acceptable
description: The new surge of opposition to imposing tons on free city bridges is discouraging because it so badly misses the point. The critics, including several Congressmen from Brooklyn, have now so confused the problem with the solution that their opposition looks more like selfish borough politics than concern for New York.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Confronted by budgetary overexpenditures and continuing problems with probationary accreditation at the Bergen Pines County Hospital, G. Roger Martin resigned as the public hospital's executive director in a telephone call to its board of managers. Mr. Martin, 39 years old, who assumed the $55,000 post last July, had been under pressure from the county's Board of Chosen Freeholders recently over $100,000 in excess spending at the hospital in 1976.

title: L. I. Prosecutor Promises To Prove Busacca Guilty Without Body Being Found
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 2  The trial of Thomas F. Busacca, accused of the murder of his wife, opened today with the defense attorney saying there was no evidence that the 51yearold singer was dead. She could have gone off to Rome and be singing at La Scala now, said the attorney, Marvin Zevin.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Concert: Bernstein and Berman
description: The Pension Fund Benefit Concerts of the New York Philharmonic generally offer something special, which they should at a $40 top. Last night in Avery Fisher Hall it was the combination of Lazar Berman and Leonard Bernstein. The popular Russian pianist played two Russian concertos the Prokofiev No. 1 in D flat and the Rachmaninoff No. 3 in ID minor. To round out the evening of Russian music, Mr. Bernstein led off with Tchaikovsky's Romeo and Juliet.

title: LeDoux Outpoints Soto at Garden
description: Scott LeDoux of Minneapolis, who had to apologize to a national television audience the last time he fought, had no problem in Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Klutts Getting a Shot at Stanley's Job
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, March 2  The Yankees resolved the Mickey Rivers problem today and turned to their next potential trouble spotFred Stanley and shortstop.

title: Holy Trinity, St. Agnes Win
description: FARMINGDALE, L. L. March 2 Holy Trinity of Hicksville defeated Chaminade of Mineola, 8164, tonight in the semifinal round of the NassauSuffolk C.H.S.A.A. basketball tournament. In the other semifinal. St. Agnes of Rockville Centre beat St. Anthony's of Smithtown, 6347.

title: About New York
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 2  The urbanization of Nassau Countyindeed its New York Citificationadvanced well beyond such experiences as beach pollution and sidewalks when County Executive Ralph G. Caso saw bossism rear its vivacious head one desperate moment last fall.

title: 2 WOMEN ARE SLAIN NEAR POUND RIDGE
description: Two women were found fatally shot through the head late yesterday afternoon, the apparent victims of a robbery attempt at a large home in tewisboro, an affluent Westchester Community on the Connecticut border, the state police reported.

title: Joint New York Budget Session Is Found Short of Leaders
description: Paul O'Dwyer, the City Council President ruefully pronounced the unusual joint session held yesterday by the City Council and the Board of Estimate a failure. Councilman Henry J. Stern agreed with him, and his Council colleague, Carter Burden, characterized it as a waste of time.

title: Syracuse Gains Final, Ousting Bonnies, 8572
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 2  That old home brew of a screaming home crowd in Manley Field House and a tradition of postseason success was just what Syracuse needed tonight to defeat St. Bonaventure, 8572, in the first round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference playoffs.

title: Fact Is Reassigned To McCannErickson
description: While the agency world is awaiting with moderate anticipation for Brown 8c Williamson Tobacco to choose between McCannErickson and Roser Reeves Inc. to do advertising for its Viceroy cigarettes, the company has suddenly decided to reassign Fact, and that's a fact.

title: G.M. Is Set to Respond To Tax Charge by U.S.
description: DETROIT, March 2  Thomas A. Murphy, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said today that a Federal grand jury might be impaneled to consider charges of income tax violations against G.M.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Walt Street and the business community remain apprehensive over potential clash between a new Administration with a fiscal policy aimed at promoting more rapid expansion and a Federal Reserve System bent on holding the growth of the money supply in check to keep inflation down. Will this be the case of an irresistible force meeting an immovable object? And will the outcome be a credit crunch, with disastrous results for the stock and bond markets and the economy in general.

title: Down at Doubles, With Friends of Friends
description: The poor seek them of necessity.

title: Big Board and Amex Issue Reports Of Changes in Stock by insiders
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers Of their listed companies.

description: The major New York City banks have informally submitted stringent new proposals for an independent agency to control city budgets, but City Hall aides said the proposals were stiffer than what had been offered so far and were very likely unacceptable to Mayor Beame.

Lefkowitz was arraigned in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday on charges of accepting a bribea trip to Las Vegasin exchange for letting himself be influenced in a State Department of Mental Hygiene investigation of school for the metntally retarded.

title: Deaths
description: BAIRDColller W., of Saranac Lake,l N.Y. on March I. 1977. Husband of Patricia, father of Collier Jr., John, William, Or. Dorothy Lieb. Louise Baird, Mrs. William P. Person. 14 grandchildren, 10 greatgrandchildren, a brother, William. Funeral services Friday, 2 P.M., St, Luke's Church. Saranac Lake, N.Y. Cremation. Troy. N.Y.

description: WASHINGTON, March 2The Supreme Court struck down today a requirement that made it more difficult for widowers than it was for widows to collect Social Security survivors benefits. That provision of the Social Security Act is unconstitutional sex discrimination, the Court said.

title: PLAYBOY WILL SEEK GAMBLING LICENSE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 2  Playboy Clubs International disclosed today that it would invest in a multimilliondollar operation here and seek a casino license.

title: Playboy Seeks Rights For CasinoGambling
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 2  Playboy Clubs International disclosed today that It would invest in a multimilliondollar operation here and seek a casinogambling license.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 2  Property owners in 501 communities across the state that had not anticipated full financing of the schoolaid formula when preparing their budgets for the current year will get onetime property tax rebate checks totaling more than $200 million according to figures released today by Governor Byrne.

title: Leon Goldfarb Doubly Happy With Decision
description: Leon Goldfarb was afraid of sounding, in his words, mushy of ridiculous,

title: Asarco Lifts Price Of Copper 2 Cents To 70c a Pound
description: Twotiered pricing returned yesterday to the copper industry. Asarco started the latest iouna of rice inzr:nses early yesterday morning when it announced that it was increasing its spot selling price for electrolytic copper of domestic origin by 2 cents to 70 cents a pound. The Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company announced shortly afterward that it was matching that increase.

title: Democratic Candidate Is Upset in Queens in State Senate Election
description: Complacent Democrats and opponents of abortion seem to have been the major raison that a RepublicanConservative in Queens won in an upset victory in the previously overwhelmingly Democratic 10th Senate District.

title: Events/Sports
description: 7:20 P.M., WNEWAM: Hockey. Rangers vs. Boston Bruins.

title: Author Says Her Slap Shot
description: Nancy Dowd is a sweetfaced Smith College graduate from a proper Massachusetts family. She is 31 years old, has a trim figure and perfect teeth, and she would seem to be the kind of woman destined to preside over the local Junior League.

title: Dance: Local Premiere of a Meredith Monk Piece
description: In the 19th century, young Englishmen who went abroad, mainly to Italy, often felt compelled to write of their travels. Today, young Americans are doing the same, execpt that, like Meredith Monk, they may be presenting their impressions as exeprimental theater pieces.

title: ncerely Yours. Next. Si xt. Sincerely Yours. Ne
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.  Jimmy Carter may be determined never to lie to you. But the White House machinery, in continuity from Administration to Administration, is programmed for the faking of the Presidenthis letters, his messages, and even his personal signature.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Wednesday, March 2, 1977

title: COUNCIL POST SOUGHT BY SENATOR BELLAMY
description: State Senator Carol Bellamy of Brooklyn yesterday announced her candidacy for the Democratic nomination for City Council President.

title: Recall of Defrosters And Rock Polishers
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)  Nearly 50,000 toy electric rock polishers and 23,600 electric refrigerator defrosters are being recalled because they may be un. safe, the Consumer Product Safety Corn. mission announced today.

title: Philadelphia Paper Unions Ratify Tentative Accord
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 2 (UPI)  Memhers of the Newspaper Guild of Greater Philadelphia tonight ratified a tentative 31month contract agreement to end a 22day strike against The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Philadelphia Daily News.

title: Companies Issue Reports Covering Sales and Earnings Figures
Soybean Futures Prices Climb to Season's Highs For All Nine Contracts
description: Setting highs for the season in all nine contracts, soybean futures prices rose 171/2 cents a bushel yesterday, sending the price for the four oldcrop months above $S for the first time since November 1979.

title: Bobby Kaplan, 33, Leading Figure In Tennis as Coach, Entrepreneur
description: Bobby Kaplan, a leading tennis figure in the metropolitan area, died early yesterday morning at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, Li., as a result of injuries sustained in a road mishap last week. He was 33 years old and resided in Roslyn. L.I.

title: Kings Easily Vanquish Nets by 112100
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 2  The Nets ran into their own version of an energy crisis tonight at the Nassau Coliseum and the Kansas City Kings walked away with a 112100 victory as a consequence.

title: In Memoriam
description: GOSSJeftrey Kenneth, beloved son. mourn my loss. DAD

title: Christian Refugees From Uganda Detail Wave of Killing and Abuse
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 2  Slowly and timidly, refugees from Uganda who have slipped over the Kenyan border in the last few days told here today of wave of death, fear and intimidation that drove many of them to flee without their families.

title: ExVice President of Kenya Returning to Politics
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 2 (Reuters)Former Vice President Oginga Odinga said today that he was returning to active politics after a sixyear break, with the aim of preserving parliamentary democracy in Kenya.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: F. E. A. in Rollback Of Crude Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  The Federal Energy Administration announced today its second rollback in two months of some crude oil prices.

title: People and Business
description: Three top executives of GambleSkogmo Inc., who tried unsuccessfully late last year to unseat Berths C. Gamble as chairman and chief executive officer, have resigned from the Minneapolisbased retail chain, the company announced yesterday. They are Louis E. Dolan, vice chairman, member of the office of president, director and general counsel; Edwin 0, Wack, senior vice president and director, and James F. Tracy, senior vice president for buying.

title: Bernardin Finds Gain in Esteem for Catholics of U.S.
description: Despite recent troubles, the Roman Catholic Church in the United States basically sound and gaining esteem throughout the Catholic world, according to the head of the American hierarchy, Archbishop Joseph L. Bernardin.

title: Fed Expects Calmer Days Ahead For ForeignExchange Operations
description: The New York Federal Reserve Bank, reporting yesterday that the last three months had been among the most hectic on record for foreignexchange markets, tentatively forecast calmer conditions.

title: GoldMining Stocks Rise Sharply; Lackluster Dow Average Declines
description: Preciousmetal issues advanced sharply in the stock market yesterday reflecting the highest gold prices in 16 months in European bullion markets.

title: Gold at 16Month High
description: BRUSSELS, March 2 (UPI)  The price of gold jumped to its highest levels in 16 months today just before a gold auction by the International Monetary Fund. The dollar lost ground against most currencies.

title: Architects See Building Recovery
description: HACKENSACK, March 2  If the work on architects drawing boards is a reliable economic barometer, as many in the profession believe, then the hardpressed construction industry and related businesses in New Jersey may be on the threshhold of a new prosperity.

title: A Fair Fast Start on Energy
description: There is no more urgent matter before the Federal Government than the design and adoption of a longterm energy policy. That effort cannot succeed without a coherent and disciplined Government agency charged with the administration of that policy. President Carter is right to invest the prestige he brought to the White House in the creation of an Energy Department and the objectives it will pursue.

title: VOLUNTEER DEFENSE FORCE IS IN TROUBLE, STUDY FINDS
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)  A Congressional study of military recruiting concludes that the allvolunteer force is in trouble and will become increasingly difficult and costly to maintain.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: A Breeze Teases Wind Surfers on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, March 2  Wind surfing the fastpaced sport in which the enthusiast rides a surfboard and clings to a sail that can propel him over the waves at IS miles an hour has returned here with the March winds.

title: Mean Old Kindly Uncle Carter
description: In commenting this week on New York's fiscal problems, President Carter sounded like a cross between reluctant creditor and a rich, distant uncle. Which, come to think of it, is what he is. He said the Treasury would not advance $255 million under the current loan agreements with the city until local authorities had found the $1 billion the courts want paid to past lenders. Yet said lie would be glad to see what might be done stretch out the program of Federal tideover loans for five years beyond the current deadline of June 1978.

title: HOUSE CODE OF ETHICS APPROVED WITH CURB ON MEMBERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  The House of Representatives overwhelmingly adopted tonight a stringent code of ethics, including a limitation on outside earned income, in an effort to restore public confidence in Congress.

title: 35 Town Meetings in Vermont Vote To Prohibit Nuclear Energy Plants
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., March 2  Residents of Vermont participating in annual town meetings in 35 communities around the state yesterday adopted local resolutions banning the construction of atomic power plants and the transportation and storage of nuclear waste within their geographical borders.

title: 2 Killed, 7 Missing in Mine Flood; Rescue Workers Locate a Survivor
description: TOWER CITY, Pa., March 2 (AP) Voice contact was made tonight with one of eight miners trapped inside flooded coal mine for more than 32 hours, a Federal mining official said.

title: Italian Government Faces Threat From the Lockheed Bribe Case
description: ROME, March 2  The Lockheed scandal, which had at first failed to shake Italian politics, is now generating a major controversy that could determine the fate of the Government.

title: Judge Backs Indians'
description: BOSTON. March 2 (AP)  A Federal judge has allowed a suit by the Wampanoag Indians seeking Cape Cod territory to stand but says the plaintiffs will have to prove their status as a federally recognized tribe.

title: DR. NORMAN J. MEYERS
description: Dr. Norman J. Meyers, an orthopedic surgeon, died Tuesday at Mount Pleasant (N. J.) Hospital. He was 43 years old and a resident of Toms River, N. J.

title: Advertising When to See Your Agency Lawyer
description: Ad agencies lawyers should be consulted during the planning stages of a difficult compaign, not after it's completed, a major agency's counsel told a group of advertisers yesterday.

title: After Brief Flurry, Embassy Row Adapts to New Administration
description: WASHINGTON, March 3There are 129 embassies in this city, from Afghanistan to Zambia, housed in buildings that range from converted hotels to Georgianstyle mansions, a part of the official Washington landscape whose real function is only vaguely understood.

title: Citibank Found To Lead in Shift To Tax Havens
description: NASSAU, the BahamasIn the sudden growth of international banking in the Bahamas, no institution has played as prominent a role as Citibank, the United States's second largest bank and, in the scope of its global activities, the most truly international bank in the world.

title: Screen: Mr. Billion
description: THAT A COMEDY like Mr. Billion, which opened at Radio City Music Hall yesterday. should be that landmark's Easter attraction must give us all some idea of the gloomy state of the American movie business. Mr. Billion isn't really bad. It's harmless enough, but watching it is like looking at a plastic hag full of water containing some goldfish. It's transparent. It has no particular form. It's not funny, and you've seen the goldfish before.

title: Changes in TuitionAid Proposal Would Cover 5,000 More Students
description: TRENTON. March 3The state's Department of Higher Education has made significant changes in its proposed consolidation of student tuitionassistance programs under which 5,000 more students would become eligible for aid, the assistant chancellor, Dr. Haskell Rhett, said today.

title: O'Neal Reported Due For Top I.C.C. Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 3President Carter has decided to name Daniel O'Neal chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, it was learned today.

title: Sports
description: Friday

title: 3 Utilities in Accord WithW estinghouse Over Uranium Suit
description: PITTSBURGH, March 3The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and three electric utilities today reached an agreement in principle to settle a suit by the utilities against Westinghouse over the supply of uranium.

title: Judge Drops Cunningham Charge Of Trying to Coerce Bronx Paper
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday dismissed charges that Patrick J. Cunningham, the Bronx Democratic chairman; Councilman Stephen Kaufman of the Bronx, and Jerome Glanzrock, a former Bronx Democratic district leader, had tried to intimidate a weekly newspaper in the Bronx.

title: For Roger Sessions, a Tribute and a Premiere at 80
description: When Birgit Nilsson was asked what a soprano needed in order to sing Isolde, she replied comfortable shoes. In the same vein, Roger Sessions might say that what a modern composer needs mast is patience. Mr. Sessions's 80th birthday is being celebrated tonight at Alice Tully Hall, where the Julliard Orchestra performs the New York premiere of his 11yearold Symphony No. 6.

title: Price of Gold Increases Following Sale by I.M.F.; Changes for Dollar Small
description: LONDON, March 3 (AP)Gold rose 25 cents to close at $144.875 an ounce in London today, a day after the International Monetary Fund gold auction in Washington brought an average price of $146.51.
