title: Corporation Affairs
description: Twotiered copper pricing lasted just one day as all major producers raised their prices for refined copper to 71 cents a pound yesterday. Asarco Inc. and the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company, which led the latest round of price hikes on Wednesday with increases of 2 cents a pound to 70 cents, decided early yesterday afternoon to tack on another penny and meet their competitors at 71 cents a Pound.

title: Higher Prices and Lower Rates For Bonds Recorded for 2d Day
description: The credit markets, responding to news of smallerthanbudgeted Federal spending, a substantial decrease in factory orders and declines in the nation's money supply, moved toward higher prices and lower interest rates yesterday for a second day. Bond prices rose moderately as trading beCredit came somewhat more active. Markets On Wednesday, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal disclosed that the Federal Government was continuing to spend less than the budget called for and his remarks encouraged bond dealers since they signaled smallerthan expected Treasury borrowing over the months ahead.

title: Henri Filion Records 4 Victories in 5 Races
description: WESTBURY, March 3Henri Filion, the leading driver in the first week of action at Roosevelt Raceway, drove four winners in five races tonight and increased his record to eight victories in 13 drives for the week.

title: Market Place
description: A professor of law at New York University with a jaundiced view of Wall Street research suggests that mutual funds and other institutional investors pay separately for research  not through commission dollarsand that they be discouraged from buying fundamental and technical analysis in any event.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: RADNOR, Pa.Public concern over nearterm energy shortages seems to be relaxing as spring approaches in the East. but there has been no lessening, of attention to longterm energy problems in this town's headquarters for one or tne nation's largest The integrated oil companies. The guard is also being held Economic high in other energy cirScene Iles. In a recent interview at his company's modern, lowslung corporate offices near the banks of the Schuylkill River west of Philadelphia, H. Robert Sharbaugh, the chairman of the Sun Company, said he was devoting much time these days trying to alert various elements of society to the nature and implications of the complex energy situation.

title: Ringside Seat
description: Edgar Ansel Mowrer, Pulitzer Prize winner, foreign correspondent and columnist, author of a dozen books, and the reporter who for millions of Americans was the man on the scene with the Third Reich, entered journalism accidentally as a favor to his older brother.

title: BANKERS OPTIMISTIC ON FISCAL SOLUTION; UNIONS SCORE TERMS
description: On the eve of the resumption of talks aimed at averting the bankruptcy of New York City, bank officials said yesterday that they were optimistic that a solution could be worked out. But union officials reiterated their opposition to the stringent financial controls that the banks are demanding.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The obituary of Rose Herrick Jackson in The Times of Feb. 11 omitted the names of two of her five sons. Richard Seymour Jackson, who spent 35 years with The New Haven Register, died in 1974 and William Brinckerhoff Jackson, a gunner in a B29 in World War II, was killed in a mission over China in 1944.

title: Theater: New Shocks, Splendors
description: FOLLOWING HIS success with The Threepenny Opera at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center, Richard Foreman has returned to his tiny shadowbox loft theater for a new OntologicalHysteric Theater opus, Book of Splendors: Part Two (Book of Levers): Action at a Distance.

title: Austrians End Protest Of World Cup Ski Site
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 3What seemed to have the makings of an international skiing controversy was settled this morning at this plush Sawtooth Range resort. Austrian officials withdrew their protest and agreed to have their World CUD teams compete in downhill races at Heavenly Valley, Calif., March 11 and 12. The decision followed a series of discussions between Austrian and American officials. The problem was that the downhill course at Heavenly Valley, in its present shape, is 50 meters shorter in vertical drop than the minimum length required by the Federation Internationale de Ski. Heavenly Valley has a descent that meets F.I.S. standards, but skimpy snow conditions had made it necessary to lop off 50 meters at the area's base.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 3, 1977

title: At ABC, the Winds Of Change Are Blowing
description: The rumor winds that have buffeted Barbara Walters at ABC News for months have now shifted to her colleague, Harry Reasoner, and to the president of the ABC News division, William Sheehan.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The obituary of Rose Herrick Jackson in The Times of Feb. 11 omitted the names of two of her five sons. Richard Seymour Jackson, who spent 35 years with The New Haven Register. died in 1974 and William Brinckerhoff Jackson, a gunner in a B29 in World War II, was killed in a mission over China in 1944.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: UNDOUBTEDLY the most interesting broadcasting project of this weekend belongs to the generally neglected medium of radio. Tomorrow afternoon, between 2 and 4 on WCBSAM and FM, President Carter will sit down with Walter Cronkite to answer telephone calls from the American public. The experiment is part of Mr. Carter's professed desire to bring the Presidency closer to the people. The broadcast will be live, but the calls will be delayed a few minutes in transmission to prevent the possibility of obscene language littering the public airwaves. For all those TV addicts who may have lost the ability to visualize the unseen, the Public Broadcasting Service will videotape the proceedings, and the TV replay of Ask President Carter will be carried on Channel 13 on Sunday at 11:30 P.M.

title: People's Symphony, Direct From Russia
description: The Leningrad Symphony Orchestra, identified with Dmitri Shostakovich's Symphony No. 7, inspired by the heroic resistance of Leningrad to the Nazis in a 900day siege, will be playing its most famous orchestral work at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8 P.M.

title: BANKERS OPTIMISTIC ON FISCAL SOLUTION; UNIONS SCORE TERMS
description: On the eve of the resumption of talks aimed at averting the bankruptcy of New York City, bank officials said yesterday that they were optimistic that a solution could be worked out. But union officials reiterated their opposition to the stringent financial controls that the banks are demanding.

title: Carter's Oil Problem
description: WASHINGTON, March 2The Carter Administration is serious in a way that its predecessors were not about coping with an energy problem that real, growing, and a grave threat to modern civilization.

title: Notes on People
description: The Appellate Division of State supreme Court yesterday reversed lower court decision in a lawsuit involving Marlene Dietrich and the producer of a television special she starred in, in effect ordering the producer to pay her $100,000. The money was the amount that Miss Dietrich, in her suit, had contended was owed to her as the final installment of the $200,000 that the producer, Alexander H. Cohen, and his Brentwood Television Corporation, purportedly promised to pay for the right to place the special on CBSTV. In a counterclaim, Mr. Cohen mamtamea tnat Miss Dietrich, by denigrating the quality of the TV production, and his company in interviews, had hurt the program's potential for success. He maintained he had suffered $500,000 damages. The case dates to 1973.

title: Libya Reorganizes Government, Alters Its Title to
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 3 (UPI)The Libyan leader, Muammar elQaddafi, with Prime Minister Fidel Castro of Cuba at his side, presided last night over the renaming of the country and a governmental shuffle, according t) the Libyan Dress agencY.

title: Cold Holds Some Stores February Gains Below Prior Months
description: Consumer buying of clothes, home furnishings and related seasonal merchandise rose across the nation in February over the same month last year, reports from more than 10 leading national retail chains showed yesterday.

title: Mets Play It by the Book
description: ST. PETERSBURG. Fla.. March 3  The New York Mets made a final offer today to Dave Kingman and also executed two technical steps to keep him from becoming a free agent immediately: they renewed his 1976 contract under the rules and cut his pay the maximum of 20 percent.

title: His Piano, Her Voice and Their Pop Music Trip
description: This will be a particularly busy and diverse weekend for that industrious marital combine known as William Bolcom, who composes and plays the piano, and Joan Morris, who sings. Tonight at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven there will be a new production of Brecht's Mr. Puntilla and His Chauffeur Matti (to use the new translation's title), for which Mr. Bolcom has provided new incidental musicwith a country flavor, of all things.

title: 2 Former Bankers Plead Guilty To Narcotics Cash Tax Counts
description: Thomas Spinelli and Michael Strolla, two former officials of Chemical Bank branches in the Bronx, pleaded guilty yesterday to incometax charges involving payrnents they received for exchanging large amounts of cash for narcotics dealers.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: As professional hockey's playoffs near, youngsters in New York are showing their skills in roller hockey. Left: a player heads for a game. Above: contestants on phone after a hotly contested match.

title: Uganda Refugees Bring Out More Evidence of Atrocities
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 3Penniless Uganda refugees continue to arrive here carrying not much more than their recollection of atrocities, stories similar in horror to the ones that have been sifting out of Uganda for six years.

title: Head of Van Cleef's Charged With Gifts To I.R.S. Auditor
description: Claude Arpels, the president of VanCleef & Arpels, was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on a charge that he had given gifts to an agent of the Internal Revenue Service who was auditing the tax returns of the wellknown Fifth Ave. nue jewelry store.

title: Miss Pogany Bride Of H. Jerome Berns
description: Suzanne Tanzer Pogany of New York and Weston, Conn., was married yesterday morning to H. Jerome Berns of New York and Palm Springs, Calif., a widower. He is vice president, secretary and associate of the 21 Club.

title: Riches of Beekman Place
description: ONLY TWO BLOCKS long, Beekman Place has been called the most exclusive enclave in Manhattan. John D. Rockefeller 3d lives there, as do Huntington Hartford, Mark Goodson, Irving Berlin, Julie Newmar and Princess Ashraf Pahlavi, the Shah of Iran's twin sister.

title: Lord Faulkner, Ex Ulster Chief, DiesinRiding Mishap on Stag Hunt
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 3Lord Faulkner, a prominent Protestant politician and former premier, was killed today in a riding accident near Saintfield, County Down, 12 miles south of Belfast. He was 56 years old.

title: Prof. Herman Ausubel of Columbia, An Authority on Victorian England
description: Herman Ausubel, a Columbia University history professor and an authority on Victorian England, died yesterday of cancer at his home at 35 Claremont Avenue. He was 56 years old.

title: William Macchi, Backed by Jordan, Announces His Mayoral Candidacy
description: JERSEY CITY, March 3Mayor Paul T. Jordan sat in the audience at the Downtown Holiday Inn today as William Macchi, the man he wants as his successor, formally announced his candidacy.

title: Mandel Records Sought
description: BALTIMORE, March 3 (AP)Federal prosecutors subpoenaed the records of Gov. Marvin Mandel's 1973 divorce proceedings today, indicating that they would try to introduce evidence from the divorce records at the governor's retrial in a political corruption case. The surprise request came near the end of an open hearing on plans for the retrial in United States District Court. Judge Robert L. Taylor signed the subpoena, but gave defense attorneys until March 4 to I file a challenge.

title: Bergen Mall Boat Show For 77 Is Under Way
description: Sailboats, small cruisers, fishing boats and canoes arc on display every day from 10 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. through March 12 at the Bergen Mall annual boat show, Route 4 at Forest Avenue in Paramus, N.J. Admission is free.

title: Management
description: Three human characteristicslack of consideration for others, need for recognition and approval and greed for powercreate damaging competitiveness on the job among managers, according to a survey just released by the American Management Associations. The A.M.A. is a nonprofit research and educational organization supported by business.

title: Trapped Miner in Good Spirits As Rescue Workers Drill Closer
description: TOWER CITY, Pa., March 3Cramped into a dripping 4by6by8foot coal mine cavity with a steeply sloping floor. Ronald Adley, an unexpected survivor of the sudden inundation of water that killed two miners Tuesday, injured three and left seven others missing, chewed tobacco and sipped broth today as rescue workers drilled through 50 feet of coal, hoping to brim, him out alive.

title: MONTGOMERY MAYOR RESIGNS IN SCANDAL
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 3Mayor James Robinson of Montgomery unexpectedly resigned today, saying that he was no longer willing to bear the burden of criticism for the way he handled a police department scandal over the last 14 months.

title: Arabs at a Meeting With Africans Hear Plea for More Aid
description: CAIRO, March 3Foreign ministers from some 60 Arab and African countries began work here today on a program for political and economic cooperation between black Africa and the Arab world. They were immediately confronted with a plea from an African delegate that those Arabs with oil wealth share it more generously.

title: CARTER AIDES BACK BILL ON OFFSHORE OIL AND GAS
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)A bill aimed at making offshore oil and gas production safer, faster and more competitive received backing today from the Carter Administration.

title: The Pop Life
description: IT'S BEEN a tough 10 days for Bob Seger. Just as he was about to embark on his first full tour as a headlinerthe tour that was to cap his status as a national star after 13 years regional successhis drummer, Charlie Allen Martin, broke both legs in a bizarre traffic accident.

title: In Java, Political Substance in ShadowPlays
description: RINGINLARIK, Indonesia  For 10 hours, through the night and into the Own, the angular black shadows flitted across the white cotton screen, dancing to the flickering light of the coconutoil lampprinces and queens, soldiers and knaves, farmers and clowns moving in a tapestry of life, love and war.

title: All the Moos That Are Fit to Print
description: Veterinary specialization is unlikely to merit bold print in The New York Times usually, but on Dec. 9, 1976, it printed a headline Doctor of Bovinity. What followed was a reminder of 1974 article by [the British writer] Roald Dahl disclosing a farmer friend's discovery of how to produce heifer calves, and a letter from another English farmer who had experimented with this method.

title: Thousands of Birds Killed Tr, Halt Deadly Disease
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)Thousands of game birds and pet birds are being destroyed on Government orders in 19 states and the District of Columbia in an effort to halt the spread of a deadly nnultry disease.

title: Bearne, Accepting Risk of Failure, Now in Forefront of Fiscal Crisis
description: A year and a half ago, a charitable way of describing Mayor Beanie's role in New York City's fiscal crisis was that it was on the sidelines. Today. there may be a sense of (16.0 vu about much of the city's emergency but one thing is different: Mr. Beanie is in the middle, handling the negotiationsand himself accepting the enormous risk of failure. The Mayor's newly assertive role was symbolized, perhaps, by his formal appearance yesterday afternoon before his cahinet, as well as before the City Council and the Board of Estimate, seeking to rally New Yorkers to his side and vowing not to mortgage our sovereignty to the city's creditors.

title: In Memoriam
description: LIEBERMANAlbert, born, March 4. clearest Daddy, secker of wisdom and truth, I believe In YOU.

title: Bridge:
description: A player who defends poorly and gives the declarer an easy road to success can sometimes win the postmortem, proving that the contract would still have succeeded even if had defended better. A case in point is the diagramed deal played in the 1976 National Mixed Pair Championship in Pittsburgh.

title: 2 Connecticut Men Arrested in Slaying of 2 Mothers
description: Two men were arrested in Norwalk, Conn., late yesterday afternoon as they returned a blue van to a rental agency, and were charged with the murder on Wednesday of two young mothers in the quiet Westchester community of Lewisboro, N.Y.

title: Barry Farber Is Seen as Choice Of Conservatives in Mayoral Race
description: Conservative Party leaders have all but decided to nominate Barry Farber, the host of a radio interview show, for Mayor of New York City, and they suggest scenariobuttressed by some big ifsthat they say would make him a winner.

title: Principal Asserts, They're Getting Americanized
description: GRANNIS. Apr. March 1This southwestern Arkansas hamlet probably received the biggest population percentage increase from the influx of Indochinese refugees of any community in the country.

title: Carey's Aides Deny June Primary Veto Means He Is. Joining AntiBeame Drive
description: Trying to squelch suspicions at City Hall over Governor Carey's veto of the June primary, top aides to Governor Carey insisted yesterday that he was not yet joining an antiMayor Beame coalition.

title: 230 Wealthy Persons Paid No Taxes in 1975
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)TWO hundred thirty of the nation's wealthiest individuals paid no Federal income taxes in 1975, the Treasury Department reported today. But the agency predicted that that number would shrink substantially for 1976 because of changes in the tax 1.ir

title: Advertising
description: Another new magazine for women is in the works. This one, SavvyThe Magazine for the Executive Woman, is the creation of Judith Daniels, former managing editor of The Village Voice and New York magazine.

title: Cauthen Goes 0 for 7
description: When other jockeys go through a day without riding a winner, nobody writes headlines about it. When Steve Cauthen gets blanked, as he did yesterday at Aqueduct, it's news.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Thursday, March 3, 1977

title: Restaurants
description: CONSIDERING how difficult it is to find restaurants that not only offer good food pleasant surroundings, but in addition do so at moderate prices, and in the theater district, the Pantheon, on Eighth Avenue between 43d and 44th Streets, has to be regarded as something of a minor miracle.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Tickets to the Leningrad Symphony Orchestra are $4.50, $5.50 $6.50, $7.50 and $8.50. They may be purchased at the Carnegie Hall box office, open today and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. Information: CI 77459.

title: Only 40 Fewer Cars Sold During Feb. 2128 Than in YearAgo Period
description: DETROIT, March 3The domestic automobile industry reported today that sales of new cars in the Feb. 2128 period fell only 40 units below the yearearlier level and that deliveries for the full month were up 2.4 percent from February 1976 despite lingering effects of the bitterly cold winter.

title: SAVING UNITS
description: Federally insured sayings and loan associations reported net new savings receipts of $4.8 billion in January. the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday. This was the second largest volume on record, exceeded only by the $5.1 billion of net savings received in January 1976.

title: Factory Orders Showed a 2.1% Decline in January
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (Reuters)Factory orders fell 2.1 percent in January from the December level to a seasonally adjusted $105.35 billion, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Dynamics Profit Shows a 4% Rise For 4th Quarter
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's largest defense contractor, had a 4 percent earnings rise in the fourth quarter and a 17.9 percent rise for the full year. The higher earnings were attributed to fine performances by the aerospace and marine groups, David S. Lewis, chairman, reported yesterday.

title: Bathroom Science Captures the World
description: First, you will remember, there was the universe. Then came Earth, and then rain and sun and wind and amoebas and horseshoe crabs, which were followed by dinosaurs and apes, followed by man  who brought about things like fire and the wheel and civilization and the umbrella.

title: Reluctantly Wealthy, They Fund Radical Groups
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.David Crocker had an unusual problem. He was a rich kid, part of the ruling class, and he didn't particularly want to be.

title: Music: Taking Up A Mahler Gauntlet
description: Klaus Tennstedt, suffering from what is described as severe bronchitis, was unable to conduct his second round of concerts starting last night with the New York Philharmonic. Into the breach jauntily stepped David Gilbert, the assistant conductor of the orchestra. This was probably what he has been dreaming about ever since he took the post. This is what every understudy dreams about.

title: DEMOCRATS IN NASSAU FACE PRIMARY FIGHT
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 3A primary contest for the Democratic nomination or Nassau County Executive appeared likely today as David H. Peirez announced his candidacy.

title: New Amsterdam Singers In French Choral Show
description: The New Amsterdam Singers will present a program of French choral music Sunday at 4:30 P.M. at Broadway Presbyterian Church, at 114th Street. There is a suggested contribution of $3.

title: If June's Too Soon, Remember November
description: Obviously exasperated by the politicians of all parties who have tried to schedule this year's primary election to suit their own selfish interests, the Governor of New York, in solemn declaration, asserts that he will not permit a primary unless he can be sure that:

title: A Plan Would Give South Bronx Stores, a Campus and 3,000 jobs
description: A plan that could give the improverisbed South Bronx a new shopping center and college campus and 3,000 new jobs was announced yesterday by Bronx cornmunity and political leaders.

title: Antonia Brico Wields Baton in Brooklyn
description: Crouched over the score, but peering out rather sternly from her high perch at members of the orchestra, Antonia Brim baton in one hand, asked with the other for more expression from the strings. Later she spoke: All brass: fortissimo, then diminuendo at onceTaaaaa. When the next movement of Dvorak's Fourth Symphony had ended, the 74yearold conductor was smiling.

title: Beanie, Accepting Risk of Failure, Now in Forefront of Fiscal Crisis
description: A year and a half ago, a charitable way of describing Mayor Beame's role in New York City's fiscal crisis was that it was on the sidelines. Today, there may be a sense of dejil vu about much of the city's emergency, but one thing is different: Mr. Beame is in the middle, handling the negotiationsand himself accepting the enormous risk of failure.

title: Blumenthal to Seek Counsel of Business
description: The Carter Administration yesterday endorsed the idea, strongly espoused by the outgoing Republicans, that American industry was running short of investment capital and needs tax concessions and other Federal aid to stimulate fresh investment.

title: Dim Sum 10 From Column A
description: Sameness in food and, habits depresses; variety stimulates, an ancient though anonymous Chinese philosopher is supposed to have said.

title: Many Top Aides In Carter Team Still Not Sworn
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Six weeks after President Carter took office, fewer than half the major subCabinet positions in his Administration have been officially filled, and some Administration officials privately say these delays in appointments are hampering the functioning of various departments and agencies.

title: 2 Men in Ulster Accuse Police of Brutality
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 3Allegations of brutality on the part of the Ulster police during questioning of suspects believed to belong to the Irish Republican Army led today to demands for an independent inquiry into interrogation methods.

title: No Bankers
description: Last night around 11 o'clock, suddenly no one could remember what day it was, said the banker. They had to stop to figure it out. Do we have to get this thing in this morning or the next?

title: At the Movies
description: THIRTY YEARS AGO, Richard Widmark was propelled to stardom when he pushed the crippled mother of a stool pigeon down flight of stairs in Kiss of Death. At 61, Mr. Widmark is still pushing people around, even Presidents of the United States. In Twilight's Last Gleaming, he casually instructs his troops to gun dokvn troublesome group that happens to include the panicked President, and in the coming Domino Principle, he springs a sharpshooter from prison for the purpose of Presidential assassination. On a more plebeian plane, he will stalk a spoilsport who threatens to blow up an amusement park in Rollercoaster.

title: 5 Are Indicted in Florida For Allegedly Defrauding Vietnam Prisoners of War
description: MIAMI, March 3 (AP)A Federal grand jury has indicted five men for fraud in an alleged investment scheme that bilked former Vietnam prisoners of war out of 81.9 million through a nowdefunct bond firm, the authorities said today_

title: Resignation Request Starts Political Crisis in Belgium
description: BRUSSELS, March 3 (AP) Prime Minister Leo Tindemans has asked two of his Cabinet ministers to resign, starting a political crisis that could topple his coalition Government and lead to general elections a year early.

title: Syria Is Said to Reduce Military Role of Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)Syria is reported to be gradually reducing the number of Soviet military advisers serving with Syrian forces.

title: Waterbury Schools Are Reopened
description: WATERBURY, Conn.. March 3The 29 public schools here reopened today after a sixday teachers strike that resulted in a contract settlement described by Mayor Edward D. Bergin Jr. as unique in the State of Connecticut and probably in the nation.

title: REORGANIZATION BILL APPROVED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Without opposition and with little debate, the Senate approved today a bill that would give President Carter the broad authority he, requested to reorganize the Government.

title: Rusko Scores Big Upset, Wins SkiJumoinz Contest
description: FALUN, Sweden, March 3 (AP)Josef Rusko, a virtually unknown Czechoslovak ski jumper, scored the biggest upset of the season by winning the 70meter specialhill contest at the 28th Swedish Nordic games tonight. The 20yearold produced two nearly flawless jumps.

title: Indochina Refugees Fleeing Arkansas Jobs
description: GRANNIS, Ark.. March 1The large number of Indochinese refugees brought here to ease the labor shortages of a poultryprocessing plant is dwindling rapidly as many find they cannot earn enough in the recently depressed industry to pay the rent on their companyowned mobile homes.

title: Treasures From A Pleasure Dome
description: SOME OF THE MOST exotic and splendid decorations and furnishings from the opulent, onioncome Royal Eavilion at Srighcon, England, went on view yesterday at the CcoperHewith Maseam wnose interiors they will lend drama to through May 23.

title: Cabaret: Love Songs for 2 Saxes
description: The only jazz band in town that sports two bass saxophones is the New California Ramblers, a ninepiece band that plays at Stryker's, Columbus Avenue at West 86th Street, on Wednesday evenings. As a result, it is the only hand in town that offers basssaxophone duets that, as played by Sam Parkins and Vinnie Giordanogalumphing through Sweet Georgia Brown, for instanceare wondrously deepthroated swinging things.

title: HOUSE REBUFFS NAVY ON NUCLEAR CARRIER, SUPPORTING CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Navy's quest for another Nimitzclass nuclearpowered carrier foundered in the well of the House today when a proposal for further funding of the $2.2 billion ship was voted down, 262 to 161.

title: Beame Says Moratorium Problem Is Undermining City's Credibility
description: Mayor Beame warned yesterday in his annual State of the City message that the continuing failure to resolve New York City's $1 billion moratorium debt problem was undermining the credibility we need to reenter the municipal bond market.

title: People and Business
description: Emphasizing that he spoke as a political independent, Donald I. Baker, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division of the Department of Justice, declared here yesterday the division had a tough, strong hardworking staff of professionals and that he hoped for a continuation of the present antitrust program under the Carter Administration. Mr. Baker,

title: Irvine Heiress Outflanks Mobil In a Feud Over California Land
description: LOS ANGELES, March 3Joan Irvine Smith, the feisty California land heiress, appeared again to have outflanked the Mobil Oil Corporation and a charitable foundation with whom she has feuded for more than 20 years in a battle over some of California's most valuable real estate.

title: Earnings for D.D.S. Up 22.3% in Quarter
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach had 22.3 percent increase in earnings in the fourth quarter and a record 73 percent increase for the year.

title: About Real Estate
description: Ah, precious Environment, how the heavy wheels of government churn in thy name!

title: Weekend Gardening: Gadget Guide
description: WHEN it comes to gimmicks, I'm as susceptible as the next gardener. Some novelties really do work as well as they say, which is why, I suppose, I keep trying out the new gardening gadgets. Others  well  they're like planting mushroom spawn around the Alamo. Who needs them? And they just don't work.

title: HOUSE REBUFFS NAVY ON NUCLEAR CARRIER, SUPPORTING CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Navy's quest for another Nimitzclass nuclearpowered carrier foundered in the well of the House today when a proposal for further funding of the $2.2 billion ship was voted down, 262 to 161. ne action was the first legislative victory for President Carter's leaner defense budget and a defeat for his former Navy mentor, Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, who had strongly endorsed building fourth 93,400ton nuclearpowered carrier.

title: ASSASSINATION PANEL WANTS 3 TO TESTIFY
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, said today that members of the troubled Assassinations Committee hoped that testimony from three witnesses might persuade the House to let the committee continue its investigation into the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: A Baker's Dozen of Critics Choose
description: All right, everyone has badgered you with 10 bests and insufferably long lists of choices, and it has all become inextricably confused in your mind. Do you really want to know what to do this weekend? Here are the selections, three each, made by 13 critics of The New York Times who spend their time going out for a living. These are the shows and programs and exhibitions they would go to if they had a free weekend. You may want only one, but if you are really dedicated and move fast, you might squeeze in as many as five between today and utter exhaustion late Sunday night.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: And so, Doctor, how do you feel about allowing a baby to cry?

title: Goodrich Proposes Plan For Binding Arbitration
description: AKRON, Ohio, March 3 (AP)B. Y. Goodrich Company has proposed a binding arbitration plan intended to avert what it calls the trial by ordeal of strikes.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 4, 1977

title: U.S. Unit Finds Imports Imperil Sugar Industry
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)In an action that could lead to higher sugar prices, the International Trade Commission agreed today that the domestic sugar industry is being jeopardized by rising imports.

title: Books of The Times
description: HEN the great ones stoop to memoirthat version of themselves they would commend to posterityit is fun to roam around among the denials and aggressions, old loves remembered and old scores settled, in search of an anecdote that seems to hear the watermark or signature of their :ife's work. We are finding ourselves, of course, not them. But still: one thinks of Andre Malraux always ending up in a Lascaux cave, his womb. Or of JeanPaul Sartre in the library. discovering books, comparing them to oysters and mushrooms. Or of young Vladimir Nabokov watching through the dining room window as his father soars like one of those paradisiac personages . . . on the vaulted ceiling of a church.

title: From a Sociologist's Workshop
description: Some of the findings of sociology take a considerable time to enter the public domain, Robert K. Merton, the doyen of American sociology and University Professor at Columbia, remarks resignedly in an essay in this hook. This time lag is partly the fault of sociologists themselves and the reharbative jargon in which many of them write.

title: 8 on Newark Council Seek School Chief's Resignation
description: NEWARK, March 3Eight of Newark's nine City Council members called today for the resignation of the head of the city's public school system on the grounds of poor leadership and failure to carry out essential educational reforms.

title: Vermont House Backs Lottery
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., March 3 (AP)The Vermont House gave final approval today to legislation enacting a state lottery, sending the bill to the Senate where its fate is uncertain. House passage came on a 98to49 rollcall vote.

title: Music: What Cellos Tell Pianos
description: In their fourth annual concert in New York since 1974, Harry Clark and Sanda Schuldmann, a cellopiano duo, gave the first performance of Benjamin Lees's Dialoeue for Cello and Piano.

title: High Cost of Family Homes Called New Form of Housing Deprivation
description: The excessive portions of income that more and more families are paying for adequate housing mark a significant new form of housing deprivation in the United States, according to a major study made public yesterday

title: Militants in a Paris Church Attack a Priest
description: PARIS, March 3Some members of a group of militant Roman Catholics who are demanding a return to Latin masses beat a priest unconscious this morning inside a church that the group has been occupying in the Latin Quarter since last Sunday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: David Owen Cautions the Soviet Bloc on Rights Issue
description: LONDON, March 3Britain's new Foreign Secretary, David Owen, said today in his first major speech that the Soviet bloc must recognize that concern for human rights is not a diversionary tactic but an integral part of foreign policy in the Western democracies.

title: Sakharov, Seeking a New Apartment in Moscow, Finds a Tangle of Red Tape Barring the Door
description: MOSCOW, March 3Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet Union's most celebrated humanrights activist, has been locked in a mundane struggle familiar to millions of ordinary Soviet citizens. He is trying to move into a new apartment.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Loans to Spa Are Said to Have Cut Reserves of Union Pension Fund
description: SAN FRANCISCO. March 3Real estate development loans to a spa in a remote area of Southern California have seriously depleted the reserves of a union pension fund, and two trustees resigned in protest when the loans were made, according to confidential sources.

title: Television
description: TOP WEEKEND FILMS

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: TaxiLicensing Fee at Meadowlands Is Found Illegal
description: HACKENSACK, March 3A yearold taxilicensing fee that has all but eliminated cab service at the Meadowlands Sports Complex in East Rutherford was declared illegal and invalid today in State Superior Court.

title: Lefkowitz Mows Down the Sale of Grass
description: When it is packed into onequarter ounce bags and cleverly marketed as if it were the variety that is smoked. according to Louis J. Lefkowitz, the State Attorney General.

title: Beame Seeking Private Financing For City Arts Expansion in 19791
description: New York City officials are seeking funds from private foundations to plan na international exposition of the arts in 1979, Mayor Beame said yesterday in his State of the City message.

title: DR. DAVID M. LEVY, 84, A PSYCHIATRIST, DIES
description: Dr. David M. Levy, a pioneer in child psychiatry who introduced the. Rorschach test for measuring personality traits and general intelligence to the United States and coined such terms as sibling rivalry, died Tuesday in his apartment at 993 Fifth Avenue. He was 84 years old.

title: Miss Fratianne Takes World Figure Skating Championship
description: TOKYO, March 3 (AP)Linda Fratianne of Northridge, Calif., won the women's world figure skating championship today, saving herself with grace and technical control after a fall in the important freeskating event. The 16yearold United States champion, received 10 ordinals and 189.26 points, which means that eight of the nine judges gave her first place and one gave her second.

title: Friday
description: HUREYEV SHOW

title: 2 Men in Blue Van Sought in Slaying of 2 Mothers
description: LEWISSORO, N. Y., March 3 New York and Connecticut police were searching today for a blue van and two men whose burglary of a home in this quiet Westchester community ended at dusk yesterday in the murder of two young mothers.

title: ARGENTINA ORDERS BAN ON ANTISEMITIC WORKS
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 3The Argentine military Government today banned the publication and circulation of antiSemitic Nazi literature by a publishing house here and ordered the confiscation of its publications now on sale.

title: Swallowed Up
description: Our freeenterprise system is in peril because of unbridled and excessive merger activity by the corporate giants. In ,the past 25 years, thousands of viable companies have been swallowed up by large companies in questionable mergers. And the pace is quickening. Almost daily we read about some corporate giant planning to acquire another. Acquisition targets in 1976 included over 100 big companies, about 40 with a purchase price exceeding $100 million. Indeed, two had price tags of $2 billionMarcor acquired by Mobil Oil and Utah International by General Electric.

title: A Sleepy Suburb
description: LEWISBORO, N.Y., March 3This town in northern Westchester County, where two young mothers were murdered yesterday nas been growing rapidly and the growth has brought trouble neonle here say.

title: California to Consider DNA Limits
description: SACRAMENTO, March 3The first state bill regulating the controversial genetic research called recombinant DNA was introduced today in the California Legislature.

title: For Children
description: A Purim Happening

title: Many Top Aides In Carter Team Still Not Sworn
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Six weeks after President Carter took office, fewer than half the major subCabinet positions in his Administration have been officially filled, and some Administration officials privately say these delays in appointments are hampering the functioning of various departments and agencies.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 3The State of New Jersey asked the State Superior Court in Elizabeth today to order the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to help pay the $50 million cost of building a new approach to the Newark International Airport.

title: Britain Deported 22 Americans
description: LONDON. March 3 (Reuters)Twentytwo United States citizens were deported from Britain in 1976, Home Office Under Secretary Shirley Summerslcill told Parliament today. She gave no other details.

title: 29 Civilians in Thailand Reported Killed in Ambush Of Convoy by Insurgents
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, March 4 (AP)Thai insurgents ambushed a convoy in a mountainous northern area yesterday, killing 29 civilians with automaticrifle fire and grenades in what military authorities here described today as one of the costliest attacks by rebels in the 12yearlong conflict with the Government.

title: Abercrombie and Creditors Agree
description: The Abercrombie & Fitch Company, the ninestore chain catering to affluent sportsmen, announced yesterday that it might soon emerge from the Chapter XI provisions of the Bankruptcy Act after having reached an agreement in principle on a repayment arrangement with the official creditors committee.

title: Retail Store Sales Rise 9%
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Department of Commerce reported today that total retail store sales last week were an estimated $13.11 billion, up 9 percent from the yearearlier level of $12.02 billion. Department store sales were about $1.12 billion, up 17 percent from last year's $962 million.

title: DRIVERS IN RISK POOL FACE INSUPDCE RISE
description: The 500,000 motorists who get their insurance coverage through New York State's assignedrisk pool face an average increase in rates, statewide, of 13.5 percent, it was learned yesterday. Industry sources reported, and the Statc Insurance Department confirmed, that the Automobile Insurance Plans Services Office, which manages the pool for the in. surance companies, had been authorized to increase its rates 39.4 percent on the minimum amount of liability and nofault coverage required by law.

title: White Teachers to Pay $3,000 For Cutting Black Student's Hair
description: LENOIR, N.C., March 3 (UPI)TwO white high school teachers who cut tuft of hair from a black student's head will pay the youth $3,000 in an outofcourt settlement.

title: Broadway
description: A LPACINO will come back to Broadway some time next month when he appears in The Basic Training of Pavia Hummel. This will be the Theater Company of Boston's production of Pavlo Hummel, which was David Rabe's first play, and which the company originally did with Mr..Pacino in 1972. The production will be directed by David Wheeler, who is artistic director of the Theater Company of Boston, and it will be on Broadway for what the producers, Moe Septee and Carmen F. Zollo, call a limited engagement. Negotiations are still way under for a theater.

title: How Justices on Supreme Court Voted in the Social Security Case
description: In the Supreme Court's 5to4 ruling on Wednesday that struck clown a requirement making it more difficult for widowers than widows to collect Social Security survivors benefits, the vote was as follows:

title: New Yorker Offered Mass Transit Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Louis T. Gambaccini, director .of rail transportation for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. has been offered the job of administrator of the Urban Mass Transit Administration here.

title: PEOPLE'S FIREHOUSE TO RESUME SERVICES
description: Firemen will return to the socalled People's Firehouse in Brooklyn for the first time in 15 months under a cornpromise reached last night between the city and community activists.

title: Music: Penderecki Conducts Himself
description: Krzysztof Penderecki, one of the artists who made Poland a center of avantgarde ferment in the late 1950's and early 60's appeared in his New York conducting debut on Wednesday night at Carnegie hall, where he led the Philharmonic Orchestra of Yale in a program of his own compositions. Mr. Penderecki, who has been on the Yale University music faculty since 1972, conducts like a composer, which is to say he employs a sturdy uncomplicated beat and gestures that are aimed at getting the most out of the performers, rather than at dazzling the audience.

title: State A.F.L.C.I.O. Turns Down Carey's Albany Dinner Invitation
description: Increasingly strained relations between Governor Carey and organized labor broke into the open yesterday when the 29member executive council of the New York State A.F.L.C.I.O. rejected the Governor's invitation to meet with him at dinner next Wednesday.

title: ShakeUp and Roundup at City University
description: To Merge or Submerge CUNY?

title: DRIVERS IN RISK POOL FACE INSURANCE RISE
description: The 500,000 motorists who get their insurance coverage through New York State's assignedrisk pot)! face an average increase in rates, statewide, of 43.5 percent, it was learned yesterday.

title: Bruins
description: The New York Rangers halfhearted playoff drive sputtered again last night in a 41 loss to the Boston Bruins in Madison Square Garden. The defeat left Coach John Ferguson wondering whether his team of youngsters and older players really wanted to be in postseason play.

title: Unionization of Armed Forces
description: President Carter's negative comments on unionization of the armed forces have focused attention on the often heated debate over the subject that has agitated the services in the last three months. Speaking to Defense Department employes on Tuesday, Mr. Carter said he was opposed to unionization of the armed forces and was unaware of any strong movement toward it supported by leaders of national and international unions.

title: Taiwan Oil Spill Fouls 50 Miles of Island's Coast
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 3An oil spill from a Kuwaiti tanker that sank last week off Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan has spread to contaminate 50 miles of the island's northeastern coastline, threatening the livelihood of 50,000 Taiwanese dependent on the fishing industry, according to Government officials.

title: Treasury and H.U.D. Appointees
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)President Carter today appointed a Georgia woman as Under Secretary of the Treasury and a University of Massachusetts vice president to be Under Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Both will be paid $52,500 a year.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney discusses proposals of two leaders of the oil industry to cope with the longterm problems of the energy situation. Page D3.

title: 4 Japanese Rightists Free Hostages, Surrender After Seizing Building
description: TOKYO. Friday, March 4Four armed rightwing extremists invaded a downtown office building here yesterday afternoon, seized a dozen hostages and demanded basic changes in the postwar society that has developed in Japan. They released their prisoners last night unharmed and surrendered peacefully early today.

title: Edgar Ansel Mowrer Dies at 84; Won Pulitzer for Reports on Hitler
description: LISBON, March 3 (AP)Edgar Ansel Mowrer, the American foreign correspondent who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1933 for dispatches detailing the rise of Adolf Hitler, died Wednesday on the Portuguese island of Madeira. He would have been 85 next Tuesday.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 4, 1977

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: MANHATTAN BRONX

title: Art: Fierce Energy Of a Fantasist
description: SOME DAY, perhaps, some New York museum will give us a retrospective exhibition of the art of Richard Lindner. Paris has already had one, and it seems odd that New York, where this Germanborn painter has lived much of his life since the 1950's and which has so decisively influenced the iconography of his art, should be denied a comprehensive survey of his extraordinary oeuvre. Perhaps our curators find his work too exhausting; compared with what they generally prefer to show us nowadays, there is awful lot to look at in it.

title: HandtoHand Combat Over Equal Rights
description: When the Supreme Court struck down sex discrimination in the payment of Social Security survivors benefits this week, it provided an unintentionally bitter symbol to supporters of equal rights for men and women.

title: Winners and Brand New Champions
description: Such as they are, these men are American champions: Ron Harris, middleweight; Harold Weston Jr., welterweight; Mike Rossman, lightheavyweight; Scott LeDoux, heavyweight. American champions are not to be confused with United States champions, who are designated by the promotional team of Don King and American Broadcasting Companies. They are not the same as world champions or World Boxing Association champions or World Boxing Council champions. These men were enthroned as American champions by Madison Square Garden, which ran a show topped by four 10round bouts Wednesday night and advertised the bouts as American championships. Not North American or Central American or South American or even Latin American. Just American. Thus are fame and fortune achieved by fist fighters in the Year of Our Lord, 1977.

title: Art: Ghoulish Wit Of Llyn Foulkes
description: LLYN FOULKES has not shown in New York since 1975, when his exhibition at the Willard Gallery was widely noted for its ghoulish wit and its readiness to turn the conventional pictureprocess inside out. He has now returned to town and can be seen (through March 19) at the Gruenebaum Gallery, 25 East 77th Street

title: A Whirlwind Visit to Washington by Mayor Beame Finishes With GrabBag of Promises From the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  Mayor Beanie made a whirlwind visit here today and left with a grab bag of promises that he interpreted to mean: 10,000 federally supported housing starts in New York in the next 12 months and a speedup in selling off cityheld mortgages to obtain $200 million by June 30.

title: Reports of Nearby Skiing Conditions
description: (Reports supolled by resort owners.)

title: Fewer Students or Lower Standards?
description: The City University has begun a crash drive to corral warm bodies into its classrooms. Enrollment has been declining precipitously, and since some state aid is pegged to the number of students, university administrators are worried. If applications don't pick up, they may be compelled to make cutbacks, which could adversely affect many careers. So they have decided to make admission easier by assorted forms of salesmanship, and a lowering from 87 to 80 of the high school average required for admission to one of the senior colleges.

title: Stocks Advance on Assurances From Carter to Lick
description: The stock market, responding to assurances that the Carter Administration is committed to licking inflation, rallied modestly yesterday.

title: Jane Frederick Wins Triathlon And Hurdles
description: TORONTO, March 3At first, she thought it was merely a bruised ankle. It hurt but not that much. Then, she saw blood flowing from a deep gash.

title: Futures in Gold And Silver Fall; Soybeans Rise
description: Prices of gold and silver futures fell yesterday after climbing spectacularly for several sessions.

title: HANOI IS AFFIRMATIVE ON AMERICAN MISSING
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Friday, March 4 (AP) A Vietnamese Foreign Ministry spokesman, quoted by Hanoi's official press agency, said today that Vietnam was prepared to consider and to settle the question of Americans missing in action in the Indonchina war.

title: Eugenie Brazier Dies in France; Chef Put Emphasis on Simplicity
description: LYONS, France, March 3 (AP)Eugenie Brazier, whose quiet rebellion against ostentation in French cuisine brought her to the highest ranks of the predominantly male world of great chefs, is dead at 81.

title: Orpheus Trio Is Thriving
description: For the members of the Orpheus Trio, happiness is no longer having to crisscross the country to set up rehearsal dates. All three are now firmly ensconced in New York, and are looking forward to two concerts this weekend practically in their own backyard at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Turkish Ghetto in West Berlin Plagued by Unemployment
description: WEST BERLINBlock by block, the crumbling Kreuzberg neighborhood is becoming a ghetto of Turkish migrant workers and their families, a slum spreading along the concrete wall that slashes through Berlin like a scar,

title: Announcer Riles Borg, but He Wins
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 3 (UPI)Bjorn Borg, starting his match with a show of temper, rallied and beat John Lloyd, 06. 62, 64, today in the third round of the United States national indoor tennis championships. The 20yearold Swede, who cursed an official and demanded his ejection from a match yesterday was obviously upset today by a pregame remark made by a public address announcer and put up no fight in the first set.

title: U.S. Again Protests Curbs On Embassy in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, March 3 (Reuters) The American Embassy today delivered its second protest this week to the Foreign) Ministry following the seizing of two Jewish activists who tried to meet a diplomat.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 4, 1977

title: Edwin Hammond Todd, 61, Dies; Was Vice President of Inmont
description: Edwin Hammond Todd, former vice president of the Inmont Corporation, chemical concern, died yesterday at his home in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 61 years old.

title: There's More Than Fish in the Sea
description: As of this week American fishermen have prior claim to the catch within 200 milesinstead of only 12 milesof this nation's coasts, with quotas assigned to foreign fishing fleets for the remainder. Critics of the arrangement, mandated by Congress last year, have deplored it as a curtailment of freedom of the seas and a setback to attempts at reaching worldwide agreement on oceanic problems through the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea.

title: Unsigned Rose Reports As Reds Start Workout
description: TAMPA. Fla., March 3Pete Rose, unsigned but unbowed, drove his gray RollsRoyce through the gates today and joined the first full reunion of the Cincinnati Reds since they crunched the New York Yankees in the World Series last October.

title: Plains, Ga.: Merchandising the Presidency
description: PLAINS, Ga., March 3The merchandising of the Presidency begins about 40 miles from here on Interstate 75.

title: Legionnaires
description: ATLANTA, March 3 (AP)The National Center for Disease Control has ruled out legionaires disease as the possible cause of the deaths of two center workers who died earlier this week. However, the center said yesterday that it still did not know what caused the deaths of George Flowers, 49 years old, and Robert Dubingon, 43.

title: A Mies Chaise Longue That Swept Them Off Their Feet
description: Dean James Stewart Polshek of Columbia University's School of Architecture had just been catapulted from Ludwig Mies van der Rohe's bouncy chaise longue in full view of hundreds of champagnesipping furniture testers. It's grossly proportioned, he insisted.

title: New Face
description: Sandy Stewart, who used to sing on Perry Como's television show and who won a Grammy Award for her record of My Coloring Book in 1962, is being rediscovered by enthusiastic audiences at the Ballroom, where she is resuming the career she once thought she had left behind.

title: Kuhn Approves Finley's Sale of Lindblad
description: Bowie Kuhn approved Charles O. Finley's $400,000 sale of Paul Lindblad, the relief pitcher, from Oakland to the Texas Rangers yesterday. But the baseball commissioner said he would keep a sharp eye on future dealing by the controversial owner of the A's.

title: S.E.C. and Dutch Exchange. Begin Talks on Option Trade Regulation
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Amsterdam Stock Exchange have begun discussions on options trading that could, lead to a major breakthrough in the international regulation of securities.

title: 170 Elderly Evacuated in Blaze. At the Breakers Hotelin Long Beach
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., March 3More than 170 elderly people were evacuated from the Breakers Hotel here this afternoon as fire swept through the sixstory Boardwalk hotel. Three residents and two firemen were treated at the local hospital for smoke inhalation and minor injuries and then released.

title: Uganda Refugees Bring Out More Evidence of Atrocities
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 3Penniless Uganda refugees continue to arrive here carrying not much more than their recollection of atrocities, stories similar in horror to the ones that have been sifting out of Uganda for six years.

title: Stanford Biology Professor Is Named to Head F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Carter Administration today chose Dr. Donald Kennedy, a biology professor at Stanford University, to be Commissioner of Food :md Drugs.

title: A Question of Power: What Makes Peter Tufo Run?
description: Beep. Beep. Beep. The blacktie dinner party on East 72d Street was just beginning to break up the other night when the electronic alarm that Peter Tufo always wears on his belt went off. It signaled trouble in one of the prisons on Bikers Island.

title: A World of Theater at La Mama
description: A New Yorker who puts down more money than he should for tickets to an expensive, imported performing arts group such as the Bolshoi Opera or the Royal Ballet can always console himself with the thought, Well, I saved money on the air fare.

title: A Question of Power: What Makes Peter Tufo Run?
description: Beep. Beep. Beep. The blacktie dinner party on East 72d Street was just beginning to break up the other night when the electronic alarm that Peter Tufo always wears on his belt went off. It signaled trouble in one of the prisons on Rikers Island.

title: Skidmore Polo Victor
description: ITHACA, N.Y., March 3Jed Levitt scored seven goals tonight to lead Skidmore to a 138 victory over Norwich in a firstround game of the national intercollegiate indoor polo tournament. Skidmore plays Yale and Cornell meets Harvard in a secondround doubleheader at the Shallowbrook Riding Club in Somers, Conn., Saturday night.

title: Publishing: Fallout Of Atom Secrets
description: ANTHONY CAVE BROWN the nalist British journalist who specializes in militarydiplomatic affairs, was walking down the hall on the 13th floor of the modern military records section of the National Archives when he spotted a rickety wooden cart stacked with a number of tattered document boxes, Each box was labeled MEDOfficial History.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: The Gentle Giant
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Tip O'Neill of Massachusetts has just moved into his new headquarters as Speaker of the House of Representatives, and it is now becoming clear in Washington that when this gentle giant moves anywhere, people tend to get out of his way.

title: SHORTTERM LOANS GROWING IN DEMAND
description: A variety of indicators have been pointing to increased demand for shortterm credit over the last two weeks, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York rep8rted yesterday.

title: Race Track in Suffolk Faces Decisive Period
description: YAPHANK. L.I., March 3Ronald Parr is heading for the most grueling homestretch that his race track. Parr Meadows. will ever see.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Red Chiefs at Madrid Parley Skirt Issue of SovietBloc Repression
description: MADRID, March 3The leaders of the Spanish, Italian and French Communist parties called today for the full application of the 1975 Helsinki accords, which included pledges by both Eastern and western countries of respect for human rights. But the three leaders did not specifically mention recent attacks on dissidents in the Soviet bloc countries.

title: St. John's Ousts Jaspers; Seton Hall Tops Army
description: St. John's put together a fast start and a tough finish last night to outdistance Manhattan, 7364, in the first round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metropolitan Division playoffs.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Islanders Triumph, 42, On Harris's Two Goals
description: DETROIT. March 3  The Islanders got the first laugh tonight in their game with the Detroit Red Wings when Lorne Henning scored his sixth shorthanded goal of the season, a little more than 3 minutes from the start.

title: Stock Exchange Member Firms Report Net Rose in 4th Quarter
description: Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange reported total net income for the fourth quarter of $111.5 million, compared with $74.2 million in the 1975 period, the exchange reported yesterday. Aggregate earnings for member firms in 1976 were $507.5 million, compared with $414.7 in 1975.

title: Art People
description: DOCUMENTA, the big and trendy international art Show that enlivens the placid German city of Kassel every four years or so is almost upon us again. The sixth version of the quasiquadrennial, begun in 1955 to expose Europe to postwar art will open June 24 and run for 100 days showing us what's up in sculpture, painting, drawing, photography, films video and performance art anda new categorythe books that more and More artists have taken to doing.

title: Commodity Price Index Advances 3 to 215.5 From WeekAgo Levet
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 215.5 from 212.5 last week.

title: Court Awards Bank $790,000 in City Suit
description: The Flushing National Bank, whose suit upset New York City's moratorium en repaying $1 billion in shortterm notes, was awarded $790,000 yesterday by Justice James Gibson of State Supreme Court, the judge designated to. handle the case. In addition, Flushing National is to recceive 6 percent interest from June 30, the date the notes matured.

title: Korea Inquiry Goes On, Bell Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that the investigation of all substantial leads in the Korean C.I.A. case is continuing and that he intended to prosecute cases where proof of criminal violations was found.

title: Notes on People
description: Taking curtain calls at the end of a 50thyearinshowbusiness special being taped for CBS Television, Bing Crosby stumbled and fell about 15 feet into the orchestra pit and suffered minor head cuts and bruises. The 72yearold singer was in Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena, Calif., yesterday, but hoped to be released today. He has bruises and is a bit sore, a spokesman said When Mr. Crosby took the fall Thursday night, hundreds of spectators in the Ambassador College auditorium in Pasadena gasped. Kathryn Crosby, the old groaner's wife, rushed from the wings, as did their three children and Bob Hope, and Pearl Bailey. Mr. Hope yesterday called his old friend the luckiest man alive for having survived the fall. He grabbed a big piece of proscenium arch made of wood with lights on it, said Mr. Hope. It broke his fall and saved his life.

title: A Building Fit for Buildings
description: Sometimes Washington seems to consist of nothing but bureaucracies and museums. There is even a bureaucracy, the Smithsonian Institution, that runs a lot of the museums. It oversees a marvelous and motley assortment of arts and science showcases. from the National Gallery to the Air and Space Museum, which line the Mall in marble monuments of leviathan scale. Not much is missing from the Smithsonian's comprehensive and curious collection, except a museum of the American building arts.

title: Carters Weigh Personal Campaign For the Equal Rights. Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, March 4In the wake of the defeat of the equal rights amendment in North Carolina earlier this week, President and Mrs. Carter are reassessing their campaign strategy for ratification, White House aide said today.

title: MARK FLANAGAN, EXGOLFER AND RETIRED L.I. BROKER
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 4  Mark Flanagan, a prominent competitor in amateur golf in the New York area from the middle 1920's through the 1940's, died here today. He was 70 years old.

title: A Checklist for Making The Carter Guest List
description: WASHINGTON, March 4Do you crave an invitation to a statusspiced state dinner at the White House, complete with the chance to watch Amy Carter read a book? It helps to know some of the guidelines on how to wangle one.

title: Bucharest Witness Tells of  Long Roar As Quake Struck
description: VIENNA, Saturday March 5An employee of the Austrian Embassy in Bucharest reported by telephone to Vienna shortly before 7 A.M. to day that she had seen the ruins of two or three highrise buildings that had collapsed in the quake.

title: GREGORY F. COLEMAN, 75, WAS HOME NEWS EDITOR
description: Gregory F. Coleman. a former city editor of the defunct Bronx Home News, died early yesterday in Gracie Square Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 4380 Vireo Avenue, the Bronx.

title: The Wonderful Crook Deals Delightfully With the Swiss
description: Switzerland, Swiss film makers seem to be telling us. is a perfect Swiss movement that doesn't deliver the correct time. None of the best Swiss films we've been seeing here recentlyLa Salarnandre. The Middle of the World and The Invitation, among otherscould be easily categorized as social or political in content. They share a comically reserved manner that is hardly the thing for agitprop. Yet each in its way is as deeply concerned about the quality of life as any of Godard's more revolutionary films.

title: The Apple Hill Chamber Players
description: The Apple Hill Chamber Players, a deliciously named and reasonably polished young organization that has its roots at Apple Hill Farm in Nelson, N. H., put a peck of its wares on display at Tully Hall on Thursday night. There are 14 musicians in this commune and school, whose headquarters is a farmhouse in the Monadnock region, though only nine of them, in addition to the guest soprano, Mary Burgess, took part in the three works on this program.

title: 2 Brothers Kill Officer In Courtroom Gunbattle
description: CALIENTE, Nev., March 4 (UPI)Two brothers, apparently enraged that a police officer suspected one of them in a hitandrun accident, burst into a courtroom. today and, shot the policeman to death in a gun battle in front of a municipal judge.

title: About 75 Likely to Reach Carter
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI)Fewer than 75 people are likely to get through to President Carter during his twohour radio callin tomorrow, and those who do must call from a publicly listed phone and be ready to wait on the line.

title: Text of Banks' Proposal for New City Review Board
description: Following is the text of the proposal by a group of New York banks for new Review Board to he set up to monitor New York City's finances:

title: For Blind Youths A Special Tour of Art Museum
Court Decides to Oust Judge Y engo As Totally Unsuited for the Bench
description: TRENTON, March 4The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that John W. Yengo was totally unsuited, by temper and temperament, for judicial office and ordered his removal as a judge in the Jersey City Municipal Court.

title: Xerox Files Suit Against I.B.M., Alleging Infringement on Patents
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday filed a new suit against the International Business Machines Corporation, charging that its patents on plain paper copying and duplicating equipment had been infringed by the giant computer manufacturer.

title: Communists Ask a Battle on Rights
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia. March 4 (UPI) Communist nations called today for decisive battle against the human rights movement spreading through Eastern Europe.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONPedagogy and plastics are joined in one of this week's patented inventions. The inventor, Howard Natter of Yonkers, retired in 1975 after IS years as assistant principal for industrial arts at Stuyvesant High School in New York City. The formal title on his patent (No. 4,010,063) is Pedagogic Thermal Pulse Sealing Apparatus.

title: Young Tells U.N. Students They Can Effect Change
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 4Andrew Young, the United States,delegate, drew on his experiences today as a lobbyist, civil rights advocate and Congressman to persuade students from the United Nations International School that teenagers can bring about changes in the world

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 4, 1977

title: CHARLES MORROW WILSON, REPORTED ON AGRICULTURE
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., March 4 (UPI)Charles Morrow Wilson, author and journalist, of Putney, Vt., died or cancer Wednesday in a hospital in Hanover. N. H. He was 71 years old.

title: National Medical Ends Becton Merger Talks
description: National Medical Care Inc. and Becton Dickinson & Company announced that they had terminated negotiations for their previously announced merger.

title: Perskie Likely to Oppose McGahn in Senate Race
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 4The principal sponsors of legislation to regulate casinos in the Senate and Assembly will  probably run against each other in the State Senate contest in Atlantic County this year.

title: Westchester Nominee
description: Gordon W. Burrows, who is serving his sixth term in the New York State Assembly, has been unanimously endorsed by Westchester County's Republican leaders as their nominee to oppose Alfred D. DelBello, the Democratic County Executive, in the November election.

title: Francie Lutz, Riddick Extend Track Reigns
description: TORONTO, March 4Fran??e Lutz. Crown her queen of the Carren indoor season. Steve Riddick Call ?? the king.

title: Amin Thanks Soviet And Cuba for Support
description: LONDON, March 4 (Reuters)President Idi Amin of Uganda met with the Soviet and Cuban envoys in Kampala today and thanked them for supporting his country, the Uganda radio said.

title: 2 Get 99Year Terms In Torture Death of Child
description: ATHENS, Tenn., March 4 (AP)Ten months after state officials returned 4yearold Melisha to them, Ronald and Wanda Gibson Maddux was sentenced to 99 years in prison for torturing the child to death.

title: 15 Persons Indicted In Check Forgeries Involving $350,000
description: An investigation called Operation. Black Light has resulted in the indictments of 15 persons charged in State Supreme Court in Manhattan with cashing stolen checks at different Citibank branches by forging a bank officer's sign. of approval on the backs of the checks.

title: Accounting Board Clarifies 2 Technical Interpretations
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the rule making organization for accounting practices, yesterday issued two technical interpretations to clarify application of its accounting standards.

title: Pillsbury Keeps Base
description: The Pillsbury Company of Minneapolis, which has been considering moving its headquarters to a suburb of the city or possibly out of Minnesota, announced that it would stay in downtown Minneapolis. The company a major flour, and food specialties company, which also operates the Burger King chain, said that it would become the prime tenant in a new 35story, $40million buildingthe Pillsbury Towerthat may be completed sometime in 1980. It estimated that construction could begin in a year.

title: Two Major Producers Lift Paperboard Prices
description: Price increases of $20 a ton on linerboard and corrugated medium paperboard, materials used mainly in shipping containers and boxes, were announced by two major producers, the forest industry division of the Continental Group Inc. and the Weyerhaeuser Company.

title: Accord by Allied Chemical And S.E.C. Reached in Suit Citing Antifraud Complaint
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission said it reached an agreement with the Allied Chemical Corporation in settlement. of a complaint charging Allied with antifraud violations under the Securities Exchange Act. S.E.C. said Allied failed to disclose potential financial losses it might suffer from discharging toxic chemicals. including Kepone, into the environment from its own and other facilities.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 4A bipartisan bill in the State Legislature that would allow the Health Department to regulate hospital costs for all patients, not only those covered by Blue Cross, will come up for a vote in committee on March 14, according to State Senator Joseph P. Merlino, Democrat of Trenton, cosponsor of the bill with Senator Barry T. Parker, Republican of Mount Holly.

title: State Dept. Not Opposed To Yanks Visiting Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI)The State Department, which has opposed the presence of American in Cuba, apparently wouldn't mind the New York Yankees playing an exhibition series in Havana.

title: Felonies in New York City in 1976 Up 13.2%, Worst Rate on Record
description: A total of 658,147 serious crimes were reported in New York City last year, making it the worst crime year for the city since the Police Department began compiling such data 45 years ago.

title: Reye's Syndrome
description: A 6yearold girl from Port Chester. N.Y., who was admitted to a New York City hospital this week has been reported to Westchester County health officials as possibly having Reye's syndrome.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reported in The Times during the last week.

title: VANCE SAYS MOSCOW STILL SEEKS DETENTE
description: WASHINGTON, March 4Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that Soviet leaders had shown a continuing deep and abiding interest in concluding further arms control and other agreements with the United States despite the strains that had arisen recently over human rights issues.

title: Minnesota Curlers Triumph
description: NORTHBROOK, III., March 4 (UPI)The undefeated Roberts rink of Minnesota captured the 21st annual men's United States curling championship tonight, defeating Wisconsin 106, in the deciding match. Minnesota won 10 games. The Somerville rink of Wisconsin finished S2.

title: International Bank Gets Offer for a Holding
description: International Bank of Washington, a diversified financial services company, said that it had received an offer for its 22.2 percent interest in Financial General Bankshares Inc. from 3. Wiliam Middendorf 2d, former Secretary of the Navy, for an investors group that he heads.

title: Britain Wonders if Takeover of Troubled Leyland Was a Step That Could Rattle Its Entire Economy
description: LONDON, March 4  Eighteen months ago, Britain nationalized its biggest automobile company, British Leyland, and saved it from likely collapse. But after spending more than $450 million, the Government is beginning to wonder now whether it made a colossal mistake whose consequences could rattle the entire economy.

title: West Germany Reports Deficit In January Payments Balance
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, March 4 (UPI)West Germany had a balance ofpayments deficit of $180 million in January, the Central Bank said today.

title: Space Salesmen
description: Many years ago a science fiction writer published a short story about how human beings might get to the moon via free enterprise financing. Moon concessions were sold to various corporations, giving one the monopoly of prospecting for diamonds. another the exclusive right to manufacture soft drinks, and so forth. With the money thus raised, the first man was sent to the moon.

title: Dave Anderson
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 4Even with a 207 wonlost record for the Baltimore Orioles last season, Wayne Garland often was confused by fans with another Oriole pitcher, floss Grimsley.

title: REPORT ON HEAD OF S.E.C. DESCRIBED AS PREMATURE
description: A source involved in the choice said last night that reports that Harold Williams, the dean of University of California's Graduate School of Management, would be nominated as the new head of the Securities and Exchange Commission were premature.

title: Spokesman Denies That H. L. Hunt Ever Communicated With Oswald
description: DALLAS, March 4 (UPI)A spokesman for the Hunt Oil Company denied today that the late billionaire, H. L. Hunt, ever knew or communicated with Lee Harvey Oswald.

title: Philadelphia Papers Return
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (UPI)The Philadelphia Inquirer and Daily News were published today for the first time in more than three weeks. About 800 news and business employees struck the newspapers last Feb. 8. The strike ended Wednesday night when members of Local 10 of the Newspaper Guild approved new 31month contract with the Philadelphia Newspapers Inc.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 5, 1977

title: William Miller, 64, TaxLaw Specialist, Is Dead in Princeton
description: William Miller. a lawyer specializing in government tax policy, died yesterday at the Princeton Medical Center after long illness. He was G4 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: COL. MAURICE FITZGERALD, ARMY AND POLICE OFFICER
description: Col. Maurice J. Fitzgerald, a retired Army and police officer, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital of injuries sustained in a fall on a subway station plattorm on Feb, 15. He was 76 years old and lived at 156 East 79th Street.

title: People in Sports
description: Mike Schmidt, the Phillies' third baseman who led the major leagues in home runs with 38 last season, signed a sixyear contract yesterday with the Philadelphia club in Clearwater, Fla. Schmidt refused to give the exact p??ce of the pact, but answered yes when asked whether it was in the vicinity of the $2 million reportedly sought by his agent.

title: Trudeau Asks for Report On Bias of State Network
description: OTTAWA, March 4Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau today asked the national regulatory body for broadcasting to investigate charges that members of the Frenchlanguage news staff and other personnel of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, the governmentowned network, have shown a bias in favor of independence for Quebec.

title: 2 Suspects Booked In Lewisboro Deaths
description: 2 Suspects Booked In Lewisboro DeathsLEWISBORO. N. Y., March 4Three men who made no effort to escape or avoid detection after being linked to the murders of two mothers in this northern Westchester community were arrested yesterday in Norwalk. Conn., and arraigned today in Stamford.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Kennedy, Out of the Limelight, Is Content in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 4When Jimmy Carter was elected President four months ago. the pressures on Edward M. Kennedy for nearly a decade to follow two of his brothers and seek the nation's highest office seemed to disappear.

title: Nun Cleared of Charge She Killed Newborn Son
description: Sister Maureen Murphy, a Roman Catholic nun, was cleared today in Rochester in the death of her newborn son last April. Judge Hyman Maas in Monroe County Court found the 37yearold defendant not guilty of the original firstdegree manslaughter charge, as well as of the seconddegree manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide counts suggested by the prosecutor.

title: Giscard Calls Carter on Concorde
description: PARIS, March 4President Valry Giscard d'Estaing has personally joined a French campaign to try to win landing rights for the supersonic jetliner Concorde in New York by making a telephone appeal to President Carter.

title: No Schools Is No Solution
