description: Some years ago, there was a budding movement to keep schools open all year, thus using costly facilities to the maximum. For a variety of reasons. including opposition by the summer travel and recreation industries, the proposal faltered. We recall it now only because the New York State Board of Regents seems on the way toward the opposite extremesaving money by closing the schools rather than by keeping them open.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in orcer of post nositioss letter ?? OTB ??

title: Albrecht Is Dismissed
description: ST. LOUIS, March 4 (UPI)Randy Albrecht was dismissed today as head basketball coach at St. Louis University. The 33yearold Albrecht had been associated withthe university for 14 years as player, assistant coach and coach. He was in the third year of a fouryear contract The Billikens wonlost records in his years as coach were 1214, 1314 and 719.

title: Boy, 14, Abducts Officers
description: KINGSVILLE, Tex., March 4 (UPI)A 14yearold boy abducted two policemen today, forced them at gunpoint to drive eight miles to Bishop, and escaped into a mesquite thicket. The youth then returned to Kingsville and surrendered to the police. The boy, identified as Rolando Ramirez had escaped in November from the Gatesville reformatory. Sheriff Jim Scarborough of Kleberg County, said the boy had called the police for help in Kingsville this morning. When Officer James Phipps entered the house, the boy, holding a .38caliber pistol, forced the officer to surrender his gun. He then told Officer Phipps and his partner to take him to Bishop.

title: What Is This Slander?
description: In the Soviet Union persons are prosecuted not for their opinions but only for concrete acts. This bit of hypocrisy is now regularly used to justify political repressions. This statement says: You may hold any opinion you wish, if you keep silent; express your opinion in any form, and you can be put behind bars.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: BAfter $191.000 tax credit. CNet loss after $900,000 provision for estimated loss on discontinued operation.

title: Happy Reunion WithDaughter Ends Father's 30Year Search
description: As an engineer in the Merchant Marine, 57yearold John I.ee Johnson had traveled the world several times.

title: Carter Walking in Predecessors Footsteps
description: WASHINGTON, March 4At a White House banquet for the nation's governors this week, President Carter opened a brief talk with the offhand jest, We Washington insiders want to give you a hearty welcome. It was intended as a bit of banter, spoofing the switch from his former role as an outsider and Governor of Georgia. But it coincided with signs that, in spite of his desire for a fresh image and a new style in the White House, Mr. Carter is finding it difficult at times to avoid the patterns of previous Presidents or some of the inescapable realities of the Presidency.

title: Rockwell to Move Unit
description: The Rockwell International Corporation of St. Louis announced that it would move its Sabreliner division, a manufacturer of business jet aircraft, from Los Angeles to St. Louis.

title: In Memorian
description: I DRAKEJohn E.. on M?? ?? Your love and happiness ?? ?? us stunned but the true ?? of ?? post Will long 110 ?? ?? miss you mough may ?? ?? rest in peace. Ted ?? ??

title: NET MUTUAL FUND SALES AT 141 MILLION IN JANUARY
description: Net sales of mutual fund shares in January were the largest since January 1975, as sales exceeded redemptions by $141 million, compared with December's excess of only $33 million, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Rice Sale to Syria Gets Financing
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI)The Agriculture Department announced today an agreement to finance the sale of $15 million worth of American rice and tobacco to Syria under the longterm easycredit provisions of the Food for Peace program.

title: Kennedy, Out of the Limelight, Is Content in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 4When Jimmy Carter was elected President four months ago, the pressures on Edward M. Kennedy for nearly a decade to follow two of his brothers and seek the nation's highest office seemed to disappear.

title: Personal Investing
description: While A.T.&T. climbs on the strength of its affilates' prosperity, the market continues to price the stock of the affiliates below A.T.&T. levels, creating the possibility of some bargain hunting for investors. Page 26.

title: Koch Joins the Mayoral Contest; Questions Beame's Competence
description: Representative Edward I. Koch announced his candidacy for the Demo9ratic mayoral nomination yesterday, declaring that New York City may be facing its darkest hourthe continued threat of bankruptcy, the loss of more than more jobs and the steadily increasing crime rate.

title: Odometer Fraud Punished
description: A Long Island usedcar dealership has been fined $25,000 for rolling back the mileage on odometers. Judge Richard Delin of Nassau County Court also imposed a $10,000 fine on the concern's president, Edward Rosenstock, 62 years old, of 3 Linden Boulevard, Great Neck, L. I.

title: NEW DUST BOWL PERIL RAISED IN WHEAT BELT
description: NORTH PLATTE, Neb., March 3In the great sweep of the High Plains from here southward to the old dust bowl areas, thousands of acres of range and crop land are so dry today and the cover on them is so sparse that they are on the verge of destruction by the wind.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 5, 1977

title: UNIONS ALSO OPPOSED
description: The major New York City banks. in a longawaited counterproposal on the future structure of city finances, urged yesterday the formation of a new statedominated Budget Review Board, with sweeping powers over city budgets, a suggestion that was swiftly rejected by Mayor Beame.

title: Jupiter Spacecraft Named Voyager
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)Two Spacecraft Scheduled to be launched this summer on journeys to Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and possibly Neptune will be called Voyager 1 and 2, the space agency said yesterday. Voyager 1 is scheduled to ??eave Cape Canaveral, Fla., Aug. 20 and Voyager 2 on Sept. 1.

title: Looking Cheerful and Stylish on a Rainy Day
description: After the cold and the snow came the deluge. Yesterday's downpour, actually a preview of the first spring shower, brought a swift change from arctic to rain gear.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: PITTSBURGHThe place of poetry in American life is, to put it charitably, peripheral. Granted, poetry is published regularly. Granted also that poets haVe campus posts or, like Robert Frost and James Dickey, are invited to speak on state occasions. Granted as well that 125 forums exist (exclusive of universities and colleges) where poets can recite to audiences. Still, poetry is not the livedwith art that pubtalk is to the Irish, music to the Italians, and Oriental rugs, tapestries and handcrafts to the Persians and Arabs.

title: Consumer Debt In January Had 3d Biggest Rise
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI)Consumers increased their debts by S1.92 billion in January, the third largest monthly increase, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: EXCHANGE TRADING IN PUTS ON 5 STOCKS APPROVED BY S.E.C
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today its longanticipated formal approval of exchange trading in put options, which it said could begin June on five stocks.

title: Market Is Cheered by Money Report And Dow Advances 4.82 to 953.46
description: The stock market, encouraged by a decline in the nation's basic money supply and other factors, ground out small but steady gains yesterday.

title: Woman Is Acquitted Of Killing
description: SALINAS, Calif., March 4 (AP)Inez Garcia, who killed a man she said helped rape her and became a feminist symbol of a woman's right to selfdefense, was acquitted today of seconddegree murder after a retrial.

title: Pear and Stress in the Police Departmen
description: The acquittal last week of Officer William L. Walker by an allwhite jury in Brooklyn of charges that he murdered a young black man named John Brabham would be troubling in any event. Unfortunately, in context the Walker case is even more disturbing. Over the past four years, three other blacksClifford Glover, Claude Reese Jr. and Randolph Evanshave been shot and killed by white police officers in New York in circumstances that have frightened and enraged residents of black communities and have troubled thoughtful citizens everywhere.

title: Kirby Block Marketing Closes After 60 Years
description: The Kirby Block Marketing Company, one of New York's oldest resident buying offices, terminated its business on Thursday after 60 years of operation.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Dorati Leads Variety By Richard Strauss
description: Music by Richard Strauss was the subject of the National Symphony Orchestra's concert et Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. With Antal Dorati conducting. use von Alpenheim as soloist in the Burleske for Piano and Orchestra, and Evelyn Lear an hand to sing the final scene from Capriccio, there was no lack of capable talent to present a varied sampling of Strauss' musical output. The program also included Strauss' first significant work, the Serenade in E flat for 13 Wind Instruments, and one of his autobiographical tone poems, Ein Heldenlehen.

title: Despite Low Budget,Bryant Five Is Rich in Talent for the Playoffs
description: Lou Hacker says his Bryant basketball team has been operating on a broken shoestring this season, but that hasn't stopped the Owls from gaining a semifinal berth in the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs. Bry

title: PURPORTED RAY LETTER HINTS HE WILL TESTIFY
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)The House Assassinations Committee has a letter, purportedly from James Earl Ray, indicating he is willing to discuss testifying on the slaying of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: HighPowered Spurs Trounce Nets, 135121
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 4The New York Nets ran into the San Antonio Spurs, the National Basketball Association's best offensive team, on one of their good shooting nights tonight and the result was a predictable 135121 defeat.

title: Playboy HotelCasino
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. plans to build a 660room $50 million casinohotel on the Boardwalk adjacent to Atlantic City's Convention Hall. Playboy is the second major hotel concern to announce an investment in the city since Nov. 2, when New Jersey voters approved casino gambling for the resort.

title: Municipal Unions Expect Intervention By Albany or U.S.
description: The municipal labor unions, locked a seemingly irreconcilable clash with the city's banks over solving New York's money problems, believe that the current crisis will be solved next week through intervention by Albany or Washington, if necessary, and that it will not end in the unions caving in or in default.

title: Automatic Dialer Used With Conventional Phone
description: An automatic telephone dialer, patented this week by Cheng Shio of Flushing, Queens, is designed to be operated with a conventional telephone of either the rotary or pushbutton type. Mr. Shio, an electrical engineer. said the other day that plans for production were under way.

title: Mondale Opposes C.I.A. Director On Criminal Penalties for Leaks
description: WASHINGTON. March 4 (AP)Vice President Mondale, disagreeing with the newly named head of the Central Intelligence Agency, told an interviewer that he is personally opposed to imposing criminal penalties on Government officials who permit intelligence secrets to become public.

title: Talking Heads Rock Band Becomes Fine Quartet
description: Talking Heads's current run at CBGB's (which began Thursday and ends tonight) is of special interest because it represents the first performances of the rock band in its new quartet configuration. Heretofore, David Byrne (singer, guitarist and songwriter), Tina Weymouth (bass) and Chris Frantz (drums) have either gone it alone or jammed, occasionally, with others. Principal jammee was Jerry Harrison, the exModern Lover who plays keyboards, guitar and percussion. Talking Heads had been trying to persuade Mr. Harrison to come down from Boston and join them formally, and now he has done so.

title: Carter Rights Stand Worries Europe
description: BONN, March 4President Carter's open support of dissidents in the Soviet Union is beginning to cause nervousness in Western Europe as a result of Moscow's increasingly bitter reactions.

title: 24 Indicted in Case Involving the Sale Of Mexican Heroin
description: Twentytwo men and two women were charged yesterday with participating in a major narcotics conspiracy in which 1,500 pounds of Mexican heroin with a wholesale price of $33 million was allegedly sold in New York City.

title: Soviet Union Duo Takes World Ice Dance Title
description: TOKYO, March 4 (AP)Irina Moiseyeva and Andrei Minenkov of the Soviet Union regained the ice dancing title tonight at the world figure skating championships. The Russian pair, champion in 1975 and runnerup last year, was the unanimous choice of the judges for first place after an elegant and theatrical freeskating program, receiving nine ordinals and 207.82 points.

title: Predicted Order of Finish in IC4A Track
DISCRIMINATION CURB IS VOTED IN RHODESIA
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 4A vote switch by three black members of parliament today gave the white minority Government of Rhodesia the twothirds majority it needed to win passage of its bill curbing racial discrimination, a cornerstone of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's bid for a political settlement with this nation's 6.3 million blacks.

title: Improved Radial Tire Developed by Goodrich
description: DETROIT, March 4 (Reuters)The B. F. Goodrich Company announced had developed a new radial passenger tire that never goes completely flat and could eliminate the need for a snare.

title: Princeton Five Wins, Clinching an Ivy Tie
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 4Princeton played mediocre basketball for 20 minutes tonight and looked more like a team in the lower half of the Ivy League than the team that is now just 24 hours from its second straight Ivy championship.

title: Lean Days In the Rage Market
description: You can tell things are bad. Hardly anybody has time or money to enjoy a good rage any more.

title: Report Indicates Violation Of Probation by Agnew
description: BALTIMORE, March 4 (AP)A Justice Department report indicates that former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew violated his probation at least once, and a hearing has been set for March 14. However, the report recommended that no action be taken against Mr. Agnew. Federal District Judge Roszel Thomsen released the re. port yesterday.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: About 1,100 pounds of marijuana and $50.000 in cash were seized by a Federal, county and local task force in a drug raid at a house at 438 Briarwood Lane. Northvale, in Bergen County. Arrested was the occupant, 33yearold Raul Reyes, who authorities said was a key figure in a marijuanaselling ring that netted at least $50,000 a month in Bergen.

title: Administration Steps Up InvestmentCredit Drive
description: WASHINGTON, March 4President Carter's chief economic spokesmen stepped up their campaign today for the higher investment tax credit that the House Ways and Means Committee wants removed from the Carter package of economic stimulus.

title: Auto Workers Strike at Chrysler
description: DETROIT, March 4 (AP)Some 2,500 workers from United Automobile Workers Local 7 walked off their jobs at the Chrysler Corporation Jefferson Avenue assembly plant today in a dispute over local issues. No negotiations were scheduled. the company said.

title: Revitalizing the Northeast
description: Has the Northeast had it? There is a group of economists that think so.

title: Choreography By Grossman Is Successful
description: The athletic exuberance that makes Danny Williams Grossman's dancing such a pleasure to watch characterizes his choreography as well. Mr. Grossman showed a gymnastically graceful duet to audiences in the Delacorte Theater last summer that was tantalizing. And he brought his full company to the American Theater Laboratory on Thursday evening for his official debut as choreographer. The company and program proved very good.

title: Giscard Calls Carter on Concorde
description: PARIS, March 4President Valry Giscard d'Estaing has personally joined French campaign to try to win landing rights for the supersonic jetliner Concorde in New York by making a telephone appeal to President Carter.

title: Idaho Finds Famed No. 1 Potatoes Are Substandard in Idaho Stores
description: BOISE, Idaho, March 4Where does an Idaho housewife go for Idaho U. S. No. 1 potatoes? Not to an Idaho store, according to the state's attorney general, Wayne Kidwell.

title: Camera to Seek Missing Miners; Rescuers Near Trapped Survivor
description: TOWER CITY, Pa., March 4Tired miners, tunneling inch by inch, came within about 20 feet tonight of rescuing Ronald Adley, the remaining known survivor of a sudden coal mine inundation on Tuesday that killed two men and iniured three.

title: The Bankers' Tough Terms
description: The tough terms that the major New York City banks have submitted to the Mayor for solving the city's present, and chronic, fiscal crisis is based on the proposition that they, as professional financiers and marketers of debt, know what it will take to sell the city's securities to the market out thereespecially the market west of the Hudson. But some city officials and union leaders insist that the banks are not simply interpreters of what the market is saying, but that they themselves are a powerful force in the market and that the stringent terms they are proposing are in their own interests as well as those of potential purchasers of city securities.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SCALE & SCENE Two prominent chamber ensembles in classical music are performing this weekend in picturesque settingsone a venerable church in Greenwich Village and the other a beautiful Upper East Side home.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: I got away . ... the man says.

title: A Revealing Report Card for the City
description: While most city officials were worrying about the city's search for another $1 billion to meet a court deadline on paying off pastdue notes. Mayor Beame devoted the major part of his annual State of the City Message this week so the management of city government. Relying on a report prepared by his Management Advisory Board. the Mayor stressed that most of his agencies are approaching or meeting the performance goals they set for themselves; it remains for us to stress the problems that lie between the lines.

title: Chinese Promote Officials While Deriding Others
description: HONG KONG, March 4 (UPI)The Chinese Government has named three new provincial leaders and has paraded disgraced officials before jeering crowds in a continuing campaign to expose backers of the socalled gang of four.

title: Mexican Army Restores Order in Oaxaca State
description: OAXACA, Mexico, March 4 (AP)The army has restored order in the southern Mexican state of Oaxaca after 10 days of clashes between policemen and demonstrating students, and landless Indians in which at least 16 persons were killed.

title: Teen Pregnancies Found Rising at Record Pace
description: CHICAGO, March 4 (AP)Pregnancies among teenage and preteen girls are Increasing at record rates, according to the National Alliance Concerned With SchoolAce Parents.

title: Scientists Achieve Fusion Reaction With Carbon Dioxide Laser System
description: What had been thought a serious handicap in the use of gas lasers to release energy from the fusion of hydrogen atoms appears to have been eliminated.

title: STATE COST BACKS I.T.T. SETTLEMENT
description: Six shareholder suits against 22 present and former directors of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation as well as five other defendants, including Mediobanca of Italy, were settled yesterday for $3.2 million. The funds will go to I.T.T.

title: Holzman To Retire?
description: The Knicks have called a news conference at noon today to discuss the coaching situation.

title: CONVICTION OF PAPER IS UPHELD IN VIRGINIA
description: RICHMOND, March 4The Virginia Supreme Court today upheld by a 6to1 vote the criminal conviction of a Norfolk newspaper corporation for publishing an article about a state investigation into the conduct of a juvenile court judge.

title: The Muse Finds a Home at I.S. 162 in the Bronx
description: The classroom was as quiet as a church during services and in the back sat Reggie Brooks, keeping as cool as an eighthgrader can when the teacher is reading his work aloud.

title: About NewYork
description: The woman came to know the clenched fist of the beloved. And soon after, she concluded that the court system could be as fragile as love. All she wants now is physical protection, she says, from this man, her husband.

title: Miss Cueto Refuses To Talk on FALN Before Grand Jury
description: Maria T. Cueto. director of the National Commission of Hispanic Affairs for the Protestant Episcopal Church, refused to answer a Federal grand jury's questions yesterday concerning a Puerto Rican terrorist group known as the FALN.

title: Stagey Sex in Sandstone
description: Sandstone is supposed to he a documentary about new styles of sexual relationships. Instead, it conies across as a commercial for them and for the Southern California establishment  more resort than commune, it appears. where the relationsips are conducted.

title: Zender, With 67136, Leads Golf by a Shot
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 4 (AP)Bob Zender, who was a Chicago stock broker before he joined the pro golf tour six years ago, shot a fiveunderpar 67 today and took a onestroke lead after the second round of the $200,000 Florida Citrus open golf tournament.

title: Giants' Clyde Powers Misses a Special Friend
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 4In the finished basement of Giants Stadium, where the National Football League's bestpampered 311 team plays, Clyde Powers was driving golf balls, talking about printing and feeling sorry that he was not working with handicapped children.

title: Busing Postponed in Plan For Integration on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, March 4 (AP)The nation's second largest school system, a 710squaremile district with white students in the minority, has adopted an integration plan that postpones mandatory busing for a year.

title: McCree. Is Confirmed as Solicitor General
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)The Senate confirmed today President Carter's nomination of Judge Wade H. McCree of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit to be Solicitor General, the No. 3 post in the Justice Department. He will be the highestranking black in the department.

title: 12 Hurt in San Francisco Fire
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 4 (UPI)A fivealarm fireits flames spiraling 50 feet highengulfed a downtown office building last night, injuring 12 firemen and causing at least $400,000 damage.

title: VANCE SAYS MOSCOW STILL SEEKS DETENTE
description: WASHINGTON, March 4Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that Soviet leaders had shown a continuing deep and abiding interest in concluding further arms control and other agreements with the United States despite the strains that had arisen recently over human rights issues.

title: WHITE HOUSE DEFINES ROLE IN PROSECUTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, March 4A White would make the decision whether to prosecute and the White House would make the decision on which documents could be introduced as evidence in open court House spokesman said today that if situation arose in which a criminal prosecution required declassification of sensitive documents, the Attorney. General

title: Hundreds Reported Killed By Earthquake in Rumania
description: A strong earthquake centered north of Bucharest, Rumania, rocked Southern and Eastern Europe last night, shaking buildings from Rome to Moscow.

title: DR. JOSEPH H. FARROW, 73; RAN CANCER HOSPITAL UNIT
description: Dr. Joseph Helms Farrow, former chief of the breast service of Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, died yesterday. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Two Hotels in Los Angeles: Contrast in Fresh Attempts
description: LOS ANGELESThere are two hotels in the downtown section here that have been causing a lot of talk lately. One has a lot of cool white walls, Jim Dine prints and furniture by Mies van de Rohe. The other is full of plush materials and nooks and crannies with upholstered banquettes. One hotel was opened last month and the other in 1923. It is the old hotel, the Biltmore, that has the white walls and Mies chairs, and it is the new one, the Bonaventure, that has the nooks and crannies. The Biltmore is in the midst of a $16.9 million renovation by its architectowners, Phyllis Lambert and Gene Summers. The Bonaventure is the latest in the series of hotels that the architect John Portman has put in cities around the country. The comparison is fascinatingeach hotel is a gesture of faith in downtown Los Angeles, a section of this sprawling city that is almost, but not quite, irrelevant, and each hotel represents an attempt to break free in one way or another from the stereotype of the new American hotel.

title: Harvard's 400 Relay Sets Swimming Mark
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., March 4Led by a record performance by its 400yard medley relay team, Harvard jumped to a surprising 23point lead over Princeton, the defending champion, at the start of the annual Eastern Seaboard intercollegiate swimming championships yesterday.

title: Mary Hurlimann Wed To John C. Armstrong
description: Mary Helen Hurlimann of Greenwich, Conn., widow of Conrad G. Hurlimann, a former vice president of the CibaGeigy Company, was married in Greenwich yesterday to John C. Armstrong, a widower, of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Greensboro, Vt. The Rev. Richard Van Werly performed the ceremony in St. Barnabas Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Thomas Stiers of the First Congregational Church of Old Greenwich.

title: Deaths
description: ARBEITReba. Beloved wife of the late Herman Arbeit, devoted mother of Lillian B. Enzler and Dr. Stanley Arbeit. Cherished grandmother of Ellen R. and Barry W. Ender and, Judith A. and Holly S. Arbeit. Services Sunday. 12:45 at The Riverside 1250 Central Ave. Far Rock away, N.Y.

title: SUPREME COURT SET TO MOVE ON NEWARK
description: NEWARK, March 4The New Jersey Supreme Court is preparing an opinion that could lead to the jailing of five Newark City Councilmen for their refusal to vote the necessary funds for revaluation of property in this city.

title: Federal Paper Reaches an Accord To Sell Glass Unit to Lancaster
description: The Federal Paper Board Company of Montvale, N.J., announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell its glassware division to the Lancaster Colony Corporation. Federal said that proceeds from the sale would amount to $45 million including a $9.8 million sixyear note.

title: Prisoner Escapes From Police Van
description: A 31yearold prisoner en route in police van to the 20th Precinct station house on the Upper West Side escaped last night, apparently by slipping his hand through a handcuff, the police reported. The prisoner, Robert Sarosick of 18,1 Bay Avenue in Dover, N. J., was under arrest for allegedly houlding 12 people at gunpoint for 10 minutes Thursday night inside the heliport atop the Pan Am Building. No one was inqured in the incident.

title: THAIS AND MALAYS SIGN BORDER ACCORD
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 4Thailand and Malaysia signed a joint border agreement today, the first bilateral defense pact in Southeast Asia since the end of the Indochina war two years ago.

title: Belle Helene By City Opera Shows Charm
description: If French opera is difficult to transplant outside of a French milieu, then French operetta is all the more difficult. Offenbach's La Belle Hlne, which is back in the New York City Opera repertory after a hastily prepared premiere last fall, does not captivate with the same heady fragrance might be expected to exert in a properly tacky Parisian theater. The New York State Theater is too big, and the English language slightly incongruous.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: 2 Suspects Booked In Lewisboro Deaths
description: LEWISBORO, N. Y., March 4Three men who made no effort to escape or avoid detection after being linked to the murder of two mothers in this northern Westchester community were arrested yesterday in Norwalk, Conn., and arraigned today in Stamford.

title: Leningrad Symphony Makes Local Debut
description: It was an evening of about 100 percent humidityjust great for violinists and visiting orchestras. But the Leningrad Symphony Orchestranot to be confused with the Leningrad Philharmonicput its best face on the situation in its New York debut last night in Carnegie Hall.

title: Carter Rights Stand Worries Europe
description: BONN, March 4President Carter's open support of dissidents in the Soviet Union is beginning to cause nervousness in Western Europe as a result of Moscow's increasingly bitter reactions.

title: Municipal Unions Expect Intervention By Albany or U.S.
description: The municipal labor unions, locked a seemingly irreconcilable clash with the city's banks over solving New York's money problems, believe that the current crisis will be solved next week through intervention by Albany or Washington, if necessary, and that it will not end in the unions' caving in or in default.

title: Hofstra Routs Temple, Plays La Salle in Final
description: EASTON, Pa., March 4Rich Laurel did not shoot like the nation's fourth leading scorer tonight, but John Irving picked up the offensive slack with 21 points to lead Hofstra to a 7158 victory over Temple in the semifinal round of the East Coast Conference playoffs at Lafayette College's Kirby Field House.

title: Phelds Dodge Lifts Prices
description: The Phelps Dodge Brass Company announced further selective price adjustments on copper water tube in line with recent industry pricing actions. The price for sizes up to 2 inches will be increased 2 percent over March 1 price levels. Drainage and Waste tube (DWV) will be increased by 4 percent, while red brass and copper pipe will remain at previously announced levels.

title: Du Pont Trims Increase
description: The E. I. du Pont de Nemours Company Inc. said it is revising downward a 2centsapound increase announced earlier this week on its domestic prices for antiknock compounds to an increase of 0.8 cents a pound.

title: Books of The Times
description: All sorts of ironies are implicit in the title of this work. Gable was the reigning male star at MetroGoldwynMayer Inc., the preeminent Hollywood film factory, for nearly 20 years. In the late 1930's he was receiving an annual salary of $300,000, worth five times that much in today's dollars, and the intensity of the adulation he inspired in movie audiences in those comparatively innocent times can scarcely be imagined nowadays.

title: JAN FRYLING
description: Jan Fryling. Minister to China for the Polish Government in Exile in London from 1943 to 1945, died Wednesday night in Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness. He lived at 246 West End Avenue.and was 86 years old.

title: Congress Is Urged By Carter to Ease Airline Regulatior
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)President Carter called today for reduced Federal control over the airline industry, a move he said could lower airplane fares and increase competition by this summer.

title: DRIVE IS ON TO BLOCK
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The first Congressional test of the emerging foreign policy of the Carter Administration opened today as some senators from both parties began an attempt to block confirmation of Paul C. Warnke as the President's disarmament director and negotiator.

title: Threatened by Weather, Wheat Draws Spotlight From Soybean Futures
description: Wheat futures replaced those of soybeans as the main attraction on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as prices of grain rose sharply while soybeans fell.

title: PRAGUE INTENSIFIES DRIVE ON DISSIDENTS
description: VIENNA. March 4Czechoslovak authorities have steeped up pressure in the last few days against the humanrights activists of the Charter 77 group and against Western reporters attempting to talk with them, according to information reaching here.

title: Soviet Starts Furor in Italy Over Art Show
description: ROME, March 4The Soviet Union has generated a furor here by officially intervening to try to prevent the organizers of a major arts festival from devoting this year's show to dissidents in Eastern Europe.

title: A Policy of No Divorces Stirs a Campus Ferment
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., March 4  California Baptist College has adopted a policy barring divorced persons and those married to such persons from serving on its faculty or administration, because, campus officials said, these people set a bad example for students.

title: Salesman Given in Stamford
description: STAMFORD, Conn.Death or a Salesman, a domestic drama dealing with characters no larger than life and using everyday language, has within it the seeds or banality. In order to retain its tragic dimensions, the play demands sizable acting and an authoritative production. Del Tenney's production at the Hartman Theater Company is, at best, passable.

description: Following are highlights of the nine point proposal yesterday by the major New York City banks for new fiscal controls to serve as the terms of new city bond issue:

title: Canada and U.S. Concur on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, March 4In an atmosphere of unusual warmth, the Canadian and American energy chiefs ended two days of talks today and announced they were working closely on oil and gas pipeline projects and on solar energy research.

title: AL ABRAMS DEAD AT 73; SPORTS EDITOR, WRITER
description: PITTSBURGH, March 4Al Abrams. sports editor of The Pittsburgh PostGazette from 1947 to 1974, died in a hospital last night after having suffered a heart attack in his apartment at the Carlton House Hotel. He was 73 years old.

title: MasseyFerguson in Deal
description: MasseyFerguson of Toronto said that its Perkins Engines division had entered a supply agreement with Toyo Kogyo, Japan's third largest automobile manufacturer, under which the Japanese company will build sixcylinder Perkins diesel engines for worldwide marketing by Perkins. Toyo Kogyo, which has headquarters in Hiroshima, also makes trucks and rotary engines. Details were not announced.

title: Seger, Rush, Starz Postpone Concert
description: The rock concert of Bob Seger, Rush and Starz, scheduled for tomorrow night at the Palladium, has been postponed until March 17. Ed (Punch) Andrews, Mr. Seger's manager, said he had decided yesterday that the group had not had sufficient time to rehearse substitute drummer since the group's drummer had been injured in an accident.

title: Soviet Links Dissidents to C.I.A.; Arrests Expected
description: MOSCOW, March 4The Government newspaper Izvestia today accused several leading dissidents, all of them Jews, of working for the Central Intelligence Agency. Tonight, according to Jewish sources, apartments of several of the dissidents were being searched and some of them believed that arrests were imminent.

title: UNIONS ALSO OPPOSED
description: The major New York City banks, in a longawaited counterproposal on the future structure of city finances, urged yesterday the formation of a new statedominated Budget Review Board, with sweeping powers over city budgets, suggestion that was swiftly rejected by Mayor Beame.

title: JOBLESS RISE SLIGHT IN SPITE OF THE COLD
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The bitterly cold weather in February had less impact on the economy than had been feared. Carter Administration officials said today after the Labor Department reported that the unemployment rate rose only slightly last month.

title: I.M.F. Auction Raises Gold to 16Month Peak; Dollar Finishes Mixed
description: LONDON, March 4 (AP)Gold jumped store than $1 an ounce today to close at a 16month high of $146 following Wednesday's Washington gold auction. The dollar's performance was mixed.

title: Teachers in Greenwich End Strike
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 4Six hundred striking Greenwich teachers returned to work today, while union leaders and the Board of Education met to begin negotiations on their stillunresolved dispute. An additional 100 teachers and 16 school principals did not join the walkout.

title: Personal Investing
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, thanks to the rising profitability of its 21 operating subsidiaries, is prospering mightily.

description: The Singer Company announced yesterday that its own audit committee had found that the company made numerous questionable payments to officials of foreign countries since January 1971, including payments of $1.5 million to procure business in five operations abroad.

title: Bankruptcy Judge Orders Closing Of French and Polyclinic Center
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge yesterday ordered the closing by June 5 of the debtridden French and Polyclinic Medical School and Health Center at 330 West 30th Street.

title: OIL COMPANIES SLOW F.T.C. BREAKUP SUIT
description: In a somewhat ironic development, a group of oil companies has succeeded in slowing a Federal Trade Commission move to break them up by citing environmental considerations.

title: Japan Rightists Again Use Force In Effort to Recapture Past Glory
description: TOKYO, March 4The seizure by Japanese rightists of an office building here has again focused international attention on this country's unique rightist political extremists, the small bands of militants with powerful ideologies and visions of an older Japan in which strongwilled warriors fought to the death or killed themselves over honor. The incident was, too, a measure of the changes that have crept across Japan in recent times.

title: Cauthen Ends a 13Race Slump, Then Piles Up 7 Straight Losers
description: Steve Cauthen's 13race riding slump ended not a race too soon at Aqueduct yesterday when the 16yearold steered home Make Our Move in the first race.

title: Soviet Rebuffs U.S. on Requests For Data on Hazard at Embassy
description: MOSCOW, March 4A State Department medical team reported today that Soviet health authorities had twice refused to provide basic data requested for an investigation into unusual blood counts found among American Embassy personnel here.

title: An Agency to Assist Harlem Businesses Formed by CORE
description: William Perry runs a wholesale clothing business on East 125th Street and has been a businessman in Harlem for 12 years. In that time, he has by his own count been burglarized or robbed at least 10 times.

title: U.S. Checking Transfers Of Exported Nuclear Fuel For Plutonium Conversion
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The State Department is examining transfers of spent nuclear fuel from three countries to France and Britain for reprocessing into plutonium to see if they run counter to the nuclear policy of the United States, a State Department official said today.

title: Who Calls The Kettle Black?
description: BRUSSELSIt is fortunate that the Soviet Government is relatively accustomed to being called conscienceless and therefore has no evident feelings of embarrassment about its present position on the issues of dtente. While arming to the teeth in a process that has accelerated rather than lessened since the socalled cold war ended, Moscow accuses the West of feverish militarist preparations.

title: Track Gets Approval
description: The promoters of the Sawmill Brook Race Course won environmental approval today for a proposed thoroughbred and harness racing track in Middletown, south of Hartford on the Connecticut River.

description: To the Editor:

title: Toy Train Transformers Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP)Three electric toy train transformers have been ordered recalled, the Consumer Product Safety Comm??sion said today. Involved arc the Marklin miniclub transformer model 6727, the Marklin transformer model 6153 and the Marklin transformer model 6667. Models 6727 and 6153 contain improperly soldered connections and model 6667 failed to meet impact tests, officials said. No injuries were reported.

title: Beryl Janoff Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Janoff of Rego Park, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Beryl Janoff, to Richard L. Greenfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Greenfeld of Brooklyn. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Jonathan Hunt Weds Laurie H. Jennings
description: Laurie Haven Jennings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Joseph Jennings Jr., of Rochester. Mich., was married yesterday in Rochester to Jonathan Adams Hum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Wesley Hunt of Weston. Mass. The Rev. William Berkampas performed the ceremony in the Paint Creek Methodist Church.

description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Dance: FullLength Richardson
description: Larry Richardson and his Dance Company are currently giving a season at The Dance Gallery at 242 East 14th Street. Mr. Richardson is unusual among modern dancers in that currently lie is concentrating on fullevening works. Hit present season consists of three of them, The Heart's Rialto, Kin and Earth, which is having its world premiere this season.

title: Westchester Board Investigates Negotiations on Waste Disposal
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 5Westchester County's Republicancontrolled Board of Legislators has opened an inquiry that could have major political implications into the collapse of negotiations led by Alfred B. DelBello, the County Executive and a Democrat, on a key phase of the county's solidwaste disposal program.

title: Joint Custody: Victory for A11?
description: I WOULDN'T exactly say it's sweeping the country. Or that as an idea it has fired the imaginations of the divorce judiciary or members of the bar who practice matrimonial law. Most judges, in fact, favor traditionally neat, uncomplicated solutions to family problems and wish they had never heard of it. But I think joint custody is, and should be, here to stay.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market, aided more by encouraging economic news than by aggressive buying, scored solid advance last week that contrasted with its more typical weakness so far in 1977.

title: Disintegration of the Community of East Africa
description: The latest excesses by Uganda's President Idi Amin have further damaged the tottering East African Community, whose member states, Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania, are already divided by economic confrontation, personal abuse and ideological differences.

title: Human Rights: The Rest of the World Sees Them Differently
description: WASHINGTONIn a sense, President Carter's espousal of human rights reflects a peculiarly Western concern. most parts of the world, outside North America and Western Europe, there is no tradition of political freedom. Moreover, modern technology has given autocrats an unparalleled ability to direct, control and discipline their people.

title: Witches and Werewolves
description: Wolfman Jack, the feralvoiced DJ on AM radio, peddles a product sworn to cure teenage skin of blackheads and pimplesthe woeful stigma of glandular change. But what do you do, Jack, if you develop fangs, fur and a surplus of nipples? You don't go to the Harvest Moon Ball, that's for sure. Precisely the problem Lisa Kane faces in a new novel I ISA KANE (BobbsMerrill, $7.95.) by Richard A. Lupoff. Lisa, just a regular gal most of the time sipping sodas, gossiping with friends, stuck on some guynotices that her body is undergoing dramatic changes. Always a delicate matter, she gingerly broaches the topic with her father (with whom she lives alone), only to learn that her monthly complaint will shortly include running with the pack and baying at the moon. So this is what they mean by identity crisis . . what to do? She passes up the dance and turns to scholarly tracts. She even attends an academic conference at Berkeley where the matter is freely discussed. While she is there she learns she is only one of many closet werewolves, all of them swell people. They all go for and de cide hairy is heavenly. In short, they come out. Eureka! A new minority group.

title: A Local Paper Slighted Carter As a Candidate
description: OPELIKA, Ala.If Jimmy Carter had listened to Millard Grimes, Mr. Grimes ruefully admits today, he'd he only as close to the White House as the next tour.

title: Carter Discusses Problems and Policies With Telephone Callers From 26 States
description: President Carter responded to the complaint; hopes, problems, questions and praise of a cross section of the American public yesterday as he spent two hours answering telephoned inquiries on a nationwide radio broadcast.

title: Advertising Executive
description: Eve Arden and Roz Russell did it just right for their time the woman executive, brisk, smarttalking, impeccable in steelshouldered gray flannel suits.

title: Laura Marie King Engaged
description: The engagement of Laura Marie King to J. Stewart McLaughlin, son of Mrs. Warcle G. McLaughlin of Bay Shore. L. I., and the late Mr. McLaughlin, has been announced by the future's bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. King of West Islip, L. I. A June wedding is planned. Miss King, who attended Suffolk Community College, is a personnel assistant with Litton Industries in Melville. L. I. Her fianc. a partner in Wellersdieck & McLaughlin, a Bay Shore law firm, graduated from Brown University and the Cornell Law School. He received an LL.M degree from the New York University School of Law.

title: Point Pleasant Pharmacy Tests Electronic Ordering Device
description: WITH a wave of his hand, Norman Beyer, the owner of a pharmacy in Point Pleasant, sets in motion an electronic system that reorders hundreds of items for his store, prints out sales tickets with his designated prices on them and sends him periodic management reports.

title: Notes: Gambia Tours Sprout From Roots
description: Rootsthe book by Alex Haley and the eightpart television series based on ithas inspired a rash of tours that include the West African republic of Gambia. The first organization to set up a package that will take travelers to Gambia is Henderson Tours, of Atlanta, Ga., which has specialized in heritage tours to West Africa for 20 years. Other tour operators are planning to offer similar packages, and still more are arranging excursions to Gambia as offshoots of their existing itineraries in neighboring Senegal.

title: FOOD
description: RAVIOLI is in good supply on the Island. In the old neighborhoods, new shopping malls and on refurbished main streets, windows of shops display curtains of cheeses, and the neat white boxes of homemade ravioli and manicotti are stacked in refrigerator and freezer cases.

title: Technology Goes to Sea
description: Bill Schaefer and Teddy Blankenship are both American merchant seamen. Both ship out on the SeaLand Consumer, a new, automated, 23knot container vessel operated by SeaLand Service Inc. But the similarities between the two sailors stop there.

title: What the Figures Tell About Voters
description: PATRICIA TREANOR, a vice chairman of the Democratic State Committee, recalled with a chuckle the other day the upwardly mobile Bronx Democrats who used to move across the border into Westchester and promptly enroll as Republicans.

title: Lindbergh Plane Replica Is Being Built to Retrace His 1927 Tour of Nation
description: MILWAUKEE, March 5 (AP)Fifty years after a daring young Charles A.Lindbergh captured the world's fancy, the Spirit of St. Louis will fly again.

title: Deborah Anne Proctor Bride of Robert B. Ill
description: In St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church yesterday afternoon, Deborah Anne Proctor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dean Wesley Proctor of New York, became the bride of Robert Burnett Ill. son of Edmund Waldemar III Jr. of Mantoloking, N. J.. and the late Jeanne McCormick Ill. The Rev. Gerard Di Senso performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Johnson Voted Top Player
description: Marques Johnson. a University of California, Los Angeles forward, was selected yesterday as United Press International's college basketball player of the year for the 197677 season. The 6foot7inch senior was the overwhelming choice of the nation's sportswriters and broadcasters, receiving 84 votes. His nearest competitor, Rickey Green of Michigan, had 15.

title: The Region
description: The use of quotas based on race to reapportion certain legislative districts has been upheld by the United States Supreme Court in a case brought by residents of Brooklyn. Just how broad an impact the decision will have is not possible to gauge largely because the Justices differed among themselves in their reasoning. In fact, the opinions of the majority in the 7 to 1 ruling appeared to seek to underplay its scope.

title: U.N. School's New Campus in Berkshires Gets Mixed Reception From Townspeople
description: NEW MARLBOROUGH, Mass.The blueandwhite sign above the farmhouse door is modest: United Nations International School.

title: Tina Warner Is Bride Of Peter Jason Locke
description: Tina Gardner Warner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Colin Gardner 3d of Middletown, Ohio, and Winter Park, Fla., was married yesterday evening to Peter Jason Locke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Locke of Garden City, L. 1. The Rev. Edwin W. Marohn performed the ceremony.

title: Antonia Brico Plays in Brooklyn
description: Antonia Brico is now busily reaping the rewards of the kindly largesse showered upon her by Judy Collins. In other words, the 74yearold conductor, after her career had languished for decades, now finds herself again in demand thanks to Miss Collins's film about her. Her appearance Friday night with the Brooklyn Philharmonia (or the New Brooklyn Philharmonia, as it seems to be calling itself these days) at the Brooklyn Academy of Music was testimony to that demand. (Her program was repeated last night and can he heard again this afternoon at 2.)

title: The New Gutenberg
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  When Gutenberg invented the printing press, farseeing men of his day wondered what would be the consequences of device that could actually put a Bible in the hands of every man. Now the experts say there's about to be a communications revolution to rival or surpass the one Gutenberg wrought, and once again mere mortals can't quite conceive what the consequences might be.

title: ART
description: FEW bodies of water have inspired poets and painters as much as the Hudson River did in the 19th century, and it is little wonder. The river, which was once known as the Rhine of America, was a magnificent panorama of nature, with its widely awesome stretches of water, the grandeur of its surrounding mountains, the graceful sloops that plied its waters and the sumptuous homes of the rich looking down upon its unspoiled wilderness.

title: THEATER MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Saturday. March 5. 53 day. Weather clear, track sloppy. 1977, by Triangle Publications. Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Carter Is Urged to Give Peace Corps New Start
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)The Peace Corps, a product of the New Frontier that has sent 66,000 Americans overseas in 16 years. needs a new beginning and help from President Carter to overcome years of lethargy, according to a report for the Government.

title: ANGELA M. LYONS
description: Angela M. Lyons, controller of the New York Public Library from 1964 to 1969, died Saturday at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. She was 77 years old and lived in Tudor City.

title: For young readers
description: Fantasies, especially tripledecker ones, require an unholy amount of imagination: you have to start from scratch, become God, create a world. Trilogies, from Mervyn Peake and Tolkien to Isaac Asimov and Ursula LeGuin, have been the opportunity for some talented and sometimes ingenious people to write at length and give their worlds the wealth of imaginative detail needed to convince. Trilogies also, how ever, have been an unspoken invitation to windiness, stilted prose and writing beyond one's powers. Patricia McKillip who showed a talent for pop fantasy with The Forgotten Beasts of Eld, is here trying her best with what promises to be the first novel in a set of three; it's a weak beginning and a rather tiring book.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: On the island of Yamaca (the old West Indian spelling for Jamaica, also called the Isle of Many Rivers), many people would refer to the coin pictured here as boonoonoonoos, which means something that is really nice. (Something that is not very nice would be mecky mecky.)

title: Utility BillsA Lohng Look Back
description: ORADELL FOR the 18 years that I've lived in this Bergen County community, I've saved my gas and electric bills and never knew why. When I got last month's bill, though, I realized that it was all part of the nostalgia craze, for the earlier bills helped me tolook back on the good old days.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodaySnowbird, Four Seasons Farm, Ilillerest Road, Readington, N.J. Maiden. novice, limitopen, and nonthoroughbred working hunters; preliminary and open jumpers, pleasure horses, adult equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: For more than 15 years, both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal courts have played activist roles in implementing the securities laws

title: Yanks Plan To Discipline Absent Lyle
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 5The Yankees have notified Sparky Lyle, their No. 1 lefthanded relief pitcher, that they will take disciplinary action if he doesn't report to training camp by tomorrow.

title: Home Clinic
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, most of the Home Improvement Column this week is again being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of the letters published here pose questions similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not appear here, but who will, nevertheless, find their answers printed below, Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered here.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Off the Walls

title: The Crisis Routine
description: New York City's floating deadline for averting default, assigned various dates in recent weeks, is now set for Friday. The crisisand that seems the proper wordcould be ended in a moment, but none of the parties involved in protracted financial negotiations has been willing to take the necessary first step toward a compromise.

title: Soviet Expulsion of A.P. Reporter Called Helsinki Violation by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, March 4 (UPI)The Senate approved without dissent Friday a resolution terming the expulsion of an Associated Press reporter from the Soviet Union a violation of the Helsinki declaration regarding the rights of journalists.

title: WILLIAM PAUL SR., LAWYER ACTIVE FOR ALASKA NATIVES
description: SEATTLE, March 5 (AP)William Lewis Paul Sr., who spent much of his life fighting legal battles for the rights of Alaska natives, died yesterday at his home. He was 91 years old.

title: David Lavender's Colorado
description: For most Easterners Colorado is Denver, the bustling gateway to the West, deserted mining amps, poshy ski centers like Aspen and Vail. For David Lavender, novelist and historian (Bent's Fort, The Big Divide), it is the mountain ranges and waterways, wilderness flowers and cow towns through which he has wandered in all seasons of a long life. lie recalls his experiences, some entertaining, some instructive, in this fine example of nature writing. The 105 color photographs he and Lee Boltin took for the book leave a city dweller envious if not downright restless.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: WHY is it that whenever we are able to reach for the top, sufficiently proficient to grab hold of it, we occasionally reject the opportunity? I really don't know how often that happens to other people, but I do it all the time. It's difficult to explain, I suppose, except for psychologists.

title: Here Comes Jackson, In His New York Era
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 5The list of Yankee greats and near greats runs longer than your weekly grocery list, and now comes a prospective additionReggie Jackson.

title: Gerulaitis Gains Final
description: MONTERREY, Mexico, March 5 (AP)  Vitas Gerulaitis of New York and Wojtek Fibak of Poland qualified today for the final of the $100,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Letters to the Editor: Robert Frost
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IWAS rather disappointed the other Sunday, that dreary snowy one. I was rather hoping that some big event would engulf usa storm or the sudden return of the Bicentennial, something really joltingand I would be in the position to write a major Long Island work, A Sunday to Remember.

description: AT 102d ENGRS. ARMORY FIELD EVENTS

title: Lacrosse Hall Picks 5
description: Robert H. Scott, the athletic director at Johns Hopkins University and one of lacrosse's most successful coaches, has been inducted into the Lacrosse Hall of Fame. In the two decades that Scott led Johns Hopkins, he won seven national championships, the last in 1974, his final season. He was named lacrosse coach of the year three times.

title: Engagements
description: Finkelstein Jacobs

title: Auto Racing
description: AT JOHANNESBURG

title: EXMAYOR IN ST. LOUIS RUNS FOR THIRD TERM
description: ST. LOUIS. March. 3As the public relationsminded Mayor of St. Louis, Alphonso J. Cervantes docked a replica of Columbus's lead ship, the Santa Maria. on the Mississippi River here, but she sank. When he brought the Spanish Pavilion, which was a big hit at the World's Fair in New York in 1964, to downtown St. Louis. it turned out to be a bust.

title: For Beverly buffs Bubbles
description: The demand for tickets was the greatest in the memory of the Metropolitan Opera's Assistant Manager, Francis Robinson. The longawaited event was still a week or two in the future, but the electricity began to fill the main stage as rehearsals got under way for The Siege of Corinthnot only the first time ever at the Met for that Rossini spectacular, but also for a titianhaired spectacular named Beverly Sills.

title: ROUNDUP
description: Although April Fool's Day has long marked the unofficial start of the twomonth peak season of annual stockholder meetings, plans for this year's gatherings are already well under way. In giving an accounting of their stewardship to their bosses'the shareholderscorporate managers will be facing increasingly difficult questions and proposals concerning social and moral as well as economic attitudes.

title: I Get Along Well With Wild Personalities
description: ROME The scene is the bar and dining room in a Rome studio where Line Wertmuller, the Italian directorwriter, is shooting her first picture in English: The End of the World in Our Usual Bed in a Night Full of Rain.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE is a thriving Indian community Flushing and a recent proliferation of Indian restaurants in Manhattan. Eventually, some of this activity might be expected to spill over into Nassau County. It has. A few months ago, Moti Mahal (House of the Pearl) was installed across from the Great Neck station. Its namesake is one the most popular restaurants in New Delhi. Moti Mahal is the most popular Indian restaurant in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. (From what I have been able to determine, it is the only Indian restaurant

title: Anniversary
description: Kowit

title: One Woman Scores a Victory Over Mobil
description: No merger fight hath the fury of an heiress scorned, particularly one who has had four husbands, rides to the hunt in West Virginia, is the granddaughter of a pioneer California land baron, and who is willing to battle both the Mobil Corporation and a charitable foundation created by her father.

title: Could There Be Another Holocaust?
description: COULD it happen again? Could it happen in the United States? These are the basic questions being discussed in a popular University of Bridgeport lecture series, Holocaust: Public Policy Implications, being presented this semester at 7:30 on Monday evenings through May 16, free to the general public.

title: In Order to Achieve Real Wings in Chekhov, You Just Live It
description: Atriumph as Madame Ranevskaya in Anton Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard is the dream of virtually every actress, and it is evident that Irene Worth now realizes that the dream is hers. Joseph Papp's Lincoln Center production of the play, in which the character of Madame Ranevskaya is pivotal, has won acclaim, and Miss Worth's demeanor offstageconfident and articulateattests to the success that she and the prodution are enjoying. Clive Barnes has extolled heras peerless among her set of peers, and Walter Kerr has called her final scene in the play one of five images I shan't forget as long as I live. But the general acclaim has been accompanied by some severe strictures from other, less benevolent reviewers. Their criticism has been aimed mostly at Andrei Serban, the controversial avantgarde Rumanian director, rather than at Miss Worth. John Simon denounced the production harshly, and asked: Shall we laugh or weep at what is being done to Chekhov at Lincoln Center. . . The production is a total betrayal of Chekhov's simplicity. And Brendan Gill praised Miss Worth but wrote: If Mr. Serban is wanton in removing so much that Chekhov has cunningly inserted, he is also, on occasion, gratuivulgar.

title: Whooping Cranes Begin Migration
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., March 5 (UPI) Two young whooping cranes have begun the migration from their winter home, in New Mexico to summer grounds in the northern Rocky Mountains, the Fish and Wildlife Service says. The two whoopers are part of a plan to establish a second wild flock of the rare birds. They were hatched from eggs taken from the Canadian nesting grounds of the only surviving wild flock.

title: White Plains to Throw Open City Doors
description: THE City of White Plains will hold open house in April to help solve some problems that were evident even as organizers were summoning community leaders to a meeting in City Hall this week.

title: Filming The Volga Wasn't All Caviar
description: Never in my career have I run into such curiosity about my travels as I did after the three trips I made to Russia in connection with The Volga, a 60minute television special, which I wrote, produced and directed for the National Geographic Society and WQED, Pittsburgh, and which will be telecast on Channel 13 this Tuesday at 8 P.M. Everyone wanted to know what it was like to work there.

title: Giving the A. To the Tax Q.
description: THE class of 25 Internal Revenue Service trainees turned to video monitor to watch a simulated example of how not to deal with a taxpayer. A man playing the part of a befuddled taxpayer was seeking help from an I.R.S. employee.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: AT 5 A.M., how many women with a net worth of $5 million are getting up to go to work these days? One, for sure, is. That's Representative Millicent Fenwick, whose prosperous Fifth Congressional District stretches from north of Morristown southward to Princeton.

title: Tigers Advance on 6139 Rout of Yale
description: PRINCETON, March 5After Coach Pete Carril of Princeton had removed Frank Sowinski late in tonight's 6139 victory over Yale, the 6foot5irich junior from East Hanover, N. J., didn't know exactly where he stood in the Ivy League scoring race. What's more, he didn't care.

title: Dredging Up The Sound Issue
description: HE IMPENDING Battle Of Long Island Sound will not be a delayed postBicentennial pageant to be staged by enthusiastic Rotarians from Stamford and Jaycees from Darien, arrayed in homespun blue uniforms and launchingoakribbed longboats from the Stamford Yacht Club in the general direction of an imaginary British flotilla bobbing unsuspectingly off Huntington Harbor.

title: West German Results
description: NATIONAL DIVISION

title: Miss Gilliam Fiancee Of Todd D. Jacobson
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Frank Gilliam of Princeton, N.J.. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Gilliam, to Todd Durwood Jacobson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton D. Jacobson of Charlottesville. Va.

title: LETTER FROM U. OF B.
description: WHEN Patrick Cocchiarella was an undergraduate at the University of Bridgeport in 1968, some students were grumbling about the proposed institution of an Army Reserve Officers Training Corps on campus.

title: Elections Are Coming Up in India and Pakistan, Perhaps in Sri Lanka
description: NEW DELHIDemocracy, which has at times been a stranger to South Asia in recent years, seems at least on the surface to be coming back, to the delight of millions of voters. In the largest exercise of democratic franchise in history, Pakistan and India, which have between them onesixth of the world's population, will hold parliamentary elections in the next few days, and in both cases, wellentrenched Prime Ministers are facing unexpectedly strong political challenges. Sri Lanka, the island republic that used to be called Ceylon, is also likely to go to vote this year, and the threat to the Government there is also real. Among the region's major countries, only Bangladesh, the most overcrowded and least promising economically, is moving in the other political direction with a rigid martiallaw regime under Maj.Gen. Ziaur Rahman holding power and elections postponed indefinitely.

title: POLITICS
description: THOMAS JEFFERSON was a believer in the continuing revolution, Andrew Jackson seemed to thrive on the excitement of an unruly crowd. These two party heroes would probably have enjoyed the ferment that has persisted in the Democratic Party in Connecticut since the outward display of harmony couple of weeks ago at the fundraising dinner in their name. The dinner was named this time also for the late John M. Bailey, the party chairman, after whose death the unsettled condition at the top of the party has increased..

title: A Memo to the U.S.A. From N.Y.C.
description: It must be disconcerting to the United States beyond the Hudson River to watch a virtually bankrupt New York City being dragged once more toward the brink of Insolvency. The noisy struggle among our banks, unions and officialdom over the next phase of debt management is real enough, but they deserve a bit more understanding and patience if those qualities can still be mustered for Our Town.

title: Soviet Jewish Dissidents Call Charges of Spying Slanderous
description: MOSCOW, March 5 (Reuters)Soviet Jewish dissident leaders said tonight that allegations in the official press that some of them were paid American agents were crude and slanderous inventions that could herald trials reminiscent of the Stalin era.

title: The Open Conspiracy;
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The Russians are sneering at President Carter's defense of human rights, as if it were a dreary Sunday school lesson out of Plains, Ga., but it is much more serious than that.

title: Judaism Is Called Cool to Feminism
description: The response of the Jewish community to the feminist movement and its demand for equality in all areas of life has been tentative and limited, in the view of pamphlet issued by the American Jewish Committee.

title: Virginia Clare White Plans May Wedding
description: Mrs. Martin White 3d of Rumson, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Virginia Clare White, to Brian John Holtby, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Holtby of Edmondton, Alberta.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: White Plains Official Defends Bus Program

title: Fire Kills 14 in Korea
description: SEOUL, March 5 (Reuters)Fourteen people were killed today when a fire swept through a fourstory building in the center of the city. Authorities said the fire raged through the building's two upper floors while dozens of fire engines stood useless outside because hydrants had frozen in the 5degree weather.

title: Beverly Day Is Married to Vincent C. Banker
description: Beverly Vander Poel Day of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday afternoon in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church to Vincent Campbell Banker, vice chairman of R. W. Pressprich & Company, members of the New York Stock Exchange. The Rev. Jerre Feagin performed the ceremony, which was followed by a small reception at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Farnsworth Vander Poel, in Oyster Bay, L.I. Linda Duryea was matron of honor for her sister. Peter A. Banker, brother of the bridegroom, served as best man.

title: ASSASSINATION PANEL MIRED IN PROBLEMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The special House committee set up in September to investigate again the assassinations of President Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. may be abolished this month, according to many senior House members, and its plight, only six months after it was established by a vote of 280 to 65, provides an insight into the workings of Congress and the relationship between its members and their staffs.

title: Catholics Asked To Aid the Poor In 1977 Appeal
description: Nearly 10,000 volunteer lay workers in the 10county Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York were called on last week by Terence Cardinal Cooke to be advocates of the poor.

title: Hackensack Gets New Shopping Mall
description: AFTER two years of planning, building and promotion, Bergen County's newest shopper's paradisea lavishly appointed, twostory enclosed mall called Riverside Squareis set to open in Hackensack Thursday morning.

description: AT ORLANDO, FLA. FLORIDA CITRUS OPEN The Leading Scores

description: LOUISECharpentier's opera of life among the Paris working class in 1900 returns to the City Opera tonight with John Alexander and Beverly Sills. Julius Rudel will both conduct and direct the revival.

description: FIRST PERIOD1, St. Louis. Unger (26) (Butler, Irvine). 17:75 PenaltiesPatey, (5:53); Lewis, (16:51).

title: Washington Restores Lights at Monuments
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) Partly because of appeals from the public, the floodlights displaying Washington's historic monuments at night have been switched on again.

title: Guest Observer
description: I have a sneaking suspicion that police argot has just tripped on its own laces. It is one thing to make observations upon an alleged perpetrator instead of tailing a thief. It is quite another, as The New York Times reports, to call sneakers felony shoes. True, purse snatchers are sometimes caparisoned in springsoled footgear for a quick getaway. But these felons are a small, if mercurial, minority. It is unfair, in one cruel coinage, to reduce a great 20thcentury invention to a burglar tool. The term betrays a deaf car to the music of shoe business.

title: Being Kind to Veterinarians
description: AS a veterinarian, I am concerned that the highest standards be maintained in my profession. Because of recent actions by the state's Division of Consumer Affairs, it seems to me that the division says I have an obligation to treat any animal brought to me in an emergency, regardless of whether or I am compensated

title: DINING OUT
description: LIKE your favorite supporting actor, Nino's will rarely steal the show. On the other hand. you can almost always count on getting a solid, professional performance. Nino's has been playing its roleand wellsince 1953 when Nino (now retired) brought his brand of North Italian cooking to a rambling, 200yearold house in northern Westchester.

title: New Deal Veterans, Gathered for Evening of Nostalgia, Commemorate Days of F.D.R
description: WASHINGTON, March 5It was night of Washington memories that began with laughs and ended in quiet melancholy. It was a night of F.D.R. and the New Deal.

title: A JAIALAI PROMOTER HAS CHARGE DROPPED
description: HARTFORD, March 5Assailing the press and public officials for making a soap opera of the case, Judge Simon S. Cohen of Connecticut Superior Court yesterday dismissed a perjury charge against David Friend, the jaialai promoter who contended that he surreptitiously had given John M. Bailey, the late Democratic party chairman, $200,000 in cash for help in obtaining a license to introduce the Basque sport in Connecticut.

title: Card of Thanks
description: EHRLICHThe family of Sidney J. Ehrlich extend their deep appreciation to the members and associates of the Wilbar Photo Engraving Company or their kind expressions of sympathy.

title: Headliners
description: An executive assistant to New York State's Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, has been accused of taking a bribe in exchange for certain unspecified actions in a state investigation. It is the third time in five months criminal charges have been filed against aides to Mr. Lefkowitz, who has been in office for over 20 years.. A Manhattan grand jury last week accused the executive assistant, Lee R. Miller, of accepting a free gambling trip to Las Vegas; the man who allegedly offered the bribe was also indicted. What Mr. Miller was supposed to have done in return is not clear: His normal duties would not have involved him in the investigation at issue, a State Department of Mental Hygiene examination of a school for the mentally retarded.

title: Carter So Far: Mix of Symbol and Substance
description: WASHINGTONIt is surprising how quickly everyone has forgotten that in a moment of candid reflection right after the November elections, Jimmy Carter acknowledged that toward the end of the campaign Gerald Ford had damaged his reputation and skillfully exploited uncertainties about a Carter Presidency.

title: INVESTING
description: Gold fever has once again infected investors despite the strenuous efforts of government officials and private bankers to fight the disease that consumes the paper money the central banks create.

title: Dog Shows
description: AT KINGSBRIDGE ARMORY

title: RIGHTS RALLY IN CITY MARKED BY RANCOR
description: At a human rights rally here yesterday for Vladimir K. Bukovsky, the deported Soviet dissident, cheers and applause erupted from the audience of Ukrainian and Russian migrs when the chairman reminded them that the day was the 24th anniversary of the death of Stalin, the most disgusting dictator in the world, as one speaker declared.

title: VIEW OF MAO'S WORLD IN A BOOK ON HIS WIFE
description: A glimpse from China of the world of Mao Tsetungincluding the changing guard in Peking, the role of women and of the proletarian artswill soon appear in the United States in the form of biography of Chairman Mao's widow, Chiang Ching.

title: Newark Fears Property Revaluation
description: IF WHITE residents leave Newark, business leaders won't be far behind, and the largest city in the Garden State will be turned into a reservation housing the black poor.

title: Kathleen Malloy Wed To Robert M. Allen
description: Kathleen Patricia Malloy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Malloy of Los Angeles. and Robert Montgomery Allen, son on Mr. and Mrs. Paul NI. Allen of Long Island City, Queens. were married yesterday in St. Brendan's Roman Catholic Church in Los Angeles by the Rev. Frank Meskell, a chaplain at Claremont College.

title: Realty News
description: The prices and sales volume of luxury tenantowned apartments in Manhattan have remained steady over the last four years despite a onethird increase In maintenance charges, according to a survey by a leading management firm.

title: Sarah Vaughn Sings Jazz at Avery Fisher Hall
description: Sarah Vaughan has such a rainbow of colors in her voice, a range that peaks in airy birdsong and goes down to ominously dark rainbarrel rumbles, and control that takes her from one extreme to the other with seemingly effortless case, that one would think her voice would be the least of her problems as a singer. And yet all through her career she has been battling the question of how to use all that voice on a relatively simple song structure.

title: LOUISIVLLE BACKING HOMEBASED ARTS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.Paint, tobacco and bourbon, like horse racing and Muhammed All, are so much a part of life in this city that many here find it difficult to Imagine a future without these assets.

title: New Magazine Seeks to Aid Slow TeenAge Readers
description: A new indication of the severity of the reading problem in the nation's schools is the start of a magazine aimed specifically at junior high school students reading on the secondgrade level.

Nino's has been playing its roleand wellsince 1953 when Nino (now retired) brought his brand of North Italian cooking to a rambling, 200yearold house northern Westchester.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Sales rep. Over the years, writes one of our readers who works for a major paperback house. you've sung the achievements of authors, editors, cover designers, publicity and promotion people  but never said a word about those who sell the books. Won't you give us sales reps a break?

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: IN government as well as in romance, in the view of some. little things mean a lot. If this is true, some recent little things may provide further insight into how the New Jersey state government works in Trenton.

title: Marion Morsey Is Engaged
description: Marion Leschen Morsey, a senior at Manhattanville College, and David Farrell Boucher, a marketing representative with the Interconnect Planning Corporation, a communication systems concern in New York, plan to be married on May 21.

title: Two 14Year Old Boys Are Held After Police Blockade Halts a Stolen Greyhound Bus
description: Detective Frank Gilberti and Officer Gerard Devlin were ridinng in a police radio car on Madison Avenue and 116th Street yesterday morning when they saw a sight that made them blink.

title: Nan Waksman Bride of Walter Schanbacher
description: Nan Waksman and Walter W. Schanhacher. thirdyear law students at Villanova University, were married in the Dwight Memorial Chapel on the Yale University campus in New Haven yesterday. The Rev. Charles Hoffman of the Episcopal Church of the Messiah in Woods Hole. Mass.. performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Lafayette Coach Cited
description: EASTON, Pa., March 5 (UPI)Dr. Tom Davis, the Lafayette basketball coach, was named today East Coast Conference coach of the year in a poll of the conference's head coaches. It was the second time in three years that Davis, who will soon take up the head coaching job at Boston College, has been named top coach.

title: Music in Review
description: The De Vos Quartet, an ensemble made up of firstchair members of the Grand Rapids Symphony, made an impressive New York debut at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night. Just, how Yosef Yankelev, William Patterson, George Woshakiwsky and Ross liarbaugh happened to Land in the orchestra of Gerald R. Ford's hometown at the same time, this reporter does not know, but it seems to have been happy circumstance that brought them together.
