title: Shakespeare as They Like It
description: HEMPSTEAD TRADITIONS sometimes have the most unexpected reasons for developing. For example, take Hofstra University's 28th annual Shakespeare Festival, which begins Thursday. For six weeks now, students in the drama department have been working at a fevered pitch memorizing their lines from Romeo and Juliet, sewing Renaissance costumes, hammering together on authentic reproduction of the Globe stage, learning the intricacies of swordplay, repainting curtain tapestries and composing and recording Baroque music.

title: Like Chatting With the Neighbors
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Walter Cronkite touched his mustache, cleared his throat, took his cue and cautiously called it an experiment in communications.

title: POLITICS
description: SOMETHING strange is happening to New Jersey Republicans. Their wellknown reputation for snatching defeat from the jaws of victory may be ruined this year if any more gubernatorial candidates take themselves out of the picture and leave the party relatively united.

title: Claudia M. Radigan To Be Wed in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Radigan of Summit N.J. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Claudia Marie Radigan, to Geoffrey S. Mason. son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon L. Mason of Casey Key, Fla. An April wedding is planned.

title: Japanese Act to Position Satellite
description: TANEGASHIMA, Japan, March 5 (Reuters)Japanese scientists fired rockets by radio signal today in an effort to emulate the American and Soviet feat of positioning an experimental earth satellite over a fixed point. The National Space Development Agency said the adjustment rockets had fired successfully; but that it would not know until Monday whether the satellite was in the intended orbit over the western tip of New Guinea.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may he obtainedfrom the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: An Old Trouper Finds New Angels
description: IN ITS HEYDAY, five or six decades ago, the boards of the Palace Theater in South Norwalk supported the substantial talent of Mae West, Webber & Fields, Houdini and other headliners. Like the Danbury Opera House and many New England theaters, the 1,000seat art deco Palace was strictly legitplaying everything from trained seals to Il Trovatore.

title: F.C.Spogen 3d Plans to Wed Miss Bowers
description: The engagement of Martha Dandridge Bowers to Frederick Clifford Spogen 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Spogen Jr. of Herkimer, N.Y., has been announced by Helen Wolcott Bowers of Fly Creek, N.Y., mother of the future bride.

title: LETTERS
description: U.S. Stockpiles

title: Runestruck
description: Grease monkey Duane Minnick of the small coastal town of Berryville, Me. is out clamming one day when he comes across this real weird rock. Duane and his friend Clifford Bates, noted for his toilettongue and crude wayshe once named a dog Full Frontal Nuditytake their find to Sam Brewster, president of the Berryville Archeological Society. for identification. The runic inscriptions on the rock appear to be authentic, convincing Brewster that Leif Erickson and his merry band of Vikings had once stepped upon those very shores. Berryville, so it seems, is the fabled Vinland.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BRIDGEPORTPhotographs of Connecticut Architecture from 1650 to 1960 on exhibit in the Museum of Art, Science and Industry, 4450 Park Ave., starting Friday through April 10. Also, an exhibition of Contemporary Graphics. All on the main floor, 2 to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays.

title: Can a war be contained in Europe?
description: If it seemed upon Jimmy Carter's victory that economics, domestic and foreign, would dominate the launching of the new Administration, now the specter of foreign policy is creeping back into the political arena. The old issues remain SALT, international economic cooperation, relations with the poor and wealthy third world, normalization of ties to China and Vietnam and so on. But an odd new issue has appeared: human rights. The new wielders of power, seemingly intent on giving United States foreign policy a moral rudder, are voicing concern for human rights violated throughout the world. But Voice of America broadcasts in assorted languages are showing certain patterns  human rights violations in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union are being stressed more and more.

title: Judicial Dispute Affects Makeup Of Juries on S, I.
description: Because of a judicial disputeand more than three months after it was told to put changes into effect  Staten Island continues to have a jury selection system marked by the substantial underrepresentation of women and people between the ages of 18 and 30.

title: Miss Arrauzau in Carmen Debut
description: Friday night's Carmen at the New York City Opera marked the American debut of Francine Arrauzau in the title role. The French mezzo, who sings at both the Paris Opera and Opera Comique, made a positive impression without ever igniting any special excitement.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: SO WHAT was I doing there under those hot studio lights with a microphone tied around my neck and a false smile plastered on my mouth?

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: WINTER 1977, the coldest on record (almost), so say those jolly television weatherpersons who announce catastrophe with the broadest Of smiles; bad news makes good news stories.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Ever since conductors started to mount podiums, a sliver of wood in their hand, there has been tension between them and the players. The conductor thinks the knows best, the players think they know best, and an uneasy tug war results. Until the last generation, the issue always was settled in favor of the conductor who, after all, had absolute power. He could hire and fire at will.tint not today, when orchestra players are protected by unions. Thus unusual things have been happening in recent years. The players are getting more and more powerpower over choice of conductor, power over repertory.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: 76ers Topple Knicks at Garden, 117114
description: The Knicks seasonlong weakness of too much oneonone play and too little helpingout defense unfolded again last night in the third period against the Philadelphia 76ers.RefereesJack Madden and f'd Middleton. Technical foalsHaywood, Bibby. Attendance19,694.

title: WolfFerrariHe Was a Major Among Minor Masters
description: A belated happy birthday to Ermanno WolfFerrari. The centennial of his birth came and went last year without anyone paying much notice, but London Records has just released two betterlatethannever tributes to the composer: a performance of his most popular opera, the oneact farce The Secret of Susanna, and a disk of overtures, intermezzos and dances drawn from five of his 13 operas. Not only that, the Manhattan School of Music will be giving three performances of I Quattro Rusteghi this week, on Thursday and Saturday nights, and next Sunday afternoon.

title: An OpenDoor Policy on Banking
description: FROM the earliest days of its settlement to the recent relocation of corporate headquarters in Connecticut the state has benefitted from the talents of newcomers. We have welcomed immigrants from all parts of the United States, from all parts of the world. We actively solicit industry to establish facilities in our state. Why not banking offices of companies with headquarters outside of our state?

title: GARDENING
description: MARCH is sort of an inventory montha look back and a look forward to summer garden plans. Will there be a vegetable patch this year?

title: A Work Crew to Help the Aged
description: THIS coldest of winters has been particularly hard on elderly homeowners, who are often unable to insulate their houses themselves and too poor to afford to hire someone else to do the job.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Edgar Degas today is so universal a favorite that the Metropolitan Museum cannot fail to delight its public with its Degas in the Metropolitan exhibition. This consists of everything by Degas that is in the Museum's own collections, together with much related material from the same overflowing source. The show runs right through the summer (until September 4) and it offers us a manifold education.

title: Albany Is Reducing Funds for Medicaid
description: The Carey administration will cut Its annual $3 billion state Medicaid expenditures by roughly $360 million beginning April 1.

title: The Leaves of Geraniums Can Be Rather Fancy
description: Though many have tried to describe the fancyleaved geraniums with their marvelous patterns of color, these plants must be seen to be believed. The brilliant, multicolored foliage shows reds, golds and browns. Some tricolors resemble spectacular sunsets while others with green and white or bronze and gold leaves, are more subtle but equally beautiful.

title: BRIDGE
description: The Blue Ribbon Individual played a month ago shed some interesting light on the bidding habits of New York experts. A few of the more versatile players expressed a willingness to play ??tever their partners preferred, and o?? them found he had the following results: six rounds playing a variety of strong club systems, Precision three times, Blue Team twice and Schenken once; two rounds playing traditional methods with fourcard major openings; one round playing RothStone; and 26 rounds playing Eastern Scientific.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: One day after striking teachers in Greenwich, Conn., returned to their classrooms under a court injunction, their union leaders reached a tentative agreement with the Board of Education. Talks were concluded yesterday afternoon with the aid of a state mediator.

title: Deborah V. Current Is Engaged
description: Deborah V. Current and James Shea Burns Jr., sales representatives for Milliken & Company, plan to be married next October. Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Current of Westport, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burns of Narberth, Pa.

title: Here Come the Buses
description: ANYONE in Fairfield County who still thinks that buses are for schoolchildren, mass transit is for cities and suburban streets are only for cars is in for a surprise sometime in the next few months, as towns from the Byram River to the Housatonic and north to Candlewood Lake begin to develop fullscale bus systems.

title: Sarah Bonsai, James Miller Will Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard I. Bonsai of Upper Montclair, N.J.. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Todd Bonsai, to James Edwin Miller. son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacques C. Miller of Modesto, Calif. A July wedding is planned.

title: Henry Amber to Marry Laurie Kaufman in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kaufman of Hollis Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Kaufman, to Henry Amber, son of Dr. and Mrs. Carlo Ambrosino of Key Biscayne, Fla., formerly of Turin. Italy. Dr. Ambrosino, formerly a professor of biophysical chemistry at the University of Turin, is a professor at the Florida International University in Miami.

title: Miss Wilde Fiancee Of James C. Jordan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Merbach Wilde of Bryn Mawr, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Louise Pressler Wilde, to James Caldwell Jordan, son of Mrs. Canfield Jordan of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Jordan. The wedding is planned for fall.

title: Logs for the Cutting In State Preserves
description: WITH a cord of wood fetching upward of $60 this winter, the most valuable item in the doityourself firewood scavenger's kit may not be a sawn or ax, hut a bit of buffcolored paper stamped with the markings of the Bureau of Parks of the state's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: STAMPS
description: After the seemingly endless bitter cold of this winter, there comes at last a harbinger of spring, cheering and familiar to all collectors of stamps. It is INTERPEX '77, and the 19th annual edition of this international philatelic exhibition is taking place this coming weekend, Friday through Sunday.

title: Morocco Developing West Sahara
description: RABAT, Morocco  Despite delays caused by continued guerrilla warfare in the Western Sahara, Moroccan Government planners say they are working out ambitious projects to develop communications, irrigation, fishing, schools and housing in the former Spanish Sahara in an effort to win the support of the desert population.

title: Dances by Paul Wilson Offered, Including Premiere of Secrets
description: There was something subtly wrong in the proportions of Paul Wilson's Theatredance Asylum concert Friday evening. The dances that were serious in intent had incongruous bits of humor, and the humorous ones had moments of serious drama that went against their drift. The company appeared at the Sun Ock Lee Studio with a program of five works.

title: Keeping Out Of Deep Water
description: SENATOR FRANK J. DODD'S recent attempt (Feb. (6) to masquerade a deepwater port under the banner of environmental protection misrepresents the entire issue of environmental quality while urging support of a facility that is both illconceived and unwanted.

title: Center Helping Students Select a New York College
description: Charles Ng, a New York City high school senior, had not expected any difficulty in getting into a good engineering program in an independent college: He had a 90plus average (almost 92 in mathematics and science), high scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Tests and a rank in the top 18 percent of his class.

title: Steam Train Begins Trip April 13
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)Railroad buffs will have a chance to take nostalgic journey starting April 13 when an Amtrak train drawn by steam locomotive No. 4449 sets out on a special 3,655mile trip from Birmingham, Ala., to Portland, Ore. For the last two years No. 4449 has powered the American Freedom Train across the country as part of America's Bicentennial celebration.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Bee Pollen and Nutrients
description: Your article on bee pollen (Bee Pollen: Wonder Drug or Humbug? Feb. 6) raised a lot of questions. It is Important to note that bee pollen is a 100 percent natural food. Your headline, Wonder Drug or Humbug? was challenging but people might get the impression that bee pollen is a drug when it is not.

title: The New Romanticism
description: Off with the old. On with the new. Fashion has made a complete turnaround in one season. Gone are the mantailored huntcountry tweeds of last fall. Gone also is the rugged backpack look. What's coming is soft, even romantic. And it's more than simply a change from coldweather gear to warmweather dressing. Instead of blazers, kilts and anoraks, there are full dirndl skirts, big overblouses, loose, unlined shirt jackets, frail sundresses, even flowers in the hair. It's almost as if women have proved to themselves that they're equal to men and are now secure enough to want frankly feminine clothes.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: This Week: Get tools in readiness. . . . Service the lawn mower.. . . Start tuberous begonias and caladiums indoors. . . . Sow broccoli, cabbage, lettuce indoors for early outdoor planting . . . Prune grapevines and fruit trees.

title: The Silent Springs of Manhattan
description: For most New Yorkers, the streams of Manhattan survive only in street names or old maps. Maiden Lane recalls the time when young Dutch washerwomen soaked dirty laundry in the brook along that street. Canal Street was such a swampy place that high tides sometimes bisected the island. And the name Gramercy Park was derived from the Dutch Krom Maerasje or Crooked Little Swamp.

title: Carter's Economic Team: Style and Substance
description: WASHINGTONIt used to be called the Fish Room of the White House because Franklin Delano Roosevelt kept his fish tanks there, and John F. Kennedy proudly hung the sailfish he had caught during his Mexican honeymoon.

title: C.I.A. Considers Much of Its Money Well Spent
description: WASHINGTONFor most foreign political leaders, including those considered friendly towards the United States, an allegation that they received money from the Central Intelligence Agency is an embarrassment as well as a liability, like being accused of profiting from the opium trade. It is not surprising, therefore, that most of the dozen or leaders said to have received the intelligence agency's money were quick to issue denials.

title: About the Mets . . .
description: In St. Petersburg, Fla., the New York Mets opened their second week of training and aligned the pitchers who will work the first exhibition game next Friday against the Toronto Blue Jays. The pitchers will be drawn from a group of eight men who threw batting practice Saturday. and they inedluded Jerry Koosman, Skip Lockwood and Ray Sadecki. The second group, including Tom Seaver and Jon Matlack, will throw Sunday in practice and then next Saturday against the St. Louis Cardinals. . . . the Mets say it's too early to tell whether there is any difference between the new Rawlings baseball and the Spalding ball it replaces this year. Might be a little slicker, reported Jerry Grote, the catcher. The seams may be a little higher. said Bud Harrelson, the short stop. . . . Dave Kingman still holding out, still going fishing on his new boat in the afternoons. Also unsigned: Grote, apparently waiting for the Kingman case to be settled.... Phil Cavarretta, onetime batting star of the Chicago Cubs, coached the Mets hitters in recent years and was credited with success in curing some glaring problems. But this spring he will work only with minor leaguers. His replacement? Manager Joe Frazier

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Never mind the world, which is in bad enough shape and will just have to take care of itself. It's not my department. But is drama on the verge of going out not with a bang, but with a whimper? I don't invent the question. I ask it of myself, sitting in darkened theaters night after night (or in brightly illuminated theaters if the sceneryis made of solid ice, which tends to reflect light), watching the promise of action, noise, contest, accomplishment disappear and a steady mewl take over. It's as though playwrights were giving up all hope of ever having their characters do anything and were willing to settle for a steady gabble, occasionally rising to a whine, by way of compensation.

title: Brooklyn Gunfight Leaves 1 Man Dead And Policeman Hurt
description: One man was shot dead and a police officer was seriously wounded last evening in a gunfight between the police and three man who had held up a gasoline station in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, the police reported.

title: What's Doing in ROTTERDAM
description: NEW CITY  Putting muscle behind its heraldic motto, Stronger Through Struggle, Rotterdam rose like a phoenix from the ashes of World War II. The port got top priority. Ring roads were built for easy access; new housing mushroomed; the Continent's largest concert and congress center was linked to a downtown pedestrian shopping mall. The landmark 15thcentury St. Laurens Church was restored, museums opened and parks laid out. The country s first (and Still only) subway was dug. The Rotterdam/ Europoort harbor complex now stretches along 25.000 acres of the world's busiest estuary, the Rhine River gateway to industrial Western Europe. Rotterdam has become the world's busiest port.

title: Hearings Are Set on Eight Projects Far Which Carter Would End Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 5, (UPI)The Interior Department will hold four days of,hearings beginning March 21 on President Carter's proposal to delete budget funds for eight Bureau of Reclamation projects for the fiscal year of 1978, was announced yesterday.

title: A.A.A., Marking Its 85th Year, Is Criticized in Nader Study
description: There were some 23,000 motor cars and 17 million horses in the United States on March 4, 1902, when members of nine fledgling automobile clubs met in Chicago and founded the American Automobile Association.

title: Forty Nine Sunsets Pays $10.40 in Aqueduct Score
description: Warm weather is obviously better than hot jockeys for attracting crowds to Aqueduct.

title: COAST DOCTORS COPE WITH INSURANCE RISE
description: LOS ANGELES, March 5Despite predictions two years ago that thousands of California doctors would relocate rather than pay malpractice insurance premiums as high as $26,956 a year. few physicians have left the state as their insurance rates rose as much as 327 percent, according to a report by the Rand Corporation.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN water starts seeping in through a crack or hole in the basement wall, most people think that repairs cannot be made until later in the year, after the ground has thoroughly dried and water is no longer seeping. This is true if ordinary patching cements are used, but special hydraulic cements can be used to plug holes and cracks in masonry even while water is still running through them.

title: Letters
description: We Have Provided Amin With the Dollars . .

title: In Costa Rica, Rapido Pachuco To San Jose
description: Puerto Limn, Puerto Limn Vamonos en el rapid Pachuco . . . So sings Costa Rican guitarist Ray Tico in his downtown bar in San Jose. Rattling over tropical swamplands and through rain forests, tunneling into mountains and bridging white water rivers, the rapido Pachuco is one of the few narrow gauge railroads in tha world today. For 87 years it has been the lifeline between San Jose, the capital, 5,000 feet up in the Central Highlands, and Puerto Lim, the thriving Caribbean outlet to the trade routes of the United States and Europe.

title: Stunned Bucharest Begins Relief Efforts After Quake
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 5Rumania's capital lay stunned and suffering today from an earthquake that was believed to have caused hundreds of deaths and left the city as mutilated as by an air raid.

title: Athletes in Action to Play Soviet Quintet Tomorrow
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., March 5 (AP)The Athletes in Action basketball team, which has beaten topranked University of San Francisco and fifthrated NevadaLas Vegas, will face the Soviet Union's national team in Long Beach Monday.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: The other day a woman from the New York bureau of an Italian magazine started to talk to me about the manifestations of feminism in new movies. I tried to explain that I did not happen to be a movie critic, and I referred her to a friend of mine named Vincent, and hoped for the best. But the conversation with this woman started me thinking. I mean, how about women in dance? The more I thought about it, the more interesting it seemed.

title: Elizabeth Hayden Plans Wedding to William Reiss
description: Elizabeth Wallace Hayden, a kitchen designer in Darien, Conn., and William alas Ryal Reiss, a literary agent with the Paul R. Reynolds Agency Inc., plan to be married in the spring.

title: Ice and Cold Said to Have Killed 80% of Crabs in Chesapeake Bay
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 5 (UPI)The ice and bitter cold apparently killed up to 80 percent of the crabs in the Chesapeake Bay and may have damaged the already declining oyster population, according to a University of Maryland scientist.

title: LEGISLATORS FACING CHOICE OF REGENTS
description: ALBANY, March 5Only three days remain before the Legislature must pick three new members of the State Board of Regents and no leadingor even likely candidates have emerged for the unsalaried but powerful posts.

title: TWO KEY I.L.O. VOTES ENCOURAGING TO U.S.
description: GENEVA, March 5American members of the International Labor Organization's executive council say they are encouraged by signs that the agency is turning away from the politicization that Washington said must be shunned If the United States is to withdraw its notice of resignation.

title: Carol E.Tamm To Be a Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Igor Tamm of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Elizabeth Tamm, to William James McKee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McKee of Ardmore, Pa.

title: Theater
description: Opening This Week

title: Garbage Is No Longer Treated Lightly
description: The East Coast cannot afford to throw away its garbage anymore. Refuse, and the available land to dump it on, have become precious commodities, and urban areas around New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are threatened with burial under their own debris,

title: Concert: Symphony by Sessions
description: Roger Session's Symphony No. 6 was written to celebrate the 300th anniversary of New Jersey. and it had its premiere in 1966. when it was played by the New Jersey Symphony under the direction of Kenneth Schermerhorn. Now, almost H years later, it has crossed the Hudson River, and it was given its New York premiere in Alice Tully Hall on Friday night.

title: Customs Change Slowly
description: During the 1960's, when United States reserves of dollars were dwindling, the Johnson Administration moved to cut back American tourist spending overseas. The dutyfree allowance on purchases abroad was reduced from $500 to $100. And there it stays to this day, centerpiece of a controversy over the confusions of the tariff laws.

title: How to Sue (Small) in One Easy Lesson
description: IF YOU'VE been cheated by a merchant, can't get your security deposit back from your landlord or have a neighbor who won't pay for the dent he put in your automobile, there is a free booklet that tells you how to sue him in Small Claims Court without a lawyer.

title: New York Hearings By State Legislature
description: The following public hearings will be held in the New York metropolitan area by state legislative committees this week:

title: PITTSBURGH N.A.A.C.P. TO OPPOSE FLAHERTY
description: PITTSBURGH, March 5The executive board of the Pittsburgh branch of the National Association for the Advancemerit of Colored People said yesterday that it planned to oppose the nomination of Mayor Peter F. Flaherty as Deputy Attorney General.

title: Eden Itsn't So Hot
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M.On a recent network television broadcast, a harassed Buffalo businessman, tired of the cold and 15foot snowdrifts, expressed his desire to move South, to escape the discomfort and dislocations of the unusually severe winter. According to most predictions, we in the Sunbelt can expect thousands of similarly minded Northerners to migrate to the South and West.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: CEDARHURSTExhibition of paintings and collages by Babs Kent and Marilyn Magaliff; today through March 27, Wednesdays through Saturdays 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays 12 noon to 5 P.M.; AlperGoldberg Gallery, 493 Chestnut St.

title: Brooklyn Man a Little Nervous At Start of Phone Call to Carter
description: Mark Fendrick, a 24yearold retail planner for a Robert Hall clothing store in Brooklyn, made three attempts to talk to President Carter yesterday. The White House answered on the third try, and shortly after the national callin program went on the air. Mr. Fendrick did, too.

title: Less Is Better Than More
description: This is the year of the clean, uncluttered look. That goes for accessories as well as clothes. Some days, all you need is a pair of flat scuffs and a soft rolled hag tucked under the arm: some nights, just a pair of seethrough vinyl slippers and a delicate silk flower tucked into the hair.

title: The IceSkating Boom Cools Off
description: Northern industrialists may look jealously at the Sunbelt's industrial growth and curse this season's frigid weather for sending their own fuel bills skyhigh, but the Northernbred iceskating industry, at least, is finding the current winter heartwarming. Right?

title: SUPREME COURT OPINIONS FOUND UNCLEAR IN POLL
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)The United States Supreme Court is doing better now philosophically than it did under the late Chief Justice Earl Warren, hut its opinions still are too long and fuzzy, according to a survey of about 500 judges and leading lawyers.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on Fresh:Male) reorganization of agencies of the executive branch of the Government, which passed, 94 to 0, March 3.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMSydney. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Jay Abrahams and Bonnie Fogel. Brother ol Monte, Gus. Louis and Lillian Good. stein. Founder and Honorary President of Israel Center of Hilicrest Manor. Services Sunday 1 P.M. at Schwartz Brothers Forest Park Chapels Queens Blvd and 76th Rd., For. est Hills.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE The Fantasticks. Thursday to Saturday at 8 P.M. (through March 19). Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Route 6. $5.50 and $6.50, discounts for groups, the elderly, students and children available, except on, Saturdays. 6281169.

title: REMOVAL OF EDITOR STIRS A CONTROVERSY
description: The removal of the editor of a Roman Catholic diocesan newspaper in Camden, N. J., by his Bishop is raising questions about the role of the Catholic press and its right to independence from ecclesiastical authority.

title: RON LETELLIER
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I., March 5 (UPI)Ron Letellier, the golf professional at Cold Spring Country Club in Cold Spring Harbor, died of cancer today. He was 42 wars old.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MESA, Ariz., March 5In other years, the Oakland A's trained at Rendevous Park on this desert plateau. But that little green grandstand has been leveled for the construction of a civic center. Now the A's are perspiring at new HoHoRam Park, named after an ancient tribe of Indians who died out seven centuries ago.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS GROUP SUPPORTS PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, March 5A human rights organization has defended President Carter's emphasis on rights in the conduct of foreign affairs and made 40 proposals for advancing that policy.

title: A Clinic Built by Pet Lovers
description: EACH day about 100 patients wait in the reception room of a modern $600,000 medical treatment center on the Island. They are apparently nervous, and they show it by growling, barking and meowing. They are waiting in the new clinic of the BideAWee Home Association, one of the country's oldest voluntary agencies for the care and placement of pets.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: At Least 20 Dead in Bulgaria
description: VIENNA, March 5 (AP)The earthquake that struck Bucharest yesterday and was felt from Rome to Moscow, caused death and damage in Bulgaria as well as Rumania.

title: Power of Third World Fading on U.N. Rights Panel
description: GENEVA, March 5Some cracks have begun to appear in the overwhelming Communist, Arab and third world majority that had previously succeeded in largely confining the investigations of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to South Africa, Chile and the Israelioccupied Arab territories.

title: Brazilian Government Rejects U.S. Military Sales Credits for 197879 Period Over the Human Rights Issue
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 5The Brazilian Government informed the United States Embassy today that it would not accept an expected $50 million in military sales credits for the fiscal year beginning October 1978.

title: Asking Americans about America
description: Although I didn't know it until I read this book, my greatgrandfather and Harrison Salisbury's great  grandfather's brother were neighbors. Early in the last century, both lived in that corner of New England where Connecticut, Rhode Island and Massachusetts meet.

title: Many Tuna Vessels Are Tying Up
description: SAN DIEGO, March 5 (UPI)  Most of the 140ship American tuna fleet should be back in port this weekend, the owners balked by a recent flurry of court decisions and restrictive regulations because of the possibility of netting porpoises. The American Tunaboat Association said yesterday that 96 vessels would be in port by tomorrow.

title: The Population Implosion
description: Washington CONNECTICUT is edging downward toward zero growth in the annual count of births measured against deaths in the state, according to recently available Census Bureau figures.

title: Fine Blues From Muddy Waters
description: Muddy Walers has been an imposing figure in the blues, probably the music's most imposing figure. since Alan Lomax recorded him for the Library of Congress in 1042. His Chess records of the 50's were so powerful and intense that dew other bluesmen have come close to matching them. But lately Mr. Waters has been ill, and at his apparance during the Newport Jazz Festival last summer he was a shadow of his former self.

title: Workshop for Writers Flourishing in Jail
description: SAN PEDRO, Calif., March 5The night school class in creative writing at Terminal Island is similar to those taught in high schools, community colleges and universities around the country. The students are men and women from a variety of backgrounds. The teacher, Robert Dellinger, is an alumnus of the course.

title: WESTERN SOURCES DOUBT CUBA FORCE IS IN UGANDA
description: NAIROBI, March 5Western diplomats and intelligence sources here and In Dar es Salaam indicated today that they thought news reports of a Cuban military presence in Uganda to be untrue.

title: Aussies Leave Them Gasping
description: ABOUT 400 youngsters from ages 6 to 18 are learning to play tennis the Australian way at the Rye Tennis Academy, which is part of the Rye Racquet Club in Harrison. The Australian way? Actually, there isn't a big difference between Australian and American coaching, said Rod Brent, a 35yearold Aussie who is director of the academy. But the one thing that we stress heavily in Australia is physical fitness, which is why, over the years, most of the Australians are known for having stamina, for being able to outlast an opponent in a grueling fiveset match.

title: 6 on Oyster Boat Die in Bay
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., March 5 (UPI)Six fishermen aboard an oyster boat drowned and a seventh man was missing in two separate accidents in a storm in the Smith Island area of Chesapeake Bay, the Coast Guard said today. The six men, ranging in age from 20 to 64 years, apparently drowned after their 55foot skipjack went down in 12 feet of water when a storm with winds up to 65 knots passed through the area yesterday, The body of Thomas J. James, 20, of Princess Anne, Md., was found last night and the search continued for a seventh man reported missing in a separate boating mishap.

title: Helayne Hill Married To C. Giles Smith Jr.
description: Helayne Hill. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norris L. Hill of Venice. Fla., was married there yesterday afternoon to C. Giles Smith Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Smith of Rye, N.Y.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE is an important segment of the populace that will not eat fish. To them, fish means canned tuna and sardines, codfish cakes and that unspeakable thing called fish stick. To them, fish means grease and breadcrumbs and nothing at all to do with the sea.

title: ART
description: FEW bodies of water have inspired poets and painters as much as the Hudson River did in the 19th century, and it is little wonder. The river, which was once known as the Rhine of America, was a magnificent panorama of nature, with its widely awesome stretches of water, the grandeur of its surrounding mountains, the graceful sloops that plied its waters and the sumptuous homes of the rich looking down upon its unspoiled wilderness.

title: THEATER
description: STAMFORD'S HARTMAN Theater Company must feel very secureit has allowed competition to open directly across the street for a threeplay season. Housed in a cinderblock rectangle that seats 99 people on folding chairs, The Company Storeas the members of the Hartman Theater Conservatory, a twoyear professional training program, call themselveshas burst into life. The opening show is Olympian Games, a highly imaginative and slightly flippant retelling of the stories of mythology, in the manner of Story Theater. It is the work of Barbara Damashek (music and lyrics), Kenneth Cavander (book) and Larry Arrick (direction), all of the Hartman.

title: New York
description: Many a New Yorker, when he plays host to a savvy visitor, discover aspects of his home town that he never knew before. This collaboration of the British novelist Anthony Burgess and the Londonbased picture staff of TimeLife Books will evoke similar sensations among residents of the Big Apple  and, indeed, most Americans. Through several long stays here as a university teacher and practicing playwright. Burgess came to share the lovehate relationship most New Yorkers have for their home town; his crisply written text makes clear the reasons for it. Even more remarkable are the several hundred photographs, most of them in color, of familiar faces and places caught from refreshingly unfamiliar angles. The polyglot population, the worlds that are Wall Street, the Village, Park Avenue, Broadway, Central Park, Harlem, even Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx are all here in 200 pages. The best book about Our Town in a long while.

title: ART
description: ROSLYN THE exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts of works by Karen Shaw is not for the phlegmatic observer echo prefers not to think too much while looking. It is not the sort of show that gives pleasure or stimulation effortlessly, allowing for a comfortable passivity or lack of involvement. These are pieces, rather, that require purposeful involvement of both the eyes and the mind and will gradually yield their special attractions as we unravel their particular meanings.

title: Nurses in Practice on Their Own
description: WANTACH ONCE a week, Lynn Bernstein visits a home in this Nassau County community to see a woman who suffers from a severe case of depression. Talking to the woman, Mrs. Bernstein helps her work through her fears and anxieties. bringing In the other members of the family from time to time to discuss their involvement in the woman's illness.

title: Tenafly Beekeeper Fights to Keep Hive
description: EDGAR HIRST'S backyard beehive has stirred up a lot of trouble in Tenafly and provoked a lot of predictable puns. But neither Mr. Hirst nor the local Board of Health is amused.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: BECAUSE many amateur photographers limit their picturetaking sessions to photographing family and friends, plus occasional shots of outdoor scenes or vacation trip experiences, they often forget about the many other creative opportunities for using their cameras.

title: When NATO Is Viewed As an American Heritage
description: BRUSSELSI still think It was a mistake not to propose a European officer as NATO's high commander in the 1950'ssome time after General Eisenhower and before General Lemnitzerto demonstrate United States recognition of true philosophical equality in the West's grand alliance.

title: Marlboro Inn Will Stay Dry
description: AFTER months of anxiety and some acrimony, the residential purity of Montclair, an imageconscious Essex County town, has been preserved. The Marlboro Inn, which might have become a midtown oasis of gracious dining with alcoholic refreshment, a place where wine corks might have popped and ice could have been stirred with gin and dry vermouth, will remain dry.

title: Birth Certficate Unchanging
description: SALEM, Ore., March 5 (UPI)The Oregon Supreme Court has ruled that a sex change operation does not mandate switching the sex of a person on a birth certificate. The court reversed a decision of the State Appeals Court in a case involving a person who was born female but underwent a sex change operation to become a male.

title: Not the stereotype at all
description: Andrew Greeley, Catholic priest and social scientist, has written a book packed with surprising findings. Drawing on massive survey data collected by the National Opinion Research Center (NORC) at the University of Chicago, he sketches a social portrait of the presentday American ethnic Catholic that is at odds, at almost every point, with the image of the hardhat, reactionary, antiSemitic, racist, lunchpail Catholic who populates the media and constitutes what everyone knows about Catholics.

title: Come Back, Lolly Ray
description: Lolly Ray Lasswell comes strutting down the main drag of Eunola, a small Mississippi town, and she's leading the parade in a uniform made entirely of gold, dimesized sequins that catch the sun as it slides above the levee. She has batons going like crazy in both hands, the crowd is bugeyed watching her, and when she arrives at the main intersection she executes a full split against the hot street exactly beneath the blinking red traffic light.

title: GARDENING
description: THE first fine day now, some beginning gardener is going to dash out into the yard with his pruning shears and, just for the fun of it, slash some branches from deciduous trees or shrubs. Take it easy, Mr. Gardener. And leave the evergreens for later.

title: Heiress, Working Girl
description: When Delfina Rattazzi was growing upfirst in South America, and then in Romeshe and her five brothers and sisters used to dress in matching outfits, right down to the underwear. Clothes for the Rattazzi children, who belong to the Agnelli family, which owns the controlling interest of the Fiat Automobile Company, were generally made by a seamstress. They were nothing very fancy, said Delfina, who is 25 now, and living in New York. Of course, now and then we would dress up, she added, when queens came.

title: YOUNG ENDORSES A BLACK AS SUCCESSOR IN HOUSE
description: ATLANTA, March 5 (AP)  Andrew Young. representative to the United Nations, has urged voters to elect a black to succeed him as Representative of Georgia's Fifth Congressional District.

title: Safety Board Finds Pilot at Fault In St. Thomas Crash That Killed 37
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)The pilot was at fault in the fiery crash of an American Airlines Jetliner that killed 37 persons on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands last April 27, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Editors' Choice
description: GEOGRAPHY III, by Elizabeth Bishop. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $7.95.) A muchhonored American poet's latest collection, in an austere, meditative style, autumnal in tone, endowing homely particulars with grave tenderness.

title: Governor's Aides Give Approval To Wing to a Psychiatric Center
description: ALBANY, March 5 (AP)Governor Carey's top aides have given the go ahead for construction of a longdelayed 1300bed wing at the St. Lawrence Psychiatric Center near Ogdensburg following a meeting with local officials.

title: Falconer
description: Some of us are not Jews. Neither are some of us Southerners, nor children of the Iroquois, nor the inheritors of any other notably dark and bloodied ground. Some of us are even Episcopalians. In the popular mind this absence of any particular claim on the conscience of the world is generally construed as a historical advantage, but in the small society of those who read and write it renders us different, and a little suspect. We are not quite accredited for suffering, nor do we have tickets for the human comedy. We are believed to have known no poverty except that of our own lifeforce. We are seen by the tolerant as carriers merely of an exhausted culture, and by the less tolerant as carriers of some potentially demonic social virus. We are seen as dealers in obscure manners and unwarranted pessimism. We are always looking back. We are always lamenting the loss of our psychic home, a loss which is easy to dismissgiven our particular history in this particular countryas deficient in generality and even in credibility. Yet in a very real way the white middleclass Protestant writer in America is in fact homelessas absent from the world of his fathers as he is different within the world of lettersand it is precisely this note of homelessness that John Cheever strikes with an almost liturgical intensity in his extraordinary new novel,Falconer.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WHEN on a trip to Mexico nearly 20 years ago, Mildred Morganstern met an American woman with a quick tongue, a hard luck story and some handcrafts to unload. The $25 invested in that group of Mexican clothing eventually led to her own shop in Darien.

title: CHESS
description: Havensor supposed havenssuch as those of the semiclosed positions, often turn out to be no havens at all. Which is probably the most disconcerting thing about defending against the bishop pair. Usually, one of the bishops is more limited in scope than its partner, but it can happen that if the weaker one finds a single useful diagonal, that will be sufficient to win the game.

title: Summaries of IC4A Track Meet
description: FIELD EVENTS

title: Phone Company Describes Mass Callin Program As Successful Venture
description: It was a good day for the longdistance telephone system: The longdistance network functioned very well today, a spokesman for American Telephone and Telegraph Company said shortly after the socalled DialaPresident program went off the air.

title: Drive Opens Against Con Ed Atomic Plants
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y.An organization of opponents of nuclear power has called upon residents and public officials in the MidHudson Valley to resist Consolidated Edison's proposal to build new power plants in the area to serve metropolitan New York.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: WednesdayWestchester Sports Car Club meeting at Sir Loins. Greenburgh Shopping Center, Route 100 A, Hartsdale, N.Y. 8:30 P.M. interested persons welcome. information: Mery Minkon, phone (91417699314.

title: For Foreign L. P. G. Shippers, No Legal Thaw
description: In a move that appeared to symbolize the end of the winter's energy crisis. the Treasury Department in Washington rejected an application to waive domestic shipping laws and permit the transportation In foreignflag vessels of 20.5 million gallons of liquefied petroleum gas (L.P.G.) between American ports.

title: Water Fight in the West
description: PASCO, WashSome of the farmers who cultivate dry wheat here in the Columbia River basin are on the verge of deciding to plow under their winter crops and leave the ground fallow to save some of the precious moisture that remains after the worst drought in the West since the 1930's.

title: Three Die as Cars Fall Off Bridge
description: SHILOH, Tenn., March 5 (UPI)Three cars plunged through a torn bridge span into floodswollen Owl Creek yesterday, killing three persons and injuring another The Hardin County sheriff's office identified those killed as James H. Taylor, 55 years old, and his son, James Jr., bath of Corinth, Miss., and Judy Miller, 23, of Shiloh.

title: SummerJob Time Again
description: SUMMERTIME. The sun is shining, temperatures are in the 90's, Frisbees are flying over crowded beaches, Tshirted girls are out on the streets and icecream cones are melting all over little boys' hands.

title: Constance Corbett Affianced to Juan Mejia
description: Dr. and Mrs. Austin Corbett of Troy. N. Y. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Constance A. Corbett of Washington and Troy, to Juan Andres Mejia of Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andres P. Mejia of West Chester, Pa., formerly of Medellin, Colombia.

title: Ending Aid To Unborn
description: THE county has decided to sue the State Commissioner of Social Services, Philip L. Toia, in an effort to force termination of what Westchester officials regard as a costly, unnecessary and illegal program: aid to the unborn.

title: BOMBAY RACE SHOWS VOTE FERVOR IN INDIA
description: BOMBAY, India. March 4In a sprawling urban neighborhood at the edge of the Arabian Sea, two of India's bestknown lawyers are locked in a contest that reflects the basic national elements of the country's parliamentary election campaign.

title: CORRECTION
description: The reference to Jimmy Carter's astrological chart in R. Valadi's letter to the editor of Feb. 6commenting on Washington's star stargazer by Mary Alice Kellogg, Jan 16should have noted that the planet Mercury was in opposition to Uranus.

title: The Brotherhood Of the Grape
description: Those who remember The Godfather will have an inkling of the unconscionable behavior to expect from a closeknit ItalianAmerican family such as the Molises. They are not gangsters, in this case, though they sometimes treat each other as if they were. They are impulsive, hotheaded, passionate people, capable of extreme devotion, arrogance or malice. They may weep over the simple lusciousness of a good homecooked supper or nurse a vicious grudge for 50 years. Some of the Molises' antics are so excessive, one wonders that they don't seem made up; yet the sense of verisimilitude in this novel, Fante's fifth, is unwavering, and its action compelling.

title: Soviet Relay Team Wins
description: FALUN, Sweden, March 5 (AP)The Soviet Union won the men's relay race today at the 28th Swedish Nordic ski games. The men's teamYevgeni Belyayev, Nikolai Bashukov, Sergei Savelyev and Vasily Rochevled from the start to win the 40kilometer relay in 1 hour 53 minutes 30.53 seconds.

title: Miss Walker Sets Nuptials
description: The engagement. of Catharine Kim Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Walker of North Haven, Conn., to Per Torbjoern Bergstroem, son of Mr. and Mrs. Goesta Bergstroem, of Storfors, Sweden, has been announced by the future bride's parents. A fall wedding is planned at the United Church on the Green in New Haven.

title: GARDENING
description: Do your house plants droop and your tomatoes fail to set fruit? Are your roses covered with black spot all summer and your rhododendrons persistent in their failure to bloom? If so, you will find the solution to these and many other garden problems at Flora 77, the Long Island Garden and Flower Show, which opened yesterday at the Nassau Coliseum. While most people will go to the show for a preview of spring, the wealth of horticultural information available is in itself sufficient to warrant attendance.

title: Portisch Triumphant Over Larsen In Fourth Round of Chess Series
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, March (AP)Lajos Portisch of Hungary won the adjourned fourth game today in his quarterfinal world chess elimination match against Bent Larsen of Denmark to regain the lead at 21 in the 12game series.

title: Veterans Are at Full Strength in Washington...
description: WASHINGTONOld soldiers never die. they lobby. They do it so well that President Carter was given some friendly. but blunt, advice recently from the chairman of the House. Committee on Veterans Affairs: Don't mess with the Veterans Administration.

title: Manila Ends Talks With Rebels
description: MANILA, March 5 (UPI)  The Government announced today that peace talks in Libya with Filipino Moslem rebels have been indefinitely recessed and the Government's negotiator had been ordered to return for consultations. President Ferdinand E. Marcos said both parties had agreed on the new recess because both sides no longer had the authority to negotiate. He said their powers lapsed Thursday under the initial agreement signed in Tripoli on Dec. 30.

title: Soviet Ship Is Heading Home After Slow, Slow Crossing
description: The Soviet rollon, rolloff ship, Skulptor Vuchetich, will be at sea today on the return leg of record breaking transAtlantic voyage.

title: The World
description: The erratic President of Uganda, Idi Amin, appears to have sidestepped a confrontation with the United States by changing his mind about forbidding Americans to leave Uganda if they want to.

title: CHURCH GROUPS SEEK TO CURB TV VIOLENCE
description: Ezekiel's words were directed against the prince of Tyrus, but television executives are likely to be hearing echoes of them this year as more church groups join the battle against what they see as excessive violence, discrimination and stereotyping in TV programming.

title: Travel
description: Back in the days when the sun never set on the British empire, travel books were funsometimes a delightto read. From Henry Fielding to Henry James to E. M. Forster, writers lavished on them all the talent and care due a work of art. Most of their readers were armchair travelers, for tours were then costly and timeconsuming ventures to be planned well in advance and reflected on long afterward.

title: Miss Beckmann To Wed in Fall
description: Mrs. August P. Beckmann of Yonkers has made known the engagement of her daughter, Kathryn Mary Beckmann, to Amin Ibrahim Khalifa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ibrahim Khalifa of Bronxville, N. Y. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Swim Times Fastest
description: BREMEN, West Germany, March 5 (UPI)  A West German men's 400meter team clocked a world best time for a 25meter pool of 3 minutes 23.47 seconds today at an invitaiton indoor swimming meet. The team consisted of Andreas Schmidt, Werner Lampe, Peter Nocke and Klaus Steinbach. Barbara Kraueuse of East Germany clocked world best time of 4:09.77 in the women's 400meter freestyle. The pool's 25meter length did not allow the posting of world records, which are only recognized in pools of 50meter length.

title: Byrd Gives Warnke Reluctant Approval As Arms Negotiator
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, said today that he had reluctantly decided to support the nomination of Paul Warnke as chief United States disarmament negotiator, but said that he would not use his leadership position to seek to perguade other senators.

title: Mary Louise Gruber Planning Marriage To Stephen Pollack
description: The engagement of Mary Louise Gruber, an admissions counselor at Ursinus College, Collegeville, Pa., to Stephen J. Pollack, a vice president and shareholder with Drexel Burnham & Company, member of the New York Stock Exchange, has been announced by the bridetobe's mother, Mrs. Dempsey Gruber of Pottstown, Pa. Mr. Pollack is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Pollack of Orwigsburg, Pa.

title: Design
description: Everyone is involved with creating a stage setting for themselves, says Mary McFadden, socialite and Cotyawardwinning fashion designer. Miss McFadden's stage is her new apartment, which she has turned into a personal museum.

title: Mistakes That Delay Refunds
description: AS April 15 approaches, truckloads of tax returns are piled into the two major Internal Revenue Service centers for the. North Atlantic region, in Andover, Mass., and in Holtsville. At the Holtsville facility, 2,400 seasonal workers have joined the 1,600 yearround employees to expedite the processing steps known as the pipeline.

title: WILLIAM D. BOUTWELL, AIDE TO PUBLISHERS
description: William D. Boutwell, a founder and chairman of BoutwellCraneMoseley Associates, publishing consultants, and former editorial vice president of Scholastic Magazines, died Friday of a heart attack at New York University Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN water starts seeping in through a crack or hole in the basement wall, most people think that repairs cannot be made until later in the year, after the ground has thoroughly dried and water is no longer seeping. This is true if ordinary patching cements are used, but special hydraulic cements can be used to plug holes and cracks in masonry even while water is still running through them.

title: Southeast Asia Steps Up Curbs On Journalists From the West
description: SINGAPORE, March 5 (AP)Foreign correspondents appear to be under increasing pressure from governments in Southeast Asia. Several have been expelled, threatened with expulsion or denied reentry. Curbs on news coverage have been imposed, most recently on Indonesia's elections in May.

title: The Nation
description: The House of Representatives has passed a new and strict code of ethics. As.expected, it dealt with the proposed legislation in detachable sections, and, as predicted, the section that caused the most debate was the one that would limit outside earned income.

title: The auction crowd
description: Rush right out now and reserve seat at Sotheby Parke Bernet for o'clock Saturday afternoon. May 7. And, while you're at it, book a table at Les Pleiades in the Surrey Hotel, across the street. for lunch beforehand. Are you back? Then we'll tell you why the date is so important. That is when the glittery collection of Mr. and Mrs. Alfonso Landa will go under the gavel at the famous auction house. Mr. Landa is the wealthy Washington lawyer and chairman of the Fairbanks Whitney Corporation, among other things. The collection, including porcelains French furniture, chandeliers and other decorations, is from the Landas Palm Beach house on El Vedado Way, which is also up for sale. A lot of the .Palm Beach crowd will turn up at the Landa sale. All seven of the Annenberg sisters may be there. Rose Kennedy might show up. And so on. Very definitely, Sotheby Parke Bernet will be an important place to see and be seen on the 7th of May.

title: FOOD
description: WHEN your shopping list in eludes imported linguine, fresh snow peas. celery root, a standing rib roast. spanakopita and stoneground wheat flour, how many stops will you have to make :n order to find everything? Just one if you head for Bongiorno's in Stamford.

title: On Mali's Niger, Slow Boat To Timbuktu
description: I had become addicted to outoftheway places: the headwaters of the Amazon, the Khyber Pass, the ox trails of Burma. Now two muchtraveled friends were calling. Vyvian, a teacher from upstate New York, had bought a Land Rover; together with Connie, an anthropologist, she was planning to drive all over Africa. Would I care to come along for part of the tripto Timbuktu?

title: Moffitt: 5Year Pact
description: CASA GRANDE, Ariz., March 5 (AP) Randy Moffitt, relief pitcher, signed a fiveyear contract with the San Francisco Giants today, for a reported $600,000.

title: B1 Flies First Test With Missile
description: WHITE SANDS, N.M., March 5 (UPI)A B1 bomber has taken its first flight with an unarmed shortrange attack missite in preparation for the scheduled launching of a live missile in June. A spokesman at the White Sands Missile Range said the bomber took off yesterday from Edwards Air Force Base in California, flew a mission over the southern New Mexico missile range and returned to Edwards.

title: Keeping James Waring's Choreography Alive
description: A year ago, the choreographer James Waring died at the age of 53 after a short illness which was as virulant as it was unexpected. At the time, he was not maintaining his own company; nor did he have any opportunity to make any of the normal arrangements for his artistic legacy, so his work was destined to be confined to the footnotes of history.

title: Unsoldierly Soldiers In New Nichols Play
description: LONDON Of the concertparty of soldiers touring 1949 Malaya in Peter Nichols's new play, Privates on Parade, one or two, to be sure, are snugly heterosexual; the others are ostentatiously not, and the star of the show is a captain whose specialty is fulldrag imitations of Marlene Dietrich and Carmen Miranda. You dare speak to an officer like that, squawks this wigged apparition at an insolent subordinate, and I'll scream the house down.

title: Transcript of Questions and Answers in President Carter's CallIn
description: MODERATOR. Good day. President Carter and I are in the socalled Oval Office of the While House. We're in a couple of wingback chairs in front of a coffee table. And in front of the fireplace across from us is the desk at which the President spends much of his day working; over to the left the large doors opening out onto the beautiful Rose Garden of the White House on a very nice springlike day here in Washington.

title: Janet Christenfeld to Be Wed To Peter A. Turkell in Autumn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley S. Christenfeld of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Louise Christenfeld, to Peter Arthur Turkell, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Turkell of Woodmere, L. I., and Hallandale, Fla, An autumn wedding planned.

title: Herbs to Grow for Refreshing Cups of Tea
description: The high price of coffee is encouraging many to consider other sorts of hot reviving drinks. For me, many herbs make healthful, refreshing teas. Some I find are more desirable than others.

title: A Timely Step in Electric Rates
description: THE article Time for TimeofDay Rates [Feb. 6] reported a great deal of opposition, some doubts and little apparent joy over the new tariff introduced by. the Long Island Lighting Company for its large commercial and industrial customers. The Environmental Defense Fund has pressed for just such utility rate reforms across the nation for over five years and is convinced that they make good sense. Two years ago we petitioned the New York Public Service Commission for timeofday electric rates based on today's cost experience.

title: Iowa Wrestlers Capture 4th Big Ten Title in Row
description: MADISON, Wis., March 5 (AP) Iowa grabbed five individual titles, including a second consecutive 177pound championship by Chris Campbell, and rolled up 107 points today to capture the Big Ten wrestling championship with ease.

title: State Aids Errant Drivers
description: MORE than 1,000 of the 20,000 motorists in the state whose drivers licenses have been suspended for at least six months because of drunken driving have already applied for their reinstatement under a bill that Governor Byrne has signed into law, and the Division of Motor Vehicles expects that it will soon be swamped with reauests.

title: ...But the Army Of Volunteers Is Worried
description: WASHINGTONFour years after the draft was ended, the first serious questions are being raised, within the military and in Congress. about whether the nation can continue to maintain a two millionman military force on a volunteer basis.

title: A Ranger. Tells Of a Romance With a Big City
description: A very, very short time ago, when was a teenager, I came to this big city of New York. Many people told me it was scary, cold, unfriendly and, more than that, intimidating.

title: Luxury Of St. Moritz
description: The morning sky is gray, the streets drifting with fog. The Swiss train is quiet, a smooth gliding snake slipping through Zurich's streets and out to the mountains. As we climb, the sun comes out, and the train begins to move alternately through sunlight and the rattling blackness of tunnels: We are moving higher into the mountains but seem only to move deeper into them.

title: World News Briefs
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 5 (AP)The Government Prosecutor's Office today indicted the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the church's pharmaceutical subsidiary and six of its officers on tax evasion charges. The indictments charge that the II Hwa Pharmaceutical Company evaded $6 million in taxes in connection with the production and export of ginseng tea.

title: Will New York Always Be on the Brink?
description: New York City's brush with insolvency in late 1973 put into place a jerrybuilt structure of Federal loans and municipal labor union aid to meet its credit needs for two and a half years. That was considered barely enough time for the city to reenter the regular borrowing markets that had abruptly closed when bankruptcy seemed imminent.

title: Robert De NiroThe Return Of the Silent Screen Star
description: In front of a palatial estate in Bel Air, tires crunch on the gravel parking lot and an unsteady saxophone howls the last bars of Misty in the cool evening air. That's Bobby, notes an early dinner guest. He's practicing for New York, New York, the film about big bands he's shooting with Marty Scorsese.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: THEATER
description: STAMFORD'S HARTMAN Theater Company must feel very secureit has allowed competition to open directly across the street for a threeplay season. Housed in a cinderblock rectangle that seats 99 people on folding chairs, The Company Storeas the members of the Hartman Theater Conservatory, a two year professional training program, call themselveshas burst into life. The opening show is Olympian Games, a highly imaginative and slightly flippant retelling of the stories of mytholo gy, in the manner of Story Theater. It is the work of Barbara Damashek (music and lyrics), Kenneth Cavander (book) and Larry Arrick (direction), all of the Hartman.

title: EDGAR SMITH PLANS A PLEA OF INSANITY
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 27Edgar H. Smith Jr.. who attained national notoriety during the r4 years he spent on New Jersey's death row for killing a high school girl, is hoping that a plea of insanity will save him from going back to prison to serve a mandatory life sentence for kidnapping.

title: Parks Budget Needs a Little More Green
description: WESTCHESTER'S budgets all Look a beating this year, but the Parks, Recreation and Conservation Department's operating budget has been cut 25 percent, and a big hunk removed from its parks budget for capital projects.

title: A Line for Black Bassin a Diary
description: AN unprecedented and comprehensive fouryear study of the life and habits of the black bass, the state's most popular fish for freshwater fishermen, is about to begin.

title: INTERVIEW
description: MENLO PARK, CALIF. THE POLICE DEPARTMENT of Stamford is in for a thorough, businesslike modernization if Victor Cizanckas, the police chief of this small suburb south of San Francisco, is approved by Stamford's Board of Representatives as their new police chief.

title: GARDENING
description: MARCH is sort of an inventory montha look back and a look forward to summer garden plans. Will there be a vegetable patch this year? Because of poor harvests from last season's efforts, there may be some Westchester County gardeners who decide to give up vegetables this summer and go all out for flowers.

title: Doreen McFarland to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William McFarland of Montville, N. J.. have announced the engagement of their daughter. Doreen Ann McFarland, to Alan Francis Herdan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Berdan of Natick, Mass. Miss McFarland and her fianc are seniors at Fairfield University.

title: ExJeweler Sentenced in Loan Plot
description: Howard E. Saft, a New York businessman, has received a threeyear prison sentence in a whitecollar crime case involving millions of dollars of bank loans for a jewelry company that went bankrupt.

title: SHOP TALK
description: COUNTLESS people who heard about the Banksville Farmer's Market and tried it on the weekend won't set foot in the place again. The market is open Thursday through Sunday, and Thursday is the only time to go. The crates of fresh produce are brought in Thursday morning and the handful of shoppers that show up that day scarcely make a dent in the stacks of greens, piles of fruit and bins of tubers. By Saturday or Sunday the aisles will be choked with people and the produce well picked over. The weekend shopper elbows in only to be faced with rejects.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: 2 Die as Liberian Ship Sinks
description: KOBE, Japan, March 5 (P)A Librarian freighter carrying Canadian wheat collided with another cargo ship and sank in rough seas off western Japan yesterday, the Maritime Safety Agency reported. The agency said two crew members aboard the Eastern Rose were killed and two were missing.

title: Completed In 1976
description: Buildings Projected for 1979 and Later

title: Pamela R. Goldman Married To Bruce Irwin Silberman
description: Pamela Rae Goldman, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Julius Goldman of Charlotte, N. C., was married last evening to Bruce Irwin Silberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Silberman of Statesville. N. C. Rabbi Richard Rocklin performed the ceremony In Charlotte's Temple Israel.

title: New Products for the Home
description: Aselfcontained fluorescent light that has no separate bulb or tube, and no separate ballast, starter or other parts that will ever need repair or replacement, has just been introduced by General Electric. Called Bright Stik, and measuring 25 inches in length, this fluorescent lighting unit needs no separate fixture and comes ready to install and plug in anywhere that a stick of light is needed. Producing as much light as a 50Watt light bulb, but consuming only 33 watts, it will last from three to five years (5,000 hours), according to the manufacturer, and carries a suggested selling price of $13.50. When the bulb burns out, the entire unit is discarded. Much smaller and slimmer than a conventional fluorescent fixture with tube, Bright Stik weighs only nine ounces (compared with three to four pounds for a normal 20watt fluorescent), and its deluxe white tube has a warm color similar to that of incandescent lighting. It is easily installed in kitchens, study areas and workhops with the hardware supplied.

title: New Character Steps on Stage In Fiscal Play
description: New York City's fiscal dramas seem to unfold according to a routine that is remarkably familiar, if not predictable. Bankers demand, labor leaders deplore, and in the middle sit Mayor Beame and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who have held so many joint news conferences in the last few months that they must feel like cohosts in a television talk show. It thus surprised some people when Mr. Beame and Mr. Goldin were joined at recent news conferences by a new presence, one that has not made itself felt in fiscal affairs lately: Paul O'Dwyer, the City Council President.

title: 7 Inmates Complete Journalism Course
description: BALTIMORE, March 5 (AP)Seven inmates at the Maryland Penitentiary, serving sentences ranging from 20 years to doublelife imprisonment, have received certificates for completing the prison's first journalism course

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: A Case of Arrested Adolescent Development

title: Letters
description: Driving home a point

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: Almost every bowler has started by using the pin bowling method and continued with it, maybe for years. It may be the most difficult habit that must be broken.

title: Brian Faulkner Buried
description: MAGHERA, Northern Ireland, March 5 (AP)Brian Faulkner, former Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, was buried Saturday near the rolling Ulster farmland where he loved to hunt. The 56yearold Lord Faulkner, a former leader of the Unionist Party, died Thursday when his horse slipped during a stag hunt.

title: In Memoriam
description: BRITTJacqueline Sue (Jackie). March 6, 1974. Beloved daughter and loving sister. We shared you for such little while, God grant we meet again. We love you and miss you more each

title: 2 Die as Lauda Wins So. Africa Race
description: KYALAMI, South Africa, March 5The South African Grand Prix, won today by Niki Lauda of Austria in Ferrari R312B, was marred by a bizarre accident in which a Welsh driver, Tom Pryce, and a South African track marshal were killed.

title: Eggs to Crow Over
description: When Mrs. D. Scott Severns decided to have a buffet supper after the recent concert in honor of Marian Anderson and Young Audiences, she also decided to use as a centerpiece a plain white plate with a dozen eggs around the rim.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Curing the Malaise Of Simsbury Housewife

title: Allen Ginsberg Charms at Cabaret
description: Allen Ginsberg, who was at the Other End last night, is not normally thought of as a nightclub entertaineror even as a musician. But not only did he hold forth in those capacities, he also may have started a trend of 1960's cult figures descending on Greenwich Vilage nightspots, since Timothy Leery has been booked into the Bottom Line on April 25 and 26.

title: Good skate
description: Even before she gets out of bed the morning, Barbara Williams is tired, because lately she has been skating in her sleep. Counting up the hours she workssix days weekat the two Long Island rinks where she's direc for and skating instructor. Barbara Williams figures she spends more Intl rs on ice than on ordinary ground. She's at Superior lee Rink. most mornings. by 8 o'clock, coaching the South Shore Youth Hockey League on fast takeoffs, reminding members of the Beaver Dam League to bend their knees, or teaching a class of 4yearolds how to fall down. Then Barbara Williams heads for the Racquet and Rink club, in Farmingdale, L.I.a drive she makes wearing blade guards snapped over her size 3 hockey skates, because it's too much of a bother to change into shoes. And by noon she's on the ice again, with it different, and somewhat beefierlooking set of studentsthe New York Islanders hockey team.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n.
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Ivory Wins Long Jump, Maryland Leads in IC4A
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 5Dennis Ivory wasn't satisfied. No, sir. He won a second consecutive IC4A indoor title in the long jump today, but had expected something more than 24 feet 4 inches.

title: LETTER FROM HOFSTRA
description: ANYONE who arrives on the Hofstra University campus at 8:55 in the morning for a 9 o'clock class is resigned to defeat. By then, the only parking spaces left are those on the extreme northern tip of the campus, on a runwaycumparking lot, a vestige of the old Mitchel Field military complex.

title: Stories Told in Stone
description: WHEN early Christian settlers on the Island buried their dead in the 17thand 18thcentury graves behind church or, perhaps, in woods overlooking the sea, they marked the graves with carved stones reflecting how they viewed life and death. The beautiful, curious designs cut in the stones show a unique cross section of thought, carving and history from all over the Northeast of colonial America. The old grave yards throughout the Island are a kind of living museum and, with information only they can tell us, an important cultural resource now badly in need of attention.

title: Unfinished Bicentennial
description: THERE is one corner in Westchester where the Yonkers fiscal crisis is not an issue and controversies over zoning barely matterBehind the door at 43 Read Avenue in Crestwood, the British are still riding up Lake Street White Plains, trying to outflank and capture George Washington; the phenomenon of railroads is changing the life amid the hills and valleys of the county: Indians are still massacring settlers, and shillings and sovereigns are clattering down on barrelheads because American Express and Master Charge do not yet exist.

title: Connors Tops Nastase In 4 Sets for $250,000
description: DORADO BEACH, P.R., March 5For a player whose nickname is Nasty, it was a sweetheart of a battle plan: Let Jimmy Connors destroy himself. Hit him lobs, chops, spins, whatever he's apt to whack into the net or out of bounds with his overstated attack.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey 34th show. Racetrack Grandstand Building, the Meadowlands. East Rutherford, N.J.; 1,900 dogs; 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: The Real Music Of Roots
description: Alex Haley writes about music affectionately and vividly in Roots, his bestselling account of the successful search for his African ancestry. Talking drums send their messages from Juffure, the West African village where Haley's greatgreatgreatgreatgreat grandfather Kunta Kinte is born and spends his youth, to neighboring communities. At festival time. young Kinte and his playmates march around the village playing wooden flutes and bells while professional musicians perform on drums, African xylophones called balaphons, and 24stringed kora harplutes. Everywhere there is singing. Later, when Kunia Kinte is kidnapped by slave traders and carried off to America, there are other sounds, including banjos, fiddles, and the collective wail of spiritual singing.

title: Callaghan to Seek Close Ties to Carter in U.S. Talks
description: LONDON, March 5Prime Minister James Callaghan sets out for the United States next week in the hope of forging as close a relationship with President Carter as he had with former President Gerald R. Ford.

title: Certain Key Firms Know Where the Power Is, and How to Influence Its Application
description: As government at all levels grows more complex and pervasive. reaching far into the affairs of individuals and business, a growing number of politically connected lawyers are prospering by offering access to the decisionmakers.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: College Results
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL

title: Letters: A Detour For Bobby Burns
description: To the Editor:

title: Karmen the King Of the Jingle
description: HOLDING a foamcovered hammer poised over a huge Chinese bronze gong, Steve Karmen said: We are not ready for the short doughnut yet.

title: LETTER FROM MERCY COLLEGE
description: The students at Mercy College care about ideas. That becomes evident not only from the personal involvement with issues we feel, but also from the articles have received from them during my editorship this year of the campus newspaper.

title: Brazil Shifts Coaches to Perk World Cup Effort
description: The news from Brazil, the land of soccer and coffee, is that the national game is in a state worse than $5 a pound. The country's problems started two weeks ago when the national team, which captured the American Bicentennial Cup last sum mer rather impressively. played Colombia to scoreless tie in Bogota. The problem was that the game counted toward the World Cup, two words worshiped by Brazilians. What. left an even more bitter taste was Paraguay's 10 victory over Colombia in Bogota last Sunday. Paraguay is the third nation in the group, only one of which advances to the finals in Argentina neat summer.

title: 12Meter Rivals Set to Start Warmups
description: The 12Meter yachts Enterprise and Intrepid begin six days of match racing Tuesday off San Diego in preparation for the America's Cup trials this summer. They will race shortened versions of the 24mile course off Newport, R.I., according to Edward News du Moulin, 12Meter coordinator for the Fort Schuyler of Foundation of Maritime Boating College, which owns both yachts. These trials won't necessarily show one Twelve as being faster than another. I don't think Lowell North will let them know much about Enterprise yet, says du Moulin, chuckling.

title: This Week in Sports
description: High School Basketball

title: Are Swiss Gnomes Guarding the Franc?
description: For a few hours last Tuesday, visions of an economic doomsday crossed the screens of moneymarket monitors in the world's foreignexchange house. The value of the Swiss franc was falling, and Swiss monetary managers were doing nothing about it.

title: Figure Skating
description: WORLD CHAMPIONSHIPS Mon's Singles Final

title: Skiing
description: AT SUN VALLEY, IDAHO WORLD CUP Men's Slalom

title: Last Shot by Holy Cross Upsets Providence, 6867
description: HARTFORD, March 5Chris Potter, a young man who grew up in the Bronx and attended Cardinal Spellman High School there, got Holy Cross into the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship tournament today.

title: A starcrossed childhood
description: Haywire is a Hollywood childhood memoir, a glowing tapestry spun with equal parts of gold and pain.
