As a hook it is an absolute beautya Hollywood beauty, to be precisewith all the charm that term implies, the deceptive simplicity, the complex hidden machinery and, above all, the terrible cost.

title: Williams the Star in 9382 Irish Victory
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 5Twentynine and one.

title: Endpaper
description: Edited By Glenn Collins

title: For This Gentle Giant, the Cello Is a Way of Life
description: Lynn Harrell doesn't know where his cello playing begins and his life lets off, and that's the way he likes it. The towering young musician, who gives a sonata recital this afternoon at Alice Tully Hall with James Levine as the pianist, believes that an artist who compartmentalizes his work stunts it, and eventually smothers it. This is a strong belief of mine. I do feel that the way one runs his entire life, what one does all the day long, mentally and physically, has a bearing on what kind of art is produced. The kind of music that seems to be created on the spot, rather than imitatively reproduced, can happen only through a direct communication of the spirit, and that happening can only result if the whole balance of the personality is full, respectful, cultured andturned on.

title: A New Salvo From Kelley
description: EUGENE R. KELLEY'S broadside attack on Special State Prosecutor Alfred J. Scotti, Suffolk District Attorney Henry F. O'Brien and the entire state Democratic party organization last Monday has left the Police Commissioner's fellow Suffolk Republicans shaking their heads with dismay and anger.

title: The Green Miracle of March
description: It's really a matter of proportion, relative to the season. In another two months bees and blossoms and balmy air will be taken for granted. There will be much green that another new shoot or another bright leaf will go unnoticed. But right now the sight of a crocus bud poking through the cold soil or a few pale green tips of daffodils are reason for exclamation and delight. Spring!

title: Back to Basic Heating
description: HE WHO CUTS his own firewood warms himself twice. We've gone that old saying one better since installing a woodburning stove in our house. When the oil bill arrives each month, it is so low that our hearts, too, are warmed.

title: They Call It Retirement
description: The recipe is this: Take a couple of socalled retired people, longtime summer residents who have settled into a suburban or rural community full time. Confront them with a local problemsay, the potential razing of a historic and handsome churchand blend in equal parts of indignation, enthusiasm, concern, initiative and savvy. While mixing well, add a leavening of humor and a goodly dollop of the ability to get people to pitch in and help.

title: It's Poetry, It's Art, But It's Just a Game
description: The athletic aesthetic is a tricky thing. Roy Blount, a journalist and writer of football books, once rhapsodized that football is like improvisational theater . . . football is like sculpture . . . football is like music . . . football is like poetry. Olga Korbut, the pixiecute Soviet gymnast who made a big splash in the 1972 Olympics, took one look at the object of Blount's love and said, What a mess these people are doing on the ground.

title: Mahre  Brothers Finish 1, 3 in Cup Slalom Event
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 5  In keeping with a kind of tradition that America's top men skiers are best at home sites  Phil and Steve Mahre, the 19yearold twins from White Pass, Wash., provided a surprise ending today to World Cup competition with a 1, 3 finish.

title: Book Ends
description: Christopher. Down here on a visit recently was Christopher Isherwood, whose latest book is Christopher and His Kind, a retrospective gloss on the Berlin years upon which Goodbye to Berlin was based. Just as the Berlin stories underwent many subsequent transmogrificationsplay (I Am a Camera), movie, musical (Cabaret)  so Mr. Isherwood's version of his life has gone through changes, the main one being, in Christopher and His Kind, a more open discussion of his homosexuality. Earlier I could have written a hook with those admissions. he told us. which are terribly mildand got it published and probably sold a lot of copies. But 20 years ago it would have been more of productiona J'accuse. Now these things I talk about have been known for years and people say, So what?

title: What Famous Designers Have to Say About Faces
description: Most of the time, of course, fashion designers are concerned with how a woman looks below the neck. They would like her to watch her calories and go to gym classes and have the sort of figure that does right by their clothes.

title: College Basketball
description: AT GARDEN

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHILE growing up in Princeton, Christopher Reeve, young actor recalls, friend he will identify only as Roger used to regularly beat the hell out of me. What Roger didn't knoW is that he was thrashing someone who would one day be that marvel of strength, Supermanat least in the movies.

title: Reed Is Set to Get Coaching Job
description: Red Holzman, the coach of the only two Knick teams to win National Basketball Association championships, announced his retirement yesterday, effective at the end of the season.

title: Mayoral Race In Paris Shows Chaos Leading
description: PARIS, March 4It is a basket of crabs, said one City Hall official of the Paris mayoralty campaign, now in fullswing confusion, after more than a century in which the capital had no mayor at all.

title: Redwoods Are CrossPollinated; Goal Is Better Commercial Crop
description: BERKELEY, Calif.After four years of experimentation, a forestry team from the University of California has succeeded in crosspollinating two specimens of the majestic Coastal redwood, a first step toward possibly creating superior tree in commercially valuable quantities.

title: Butt Helps Conteh Win Title Bout
description: LIVERPOOL, England, March 5With some ifs, no ands and one definite butt, John Conteh retained his World Boxing Council lightheavyweight title tonight in a 7minute6second bout against Len Hutchins of Detroit.

title: 2D F.A.L.N, WITNESS RULED IN CONTEMPT
description: Maria T. Cueto, the former director of the Protestant Episcopal Church's National Commission on Hispanic Affairs, was ruled in contempt of court yesterday for her refusal to testify before a Federal grand jury that is looking into terrorist bombings claimed by the F.A.L.N.

title: TV VIEW
description: Before going into selfimposed exile from his native Sweden last year, following a humiliat ing dispute with government officials over taxes, Ingmar Bergman confided to an interviewer: I live on a small island, Faroe, in the Baltic Sea, with mostly farmers and fishermen. For the first time, they really liked something had done. They discussed it with me on the ferryboat the island. . . . Nothing I have done means anything until two other people start talking about it on the basis their experience. That something was a series of six 50minute episodes called Scenes From a Marriage. Surprisingly, the project was created and produced for television, a fact that continues to confound those who insist on underestimating both the solid achievements and the potential of the medium. Here was one of the world's foremost filmmakers turning intentionally to television and fashioning a work of immense popularity and stunning artistic achievement.

title: Fun with the C.I.A.
description: To hear David Atlee Phillips tell it, serving as a covert operator for the C.I.A. was a barrel of fun, a sort of freefloating pantyraid where the dirty tricks were played by the fellows in the frat house mostly on each other. Remember the time a Chief of Station in Latin America got drunk and stole the Ambassador's Thanksgiving turkeys? A real sidesplitter. Or the 34foot snake a C.I.A. man zipped up into a bag in Peru? Or the time when Big Dave Phillips was station chief in Rio and they had this party and poured champagne out the windown?

title: Chicago Gives Its Fans A Show Within a Show
description: Big, bold and colorful enough to draw 50,000 enthusiastic fans twice each year, the International Kennel Club of Chicago allbreed dog shows are encircled by a raw aura of Western warmth in keeping with the bustling tempo of the city. Since 1971 entries have been running well over 3,000 and a turnout in this vicinity is again expected for the twoday Spring edition scheduled for April 2 and 3 in the fiveblock International Amphitheatre on South Halsted Street. Larry Caine, the man backstage putting the shows together, believes in giving the crowds entertainment along with the nation's superstars of dogdom. This year I'm bringing in Willie Necker of Wheeling, Ill., a worldrenowned dog trainer with his circusperforming team of Dalmatians, the Amphitheatre manager said.

title: Drillers Reach Trapped Miner; Dull Bits Had Slowed Rescue Bid
description: TOWER CITY, Pa., March 5A rescue team reached a miner trapped for more than four days in a flooded anthracite coal mine here and began efforts to bring him to the surface.

title: Action Against Sheriff Is Weighed
description: Governor Carey's office is considering charges against Sheriff Lawrence . Quinlan of Dutchess County that could lead to the first expulsion of an elected official by a Governor in New York State in 40 years.

title: Political Prisoners In Indian Jails Planning a 24Hour Hunger Strike
description: NEW DELHI, March 5Over 15,000 political prisoners held in jails all over India will go on a 24hour hunger strike March 10.

title: Brian H. Bodkin to Wed Karen Ross on May 28
description: Mr. and Mrs. James R. Ross of Seaford. L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Marie Ross, to Brian Hamilton Bodkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Bodkin of Merrick. L.I.

title: UNITED STATES VERSUS
description: When Al Goldstein, who publishes Screw magazine in New York, found he was going to be tried in Wichita, he didn't think much of his chances. When he heard about the grand jury proceedings, he thought even less. The door to the bankruptcy courtroom in Wichita's Federal building where the grand jury was deliberating was open when a lawyer on Goldstein's defense staff happened to pass by. What he saw stunned him. The jurors had their hands clasped and their heads bowed. They were asking the Lord for divine guidance in their task of indicting Al Goldstein. How did Al Goldstein, New York publisher, come to be on trial in Wichita, Kan.? How did Harry Reems, a New York actor, come to be on trial in Memphis, Tenn.? The story begins with a Supreme Court ruling in 1973.

title: La Salle Falls, 9281, in E.C.C. Final
description: EASTON, Pa., March 5Early today, it was announced that Rich Laurel of Hofstra had been chosen by the coaches of the East Coast Conference as the league's most valuable player. This afternoon, the 6foot7inch senior forward from Philadelphia showed why he deserved the honor.

title: Syria and Egypt Are Boss
description: JERUSALEMFrom the Rabat conference of Arab states in October, 1974 to the fall of the Tell Zaatar camp Beirut almost exactly two years later, the Palestine Liberation Organization indisputably led and spoke for the Palestinian people. During this period, the principle Palestinian selfdetermination was recognized by the United Nations on the organization's terms even though the Palestinians rejected Israel's rights to political sovereignty. But the Liberation Organization's role in Lebanon, where it was still engaged in fighting last week, was ruinous to the movement and alerted most Arab states to the dangers a radical force rolling around the area like an unexploded grenade. Today the organization is physically at the mercy of Syria, politically controlled by Syria and Egypt and may be forced into a diplomatic partnership with Jordan.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABCAM: Message of Israel. Address by RabbiEmeritus Hyman Judah Schachtel of Temple Beth Israel, Houston, Texas.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Puppet Show for Children
description: An original puppet show about a little girl who dreams she meets the Ice Cream Monster in the Land of Ice Cream will be presented on March 16 at 3:30 P.M.! at Brooklyn's Central Library at Grand Army Plaza. A children's librarian wrote! the script as well as an I Like Ice Cream song which other library staffers have set to music. Tickets, required for admission. may be picked up in advance at the Children's Room at the library.

title: Robert Birdsong Jr. To Wed Lee Morris
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Rufus Morris of Dersingham, England, and Gladwyne, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lee Frances Morris, to Robert Boyd Birdsong Jr.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Birdsong of Caldwell and Normandy Beach, N.J.

title: Paris! Paris!
description: By Irwin Shaw and Ronald Searle.

title: New and Noteworthy
description: THE GENTLE TASADAY, by John Nance. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $5.95.) What happened to a totally isolated, peaceable Philippine tribe when it was discovered by civilization: an account by a newspaperman involved in the confrontation.

title: Buying American foreign policy
description: Russell Warren Howe and Sarah Hays Trott, good journalist plumbers, have held their nose and rooted out some very unpleasant stuff about lobbyists and foreign affair Everywhere there is money. Justin ?? experts, they tell us ?? that over one hundred million dollars (up from thirty million dollars a decade ago) are spent each year by foreign governments and corporation. on shaping U.S. foreign policy and influencing policymakers ?? and they properly remind us that th?? money is being spent to subvert our wishes, for most successful lobbies represent minority opinions, and enforce policy. making decisions m which most Americans are either opposed or indiffer

title: KOREA LOBBY INQUIRY SHIFTS TO TAX AREAS
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Justice Department investigators, encountering difficulties in their attempts to obtain solid evidence of bribery in their investigation of alleged influencebuying by the South Korean Government, have begun to concentrate on possible tax violations by Congressmen, a number of Government sources said today.

title: HAS THE FIRSTAMENDMENT MET ITS MATCH?
description: According to Larry Flynt, all he ever wanted to do was become a millionairewhether by robbing a bank or by publishing a magazine. Yet almost overnight, the publisher of Hustler has become a strange and unlikely symbol to the continuing controversy over freedom of the press. Gruff, paunchy and swaggering, Mr. Flynt makes no bones about the purpose of his magazine. wanted to talk about sex the way we talked about it on the farm, at the factory and in the Navy, he says. Last month in Cincinnati. Mr. Flynt was sentenced to 7 In 25 years in jail for pandering obscenity and engaging in organized crime (the latter charge flowing from the former as the result of a conspiracylike statute in state law). Immediately, Larry Flynt became the center of an tense debate in the liberalminded world of letters and law.

title: Miss Evert Extended
description: SAN FRANCISCO March 5 (AP)Chris Evert needed all her skills to beat Betty Stove of the Netherlands, 76, 64, in the quarterfinals of the $100,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament last night.

title: State Aid And the Schools
description: IN a few days, more than 500 local and regional school districts in New Jersey will be presenting their 197778 budgets to the people of their communities for a vote. About 65 percent of the budgets were defeated last year,

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHEN Jonathan Sherman first came to the Island in 1935, the great aircraft industries of Farmingdale were just getting under way. Between Farmingdale and Hempstead, it was mostly potatoes. And, he added, we had coal steam engines on the Long Island Rail Road.

title: U.S. SUES T.W.A., CHARGING U.S. ASKS U.N. BODY TO SEEK FAILURE TO DETECT GUNS REPORTS ON SOVIET ARRESTS
description: Trans World Airlines was sued last week in Federal Court in Brooklyn by the Federal Government for having failed to detect handguns and a sword in the carryon luggage of four passengers.

title: The Push Pin conspiracy
description: ratefully, no doubt. considering the unlikely circumstances of its origin, The Push Pin Graphic will celebrate its 20th anniversary on March 24 with a retrospective exhibit of past issues at the Mead Gallery in New York City. The Graphic is one of the least known periodicals of its lime, except to its small audience, which views it either as counterrevolutionary or irrelevant. (The February number, its most recent, has 32 pages of drawings and text devoted to The Complete History and Knowledge of the World.) It is mailed free to its several thousand readers, but none of them. however they may regard it, will pay as much attention to what it says, as to what it shows.

title: Bossisma Theme Played Up and Down
description: POLITICAL bosses clearly constitute a potential issue in the bitter and unprecedented struggle over the Republican nomination for Nassau County Executive. The Republican county chairman, Joseph M. Margiotta, has decided on the basis of polls and informal soundings to attempt to deny renomination to the incumbent County Executive, Ralph G. Caso, and support instead the Hempstead Town Presiding Supervisor, FranCis T. Purcell.

title: Old Spaces and Odd Places Recycled for the Arts
description: ACENTURYOLD grainandfeed building has been conAverted into a theater for the Chappaqua Drama Group, and a former church, with pew backs for doors, provides ample space for the Rye Art Center. The mezzanine of the White Plains railroad station is the home (he Council for the Arts in Westchester, an elementary school Yorktown Heights that stood vacant for a year for lack students has been remodeled for the Yorktown Museum and Peekskill tiny castle houses cooperative cultural center.

title: SHOP TALK
description: ONE of the best ways to brighten a dull room or change the look of a drab one is with an accessory. Two shops that offer a wide range of eyecatching objects are Deva Designs in Livingston and HuffmanKoos in North Hackensack.

title: Red Smith
description: Luis Tiant, the revolving pitcher, was talking contract with the Red Sox management last week and Bob Woolf, the attorney who is his agent, was talking to the Harvard Law School Forum. Tiant told the people who run baseball in Boston that they hadn't kept Tom Yawkey's word and this rankled him. Woolf told the Felix Frankfurters and Oliver Wendell Holmeses of tomorrow that some agents for athletes had engaged in practices he deplored. Incidentally, a report has been circulated that Woolf was trying to renegotiate Tiant's contract although he has frequently spoken out against athletes who welsh on their agreements. The fact is, he and the pitcher are only trying to get what Yawkey promised when he signed Luis in 1976.

title: Boys High Wins Track, But May Lose a Coach
description: It should have been a happy moment for Jimmy Jackson. His Boys High team had just captured the Public Schools Athletic League indoor track championship at the 102d Engineers Armory, the first tide for Jackson since he took over the coahring reins in 1973.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$7.000, pace, mile.

title: Corrections
description: A caption on this page last week incorrectly identified the conductor of the Fairfield County Chorale. The conductor is Johannes Somary. The accompanying article contained a typographical error in the telephone number to he called for information on this evening's concert at St. Catherine of Sienna Church in Riverside. The correct number is 2032263687.

title: Memory Of the Montafon
description: In the final section of A Moveable Feast, Ernest Hemingway's rich memoir of getting started in Paris in the 1920's, he wrote about Schruns and other neighboring villages of the 15milelong Montafon Valley on the SwissAustrian border.

title: Behind Pro Football's Labor Peace: A Conversation Over Steak Dinner
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI)Sometimes you play things so close to the vest, you can't see your own cards. So we gave them a little peek at our hand and they gave us a peek at theirs and it worked.

title: Appeal on Behalf of Rudolf Hess Sent to Carter by ExJailkeeper
description: WEST BERLIN, March 5 (Reuters)The former United States commandant at Spandau jail here appealed to President Carter today to release the prison's only inmate. Rudolph Hess.

title: Staying Together in the Skies and on Skis
description: It would seem that Jessie Farrington and her relatives have gone to quite an extreme to maintain a family spirit. The 27yearold Mrs. Farrington, her husband, Jeff, her brother and her 62yearold father all have pilots licenses, all ski and all sky dive. Put that together and you have a family of paraskiers. Para  what? Paraskiers. An esoteric sport, paraskiing combines giantslalom ski racing with parachute jumping.

title: Life in a TermPaper Factory
description: GHOSTWRITING can be glamorous profession when one's client is a politician, in show business or an inarticulate scientific genius. But my brand of ghostwriting is considered by many to be immoral, if not illegal.

title: Bailing Out Our Banks Abroad
description: The nation's foreign policy in the third world is being shaped by a complex banking problem that requires immediate attention. American banks have loaned almost $50 billion to less developed countries. With the increased price of oil, these countries are running larger deficits than the bankers had expected. Their economies have not adjusted to the postembargo world, and many of them will have trouble paying their debts when they fall due in unusual volumein 1978 and 1979. Normally banker can tell a client to tighten up, and work with him to clear his debts. But the kind of strict corrective policy that would Satisfy a banker could produce street riots in a poor country, and add political and diplomatic problems to those of economics. In any case, the worldwide problem is fast outrunning the private banks capacity to cope.

title: Nancy Weinberger Fiancee of Alan J. Isserlis
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Weinberger of Woodmere, L.L, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Lizbeth Weinberger, to Alan Joseph Isserlis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Isserlis of Syracuse.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: For sheer futility, the Paris peace talks of 1968 were among the outstanding losers of history. They opened in early May as a mutual and serious movement by all parties toward peace M Southeast Asia. While the long war ground on in Vietnam, the talks soon settled into endless arguments over the shape of the peace table.

title: Criminals At Large
description: A couple of years ago it was a shark. A couple of months ago it was a pair of maneating tigers released on the British moors. Now meet Moby Alligator, in ALLIGATOR by Shelley Katz (Dell, paper, $1.95). Naturally it was Peter Benchley's Jaws that spawned this book, except that Katz carries the Melville symbolism a few steps further. Where the giant shark was mostly brute predator, the giant alligator seems to be a relentless dark angel with some kind of intelligence and with specific victims picked out.

title: BOOKS
description: Much was expected from the second edition of The Handbook of Modern Accounting. both because the first edition was acknowledged as the leading reference work in the field and because the credentials of the editors are outstanding.

title: Misdirected Calls Reach Wisconsin
description: Otto Flaig thought at first it was Joke. but quite a few citizens of Wisconsin kept telephoning him yesterday and asking for President Carter.

title: Joseph M. McGuinness, 61, Director of an Insurance Agency
description: Joseph M. McGuinness, treasurer and a director of the John F. Curry Agency Inc., 225 Broadway, an insurance agency, died Friday at his home In Queens. He was 61 years old and liver at 2616 166th Street.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: If the city fathers of New York are angered by the reluctance of the city's hanks to lend them more money and alleviate the ongoing fiscal crisis, they need look no farther than Walter Bigelow Wriston to find a scapegoat for their woes.

title: Carol L. Eaton Is Engaged to Roger D. London
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Eaton of New York City and Gallatin, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Louise Eaton, to Roger David London, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert D. London of Pound Ridge, N. Y.

title: Dr. Finley vs. the Hospitals
description: DR. JOANNE E. FINLEY, the state's Commissioner of Health, is preparing for another battle with New Jersey's hospitals. In the midst of experimenting with an entirely new way of paying hospitals for the care they provide, Dr. Finley also is attempting to extend the ratesetting authority of the state in an effort to achieve a more equitable sharing of the cost for those patients who cannot afford to pay for the care they receive.

title: Schools: Classes Shrink, Budgets Grow
description: DESPITE assurances of additional state aid from incometax revenue and declining enrollment, many New Jersey school districts are asking their mumcipalities for more money from local property taxes in their budgets for the 197778 fiscal year. There will be public hearings on the budgets this week.

title: Redmen Vanquish Seton Hall, 8373
description: St. John's, displaying control most of the time and abandon when necessary, advanced to the National Collegiate basketball tournament yesterday by defeating Seton Hall, 8373, at Madison Square Garden. With the victory. St. Johns took the Metropolitan Division Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference playoffs and won a spot in the 32team field for the N.C.A.A. competition that will begin next weekend. It is the 13th season in a row that St. John's will see postseason action.

title: The son of Love Story Oliver's Story
description: Erich Segal's Love Story was one of those perfect little pop entertain. rent machines, gears greased by schmaltz, purring and clicking as it delivered simulated sentiments like a Swiss townhall clock parading its figurines on the stroke of the hour. It served up a love affair between a rich WASP Harvard jock and a pretty, poor, dirtytalking dilutedethnic girl, in dialogue that was glib, contemporarycollegiate and sometimes funny.

title: Events Today
description: THE RELUCTANT DRAGON: Musical marionette show; 12:30 A d 3 P.M Cottage Marionette Theater, Swedish Cottage Central Park at Central Pack West near 81st Street. ( Admission free but contributions will be accept?? Phone reservations 930 9093) FILMS: Movies on flower hones on and plant ?? 1:30 and 3 P M., auditorium Brooklyn Botanic Garden 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: David>Buenos Aires: Is It Safe?;
description: The jet was delayed at Kennedy Airport for six hours. The travel agent who had secured our cutrate fares on Argentine Airlines ($636) apologized. There has been a problem. You have read the papers? He smiled helplessly.

title: My name in Tsoaitalee
description: The Names is an Indian book, but not a book about wrongs done to Indians. It is a search and a celebration, a book of identities and sources. Momaday is the son of parents who successfully bridged the gulf between Indian and white ways, but remain Indian. In boyhood Momaday made the same choice, and in making it gave himself the task of discovering and in some degree inventing the tradition and history in which he finds his most profound of himself.

title: The Easy Access to Medical Records
description: Beginning with the birth certificate and ending, a lifetime later, with the death certificate, every American is part of the medical records system.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Wood, Field, Stream: Bass Get Wider Play by Anglers
description: There was a time when the black bass was largely ignored by Northeast anglersexcept for a few devoteesbut during the last 10 years that has changed dramatically.

title: Making a Caesarean a Birth
description: CAN a Caesarean parent experience the same feelings about the birth process so often claimed by advocates of natural childbirth? Members of Westchester's Prepared Caesarean Parents Committee would like that answer to be yes.

title: For Lenny lovers Honey
description: Everybody has at least one book in them, or so they say. One can hope it does not have sharp edges, or weigh too much: a book should not be a potential medical problem to the author or her readers. However, Honey, by Honey Bruce, is bound to cause a few headaches and other unpleasant side effects (such as suddenly slamming the book to the table and rushing out to take an invigorating walk). One guesses that the editors of Playboy Press or somebody exerted their influence on Bruce and Benenson to insert chunks of tired pornprose into their literary endeavor, in order to appeal to a typical strokebook readership. To be fair, they have also thrown in some feminist jargon (feminists buy books too), plus a few secondhand mottoes for those shorn of hope and stuck on dope.

title: Vienna Savors Magnate's Scandal
description: VIENNA, March 5Investigations of art thefts in Austria and Yugoslavia that led to the arrest of a wealthy, politically connected young businessman have supplied this gossipy capital with one of its most bizarre scandals in years.

title: BEAME MEETS UNIONS TO DEVISE WAY TO PAY $1 BILLION NOTE DEBT
description: Mayoral aides and Municipal Assistance Corporation officials met all day yesterday at City Hall with union representatives in an effort to shape their own program to pay off the city's 31 billion moratorium debt, as the city's bankers pleaded for no unnecessary overreaction to their own proposal for budgetreview board.

title: Mother, Wife and
description: Suzanne Lindsay has a favorite necklace made of big navy beads and an old silver hashish box from Turkey. Once when she was wearing it, a policeman stopped and frisked her. Considering the way Suzanne usually dresses, howeveron an ordinary weekday she might wear the hashish  box necklace over a white silk shirt with a pair of navy Saint Laurent slacks, navy shoes and maybe a navy cashmere sweater tied around her neckit isn't likely that she's taken for a junkie very often. In fact, though she dropped a formal modeling career about five years ago. Suzanne is almost never out of the classic designer sportswear she once posed in for Glamour. Even when she's slumming around homea painstakingly converted former chicken coop in West Orange, N. J.she's apt to he wearing slacks and a shirt by Ralph Lauren and brown leather pumps from I. Miller.

title: Mark H. Matthews Becomes the Fiance Of Ann M. Devroy
description: Mrs. Turek Ryan of Green Bay, Wis., has announced the engagement of her daughter. Ann Mary Devroy, to Mark Howard Matthews, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Burrell Matthews of Scotch Plains. N.J.

title: The Kurt Weill Nobody Knows
description: September Song and Mack the Knife don't begin to tell the whole story! declared Lotte Lenya recently, punctuating the air with her everpresent cigarette and speaking with the strident yet magnetic quality that has endeared her to three generations of music lovers, The concert at Lincoln Center tomorrow night will present a very different and relatively unknown Kurt Weill. The audience is likely to be surprised, if not shocked.

title: Paris versus New York
description: In this corner, Paris. Fashion arbiter of the world. Purveyor of chic since the days of Louis XIV. Source of finery for women from Columbus, Ohio, to Abu Dhabi. And in this corner, New Yorkwith outposts in Boston, Dallas, Milwaukee, St. Louis, San Francisco and Los Angeles. Latecomer to the world of fine seams and silks. Inventor of massproduction techniques. Brass, aggressive, presumptuous. In fashion, the old world versus the new. How is the contest going?

title: INTERVIEW
description: RON TOCCI says his interest in power and energy began when he was a laborer in the construction trades. The cost of electricity always seemed to come up in one way or another, and it still does, he said.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: TRAVEL TRAVEL TRAVEL

title: College Law Enforcement Student Convicted in Mississippi Killing
description: INDIANOLA, Miss., March 5 (UPI)A 28yearold college law enforcement student was convicted of murder yesterday in the slaying of a teenager who allegedly raped his wife.

title: Civil Rights: An Active White House?
description: WASHINGTONCivil rights lawyers and lobbyists are turning away from the courts and to the Carter Administration for leadership in the drive toward racial and economic equality for black Americans because, they believe, they can no longer depend on the courts to advance their cause.

title: Katharine Hansen Wed to C. S. Ralston
description: Katharine Dole Hansen. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Leighton Hansen of Cazenovia, N. Y.. was married yesterday to Craig Stanley Ralston. son of Mrs. Paul MacDowell and John Stanley Ralston Jr., both of Denver. The Rev. Benjamin J. Lake performed the ceremony in Cazenovia's First Presbyterian Church.

title: MAILBAG
description: That was a curious piece of criticism by John Culhane, Where Documentaries Don't Dare to Tread(Feb. 20).

title: Vassar Protesters Ask Rules Against Racist Acts
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 5  A demonstration this week by 300 Vassar College students demanding the enactment of college regulations against any acts with racial overtones has brought a pledge from the college's president to support such regulations.

title: The Complete Guide to the Soviet Union
description: By Victor and Jennifer Louis. St. Martin's. $17.95.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, March 5 (UPI)Adoption of the 55milesanhour speed limit has saved at least 27,000 lives in the past three years, the National Safety Council said today.

title: ART
description: WILLIAM C. SEITZ was unquestionably one of the leading figures of art in America. Had he been only a scholar, he would be grandly remembered for his vital perceptions into the work of artists such as Monet, Turner and ToulouseLautrec.

title: Traveling in Fashion
description: What does a fashionconscious woman pack for a trip to Europe (or wherever) this summer on an economy flight with a baggage allowance of 44 poundsand a knowledge that even if she wanted to take more than two bags there are never enough porters at any airport anywhere in the world? Now can she cope with all those highly wrinkleprone linens and cottons that designers are showing? In the 1960's, when jet planes replaced luxury liners for most travelers, those uncrushable jersey dresses (Pucci silk jersey if you wanted to indulge yourself, Wilroy nylon jersey if you wanted to he practical) made traveling carefree.

title: Births
description: Alscher

title: A 1912 Blue Book for L.I. Motorists
description: In 1912, the pioneer motorist, drove from New York City to Oyster Bay. L.I., and was plagued along the way by horsewatering troughs, intersections and trolley lines. The distance then was 37.2 miles.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Jan. 30 Week in Review stated incorrectly that members of Congress are subject to impeachment. The impeachment provision of the Constitution does not apply to members of Congress, but either house is empowered to punish members for disorderly behavior and to expel them by a twothirds vote.

title: Tawny Godin, Dr. F. M. Little Have Nuptials
description: The Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner) was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Tawny Elaine Godin. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Godin of Yonkers, to Dr. Fanning Miles Little, son of Mrs. Lewis Perrin Smith of Spartanburg, S.C., and the late Herbert Lindsay Little.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN water starts seeping in through a crack or hole in the basement wall, most people think that repairs cannot be made until later in the year, after the ground has thoroughly dried and water is no longer seeping. This is true if ordinary patching cements are used, but special hydraulic cements can be used to plug holes and cracks in masonry even while water is still running through them.

description: WHEN water Starts seeping in through a crack or hole in the basement wall, most people think that repairs cannot be made until later in the year, after the ground has thoroughly dried and water is no longer seeping. This is true if ordinary patching cements are used, but special hydraulic cements can be used to plug holes and cracks in masonry even while water is still running through them.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Mickey Mantle's advice to promising high school baseball players: There is good ball being played in college, and college ball is definitely replacing the minors. I tell kids to go to college, and that's where my four boys are now.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: INTERNATIONAL economic problems have slipped quietly into the background in this country during the early months of 1977and quite naturally. since serious domestic issues and the effects the abnormally cold weather have usurped so much attention. Before long, however, there could be change in focus.

description: Sexual Exploitation And Advertising

title: Chilean Peso Revised Upward
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 5 (Reuters)The Chilean Government raised the value of the peso last night, setting a new rate of 17.77 to the dollar compared to 19.75 previously.

title: Katherine A. Rogers Fiancee of Lieutenant
description: Col. Manley Eaton Rogers, director of admissions and registrar at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N. Y.. and Mrs. Rogers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Anne Roger.;. to Lieut. Louis Graham Burgess, who graduated from West Point last year and is assigned to the infantry. He will leave for Korea this month.

title: Kojak Best Dog At Bronx County
description: Ch. Rexpointe Kojak, the black and white particolor cocker spaniel owned by Mrs. Mai Wilson of New York City, topped 1,565 contenders for his third allbreed bestinshow victory at the Bronx County Kennel Club's 55th Show yesterday at Kingsbridge Armory.

title: Argentina to Build A Nuclear  Reactor For the Peruvians
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 5Argentina extended its atomic diplomacy in South America today with the signing of an agreement to build a research nuclear ceactor in Peru using Argentine technology and equipment.

title: Borg Reaches U.S. Final
description: MEMPHIS, March 5 (AP)Tom Gullikson, a 25yearold pro from Easton, Pa., became Bjorn Borg's victim today in the semifinals of the $175,000 United States indoor tennis championships.

title: St. John's Women Win, Too
description: St. John's women's varsity basketball team captured the New York State A.I.A.W. championship yesterday with a 7755 victory over Long Island University at Alumni Hall, Jamaica. The women thus kept pace with the men's varsity which won the E.C.A.C. final yesterday.

title: Peggy Kuhn, Writer, Planning Nuptials To Michael G. T. Thompson in California
description: Edith Lyman Kuhn of Woodside, Calif.. and Charles Bowman Kuhn of San Jose, Calif., have announced the engagement. of their, daughter. Margaret Lyman Kuhn, to Michael Gordon Tackaberry Thompson. son of Mr. and Mrs. James Daniel Thompson of New York.

title: Joe Baum's food machine
description: Not long ago, Joe Baum was walking through the kitchen of Windows on the World in New York's World Trade Center when he stopped a waiter holding two silverclad coffee thermoses in one hand. Please carry them on a tray, he admonished the man. You bang them together and ruin them, if you hold them like that.

title: Red Tape Slows U.S. Diplomats At Kiev Mission
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R.The first American diplomatic mission in the Ukraine has been operating out of a couple of modest rooms rented at prime tourist rates in one of this city's lesser hotels.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: Koch Sets Pace In Citrus Golf On 65 for 204
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 5 (AP)Gary Koch capped a sevenunderpar 65 today with a dramatic 20yard pitch shot that found the cup for a birdie on the final hole, and he gained the thirdround lead in the $200,000 Florida Citrus open golf tournament.

title: ART VIEW
description: The exhibition of Lee Krasner's Large Paintings, which Marcia Tucker organized at the Whitney Museum in 1973, was something of revelation to those of us who did not then have a very distinct impression of this artist's oeuvre. Miss Krasner had been a painter on the New York scene for many years, of course, but her position in those years was ambiguous, to say the least. She was better known first as Jackson Pollock's wife and then as his widow than as an artist in her own right. Pollock wasand remainsa mythic figure in the art of our time, and it was Miss Krasner's unfortunate fate to be regarded, first of all, as an appendage to the myth. As consequence of this, her own artistic accomplishments tended to be overlooked.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Atitle card at the beginning of Rainer Werner Fassbinder's 1969 film, Katzelmacher, says sternly with no hint of apology, It's better make new mistakes than to repeat old ones until the mind goes numb. Katzelmacher was only Fassbinder's second film but this extraordinary German filmmaker, who's now just 31, was already off and running. It's as if he were perfectly aware that this talent that was bursting forth would lead him into occasional deadends and he didnt want to waste time in critical quibbling. So what if there are mistakes? The important thing is to move on, to explore, to develop, push oneself to the furthest limits.

title: Energy in Cabinet?
description: Having cursed the darkness surrounding the Government's plans to cope with the worsening energy situation, President Carter lit the first candle last week by asking Congress to create a Cabinetlevel department to carry out his energy policies.

title: 3d Suspect Sought In Midweek Slaying Of 2 in Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 5The Connecticut police were searching today for a third person who might have been involved in the burglaryslaying of two mothers in the northern Westchester community of Lewisboro, perhaps as the driver of the vehicle used in the incident or as a lookout.

title: Human Wastes Used as Fertilizer in Experiment in Dutchess County
description: LAGRANGE, N.Y.A big, balloontired truck with Big Bertha painted on the side rolled across the muddy cornfields of Karl Ehmer's Dutchess County farm recently, spouting greenish liquid for about 25 feet on each side.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE XEROX CORPORATION has filed a new patent Infringement suit against the International Business Machines Corporation over its plain paper copying and duplicating equipment. Xerox previously sued I.B.M. in 1970, 1972 and 1973. I.B.M. denies it has infringed on Xerox's patents.

title: A Superstar In Storrs Firmament
description: BASKETBALL STATUS being a matter of statewide pride bore dering on fanaticism, it is said that Kentuckians and Indianans can supply not only the wonlost record of their state university team, but also the scoring averages and shooting percentages of the team's star players. Hundreds of miles from either campus, many people who have never set foot in Lexington or Bloomington can furnish every vital statistic about the hardwood heroes attending the state universities except their scholastic standings.

title: Jersey City: Remember The Dodgers?
description: JACKIE ROBINSON stormed into the dressing room, slammed down his glove and began yelling in his distinctive highpitched voice. Racists, racists, racists! he screamed.

title: Watergate Is a Big Part of It
description: The last two decades have seen an almost incredible profusion of journalism students in the United States. Enrollments increased 93 percent between 1970 and 1975, and 481 percent between 1960 and 1975. For the first time in years, however, new figures show there may be a slackening of student interest in journalism programs.

title: Oklahoma House Backs Laetrile
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 5 (UPI)The Oklahoma House has passed a bill to bar the disciplining of a physician for prescribing or administering the federally banned drug laetrile to cancer patients. The measure, which was voted Wednesday, also would prohibit a hospital from restricting or barring the use of laetrile when requested by a patient and prescribed or administered by a physician. If passed by the Senate and signed by the governor, the bill would become effective next Oct. 1.

title: They Lessen Risks in Releasing Suspects
description: AYOUNG WOMAN arrested for passing a bad check was being interviewed in the White Plains city jail by a friendly representative of a comparatively new organization in the criminaljustice system called Pretrial Services Institute of Westchester. She was balking at the questions when her cellmate, a former ?? of the agency, spoke up.

title: Rangers Scoring
description: FIRST PERIODI, Montreal, Lemaire (30) (Lafleur, Lambert), 3:47. 2, Montreal, Jarvis (13) (Roberts. Savard), 5:47. 3, Montreal, Gainey (I2) (Sevard. Rnhinson), 16:29. 4, Rangers, Tkaczuk (9) (Polis), 19:42. PenaltiesGoldsworthy (7:48); Tremblay, (7:48); Dillon, (18:15).

title: An OpenDoor Policy on Banking
description: FROM the earliest days of its settlement to the recent relocation of corporate headquarters in Connecticut the state has benefitted from the talents of newcomers. We have welcomed immigrants from all parts of the United States, from all parts of the world. We actively solicit industry to establish facilities in our state. Why not banking offices of companies with headquarters outside of our state?

title: Talk With John Cheever
description: One end of the living room in a house built in 1799, in Ossining, N.Y. A table has been pushed against the lefthand wall, under a large print of Hadrian's tomb spouting frenetic fireworks. Cheever, in a brown pullover, is seated beyond the table, with a window at his back. He is 64; looks like a man of 34 who has been to a hilarious but awfully late party the night before. Face flushed: recent skiing in Utah mountains. Nut brown hair. Sharp eyeheams. The brilliant glow behind him is mistfiltered sunlight. Two large glasses of dark amber liquid on the tableiced tea. Cheever is smokine.

title: One Champion Retired, Another on Way
description: The road back, they say, is a long one. But Redd Crabtree is not so sure.

title: Inside South Korea's C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, Until last Thanksgiving. Kim Sang Keun, a 43yearold counselor of the South Korean Embassy in Washington and a Chinese literature scholar, lived with his wife and three children in a modest apartment on Kennedy Drive in suburban McLean, Va., not far from the headquarters the Central Intelligence Agency. His neighbors and those who happened to notice him on the crowded Washington diplomatic circuit, remember Kim vaguely as a timid, selfeffacing man who preferred to smile rather than talk.

title: Garden Units Planned
description: The Segal Development Company of South Orange, N.J., has purchased for $850,000 a 36acre site in Roseland, N.J., on Eisenhower Parkway, near Eagle Rock Avenue and Route 280, for a gardenapartment project called Nob Hill. The seller was Walter Kidde & Company Inc. of Clifton, N.J.

title: Hospital Plans Lecture Series
description: A series of lectures will be established at the Maimonides Community Mental Health Center to honor the late Dr. Gary N. Spero, a 38yearold member of the center's staff who specialized in community and geriatric psychiatry. The center at 920 48th Street in the Borough Park Section of Brooklyn, houses a psychiatric inpatient unit and provides a comprehensive range of outpatient services.

title: Fashion Scene Deep Freeze
description: Dorothy Hamill, America's figure skating queen, was recently trained to the International Best Dressed listfor her hairstyle, not her clothes. Not since Sonja Henie, the blond and bejewelled star from Norway, took to the ice in a modified version of the ballet dancer's tutu in the 1930's, has there been a significant development in iceskating fashion.

title: Wooing Industry From Abroad
description: AFTER a string of successes in luring business from neighboring New York. Connecticut is now going further afield in its search for jobs and industry. A highpowered team of 11 Connecticut businessmen and officials is to leave Saturday for a weeklong foray into West Germany in hopes of quickening the flow of German industries into the state.

title: Weddings
description: Mr. end Mrs. Melvin K?? of Jericno, N.Y. announce the marriage of their daughter, Lisa Green, to Mr. Michael P. Kossar on Fed. 19. 1977.

title: Dream Towns Of Europe
description: By Joseph Weschsberg. Putnam's. $17.50.

title: Kovalev's Triumph Gives Soviet Third Skating Gold
description: TOKYO, March 5 (AP)Minoru Sano of Japan says he hates the compulsory figures, and that could be one reason why Vladimir Kovalev won the men's title in the world figure skating championships tonight, giving the Soviet Union three gold medals in the four events.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 6, 1977

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: GOING to the movies used to be funan adventure. For the price of your ticket, you entered a darkened cavern where, quietly, breathlessly, you watched tale unfold in glorious color.

title: The $73,000 abandoned babies
description: Michael Vladek, lying in a crib in the children's ward of Rings County Hospital in Brooklyn, does not see or hear or speak or eat. He is kept alive by a tube that leads from his nose to his stomach. Severely braindamaged by a mother who either beat him or threw him on the floor, Michael has spent all but six months of his six years as a boarder baby at Kings County.

title: Let Them Drink Champagne
description: AS I READ the alarming headlines of the contamination of beautiful Long Island and the intergovernmental response to these problems, I think of Marie Antoinette's suggestion to the hungry people of France. It is not that our leaders don't care; Government is concerned. But somehow all the concern has not been mobilized into meaningful action.

title: Soaring Price of Coffee Inspires Protesters and a Wave of Thefts
description: As a small hand of New Yorkers dumped a symbolic pound or so of coffee into the Hudson River yesterday to protest high prices, another group of citizensby the account of law enforcement authoritieswas busy trying to devise even more ways to spirit the valuable beans away.

title: A Legislator Put Her Marriage First
description: HUNTINGTON CLAIRE SAUER'S election to the Suffolk County Legislature in 1975 was a political as well as a personal triumph. The victory came in a heavily Republican district just a few years after Mrs. Sauer underwent surgery for a malignant tumor on her face.

title: TIMMY EVERETT, WINNER OF TWO ACTING AWARDS
description: Timmy Everett, actor and dancer who won the Daniel Blum Theater World Award in 1957 for his supporting role as the young Jewish boy in William Inge's The Dark at the Top of the stairs. died in his sleep on Friday, apparently of heart failure. He had been visiting a friend at 201 West 77th street. He was 38 years old end lived in California.

title: For Cuban Women, Miami Is a Refuge From Tradition
description: MIAMICuban women here have shed a refugee mentality and adjusted to life in the United States faster than men and, in the process, have abandoned the submissive role their mothers had in Cuba's maledominated society.

title: LEBANON LEADER SEEKS TO STOP WAR IN SOUTH
description: BEIRUT, March 5Efforts are under way to get rival factions in southern Lebanon to agree to a truce that would stop three weeks of fighting there.

title: 2.6 Million Enough to Run Summer Lunch Program, Says New York  Withan 'If'
description: ALBANY, March 5The state's Education Department said this week that could run the troubled summer program to feed needy children for about $2.6 million, if New York City's Board of Education allowed the program to operate in its public schools this summer.

title: Pastoral Complexity
description: THE DOMINANT STYLE of the buildings this countryside is still that of the 18th century and its variants in the 19th, and this inherited imagery is the ground upon which a kind of unpremeditated discontinuityeven a surrealistic qualityemerges. The visible image is of hardheaded, realistic people suspicious of fantasy, confined within utilitarian routines and a nononsense religion bare of ritual and vain show. But in fact, the people here are as often playactors and far more fantastic than efficient; despite the legend, they live in an old country, and under the oldest continuous government on earth, with a past mistily evocative as that of a European culture and countryside.

title: A Correction
description: In the issue of Feb. 13, a caption with a picture accompanying an article on New Rochelle erroneously identified an empty building there as having once housed Arnold Constable's. The former Constable building is also empty, but it is located elsewhere in New Rochelle.

title: Crosby Stays in Hospital
description: PASADENA, Calif. March 3 (Reuters)  Bing Crosby, telling Bob Hope he needs to get a new finish to the act' decided today to remain in hospital over the weekend to recuperate from his 20foot fall Thursday. Huntington Memorial Hospital said of the 72yearold singer He's still sore and he needs the rest, so he may as well stay here through Sunday.

title: Food
description: Some of the legends in the world of food are amusingly apocryphal. Some of the leg??nds are irritatingly apocryphal. and that is Into we react to the tedious, naive and muchrepeated anecdote about the origins of crepes suzette. It is a ridiculous and foolishly romanticized tale that would give Georges Auguste Escoffier acute indigestion, if not a fullsize ease of crise de ??e. It is suitable for a TV script. and to tell the truth it was dramatized. if memory serves, about Id years ago with Walter Slezak flaming the crepes as the alleged creator of the dessert. idle legend goes like this.
