title: Look for a Comeback in '77, Say the Office Market Experts
description: Office leasing activity, a barometer of the city's economic health, is rebounding after several years of stagnation.

title: Canadiens Top Rangers;Blues Defeat Islanders
description: MONTREAL, March 5For the second time in a week the Montreal Canadiens did as they pleased with the New York Rangers tonight, beating them by 72 before 17,765 persons in the hallowed Montreal Forum. In their last four games, all losses, the New Yorkers have allowed 21 goals, 15 by Montreal, and have scored just five.

title: Four novels
description: It is undoubtedly a rarity to find a novel of entertainment that is this well written. One immediately wants to consult some nonexistent oracle to help formulate the distinctions between literary, that is, serious, fiction and mere entertainment. One easy difference may be that the former usually concentrates on complexities of character and the latter on plot.

title: Panama's Canal Negotiator Says Talks Are in Substantive Stages
description: PANAMA, March 3The United States and Panama failed to achieve a major breakthrough during last, month's round of canal treaty negotiations, but for the first time the truly important substantive issues were discussed in depth, according to Panama's chief negotiator.

title: Best Seller List
description: Fiction

title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Is An Iron Pumper
description: THOUGH night has fallen and the toll plaza is dimly lit, the attendant seems to recognize the driver of the gray Toyota. As he makes change, the attendant looks carefully at the man who sits huddled in a big fleecy Jacket against the cold.

title: The Campaign, Continued
description: Two thoughts sprang most conspicuously from President Carter's informed, personably and only sometimes treacly telephone conversations with assorted Americans yesterday afternoon.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: In a decision that represents psychological victory for women's rights advocates and a financial boon for thousands of men, the Supreme Court has struck down, by a 5to4 vote, a section of the Social Security Act making it harder for widowers than for widows to collect survivors benefits.

title: Mobile Homes for Elderly
description: TRENTON, March 5 (UPIEnvironmental Commissioner David J. Bardin approved an application yesterday for the Sunny Pine Contracting Corporation to build 332 mobile homes for the elderly in Manchester Township, Ocean County, at awn estimated cost of $1.3 million. The homes will be situated on 65 acres of land north of the existing Pine Ridge section at Crestwood Mobile Home Park. The homes will cost an average of $17,000.

title: The Ides of January
description: The recent record cold wave may be melting from memories as spring approaches, but the havoc it played with the economy was starkly frozen in January's statistics.

title: Inner Circle's Review Lampoons Mayor's Troubles
description: The coming mayoral election and the city's fiscal crisis were satirized last night in patter, song and dance at the annual revue staged by The Inner Circle, an organization of New York political reporters, past and present.

title: Corporate Architecture
description: In an appraisal of corporate architecture (Westchester Weekly, Feb. 20) the Cross Westchester Corporate Park and its architect were incorrectly identified. Matthew J. Warshauer was among the designers of the Cross Westchester Executive Park in Elmsford, a development of industrial and warehouse buildings combined with office space. Mr. Warshauer had nothing to do with the design of the Cross Westchester Corporate Park, which is in Harrison.

title: Out in Suburbia, The Frontier Spirit Isn't What It Was
description: Buying a house in the suburbs nowadays means checking the want ads for the good school districts, finding the right exit on some expressway. trying to get the broker to be absolutely clear about the taxes, andof coursegoing down to the bank for a mortgage.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A.M. (Channel 2) Lamp Unto My Feet: Holy Moslem shrines in Jerusalem.

title: The Bridge To Nowhere
description: THE gleaming new Betsy Ross Bridge at Pennsauken is a modemday marvel that, by almost any standard, is a stunning success. A technological triumph and an esthetic achievement, the $105 million masterpiece arches high over the Delaware River and curves gracefully into Philadelphia, a magic carpet of concrete and steel whose eightlane roadwayone of the widest in the worldoffers a blissfully unimpeded flow of traffic to motorists long accustomed to the pestering delays of the creaking TaconyPalmyra drawbridge a mile upstream.

title: U.S. WouldPay $4.6 Billion to Tap Hudson for New York and Nassau
description: ALBANY, March 5A $4.6 billion project to provide drinking water from the Hudson River for New York City and Nassau County has been recommended by the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: Bond Prices End UpandDown Week Little Changed
description: After a puff of optimism on Wednesday and Thursday, the credit markets deflated on Friday as some traders became disappointed that unemployment did not Increase more than it dida twist in the economic news that seemed to indicate business activity was rebounding from this winter's severe weather much more quickly than expected. After their minor ups and downs, bond prices closed little changed from where they were a week earlier.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Readers of The Wall Street Journal may have been surprised recently by an editorial entitled Keynes Is Dead, a good 30 years after the event. The editorial itself, however, contained no surprises. The Journal's editors believe that big government is harmful to children and other living things, and had assembled some casual statistical evidence to buttress their position.

title: Jax Bounces Back
description: When Sally and Jack Hanson, the owners of a series of fashion shops across the country, split up a couple of years ago, she got the New York outlet as part of the divorce settlement.

title: West Bank Students Demonstrate
description: TEL AVIV, March 6 (AP)Soldiers used tear gas to break up a demonstration today by students In Ramallah in the occupied West Bank of Jordan, the state radio reported. The students were supporting 250 Arab prisoners in an Israeli prison in Ashkelon who are a hunger strike to protest prison conditions.

title: Supporters Are Raising Money for New Jersey Opera
description: MIDDLETOWN, March 5It appeared to be a social gathering to plan for opera in New York, Boston or Washington. But those who met in the big white mansion overlooking the Navesink River were concerned about Symphony Hall in Newark, home of the New Jersey State Opera.

title: Adams, Unhappy at Pace of Work On Rail Corridor, Acts to Speed It
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Transportation Secretary Brock Adams, disappointed in the slow pace of a project to improve rail facilities in the Northeast Corridor, is bypassing the project's director and taking a personal hand in the matter.

title: Flights of Fancy Take Wing in Low Library
description: There are headon collisions, sudden changes of direction and turbulence at the highest levels in the executive office building at Columbia University on Sunday afternoons.

title: Excerpts From New Reform Prayer Book
description: The following excerpts are taken from the new Reform prayer book the home.

title: Holy Trinity Five Takes L.I. Catholic Title. 8270
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., March 6Holy Trinity High School of Hicksville retained its basketball championship in the NassauSuffolk Catholic High Schools Association today with an 8270 victory over St. Agnes of Rockville Centre at the State University at Farmingdale.

title: McKinney Quits Posts at Paper
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 6 (AP)Frank McKinney, 61, resigned yesterday as first vicepresident and general manager of the Kansas City Star. Mr. McKinney said he would continue as a member of the board of directors and chairman of the board of directors of the Star's paper and pulp mills in Wisconsin. Last month, the employeeowned company became a subsidiary or Capital Cities Communications Juc. of New York as stockholders sold their shares for $125 million.

title: Drs. Karen Toskos and W. S. Robertson Wed
description: Dr. Karen Toskos and Dr. William Scott Robertson. physicians in Massachusetts. were married yesterday afternoon in Hempstead, L.T. The Rev. Nicholas J. Margoulias performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church.

title: Bronx Boy, 15, Crushed to Death While Playing Atop an Elevator
description: A 15yearold South Bronx boy who the police said had apparently been playing on top of an elevator, was killed yesterday when he lost his balance and was crushed between the side of the elevator and the elevator shaft.

title: U.S. Steel Plans Resin Plant
description: The USS Chemicals division of the United States Steel Corporation announced over the weekend that planned to build an unsaturated polyester resin facility at its Neville Island, Pa., chemical production complex. Startup of the new facility with capacity of 90 million pounds a year, is scheduled for early 1979.

title: Power Memorial Beaten for C.H.S.A.A. Title
description: Kevin Dunleavy calmly dropped in two foul shots with seven seconds remaining to give Nazareth High 5957. victory over Power Memorial in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball championship final last night before a full house of 3,500 at the Fordham University gym.

title: Track and Field
description: AT PRINCETON

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY'S GAS SUPPLIER GETS NEW HIGH RATE
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Chairman Richard L. Dunham of the Federal Power Commission has approved a record high price for emergency natural gas purchases by the Trans Continental Gas Transmission Corporation, an important supplier to New York City and other East Coast markets.

title: The Rolling Stones Think Small
description: TORONTO, March 6  The Rolling Stones, who have played for crowds ranging from 15.000 to 400,000 over the last decade, performed in a 350seat club here this weekend. The British rock band's appearances at the El Mocambo club were planned to provide additional material for a projected live double album and for fun, as Mick Jagger put it last night.

title: Occupation of Notre Dame Threatened by Protesters
description: PARIS, March 6 (Reuters)A traditionalist Roman Catholic priest threatened today to occupy Notre Dame Cathedral. if force was used against him and his followers in their occupation of a Latin Quarter church.

title: Provincial Leadership Changes Create Southern Power Base in China
description: HONG KONG, March 6There is no connection with the ascendancy in the United States of President Carter and his fellow Georgians, but in the last few months something of a southern political group has emerged in China, too. Shifts of provincial

title: ExOfficer Slain as Holdup Suspect
description: A man who was shot to death by a police sergeant after allegedly wounding a policeman in a Brooklyn gasoline station holdup Saturday night was identified yesterday as a former New York City policeman who had been dismissed from the force in 1968.

title: ExNew Zealand Premier Named Governor General
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Monday, March 7 (AP)Sir Keith Holyoake was appointed today by Queens Elizabeth II as New Zealand's 13th governor general.

title: Bizarre Rock By Split Enz At Bottom Line
description: Split Enz, which opened Henny Youngman's shows at the Bottom Line on Friday and Saturday, is not just another rock group. In fact, it is not just another anything. Using a combination of blackout skits, lighting tricks, pantomime and electronics, it presents an evening's entertainment that is not always funny but is always bizarre.

title: McGovern Urges Slash in Defense Funds
description: ORONO, Maine, March 6 (AP)The national defense budget should be massively reduced and the savings spent to rebuild the forgotten American railroad system and to provide jobs for the unemployed. Senator George McGovern said tonight.

title: Betting on Casinos
description: Now that casino gambling is coming to New Jersey can New York afford to be far behind? Dismayed at the prospect of losing tourists to a revivified Atlantic City, enticed by visions of Vegaslike profits, boosters from the Catskills to the Rockaways, from Niagara Falls to Saratoga to New York City are placing their bets on casinos. They have won the support of New York State's Department of Commerce, which is drafting legislationsubject to referendumto eliminate the constitutional ban against gambling casinos.

title: Millions Tried To Call Carter; 42 Got His Ear
description: Behind the 42 callers who got to talk to President Carter on his callin radio show Saturday were 9 million to 9.5 million attempts by other Americans who heard recordings or busy signals rather than toplevel answers to their questions, according to officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Bridge:
description: When a match is over, most players are far more conscious of deals that represented disasters than they are of the triumphs. So when the team that produced the biggest upset of the Grand National Knockout Teams here recently was asked for an interesting deal, the one that came to mind was one on which the opponents had been allowed to make an impossible contract.

title: PITTSTON TO BID FOR ELGIN IN TWOSTAGE OPERATION
description: The Pittston Company announced yesterday that it was planning to acquire Elgin National Industries Inc., in what is, in effect, a twostage operation. The cost would be in excess of $50 million.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Lester Krugman,Executive Of North AmericanPhilips, Dies on L.I. at Age of 63
description: Lester Krugman, public relations director of North American Philips Corporation, died yesterday at his home at 199 Harvard Avenue, Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 63 years old.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Carter's Comments On Rights A re Said To Anger Castro
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI)Fidel Castro is outraged over a demand by the United States that Cuba show more attention to human rights as a precondition for resumption of trade or diplomatic relations, an American newspaper editor said today.

title: INTEREST GROUPS AID 49 ON FISCAL PANELS
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Members of the Senate Finance and House Ways and Means Committees, among the most powerful in Congress, received more than $2 million in campaign contributions from special interest groups representing business, labor and professional associations the last time thew sount reelection.

title: Lewis G. Weeks Dies; Founder Of Weeks Petroleum Corporation
description: Lewis G. Weeks, founder of the Weeks Petroleum Corporation and an authority on oil and natural gas exploration, died Friday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 83 years old.

title: Reform Jews Publish New Prayer Book for Home
description: The Reform branch of Judaism has published its first new prayer book for the home in more than 25 years, a blend of traditional and innovative texts designed to encourage prayer in the specific situations that arise in everyday life.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Is Black Deputy Mayor Powerful? Debate Is Rekindled in New York
description: Three years ago, when Paul Gibson became a deputy mayor, blacks hailed the appointmenta firstas one of the most significant moves by blacks into the upper echelons of political power in New York City's history.

title: Benitez Advances Handily In King's Boxing Series
description: MARION, Ohio, March 6Number 125734, a former inmate of the Marion Correctional Institution, brought his road show to his alma mater this afternoon.

title: Republic Steel Plans to Start Up Furnaces at Cleveland and Gadsden
description: The Republic Steel Corporation announced over the weekend plans forstarting up two blast furnaces. The company explained that the additional iron would be needed to increase production of raw steel for flatrolled and bar steel at Cleveland and for flatrolled steel at its Gadsden, Ala., plant.

title: Two Democratic Leaders Charged in New Mexico In Insurance Policy Plot
description: ALBUQUERQUE. N. M., March 6Two state Democratic Party leaders have been released on their own recognizance after pleading not guilty to bribery and conspiracy charges in connection with an alleged insurance policy plot that has resulted in the cancellation of employee liability coverage for 40 municipalities and counties in New Mexico.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: SUMMITS By now even those who have never heard them should be familiar with the musical reputations of Claudio Arrau, the keyboard wizard, and Ravi Shankar, undeniably the most effective tonal ambassador to the world at large from his native India.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Dr. Charles G. Herbermann, 92; ExOfficial at a Hospital in Bronx
description: Dr. Charles G. Herbermann, a , past president of the medical board of St. Francis Hospital in the South Bronx, which closed at the end of 1966, died Saturday in a nursing home in Paramus, N.J. He was 92 years old and lived at 100 West Ridgewood Avenue in Paramus.

title: Karl Richter in Concert Of Bach's Organ Music
description: Though Karl Richter is probably best known here as the conductor of the excellent Munich Bach Orchestra and Choir, he is also an organist of note, and it was in the latter capacity that he turned up at Alice Tully Hall Sunday afternoon.

title: Bridal at All Souls For Barbara Heine, Edward Costikyan
description: Barbara Heine, a freelance writer, and Edward N. Costikyan, a partner in the Paul, Weiss. Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison law firm, were married yesterday afternoon in the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The Rev, Dr. Walter Donald Kring performed the ceremony.

title: West's Water Fight Intensifies as Carter Plans Project Cuts
description: DENVER, March 6President Carter's controversial attempt to stop funding for 19 Federal water projects in this drought year has intensified a centuryold battle in the Westthe war of water politics.

title: Rep. Holtzman Seeks Law To Deport Nazi Criminals
description: Miss Holtzman said that the bill, which she plans to introduce tomorrow, was cosponsored by 39 Democrats and 11 Republicans.

title: A Secret Weapon for New York: City Could Control Pension Fund
description: A secret weapon in the hands of New York City's elected officials gives them power to rescue the city from the immediate threat of default, even if no mutually acceptable deal is worked out with the municipal labor unions or the banks.

title: ItalianAmerican Leader Wants Bell to Apologize
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 6 (UPI)  The president of an ItalianAmerican fraternal group demanded today that Attorney General Griffin B. Bell apologize for using the terms Mafia and Cosa Nostra as synonyms for organized crime in the United States.

title: S. E. C. IN EFFECT ENDS ITS LENIENT PROGRAM ON ILLICIT PAYMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The Securities and Exchange Commission is in effect killing its program under which companies could obtain lenient treatment by confessing any bribes or questionable payments they made abroad.

title: Over65 Age Group Grew, Under5 Fell Since '70
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)There are more persons in the United States today over the age of 65 and fewer under the age of 5 than there were in 1970, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Red Smith
description: MARION, Ohio, March 6For two rounds a Brooklyn heavyweight named Kevin Isaac shuffled, shrugged, feinted and circled warily while huge Stan Ward of Sacramento fixed him with a beady glare of waiting.

title: Top Horses Missing From 20 Named To Start in Split Florida Derby Today
description: MIAMI, March 6When enough Triple Crown candidates to fill two races are entered in a demanding event like tomorrow's Florida Derby, it usually means one of two things: an abundance of quality, or a lack of it.

title: Koch Takes Citrus Open By 2 Shots
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 6 (AP)Frontrunning Gary Koch carded a twounderpar 70 today to win the Florida Citrus open. The slender 24yearold, a product of the University of Florida, was urged on by almost constant cries of Go, Gators, Go.

title: Time Says That Bramlet Was Talking With Mob
description: Al Bramlet, the Las Vegas labor leader missing since Feb, 24, had been negotiating with mobsters concerning a clinic and pharmacy to be built for members of his culinary workers union, Time magazine reports in its current issue

title: Fire in Grand Canyon Cave Perils Rich Source of Fossils of Ice Age
description: One of the world's richest known sources of fossils and other evidence of life in the ice age is slowly burning up in a cave in the Grand Canyon, but the authorities say any effort to put out the fire must await completion of paper work required by the Federal agencies involved.

title: Crystal Water Breaks Track Mark in Handicap
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 6 (AP)Fouryearold Crystal Water broke the track record today in the 40th running of the $273,550 Santa Anita Handicap. He edged the longshot, Faliraki, and the favored King Pellinore to win the 1mile race in 1:59 1/5.

title: Odermatt Wins Dual Slalom
description: HUNTER, N.Y., March 6  Josef Odermatt of Switzerland swept by Werner Bleiner of Austria today and took first place in a dual slalom competition of the professional ski racing tour at Hunter Mountain Ski Bowl. Odermatt, who is second in earnings, moved within 15 points of Henri Duvillard, the leader for the season.

title: Kenneth Klein in Local Debut Leading American Symphony
description: The conductor of yesterday afternoon's American Symphony concert at Carnegie Hall was Kenneth Klein, who was making his New York debut. Mr. Klein, 36 years old and a native of Los Angeles, has had a curious career. For 10 years he has been based in Guadalajara, Mexico, where he has reportedly built up the orchestra far above its status of 10 years ago. He has done guestconducting of various sorts here and there, but he hasn't followed the normal careerbuilding route of the ambitious young maestro.

title: Dr. Tibor A. Weber, 82, Officer Of Hungarian AntiCommunists
description: Dr. Tibor A. Weber, former foreign relations officer of the Hungarian National Council, which called itself the antiCommunist Hungarian government in exile in this country, died Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in the Lancaster Hotel.

title: Natural Gas and a Vaporous Theory
description: Millions of Americans out of work this winter due gas shortages would like to know whom to blame, and many believe they have found a candidate. A report prepared by the Department of Interior points to the tardy development of offshore gas reserves leased private producers. Gas industry critics take the Interior report as evidence that offshore gas producers are deliberately withholding reserves in expectation of higher prices later on. If only the lease provisions for speedy development had been enforced by the Feds, critics conclude, this winter's severe gas shortages could have been avoided.

title: Experts See New Energy Crisis And Again Ask Coherent Policies
description: HARRIMAN, N. Y., March 6Chilly warnings of an approaching new energy crisis and repeated calls for coherent policies were offered here over the weekend by experts at a Columbia University conference.

title: Books of The Times
description: The television set is in big trouble around our place. I'm thinking of putting out its eye with a sharpened log, if only we can get the child through the withdrawal period with hot compresses and effigies of Donny and Marie. First came jeremiads from the ParentTeachers Association, warning us that television certainly wasn't helping. Then came a Newsweek cover story with the intelligence that had programming drives out good activity. Then came the

title: Millions Tried To Call Carter; 42 Got His Ear
description: Behind the 42 callers who got to talk to President Carter on his callin radio show Saturday were 9 million to 9.5 million attempts by other Americans who heard recordings or busy signals rather than toplevel answers to their questions, according to officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMSSydney. We record with sorrow the passing of our Honorary and First President and extend sincerest condolences to his wife and family.

title: DR. T. EDWARD TEMPLE
description: RICHMOND, March 6 (UPI)Dr. T. Edward Temple, president of Virginia Commonwealth University, died today at Medical College of Virginia Hospital of complications from a heart attack suffered Friday. He was 61 years old.

title: Doctor Cited in Hepatitis Outbreak Will Go on Trial in Newark Today
description: NEWARK, March 6Dr. Peter T. DeMarco of Pine Hill will go on trial here tomorrow on state charges of causing an outbreak of infectious hepatitis last year.

title: I Am Curious (Black)
description: DAYTON, OhioThe pretty blonde I had known for more than a year explained, not long ago, in a suburban discothque, why she could not relate to methis despite the frequent barhopping, dining and dancing dates and longdistance telephone calls between here and her Columbus home.

title: Contributions to Key Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Following is a list of all members of the Senate Finance and House Ways and Means Committees with the amounts of money they raised and spent in their most recent reelection campaigns and the part of their campaign contributions that came from special interest groups sponsored by business and labor:

title: Dinkins in Borough President Race
description: David N. Dinkins, the City Clerk, announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Borough President of Manhattan yesterday with a speech praising New York City and sharply criticizing those who do not believe in the future of this city.

title: IC4A Title In Track Goes To Villanova
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 6A triple jumper from Athens, Ga. at Villanova? Impossible. Does George Allen like rookies? Do birds fly north for the winter? What does Jumbo Jim Elliott know about people wh ohop instead of run?

title: LABFEE LEGISLATION IS OPPOSED IN ALBANY
description: A bill that New York City and state officials say would make the state more attractive for large medical laboratories is facing strong opposition from Republican leaders in the State Senate, who say that it would weaken safeguards against Medicaid fraud.

title: Commodities
description: The marketplace began rationing the nation's supply of protein rich soybeans last week as all oldcrop futures deliveries soared across the $8abushel level for the first time since late 1974.

title: STUDY SAYS U.S. AND ALLIES RETAIN LARGE NAVAL LEAD
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The United States and its allies have considerably more warship tonnage than the Soviet bloc naval forces, according to Pentagon statistics released today.

title: Stenmark, Miss Morerod Widen Leads. in Cup Skiing
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 6Ingemark Stenmark of Sweden and LiseMarie Morerod of Switzerland registered stirring runs today and added to their leads in World Cup overall skiing competition.

title: Chess :
description: Mark Diesen's victory in the world junior championship is atiributa le largely to his solid grasp of positional play and his unflappability under fire.

title: COAST HEARING TODAY ON A CHIEF JUSTICE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 6A landmark California political event will occur in the State Supreme Court chamber tomorrow when Rose Bird's nomination as Chief Justice comes before the State Commission on Judicial Appointments.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, MARCH 7, 1977

title: American Popular Songs Offered
description: Although the program that William Bolcom and Joan Morris gave at Alice Tully Hall on Friday evening was announced as American Popular Songs From the 1890's to Now, it actually began in 1823, with Home, Sweet Home, and included English as well as American songs. This gave Miss Morris an opportunity to expand a variety of the singing styles that she displayed, to give herself more depth in the area for which her trained voice is best suited and to allow herself to point up the place of the hustle in 19century fashion.

title: Lyle Sticks to Same Pitch on Arrival At Yank Camp: Pay Me or Trade Me
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 6The team's newest player noticed the team's newest arrival sitting in front of his locker and walked over.

title: Borg Beats Gottfried for Indoor Title
description: MEMPHIS, March 6 (AP)Bjorn Borg, seeded No. 1 in the tournament; defeated Brian Gottfried by 64, 63, 46, 75 today to win the $28,000 singles prize in the United States national indoor championships.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Employees at Newsday represented by Local 406 of the International Printing and Graphic Communications Union authorized their officers to call strike at the Long Island newspaper if they felt it necessary to get an acceptable contract for 24 telephone and mail room employees. Although only the 24 members of the administrative unit would strike, the other employees in the local were expected to respect their picket lines. Local 406 represents editorial workers, drivers, pressmen and maintenance workers at the daily paper in addition to the administrative services unit.

title: Leonard Silk
description: I was told that the Privileged and the People form Two Nations, wrote Benjamin Disraeli, the Conservative 19thcentury British Prime Minister. Similarly, many New Yorkers believe they form Two Citieswith the big New York banks as the emissaries of the Privileged and with Gracie Mansion. the Mayor's residence, as the voice of the People.

title: INTEREST GROUPS AID 49 ON FISCAL PANELS
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Members of the Senate Finance and House Ways and Means Committees, among the most powerful in Congress. received more than $2 million in campaign contributions from special interest groups representing business, labor and professional associations the last time they sought reelection.

title: Brazil's Opposition Joins Protest To U.S. Over Human Rights Report
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 6Leaders of the centerleft opposition party today joined the rightwing military Government of Brazil in protesting a report by the Carter Administration that criticized the human rights situation here.

title: Recital: Pianistic DazzleDazzle From Entremont
description: Philippe Entremont would be a more consistently pleasing pianist if he knew his limitations and played within them. Instead, the French musician forces tempos past the point where clarity of detail is possible for him; he hammers at the keys so that his tone is a glassy clatter most of the time, and his interpretations generally end by disintegrating into headlong, thoughtless bravura.

title: Indoor HighJump Mark Set
description: EAST BERLIN, March 6 (UPI)The Olympic gold medalist, Rosemarie Ackermann, cleared 1.95 meters in the women's high jump today for a world indoor mark at the East German national indoor track and field championships. Miss Ackermann achieved the record on her second jump.

title: THEORA HAMBLETT, PAINTER WHO STARTED IN MIDLIFE
description: OXFORD, Miss., March 6 (AP)Theora Hamblett, a shy Mississippi school teacher whose paintings are in the art collections of former Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller and the Museum of Modern Art in New York, died today. She was 82 years old.

title: 15,000 at Meadowlands See Irish Setter Judged the Best
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 6The first dog show held at New Jersey's sports complex, the Meadowlands, was an instant success today, with more than 15,000 spectators recorded on the turnstiles. The scene also included breed and group rings lined six rows deep with people, ring activities on 50 closedcircuit TV sets and a video screen that showed ringside activities outside the racetrack building.

title: Maltese Group in Queens Takes Voting and Culture Seriously
description: Beneath a Maltese cross and a color photograph of President Carter, the pool balls clicked, a father and son twisted the knobs of a mechanical soccer game and men leafed through the latest Maltese newspapers.

title: Columbus, Ohio, Schools Are to Reopen Today
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 6 (AP)City schools, which were closed a month ago by the natural gas shortage, are scheduled to reopen tomorrow. The city's 96,000 pupils nave been attending classes in a variety of makeshift classrooms, including pool halls and beer parlors.

title: Boston's Russian and Ludmilla New Jewel in Caldwell Crown
description: BOSTON, March 6Through the years Sarah Caldwell and her Opera Company of Boston have staged some unusual pieces, but few will have been as unknown to American audiences as the one unveiled at the Orpheum Theater last night. It was Russian and Ludmilla by Mihkail Glinka, and this is believed to be its first American staged presentation.

title: Grich Placed in Traction
description: HOLTVII.I.E, Calif., March 6 (AP)Bobby Grich, the California Angels shortstop, plagued by back spasms that have kept him out of spring training, was placed in traction today. Club officials said Grich would he examined tomorrow by an orthopedic specialist.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Advertising
description: Both wear beards. Both are writers. And both are presidents of ad agencies. But that's about where the surface similarities between James C. Nelson Jr. and Dick Tarlow seem to end.

title: Dr.AbrahamTauber; Was Founding Dean Of Bronx Faculty
description: Dr. Abraham Tauber, founding dean of faculty of Bronx Community College and chairman of the speech and drama department at Yeshiva University, died yesterday at Montefiore Hospital after a threeyear fight with cancer. He was 64 years old.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, MARCH 7. 1977

title: Greek Immigrant's Bequest Was Too Much for His Spartan Village
description: SCRANTON, Pa., March 6A Greek immigrant who parlayed a candy business, some real estate holdings and shrewd stock investments into a modest fortune left his estate 11 yeas ago to the youths of his native village in Greece.

title: Retailers Sales Surge in New York
description: After a puny gain in January, sales of New York's largest retailers rose well above the inflation rate in February, aided by strong consumer response to Lincoln's Birthday and Washington's Birthday sales and early reaction to spring merchandise.

title: DONALD J. MINER
description: Donald D. Miner, retired vice president of the municipal bond portfolio department of the Chemical Bank of New York, died Thursday of heart failure at a hospital in Hilo, Hawaii. He was 64 years old and had lived in Hawaii for several years. He leaves his wife, the former Dorothy Baldwin; and three sons, Donald Jr., Robin and Jonathan.

title: Amex and Chicago Board Accelerate Options Race
description: A competitive battle is heating up between the American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange over the fastest growing securities market in the nation. The market is in options and the battle is over those that are traded on both exchanges.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: UTILITY BONDS

title: Museum's 12 Doll Houses Recreate Old New York
description: Red plush overstuffed parlors, a swan pool, peacock garden and the rustic landscapes of New York a century ago come alive in a world of miniatures and make believe at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Ever since 1962, when the British and French took the gamble to build the Concorde, whatever chances the project has had for profitable operations have been predicated, increasingly, on service to New York.

title: For Portuguese, Disillusion Is Replacing Revolution
description: LISBONAfter three years of political upheaval and economic improvisation, Lisbon is showing clear signs of exhaustion and even disillusion with the country's celebrated Revolution of the Flowers.

title: Amin, in Interview, Asks U.S. to Reopen Kampala Embassy
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, March 6 (AP)President Idi Amin said today that he would like the United States to reopen its embassy in Kampala and he predicted that one day President Carter would be one of my best friends.

title: Frustrations of Jobless University Graduates Are Erupting in Italy
description: ROME, March 6Lori Mancini, a 24yearold law student at the University of Rome, stood outside the school gates on the Via Nomentana the other day and talked of the grim prospects for work. After graduation this spring I haven't the slightest idea what I'll he doing, she said. Neither do the vast majority of my classmates.

title: School Budgets Forecast Rise in Costs For Education Starting in September
description: Preliminary school budgets indicate that New Jersey taxpayers will be spending millions of dollars more for education starting in September.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: President Telephones Widow of Minister
description: RIDGELAND. S. C., March 6 (AP)The wife of a minister who died of a heart attack shortly after talking to President Carter said she was comforted by a telephone call from the President last night.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT BLOOMINGTON, MINN.

title: Rep. Hughes Urges Federal Law On Stoning or Shooting at Trains
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (UPI) Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of New Jersey, urged this weekend that shooting or throwing objects at trains be made a Federal offense to help protect railroad workers end passengers.

title: Market Place
description: Energy is a glamour business these days, but diversification into the field may prove harmfully distracting for some companies. At least that is how The OTC Review, a publication devoted to stocks traded over the ,counter, sees Dekalb Agresearch's diversification into oil and gas exploration.

title: A Secret Weapon for New York: City Could Control Pension Fund

title: About the Mets ...
description: In St. Petersburg, Fla.. where teams have gone for spring training since 1914, the New York Mets said they would reopen the new Al Lang Field on Saturday with their best pitcher: Toni Seaver. He will pitch the first three innings against the St. Louis Cardinals in the game dedicating the 8.000seat waterfront park, which was rebuilt 1 the city in the last two years. Larry Dierker, who was to have started for the Cardinals, broke his leg while running last week and will not pitch until May. . . . Don't take seriously the Dave Kingman experiment in center field. As any Met pitcher will tell you, the 6  foot  6  inch Californian has enough trouble playing left field. I've got him throwing from center field, said Manager Joe Frazier, and every day I hit fly balls for him to shag in center. It's a good place for him to learn. But it doesn't mean he's going to play center. He's not. . . . . Kingman's holdout for a $3 million contract goes on. If he doesn't play out his option, which he doesn't want to do, he may finally sign for a flat salary near $200,000  still below Seaver's $225.000. . . . Mets joined other baseball people in annual golf tournament here. One of hottest golfers in baseball happened to he visiting and joined in: Pee Wee Reese, exDodger shortstop. Nobody's as good as Peanuts, said Willie Mays, anointing his old enemy from the GiantDodger wars.

title: The Theater: Brecht and Shaw
description: NEW HAVEN, March 6At first glance Bertolt Brecht and Bernard Shaw might seem to have little in common. Shaw's polite Fabian Socialism had little to do with Brecht's workingClass Communism, and Shaw's cultivated wit is a far remove from Brecht's guttersnipe humor, while their ideas of the theatrical concept, with Shaw embracing the wellMade play and Brecht expressing a people's theater of illustration and vaudeville, are light years in difference. Yet both were didactic. And how they could talk.

title: Fassbinder Hits the Mark Again In a Pessimistic 'Mother Kusters'
description: Mrs. Kusters is one of those people strangers take to be prototypical, though secretly she's far from ordinary. She simply appears to be. She's short, stocky, middle-aged, soft-spoken, nave and inclined to be optimistic as she presents the world with a face that looks as if it had been shaped in modeling clay that fell to the floor before the features had been firmly set. People she doesn't know call her Mother Kusters and assume that she is Everywoman, which she isn't.Mrs. Kusters is the sort of exception to the rule about the common person that was the inspiration of so much left-wing literature of the Depression about worms that turned, about little guys who fought heroically (and often futilely) back.In the indomitable presence of Brigitte Mira, the German actress, she's also an essentially comic, idiosyncratic life-saving force that separates Rainer Werner Fassbinder's "Mrs. Kusters Goes to Heaven" from most other agit-prop drama that you've ever seen.If you weren't already aware that Mr. Fassbinder, the 31-year-old German director ("Ali," "Fox and His Friends," "The Bitter Tears of Petra Von Kant," etc.), refuses to make movies that are like anyone else,'s, you have a far from solemn obligation to go to the New Yorker Theater where "Mother Kusters" opened yesterday. This fine film, which is being given its New York premiere, is the initial attraction in the first reasonably complete Fassbinder retrospective we've ever had here.In addition to revivals of six Fassbinder films already seen in New York, the retrospective will include six Fassbinder works, dating from 1969 through 1976, that have never before been given theatrical showings locally. They are not all equally successful. They include a couple of films that look like clever doodling, but they also include one, "Effie Briest," that is as beautiful as anything that Mr. Fassbinder has done. Taken together, they constitute the most remarkable, original group of films made by a single director anywhere in recent years."Mother Kusters Goes to Heaven" is Mr. Fassbinder's contemporary variation on a 1929 German film, "Mother Krause's Journey to Happiness," directed by Piel Jutzi, which, as far as I can tell, was never released in this country. The screenplay of that film, which some sources (incorrectly, it seems) have attributed to Brecht, was set in the Berlin slums, and the title referred to Mrs. Krause's suicide after her daughter had been seduced and her son arrested for theft.Mr. Fassbinder's pessimism is far more complex. "Mother Kusters," which Mr. Fassbinder wrote with Kurt Raab, who often acts in Fassbinder films and is sometimes their art director, is a furious morality tale that's been slightly bent. Set in contemporary West Germany, it's about Mrs. Kusters, a working-class housewife, who answers the door one evening to be told that her husband, Herman, has, that afternoon, run amok at his factory, murdered the boss's son and then committed suicide. Why would old Herman do such a thing?Mrs. Kusters can't imagine. "He never complained," she says. "We just lived our life day by day. He was too good for this world." Her daughter-in-law (Irm Hermann), who's preoccupied with her pregnancy and a promised vacation in Finland, says, "Sometimes he looked tired, but all he ever said was, 'We're not getting any younger.'"When it's learned that old Herman had been told he was going to be discharged, an extremely chic, elegant Communist couple (Karlheinz Bohm and Margit Carstensen) swoop down on Mrs. Kusters. They persuade her that Herman's act was revolutionary, "in a way," and proceed to use her in an election campaign.All Mrs. Kusters wants is that her husband's name be cleared of smears that appeared in the tabloid press. She puts her faith first in the Communist Party, because she likes the friendliness of the meetings, and when the Communists don't help, she joins an anarchist whose "party" consists of himself and his girlfriend. They, too, fail the widow, which leads to an ending that some people interpret as Mr. Fassbinder in a gentle mood, though the way I read it, it's far more bleak than sentimental.As a social critic, Mr. Fassbinder is skeptical of all prefabricated solutions. His sympathies are with the left, but he doubts everything except the will to survive. All other impulses, he seems to be saying, can be co-opted and exploited by the Establishment."Mother Kusters" is a witty, spare, beautifully performed political comedy that, according to an early synopsis I have, was supposed to end with Mrs. Kusters being gunned down by the police. Nothing so wild happenswhich makes me wonder about the system of checks and balances that is at work within the artist. The original ending of his "Ali" also was to be a murder instead of the reconciliation that now ends the movie.It's not, I think, that Mr. Fassbinder has gone soft but, rather, that he sees a gradual, peaceful accommodation to outrageous circumstances as the worst surrender of all.

title: Long and Short of It
description: PARIS, March 7The thigh's the limit these days along the streets of Paris. The bulky top silhouette that made its appearance at recent fashion shows is now out of the showrooms and onto the boulevards. But the look is evolving as the weather warms. The trousers worn beneath the tops were the first to vanish. Then the leg warmers. Then the bulky wool tights, which were replaced by sheer tights. Forecasters who watch the weather and watch women predict that one day when it's hot, the tights will vanish too.

title: Dave Anderson
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7Bobby Hull virtually created the World Hockey Association when he signed a $3 million contract with the Winnipeg Jets five years ago. Now he is willing to create a truce with the National Hockey League by returning to the Chicago Black Hawks, if that stipulation were part of the treaty. If that's what it takes, I'll do it, Bobby Hull said. Getting the two leagues together is the only sane thing. Bobby Hull is 33 years old now, a statesman among hockey players with 20 seasons of icetime in his facescars around his eyes and chin, flattened nose that is bent like his curved Sports stickblade. Bobby Hull might appear to of a lost soul in the W.H.A. but with his smile The Times and his manner, he is the essence of big leaguer. This season, unfortunately, two serious injuries have kept him out of 46 of the Jets 65 gamesa broken wrist and a slashed ankle tendon that was cut by a teammate's skate blade. Because of the injuries, Bobby Hull has scored only five goals. In the Jets 41 loss to the Phoenix Roadrunners Saturday night, his first game in six weeks, the left wing known as the Golden Jet was skating with prop engines. his facescars around his eyes and chin, flattened nose that is bent like his curved Sports stickblade. title: Then and Now
description: TESUQUE, N. M.It is a time of auspicious beginnings, these first weeks in the foreign policy of a new Administration. New diplomats bound down the ramps in Berlin and Jerusalem, Tokyo and Cairo. Fresh voices promise to avoid the sins of the past.

title: Rudel's Revival of Louise Apt to Win Friend
description: Gustav Charpentier's Louise, which the New York City Opera restaged Sunday night, makes an apt candidate for revival in these days of awakening feminism. The opera, which has been a staple of the French repertory since its first production in 1900. actually reads like a political screed of an alternatively looney and realistic sort.

title: New Senators From House Enjoy Power, Miss Spirit
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  They yearn for the camaraderie of the House of Representatives. They say that the Senate is too formal, too clubby, too austere. They assert that it is medieval and inefficient compared with the House.

title: $1.4 Million Theft at London Airport
description: LONDON, March 7 (AP)Six armed raiders escaped with $1.4 million tonight from a security van at a KLM Royal Dutch Airlines warehouse at Heathrow Airport, the police reported.

title: Russian Fishing Trawler Charged With Unlawful Fishing Off Alaska
description: JUNEAU, Alaska, March 7 (UPI)A Federal officer boarded a Russian fishing Vessel in Alaskan waters today and cited it for unlawful fishing.

title: CAREY AND UNION HEADS TO DISCUSS LEGISLATION
description: Members of the executive council of the New York State A.F.L.C.I.O. have accepted an invitation to meet with Governor Carey at 4 P.M. tomorrow in the Capitol in Albany to discuss legislative matters of special interest to labor.

title: Central Michigan Five Gains N.C.A.A. Playoffs
description: .. Central Michigan used a balanced scoring attack to defeat Ohio University, 7664, last night at Athens, Ohio, and capture a berth in the National Collegiate basketball playoffs. With the victory, Central Michigan tied Miami University for the MidAmerican Conference crown. Having beaten Miami twice in regularseason games, the Chippewas won the chance to face North Carolina, Charlotte, on Sunday at Bloomington, Ind., in the playoffs first round.

title: Memorial Seruices
description: KILBONR. Kenyon. Memorial service will be held al the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Ave. and 80th St.. on March 9, 1977, at 4 P.M. JOHNSONAnn Gustin, of Darien Connecticul. on Feb. 27, 1977. A memorial will be he'd at St. Luke's Eplscopal Church, 1882 Post Road, Noroton, Darlen, Conn., at 12 noon on Saturday. March 12. 1977.

title: Saudis Turn Down Western Bids
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 7 (AP)Saudi Arabia has rejected Western bids and awarded electrification contracts worth $400 million to builders in India, Pakistan, Taiwan and South Korea, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.

title: Reluctant Rescuer in Wings
description: WASHINGTON, March 7President Carter took office grateful for the crucial support of New York State's 41 electoral votes and sympathetic to New York City's financial predicament, but his Administration has taken almost as tough a line in the current city crisis as the Administration of Gerald R. Ford. The problem faced by Mr. Carter and his Treasury Secretary, W. Michael Blumenthal, is that they would like politically to help Mayor Beanie, but they are determined not to be drawn prematurely into keeping the city financially afloat. Their idea is to keep the pressure on the Mayor, the unions and the banks to reach a local compromise.

title: Coffee Again King in Brazil As Prices Prime Economy
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 7It's King Coffee again In Brazil. Almost overnight, soaring coffee prices have dramatically improved the country's economic outlook and raised the bean to a position of eminence that it has not enjoyed here in more than a decade.

title: STEEL OUTPUT REACHES 4TH CONSECUTIVE HIGH
description: Steel production reached its fourth consecutive weekly high for the week ended March 5, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The trade association said that domestic mills poured 2.36 million tons in the latest week, a gain of 2.3 percent over the 2.31 million tons poured a week earlier. This meant that the industry was putting to use 76.8 percent of its total available capability, the year's high, against 75.1 percent a week earlier.

title: Port Agency Delays Ruling on Concorde; The French Protest
description: A 'showdown meeting set for Thurs. de, on whether to allow the Concorde to land at Kennedy International Airport was postponed yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to allow time for talks with the British and French on new ways to deal with ile plane's noise.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Arizona Businessmen Hire Think Tank to Study State's Future
description: PHOENIX, March 7The business establishment of the fastestgrowing state in the Sunbelt, concerned about shadows cast recently by murder, land fraud and allegations of corruption, has hired a New York think tank to peer into Arizona's future.

title: Plastic Beverage Bottles Made From Acrylonitrile Are Banned by the F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON. March 7 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it will suspend approval of plastic beverage bottles made from acrylonitrile as of Friday.

title: Reform, or Something
description: WASHINGTONReform is generally thought to be a good thing, especially in politics, but sometimes brings about the kind of change that nobody expected. As Dr. Jeanne Kirkpatrick of Georgetown University put it during a twoday forum on political reform held here last week: Always, in every case that I'm aware UAL reforms have unanticipated consequences.

title: Gold Prices Climb By More Than $3; Dollar Is Irregular
description: LONDON, March 7 (AP)Gold prices jumped more than $3 in both of Europe's major bullion centers to close today at just under $150 an ounce. The dollar had a mixed performance.

title: Inver House Going To Lois's New Shop
description: It took only a week for one of George Lois's former clients at Lois, Holland, Callaway to announce that it was following him to Creamer/FSR, where he took over the job of president on Feb. 28.

title: Contagious Agent Unlikely In 2 Deaths, Center Says
description: ATLANTA, March 7 (AP)The deaths of two employees last week at the National Center for Disease Control may have been caused by a noncontagious disease such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever, officials at the center swirl today.

title: And Now California Develops a Square Tomato
description: LOS ANGELES, March 7Farmers have realized a dream: the square tomato.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Madison Square Garden Is Up 43 As Dow Gains 1.66 in Slow Trading
description: The stock market advanced slightly yesterday in continued slow trading, with the widest price moves concentrated among specialsituation and lowpriced issues.

title: PUBLIC FUNDING OF RACES FOR SENATE IS PROPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)Decrying the increased flow of special interest money into Congressional campaigns, five senators introduced a bill today to extend public financing to Senate races. They said that a similar bill would be filed soon dealing with races for the House.

title: Doctors Offer Guidelines to Women on Breast XRays
description: The medical controversy over the use of Xrays to detect breast cancers in their earliest stages has led to publication of a set of practical guidelines for women in yesterday's issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Unions Agree to a Role in New York Package on Moratorium Debt
Mine Rescuers Hoping For a Second Miracle
description: TOWER CITY, Pa., March 7 (AP)Rescuers hoping for a second miracle pressed the search for five men trapped inside a coal mine today, but expected to find no other air pockets like the one that saved Ronald Adley, a miner.

title: Foyt Takes IndyCar Half Of Twin 200's on the Coast
description: ONTARIO, Calif., March 7 (AP)A. J. Foyt, making his 250th start in an Indianapolistype car, moved ahead on the 21st lap, steadily built his lead and won the $40,000 championshipcar portion of the Twin 200's yesterday.

title: DR. T. EDWARD TEMPLE
description: RICHMOND, March 6 (UPI)Dr. T. Edward Temple, president of Virginia Commonwealth University, died Sunday at Medical College of Virgina Hospital of complcations from a heart attack suffered Friday. He was 61 years old.

title: Events Today
description: Music

title: JUDITH P. MANDELBAUM, 70, WAS A MIZRACHI OFFICIAL
description: Judith Pinta Mandelbaum, honorary national vice president of American Mizrachi Women, died Sunday night in Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center in Brooklyn. She was 70 years old and lived at 1021 East 14th Street in Brooklyn.

title: Who Did It?
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.Has Mother Nature lost her virginity? Apparently so, according to opinion ranging from the Idaho Attorney General, Wayne Kidwell. to scientists in St. Louis.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: BRIGANTINE, N. J.The rigors of the bitterest weather in many decades have taken their toll of waterfowl and upland birds accustomed to spending the winter in the Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge.

title: MONETARISTS MEET AND CRITICIZE CARTER
description: The exponents of monetarism held their semiannual convocation in New York yesterday and offered the President, the Congress and the Federal Reserve Board some entirely predictable advice about the management of the nation's economy.

title: Bethlehem Steel Gets Loan
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a credit agreement with a group of banks headed by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York calling for borrowing of up to $300 million prior to March 1, 1980. on a revolving credit basis. The big steel company. second in this country only to the United States Steel Corporation, said the agreement also gave it the right to borrow on March, 1. 1980, up to $300 million payable in 16 equal quarterly installments ending March 1, 1984. Bethlehem said it would use the funds for general corporate purposes.

title: N.B.A. Acts To Cut Down On Fighting
description: Larry O'Brien, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, was given sweeping powers yesterday to levy heavy fines and suspend players to curb the recent rash of fighting and growing violence during games.

title: Companies List Sales and Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Dec. 31 unloss otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: TV: Fare With a British Accent
description: It is a measure of public television's continuing plight that most of the significant programming being offered on the Public Broadcasting Service's Festival '77its third annual national fundraising periodconsists of imports, especially those with a British accent. So, on Channel 13 this week, the regular outstanding presentations of Upstairs, Downstairs, The Pallisers and Childhood will be joined by a number of special acquisitions, most notably Rock Follies and The Bar Mitzvah Boy.

title: Saturday Review Sold by Cousins To Son of Prominent Publisher
description: The Saturday Review has been sold to a group headed by the 25yearold son of a prominent publishing family with other communications ties.

title: Dream and Reality
description: A catalogue of earthshaking events and their consequences:

title: Way of Adopting Charters In Counties of New York Is Upheld by High Court
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The United States Supreme Court unanimously upheld today New York's system for restructuring county governments, in which a new county charter may be adopted only if it is approved both by a majority of the county's city dwellers and by separate majority of the county's noncity dwellers.

title: Retired Chemist Helps Bluebirds Find Happiness in Protected Nests
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Md., March 7A longtime symbol of life, happiness and hope, the bluebird has become in recent years little more than a creature of daydreams and songs, seldom seen except on Valentine's Day cards or in the imagination.

title: Mr. Warnke Needs a Mandate
description: What accounts for the virulence of critics of Paul Warnke, whose nomination as chief American disarmament negotiator will be voted on tomorrow by the Senate? To judge by the heat, he must be the sort fellow who, when Soviet soldiers come marching down the streets of Washington, will be in the basement hammering his spear into a pruning hook.

title: Symphony Heading for Carnegie To Bolster New lmage of South
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C.Why would the North Carolina Symphony, an orchestra whose major endeavor for years has been concert tours for 250,000 North Carolina schoolchildren, decide suddenly to appear at New York's Carnegie Hall in the most culturally competitive city in the country?

title: Mabel Mercer Improves With Age
description: When Mabel Mercer and Bobby Short gave joint concerts at Town Hall in 1968 and 1969, Miss Mercer, in her late 60's, was leaning on her years of experience as a performer to make up for a voice that had grown disconcertingly uncertain. But on Sunday evening in Carnegie Hall, at their first concert appearance together since then, Miss Mercer, now 77, appeared to have discovered the fountain of youth.

title: Court Backs Klein On Power to Reject Suffolk Police Head
description: The State Appellate Division yesterday ruled, 3 to 2, that the Suffolk Legislature must submit its choice for a new County Police Commissioner to County Executive John V. N. Klein for his approval.

title: State Dept. Aides Testify Rights Are Key Concern In Carter Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI)Two State Department officials said today that the Carter Administration considered the promotion of human rights around the world a vital and integral part of United States foreign policy.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: SUPREME COURT RULES MISSISSIPPI MAY TAX INTERSTATE CONCERNS
description: The United States Supreme Court yesterday upheld a 5 percent tax levied by Mississippi on interstate businesses operating within the state, striking down a ruling on a similar case by the Court in 1951.

title: Leafs Beat Flyers, 42; Six Players are Ejected
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 7 (AP)Jim Mckenny scored two goals at the Spectrum tonight to help the Toronto Maple Leafs defeat the Philadelphia Flyers, 42. in a National Hockey Leaeue name.

title: Artists and Writers in Rumania Among 1,000 Earthquake Victims
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 7A number of Rumanian artists and writers were reported today to have been among the thousand or more people killed in the earthquake that struck last Friday.

title: Final College Standings
description: IVY LEAGUE

title: Yankees Like Idea of Cuban Trip, But a Few Prefer to Duck Castro
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 7Not all of the Yankees are intrigued with the prospect of meeting Fidel Castro, but they would appreciate the experience of going to Cuba for a series of exhibition names next month.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: CARTER CAUSES STIR BY SEEMING TO BACK ISRAEL ON FRONTIERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 7President Carter told Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin today that the United States believed that in any Middle East peace settlement Israel should have defensible borders to insure that agreements might never be violated.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Opposes Flaherty
description: PITTSBURGH, March 7 (UPI)The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today it would oppose the expected nomination of Mayor Pete Flaherty of Pittsburgh to be Deputy Attorney General because of his record on school integration.

title: Larry Ketron's Atmospheric Quail Southwest
description: In Quail Southwest at the Manhattan Theater Club. Larry Ketron demonstratesas he did last season in Patrick Henry Lake Liquorsthat he has an understanding of localized provincial atmosphere and eccentric characters.

title: $70 Million Loan for Ecuador
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 (Reuters)  Wells Fargo Bank N.A., acting as agent for 16 international banks, said it had signed a loan agreement in New York to provide $70 million in financing to Ecuador for industrial projects.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Carter Administration is drafting a comprehensive new policy for restraining United States arms sales around the world and, it is hoped, sales by other international suppliers of weapons.

title: Burke Cancels Trip to 3 East African Nations Because of Controversy
description: TRENTON, March 7The State Education Commissioner, Fred G. Burke, canceled plans today to study educational facilities in three East African nations. The trip was to have begun Thursday.

title: Supreme Court Voids Oklahoma. Press Curb in Juvenile Shooting Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Supreme Court ruled today that courts may not ?? the press from publishing or broadcasting information about juveniles who are involved in delinquency proceedings if the information was disclosed in courtroom hearings that were open to the public.

title: The Heinz Solution: Still Inflationary
description: Congress is close to approving a $4 billion public works bill, one part of Jimmy Carter's economic stimulus package. Still at issue, though, is the formula to be used in parceling out funds to individual states. New York's stake in the outcome: $111 million.

title: Quake Halts Gymnasts
description: Because of the earthquake that struck Rumania last Friday, Nadia Comaneci and the Rumanian gymnastics team have canceled a scheduled trip to New York this week.

title: Youth Boots In 4
description: It was shortly after high noon when the champion swaggered into the Aqueduct jockey room, much like the marshal who had been out of town on business. Things had changed while he was gone, but now Angel Cordero Jr., Numero Uno himself, was back to straighten things out.

title: BRITAIN CUTS ESTIMATES OF NORTH SEA OIL OUTPUT
description: LONDON. March 7 (Reuters)The British Energy Department has revised downward its estimate of North Sea oil production and the surplus to be available for export during the early 1980's, Government sources said.

title: New York Savings Banks Post Decline in January Mortgages
description: Savings banks in New York State closed $668 million in new mortgages in January, down substantially from an alltime high of $838 million closed in December but almost twice the $335 million in new mortgages closed in January 1976, the Savings Bank Association of New York State reported yesterday.

title: U.C.L.A.'s Johnson Is Player of '76
description: Marques Johnson, the U.C.L.A. forward who is likely to be picked near the top of the professional draft, was named The Associated Press college basketball player of the year yesterday. On Saturday he was named for that honor by United Press International.

title: UNIONS AGREE TO ROLE IN NEW YORK PACKAGE ON MORATORIUM DEBT
description: New York City moved a step yesterday toward a possible patchwork solution to its moratorium debt crisis when the municipal employee unions unanimously agreed to participate in a revived $1 billion financing package aimed at meeting the city's borrowing needs without reliance on the leading commercial banks.

title: Coffee for Delivery This Month Passes Level of $3 a Pound
description: The price of green (unroasted) coffee for delivery this month on the docks of New York crossed the $3apound level for the first time yesterday.

title: Too Many Federal Aides Are Getting Excessive Pay, President Informs Cabinet
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI)President Carter said today that the Government was paying excessive salaries to too many workers and told Cabinet members they should try to remedy the situation.

title: Three Children Abandoned Upstate
description: KINGSTON, N.Y., March 7Ulster County authorities searched today for a young mother who allegedly abandoned her three young children in the county welfare office here last Wednesday and left a note saying that she could no longer care for them.

title: Actions by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Track and Field
description: EASTERN STATES MEET AT PRINCETON, N.J. TRACK EVENTS

title: Colorado Criminals Paid Victims $658,717 in 76
description: DENVER, March 7 (UPI)Victims of crimes in Colorado received $658,717 last year from the men and women who robbed or assaulted them.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: PARTY AND FARM LEADERS DISMISSED IN BYELORUSSIA
description: MOSCOW, March 7 (Reuters)More than 60 Communist Party officials and agricultural leaders have been dismissed in a largescale anticorruption campaign in the Soviet Byelorussian Republic, according to a local newspaper that reached here today.

title: Soviet Dissidents, Guests Of U.S. Newsman, Seized
description: MOSCOW, March 7Two Jewish dissidents, Vladimir Slepak and Anatoly Shcharansky, were blocked today by K.G.B. agents from accompanying a Los Angeles Times correspondent into his apartment. The newsman, Robert C. Toth, had invited the activists to lunch.

title: The Detente of Disaster
description: The immense destruction of life and property caused by an earthquake centered in Bucharest, Rumania, has brought forth, as all disasters do, offers of aid from many countries: There is no stinting on international cooperation when nature demonstrates that it still has the upper hand. But that raises an old question: Why is it that the nations of the world can be so generous in alleviating the consequences of natural disasters and yet be so grudging when it comes to preventing the manmade kind?

title: Peking Fills Four Provincial Posts
description: HONG KONG, March 7China has shuffled four more provincial party leaders end reportedly named new officials to press and broadcast posts. as the regime continues to move systematically, if slowly, to resolve the political problems left over by factional conflict in the last few years.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Dr. Tibor A. Weber, 82, Officer Of Hungarian AntiCommunists
description: Dr. Tibor A. Weber, former foreign relations officer of the Hungarian National Council, which called itself the antiCommunist Hungarian government in exile in this country, died Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in the Lancaster Hotel.

title: Case of the Smuggled Smokes
description: Lawenforcement officials believe that in New York City, one out of every two packs of cigarettes is distributed and sold by the underworld. The tobacco industry, once complacent about smuggling, is now alarmed that the mob has become its unwelcome partner. At the suggestion of the industry, former United States Attorney Paul Curran last week formed a Citizens Committee Against Bootleg Cigarettes to educate the public and agitate for a crackdown.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: The current tax bill covering elements of the Carter economic stimulus makes an attempt to simplify the complicated tax forms by greatly revising the standard deduction. Page 45.

title: Trade Parley Seeking a President
description: GENEVA, March 7 (Reuters)The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development opened a fourweek session today and adjourned after 30 minutes because delegates could not agree on a president. conference sources said. The choice is between Manuel Armendariz of Mexico and Herbert Walker of Jamaica.

title: South Korean Opposition Leader Says U.S. Troops Should Remain
description: The leader of the political opposition in South Korea said yesterday that there should be no hasty withdrawal of American troops from his country, declaring that United States forces should remain until solid progress for unification of the two Koreas became evident.

title: Briton Sees a Treaty Breach
description: LONDON, March 7A minister of the Labor Government told the House of Commons tonight that a refusal to allow the supersonic Concorde airliner to use Kennedy Airport would be regarded as a breach of treaty rights.

title: Mary Donlon, 1st Woman In New York State Named To Federal Bench, Is Dead
description: Mary Honor Donlon, the first woman in New York State to be appointed to the Federal bench, died Saturday in the Tucson (Ariz.) Medical Center after a brief illness. She was 83 years old.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: PHILADELPHIAJohn A. Durant an ambitious 47yearold black who has not worked regularly since he lost his civil service clerk's job in Connecticut more than three years ago because of a cutback in Federal funding. Now, as the only male student in a class of 25 learning typing skills in jobtraining program here for poor and disadvantaged persons, he is determined to get back on the Government payroll in a higher classification as a clerktypist.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: West Bank March Foiled By Israeli Forces
description: RAMALLAH, Israeli  Occupied West Bank, March 7 (Reuters)Israeli troops today hurled tear gas to break up demonstration by hundreds of Arab youths backing a hunger strike by Arab guerrillas in Israeli jails.

title: DEBATE IS RENEWED OVER PRIMARY DATE
description: ALBANY, March 7Barely pausing for breath, Democrats and Republicans here are getting ready for yet another round of partisan squabbling over the date for this year's primary election.

title: Kearny School Superintendent Is Arraigned on Morals Charge
description: UNION, March 7 (UPI)The Kearny School Superintendent was arraigned today on a morals charge filed by an undercover state policeman.

title: Bonn Minister Assailed Over Bugging Incident
description: BONN. March 7West Germany's Interior Minister is drawing increasingly heavy fire for letting the West German secret service plant a bug in the home of a nuclear physicist who is suspected of ties with terrorists.

title: New York to Florida: A New Look in Commuting
description: There are no drafty stations, gruff conductors or teethchattering waits in the neardark for these commuters. Instead, they begin their trip in a comfortably upholstered chair, their feet resting on a thick carpet and their hands circling generously filled drinks.

title: In Memoriam
description: GITTERAbraham. March 8, 1959. In loving, everlasling memory of dear husband and father.

title: Carter Plans to Come to New York To Take Part in St. Patrick's Parade
description: Jimmy Carter plans to join the St. Patrick's Day parade up Fifth Avenue next week, shrugging off the reception given hitn just a year ago, when he was twice ejected from the line of March.

title: Reluctant Rescuer in Wings
description: WASHINGTON, March 7President Carter took office grateful for the crucial support of New York State's 41 electoral votes and sympathetic to New York City's financial predicament, but his Administration has taken al most as tough a line in the current city crisis as the Administration of Gerald R. Ford. The problem faced by Mr. Carter and his Treasury Secretary. W. Michael Blumenthal, is that they would like politically to help Mayor Beame, but they are determined not to be drawn prematurely into keeping the city financially afloat. Their idea is keep the pressure on the Mayor, the unions and the banks to reach a local compromise.

title: MARCEL DUHAMEL
description: PARIS, March 7(AP) Duhamel, founder of a popular murdermystery book series numbering more than 1,700 titles and 70 million copies, died at his villa in southern France yesterday, Editions Gallimard announced today. He was 76.

title: MAUDE E. TEN EYCK, 74, EXASSEMBLYWOMAN
description: Maude E. Ten Eyck, a former New York State Assemblywoman from Manhattan and a lifetime Republican activist, died yesterday morning in Cohoes Memorial Hospital in upstate Cohoes, N.Y., at the age of 74. A former resident of East 22d Street, Mrs. Ten Eyck lived more recently in an old family home on the Mohawk River in Waterford, north of Albany.

title: Threat of Boycotting U.S. No Bluff, Africans Warn
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 7The bureaucrats of national sport in black Africa are insisting that there is no bluff in their collective decision to boycott all sports competition with those countries whose teams play South African teams. And they add that the first application of the new policy may be aimed at the United States if its Davis Cup tennis team goes through with Plans to meet South Africa next month.

title: French Parliamentary Leaders Plead With U.S. Envoy for Concorde
description: PARIS, March 7Delegations of French parliamentary leaders, including Communists, went to the United States Embassy today to emphasize the persistent and mounting French demand that the Concorde supersonic aircraft be allowed landing rights in New York.

title: About New York
description: Jack Bigel, the municipal union strategist in the fiscal crisis whose pipe smoke wreathes him like layers of the rich leftwing union rhetoric that warmed his youth, could not resist and had to request autographs from Pat and Bill and Al, three of the city's leading bankers.

title: Northern Mariana Isles Approve Commonwealth
description: AGANA, Guam, March 7 (Reuters)Residents of the Northern Mariana Islands, a small western Pacific community of 14,000 people, have overwhelmingly approved a proposed commonwealth constitution that would tighten the islands' political bonds with the United States.

title: F.D.U. Nine Fielded Ineligible Player in 76
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 7 (AP)Fairleigh Dickinson University has forfeited seven of its 1976 baseball games because of the use of an ineligible player.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: KAZUSHIGE HIRASAWA
description: TOKYO, March 7 AP)  Kazushige Hirasawa. a foreign affairs commentator for the Japan Broadcasting Corporation and former consul in New York, died of cancer tonight at a Tokyo hospital. He was 67 years old.

title: G.M. Sued on Switched Engines; Illinois Asks Restitution to Buyers.
description: CHICAGO, March 7 (AP)  The General Motors Corporation owes $175 each to 43,000 persons who bought 1977 Oldsmobiles equipped with a lowerpriced Chevrolet engine, the Illinois Attorney General asserted today.

title: CONVICTION IS VOIDED IN VOICEPRINT CASE
description: SCRANTON, Pa., March 7A man convicted here of a 1972 murder largely on the basis of spectrograms, or voiceprints, has been granted a new trial because the Pennsylvania Supreme Court has held that such techniques have not been generally accepted by the scientific community.

title: Brown Warns of Drought Disaster; Says Hard Choices Face California
description: LOS ANGELES, March 7Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., warned here today that droughtstricken California was facing a disaster of immeasurable magnitude.

title: Notes on People
description: Sources in the Vatican said yesterday that Pope Paul VI plans this year to proclaim two new saints, one an American, John Nepomucene Neumann, a Bishop of Philadelphia in the 19th century. Bishop Neumann would be the first male American saint. He was a naturalized citizen born in what is now Czechoslovakia, who came to this country in 1836 and became known for his work in the parochial school system and among imigrants. The canonization ceremony has been set for June 19 in St. Peter's Basilica. Scheduled for canonization Oct. 9 is Charbel Makhlouf, a Lebanese hermit who died in 1898.

title: Tigers' Fidrych Still Unspoiled and Carefree
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 6Have no fear, you troubled baseball fans: The Bird is back, and he is talking to the ball again.

title: JAVITS TELLS OF ACCORD ON TAINO TOWERS WORK
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that : a tentative agreement had been reached to permit the resumption of suspended construction work at the controversial East Harlem housing project knoWn as Taino Towers.

title: CRUISE MISSILE CONTRACTS ARE AWARDED BY PENTAGON
