description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AF)The Air Force awarded the Boeing Company $300 million contract today for the full development of a bomberlaunched cruise missile.

title: Market Place
description: To investors who follow Gulf and Western Industries. the announcement yesterday that the conglomerate was offering to buy Madison Square Garden stock for $10 a share had a familiar ring.

title: Dance: Julie Fraad's Athleticism
description: The anxiety that one feels for aerialists and other professional risktakers has little place in a dance concert. Julie Fraad's choreography, however, has a brutal athleticism that flirts with falls and makes one alert to danger rather than artistry. Her program Sunday evening at the Cunningham studio was more a contest for survival than an esthetic concert.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 8, 1977

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: La Cote Basque has become the latest in a series of major restaurants to hire waitresses in the face of a sex discrimination suit. The American Civil Liberties Union, which filed a class action suit last spring against 10 of the city's best known eating places, announced yesterday that Cathryn Smith, a 26yearold Frenchspeaking waitress, would become the first woman to wait on tables at the restaurant at 5 East 55th Street. Under the terms of the settlement the restaurant also agreed to start a program aimed at attracting qualified women workers.

title: 2 Honored in S.I. School Names
description: Two Staten Islandersa policeman slain in the line of duty in 1972 and the man elected Vice President of the United States in 1816were honored in the naming of two new schools by the community school board last night.

title: Give the New Juvenile Law a Chance
description: Stimulated by the flurry of headlines about crimes against the elderly, the New York State Senate has adopted a package of fiercesounding proposals on juvenile offenders which ignores a new and promising law that has yet to receive a fair trial.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Port Agency Delays Ruling on Concorde; The French Protest
description: A showdown meeting set for Thursday on whether to allow the Concorde to land at Kennedy International Airport was postponed yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to allow time for talks with the British and French on new ways to deal with the plane's noise.

title: Coined Silver, Ruthie s Native Win; At Aqueduct: Cauthen vs. Cordero
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., March 7A few hours after two tame lions lunged down the track in Gulfstream Park's annual exoticanimal race today, a couple of potential Triple Crown tigers emerged from the divided 26th running of the Florida Derby.

title: Harrell, Levine Are Good Team On Cello, Piano
description: Whenever a string player and a pianist are cobilled and there are no pieces for solo piano on the program, one assumes that it will be the string player's recital. But when Lynn Harrell, cellist, and James Levine, pianist, got together for a Schubertiad Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, it didn't work out quite that way.

title: CARTER CAUSES STIR BY SEEMING TO BACK ISRAEL ON FRONTIERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 7President Carter told Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin today that the United States believed that in any Middle East peace settlement Israel should have defensible borders to insure that agreements might never be violated.

title: New York City Environmental Unit Asks Changes in AirPollution Code
description: The City Environmental Protection Administration has proposed sweeping changes in the airpollution control code that relax some standards while tightening others, according to city officials.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 7  A Bergen County mental health official told a legislative committee today that the state had been boarding emotionally disturbed children in virtual hell holes in other states.

title: OHIOAN, RAILING AT WHITES, TAKES 2 HOSTAGES; FREES 1
description: WARRENSVILLE HEIGHTS, Ohio. March 8 (UPI)A black gunman who said that all white people have to get off the planet in seven days released one of his two hostages at a city police station early this morning in exchange for a television set.

title: Move to Regional Planning Is Led By a MinneapolisSt. Paul Agency
description: ST. PAULNobody elected John Boland to his job, and few in the Twin Cities area really know who he is or quite what he does. But probably no one has as much say about the way two million residents of the Middle West metropolitan area will live, work and play for the next generation.

title: New York to Florida: A New Look in Commuting
description: There are no drafty stations, gruff conductors or teethchattering waits in the neardark for these commuters. Instead, they begin their trip in a comfortably upholstered chair, their feet resting on a thick carpet and their hands circling generously filled drinks.

title: U.S. Ends Effort to Force Inquiry By U.N. Panel on Soviet Activists
description: GENEVA, March 7The United States abandoned today its attempt to persuade the United Nations Commission on Human Rights to question the Soviet Union on the fate of its dissidents. The commission thereupon dropped the proposal, which the Soviet Union had denounced as unwarranted interference in its internal affairs.

title: A Newly Discovered Mosaic Reflects a Glittering Period in Greece
description: KIRAS VRYSI, GreeceToday this is a quiet farming village, dotted with groves of orange and lemon trees. Almost 2,000 years ago it was a sophisticated center of art and culture, the home of the Isthmian Games, one of the four great athletic festivals of ancient Greece.

title: Books of The Times
description: CONVENTION. By Richard Reeves. Illustrated. 246 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $10.

title: Bhutto's Party Wins Big Majority In Voting for Pakistan Parliament
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Tuesday, March 8Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto Avon a heavy majority in Pakistan's parliamentary election yesterday.

title: Kean Proposes Reforms in Elections and Curbs on State's Officials
description: Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean of Livingston, a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, proposed yesterday a series of election and government reforms, and reported on the results of a poll that he said

title: Support Rises in Senate for Energy Dept.
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Senators of both parties expressed reservations today about the Administration's plan to create a unified Department of Energy with a dominant voice in the economic aspects of offshore leasing and authority over all oil and gas pricing.

title: JUDGE REJECTS A BID TO REMOVE FELDMAN
description: NEWARK, March 7  Judge Charles S. Barrett of Superior Court refused today to order the removal of Matthew Feldman as President of the State Senate despite the Teaneck Democrat's plea of guilty to charges of commercial bribery last November.

title: Bryne Runs 4:07.4 Mile Leg In Eastern Schoolboy Meet
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 7Kevin Byrne ran an anchormile leg of the distancemedley relay in 4 minutes 7.4 seconds; Sanya Owolabi of Sleepy Hollow set a national indoor record for juniors in the triple jump, and Ronaldo Nehemiah of Scotch PlainsFanwood High tied the national mark in the 60yard high hurdles for the third time tonight.

title: H.U.D. Threatens to Cut Funds If Cities Neglect LowIncome Housing
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)The Department of Housing and Urban Development is threatening to cut off community development funds to localities that fail to use the money for projects that benefit low  and moderateincome residents.

title: CONTROL DATA SETS A 15CENT DIVIDEND
description: The Control Data Corporation had planned something different for its board meeting yesterdaya setting behind the Iron Curtain for the announcement of its first cash dividend.

title: People in Sports
description: Frank Ryan, a quarterback from Rice University who led the Cleveland Browns to the National Football League championship in 1964, has been named director of athletics at Yale University. Ryan, who will join the staff at Yale on June 1, succeeds Carmen Cozza who decided to give up the job in order to concentrate on his duties as the head football coach.

title: Money
description: Monday, March 7, 1977

title: KO JUN TAEK
description: TOKYO, March 7 (UPI)Ko Jun Taek, a former vice President of North Korea, died yesterday, the official North Korean press agency said today. It reported that he had died of illness but did not specify its nature.

title: Lear Plans an Offshoot of Mary Hartman for the Summer
description: Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman, Norman Lear's successful syndicated comedy soapopera, will not go into reruns this summer as it did last year but instead will be replaced by a new halfhour program related to the nightly serial.

title: Saudis Set $1 Billion for Africa
description: CARO, March 7 (Reuters)The Saudi Arabian Foreign Minister, Prince Saud alFaisal, said his country would allocate $1 billion for economic development in Africa. He told the AfricanArab summit here the sum included $2 million of the $5 million that Arab foreign ministers had pledged to African liberation movements.

title: Fashion Editor Gets Into the Act Now She's on Producing End
description: Not every theatergoer wants to write a play, but it seems that every fashion editor yearns to become a part of the designing or selling action. China Machado and Cathy di Montezemolo, formerly of Harper's Bazaar and Vogue, respectively, are two who have bridged the gap from observers to active participants in the fashion fray.

title: U.S. to Investibate Possible Misuse Of Public Job Funds by New York
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Department of Labor, at the request of an official of the N.A.A.C.P., will investigate possible misuse of Federal public employment funds by New York City, a department spokesman said today.

title: Citicorp Is. Planning A $350 Million Sale Of LongTerm Notes
description: While the bond market made a modest recovery in quiet trading yesterday, Citicorp, the bankholding company with the highest profits in the country, announced plans to sell $350 million of longterm notes. In addition, underwriters who have been offering $130 million of Indiana Bell Telephone Cornpany bonds since Feb. 23, Markets permitted them to trade in the open market and Illinois sold $110 million of tripleA taxexempt bonds.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAMSONMollie, In her 100th year, on March 7, 1077, singerpoet, citizen at 80, deloved wife of the Iate Isaac Abramson, devoted mother of Esther Fox, Rebecca Auramson and Debby Postal, beautiful grandmother of Vicky. Kenneth and Made??ne and dear greatgrandmother. She loved us all. Services today at 1 P.M., al Parkside, 1345 Jerome Ave. (at 170th St.), Bronx.

title: Move to Regional Planning Is Led By a MinneapolisSt. Paul Agency
description: ST. PAULNobody elected John Boland to his job, and few in the Twin Cities area really know who he is or quite what he does. But probably no one has as much say about the way two million residents of the Middle West metropolitan area will live, work and play for the next generation.

title: Giants Get Ramsey for Morton
description: Craig Morton, who was booed by fans at Giants Stadium last season, was traded yesterday for Steve Ramsey, who was booed by Denver Bronco fans last season. The Giants will also receive future considerations in the National Football League deal.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SOLID STUFF Tonight's free, illustrated lecture at 6 o'clock by Ed Hamilton, foundryman and author, is expected to draw a large audience, including outoftowners, at the New York Public Library's Donnell Center, 20 West 53d Street.

title: State Department Is Expected to Lift the Ban on Travel to Cuba and 3 Asian Communist Countries Soon
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Carter Administration is expected within a few days to lift the restrictions on travel by Americans to Cuba and three Asian countries.

title: Planning Agency Moves To Widen Limitations On Pornography Outlets
description: Despite new warnings that their action might be declared unconstitutional, a divided City Planning Commission yesterday approved two amendments to its antipornography zoning regulations that might have the effect of banning all socalled adult uses from every borough in New York City except Manhattan.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: GENERAL

title: Music: Pavarotti
description: Hearing Luciano Pavarotti's recital in Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night was like taking a trip into the past. The mutual admiration between the lovable tenor of the Metropolitan Opera and his capacity audience, which also filled the stage, was real and tumultuous. But the kind of program that was presented and the way it was sung recalled the good old days of an artist such as Tito Schipa.

title: RIFT WITH GERMANS OVER TANK WIDENING
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  A oncepromising agreement between the United States and West Germany to use some common components in their new main battle tanks is falling apart, creating a potential point of friction between the two allies.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Plans for reactivating a $77 million capital spending program for the JohnsManville Corporation's Jeffrey asbestos mine in Quebec were announced yesterday by John R. McKinney, president, who said the action was prompted by the recent modification by the Government of Premier Rene Levesque of its proposal for taking over the province's $300millionayear asbestos industry.

title: Vance to Visit Jamaica Soon
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI)Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will soon visit Jamaica and plans to arrange meeting between President Carter and Prime Minister Michael Manley, the State Department said today. The department, in a joint communiqu on the visit to Washington last week of the Jamaican Foreign Minister, Percival J. Patterson. said the two countries had agreed to set up joint technical committees for consultations on economic cooperation and assistance.

title: Bridge:
description: If a defender does something brilliant and successful it is not necessarily an indication of great expertise. It is conceivable that he made play largely by accident, without the necessary analysis. However, in the vast majority of cases, accident can be ruled out, as in the hand shown in the diagram.

title: Saudis Pledge $ 1 Billion for Africa As 59Nation Parley Starts in Cairo
description: CAIRO, March 7Saudi Arabia announced today that it was allocating $1 billion for assistance to black Africa, stealing the show on the first day of conference of African and Arab leaders from 59 countries representing more than 300 million people.

title: Marriage for the Masses
description: THE CREATION of a director with an international reputation for being enigmatic, rather difficult to decipher, Scenes From a Marriage is startling in its utter accessibility to a mass audience. The reason is simple and fascinating: The work was created for television. Ingmar Bergman moved from film to the small electronic screen, created a work of power and intensely personal beauty, and was delighted to discover that, for the first time, his bluecollar neighbors in Sweden really liked something I had done.

title: Palestinian Factions End Fighting Near Israel
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 8Militant Palestinian guerrillas who oppose a peaceful settlement with Israel were reported today to have been defeated by rival Palestinian groups in two days of fighting in Nabatiye, a Lebanese town nine miles from Israel.

title: Advertising
description: There was a time when Grey Advertising had the reputation of being a revolving door agencypeople came and went or were let go, and quite a bit, some said.

title: Notes on People
description: SINCE she's the daughter of Ronald Reagan, the actress Maureen Reagan expected to be received enthusiastically by a caucus of Republican legislators in Oklahoma City when she went there to campaign for Oklahoma's approval of the equal rights amendment. She was very wrong. After making her pitch, Miss Reagan was confronted by State Representative Joan Hastings, who said, according to United Press International, We're not used to people talking down to us.

title: Four Held in Jail Drug Case
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., March 8 (UPI)Three prison guards and a cook at the Burlington County jail have been arrested on charges of selling drugs to inmates. The arrests followed a twomonth investigation into sales of marijuana and barbiturates inside the jail.

title: Red Smith
description: When Art Smith worked on the Chicago Times the paper was run by Louis Ruppel, a big, hardnosed and aggressive editor whose speech was redolent of Brooklyn. On some assignments in the northern Wisconsin woods, Art wrote a line about a log cabin among the towering tamaracks. no doubt because the alliteration pleased him. In the first edition this caught the eye of some tree freak in the city room, who protested to Ruppel that tamaracks didn't tower, reaching a height of only 20 or 25 feet. Don't hire no more of them little guys, Ruppel told the city editor. Everything looks big to em. That wasn't why Art lost that job, though. Patti was. She was the food editor, a smashing young widow with a small daughter. An artist, she would write about how to cook turnips in beer, and illustrate the piece with penandink sketches. Ruppel fired Art for marrying her. He took my cooking editor, Ruppel said. I'll fix it so they got nothing to cook.

title: Plan Due Today For Protection Of Limit Orders
description: The National Market Associationmade up of the country's six major securities exchanges and the National Association of Securities Dealersis expected to come up with a plan today to protect limit orders at all exchanges and markets as part of its proposed electronic intermarket execution system.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE TREND is to lightness, in wine, in beer, in food and in whisky. This may be partly why cognac is in trouble. Many descriptive adjectives have been applied to cognac but light is not one of them.

title: A 3Star Chef, and Resourceful, Too
description: WHEN ALAIN CHAPEL, generally acknowledged to be one of the 10 or 12 finest chefs of France, arrived in my kitchen, he looked disconsolate.

title: Child's World
description: REMEMBER how to break in a fielder's glove? You torture itfold it, wrap it, pound it, spit in it, stomp on it, whisper to ituntil it agrees to play ball.

title: People in Sports
description: Rod Gilbert showed up at City Hall yesterday to accept his Bronze Medallion, the City of New York's highest honor, from Mayor Beame with a pain in his neck, a collar and six stitches in his head, but this is still a great week for the Rangers' right wing. The sore neck and stitches are the result of colliding with Ralph Klassen of the Cleveland Barons Sunday night and crashing head first into the Madison Square Garden ice. However, the injuries won't keep him from showing up for Rod Gilbert Night at the Garden tonight and also playing against the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Rev. Daniel Leary Sullivan, 67; Served in New York Churches
description: The Rev. Daniel Leary Sullivan, who recently served as associate pastor of the Sacred Heart Church in Manhattan, died yesterday of a heart attack at a doctor's office at 1 Rockefeller Plaza. He was 67 years old and lived at the rectory of the Roman Catholic church, at 307 East 33d Street.

title: Dispute Over Facilities Threatens Dance Series
description: Last night's performance in the weekly Dance Umbrella series at the Roundabout Theater, 333 West 23d Street, was suddenly canceled as a result of dispute involving the series producer, the theater management and the board of the cooperative housing development that is the Roundabout's landlord.

title: PEPTIC ULCER DECLINE BAFFLING TO DOCTORS
description: The incidence of peptic ulcer, one of man's most common serious ailments, has declined dramatically over the last 20 years, and doctors do not know why.

title: West German Economy Changing As Plants Go Abroad to Cut Costs
description: BONN, March 8With the stable West German mark turning made in Germany into a synonym for expensive, a fundamental change has begun. Like the American multinationals of the 1950's and 1960's, the West German industrial giants are moving many manufacturing operations abroad to save money.

title: Coffee Roasters Balk at $3 Price And Spot Contract Falls Sharply
description: Coffee roasters, a group that includes the big food concerns, balked yesterday at paying more than $3 a pound for green beans deliverable this month and the spot March 1977 contract tumbled 14.22 cents a pound.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: IF THE MAN in the Chesterfield coat with the two little girls is still wondering about the woman with the pretzel wagon outside the Whitney Museum, perhaps this will help:

title: Cabaret: Tom Petty's Pop Punk Rock Evokes Sounds of 60's
description: Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers. who are opening for Roger McGuinn at the Bottom Line through tonight, are a classic instance of that increasingly common phenomenon, the 1970's poppunkrock band with a strong feeling for the diverse sounds of the 60's. Dwight Twilley (also on Mr. Petty's record label, Shelter) and the Raspberries come to the mind, right off. Everything is executed with precision and a good deal of spirit. But at first it sounds too programmed, with all that vital rockandroll risk lost somewhere on the cuttingroom floor.

title: Japan Going Underground With Vast Shopping Complexes
description: OSAKA, JapanJapan is going underground.

title: Holdup on Bus Yields Unusual Bag of Loot
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., March 8 (AP)Two armed holdup men may he surprised when they open a laundry bag they had ordered a busload of 30 elderly passengers to fill with cash and valuables, the police said.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Levesque Will Make Proposals For Quebec Independence Vote
description: QUEBEC, March 8Premier Ren Lvesque announced today to the opening session of the Quebec National Assembly that his government would make detailed proposals for an association between a sovereign Quebec and the rest of Canada.

title: Camisole: Summer's Uniform?
description: The lace trimming is optional and the sheer blouse is obsolete, but the camisole promises to explode as one of the most ubiquitous fashions when the weather warms. In its current incarnation, it's a bare top with narrow or inchwide straps. It turns up in daytime versions for sunning (or at least keeping cool) and in evening versions in gossamer fabrics for just looking delicious.

title: Adverse Outlook on Interest Rates Helps to Push the Dow 3.08 Lower
description: Concern over inflation helped to send the stock market moderately lower yesterday in heavier trading.

title: Carter News Parley Will Be On TV Today
description: President Carter's news conference, scheduled for 10 A.M. today, will be telecast live by the three networks and their local stationsChannels 2, 4 and 7. Radio stations WCBSAM, WINS, WMCA and WNYCAM also will provide live coverage.

title: Carter Offers to Talk to Gunman if He Frees Hostage
description: WARRENSVILLE HEIGHTS, Ohio, March 8 (UPI)President Carter promised today to talk with Corey Moore, 26 years old, if the black gunman would give up a twoday siege and release the white police captain he has been holding hostage in City Hall. A friend of Mr. Moore said that the gunman believes whites should be liquidated.

title: Charges of Widespread Fraud in California Medicare Program Made at Congressional Hearing on Health
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Allegations of widespread fraud and political involvement in California's Medicare program marked the opening session today of a Congressional hearing on the nation's health.

title: AUTO INSURER IS TOLD TO LIMIT ITS POLICIES
description: The Empire Mutual Insurance Company and its subsidiary, the Allcity Insurance Company, have been ordered to cease renewing the automobile fire, theft and collision coverage of their 300,000 policyholders beginning March 21.

title: Church Loses on Hotel
description: A multiple dwelling maintained by the Presbyterian Church in Wildwood is a hotel subject to state regulation, the Appellate Division of Superior Court ruled. It upheld the Department of Community Affairs, which maintained that the building, owned by the Presbytery of New Jersey of the Orthodox Presbyterian Church, qualified as a hotel. The court rejected the church's contention that it used the building only to house participants in a summer Boardwalk Chapel program.

title: State of Emergency in Florida
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 8 (AP)Gov. Reubin Askey today declared a state of emergency for 31 Florida counties which he said had received road damage from the severe cold weather. The declaration, released by aides because Mr. Askew is in Europe, was the first step necessary to apply for Federal funds to aid in repairing the highways.

title: The U. N. Today
description: MARCH 9, 1977

title: Chess:
description: The Dutch grandmaster Genna Sosonko, a Russian emigre, and Grandmaster Efim Geller of the Soviet Union shared first prize in the 39th Hoogoven International Tournament in WijkaanZee, the Netherlands. Each scored 83 in the 12player roundrobin tourney.

title: Braves Ask Court to Lift Turner's Year Suspension
description: ATLANTA, March 8 (AP)The Atlanta Braves and Ted Turner, their owner, filed a lawsuit in United States District Court today seeking an injunction lifting Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's oneyear suspension of Turner. The suit also asks that the loss of a firstround choice in the baseball draft be overturned, but it seeks no damages.

title: ROTHKOCASE FIGURE ACCUSED OF FORGERY
description: Frank Lloyd, head of the international group of Marlborough Galleries, has been indicted on charges that he tampered with evidence he was ordered to produce during the trial of a suit over the estate of Mark Rothko, one of the 20th century's leading abstractexpressionist artists.

title: Coq au Vin
description: 1 fivepound fowl, cut into serving pieces flour for dredging

title: 4 Landmarks Designated
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission voted to designate four new landmarks in Brooklyn. They are the Fort Hamilton Officers Club, which is the original granite fort built there in 182531 within a dry moat and set into the slope of a hill; the 23d Regiment Armory, at 1322 Bedford Avenue in the Crown Heights section, resembling a medieval fortress and built in 189195; Public School 39, at 417 Sixth Avenue, opened in 1877 and built in the Italianate and French Second Empire style, and the 83d Precinct Police Station and stable, built in the Romanesque Revival style at DeKalb and Wilson Avenues and opened in 1895.

title: White House Sees Serious Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI)The White House acknowledged today that the dispute over landing rights for the Concorde in New York was becoming a serious international issue.

title: Carter Plans Trip To London to Meet Six Leaders in May
description: WASHINGTON, March 8President Carter plans to make his first trip abroad since his inauguration during May, a spokesman said today, when he and the leaders of six other industrialized countries gather in London for a conference that will go beyond the economic agenda of its two predecessors.

title: Private Lives
description: SINCE WE shall be devoting this solemn space next week to the terrors of being average, the sermon for this morning is on excellence, and what to do whenopening a refrigerator or an oven or a closet or a mindyou find it. Excellence sits there, like a rutabaga with edible tubers. It doesn't require you. In several ways, you are a threat to it. As it contemplates itself, you may be hungry, as we all are, for rainbows, approval, a second wind and a second chance, and you may settle for this rutabaga.

title: Seattle Park Sensible Response to Freeway
description: SEATTLEWhen this city decided a few years ago to turn an old gas works into a monumental sculptural centerpiece for a new park, it thrust itself into the vanguard of American park design. Now Seattle has confirmed its position with another unusual park, this one a 5.4acre mass of concrete completely covering a stretch of downtown freeway. Called simply Freeway Park, it does triple duty: It provides downtown open space, eliminates freeway noise, and links together two segments of town that the highway had cut apart from each other. position with another unusual park, this one a 5.4acre mass of concrete completely covering a stretch of downtown freeway. Called simply Freeway Park, it does triple duty: It provides downtown open space, eliminates freeway noise, and links together two segments of town that the highway had cut apart from each other.

title: Pineapple Flambee
description: 1 ripe pineapple

title: ALBANY SEEKS CURBS ON CITIES' PROPERTY
description: ALBANY, March 8Saying that they suspect the existence of many sweetheart arrangements that never see the light of day, a bipartisan group of senior legislators introduced a bill today that would impose strict controls and publicdisclosure requirements on the sale or lease of property by or to local governments throughout the state.

title: Proposal on Tuition Aid Is Given General Approval
description: NEWARK, March 8A controversial tuition assistance proposal that could adversely affect more than 8.000 middleincome college students and provide aid to an additional 14,000 lowincome students was generally approved today by leaders of student groups and opposed by college administrators.

title: Second Deputy Inspector Indicted By Jury Studying Bribery of Police
description: A special grand jury investigating whether police superior officers in northern Manhattan were taking bribes from gamblers in the late 1960's has returned, for the second time in two weeks, a perjury indictment against a member of the force who had the rank of deputy inspector.

title: Prisoner Shift Ordered
description: The Appellate Division of State Superior Court in Trenton ordered the New Jersey state prison system to accept 46 inmates from Essex County. The state had refused to take the prisoners because of severe overcrowding in its prisons. Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, Commissioner of the Department of Corrections, immediately conferred with Alan B. Handler, Governor Byrne's chief lawyer, who is a former judge. I am hopeful that Essex County will act in a constructive, positive fashion, Mr. Mulcahy said when asked whether Essex would immediately hand over inmates to the state. He said he felt Essex officials would await further court developments.

title: Drought Depletes Beef Cattle Herds
description: SUTHERLAND, Neb., March 8From the back of the nervous gray cow pony he was riding, Robert Fear swung his arm in a half circle, pointing toward the scraggly clumps of range grass stretching away over the sandy hillsides of his ranch in southwestcentral Nebraska.

title: Oil and Gas Industry Budgets A Record $28.4 Billion for U.S.
description: TULSA, Okla., March 8 (AP)The oil and gas industry has budgeted a record $28.4 billion for capital and exploration spending this year in the United States.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: THE OLD order changes with small things. Kingdoms fall. Rulers are deposed. Hellzapoppin closes out of town, and Percy Sutton says he is running for Mayor. None of this is important in the drawing room, where the issues, although not so well known, may be equally momentous.

title: Jordan Plans TV Campaign for Nomination
description: EDISON, March 8Mayor Paul T. Jordan of Jersey City could become the most familiar gubernatorial candidate in either party next month when his campaign launches a television advertising campaign that could cost $200,000.

title: Books of The Times
description: HOLD FAST IN LIFE to the nature of ordinary things, for they have the power to console, says the loner and brooder Gus Levi in Robert Kotlowitz's novel The Boardwalk. By which he means the classic events, essential matters: wedding tableaus funeral rites, the ceremonies at birth: husbands, wives children, and the dead; the apparatus of human continuity, the pursuit of the future. Gus's line provides both a text and an esthetic for the hook by the programming vice president at WNET.

title: ROTHKOCASE FIGURE ACCUSED OF FORGERY
description: Frank Lloyd, head of the international group of Marlborough Galleries, has been indicted on charges that he tampered with evidence he was ordered to produce during the trial of a suit over the estate of Mark Rothko, one of the 20th century's leading abstractexpressionist artists.

title: GATT Staff Forecasts Continued Growth in '77 In World Trade Volume
description: GENEVA, March 8World trade should continue to grow this year, a report by the staff of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade said today. But the report warned that trade could be hurt by the growth of protectionist sentiment.

title: U.S. Official Expresses Regrets For Role in Chile but Is Disavowed
description: GENEVA, March 8Brady Tyson of the United States delegation to the United Nations Human Rights Commission expressed profoundest regrets today for the part he said some American officials and private groups had played in subverting the Chilean Government of the late President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 9, 1977

title: Kidde Agrees to a Takeover of Victor Comptometer
description: An agreement in principle for the merger of he Victor Comptometer Corporation of Chicago into Walter Kidde & Company was announced yesterday by the two companies. Under the proposed terms, Kidde would pay $11.75 a share for up to 1.8 million shares, for a total of $21.1 million in cash and purchase the balance of the 5 million Victor common shares outstanding and the 77,545 Victor convertible preferred shares for securities valued at about $52.4 million.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Bucharest Tidying Up as Search for Victims Goes On
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 8Four days after the earthquake, the wrecked houses along Alexandru Sahia Street still had not been searched for possible survivors or the bodies of victims. But a squad of schoolgirls wearing the uniforms of the Communist youth organization was sweeping down the pavement outside the ruins.

title: Smeal to Be Partner At Goldman, Sachs Co.
description: Frank P. Smeal, executive vice president and treasurer of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, will join Goldman, Sachs & Company April 15 as a partner and member of the firm's management committee. He will head the fixed income department of the firm, one of the 34 banks and government securities firing that deal regularly with the Federal Reserve.

title: Sketches of New Members of Board of Regents
description: A 49year old pediatrician backed for the BrooklynStaten Island vacancy by ItalianAmerican civic organizations... lives on 78th Street in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn with his wife and three children.... Director of pediatrics at the Long Island College Hospital since 1968.... Graduate of Fordham University and New York University College of Medicine... Teaches at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, a unit of the State Unvierity of New York... A registered Republican.

title: Members of Counties Association Go to Albany to Press Legislation
description: ALBANY, March 8The New York State Association of Counties held its first County Day here to push a 12point legislative program that strongly supports Governor Carey's effort to cut welfare and Medicaid costs.

title: Cosmos Looking to Europe To Establish a Farm Team
description: The Cosmos revealed yesterday that they were planning to purchase and operate a soccer club in a European League to serve as a farm team.

title: About Real Estate
description: The Trusthouse Forte people have been out looking for presences in the main centers of the United States, as Albert C. M. Gelardi put it in his pleasantly Englishaccented voice. Last week it bought the entire Knott Hotel chain, thereby assuming a presence on Madison Avenue. The Knott plum there was the Westbury Hotel, on the west side of the avenue between 69th and 70th Streets.

title: Corporate Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (Reuters)The Alcan Pipeline Company, United States sponsor for the Alcan pipeline project, proposed to the Federal Power Commission an alternative line to transport natural gas from Alaska's Prudhoe Bay through Alaska and Canada to the 48 contiguous states.

title: EFFORT ON CONCORDE PLEDGED BY GISCARD
description: PARIS, March 8  President Valery Giscard d'Estaing said today that Britain and France would use the newly announced delay in the decision on Concorde landing rights in New York to press for an affirmative reply with every means at their disposal.

title: Amin Bars Inquiry By Any World Unit Into Bishop's Death
description: CAIRO, March 8President Idi Amin of Uganda said here today that he would not allow an international commission to investigate charges that an Anglican archbishop and two Cabinet ministers had been murdered in his country.

title: Black Bishop for a Mississippi Diocese
description: Bishop Joseph Lawson Howze, who was raised as a Baptist on the Alabama Gulf Coast, will become the first black to head a United States Roman Catholic diocese since the 19th century when he takes over the newly formed Diocese of Biloxi, Miss., this spring. The announcement of his appointment by Pope Paul VI was made yesterday by the Apostolic Delegate to the United States, Archbishop Jean Jadot.

title: A Refusal to Be Welked
description: SCARBOROUGH, N. Y.  I am 61, goingI prefer to thinkon 52.

title: Rent Break for Elderly
description: The New York City Council unanimously approved a bill yesterday that would enable elderly citizens who held rentincrease exemptions to continue to enjoy such benefits when they move to new residences. At present, persons over 62 years of age who are beneficiaries of the rentincrease exemptions lose these exemptions when they move. But under the bill that was approved yesterday, the head of an elderlycitizen household would be permitted to apply for a new exemption after moving, according to Councilman Samuel Horwitz, Democrat of Brooklyn, who was the bill's chief sponsor.

title: Federal Scientist Tells Legislators in Michigan There Is No PBB Crisis
description: LANSING, Mich., March 8 (AP)There is no PBB crisis and it is unnecessary to lower the amount of the chemical allowed in Michigan food, a Federal scientist has told state legislators.

title: The Need for a Comprehensive Energy Policy
description: The economic and social distress resulting from the naturalgas shortage is merely a sample of the trouble our nation faces unless it confronts its potential problems. Since natural gas constitutes a minor portion of our energy usage, additional probable dislocations caused by our nonpolicy on energy could dwarf our present pain.

title: Carey Takes to Hustings to Seek Support for Proposals on Budget
description: ALBANY, March 8Governor Carey took to the hustings today with his proposals for the state budget and economic development in an unusual day filled with public appearances.

title: Teachers to Be Laid Off
description: One hundredninety Newark teachers and 145 school crossing guards will be laid off soon because of a $1.3 million budget deficit. The decision of the Newark, Board of Education followed an emergency meeting of the Board of School Estimate, which voted to reject a request for $1.08 million to help save the jobs. Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson cast the deciding vote against the appropriation.

title: Rangers Rely on Fotiu To Keep Foes in Check
description: He has the same kind of hands as his coach, hands that clench involuntarily when he is under stress, hands that are knobbed in odd places from fights that tore the skin and pushed the knuckles back.

title: About Education
description: Is there such a thing as educational malpractice?

title: Sports Today
description: BOWLING

title: Islanders Defeated by North Stars, 31
description: UNIONDALE L. I., March 8If the National Hockey League playoffs had started tonight, the Islanders would be one game away from elimination. Why? Because the Minnesota North Stars took the measure of the Islanders by score of 31 tonight before 5,317 stunned fans at Nassau Coliseum. Coach Al Arbour of New York left the building as soon as the game ended and refused to be interviewed on the disappointing defeat. Can't say as I blame him, said Jean Potvin of the Islanders, who tried to make Up for what his coach might have said.

title: CITY AND THE M.A.C. GET NO ASSURANCES FROM SAVINGS BANKS
description: New York City and Municipal Assistance Corporation officials met with representatives of a dozen city savings banks yesterday, but failed to obtain a commitment from the banks to buy M.A.C. bonds to help the city raise the money needed to pay off its $1 billion moratorium debt.

title: ENERGY PANEL EASES RULES TO SAFEGUARD UNDERGROUND WATER
description: HOUSTON, March 8The Environmental Protection Agency, reacting to a deluge of protests from the oil industry, has decided to greatly ease proposed regulations designed to protect underground water supplies from pollution by oil producers.

title: RADIOACTIVE WASTES HELD UPSTATE PERIL
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)A massive pool of radioactive waste stored underground in upstate New York poses a threat to public health and could cost more than $600 million to dispose of, a Congressional subcommittee was told today.

title: Memorial Services
description: KILBOUR. Kenyon. Memorial service will be held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, Lexington Ave. and 80th St., on March 9, 1977, at 4 P.M.

title: A Science Search Yields Local Talent
description: WASHINGTON, March 8James G. Propp spends his spare time trying to invent mathematical questions his friends can't answer.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 8Ruth Ballou, who lost a challenge to a state law that gives veterans an absolute preference in competition for Civil Service posts, vowed today that she would appeal the court ruling that in effect cost her a job promotion despite her test score of 99.99 percent.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: Patients Again Side With Dr. DeMarco in Courtroom
description: NEWARK, Match ??For the second successive day, accusations of malpractice against Dr. Peter T. DeMarco brought protests today from his patients seated in the courtroom.

title: Boy, 3, Dies in Brooklyn Fire
description: A 3yearold child died last night in a Brooklyn fire that the police said may have been set by a boyfriend of the child's mother. The child was identified as Omar Godley of 21 Tompkins Avenue in the BedfordStuyvesant section. The fire was confined to the apartment of his mother, Eva.

title: California Loss Is Put at $2.9 Billion
description: LOS ANGELES, March 8  The senior economist of the California Department of Water Resources predicted here today that the drought could cost the state between $2.9 billion and $6.3 billion in its gross product this year.

title: Tax Ruling by the I.R.S. Could Affect Future Sales Of Investment Annuities
description: Insurance companies offering socalled investment annunity contracts, principally Investment Annuity Inc., of Valley Forge, Pa., yesterday were awaiting a tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service that may curtail or possibly eliminate sales of such policies in the future.

title: Ford Recalls 2,500 Chassis
description: DETROIT, March 8 (AP)About 2,500 1976model medium and heavy duty trucks and bus chassis were ordered recalled today by the Ford Motor Company for replacement of four bolts that connect the front axles to the front springs. The vehicles all were built at Ford's Kentucky truck plant between April and July 31, 1976, the company said.

title: SAVINGS BANKS RESIST BUYING M.A.C. BONDS TO EASE CITY CRISIS
description: New York City and Municipal Assistance Corporation officials met with representatives of a dozen city savings banks yesterday, but failed to obtain a commitment from the banks to buy M.A.C. bonds to help the city raise the money needed to pay off its $1 billion moratorium debt.

title: Valley Forge Poloists Beat Connecticut, 1514
description: SOMERS, Conn., March 8Harley Stimell scored with 22 seconds remaining in the game, enabling Valley Forge to defeat the University of Connecticut, 1514, tonight in a quarterfinal round game of the national intercollegiate indoor polo tournament.

title: Nutrition Data Held Likely To Eliminate Some Foods
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland said today that his department was planning a program of nutritional information for consumers that could drive some present foods off the market.

title: Soviet Winter Grain Crop Is Hard Hit by Cold
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)Severe cold has killed about onefifth of the Soviet winter grain crop, but the Russians still will harvest a crop of near normal size, according to an Agriculture Department analysis.

title: Justice Dept. Drops Term Mafia
description: A spokesman for the Justice Department said yesterday that it had reimposed a policy originated in 1970 of not using the words Mafia or Cosa Nostra in official statements about organized crime.

title: Books of The Times
description: I LIKE the heterodoxy of Morris Dickstein's Gates of Eden: American Culture in the Sixties its mix of literary, political, and popcult analysis that tries to extract almost equal significance from the literary criticism of Lionel Trilling and a rock concert by the Rolling Stones. I especially admire Professor Dickstein's willingness to inject his personal experience and testimony into what aspires to be the cultural history of an entire nation. Aside from illumi

title: Lawyer Is the First Black To Be Richmond's Mayor
description: RICHMOND, March 8A long struggle by blacks for more political representation in Virginia's capital city reached a milestone today with the new City Council's election of Henry L. Marsh 3d as Richmond's first black Mayor.

title: TV: Documentary To Peer Into Womb
description: THE LAST TIME television peered inside the human body, two years ago in a National Geographic film called The Incredible Machine. the Public BroadCasting Service scored the highest ratings in its history.

title: COMMA NOW A FOCUS OF FIGHT ON WARNKE
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The Senate debate on whether Paul C. Warnke should be confirmed as President Carter's chief arms control negotiator today turned into a shouting, deskthumping argument over a comma he dropped and then restored to a fiveyearold statement.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 9, 1977

title: U.D.C. to Gain A Solid Footing With Bond Sale
description: The twoyear effort to rescue the Urban Development Corporation, which has been proceeding quietly and successfully, reaches a milestone today.

title: U.S. to Try Croatians
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled that four Croatian nationalists, who are charged with having hijacked a Trans World Airlines jet last Sept. 10 should be tried on air piracy charges in Federal District Court before they are tried in State Supreme Court on charges of murder arising from the same incident. A police officer was killed in seeking to defuse a bomb, the nationalists allegedly placed in a Grand Central Terminal locker. Their trial is now scheduled for March 22 in Brooklyn Federal Court.

title: Pentagon Advises Ways to Upgrade LessThanHonorable Discharges
description: WASHINGTON, March 8In an effort to create a basis for a policy statement by President Carter, the Defense Department has prepared recommendations for upgrading other than honorable discharges received by thousands of Vietnam War veterans.

title: Music Plays 2d Fiddle
description: ARTHUR WEISBERG and his Contemporary Chamber Ensemble began a threeconcert series in New York University's Eisner and Lubin Auditorium Monday nightthe other two are April 13 and May 2and in the process almost drowned in media overkill.

title: Beach Fees Approved
description: The Wildwoods and Strathmere were left as the only Cape May County shore resorts without beach fees when Cape May City Council approved a beach fee for Cape May city. Atlantic City stands alone as a free beach resort in Atlantic County. In Wildwood, a beach fee is still under study, according to Mayor Guy Muziani.

title: Drought Is Depleting Midwest Cattle
description: SUTHERLAND, Neb., March 8From the back of the nervous gray cow pony he was riding, Robert Fear swung his arm in a half circle, pointing toward the scraggly clumps of range grass stretching away over the sandy hillsides of his ranch in southwestcentral Nebraska.

title: Rainmaking and Cloud Rustling
description: The Attorney General of Idaho has accused the neighboring state of Washington of cloud rustling, and announced plans to file suit in Federal court to stop its rainmaking activities. Idaho's Governor, however, objects, in part because he foresees the possibility that droughtstricken .Idaho may soon want to try its own luck at rainmaking.

title: BID FOR A VICTIM, 82, TO TESTIFY SPURNED
description: An attempt by the defense to call an elderly robbery victim to testify during pretrial hearings in the case of two youths accused of assaulting and robbing the 82yearold woman in her Bronx apartment was blocked yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice.

title: HOUSE VOTES TAX BILL; $25,000 INCOME LIMIT IS PUT ON $50 REBATE
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The House today passed President Carter's tax stimulus for the economy by a vote of 282 to 131 with modifications limiting his full $50 rebate to those whose gross annual incomes are less than $25,000 and rejecting a Carter proposal to widen the investment tax credit.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH CUP

title: Braves Ask Court to Lift Turner's Year Suspension
description: ATLANTA, March 8 (AP)The Atlanta Braves and Ted Turner, their owner, filed a lawsuit in United States District Court today seeking an injunction lifting Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's oneyear suspension of Turner. The suit also asks that the loss of a firstround choice in the baseball draft be overturned, but it seeks no damages.

title: Group's Soliciting Barred
description: Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff of State Supreme Court has granted a temporary restraining order that had been sought by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz barring the Korean Cultural and Freedom Foundation from soliciting funds in New York. The foundation, which describes itself as a charitable institution based in Washington, contributed only 6.3 percent of the money it collected to the causes in whose names it solicited, according to Mr. Lefkowitz. Court papers indicate that in the fiscal year ending June 30, 1975, the foundation collected $1,508,256 from contributors who believed the money would be used to help children in Asia and to combat

title: Guilty in Tax Case
description: Irwin T. Denberg, executive of a chain of cleaning stores, pleaded guilty in United States District Court in Manhattan to omitting more than $702,000 income from his Federal joint tax return for 1969. Mr. Denberg, 47 years old, of Alpine, could be fined up to $10,000 and he sentenced to as much as five years in prison. He is to he sentenced April 21.

title: U.N. Aides Use Women's Day to Protest on Jobs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8Today was International Women's Day and hundreds of women staff members packed a meeting room to discuss prejudice against women in United Nations employment practices.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: 10 Soviet Germans in Red Square Protest Emigration Restrictions
description: MOSCOW, March 8Ten ethnic Germans, demanding the right to emigrate, unfurled banners in Red Square today and walked shoulder  to  shoulder for several yards before security police ripped the signs from their hands and arrested them.

title: Resignation of Gonzalez From Panel Is Accepted
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)The House accepted today, by a vote of 296 to 100, the resignation of Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, as chairman of the assassinations committee despite an objection that it first should discuss his charges against Richard A. Sprague, the committee's chief counsel.

title: Alice Bache, 74; A Banker's Widow And Art Collector
description: Alice Odenheimer Kay Bache, an art collector and widow of Harold L. Bache, investment banker, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. She was 74 years old and maintained homes in Washington, Conn., and in Manhattan.

title: Israelis Seize More Arabs As Protests Expand
description: TEL AVIV, March 8 (AP)Protests by Arabs held in Israeli jails as guerrillas have spread, lawyers and prison officials said today, and the police reported the arrest of 16 new suspects as a result of violent incidents in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan.

title: 3 Held in Gambling Raid
description: Three men were charged with running a multimilliondollar numbers hank from the basement of a Carteret home, according to Federal officials. James Dowd, 32 years old, of Piscataway: Joseph Mullins, 32, and Arthur Rocco, 38, both of Newark, were arrested by F.B.I. agents who broke down the doors of a house in Carteret. The Federal agents seized several suitcases of records, four adding machines, ledgers filled with coded names and more than $4,500 in cash.

title: Commission Cites Color TV Dumping
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)  The United States International Trade Commission ruled today that the domestic color television industry is being harmed by imported color television sets. The ruling clears the way for special assistance to the industry.

title: Bernie Bierman Dies
description: Bernie Bierman, who gained fame as the University of Minnesota's football coach, died yesterday at the age of 82. An obituary appears on page B4.

title: STATE IN INDIA SHOWS AN ANTIGANDHI TREND
description: PATNA, IndiaThe eastern state of Bihar, which heavily supported the governing Congress Party in 1971, appears to be swinging strongly toward the approaches. The emergency rule imposed opposition as the election of March 16 by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi 20 months ago appears largely to blame.

title: Knicks Will Name Reed Coach Today With a 3Year Contract
description: The long  expected announcement that Willis Reed will succeed Red Holzman as the Knicks' coach next season is to be made today. The Knicks have called a news conference in which they will announce that the 6foot10inch Reed, captain and center of the only two National Basketball Association championship teams in the 31 years of the franchise, has signed a threeyear contract.

title: War in Addis Ababa's Streets Devouring the Revolution's Progeny
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 2It is 2 P.M. and the searing Ethiopian sun has moved the bikiniclad bathers at the Hilton Hotel swimming pool off their chaise lounges and under the parasols. Yellowjacketed waiters are roasting shish kebab and tossing salad. The loudest sound is the thwock of a tennis ball.

title: Careers
description: Rome means many things to many peopleantiquities, sun, wine, romancebut to some Americans it means a chance, denied them at home, to enter medical school.

title: Ann Norton Jones Dead at 48; Was a Volunteer in Social Work
description: Ann Norton Jones, daughter of the late William Warder Norton, founder and head of W. W. Norton & Company, book publishers, died Saturday at her mother's home in Wilton, Conn. She was 48 years old and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: U. S. Bans on Pest Controls Linked to Disease Threat
description: WASHINGTON, March S (UPI)Government regulations banning an increasing number of pest control chemicals are leaving the public open to growing disease risks, a California specialist told Congress today.

title: Gas Shift Reports Called Misleading In Tenneco Rebuttal
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Tenneco Inc. characterized today as confusing, incomplete and misleading news articles that it said implied the company withheld natural gas from the interstate market or contributed to the current shortage.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: * Apprentice.

title: 2 ExOfficials in Italy Deny Lockheed Guilt
description: ROME, March 8 (AP)The two former defense ministers charged with corruption in the Lockheed payoff scandal pleaded innocent today before Parliament, saying they were victims of interparty rivalries.

title: Haig & Haig Pinch Battle
description: BRUSSELSGen. Alexander Haig, NATO commander in Europe, and Gen. Alexander Haig, U.S. forces commander in Europe, have precisely the same battle to fight: squeezing more arms and men out of pinchpenny governments to give the West a better chance of deterring war or defending itself against conceivable Soviet attack.

title: SCHOOLS IN COLUMBUS TOLD TO DESEGEGATE
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 8 (UPI)Federal District Judge Robert M. Duncan found the Columbus public school system guilty today of intentional racial segregation.

title: They're Too Active To Warm Park Bench
The Economic Scene
description: A. H. Raskin says that while the White House is stressing the need to step up industrial productivity, there is as yet no specific Carter program. Page D5.

description: TORONTOGeorge Chuvalo, Canada, knocked out Bob (Pretty Boy) Feistein Canada, 9 rounds, and won toe Canadan heavyweight championship.

description: MEN'S BASKETBALL

title: FORD AND WIFE SIGN PACT FOR MEMOIRS
description: In the first such arrangement ever made by former occupants of the White House, Gerald R. Ford and Betty Ford have contracted to write their memoirs, separately but equally, under a joint program worked out with a major publisher and magazine. No previous President and First Lady have made a similar twobook deal that places their experiences as public figures on an equal basis.

title: Carter Answers the Last Question
description: SAN BERNARDINO. Calif.. March 8 (AP)President Carter returned Ruby Hewitt's telephone call today, the last of four persons whose questions he could not answer on his nationwide radio program last Saturday.

title: WIDER AUDITOR ROLE IN COMPANY AFFAIRS TO BE ADVOCATED
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The auditing profession should be required to provide a much broader range of information about its corporate clients and should on occasion expose their wrongdoing tothe public, an independent study group has concluded.

title: Holdup Suspect Shot
description: A 22yearold man with a shotgun held up the Bella Bakery in Elmont, L.I., and got $34, then shot himself accidentally while putting the gun back into his belt, according to the Nassau County police. They said that Nicola Cottone of 162 Claridge Avenue, Elmont, was fleeing when the shotgun went off and that he drove himself to Franklin General Hospital in Valley Stream. He was reported to be in serious condition.

title: RushHour Bus Service to Be Cut by 10% on March 20
description: Rushhour bus service in the city will he reduced by 208 runs on March 20 and by an additional 407 runs this summer, or a total of 10 percent, under a ruling yesterday by Theodore W. Kheel, impartial transit arbitrator.

title: Yields on Corporate and TaxExempt Issues Gain
description: As the credit markets continued to drift along without moving very far up or down yesterday, a substantial volume of new corporate and taxexempt financing was offered to investors. Yields generally were somewhat higher than rates on similar issues marketed in February, and a majority of the new offerings sold relatively quickly. Even so, investment bankers asserted that the key test of the credit markets this week would come today when the South Central Bell Telephone Company auctions $225 million of longterm bonds.

title: Thomas Mitchelson, Top Black Officer, Quits Police Force
description: The city's highestranking black police official, Thomas P. Mitchelson, retired unexpectedly yesterday after being commander of the uniformed patrol force for the last three years.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 8, 1977

title: MARGARET BROCK AURTHUR
description: Margaret Brock Aurthur, a retired elementaryschool principal, died yesterday at the Huntting Rest Home in East Hampton, L.I. She was 79 years old.

title: Trio Replaces Schippers
description: Ordinarily, when a conductor is ill and cannot appear at a concert, another one steps in to replace him, and that is that. In the case of the Cincinnati Symphony, which played at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, things were different. Thomas Schippers, the orchestra's music director, who has been suffering from a respiratory ailment for some time, was replaced not by one conducter, but by threeDavid Stahl, Kenneth Schermerhorn and Leonard Bernstein.

title: NEW BONDS ARE ORDERED FOR 2 MURDER SUSPECTS
description: STAMFORD, Conn., March 8A request this afternoon to the Stamford Court of Common Pleas to reduce $500,000 bonds for two murder suspects, Samuel Ayala, 26 years old, and Willie Profit, 25, both of Norwalk, resulted in new higher bonds set by Judge Martin L. McKeever.

title: The Need for Productivity Rise: Rhetoric, but No Carter Program
description: With the Carter Administration in headlong flight from anything that smacks of wageprice controls, the White House these days is stressing the need to step up industrial productivity as the key to noninflationary economic growth. Few public utterances by Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall, Secretary of Commerce Juanita M. Kreps or Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal fail to make reverent obeisance at the shrine of heightened productivity through cooperative labormanagement action.

title: Market Place
description: The International Business Machines Corporation's recent offer to buy at east 4 million of its common shares appears to have inspired some creative tax planning by corporations large and small.

title: U.D.C. to Gain A Solid Footing With Bond Sale
description: The twoyear effort to rescue the Urban Development Corporation, which has been proceeding quietly and successfully, reaches a milestone today.

title: James Healy Was 1st Black Bishop
description: The first black American bishop was James A. Healy, who was named to the See of Portland, Me., in 1875.

title: Personal Health
description: ARECENT survey by a formula manufacturer indicated that nearly two out of five American mothers now breastfeed their babiesdouble the percentage of 15 years ago. Breastfeeding has increased mostly among collegeeducated and welltodo women, although the poor have the most to gain from raising their infants on mother's milk. The reasons for this new and growing vogue include maternal pride, emotional satisfaction, economics, convenience, wanting to give the baby what nature provided, not wanting to waste a natural resource and believing that breast milk is healthier for the baby. But few nursing mothers realize just how much of a better lease on life they may be giving their babies by feeding them breast milk.

title: Rabin, After Carter Talks, Urges A Goal of Real Peace in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel stood firm today against making concessions on key Middle East issues and warned against any unrealistic expectations that progress could be achieved this year toward an overall settlement.

title: Theater: Angel City Flip and Irreverent
description: THERE WAS A TIME, not so long ago, while the rest of the world seemed to be waiting for Godot, American drama was still waiting for Lefty. Realism ruled the roosteven so, it was frequently a realism flavored with symbolism by such writers as O'Neill, Tennessee Williams, Wilder and, for that matter, such a far lesser figure as Maxwell Anderson.

title: All About: Bulbs (The Ones You Light, Not Plant)
description: AWOMAN complained that her electric bill was much too high, but the company, after sending a meterchecker, assured her that the bill had been correct.

title: Prisoner Shift Ordered
description: The Appellate Division of State Superior Court in Trenton ordered the New Jersey state prison system to accept 46 inmates from Essex County. The state had refused to take the prisoners because of severe overcrowding in its prisons. Robert E. Mulcahy 3d, Commissioner of the Department of Corrections, immediately conferred with Alan B. Handler, Governor Byrne's chief lawyer, who is a former judge. I am hopeful that Essex County will act in a constructive, positive fashion, Mr. Mulcahy said when asked whether Essex would immediately hand over inmates to the state. He said he felt Essex officials would await further court developments.

title: Franklin Simon Considers Closing Its 34th St. Store
description: Franklin Simon, one of the nation's largest apparelstore chains, said yesterday that it might close its main store at 34th Street in Manhattan as part of a program to improve corporate profitability.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: SHRIMP belong to that category of foods that, by their nature, can be cooked to advantage in only a minute or so and are thus ideal for a hasty food preparation. They are used here as a sort of meal in one, cooked as they are with a tomato, anchovy and caper sauce and served with freshly cooked spaghetti.

title: FIVE EXCHANGES TO BEGIN PUT TRADING ON JUNE 3
description: All five exchanges trading call options I have agreed with the Options Clearing Corporation that they will begin put option trading Friday, June 3, an O.C.C. spokesman said yesterday.

title: Technology: Investing in Molecular Biology
description: Molecular biology, the branch of science that lately has developed gene splicing and a rapid new test of potentially cancercausing substances, is unfamiliar territory for analysts and investment counselors in banks, insurance companies and mutual funds.

title: Turnpike Safety Record One of Best in the U.S.
description: The New Jersey Turnpike achieved one of the best safety records of all toll roads in the United States and Canada in 1976, officials said. The turnpike authority said statistics showed that the toll road had an accident rate of 79 per 100 million miles of travel, second only to the Pennsylvania Turnpike's 69.3. The statistics were compiled for the authority by the International Bridge, Tunnel and Turnpike Association Inc., a Washingtonbased organization made up of highway authorities throughout the country.

title: Asparagus: It's
description: WHILE SOME might consider the most welcome signs of spring to be the crocus and the snowdrop, the anemone and the daffodil, to food lovers those floral harbingers seem trivial compared to the years first asparagus. For those slender emerald spears, lightly tipped with violet, bring with them green and easy taste of springtime. In these days when availability often seems to be prized for its own sake, asparagus of sorts are with us the year round. But to true buffs, these imports are tougher, less flavorful, less joyous in the pleasures they afford. Nor are canned or frozen impostors considered satisfactory substitutes by those who value the verdant spring freshness of the originals. Better by far to eat asparagus several times a week, if not every day, while they are in season, enjoying them in myriads of ways, and then to forget them until next year's crops come to market, as it does between late February and early March. Beloved by the ancient Greeks who named this vegetable aspharagos, and by the Romans, who dried them so they could have them throughout winter, asparagus come in for a variety of delectable treatments in countries around the world. Europeans, for the most part, prefer white asparagus, achieved by growing the stalks under mounds of earth so the sun does not strike them to produce chlorophyll. But whatever the color, this vegetable has a special affinity for butter, eggs, lemon, various golden vegetable oils, almonds, walnuts and hazelnuts, ham and salmon.

title: Getting Back at Alma Mater
description: The case of Edward Donohue, who has lately brought suit against the Copiague Union Free Schools on Long Island for educational malpractice, is a provocative exercise of consumer rights. The layearold plaintiff charges that the local high school from which he was graduated in 1976 failed to educate him to cope properly with the affairs of the world. Specifically, he alleges that he was not taught enough reading and writing to get and hold a decent job.

title: Hussein and Arafat Meet in Cairo For First Talks Since 1970 Strife
description: CAIRO, March 8King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, today discussed JordanianPalestinian relations, including possible links between Jordan and an independent Palestinian state, in their first facetoface talk since 1970.

title: Seaver, Koosman, Matlack Resigned To Shouldering Load for Mets Again
description: St. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8To many in baseball, the New York Mets may own the best frontline pitchers in the business: Tom Seaver, Jerry Koosman and Jon Matlack. But to the Big Three themselves these days, with another long and harrowing season only one month away, reinforcements are urgently needed.

title: 8 British Soldiers Cleared Of Arms Threat to Ireland
description: DUBLIN, March 8 (Reuters)Eight men of an elite British antiguerrilla force were cleared today of bringing weapons into Ireland with intent to endanger life after a trial that caused tension between London and Dublin.

title: Dishes For the Luscious Spears
description: Although asparagus can be prepared to perfection with little more than a wide, deep skillet, a paring knife and a slotted spoon, few vegetables have inspired so much special equipment, both for cooking and for serving, This is partly due to the long, slender fragility of the tender spears, but mostly because the arrival of asparagus seems to inspire ceremonial celebration.

title: Foes Accuse Bhutto Of Rigging the Voting
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 8Prime Minister Zulfikar Ail Bhutto was accused by an opposition leader today of rigging, on a very massive scale, the voting yesterday that gave his party an overwhelming majority in Parliament.

title: RCA Awarded Army Contract
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday receipt of an $8.2 million order from the United States Army for an additional 12 transportable ground stations to provide worldwide satellite communications. The new order brings the total value of the contract to more than $37 million.

title: Con Ed Terminates Employment Of 211 Managers to Trim Costs
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, in the first significant reduction of its work force since World War II, has cut 211 management employees from its staff.

title: On the Art of Being Chic Though Shabby
description: How are the British muddling through their present economic stress? This paean to the pleasures of poverty was written by Mirabel Cecil, a journalist.

title: 143 Thai Students to Face Charges
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 8The Thai Government has decided to file criminal charges against 143 students allegedly involved in the bloody clashes that preceded the military coup last October.

title: Best Buys
description: PEOPLE who belong to the meatandpotatoes school of nourishment are in luck this week. Beef, poultry and pork are among the principal bargains; and potatoes, which can be counted upon to rise in price as stockpiles diminish in the coming weeks before a new harvest, are also a worthy investment.

title: Arrau Interprests Liszt With Artful Individuality
description: CLAUDIO ARRAU'S virtues as a pianist are many and obvious. The Chilean musician never dodges difficulties, his approach to every piece is sober and thoughtful, and when his fingers are behaving they let him subdue the loftiest works in the repertory with a mixture of virtuosity and intellect that gives his performances real individualism.

title: ABORTIONS ON TEENAGERS ARE ESTIMATED AT 275,000
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)one out of three abortions in this country is performed on a teenager, and teenagers had an estimated 275,000 abortions in 1974, according to the National Alliance Concerned with SchoolAge Parents.

title: Illinois State Wins, Gains N. I. T. Berth
description: OMAHA, March 8 (AP)Illinois State held off an errorprone Creighton tonight to win a firstround National Invitation Tournament basketball game, 6558.

title: Braves Ask Court to Lift Turner's Year Suspension
description: ATLANTA, March 8 (AP)The Atlanta Braves and Ted Turner, their owner, filed a lawsuit in United States District Court today seeking an injunction lifting Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's oneyear suspension of Turner. The suit also asks that the loss of a firstround choice in the baseball draft be overturned, but it seeks no damages.

title: U.S. Repudiates Statement
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The Carter Administration moved quickly today to repudiate the regrets expressed by a United States representative before the United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva for what he called an American role in undermining the Allende Government.

title: Rumania Tells Foreign Donors It Needs No More Aid
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 8Rumania today requested countries sending aid far the victims of the earthquake last Friday night to suspend further shipments.

title: 14YearOld Held in Stabbing
description: IRVINGTON, N. J., March 8 (UPI)A 14yearold boy was held today in the fatal stabbing of a neighbor during an argument with his mother. The youngster, whose name was not made public because of his age, was charged with homicide in the death of Tommie Walden Jr., 34 years old, who shared a twofamily house with the suspect's family.

title: Burke a Target of Anger at School Problems
description: TRENTON, March 8The decision yesterday of Dr. Fred G. Burke, the State Education Commissioner, to call off an 11day trip to three East African nations, where he was to have studied educational facilities, is not likely to ease the legislative attacks on him. He has become too handy a target. The trip, which was to have begun Thursday, caused such a furor that Dr. Burke had to cancel it.

title: U.S. Official Expresses Regrets For Role in Chile but Is Disavowed
description: GENEVA, March 8The deputy leader of the United States delegation to the United Nations Human Rights Commission expressed profoundest regrets today for the port he said some American officials and private groups had played in subverting the Chilean Government of the late President Salvador Allende Gossens.

title: Giants and Van Pelt Huddle on Contract, but No Gains Are Made
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 8Having traded Craig Morton yesterday, the Giants turned their attention today to keeping Brad Van Pelt.

title: Britain Cuts Payments Deficit By $340 Million During 1976
description: LONDON, March 8 (Reuters)Britain cut its balance of payments deficit by some $340 million last year, twice as much as was originally announced, according to Treasury estimates announced today.

title: West German Economy Changing As Plants Go Abroad to Cut Costs
description: BONN, March 8With the stable West German mark turning made in Germany into a synonym for expensive, a fundamental change has begun. Like the American multinationals of the 1950's and 1960's, the West German industrial giants are moving many manufacturing operations abroad to save money.

title: Carter Plans Trip To London to Meet Six Leaders in May
description: WASHINGTON, March 8President Carter plans to make his first trip abroad since his inauguration during May, a spokesman said today, when he and the leaders of six other industrialized countries gather in London for a conference that will go beyond the economic agenda of its two predecessors.

title: Legislature Names Three to Fill Regents' Vacancies
description: ALBANY, March 8The Legislature elected three new members of the New York State Board of Regents this evening with a minimum of fuss and feathers, in marked contrast to the frenetic Regents' elections of previous years.

title: The Battle of Concorde
description: That handsome, highflying, supersonic plane, the Concorde, has cost Britain and France $3 billion and turns out to be good only for ego trips. It is a commercial corpse, but no one wants the blame for its demise. So the Governments of Britain, France and even the United States have tried to dump the body on New York's doorstepKennedy Airport, to be exact. The sanity of the Western alliance, nay, the fate of democracy in Europe, are said to depend on half a million residents of Queens putting up with the plane's extraordinary takeoff roar and rumble. How shall New York cope with the Concorde? A decision Is in order in the next few weeks.

title: Cauthen Wins 1 of 7 Races At Hialeah
description: HIALEAH, Fla., March 8The sun never appeared, the programs arrived so late that post time had to be delayed half an hour, the fifth race was coming up and an army of cameramen and photographers were still waiting for the picture they had come to get: Steve Cauthen booting home a winner in his Florida riding debut.

title: Army Tells of U.S. Germ War Tests; Safety of Simulated Agents at Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Army biological warfare experts once spread bacteria over a region of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, dumped germs in the ocean off San Francisco in a simulated attack and conducetd similar openair tests of simulated germ warfare in many other cities and regions.

title: GOLD FALLS $2 IN LONDON AS DOLLAR IS IRREGULAR
description: LONDON, March 8The price of gold dropped nearly $2 in London today after rising $7.50 an ounce in Europe over the previous four trading days. The dollar had a mixed showing.

title: Penney Profits for Quarter Dip, While Kresge Gains
description: The J. C. Penney Company and the S. S. Kresge Company, the nations second and third largest retailing chains, both reported yesterday sales and profit gains for 1976. However, in Penneys fourth fiscal quarter, profits slipped 3.9 percent from a year earlier. Kresge posted a 9.4 percent gain for its quarter, which included the Christmas and Sunday openings business.

title: A STREAMLINED H.E.W. ORDERED BY CALIFANO
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today a major realignment of agencies within department in an effort to simplify and streamline its operations.

title: Something Iras Gone Haywire
description: BROOKE HAYWARD grew up in a really privileged family that had Everything. Yet her sister committed suicide, and her mother may have, too. Her brother spent time in a mental institution. Her father was married five times. And she herself has had two failed marriages.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Mirror, Mirror, Oh So Tall

title: Columbia Coed, 19, Is Slain on Street In Forest Hills
