description: A 19yearold Columbia University coed was shot to death last night on a quiet street near home in Forest Hills, Queens, only half a block from where another young woman was fatally shot five weeks ago for no apparent reason while sitting in a parked car.

title: Port Authority Appointment
description: ALBANY, March 8  Governor Carey today appointed Howard Schulman of New York City as a commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for a term ending July 1, 1931. A member of the law firm of Schulman, Abarbanel & Schlesinger, specializing in labor law, he is general counsel to a number of maritime unions, He was named to succeed Matthew Nimitz, who resigned the unsalaried post.

title: Iowa Revisited
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, March 8Jimmy Carter started his official run for the Presidency here in the Iowa precinct caucuses just over a year ago. He won 20 of the state's 47 delegates to the Democratic nominating convention in Madison Square Garden, well ahead of any other Democrat in the race, but he lost Iowa to Gerald Ford in the November election: Ford, 632,436, Carter, 619,710.

title: AUSTRALIA SIGNS ACCORD TO SELL WHEAT TO CHINA
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 8 (AP)Australia has signed an agreement to sell China 2 million tons of wheat between now and next January, the Wheat Board announced today.

title: Noise Level Meeting Scheduled
description: French and British technical experts are scheduled to meet today with representatives of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey in the first facetoface effort to prove that the Concorde could be operated to produce no more noise than many subsonic jets.

title: Yanks Upset as Kuhn Vetoes Their Cuba Trip
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 8The Yankees don't appear to be on their way to Cuba after all and they aren't happy about it.

title: Bernie Bierman, Football Coach Who Led Minnesota to Fame, Dies
description: LAGUNA HILLS, Calif., March 8 (AP) Bernie Bierman, the former University of Minnesota football coach who led the Gophers to three national championships, died last night at the age of 82.

title: Banks Seek to Avoid Public Rows With the City in Fiscal Discussions
description: The heads of major banks in New York City say they are determined to avoid further angry public fights with Mayor Beame and the labor unions on their plan for creating a financial monitor for the city.

title: Metrecal: A Shadow of What It Was
description: Its cookie still crumbles, but otherwise Metrecal has gone the way of all flesh.

title: Music ?? With Love
description: When the opera department of the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia gave a program of music by Kurt Weill last season, it was heard by the composer's famous widow, Lotte Lenya, who suggested that the school present a similar program in New York. She provided material from the 1920's that had not previously been performed anywhere, and the concert took place Monday night in the auditorium of the New York Public Library and Museum at Lincoln Center.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Skelton: How He Simplified His Life
description: PALM SPRINGS, CALIF. AWALL of eucalyptus and untamed oleander surrounds the three houses. The houses belong to Red Skelton, but he does not live in them. Although his seven RollsRoyces fill the driveways, he lives in three different houses, in the mountains, 15 miles away.

title: Bobby Kaplan Will Be Missed for Contributions to Tennis, Particularly Among Juniors
description: Bobby Kaplan's tragic death at the age of 33 deprives tennis of a dynamic figure who made an enormous contribution to the development of young players.

title: I.R.S. Seizes Goods of Korean Suspected of Bribery
description: WASHNGTON, March 8The Internal Revenue Service has seized two luxurious houses, three cars and personal property belonging to Park Tong Sun, the Korean businessman who has been a central figure in the investigation of alleged bribery of Congressmen in behalf of the South Korean Government.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: LOOK 'EM OVER It's browseorbuy time again for new and experienced collectors, as the Park Avenue Antiques Fair opens today at the Seventh Regiment Armory (at 67th Street) after an absence of several years, with wares from more than 90 dealers. As for bargainsseeing, of course, is believing, and buying, from expensive items of 17thcentury vintage to an estimable array of furniture, silver, art, porcelain, carpets and other merchandise.

title: Quebec's Thrift Has Political Clout
description: MONTREAL, March 8Quebeckers are among the most thrifty individuals in Canada, a trait that has assumed fresh importance since the advent three months ago of a government that seeks independence for this Frenchspeaking province.

title: Fingers? Tongs?
description: Forks and knives, fingers or tongs? The question is neither whether to eat asparagus nor when, but rather how.

title: Letters
description: To the Last Puff

title: Episcopal Church Worker, Still Refusing to Testify, Surrenders to Marshals
description: Smiling, as she was surrounded by cameras. Maria Cueto, the 33yearold Episcopal Church employee who has refused to cooperate with a grand jury investigating terrorist bombings, surrendered to Federal marshals yesterday afternoon to become the third witness to choose fail rather than testify.

title: Bridge:
description: In the first few tricks of play against a suit contract, many defenders have a bad habit of firing a singleton into the air and hoping for the best. But experienced defenders do not make such plays routinely. Instead, they look carefully to see if the circumstances call for something else.

title: Indian Candidate Conducts Campaign From Jail Cell
description: MUZAFFARPUR, IndiaGeorge Fernandes, an opposition candidate for Parliament, is in jail. But this is not considered a great handicap by his supporters.

title: HENRY HULL, 87, STAR OF STAGE AND SCREEN
description: Henry Hull, who created Jeeter Lester in the 1933 Broadway production of Tobacco Road, died yesterday at the home of his daughter in Cornwall, England. He was 87 years old.

title: Concern Admits Fraud
description: A Morristown engineering concern has pleaded guilty to conspiring to defraud the Camden County Municipal Utilities Authority. Attorney General William F. Hyland announced that Porter & Ripa Associates had entered the guilty plea to one count of conspiracy to defraud the authority of $170,000 by submitting bills for work that it had not performed under its former contract with the Camden agency to design a county sewer system.

title: Japan Going Underground With Vast Shopping Complexes
description: OSAKA, JapanJapan is going underground.

title: That Mysterious ginseng Brew
description: A middleaged man regarded a free sample cup of ginseng tea at the Natural Food Shoppe in Grand Central Terminal the other day, took a sip and allowed as how it doesn't taste very sexy.

title: I.B.M., General Mills And CBS Buy Stock
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said that, with the expiration at 5 P.M. yesterday of its offer to purchase at least 44 million of its common shares, it would announce the estimated number of shares tendered prior to the opening today of the New York Stock Exchange. I.B.M., whose offer included an option to buy up to 5.5 million of its shares at $280 a share, had extended the original Monday deadline for the offer by 48 hours. By Monday, about 2,160,000 shares had been tendered.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: FENSERAl, beloved husband of Betty, father at Carole Soling and Dr. Michael Fenster. Grandfather of Sha??on Mork, Andrea Fenster; Caytha, Courtney and Cevin Soling. Funeral 1 P.M., Thurs., Collins Funeral Home, Norwalk, Conn.

title: Market Place
description: The shares of the Eason Oil Company have fluctuated widely this week, presumably on speculation that the tightly held concern may be for sale.

title: Rochester, Minn., Recount Asked
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., March 9 (UPI)Mayor Alex Smekta, 68 years old, who was running for his ninth twoyear term, received 5,694 votes yesterday, 31 more than Jessie Howard. Mrs. Howard has demanded a recount.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The Knicks don't need a new coach as much as they need a new chemist. And that's really the reason Willis Reed has succeeded Red Holzman, beginning next season.

title: Fair Sentences and Equal Justice
description: There is a welcome movement afoot to eliminate the wide disparities, intentional and unintentional, in criminal sentencing. Ideas for reform take two forms. One is to abandon indeterminate sentencing, under which judges tailor the penalty to fit the criminal, and rely on tight sentencing guidelines instead. The other is to provide for appellate review of criminal sentences. The momentum for these changes arises from the often irrational nature of sentencing that explains much of the unrest inside Prison walls.

title: Democrats and Republicans Offer Own Plans in Albany on Primary
description: ALBANY, March 9Stunned by Governor Carey's veto last week of their carefully devised bill for a June primary election date this year, Democratic and Republican leaders of the Legislature came forward today with separate plans to establish a permanent primary schedule embedded in the State Constitution.

title: College Basketball
description: AT BLACKSBURG, VA.

title: Haunted by Inflation, Dow Drops 9.14, to Lowest Level Since Jan. 20
description: Fears of doubledigit inflation rates in a key set of Government statistics helped to push stock prices lower yesterday, with weakness in glamour issues particuarly evident.

title: Touro College Ordered to Return $822,533 in Tuition Aid
description: New York State authorities have asked Touro College to return $822,533 in state tuition grants that, they asserted, the college improperly received on behalf of 1,209 students enrolled in special programs for adults.

title: Westinghouse Gets Contracts For $100 Million Utilities Stock
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday that it had received contracts worth more than $100 million to supply a nuclear reactor system, a nuclear fuel fabrication system, a turbine generator and other services to a group of four Spanish electric utilities.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONA panel of experts has advised the United States Postal Service to get involved quickly in electronic transmission of funds and messages, but so far they have received a cool reception from postal managers.

title: Ramapo Maple Sap Is Running And Schoolchildren Are on Tap
description: MAHWAH March 9Stimulated by the mild temperatures, the sap flowed freely this morning, at about a drop a second, from 11 tapped sugar maple trees at the Ramapo Valley County Reservation.

title: Kissinger Back in Academia As the Professor of Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  Visiting Professor of Diplomacy Henry A. Kissinger returned to academia today after an eightyear absence.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: Foreign Relationswhile at the same time the Administration welcomed an Italian Fascist. Unita, the Italian Communist newspaper, has been trying for months now to get the visas needed to open a Washington bureau.

title: Maj. Gen. Westside T. Larson, 83; His Air Command Fought UBoats
description: INGLEWOOD. Calif., March 9 (UPI)Maj. Gen. Westside T. Larson died Monday in Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital. He was 83 years old. In World War II, he headed the Atlantic coast antisubmarine air command.

title: 3 Rich Nations Pressed to Bolster J.M.F, Lending to Needy Countries
description: Wealthier countries, notably Saudi Ara bia, Kuwait and West Germany, are being pressed to contribute toward a substantial and rapid increase in the lendable recources of the International Monetary Fund. American officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Grote Signs As Player, Then Coach
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9Not a bad day for Jerry Grote, the No. 1 catcher for the New York Mets the last 10 years and one of the 800 baseball players chasing the rainbow in Florida's 18 spring training camps.

title: Tennis
description: AT JOHANNESBURG

title: Fewer Cars Towed As Dockers Picket Pier Used as Pound
description: The towing away of illegally parked cars was reduced yesterday as longshoremen picketed Pier 76 on the Hudson River waterfront to protest against police use of the pier as a temporary car pound.

title: Gold Price Off After Two Months of Almost Steady Gains; Dollar Firm
description: LONDON, March 9 (AP)The price of gold dropped again in Europe today after nearly two months of almost steady rises. The dollar was firm.

title: NEW YORK OFFERS PLAN TO END ITS DEBT CRISIS WITHOUT AID OF BANKS
description: In a sudden and surprising move, Mayor Beame last night unveiled a plan to raise the money needed to pay the city's $983 million shortterm debt without the assistance of New York City's major banks.

title: Reed Declares N.B.A. Crown as His Goal as Knicks' Coach
description: With that remark, Mike Burke, president of the Knicks, started Willis Reed on his coaching career yesterday. Reed, the captain, center and major force behind the Knicks' only two National Basketball Association champion teams, received a threeyear contract, worth $375,000, to remold the losing Knicks' team into a winning one.

title: NAVY IS ORDERED TO PAY SETTLEMENT TO SHIPYARD
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 9 (AP)Ruling the Navy failed to negotiate in good faith, a Federal judge ordered it to pay Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Co. about $20 million to $30 million.

title: Fish Found Not Polluted In Test of Lake Ontario; Further Study Ordered
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 9 (AP)The Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation said today that laboratory tests made for it did not show that the chemical Mirex was present in some fish taken from Lake Ontario last fall.

title: Beame, Goldin Vary on Source Of Debt Funds
description: The $1 billion package to pay off New York City's moratorium debtsunveiled at City Hall yesterdaywas stitched together from sources that city officials had long been reluctant to turn to, or had discovered only in the last week or two, fiscal aides asserted.

title: 1976 U.S.SOVIET TRADE SET RECORD $2.5 BILLION
description: MOSCOW, March 9 (UPI)SovietAmerican trade during 1976 reached a record total turnover of more than $2.5 billion, the United States Commercial Office reported today.

title: A Court Upholds Staged Arrests
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that it was permissible for a prosecutor to stage a crime in an effort to catch corrupt prosecutors and judges.

title: F.D.A. Banning Saccharin Use On Cancer Links
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it would ban the use of saccharin in foods and beverages, because the artificial sweetener had been found to cause malignant bladder tumors in laboratory animals.

title: 'Islands in the Stream' Meanders Out of Control
description: As played with fine, disciplined intensity by George C. Scott in "Islands in the Stream," the film adaptation of Ernest Hemingway's posthumously published novel, Thomas Hudson is a perfectly realized late-Hemingway hero; that is, he's an idealized projection of the way Hemingway wanted to see himself. Hudson is strong, wise, secure, and though he is aware of lossesthose that could have been prevented and those that were inevitablehe is not thrown by them.The time of the film, which was written by Denne Bart Petitclerc and directed by Franklin J. Schaffner, is the summer of 1940, shortly before the United States entered the war. Thomas Hudson, a successful sculptor, twice married, twice divorced, lives in comfortable isolation on the island of Bimini in the Bahamas. He has reached a carefully maintained accord with himself  which means working well, eating and drinking well, fishing well, having friends who are good company but who don't interfere with his emotional machinery.This particular summer begins edgily with the arrival on the island of the sons he hasn't seen in four yearsTom, 19 years old: David, 14, and Andrew, 10. They descend on him as ciphers except for their associations to lives and women he has abandoned or who abandoned him. The summer, though, becomes something quite splendid.The boys fish and swim and fight, and come to appreciate themselves as well as their father, whose satisfaction in them contains a kind of terrible radiance. He gets to know and love them, but now they represent a loss that is not so easily dealt with.This is more or less the first half of "Islands in the Stream," which opened yesterday at the Coronet Theater. It's a film that begins so well, with so much genuine feeling that, as it goes on, sort of petering out, one starts wishing one could control it. Two-thirds of the way through, the wish is desperate. It is like sitting in the back seat of a car that is going gently, but unmistakably, out of control. At the end, after you've run into the tree, you aren't hurt, only very impatient.Mr. Petitclerc, a journalist and novelist who apparently has had the blessing of Hemingway's widow, Mary, in adapting the novel, has been understandably free in his work, though neither he nor Mr. Schaffner has used his freedom very interestingly. The novel, which I like and which contains some of Hemingway's most moving and funniest work, is awkward screen material, but in their changes the writer and the director have simply exchanged one sort of awkwardness for another.They haven't tightened a sprawling novel to fit the screen, they've let it sprawl in other directions, with very little grace and no feeling. "Islands in the Stream" is a movie in which a climactic death scene has less emotional impact than an earlier encounter between father and son while tinkering with an outboard motor.Especially unrewarding is the film's concluding sequence, in which Thomas Hudson and his faithful rummy of a friend, a Petitclerc invention played by David Hemmings, attempt to run through the Cuban Coast Guard to deliver some German Jewish refugees to sanctuary in Cuba.The concluding sequence in the book, no less melodramatic, is about Thomas Hudson's confrontation with the crew of a German U-boat. The film's invention, watered down "To Have and Have Not," seems almost opportunistic, as if the appearance of Jewish refgees would guarantee the film an emotional response lacking in the book.It doesn't work. Somewhat better is the central sequence in the film, when Claire Bloom, looking taut and tired as Thomas Hudson's first wife, the only woman he ever really loved, turns up on the island to mull over the past. Not all of Hemingway's dialogue can actually be spoken, but this sequence contains some marvelous lines that suggest depths of feelings that the film doesn't know what to do with. The former lovers, now middle-aged, go to bed together. They bicker, drink, remember the old days when they were poor in Paris. Says the wife, "How could we all have been such good friends, and had such a lovely time, and had it turn out so badly?"That sense of loss is what "Islands in the Stream" is all about, something that the film explores most successfully in the initial sequence with the boys and their father. I'm aware that film criticism should be more than an inventory of a film's parts, but "Islands in the Stream" is such a mixture of good and bad that it's impossible not to see the trees instead of the forest.Everyone's performance is more or less defined by the material. The young actors who play the sons have very decent moments, especially Michael-James Wixted, as the troubled middle boy. Mr. Hemmings is even better than his material, but Gilbert Roland as an ancient sea captain and Susan Tyrrell as Bimini's chief hooker are enough to snap the imaginations of even the most kindly disposed.

title: R.O.T.C. Officer Accused On Rhodesia Mercenaries
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 9A former University of California student has charged at a news conference here that an R.O.T.C. instructor at the Berkeley campus helped him get a job as a mercenary with the Rhodesian Army last year.

title: U.S. Reporters Given A Glimpse of Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, March 8 (AP)President Idi Amin, dressed in a blue tracksuit top, white shorts, gray socks and canvas sneakers, strode across the lawn of the presidential lodge, smiling and waving to the hundreds of guests gathered for his weekly basketball game.

title: DeBeers Unit and Borden Announce Price Rises
description: The Diamond Trading Company, the selling organization for DeBeers, which produces about 90 percent of all the diamonds in the world market, announced that it was raising prices on all rough diamonds by an average of 15 percent, effective March 28.

title: ANTIPOLLUTION RULES TERMED BEYOND LAW
description: TRENTON, March 9The chairman of an Assembly committee stunned a public hearing today by accusing the State Department of Environmental Protection of making a drastic departure from the Legislature's intentions with its proposed rules for controlling spills of oil and other hazardous substances.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Canadian toy maker has decided to move part of its manufacturing operation to an abandoned handbag factory in Perth Amboy, Mayor George J. Otlowski said.

title: Topics
description: Calories to Spare

title: Madrid Liberalizes Laws Against Labor Strikes
description: MADRID, March 9 (Reuters)The Spanish Government today liberalized strike laws in an effort to win labor support before general elections in June, but also gave employers more scope in laying off workers either for disciplinary or economic reasons.

title: President Requests Job Plan for Youths
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  Citing Franklin D. Roosevelt's Depressionera recovery programs, President Carter asked Congress today for a $1.8 billion jobs program that he said would benefit young people, the nation's largest bloc of unemployment.

title: A Court Upholds Staged Arrests
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that it was permissible for a prosecutor to stage a crime in an effort to catch corrupt prosecutors and judges.

title: GUNMEN LINKED TO A MOSLEM SECT INVADE 3 BUILDINGS IN WASHINGTON, KILL 1 AND HOLD SCORES HOSTAGE
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, March 10Small bands of gunmen, most saying they were members of the Hanafi Moslem sect, invaded city hall and two other buildings in downtown Washington, yesterday, killing one person, wounding at least 13 and taking nearly 150 persons hostage.

title: New York's Three for the Money
description: Even the participants seem confused as the city's fiscal crisis reaches another climax with all the dignity of professional wrestling match. Mayor Beame's surprise announcement of a plan to raise the money needed to pay off the city's shortterm debt must confound an already bewildered citizenry.

title: Workers Over Age 55 to Be Kept On New York Payroll, Beame Says
description: Mayor Beanie yesterday announced that 1,380 city workers over the age 55 would be kept on the job in anticipation of Congressional action extending funds that were to expire Monday.

title: The Objects May Be Antique, But the Prices Are Very Modern
Television
description: Cullums Happy Jazz Band, guests (13)Community of Living Things (R)

title: 5c Increase Is Seen For Orange Juice As Result of Frost
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)The retail price of a small can of orangejuice concentrate might be going up by a nickel over last year's average because of frost damage to the Florida citrus groves, new Agriculture Department crop estimates indicated today.

title: E.R.A. Suffers Setback In Illinois House
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 9 (UPI)The Illinois House dealt the equal rights amendment a setback today, voting 100 to 66 to retain the requirement for a threefifths vote for ratification.

title: College Results
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL

title: TrainCar Crash Kills Four Airmen
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 9 (UPI)A speeding train struck the side of a car at a rural railroad crossing last night and pushed it a halfmile down the track, killing four young Air Force enlisted men. The dead, all stationed at Chanute Air Force Base, were identified as Aaron D. Seidl, 18 years old, of Ruth, Mich., Dennis Reed, 19, of Worcester, Mass., David R. Tillery, 17, of Orangevale, Calif., and Billy Ray Rash, 18, of Bradford, Ark.

title: F.D.A. Banning Saccharin Use On Cancer Links
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it would ban the use of saccharin in foods and beverages, because the artificial sweetener had been found to cause malignant bladder tumors in laboratory animals.

title: Nuclear Aircraft Carrier Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)The Senate Appropriations Committee voted 18 to 4 today to drop further construction of giant nuclearpowered aircraft carriers. It approved a bill, already passed by the House and recommended by President Carter and former President Ford, to rescind funds appropriated last year to start building a fourth Nimitzclass carrier. Instead of constructing another $2 billion carrier, the plan is to build two smaller nonnuclear carriers. The cost is expected to be about the same.

title: Quebec's Leader Is Reassuring on Independence for Province and Says Aim Is the Contrary of Isolation
description: QUEBEC, March 9  Premier Ren Lvesque opened the new session of the Quebec provincial legislature yesterday by indicating a double strategy of reassurance and exhortation to persuade voters to support his idea of an independent Quebec.

title: Carter and New C.I.A. Director Divided on Need For Criminal Penalties to Prevent Security Leaks
description: WASHINGTON, March 9President Carter and his Director of Central Intelligence, Adm. Stansfield Turner, took opposing stands today on whether criminal penalties are needed to protect national security against unauthorized discosures of classified information.

title: College Woman Is Slain in Newark
description: A 21yearold Essex County College, woman student was stabbed to death in Newark in an apparent robbery early yesterday, less than a block from her home.

title: Mote And Beam
description: BOSTON, March 9Tass, the Soviet press agency, has had some heartfelt comments to make lately on the fate of human rights in the United States. The American judicial system, it said, is truly ruthless toward dissenters, against anyone who actively comes out against the United States' aggressive course in the international arena. . . .

title: His Decision Comes After Officials Learn of Impending Article on Federal Grand Jury Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Kenneth S. Axelson withdrew his name late today from consideration for nomination as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Department, the agency's second highest post.

title: Dance: Feld and Baryshnikov
description: The Eliot Feld Ballet made it to Broadway for the first time last night, and made it in a suitably spectacular way. It opened its first season at the City Center 55th Street Theater with a new duet created by Mr. Feld for Christine Sarry and the company's guest artist, Mikhail Baryshnikov. Mr. Baryshnikov will be dancing with the Feld Company three times during this twoweek engagement.

title: British Rugby
description: Aberaven 24, Bristol 16. Abertillery 6, Newbridge 18. Neath 13, Ebbwavale 6. Nuneaton 0, Nottingham 27. Pontypool 16, Glamorgan 14. Pontypridd 15, Cross Keys 7. Swansea 27, Bridgend 12.

title: With Traditional Gentility, A Club Bows to Modernity
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 9Times have changed . . . things are different . . .I'm feeling better . . . you don't look a day older. . .

title: Assembly Passes 2 Bills to Curb Redlining by Mortgage Bankers
description: ALBANY, March 9The Assembly today passed two bills to restrict redliningthe refusal by banks to make mortgage loans in certain geographic areasand a third that would allow savings bank depositors to elect the bank's trustees.

title: Cherry Orchard: Two Versions
description: Chekhov's characters are caught in time, in the emptiness of Mother Russia gone dry, in a tired countryside already undermined by the distant city, and by dreams and departures.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 10, 1977

title: LAST TRAVEL CURBS REMOVED BY CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, March 9President Carter announced today that restrictions on travel to Cuba, Vietnam, North Korea and Cambodia would be removed on March 18.

title: Senate Confirms Warnke, 5840; Vote Falls Short of Carter's Hopes
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The Senate confirmed Paul C. Warnke today as the nation's chief arms negotiator, but the vote of 58 to 40 fell short of the broad demonstration of support the Carter Administration was seeking.

title: Clerks' Union Seeks to Woo $2 Bettor Back to Aqueduct
description: An endangered species  the $2 horseplayerwas sought out yesterday for protection by hardpressed parimutuel clerks.

title: Plans of Business for Spending Lag
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)Business has demonstrated little enthusiasm for increasing plans for spending on new productive facilities this year, the Government reported today. Spending for last year turned out to be lower than originally estimated.

title: Rams Trade the Rights To Jaworski to Eagles
description: LOS ANGELES, March 9 (AP)The Los Angeles Rams have traded the rights to Ron Jaworski, a quarterback, to the Philadelphia Eagles for the rights to a tight end. Charles Young, the Rams announced today.

title: Prince Charles Leads Newshounds on a Merry Chase in Africa
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 9Prince Charles, who is in Kenya on a photographic safari, is himself the quarry in a journalistic hunt mounted by a Fleet Street caravan.

title: Imelda Marcos May Join Philippine Rebel Talks
description: MANILA, March 9 (AP)  President Ferdinand E. Marcos is sending his wife to Libya hoping that her personal diplomacy will help stalled negotiations there with southern Philippine Moslem insurgents, official sources said today.

title: Screen: 3Hour Mohammad
description: The threehourlong, achingly clumsy Mohammad, Messenger of God does perform one backhanded service for the religion of Islam. It is, of itself, a convincing justification for the traditional Islamic hostility to pictorial representation.

title: Woman's Death Held Accidental MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., March 9 (UPI)
description: A young woman who jumped from her boyfriend's van died accidentally, authorities have ruled. An investigation into the Feb. 19 death of Deborah Troop, 18 years old, of Medford, found no basis for charges against her boyfriend, Herman Walder, 19, of Medford. Authorities reportedly learned that Miss Troop jumped, from Mr. Waldter's van on at least one other occasion while it was in motion.

title: GOVERNOR HOLDS PARLEY WITH A.F.L.C.I.O. LEADERS
description: ALBANY, March 9Members of the executive council of the New York State A.F.L.C.I.O., who last week refused an invitation from Governor Carey to join other labor leaders for dinner, met privately with the Governor for more than an hour late this afternoon in what appeared to have been a spirit of dtente.

title: Hospital Agency Plans to Pressure Logan by Ending Ambulance Runs
description: In the struggle for survival between the municipal Sydenham Hospital in Harlem, and nearby Arthur C. Logan Memorial Hospital, a private, voluntary institution that is in bankruptcy proceedings, the New York Health and Hospitals Corporation has conceived what it concedes is an unsportsmanlike tactic to force the closing of Logan.

title: F.C.C. Appeals Curb on Papers Owning RadioTV in Same City
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it was appealing to the Supreme Court a decision by the United States Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia that would break up many joint ownerships of newspapers and broadcasting stations.

title: Little Support Given to U.S. On Action to Protect Ozone
description: So little support for early action to regulate fluorocarbons was voiced at a weeklong, international conference on threats to atmospheric ozone that the United States may defer plans for a followup meeting.

title: Carter Suggests Plan to Let Israel Keep Defense Line in Arab Land
description: WASHINGTON, March 9President Carter today outlined a new approach to a Middle East solution that would establish a sovereign and recognized border between Israel and the Arab countries but would also allow a possibility of Israeli defenses extended beyond those frontiers for the foreseeable future.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Envoy Who Voiced Regrets on Chile Summoned Home
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)Brady Tyson, the American diplomat who apologized in Geneva yesterday for what he said was the United States role in the subversion of the Allende Government of Chile, was called home today for instruction in diplomatic procedures.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Wednesday, March 9, 1977 Petition Filed By:

title: Carter Strikes Back on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  President Carter, shifting to the offensive against Congress today, has shown for the first time since taking office his willingness to do battle with foreign policy conservatives on Capitol Hill on the crucial issue of arms agreements with the Soviet Union.

title: Gene Engineering Causes Sharp Split At Scientist Forum
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Scientists agreed today that genetic engineering was closer to reality than most persons realized, but disagreed sharply on whether its advent would be more blessing or disaster.

title: Ohio Quarry Explosion Felt 100 Miles Away
description: CAREY, Ohio, March 9 (AP)A dynamite blast felt 100 miles away in Michigan tore through a rock quarry in rural Wyandot County today, hurling debris for a mile and causing damage to homes in a fivemile radius. There were no reports of injuries.

title: Canadian Dollar Slumps
description: The Canadian dollar fell below 95 United States cents in New York yesterdayits lowest level in more than seven years, dealers said.

title: Quigley Posts an Ace
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, March 9 (AP)Dave Quigley of the United States scored a holeinone today as he and his partner, Jaafar Ali of Malaysia, won the proamateur event preceding the $40,000 Malaysian open golf championship. Quigley, who won the top prize of $400, made his ace on the old course of the Royal Selangor Golf Course, en route to a oneunderpar 71. Jaafar All had a 72 for a net score of 58. Masuru Nakamura of Japan and George Lee of Britain were second with a net 60. Nakamura won $280.

title: People in Business
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange will each add a woman floor member today, bringing the number of women members at these once allmale institutions to three apiece.

title: Search for 5 Miners Is Delayed As Drill Hits Water at 355 Feet
description: TOWER CITY, Pa., March 9 (AP)Work on drilling a second hole into Big Lick Mountain in search of five missing coal miners was stopped shortly after noon today when the drill struck water at the 355foot mark.

title: Mirolovich Joins N.C. State
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 9 (UPI)John Mirolovich, who came to the University of Kentucky as an assistant football coach with Fran Curci four years ago, accepted a position today on the football staff at North Carolina State.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE ON CORPORATE BONDS
description: Interest rates on topquality corporate bonds moved higher yesterday. In the key corporate bond offering of the week, the South Central Bell Telephone Company sold $210 million of 40year tripleA debentures to an underwriting network managed by Morgan Stanley & Company, and the investment bankers priced the issue to yield 8.30 percent. This rate of return was up from 8.18 percent in another Bell System bold sale in February and with 7.90 percent on one sold in December.

title: Pride Is His Spur
description: Some years ago in the old Madison Square Garden. Saturday morning basketball clinics for thousands of youngsters were commonplace. The local college coaches were the lecturers and several of the Knick players served as props.

title: Notes on People
description: Supporters of Gough Whitlam, the former Prime Minister of Australia, insisted yesterday that a controversial speech he made in front of Queen Elizabeth II in Canberra was really only a goodnatured spoof, and besides, royal clearance for it had been obtained well in advance. In the speech, which brought a restrained smile or two from the Queen, Mr. Whitlam said: The United KingdomI see some of your subjects there want you to be Queen of Scots. Elizabeth Queen of Scots doesn't sound quite right, though not as bad as Queen of Queensland. And last week it was proposed that you be Queen of the Solomons. What next? Queen of Sheba? All of which brought scolding for Mr. Whitlam in some Australian newspapers. And in the British Parliament yesterday, several Conservative members rose to denounce Mr. Whitlam. One member, John BiggsDavison said: This is the small talk of a small man who abused the knowledge that the Queen cannot reply.

title: Orient Title Bout Reset
description: MANILA, March 9 (AP)Because of a schedule conflict, the Orient junior featherweight championship fight between the Filipino titleholder, Aric Quijano and Chung SoonYun, the Korean challenger, has been rescheduled from April 1 to April 15. The bout's organnizer said today the new date was prompted by a conflict with another title bout arranged here by another promoter between Soo HwangHong, South Korea's Orient champion, and Rolando Navarrette of the Philippines.

title: Automakers Warned on Price Rises
description: WEST BERLIN, March 9 (Reuters)The West German Government's anticartel bureau said today it had warned three leading automakers  Volkswagen, the Ford Motor Company and Opel, a unit of the General Motors Corporationagainst increasing their prices in the current model year.

title: Carroll O'Connor Fights With a Biographer
description: LOS ANGELESThe letter appeared as a fullpage advertisement in the Hollywood trade papers on Feb. 24.

title: Beame's Panel Urges U. S. Pay Cost of Welfare
description: The Temporary Commission on City Finances has called for a Federal takeover of all welfare costs, asserting the move would save municipalities in New York State $800 million a year.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Kissinger Back in Academia As the Professor of Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  Visiting Professor of Diplomacy Henry A. Kissinger returned to academia today after an eightyear absence.

title: College Woman Slain Near Home in Newark
description: A 21yearold Essex County College woman student was stabbed to death in Newark in an apparent robbery early yesterday, less than a block from her home.

title: RollCall in the Senate On Warnke Selection
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate voted today to confirm Paul C. Warnke as the disarmament negotiator:

title: ELECTED FOES OF BHUTTO TO BOYCOTT PARLIAMENT
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 9 (UPI) Newly elected opposition members of Parliament said today that they would not take their seats in the legislature, charging that the balloting in this week's election was rigged.

title: Seattle Slew Sets Mark In Debut as 3YearOld
description: HIALEAH, Fla., March 9Thoroughbred racing's most spectacular space }hot of the young season took off on schedule today at Hialeah Park when Unbeaten Seattle Slew won his first start as a 3yearold by nine lengths in trackrecord time. In the winner's Circle, he wasn't even breathing hard.

title: CARTER SEES PULLOUT FROM KOREA BY 1982
description: WASHINGTON, March 9President Carter said today that he intended to withdraw American ground forces from South Korea in four to five years, enunciating a critical point in a new policy on Korea that is taking shape in the Administration and the Congress.

title: U.S. Passport Is Only Half the Issue
description: President Carter's decision to lift travel restrictions abroad removes a symbolic roadblock to visiting four proscribed countries, but the major hurdle remains getting an entry visa from the Government involved.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Sparse Snow Defies a Winter Tradition at Ski Area in the Grand Tetons
description: TETON VILLAGE, Wyo., March 9He never thought it would happen, but it did. Paul McCollister, the founder of the Jackson Hole ski area in this lofty Grand Teton country, is still puzzled over what became of winter. Last year at this time we had 108 inches of the finest Rocky Mountain snow covering our area's midsection, he said. Do you know what we have up now? Thirtysix inches and most of that came only a few weeks ago. McCol lister has maintained that snow is to Jackson Hole what sunshine is to Palm Springs.

title: Leader of Hanafi Moslem Sect Once Helped Dropouts in Harlem
description: CHICAGO, March 9The Hanafi Moslem sect was organized and is led by Hamaas Abdul Khaalis, a 55yearold former New York resident, who once headed a community program in Harlem to help school dropouts.

title: Orders Rise for Women's Apparel From Europe
description: American retailers are increasing their orders for madeinEurope women's apparel, according to manufacturers exhibiting at the European Fashion Fair. The fair has drawn more than 4.500 buyers from large and small retail stores who came to inspect the fashions of 228 European companies at the fourday show which ended yesterday.

title: INDUSTRY RESPONDS TO BAN ON SACCHARIN
description: NEW YORK, March 9 (AP)A top official of the nation's largest maker of lowcalorie sweetener said today that the Government's ban of saccharin was based on flimsy scientific evidence.

title: House Panel Calls for an Inquiry, Hinting Harassment of Witness
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)A bill collector who asked to testify about abuses in the collection industry was threatened or intimidated into not appearing, a House subcommittee chairman said today.

title: COAST BROKERAGE FIRMS INVESTIGATED BY S.E.C.
description: A leading West Coast brokerage firm disclosed yesterday that it and a number of other brokers were under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission to determine whether they had given preferential treatment to an overthecounter trader for a large institutional investor.

title: CHEMICAL PLANT SHUT BY U.S. COURT ORDER
description: WASHINGTON, March 9At the request of the Environmental Protection Agency, a Federal, judge in West Virginia issued a temporary restraining order today shutting down an FMC Corporation plant in Charleston that was discharging carbon tetrachloride into the water supply.

title: GOING OUT;Guider
description: VOICES Two major spokesmen frbm the worlds of stage and verse can be heard today in public appearances.

title: A. K.C. Board Elects Woman
description: The American Kennel Club took 93 years to elect a woman vice president. Nan R. Ayling of Kings Park, L.I., a 28year employee who worked her way through the ranks to administrative posts, assumed that office this week. She joined the stair Aug. 15, 1949, as a registration clerk, and in 1951 was assigned to the registration correspondence department.

title: Hostage, Freed Twice, Is Told: Kiss Your Wife and Baby
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Paddy James Jr., his trousers splotched with someone else's blood, had nearly escaped the B'nai B'rith Building here this afternoon when one of his armed captors called him back.

title: Blair Puts in Word for Jackson, His Yankee Mate
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 9For most of his 12 years as a Baltimore Oriole, Paul Blair was recognized as the best center fielder in baseball. He also was recognized as one of the best talkers in baseball. Motormouth his teammates called him.

title: Belgium Prime Minister Calls April Elections
description: BRUSSELS, March 9 (Reuters)Prime Minister Leo Tindemans of Belgium today abandoned efforts to run the country with a shaky minority coalition and called a general election for April 17.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Paris Couture Comes to New York, And It Creates a Mood of Nostalgia
description: Though the clothes were contemporary, Andrew Goodman, the chairman of Bergdorf Goodman, called it a nostalgic occasion.

title: ExSt. Louis Mayor Loses Comeback Bid In Democratic Race
description: ST. LOUIS, March 9State Senator James F. Conway won a surprisingly easy victory yesterday in the Democratic primary for mayor of St. Louis, spoiling the bid of former Mayor Alfonso J. Cervantes for a comeback.

title: Mrs. Trudeau, Visiting New York, Denies Link With Rolling Stones
description: Margaret Trudeau, the wife of Canada's Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, flew here from Toronto yesterday to continue what she described as a longplanned vacation devoted to photography.

title: About New York
description: It must be confessed that there is initally an urge to halfsmile at the startling tales of the thousands of people all over townhumble shopkeepers and homeowners and landlords and tenantsstealing electricity and gas from Consolidated Edison, the city's ultimate power broker.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: BOLTONFrances Payne. The Officers. Directors and Staff of the Parapsychology Foundation record with deep sorrow the death on March 9, 1977 of their Vice President and CoFounder, the Honorable Frances Payne Bolton.

title: Hopes Rise for Leyland Settlement
description: LONDON. March 9After almost three weeks of deadlock, hopes rose today for a settlement of a wildcat strike that has crippled British Leyland Ltd., the country's biggest automobile producer, and set back the Labor Government's efforts to project a positive economic image.

title: People in Sports
description: Bob Gaillard, who led the San Francisco Dons to their best basketball season since the days of Bill Russell, was named the college coach of the year by The Associated Press yesterday. The Dons had won 29 games this season before bowing to Notre Dame last weekend.

title: Mrs. Carter Says She Tells The President What I Think
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)When President Carter is weighing some important policy decision, he does not have to ask his wife for her advice.

title: Will Rogers Institute Due to Move To Burke Center in White Plains
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 9The Will Rogers Rogers Memorial Hospital and Research Center, which shut down its institution in Saranac Lake, N.Y., in late 1975 that had cared for actors with respiratory ailments since the 1930's, is moving its equipment to the Burke Rehabilitation Center here under an affiliation agreement announced today.

title: Italy, With Eye on Economic Perils, Goes After Sunken Poison Cargo
description: OTRANTO, Italy  Two ships, painted bright yellow, pulled out of the small port here the other day and headed for a buoy three miles offshore. Their job is the talk of this community and all of Italy.

title: WOOLWORTH'S NET UP 8% IN QUARTER
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company, one of the world's largest retail store chains, reported yesterday an 8 percent increase in fourthquarter earnings and a 20 percent gain for all of 1976. Including the equity of earnings of its British subsidiary, the consolidated income was fractionally lower for the quarter but 9 percent higher on an annual basis. Foreign exchange translations cut the British subsidiary's earnings sharply for the quarter and year

title: Bridge:
description: Few bridge writers are good bridge teachers, and vice versa. There is no particular reason why these two abilities should go hand in hand.

title: $39.8 Million Fine Sought Against Wheeling Steel
description: PITTSBURGH, March 9The Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Resources filed a complaint late yesterday asking the State Environmental Hearing Board to fine the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation $39.8 million, charging violations of the state air pollution laws. The complaint stems from the use of cokeoven batteries, blast furnaces, boilers and soaking pits at WheelingPittsburgh's Monessen.

title: Diplomats Note Credibility Problem
description: GENEVA, March 8A number of diplomats said here today that the credibility of United States foreign policy has been damaged by the statement yesterday by Brady Tyson expressing profoundest regrets for the part he said American officials and private groups had played in the subversion of the Allende Government.

title: The Back Channel
description: SAN FRANCISCOLet us now consider the strange origin of the investigation into corruption in the House of Representatives, whichif properly pursuedwill lead to the slamming of cell doors behind one out of every ten Congressmen.

title: Man Questioned in Disappearance Of Girl, 10, From Her L.I. Home
description: MINEOLA, LI., March 9A 32yearold man was taken into custody this afternoon in connection with the disappearance this morning of a 10yearold girl from her home in South Farmingdale.

title: City U. Is Accused of Oversperzding by $400,000 on Officials Housing
description: The City University of New York spent about $400,000 more than the $1.2 million it was authorized to spend to house its chancellor and college presidents, according to a draft audit by the office of State Controller Arthur Levitt.

title: Two Fugitives From Jersey Prison Caught in New York and Returned
description: RAHWAY, N. J., March 9 (UPI)Two brothers who escaped from the Rahway minimumsecurity camp were recaptured by the state police in upstate New York after a 25mile auto chase, authorities reported.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. PLANNING SHOOTING INVESTIGATION
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., March, 9 Mayor Thomas E. Sharpe said today that the Justice Department had agreed to conduct its own investigation of a fatal shooting here on Feb. 14 of a 29yearold black man by a white policeman.

title: Manson Asks High Court To Overturn Conviction
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (UPI)Charles Manson, the former California cult leader, appealed today to the Supreme Court his 1971 conviction of multiple murders in Los Angeles.

title: Paris Wants Mothers To Get 2Year Leave
description: PARIS, March 9 (Reuters)Working mothers will receive a twoyear leave of absence from their jobs when they bear a child under a new Mother's Charter approved by the Cabinet today.

title: Wesley Lloyd of Brigham Young U.
description: Wesley P. Lloyd, an educator and former dean of the graduate school at Brigham Young University, Provo, Utah, died of cancer Monday at his home in La Jolla, Calif. He was 72 years old.

title: Reporters' Questions Show Gap Between Press and Public
description: WASHINGTON, March 9As President Carter had forecast, no one asked him today at a White House news conference about boxcars filled with snow, baseball games in Cuba or justice for Ottawa Indians.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Experts Study New Concorde Plan
description: Technical experts yesterday began studying a compromise plan that operators of the BritishFrench Concorde say would enable the plane to operate at noise levels at Kennedy International Airport no louder than those of many subsonic aircraft.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The cost of a bachelor's degree at New York University has risen to between $22,450 and $23,560 under a new schedule of higher tuition and fees, according to the university's president, John C. Sawhill.

title: Jackson to Ask Bill to Require Coal Use as Fuel
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Seizing the initiative in advance of President Carter's comprehensive energy policy statement, Senator Henry M. Jackson plans to introduce tomorrow a bill to compel electric power plants and factories to burn coal in their boilers instead of oil or natural gas.

title: TV: Two Fine Dramas, Bar Mitzvah Boy and Circle of Children, on Tonight's Schedule
description: There are two exceptionally good dramas on the schedule this evening but true to irritating form, they are running in overlapping time periods. The Bar Mitzvah Boy, an import from the British Broadcasting Corporation, is on Channel 13 from about 8:30 to about 9:45 (this is a fundraising week and times are flexible). A Circle of Children, starring Jane Alexander and Rachel Roberts, is on CBS from 9 to 11.

title: Rhodesian Asserts U.S. Actions Will Put Region in Soviet Sphere
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 9Foreign Minister Pieter K. van der Byl said today that the Carter Administration, by rejecting Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's proposals for a settlement with black moderates, is in effect condemning Rhodesiaand evenually much of subSaharan Africato Soviet domination.

title: China Steps Up Wheat Buying; Order Total Put at $550 Million
description: PEKINGAfter three years of reducing its wheat imports, China is once again diping deeply into its foreign currency reserves to feed its people.

title: CocaCola Responds
description: ATLANTA, March 9The executive vice president of the CocaCola Company, Charles W. Adams, said tonight, We regret the action taken by the F.D.A., but added: Nonetheless, we are complying with the acting commissioner's request for manufacturers to discontinue the use of saccharin as soon as possible.

title: Accord at Garden State
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., March 9 (AP)Management of Garden State Park and officials of the union representing the track's cleaning department workers, truck drivers and uniformed guards, reached agreement today on contract terms. Local 676 of the Teamsters Union had placed pickets at the track earlier in the day in a dispute over the contract's hospitalization terms. There was no interruption of the day's racing card.

title: MONDALE VOWS TO IMPROVE CONSULTATION WITH SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)Vice President Mondale listened to a barrage of complaints from Democratic senators today and then promised that the Carter Administration would do better about consultation on major decisions and appointments.

title: Ohio Black Frees White Hostage, Talks to Carter, Then Is Charged
description: WARRENSVILLE HEIGHTS, Ohio, March 9Cory C. Moore, a black former marine, released a white diabetic hostage today and then surrendered peacefully to the local authorities after hearing President Carter say at his news conference in Washington that he would talk personally with Mr. Moore.

title: Beame Clears Way For Shopping Mall On a Tour of Bronx
description: Mayor Beame, a sometime jogger, took a twohour walking tour and car ride through the Bronx yesterday. He said it was for official, not political, purposes.

title: India Expels British Reporter
description: LONDON, March 9 (AP)A reporter for The Sunday Times of London has been expelled from India, the paper announced today. It said that Ian Jack, who has been covering the Indian election campaign, had been told by Indian authorities to leave by the first available plane.

title: Texts of Blumenthal And Axelson Letters
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Following are the texts of an exchange of letters between Kenneth S. Axelson and Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal concerning Mr. Axelson's withdrawal from consideration for nomination as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury:

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Following is a transcript of President Carter's news conference in Washington yesterday morning, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 10, 1977

title: 62 Rout in Atlanta Tightens Race
description: ATLANTA, March 9Who said you can't fool all of the people all of the time? The Islanders, who had fooled all of the Atlanta Flames five previous times (70, 63, 83, 42 and 54) this season, fooled them for the sixth and final time tonight.

title: Rising Price and Shortage Spur Oil and Gas Search
description: HOUSTONIt's a busy time, said George A. Alcorn, who, with his two brothers, explores for oil around the Gulf Coast. The opportunities are super, the demand is so high and the price is right.

title: 6 Landlords and 5 Arsonists Charged With Plan to Set Fires
description: Six landlords and five torch'or arsonistsuspects were arrested yesterday and charged with conspiring to set at least four fires in the Fordham section of the Bronx.

title: Chase Manages Iranian Bank Loan
description: LONDON, March 9Chase Manhattan Ltd. said that it managed a $120 million sevenyear Eurocurrency loan fod the Industrial Credit Bank of Iran to be used to finance industrial development in the country.

title: Stars Beaten by 64 on Gilbert Night
description: A FrenchCanadian player who has sunk his roots in this city aftr 16 seasons with the Rangers and an unemployed semipro goalie hoping for a home in New York held the spotlight last night in Madison Square Garden as New York defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 64.

title: For TeenAlters, a Different Kind of Sex Education
description: SYRACUSEIn the belief that if teenage girls recognize the lines boys entice them with, it will help reduce unwanted pregnancies, Dr. Sol Gordon has been collecting and publicizing these stories, ranging from the classic, Want to see my etchings? to the more inventive If you say no I'll become mentally ill.

title: U.S. Oil Output Hits 11Year Low As Imports Climb
description: Oil imports rose to record levels for the third consecutive week while a revised estimate of domestic petroleum production for February placed United States output at 7.95 million barrels a day, the first drop below the eight million mark since the mid1960's.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Prof. Paul A. Samuelson of M.I.T.. himself a Nobel Prize winner, once remarked that the person who solves the problem of stagflationthe mixture of economic stagnation and inflation that has afflicted the Western world through most of the 1970'sshould get the Nobel Prize in economics. Thus far it does not appear that Charles L. Schultze, W. Michael Blumenthal, Bert Lance or anyone else in the Carter Administration is in the running.

title: Virginia Tech Advances in N.I.T., 8379
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., March 9 (AP)Virginia Tech held off Georgetown, 8379, tonight in a National Invitation Tournament openinground basketball game.

title: Highlights of New York City's Latest Fiscal Plan
description: M.A.C. STRETCHA surrendering of principal payments of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds paid last Feb. 1 to the city sinking funds and the municipal employee pension funds, yielding $90 million. The major New York city banks had refused to do the same for their M.A.C. bonds.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: BACHEAlice Kay. Mother of Ellen, Stephen Kay O.S.H. and Paul Kay, grandmother of Yvette and Suzanne Kay, sister of Marlon Moor and Freyhan Odenheimer. Service at Temple EmanuelEl, 5th Avenue at 65 Street, Thursday, 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Metropolitan Muscum of Art would be appreciated.

title: Big Board Audit Rule On Companies Backed
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it approved a rule proposed by the New York Stock Exchange; which would require all domestic companies with Big Boardlisted common stock to set up independent audit committees by July 1.

title: Mark Roth Finally Striking It Big on Bowling Tour
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 9Mark Roth is another tough New York competitor who rose to the top through the alleysbut with a slight difference. He came up through the howling alleys.

title: Arabs and Black Africans End Cairo Meeting in a Mood of Accord
description: CAIRO, March 9The first conference of leaders from black Africa and the Arab world ended here today with delegates from both regions declaring that they had obtained more benefit from the talks than they had dared to hope.

title: 3 Winners for Cordero
description: After two days of losers, Angel Cordero was back in the groove. The jockey, who returned from California this week, got his first winners of the New York seasonthree of them. His scores included the $36,425 Cicada for 3yearold fillies.

title: Cabaret: Broadway at Ballroom
description: The Ballroom's laudable and adventuresome Broadway at the Ballroom seriesin which noted composers and lyricists from Broadway sing and discuss their workis offering its final presentation this week. Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice opened Tuesday and will continue through Sunday.

title: NEW YORK OFFERS PLAN TO END ITS DEBT CRISIS WITH NO NEW BANK AID
description: In a sudden and surprising move, Mayor Beame last night unveiled a plan to raise the money needed to pay the city's $983 million shortterm debt without the assistance of New York City's major banks.

title: FRANCES BOLTON DIES; EXMEMBER OF HOUSE
description: CLEVELAND, March 9Frances Payne Bolton, a member of Congress for nearly 30 years, the widow of a Congressman and the mother of another one, died early this morning at her home in suburban Lyndhurst.

title: Advertising
description: Just because CBS has become a major force in consumer magazine publishing largely through acquisition doesn't mean it is committed to that route.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 9The oneweek shutdown of some New Jersey industries in January because of the naturalgas shortage apparently had one positive effect: It proved to the state's economic experts that New Jersey's apparent recovery from a twoyear recession was real.

title: The Standings
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Wirth of Foote Given Chicago Position
description: Some time during the current year, W. R. Wirth Jr., general manager of Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, will wend his way to the Chicago office to take on a big corporate job with a broad domestic and international overview.

title: Dr. Richards, Now Broke, Planning to Play New Circuit for Women; To Drop Lawsuit
description: Dr. Renee Richards, who used to earn $100,000 a year as an ophthalmologist, says she is broke and in debt as a result of her quest to gain acceptance as a professional woman tennis player.

title: NO RENT RISE SEEN IN MORTGAGE SALES
description: New York City housing officials said yesterday that the city's plan to raise cash by selling parts of more than 100 MitchellLama housing mortgages would not bring about higher rents or cooperative carrying charges in the projects involved.

title: Rulings on Imports Posing Trade Dilemma for Carter
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The Carter Administration must soon deal with a trade time bomb.

title: ADOLESCENT SOUGHT AS STUDENT'S KILLER
description: The police yesterday were seeking a youth 16 to 18 years old in connection with Tuesday evening's killing of a Columbia student a few blocks from her home in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE NIGHT WATCH. 25 Years of Peculiar Service, By David Atlee Phillips. 309 pages. Atheneum. $9.95.

title: Police Chief Behan, Considered for City Post, Shifted
description: Two of the Police Department's super chiefs were shifted yesterday, diminishing the chance that one of them, who had been sounded out about running for President of the New York City Council, would quit police work for politics.

title: Services for Bierman
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., March 9 (UPI)A private funeral service was held today for Bernie Bierman, former University of Minnesota football coach, who died Monday of a heart attack at the age of 82.

title: Combustion Engineering Gets Qatar Gas Contract
description: Combustion Engineering Inc., of Stamford, Conn., said that its Natco Crest division in Tulsa, Okla., had contracted to help Mitsubishi Heavy Industries of Japan in setting up a $170 million natural gas liquids gathering system off the coast of Qatar in the Arabian Gulf.

title: President Requests Job Plan for Youths
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  Citing Franklin D. Roosevelt's Depressionera recovery programs, President Carter asked Congress today for a $1.8 billion jobs program that he said would benefit young people, the nation's largest bloc of unemployment.

title: Rhode Island Busing Law Overturned by U.S. Judge
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 9 (AP)A Federal court decision overturning a Rhode Island law that required communities to bus students to regional, nonpublic schools will affect 13 Roman Catholic schools and about 1,000 of their outoftown students.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk discusses the problem of stagilationthe mixture of economic stagnation and inflationthat has afflicted t ho Western world in the nineteenseventies. Page 53.

title: Heart Bypasses Are Often Unnecessary, Study Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) A Federal study on treating the painful heart condition known as angina pectoris concluded that coronary bypass surgery was not necessary in many cases in which it was used, researchers said today.

title: Obituary 5  No Title
description: Bache, Alice K.

title: U.S. Will Send Experts to Rumania to Help Keep Watch for Aftershocks
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 9Rumania and the United States agreed today to collaborate in monitoring this country's geological situation during the critical weeks ahead to see whether Friday's severe earthquake will be followed by aftershocks.

title: Reports of Area Skiing Conditions
description: (Reports supplied be resort owners.)

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Lloyd Paces West Indies To Cricket Test Victory
description: TRINIDAD, Port of Spain, March 9 (Reuters)The West Indies won the second cricket test match against Pakistan today, though the touring team made them fight for the 57 runs they needed for victory. Imran Khan snatched three quick wickets as the West Indies crashed from 148 runs for one wicket overnight to 170 runs for four wickets and struggled for 114 minutes before Clive Lloyd, the team captain, struck the winning runs.

title: Catherine Parker Jones, 58; Worked for Associated Press
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y., March 9 (AP)Catherine Parker Jones, an Associated Press newswoman, died today at. St. Francis Hospital in Poughkeepsie. She was 58 years old.

title: Late Printer Dropped
description: While Seattle Slew was taking charge on the track, Hialeah's new owner, John Brunetti, was showing some forceful authority in the executive office. Brunetti announced that by mutual agreement the contract with the printing company that failed to deliver the openingday programs on time had been ended. The programs were three hours late on a day when 22,002 fans turned out. Wednesday, the track returned to its old program printer, Sullivan Brothers.

title: AXELSON WITHDRAWS FROM CONSIDERATION FOR TREASURY POST
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Kenneth S. Axelson withdrew his name late today froth consideration for nomination as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Department, the agency's second highest post.

title: Chicago Police Charged With Spying on Iranians
description: CHICAGO, March 9 (AP)Iranian students have been a target of an elaborate spying operation by the Chicago Police Department for seven years, court papers charge.

title: Moscow Takes Note of Affair
description: MOSCOW, March 9 (UPI)The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia said today that the Tyson affair had shown Carter Administration officials in their most unfavorable light since former President Richard M. Nixon's support of the coup against the Allende Government of Chile was well known to world public opinion.

title: Beanie, Goldin Vary on Source Of Debt Funds
description: The $1 billion package to pay off New York City's moratorium debtsunveiled at City Hall yesterdaywas stitched together from sources that city officials had long been reluctant to turn to, or had discovered only in the last week or two, fiscal aides asserted.

title: Another Brazilian Export Tax Rise Lifts Coffee Price
description: Coffee futures prices rose again yesterday in steppedup activity, reflecting the latest Brazilian action, which many expect to keep prices of the product abnormally high this year.

title: $430 Million Offer For Kewanee Stock Is Stalled by Court
description: A $430 million acquisition will be held or for several months to permit the Orphan's Court division of the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery, Pa., to give its approval, it was learned yesterday.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Freeport and Potash Unit Acquitted by a U.S. Jury On Conspiracy Indictment
description: CHICAGO, March 9After five days of deliberations, a Federal court jury today acquitted the Freeport Minerals Company and a subsidiary, the National Potash Company, of conspiring to control the production, distribution and sale of potash in North America from 1969 through 1974.

title: At Midtown Theater: The Movie Has Been Canceled
description: Mohammad had left Mecca and huge crowds were gathering in Medina to greet him when, without warning, the movie screen at the Rivoli Theater in midManhattan went black and the lights came on.

title: Public Broadcasting Corporation Elects Chairman
description: W. Allen Wallis, chancellor of the University of Rochester, was elected chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadratting at a special meeting yesterday. Robert S. Benjamin announced last month that he was resigning the chairmanship, but he remains a board member.

title: Mercedes Randall Dead; A LongStanding Pacifist And Writer on Feminism
description: Mercedes Randall, a prominent pacifist and for many years a member of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, died yesterday in her home at 16 Claremont Avenue in Manhattan. She was 81 years old.

title: NATALIE VON HOYER
description: Natalie Branitzka von Hoyer, a Russianborn ballet dancer and teacher, died Tuesday at Parsons Hospital in Flushing, Queens. She was 68 years old and lived in Sea Cliff, L. I.

title: H. J. WHARTON
description: H. J. Wharton, who retired in 1967 as a vice president of the Gulf Oil Corporation, died of cancer Monday in Western Pennsylvania Hospital, Pittsburgh. He lived in Mount Lebanon, Pa., and was 74 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Antismut Zoning Plan Assailed
description: A group of midtown businessmen and civic leaders, members of Community Board 5, came out yesterday against pending zoning changes in New York City that would ban socalled massage parlors and sharply curtail the number of pornographic movie theaters, topless bars, peepshows and adult bookstores in Times Square and other commercial districts.

title: Carter's Callin Program on CBS Won 30% Share of Radio Audience
description: While CBS Radio awaits the results of a more thorough national ratings survey by Trendex, a 10city telephone study by Arbitron has found that approximately 30 percent of homes with radio tuned in to President Carter's twohour callin program on CBS last Saturday afternoon.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time. For high tide at Atlantic City (Steel Pier), deduct 26 min. from Sandy Hook time. For high tide at Jones Inlet (Pt. Lookout), deduct 19 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n

title: Ford Ready to Approve 15Room Retirement Home
description: RANCHO MIRAGE. Calif., March 9Gerald R. Ford and Betty Ford, their financial picture brightened by a milliondollar contract for books they will write, are ready to approve the construction of a 15room. Spanishstyle hacienda next to the golf course home of his friend, Leonard K. Firestone.

title: F.P.C. Orders Gas Allocation Under Jan. 18 Import Mandate
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The Federal Power Commission today ordered the Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation to sell 525 million cubic feet of natural gas to the Equitable Gas Company of Pittsburgh by the end of March.

title: U.S. Says That Panama Talks Are at a Crucial Stage
description: WASHINGTON, March 9Government officials sketched out publicly for the first time today a substantial measure of agreement that has been reached with Panama about the content of a new Panama Canal treaty.

title: Official Says DeMarco Was Told By F.D.A. to Halt Drug Injections
description: NEWARK, March 9Dr. Frances O. Kelsey of the Food and Drug Administration testified today that Dr. Peter T. De Marco was ordered by her agency 12 years ago to stop injecting people with procaine polyvinylpyrrolidine w because of its potential for causing cancer.

title: Prospect Park Zookeeper Convicted Of Lying During Inquiry by the City
description: Walter Neumann, former acting supervisor of the Prospect Park Zoo in Brooklyn, was convicted of perjury yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on a charge that he had lied to the Department of Investigation when he denied shooting at birds and pigeons at the zoo.

title: HOWARD L. SCHULTZ, 64, WAS NUCLEAR PHYSICIST
description: Howard L. Schultz, a nuclear physicist who helped design and direct the first linear accelerator laboratory at Yale University, died last Friday at the University Health Services Center in New Haven. He was 64 years old.

title: MEXICO IS SEEKING LOANS OF $5 BILLION ABROAD
description: FRANKFURT, March 10(Reuters)Mexico plans to raise some $5 billion to $6 billion of foreign loans this year, slightly less than the $6 billion borrowed in 1976, David Ibarra Munoz, president of Mexico's state financing agency, Nacional Financiera, said.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 11, 1977

title: DON'T GET ME INVOLVED, MUHAMMAD ALI REMARKS
description: Muhammed Ali, heavyweight boxing champion, one of three Black Muslims the Hanafi Musl'm leaders have demanded to see, told ABC yesterday: If you're concerned about me, don't get me involved, United Press International reported.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article Wednesday on a malpractice suit against the schools in Copiague, L.I., The Times incorrectly identified a lawyer who informally advised the school counsel. His correct name is Max Margules.

title: Cypriot Sentenced in Gun Incident
description: Stavros Sykopetrides, a 29yearold Greek Cypriot, received a fiveyear prison sentence yesterday in charges of having pointed a loaded pistol at Bulent Ecevit, a former Prime Minister of Turkey who was visiting New York last July. The sentence was imposed in Federal District Court in Manhattan by Judge Henry F. Werker, who recommended that the defendant be given psychiatric treatment and that he be deported at the end of his Prison term.

title: Stockton Gives U.S. 10 Lead in World Cup Tennis
description: HARTFORD,March 10Dick Stockton took the best that Tony Roche could offer tonight, then rallied and won the opening match of the eighth World Cup tennis tournament between the United States and Australia.

title: I.T.C. Postpones Import Decision
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)The International Trade Commission postponed today a decision on sending decommendations to President Carter regarding imports of sugar and color television sets, which have been found to harm domestic industries. The commission spokesman said both issues were debated at length by the sixmember commission but there were too many questions to make a decision. The spokesman said a special meeting has been called Monday to try to resolve both issues.

title: Federal Curb Urged For Bill Collectors
description: WASHINGTON.March 10 (AP)Two state regulators of bill collectors testified today that Federal regulation was needed because state laws could do little about collectors calls from another state.

title: Young Legislator Still Enthusiastic
description: ALBANY, March 9Clifford E. Wilson. freshman legislator and quondam Candide from Queens, has survived his first two months in the Assembly with his enthusiasm intact.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 10, 1977

title: U.S. ACTS TO ASSURE ISRAELIS AND ARABS ON CARTER REMARKS
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Concerned about possible repercussions in Israel and the Arab countries, Carter Administration officials have taken steps in the last 24 hours to try to convince both sides that President Carter's new Middle East proposals did not mean an end to American evenhandedness in negotiations.

title: Wildcat Strike Ends At Times of London
description: LONDON, March 10(Reuters)A wildcat strike that top management said threatened the future of The Times of London ended tonight when the employees went back to work.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Go ahead, then, ban the television from the house, Or, as some parents have done. lock it away, like a skeleton, in the closet.

title: COSTIKYAN PUTS HAT IN THE MAYORAL RING
description: ExDemocratic Chief in Manhattan joins Sutton and Koch in Bid for Party's Nomination

title: YALE DOCTOR CRITICAL OF DE MARCO'S CURES
description: NEWARK, March 10Dr. Adrian M. Ostfeld, chairman of the department of epidemiology and public health at the Yale University Medical School, testified today in the case of Dr. Peter T. DeMarco such chronic diseases of old age as arthritis and heart trouble.

title: Freshman Assemblyman Keeps His Enthusiasm
description: Freshman Assemblyman Keeps His Enthusiasm the Assemblyproclaiming March 5 GreekAmerican voter registration day in Queens.

title: At Sweet n Low Brooklyn Plant, Action Imperils 500 Jobs, $50 Million Business
description: The sign on the redbrick factory in Brooklyn's Navy Yard district says Sweet n Low, the Perfect Sugar Substitute, but for the 500 people who earn their livelihood there, the business suddenly has gone sour.

title: 4 AMREP OFFICIALS GET 6MONTH TERMS IN RIO RANCHO CASE
description: Sixmonth prison sentences were im posed yesterday on four topranking officails of the Amrep Corporation in one of the nation's biggest fraud cases involving a scheme to sell $200 million of land in a New Mexico community called Rio Rancho Estates.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: CoWorker Calls Washington Victim Talented Reporter
description: Friends and colleagues of Maurice Williams remembered him yesterday as an aspiring journalist who displayed an enthusiastic dedication to his job at the Howard University radio station.

title: Accounting Hearings Extended
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board said its public hearings on financial accounting and reporting in the extractive industries, scheduled for March 3031, will be extended to four days because of the number of requests for time to make oral presentations. The hearings will be held at the Waldof Astoria Hotel in New York.

title: A Guide to Special Programs
description: A publication that can he helpful in the home is called Teachers Guides to Television. It's aimed primarily at teachers. but parents use it as well. The guide's main strength is that it can alert families far in advance to programs that are judged especially worthwhile for children.
