The guide is put out by an office of the National Association of Broadcasters but the recommendations it contains are made by a panel of educators. There are two issues a year for $4. The address: Teachers Guides to Television, Post Office Box 564. Lenox Hill Station, New York. N.Y. 10021.

title: Coffee Drinkers of U.S. Help Keep Amin's Treasury Well Provided
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 10Coffee buyers, mostly from the United States and Western Europe, are providing the Uganda regime of Idi Amin with increasing amounts of money that, according to Uganda refugees, is used largely to maintain the country's army, police and security apparatus.

title: Deaths
description: LEAVMildred (nee Borakove). Beloved w??e of Joseph. Loving mother of Irene Greenhall and Richard Leay Devoted grandmother of Diana ant Audrey Greenhall and Daniel ant Peter Leay. Dear sister of Sylvia Drezner and Estelle Meyer. Service: Friday, 1 P.M. at Gutterman's Nassau Memorial Chapel. Long Beacn Rd., Rockville Centre, N.Y. In lieu of flowers memorial gifts to the Solld Tumor Fund, care of Memorial Hospital would be appreciated.

title: Art: Matisse's Swimming Pool
description: ANYTHING that happens one way or another to the Matisse collections at the Museum of Modern Art is of great and lasting importance to our city. The collections in question were founded by Alfred Barr. Mr. Barr was the author of a book on Matisse that has still to be surpassed, and he took the greatest possible pains to acquire not just good Matisses but such masterpieces as Dance, The Red Studio and The Moroccans, which gave a new dimension to our understanding of Matisse.

title: Publishing: A Chapter of Storytellers
description: THE CHIEF GLORY of every people arises from its authors, Samuel Johnson wrote in the preface to his Dictionary (1755). That's putting it kindly. On other days, the commercial grubbiness resembles the literary life described by George Gissing in New Grub Street (1891). Still, we were talking to several reputable storytellers in the last few days....

title: Stage: Edna O'Brien's The Gathering
description: IFEEL a great subterranean anger toward both my personal and my social history, Edna O'rien said in an interview last year. That anger boils to the surface in her new play, The Gathering. which had its American premiere Wednesday at the Manhattan Theater Club. The writing is so filled with bitterness and had memories that it buries the drama.

title: COUNCILMEN ASSAIL REPORT ON SERVICES
description: City Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky seemed skeptical of what first Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti said at an unusual joint session of the Council and the Board of Estimate yesterday. Councilman Robert Wagner Jr. said that, in effect, Mr. Zuccotti was claiming to have invented the wheel, and Councilman Henry Jr. Stern was even more sarcastic.

title: 2 Brothers Are Indicted in Theft Of $8 Million in Insurance Fees
description: TRENTON, March 10Two New Jersey brothers whose empire of insurance firms collapsed in bankruptcy in 1975 were charged today with stealing more than $8 million in insurance premiums in what was called the largest fraud case ever brought in the state.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 10Dr. Oscar B. Sussman, the head of the New Jersey Consumer Health Services, has been rebuffed in his effort to force 200 state officials to pay 14 cents a mile for commuting to work in stateowned cars.

title: Dual Phone Listings Approved by P.U.C.
description: The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners yesterday approved free his and her dual listings for New Jersey Bell Telephone customers who want their names in the telephone book. Under the plan, a husband and wife, two brothers or any two people with the same last name can have both first names listed in the telephone book beginning on Monday.

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE (A)

title: The NoSoLong, WeLoveYouFurlong Blues
description: HANOVER, N. H.The real objection to going metric is not the pain or expense of the changeover. That, after all, would be an acute pain and expense only for a year or two, and then a mild residual discomfort in the minds of older people for perhaps a generation.

title: Spurs 106, Cavaliers 101
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 10 (AP)The San Antonio Spurs sped to their sixth straight victory tonight as they heat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 106101.

title: Senate Approves Public Works Bill Aiding Northeast
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 The Senate overwhelmingly approved tonight a S4 billion public works bill to ease unemployment after approving a formula far more generous to New York. New Jersey and Connecticut than was legislation approved by the House of Representatives.

title: On Letting the Gene Out of the Bottle
description: We wanna make sure nothing conies crawling out of that lab, said the Mayor of Cambridge, when Harvard proposed to study genetic modification. As it happened, the Cambridge City Council recently voted to let Harvard proceed, but the concerns about genetic engineering and Frankenstein genes have become international.

title: Young Says Israel Is Bearing Brunt Of African Anger
description: Andrew Young, the United States chief delegate to the United Nations, said yesterday that Israel had borne the brunt of the African countries frustration over American policies regarding African issues.

title: Saccharin Ban Causes Storm Of Complaints
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Food and Drug Administration, which yesterday proposed the banning of the artificial sweetener saccharin, today was bombarded with complaints from persons demanding that the chemical be allowed to remain on the market.

title: ExPentagon Researcher Says the Army Waged Mock Attack on Nixon
description: LOS ANGELES (AP)Army experts using mockkiller chemicals carried out a successful simulated assassination of President Nixon and the Congress in 1969 and 1970, a former researcher contends.

title: JOSEPH F. HOBBINS
description: Joseph F. Hobbins, retired advertising manager of the Anaconda Company, died Wednesday at his home in Rahway, N.J. He was 70 years old. He was a graduate of the University of Wisconsin and was associated with the copper producing company for 42 years, retiring in 1971. He leaves his wife, the former Georgeanna Boynton.

title: Bean Is in Lead By Shot; Allin Is in Groove
description: MIAMI, March 10  When Brian (Buddy) Allin won the DoralEastern open here in 1974,he was known as a hero of the war in Vietnam, a former artillery officer who had been decorated four times. All that is far behind him now, and so, for that matter, is the 1974 victory. What Allin is trying to do now is recover the swing he had then.

title: Music: Harpsichord and Friends
description: Two new works were given premieres at Carnegie Recital Hall Wednesday night, in the third and final concert of Eugenia Earle's Compleat Harpsichord series.

title: Red Smith
description: A kind man named Robert, D. Opie of San Jose, Calif., has raised holy hell with the working schedule around here. He is publisher of a collection called Great World Series Programs, which are just what the title suggests, exact reproductions of programs for old World Series with the addition of a few pages in the back describing the highlights of the games. Since the mailman delivered free samples from the collection, it has been next to impossible to leave off reading and get to the typewriter. For any baseball fan who has dipped into the history of the game, the batting orders alone are fascinating, for Sports reading them is like sitting in as a witness to eternally memorable eventsFred Snodgrass's $30,000 muff in 1912, the crooked Series of 1919 and the Yankees sweep in 1927.

title: At the Movies
description: WHEN PANDRO S. BERMAN turns 72 on March 28, he'll find an Oscar among his birthday presents, the honorary Irving Thalberg Memorial award, which is reserved for creative producers whose body of work reflects a consistently high quality of motion picture production. Mr. Berman, whose highquality body of work includes such treasures as The Gay Divorcee, Of Human Bondage, Alice Adams, Top Hat, Stage Door, Gunga Din, National Velvet and Father of the Bride, is appreciative of this tribute from his peers, but he has no intention of returning to the industry he abandoned seven years ago.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Tokyo Hints at Rights Rift With U.S.
description: TOKYO, March 10Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda, preparing for his departure next week for a meeting in Washington with President Carter, indicated today that there were differences between the two leaders over foreign policy and the auestion of human rights.

title: What's Doing on Mulberry Street
description: Mulberry Street is a street of restaurants and cafes, and so are the smaller streets that run off it. Its establishments are open early and stay open late. All of the restaurants are open Saturday and Sunday, as are the specialty and food shops. Following is a partial listing:

title: Israel Cup Soccer Victor
description: TEL AVIV. March 10 (UPI)Israel beat Japand, 20. today in the second game of the opening round of World Soccer Cup competition. Oded Mahnes and Vicky Peres scored for the Israelis. who beat Japan by an identical score in their first game Sunday.

title: City Opera: Belle Helene
description: An operetta by Offenbach is, by this listener's definition, a work that is as broad as it is long. And La Belle Hlne, which the New York City Opera has been presenting this season in a particularly broad English version, seemed appropriately long on Wednesday night in the season's third performance. The humor, what there was of it, fell flat, and the singing, what there was of it, did little to redeem a dreary evening.

title: Hamaas Khaalis: Four  Year Grudge
description: Continued From Page A1 by plainclothes and uniformed policemen, the Moslems inside held news conferences and were free to enter and leave They prepared special food for some of the armed captors.

title: Sindona Asks Time In Extradition Fight
description: Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, who is now living at the Pierre Hotel and fighting extradition to Italy to face banklooting charges, asked Judge Thomas P. Griesa of the Federal District Court in New York yesterday for 30 days to file new court papers.

title: UMass Eliminates Seton Hall From N.I.T. in Thriller, 8685
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass.,March 10Seton Hall, a ninetime performer in the National Invitation Tournament, bowed out of the 1977 version tonight, losing to the University of Massachusetts in a finalsecond thriller, 8685.

title: Spring Guide to Boulevard of Pasta
description: Little Italy, Benvenuti, reads the tinseled bunting strung over Mulberry Street at Kenmare Street and these weekend nights, as the weather gives indications that it at last intends to become milder, more lights go on, people come out into the streets, and the sign is again a universal welcome.

title: Stephen L. Freeland, 66, Former Associate Editor Of U.S. News & World
description: WASHINGTON,March 10 (AP)Stephen L. Freeland, a former associate editor with U.S. News & World Report magazine, died today at the age of 66.

title: Medtronic Discloses Payments Overseas
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 10 (UPI)Medtronic Inc. made improper or questionable payments totaling $332,000 to encourage business in foreign countries between May 1973 and February 1977, the manufacturer of pacemakers disclosed today.

title: New York Switches Attention to Deficit In Coming Budget
description: With New York City's shortterm debt problem apparently behind them, the city's fiscal officials turned their attention yesterday to New York's other outstanding quagmirehow to assemble the elements needed to close a budget deficit in the coming fiscal year, now estimated by Mayor Beame at between $585 and $725 million.

title: Fordham Five Advances In A.I.A.W. Semifinal
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., March 10  Towson State, Fordham, Syracuse and Kean College advanced tonight to the semifinals of the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women invitation basketball tournament at Manhattanville College.

title: About Real Estate
description: Before many weeks are out, the city will he in the position of conducting an environmental review whenever a discretionary zoning action is deemed to have a significant effect on the environment.

title: Stage at La Mama Gets Uptown Look
description: Songs at Twilight, which began performances last night at La Mama E.T.C., Ellen Stewart's prolific Off Off Broadway theater, is not the usual La Mama fare. Witness the credentials of the production's chief creators: The author is Maureen Howard, a highly praised extremely talented novelist (her most recent novel, Before My Time, received excellent reviews in 1975). The director is Michael Montel, who has staged plays for the Phoenix Theater on Broadway and off, a man who up to now might have seemed more at home in Sardi's than in Phebe's on East Fourth Street.

title: D. R. LUNTS DIES IN MOSCOW; FOUND DISSIDENTS INSANE
description: MOSCOW,March 10 (Reuters)Daniil R. Lunts, a psychiatrist at the Serbsky Institute of Forensic Psychiatry, died last week after a serious illness, the newspaper Vechernyaya Moskva reported.

title: Management
description: Top managers of American companies come in all sizes, shapes and visages and probably most like to consider themselves individualists. In a book called The Gamesman, Michael Maccoby, director of Harvard University's project on technology, work and character, has sorted them into four basic psychological typesthe jungle fighter, the craftsman, the company man and the gamesman.

title: Advertising
description: James Thompson Shaw is vice president in charge of sales of the ABC Television Network, which was been No. 1 in prime time ratings since October.

title: British Bank Rate Cut
description: LONDON, March 10The Bank of England reacted today to the interest rates falling all around it and lowered its own minimum lending rate by 1 point to 11 percent.

title: Girl Scouts Quit Over E.R.A.
description: CHELSEA, Mich., March 10(AP)Girl Scout Troop 47 has resigned from the Girl Scouts of America because the national organization's board endorsed the equal rights amendment. Members of the troop in this southeastern Michigan community charge that the national board is using 3,160,000 scouts as political pawns in its push for the amendment.

title: Draft of Paper Lists Provisions
description: JOHANNESBURG, Friday. March 11A draft South African white paper outlining a proposed newspaper bill is understood to provide for heavy fines and prison sentences for any reporter who contravenes the Government's press code, which, among other things, would make it an offense to report on events in a manner that brings South Africa into disrepute abroad.

title: Tiffany Diamonds Sparkle In a Salesman's Memory
description: Once, when Edmund H. Schram, for 45 years one of Tiffany & Company's top diamond salesmen, was showing his glittering wares, a customer asked if she could take a $19,000 diamond and see it in the light. He agreed. She went to the door and disappeared up Fifth.

title: Disease Center Deaths Laid To Rocky Mountain Fever
description: ATLANTA, March 10(UPI) Rocky Mountain spotted fever was identified today as the disease that killed two employees of the national Center for Disease control so quickly that normally effective antibiotics were useless.

title: Boeing to Participate In Peabody Coal Deal
description: The Boeing Company announced that it would take a 15 percent participation in the Peabody Holding Company, recently formed to take over the Peabody Coal Company, the world's largest coal mining property. Peabody Holding will acquire the stock of Peabody Coal from the Kennecott Copper Corporation, which had been ordered to divest the property by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: U.S.Canada
description: In the following record or observations yesterday at weather stations in the United States, high And low temPeratures given are for the 20hour ??? ended at 8 P.M. Precipitation tofals give are for the 24hour period, ended at a P.M. Weather descriptions, are forecaated conditions for today.(Ail times are in Eastern Standard Time.)

title: Mohammad Director Says Film Is Meant to Inform NonMoslems
description: The producerdirector of Mohammad, Messenger of God, said yesterday that he set out to create a film to bridge the gap of misunderstanding among nonMoslems about Islam. Instead, the movie has become linked with strife.

title: RawSugar Prices Show Only a Small Response; World's Surplus Is Cited
description: World prices of raw sugar, the most hardly responded yesterday to the actions taken by Ottawa and Washington to ban saccharin.

title: Sale of House Halted
description: The New York City Board of Estimate unanimously approved a resolution that would prohibit the threatened public auction of the house of an elderly Queens Village woman, Catherine Kelley. The house, at 22221 100th Avenue, had been put up for sale by the Department of Real Estate because the property taxes had not been paid, according to Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens.

title: The Pop Life
description: ROCKANDROLL is full of wild men, people who play on our voyeurism by toying with the limits of the possible or the permissible. Sometimes they're obviously playactors, as Alice Cooper used to be and Kiss is now. But sometimes they really are right at the brink, exposing their inner selves in a way that can be genuinely frightening: Janis Joplin, Jim Morrison, Joe Cocker, Lou Reed and Patti Smith.

title: Wildcat Strike at Sun Ship Company
description: CHESTER, Pa., March 10(AP)  Work at the Sun Ship Building and Dry Dock Company was disrupted today by a wildcat strike by Boilermakers Local 802. Ernest Wilson, president of Local 802, said that the wildcat action had been taken because Sun Ship refused to assign a signalman to a scaffolding that was supporting workers 30 feet off the ground. Company officials called the strike an illegal work stoppage.

title: LIFE SENTENCE GIVEN IN STABBING MURDER
description: An 18yearold youth convicted of stabbing 30yearold J. Karen Singer to death last September in Central Park was sentenced to life imprisonment yesterday by Justice Alvin Klein in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Carter and South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 4How to support a nation that genuinely fears an attack from across its border without bolstering its Government, which uses the outside threat to enforce repressive domestic policies, is President Carter's problem in South Korea,

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: THE SAFEST COMMENT to make about any Manhattan neighborhood is that it is a community in transition. Neighborhoods are constantly changing, and this applies with particular pertinence to Chelsea, the Lower West Side area that has a growing middle class moving into the handsome Greek revival homes that make its side streets such a peaceful delight. Chelsea also has poorer workingclass people and still fulfills its role as a home for artists.

title: 2 Jersey Brothers Are Indicted In $8 Million Insurance Fraud
description: TRENTON, March 10Two New Jersey brothers whose empire of insurance firms collapsed in bankruptcy in 1975 were charged today with stealing more than $8 million in insurance premiums in what was called the largest fraud case ever brought in the state.

title: Management
description: Top executives of American companies can be classified into four basic psychological types, according to The Gamesman by Michael Maccoby, head of a Harvard project. Page D5.

title: East Side Project Aided
description: A neighborhood drive on the Upper East Side to convert an unused municipal asphalt plant into a community sportsandarts center has received an important new corporate donation. The Exxon Corporation announced that it was giving $30,000 to the Neighborhood Committee for the Asphalt Green, which is renovating the landmark structure at 90th Street and the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive for use as a community center.

title: Record Earnings for Tiffany's 140th Year
description: Tiffany & Co., famous for its fine jewelry, silverware and other specialty merchandise, celebrated its 140th birthday last year by setting sales and earnings records for both the final quarter and the full year.

title: Log Exports at Record on Coast
description: PORTLAND, Ind., March 10 (AP)The United States Forest Service's Northwest Forest and Range Experiment Station says West Coast softwood log exports last year set an alltime record of 2.9 billion board feet. David Darr, a research expert, said that the 1976 volumn was up 19.5 percent from the previous year.

title: An Irish Stringfest With Everything But Harps
description: Irish Music with a Balkan beat? Gaelic tunes on the bouzouki? It's all part of the ethnic melting pot stirred by two modern troubadors who will be ringing in Saint Patrick's Day a bit early, tonight at Town Ball.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 11, 1977

title: Terrorists and the Press
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The latest outrage in the news here demonstrates that the political terrorists have figured out how to use the newspapers, radio and television for their own purposes, and that we still haven't puzzled out how to handle them.

title: That Questionnaire ... an Unrequested Reply
description: Dear Mr. President:

title: Holy Trinity Is Victor Over Nazareth, 7963
description: Bob Testa scored 14 of his careerhigh 28 points in the second quarter last night to lead Holy Trinity of Hicksville to a 7963 victory over Nazareth of Brooklyn in a battle between the Long Island and New York City Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball champions at St. Francis Prep in Queens.

title: PHYSICIST SAYS OIL SPILLS HAVE BEEN TOO PROFITABLE
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 10A nationally known oceanographer said at an international oil spill conference here today that one of the best ways to prevent massive oil spills was to make the spills so unprofitable for the oil industry and insurers that proper controls would be made voluntarily.

title: 2.56 Million Shares Of I.B.M. Tendered
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that approximately 2.56 million shares of its common stock had been tendered before the termination on Wednesday of the company's offer to buy at least 4 million of its shares at $280 a share.

title: School Cuts Protested
description: Students at Pascack Valley High School in Hillsdale walked out of class for 40 minutes to protest the State Education Department's refusal to exempt a budget cut of $246,000 from the statemandated cap, or maximum spending level. About 1,600 students gathered on a grassy slope outside the school, which serves the Bergen County communities of River Vale and Hillsdale, as student leaders assailed the reduction in a $7.3 million budget that will force the dismissal of 12 fulltime teachers and the elimination of onethird of both the athletic and extracurricular programs in the Pascack Valley Regional High School District.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Rumanian Leader Doubts U.S. Data On Quake Danger
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 10President Nicolae Ceausescu today described an American warning that Rumania may suffer another large earthquake within weeks or months as not very well founded.

title: Bridge:
description: One might suppose that the only way to emerge with a financial profit from a losing bridge match would be to bet, quite improperly, on the opposing team.

title: 3 Murders of Women Since July 29 Believed Actions of Same Gunman
description: Mayor Beame and Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd, in a joint appeal to the public for help, disclosed yesterday that the police were seeking the same man in the senseless killings of three women since July 29, including two recently in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Classic Stage Co. Rethinks Repertory
description: If the Classic Stage Company, the repertory group whose base is the Abbey Theater at 136 East 13th Street, were a business, an abstract of progress in the 10 years of its existence would warm the heart of every bank lending officer in the city. In these years the number of productions has risen from four in the 196768 season to nine in 197576; performances from 48 to 266: subscribers from 300 to 4,993, and attendance from 1,200 roughly to 34,913.

title: Canadiens 7, Rockies 1
description: MONTREAL, March 10(AP)  Guy Lafleur assisted on four goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens posted a 71 victory over the Colorado Rockies. The 4 points raised Lafleur's N.H.L.leading total to 116 points.

title: Clifford Sees Chance Of Cyprus Pact in 77
description: WASHINGTON, March 10(UPI)Clark M. Clifford, President Carter's special envoy to Cyprus, told Congress today that a negotiated settlement of the island's dispute was possible this year.

title: South African Newspapers Facing Tough Penalties
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 10(AP)The South African press faced the prospect today of tough controls after the breakdown of talks between the Government and the major newspaper owners.

title: 19Gun Salute was Canceled in Tense Capital
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The 75millimeter howitzers that usually fire 19 times to welcome visiting heads of government were missing from the sunny Elipse of the White House when British Prime Minister James Callaghan arrived today, so fearful were officials that gunfire might shatter the fragile peace at siege sites only blocks away.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article Wednesday on a malpractice suit against the schools in Copiague, L.I., The Times incorrectly identified a lawyer who informally advised the school counsel. His correct name is Max Margules.

title: Abroad
description: Local Time Temp. Condition

title: Corporation Affairs
description: De Dietrich (USA) Inc., announced yesterday that is was building a complete manufacturing facility at Union, N. J., that will enable it to build glasslined pipes and fittings. The plant will include a huge reglassing oven that will require 2,200 kilowatts of electricity for its heat source.

title: CAR OUTPUT IS SCHEDULED TO RISE BY 1.3% THIS WEEK
description: DETROIT, March 10The United States auto industry is scheduled to build 207,893 cars this week, up 1.3 percent from 205.208 last week and 12.1 percent ahead of the 185,468 cars produced in the 1976 week, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

title: MOSLEMS STILL HOLD 100 HOSTAGES AS NEGOTIATIONS IN CAPITAL GO ON; POLICE HOPE TO WAIT OUT GUNMEN
description: WASHINGTON, March 10A meeting tonight between three Moslem ambassadors, a high official of the Justice Department, the Washington police chief and the leaders of the Hanafi Moslem sect, whose gunmen have held more than 100 hostages here since yesterday, raised hopes that talks to gain the captives release were finally progressing.

title: Soviet Envoy Assails West Over Dissidents And Berlin Situation
description: WEST BERLIN, March 10The Soviet Ambassador to East Germany suggested today that President Carter's support for dissidents and human rights activists in the Communist bloc was designed to torpedo an improvement of EastWest relations.

title: Basques Protesting Death of 2 Clash With the Police in Spain
description: SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain.March 10 (Reuters)Riot policemen fired rubber bullets today at Basque demonstrators here protesting the death of two aileged members of the Basque nationalist guerrilla group E.T.A. in a shootout with the police two days ago at a roadblock near this northern summer resort.

title: Art From the Alaskan Tundra
description: In a land of inhospitable tundra, where the polar bear stalks like a great white ghost and that prehistoric leftover, the tusked walrus, floats out to sea on paperthin slivers of ice, men also liveand document their lives with the work of their hands.

title: Women Comics Get the Last Laugh
description: It was so easy for Carole Lombard to be funny. She could afford to mug and make fun, to twist her mouth into incredible lipsticked lines and stick out her tongue at leading men. She was a comedienne, yes; but she had blue eyes and blond hair, a perfect figure and Clark Gabic.

title: A Republican Care Package
description: There is no new Republican Party, no old Republican Party. There is only the same Republican Party which for half a century has opposed every major piece of social legislation. The speaker was John Kennedy and the time was the 1960 campaign, but it could have been any number of Democrats speaking at almost any time since the New Deal. Republican obstructionism on social welfare has been a stock target in Democratic shooting galleries for a generation.

title: People in Business
description: Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, yesterday urged the Senate to adopt a 12 percent investment tax credit, thus adding his voice to those of a growing number of business leaders who advocate increasing the credit from its present level of 10 percent.

title: Reports of Area Skiing Conditions
description: (Reports supplied oy resort owners.)

title: Cost of Completing the Interstate System Now 3 Times Estimate and May Go Higher
description: WASHINGTON, March 10(AP)The estimated $100 billion cost of completing the lagging interstate highway system is nearly three times above the original projection and could go higher, the Federal Highway Administration says.

title: F. P. C. Lawyers Say Reprisals Resulted From Gas Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)Federal Power Commission lawyers who were vocal in their criticism of gas producers were given transfers or made to feel unwelcome by superiors, a number of former senior F.P.C. natural gas attorneys said today.

title: Kickback Indictments Name 16 NursingHome Aides
description: Two operators of a Franklin Square, L.I., nursing home have been indicted on a charge of taking $335,000 in kickbacks from their suppliers over the last six years, New York State's special prosecutor for nursing homes said yesterday.

title: Bell and Marshall Reject Appeal To Testify on Pension Reforms
description: The first clash between the Carter Administration and Congress over the right of Cabinet officers to refuse to testify at legislative inquiries has arisen in connection with the scandalscarred Central States pension fund of the Inter national Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: New York Tightens Security
description: ALBANY, March 10(AP)Three men serving life terms for the assassination of Malcolm X were placed under special security in the New York State prison system today after the gunmen holding hostages in Washington demanded that the convicts be turned over to them.

title: Senate Backs Federal Raise Curb
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)  The Senate today quickly approved. 93 to 1, a bill to bar Congressmen, judges and other top Government officials who received recent pay raises of up to 29 percent from getting a scheduled costofliving increase in October. The only vote against passage was cast by Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska.

title: CHAVEZ SIGNS ACCORD WITH THE TEAMSTERS
description: Continued From Page A1 and M. E. Anderson, director of the Western Conference of Teamsters.

title: New Yorkers Take to the Streets and Parks: Who Says It Isn't Even Spring?
description: The New York City Sanitation Department puts the official date for the end of winter in the middle of April, when the snowplows are put on summer leave. The Hayden Planetarium pronounces the vernal equinox this year on March 20 at exactly 12:43 P.M. The National Weather Service says only that these last two days have been unseasonably warm.

title: 0.9% Wholesale Price Rise In February Is Laid to Cold
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Wholesale prices, which often foreshadow prices at the retail level, rose by 0.9 percent in February, the biggest jump in 16 months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Soviet Rebukes Western Reds
description: MOSCOW, March 10(Reuters)A Soviet commentator today complained that Western Communist parties had swallowed antiSoviet bait by coming out in support of Soviet dissidents.

title: Hatcher Scores Call to Abductor
description: GARY, Ind., March 10 (UPI)Mayo? Richard G. Hatcher said today that President Carter's phone call to an Ohio abductor was courageous but a mistake. Very courageous. It showed compassion, Hatcher said of Mr. Carter's call to Cory C. Moore, a black, who had held a white policeman hostage for 45 hours. But I still think he was wrong to do it. It sets a bad precedent, said Mr. Hatcher, one of the nation's first big city black mayors.

title: Security Tightened for Prisoners Sought in Exchange for Hostages
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 10(UPI)Three of the Philadelphia men wanted by the Hanafi Moslems holding the hostages in Washington are in prisons in Pennsylvania and another is in a New Jersey jail. All are under extra security precautions.

title: Chavez and Teamsters Sign Accord
description: BURLINGAME, Calif., March 10The teamsters union and the United Farm Workers signed here today an agreement that leaders of both unions said would end the decadelong strife over organizing agricultural workers in the West.

title: Gandhi Foes Hear Of Moves by Police As Election Nears
description: NEW DELHI, March 10The opposition Janata Party charged today that with the parliamentary elections only a week away, there had been reports of largescale movement of armed police to district headquarters all over India.

title: OIL REFINERS IN ONTARIO ASK EXPORT RISE TO U.S.
description: TORONTO, March 10(AP)Some oil refiners in Ontario are seeking increased exports of gasoline and fuel oil to the United States to reduce unusually large stores, industry spokesmen say.

title: News on Hostages Is Provided
description: WASHINGTON, March 10(AP)  District of Columbia police officials provided a telephone number today that persons could call to find out information about relatives and friends being held hostage in B nai B'rith headquarters here. The number is 2023479550. Callers should ask for extensions 802, 804, 810 or 811. the police said.

title: Letter & Reply
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Brandenburg Gate
description: From the Brandenburg Gate (Page C5) and the Alaskan Tundra (page C24) To Matisse's Pool (Page C20) and Lewis Hine's Haunting Faces (Page C19)

title: Chavez and Teamsters Sign Accord
description: BURLINGAME, Calif., March 10The teamsters union and the United Farm Workers signed here today an agreement that leaders of both unions said would end the decadelong strife over organizing agricultural workers in the West.

title: Blumenthal Says New York City Has Not Solved Its Basic Problems
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said in an interview today that although New York City now has enough money in the till for the next few months, it has not solved any of its fundamental problems..

title: Upsala Honors Students
description: Four Upsala College students and one graduate of the school were honored for rescuing tenants from a burning apartment building in Newark last month.

title: Some New Designs That Beg to Differ With Sameness of Style
description: Six hitherto unknown designers will be spotlighted by Bonwit Teller next week. Each produces highly individual clothes, some of which are oneofakind.

title: JEWISH WOMEN'S COUNCIL GIVES AWARD TO MONDALE
description: The National Council of Jewish Women presented Vice President Mondale with its John F. Kennedy Award for public service last night at the council's 32d national convention at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Her Hats Turn Heads at IRT Token Booth
description: Catherine Williams sells subway tokens in the IRTLexington Avenue 77th Street station, downtown side, and the remarkable thing is the hats she wears while selling them.

title: Antiques
description: SECTIONS of the glorious stained glass windows of Britain's Canterbury Cathedral went on view at Steuben Glass this week. The windows were conceived shortly after St. Thomas  Bucket was murdered there in the 12th century, and installed by the time Chaucer wrote about pilgrimages to the Gothic landmark in the 14th century. Some of these dazzling glass pictures were damaged when Oliver Cromwell attacked his foes in this, the seat of the Anglican church. But none were harmed when Hilter bombed it.

title: Gerald Ehrlich, 59, Dies; Coached Columbia Tennis, Ran Bronx Club
description: Gerald (Jerry) Ehrlich, the first fulltime tennis coach at Columbia University and a ranking Eastern amateur tennis player in the 1930's, died yesterday at his Closter, N.J., home after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE MIND, which is disinclined to focus under the best of circumstances, meandered everywhere while trying to put itself to Erica Jong's How to Save Your Own Life, which is the sequelI almost wrote sexualto her first novel, Fear of Flying. The mind wandered to next month's gas bill, to the future of the Equal Rights Amendment and to some of the momentous events of world literaturethe battle of Borodino, the seduction of Leopold Bloom by Gerty MacDowell, the progress of Huck Finn on a raft down the Mississippithat have unfolded in so many fewer pages than it takes Mrs. Jong's heroine, Isadora Wing, to progress from A to B in her emotional development.

title: Former Italian Defense Chiefs To Stand Trial in Lockheed Case
description: ROME, March 10The Italian Parliament voted tonight to lift the immunity of two former defense ministers and send them to trial on charges involving bribes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Schoolboy Stars Bring Cheer to Paralyzed Patients
description: In 1967. Herb Larkin was an allcity basketball player at Richmond Hill in Queens. The other night Larkin was visited by some allcity players of 1977 at Goldwater Hospital on Roosevelt Island. Larkin is confined to a wheelchair, paralyzed nine years ago by an injury suffered while playing basketball.

title: Weekend Gardening: Currants
description: FOR THE MOST part, writers nowadays are notoriously poor correspondents. Also for the most part, gardening writers are no exception to the rule. And I am certainly not. The stack of correspondence addressed to this column mounts ever higher. And if my accompanying feelings of guilt have not yet reached the critical mass for a number of reasons  including the sometimes undecipherable return addresses and the fact that if I kept up with all my correspondence I could not keep up with all my writing  I am slowly whittling away at the pile.

title: Saccharin Ban Causes Storm Of Complaints
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Food and Drug Administration, which yesterday proposed the banning of the artificial sweetener saccharin, today was bombarded with complaints from persons demanding that the chemical be allowed to remain on the market.

title: Money Supply Falls Slightly
description: The two main measurements of the nation's money supply showed a slight decline during the week ended March 2, the Federal Reserve Bank announced yesterday. Page D2.

title: Stenmark's Fast First Run Leads to Slalom Victory
description: HEAVENLY VALLEY, Calif., March 10 (AP)Ingemar Stenmark beat the field by more than half a second on the first run today and coasted to victory in an International Ski Federation men's slalom

title: Excerpts From Khaalis Interviews
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Following are excerpts from three interviews today and last night with Hamaas Abdul Khaalis. leader of the Hanafi Moslems who held hostages in three Washington buildings. The interviews were conducted by Harold Steele of radio station WMAL, as reported by Reuters; Phil Walters of WBBMTV in Chicago. a station owned by CBS. and Robert A. Dobkin of The Associated Press:

title: MOSES KOTTLER
description: JOHANNESBURG,March 10 (AP)Moses Kottler, one of South Africa's leading sculptors, died Tuesday. He was 82 years old.

title: I.B.M. and SugarRelated Issues Lead a Rally, Lifting Dow 3.83
description: The stock market shook off its latest case of inflation jitters yesterday and produced a late rally led by International Business Machines and sugarrelated issues. The glamour sector also recovered from its slump on Wednesday.

title: SARAH S. JESUP, 41, DIES; AIDE TO FRESH AIR FUND
description: Sarah Stifler Jesup, director of development and alumni affairs at the Collegiate School in Manhattan and the centennial fundraising consultant to the Fresh Air Fund, died yesterday of cancer at the Memorial SloanKettering Hospital. She was 41 years old and lived at 170 East 83d Street.

title: Earlier Clashes Reported
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 10The announcement by Zaire today of an invasion came after recurring reports over the last two weeks of renewed fighting in northern Angola involving National Front troops.

title: MOSLEMS RELEASE ALL HOSTAGES HELD AT THREE SITES IN CAPITAL; 2 DAYS OF TERROR END PEACEABLY
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, March 11More than 100 hostages held for nearly two days by a handful of armed Hanafi Moslem gunmen were released early today and sent to hospitals after three Islamic Ambassadors joined in negotiations to gain their freedom.

title: Rutgers, Seton Hall Lose
description: Rutgers and Seton Hall, the only metropolitan area teams invited to the National Invitation Tournament, were beaten in firstround games last night. Rutgers lost to St. Bonaventure, 7977, at Princeton, N. .j., and Seton Hall bowed to the University of Massachusetts, 8885,in Springfield, Mass. Details on Page A20.

title: Dollar Finishes Mixed During Gold's Recovery As Franc Loses Ground
description: LONDON, March 10(AP)The dollar lost ground against Europe's strong currencies today but gained on two weak ones. Gold recovered after a twoday slide.

title: Sect Leader's InLaw Praying for Safety
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 10(Ap)The fatherinlaw of the leader of a Moslem sect holding more than 100 hostages in Washington said today that he was praying for the safety of all concerned, but warned that anyone who holds someone hostage with a gun, they will kill.

title: MitchellLama Projects Eligible For Mortgage Sales Made Public
description: The city made public yesterday a list of the 114 MitchellLama apartment developments that are potentially eligible for the mortgagesale program under which New York City hopes to realize $410 million of the nearly $1 billion it currently needs to pay its shortterm debt.

title: Market Place
description: The hospital management company stocks were regarded as undervalued by some Wall Street analysts even before the slump that occurred after the Carter Administration indicated it would propose legislation to limit annual increases in hospital charges.

title: ExMinister Indicted
description: A defrocked minister was indicted on charges of embezzling $66,000 from a Caldwell church, from elderly women and from two phony trust funds. An Essex County grand jury charged that David O. Roberts, 48 years old, former pastor of the Presbyterian Church of West Caldwell, had borrowed $22,000 from a bank in the name of the church and defaulted on the loans.

title: Reserve Report
description: In Billions DAILY AVERAGES

title: Bail of $250,000 Is Set For Boyle Pending Retrial
description: MEDIA, Pa., March 10(AP)  A judge set bail of $250,000 today for W. A. Boyle, former United Mine Workers president, whose conviction for ordering the murder of a union rival has been overturned.

title: Utah Skiers Called Spoiled By Quick Access to Slopes
description: SNOWBIRD, Utah. March 10Utah's skiers are the most spoiled skiers in the world, said Randy Montgomery. the marketing director of the high altitude Snowbird ski area today. Some of the best skiing to be found on earth is right at their back door. Montgomery said that Utah's skiers have it made. He emphasized that six fine snow running centers were within a 40minute drive of downtown Salt Lake City. He said the quality of snow found at these resorts almost always was superior.

title: KingmanMets Gap Hardens; He Wants More Than Seaver
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.,March 10Dave Kingman accused the New York Mets today of living in the Dark Ages on money matters, reported that he was still insisting on a bonus and said that he wanted a sixyear contract for considerably more than Tom Seaver's pay of $225,000 a season.

title: Arpels Pleads Guilty
description: Claude Arpels, the president of VanCleef & Arpels, pleaded guilty to charges that he gave gifts to an Internal Revenue Service agent who was auditing his personal and business tax returns. Mr. Arpels admitted giving the agent two wristwatches, an emerald ring and a diamond brooch worth a total of almost $1,400. He will be sentenced April 20 in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The store's controller, Al I. Schwartz, pleaded guilty earlier and was fined $2,500. A spokesman for the store said that the case involved Government agents who were extracting gifts from the store and other taxpayers.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT DETROIT

title: Restaurants
description: GINNOKI, subtitled The Silver Tree, is a restaurant that probably could happen only New York. One partner, Stephen Horn is an American and a lawyer who thought it would be nice to own a restaurant. He knew lkuo Kamata, a Japanese chef with the same ambition, so they joined forces. But because they felt there were so many Japanese restaurants in the city already. they decided it would be a good idea to throw in a few French dishes for a novel touch.

title: Colombia Coffee Exports Up 120% in First 2 Months of 77
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, March 19 (Reuters) Colombia's coffee exports for the first two months of this year brought in $294 million, an increase of 120 percent, compared with the comparable period last year, the foreign trade institute Incomex said today.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 11, 1977

title: Low Voter Turnout In Pakistan Election
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 10(Reuters)  Pakistan's provincial elections were marked by a low turnout of voters today because of a boycott by the opposition coalition.

title: Missing L.I. Girl Is Found Slain; ExTenant in Her Home Arrested
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 10The body of 10yearold Lisamarie Merritt was found early this morning under a mound of leaves in a wooded area near the Montauk Lighthouse at the eastern tip of Long Island.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Cerebral Palsy Group Will Run Part of the Willowbrook Facility
description: United Cerebral Palsy of New York will take over the management of a fifth of the Willowbrook Developmental Center for the mentally retarded on Staten Island, under an agreement signed yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Company Profits Up 21% in Quarter
description: Fourthquarter corporate profits rose 21 percent over the 1975 final three months and managed to gain 5 percent over the third quarter of last year despite the lull in the nation's economic recovery, according toa Citibank survey released yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DEBT PLAN WINS QUICK APPROVAL FROM CONTROL BOARD
description: After a quick debate punctuated by expressions of relief, the State Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday unanimously approved New York City's plan to pay off its $983 million shortterm debt, an action that officials said removed the threat of insolvency that had hung over the city for four months.

title: Use of Sweetener Is Not Confined to Diet Products
description: Just because you are not on a slimming or medical, diet doesn't mean you need have no interest in the coming ban on saccharin. You and your children may be using toothpaste or mouthwash that contains saccharin.

title: Tip on a Computer Jockey
description: Such triumphs of game theory as the Edsel car and the war in Vietnam have, over the years, encouraged a degree of skepticism about mathematical systems of policy making and social analysis. But the systems themselves are couched in such arcane language (if language is liberally construed) that outsiders are limited to observing that they just seem to come up with the wrong answers. This can be explained by saying that the wrong figures have been fed into the computers: Garbage in, garbage out.

title: Irvine Offer Extended
description: The Mobil Corporation announced yesterday that it had extended its offer of $33.50 a share, a total of $281.9 million, for shares of the Irvine Company, a land development company in California, until March 18, 1977. The offer was to have expired today.

title: Impact Slight at SherwinWilliams
description: CLEVELAND, March 10William P. Inman came to work today with a bitter taste in his mouth. Yesterday the Government proposed a ban on saccharin a product that generates for his employer, the SherwinWilliams Company, 4 percent of its earnings and 1 percent of its revenues annually.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Every year at this time, spring fever breaks out at the Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street. The annual Festival of Springa show of plants and flowers nurtured by professional gardenerstakes place today and tomorrow from noon to 7 P.M. There will be thousands of flowers (tulips, hyacinths, azaleas and more) and plants of all sizes and shapes. Experts will be on hand to answer questions about spring plantings, and you can consult with a specialist about a diseased palm or any other sickly plant. The society will also offer an assortment of house plants for sale. Information: 7570915. No admission charge, but contributions would be appreciated.

title: Food Store Strike Talks Halt
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 10(UPI)Talks between butchers and food store chains were halted early today with no progress reported in efforts to settle the strike that has closed 400 stores in the Philadelphia area. Talks broke off at 2 A.M. and a Federal mediator, Charles Deussing, reported no progress in the negotiations, said to center on wages and pensions.

title: British Prefer Not to Discuss Untidy Ailment
description: LONDON, March 10 Elevenyearold Eleanor Nabney was clawing at the back of her neck one evening, so her mother, Janet, looked and found little red dots and a rash. She took her to the local health office, where the doctor prescribed cortisone ointment to relieve the rash. The itching continued, however, and now, more worried, Mrs. Nabney went to a skin specialist.

title: Moslems Release Hostages; 2 Days of Terror End
description: Continued From Page A1 pal negotiator in two days of telephoned communication with the gunmen, they spent three hours last night talking to the terrorist leaders with Ambassadors Sahabcada YaqubKhan of Pakistan, Ardeshir Zahedi of Iran and Ashnaf Ghorbal of Egypt.

title: Art: Lewis W Hine Retrospective
description: SOMETIMES the timing of an exhibition is almost as important as its content. Certain beliefsabout the function of art, and its relation to human experiencetake hold, and acquire a compelling orthodoxy. Certain tastessay, for something a little precious, a little kinky, even a little degeneratebecome inflated and chic. As a result, we are temporarily blind or indifferent to the direct human response that the art in question may once have embraced. Then a show comes along that recalls us to this lost purpose with such honesty and power that we suddenly feel restored to the real world.

title: Stage: Harrowed by Monsters
description: WHAT IS A MONSTER, and why does the world treat it that way? This is the moral basis of a couple of grimly fascinating playlets, called simply Monsters, which arrived at the Astor Place Theater last night.

title: Plantation Ablaze in Liberia
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, March 10(Reuters)Fire that broke out yesterday on Liberia's huge Firestone rubber plantation has destroyed several villages and thousands of trees, and latest reports say it is still spreading. The Americanowned company has appealed to the Liberian Government for assistance in bringing the under control.

title: Blue Law on Sunday Retail Sales Is Struck Down
description: HACKENSACK, March 10A 1959 law that prohibits the sale of five categories of retail goods in 10 of the state's 21 counties on Sundays was struck down today in Superior Court here.

title: Slight Decline Reported in Money Supply in Week
description: The New York Federal Reserve Bank yesterday announced a slight fall in the two main measurements of the nation's money supply during the week ended March 2.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Of all the unsettled legacies of the war in Vietnam, perhaps none is so emotional and divisive as the issue of amnesty for those who evaded the draft or deserted from the armed services in that protracted conflict.

title: Young Legislator Still Enthusiastic
description: ALBANY, March 9Clifford E. Wilson, freshman legislator and quondam Candide from Queens, has survived his first two months in the Assembly with his enthusiasm intact.

title: Eager Blomberg Puts Shoulder to the Wheel
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 10 Adam Lance Blomberg weighs about 19 pounds more than a baseball, and his father has not dropped him even once in four months. Perhaps there is hone yet for Ron Blomberg's hands.

title: New Mutuel Chief Vows Crackdown on Chicanery
description: With a strong challenge to Aqueduct's ticketsellers to mend their ways, James Heffernan took over the New York Racing Association's parimutuel operation yesterday.

title: Insurance Company Bars Liability in Nixon Lawsuits
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The insurance company from which Richard M. Nixon bought various insurance policies in his Presidency has just informed Mr. Nixon that these policies do not cover the damage awards that he may be ordered to pay in a wiretapping case and in several other pending lawsuits.

title: JOSEPH Y. KIYONAGA, 59; EXSOLDIER, C.I.A. AGENT
description: Joseph Yoshio Kiyonaga, who had served with the Central Intelligence Agency as chief of station in El Salvador, Panama and Brazil, died Tuesday at MemorialSloan Kettering Cancer Center. He was 59 years old.

title: Alabama 80, Memphis State 63
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 10 (AP) Reginald King popped in 26 points as Alabama turned a close game into a rout, defeating Memphis State, 8063, tonight in a firstround N.I.T. game.

title: Output Is Ending for Some Goods; Saccharin Substitutes to Be Used
description: The effects of the decision to ban saccharin began filtering through the economy yesterday with some products being pulled from production. But major users said they had substitute sweeteners for their low and nocalorie products that would lessen any economic effects.

title: Workers Strike Over Hot Meals
description: ST. LOUIS, March 10(UPI)Production on three assembly lines at the General Motors plant was shut down today by a protest over the dismissal of 12 cafeteria workers. The move affected 4,000 employees. United Auto Workers Local 25 said the layoffs meant that assembly line workers would no longer be able to obtain a hot meal at work.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Concert: Paige Brook, Flutist, Inventive in Baroque Program
description: Paige Brook, the New York Philharmonic's assistant principal flutist since 1952, was the featured artist in an evening of Baroque music for flute and strings Wednesday at Tully Hall. The program included Telemann's Suite in A minor and two works by Bachthe Suite in B minor, and Cantata No. 209 (Non sa che sia dolore), in which solo flute and soprano are equally prominent.

title: Slaying Suspect Held
description: A Newark building superintendent was held without bail on charges of stabbing a college student to death a block from her home. The superintendent, John Reddin, 35 years old, appeared before Judge Martin Oliveres in Municipal Court, Newark, and was arraigned on murder charges in the death of Mildred Webb, 21, a neighbor. He was sent to the Essex County Jail to await a hearing.

title: Carter, in Warm Welcome to Callaghan, Affirms Special Ties to Britain
description: WASHINGTON, March 10President Carter began today an intensive examination of world economic problems with Prime Minister James Callaghan after giving him a cordial welcome that emphasized enduring ties between the United States and Britain.

title: Rutgers Is Ousted By Bonnies
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 10The last metropolitan entry in the National Invitation Tournament was eliminated tonight when Rutgers went down before St. Bonaventure in overtime, 7977.

title: No Harm Is Reported In Tests on Monkeys
description: ALBANY, March 10 (AP)A researcher commissioned by the Food and Drug Administration to determine whether saccharin poses a health hazard said today the paper he will present later this month will show that massive doses given to monkeys over a period of years proved harmless.

title: Alaska Pipeline Sabotage Held Impossible to Stop
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI)Congress was told today that there was no way the multibillion dollar transAlaska oil pipeline could be protected against sabotage.

title: Revere Agrees to Sell Aluminum Unit to Alcan
description: Revere Copper and Brass Inc. has agreed in principle with Alcan Aluminum Corporation, a subsidiary of Alcan Aluminum Ltd., to sell Revere's aluminum reduction plant in Scottsboro, Ala., for about $140 million. The price would include the assumption of about $113 million in industrial development bond obligations.

title: Soviet Is Said to Arrest Jew Seized at Embassy
description: MOSCOW, March 10(AP)Joseph Begun, a Jewish activist here who was seized by policemen last month while attempting to enter the American Embassy, is under arrest on a charge of vagrancy, Jewish sources reported today.

Sheppard 26 (Park), 6:33, 3, Boston, Sheppard 27 (O'Reilly, Doak), 8:04. 4, Rangers, Greschner 9 (Esposito, Vadnais),9:42. 5 Rangers, Hodge 17, (Esposito, Farrish), 12:11. 6, Boston, Forbes 8, (Marcotte), 14:27. 7, Boston, Cashman 12, (McNab, Haiward), 16:03. 8, Boston, Marcottee 19, (Milbury, Park), 18:05. title: A Starburst of Culture From Berlin
description: A vast cultural cornucopia reaching over the Atlantic from West Berlin will spill an unusually generous serving of the German city's artistic accomplishments into New York, starting tomorrow and lasting through April.

title: Philip Morris Pursues F.T.C. Sale Approval
description: Philip Morris Inc. has asked for a meeting with the Federal Trade Commission to discuss the proposed sale of its American Safety Razor subsidiary to the Bic Pen Corporation.

title: Florio to Announce Race
description: Representative James J. Florio will announce his candidacy for Governor Monday during a swing through the state, his campaign headquarters said. Mr. Florio, a secondterm Democratic Congressman from Camden, will make his initial announcement in the morning in Newark, and then repeat his campaign speech in Trenton at noon and in Camden around 2 P.M.

title: Rams Optimistic on Getting Namath
description: Jon Namath will know by Tuesday whether his distinguished career will end with the Los Angeles Rams, to whom he has tried to escape for two years.

title: Anyone Have a Pachydermostat?
description: The pachythermal energy of elephant dung has been tapped by the New York Botanical Garden to heat a greenhouse.

title: Carter's Stimulus Plan and Unemployment
description: The February jobs figures issued at the end of last week by the Labor Department in Washington raised some eyebrows and a number of questions in political and economic quarters around the country. The surprisingly favorable character of most of the data seemed almost too good to be true, Despite the fact that last month was the second successive one of unusually severe winter weather and serious deficiency in natural gas supplies for many businesses in the Eastern half of the nation, the impact on jobs did not appear to be so traumatic as most analysts had feared. In fact, there was a sharp improvement in the number of people obtaining jobs, a lengthening of the average workweek, an increase in factory overtime, a 21month low in the average duration of unemployment and only a slight rise in the national unemployment rate.

title: THREE INDICTED IN MURDER OF 2 MOTHERS IN BURGLARY
description: WHITE PLAINS,March 10A Westchester County grand jury today indicted William Profit, Samuel Ayala and James Walls Jr. in the murders last week of two Lewisboro mothers. Sheila Watson and Bonnie Minter, during a burglary in Mrs. Watson's home.

title: New Face
description: First time out on the New York stage, in a Joseph Papp production of Macbeth at Lincoln Center in 1974, Cecilia Hart played a witch. Dressed in rags, and wearing a wig all slimy with glycerine, plus latex warts on my face, she helped stir up a mess of trouble for the erstwhile Thane of Cawdor. Not a big part, to be sure, but good nasty fun.

title: Film Forum: New Town And Mad Boy of India
description: IN 1950 the Indian Government commissioned Le Corbusier, the great Swissborn French architect, to build from scratch a new capital city in the Punjab. For Le Corbusier, who died in 1965 at the age of 77, the commission was the unique opportunity to put into practice his theories of urban planning. Sixteen years later the new city of Chandigarh provided Alain Tanner, the Swiss film director, and particularly his collaborator, John Berger, the English critic and novelist, with material for what amounts to a meditation upon all social progess, government, the uses of tradition. and architecture.

title: Key Suspect Quits French Bank Case (By Way of Window)
description: PARIS, March 10The man accused of having planned the $8 million heist of the century last July at Nice escaped from a courthouse there this afternoon in an exploit as daring as that bank theft.

title: REPLAY OF TV TAPE LEADS TO GUILTY PLEA
description: A 51yearold Bronx defendant who was scheduled to go on trial pleaded guilty to manslaughter instead after watching a videotape replay of his confession.

title: Soviet Concern on Human Rights Criticism Subsides
description: MOSCOW, March 10Signs are emerging that the Kremlin feels it has weathered its recent confrontation will the Carter Administration over human rights.

title: Legislating Secrecy
description: President Carter would have destroyed at the outset any possibility of conducting the open Administration he has promised, had he not said at his news conference that he wanted to minimize the use of any criminal penalties for disclosure of information

title: Rhodesia Cabinet Shuffled; Security Post Created
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 10(Reuters)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith reshuffled his Cabinet today following the resignation of his Defense Minister and the creation of a new post to oversee the struggle against guerrillas.

title: Notes on People
description: Leonel Castillo, City Comptroller of Houston, will be named by President Carter to be Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the first Commissioner of HispanicAmerican descent. A Justice Department source confirmed in Washington yesterday that Mr. Castillo, a 38yearold MexicanAmerican, would oversee the Federal agency that deals with six million illegal aliens, twothirds of them Mexicans, in this country. Mr. Castillo, a native of Galveston, Tex., served with the Peace Corps in the Philippines for five years and was elected comptroller of Houston in 1971.

title: Ferguson Ejected in Ranger Loss
description: BOSTON, March 10John Ferguson's fiery temper contributed to the New York Rangers ruin tonight as they suffered their worst defensive collapse this season and were drubbed by the Bruins. 103, at Boston Garden.

title: Republicans Attack Carey's Budget
description: ALBANY, March 10With the debate over Governor Carey's budget still taking place mostly at staff meetings and closed party conferences, the State Senate's Republican majority today opened its first major public attack on the document.

title: Slaying Suspect Held
description: A Newark building superintendent was held without bail on charges of stabbing a college student to death a block from her home. The superintendent, John Reddin, 35 years old, appeared before Judge Martin Oliveres in Municipal Court, Newark, and was arraigned on murder charges in the death of Mildred Webb, 21, a neighbor. He was sent to the Essex County Jail to await a hearing.

title: SUBWAY STUDY FINDS MANY TRAIN DEFECTS
description: Threefourths of New York City's, subway cars run with doors, lights or'windows that are broken, misisng fire extinguishers or other defects, a transit study group charged yesterday after a fourmonth survey.

title: Allen Agrees to Join A's
description: MESA, Ariz., March 10(AP)  Dick Allen and Charles O. Finley, two of baseball's most controversial figures, joined forces today when Allen agreed to a oneyear contract with the Oakland A's.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hamaas Khaalis: A 4Year Grudge
description: WASHINGTON. March 10 For more than a day, the voice of Hamaas Abdul Khaalis bellowed orders and complaints from the eighth floor of the B'nai B'rith Building.

title: Political Payments and Rebates Cited at U.S. Lines
description: The United States Lines paid about $1.6 million in rebates to shippers from 1970 to 1973 and made a number of political payments in the period, it was announced yesterday.

title: Hamaas Khaalis: A 4Year Grudge
description: WASHINGTON, March 10For more than a day. the voice of Hamaas Abdul Khaalis bellowed orders and complaints from the eighth floor of the B'nai B'rith Building.

title: February Retail Sales in Rebound
description: WASHINGTON, March 10(UPI)Consumer spending in February rebounded from the effects of the severe winter weather, increasing 1.8 percent from the January level, the Commerce Department said today.

title: ROYAL DUTCH PROFIT DOUBLED IN QUARTER
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the largest nonAmerican company and part owner of the Shell Oil Company here, yesterday reported a profit increase of 109 percent for the fourth quarter on a sales gain of 39.6 percent. For all of last year, net income of the AngloDutch company was up 40 percent and sales 38 percent, both setting records.

title: The Bitter Verdict Against Saccharin
description: The Food and Drug Administration had no option but to ban the use of saccharin in foods and beverages when Canadian tests showed that some rats fed large amounts of the substance developed cancer. Since 1958 there has been a statutethe Delaney clause in the basic F.D.A. statutewhich flatly bans any food additive that, in its words, is found to induce cancer when ingested by man or animal. . . . The law admits no qualifications. For example, the fact that reputable research with monkeys disclosed no abnormalities after they had been given large doses of saccharin for 6 years cannot even be taken into account.

title: Senate Approves Public Works Bill Aiding Northeast
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Senate overwhelmingly approved tonight a $4 billion public works bill to ease unemployment after approving a formula far more generous to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut than was legislation approved by the House of Representatives.

title: PriceFixing Case Of Potash Concerns Ends in a Mistrial
description: CHICAGO, March 10The nineweek trial of five major United Statespotash producers on Federal charges of priceandproduction fixing in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act ended today in a mistrial when the jury was unable to reach a verdict after six days of deliberation.

title: Houston Gas Plans to Acquire Pott
description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation said yesterday that an agreement in principle had been reached for Houston to acquire Pott Industries Inc. for stock valued at about $162.3 million. The agreement provides for a taxfree exchange of 1.35 shares of Houston Natural Gas for each of the 3.7 million shares of Pott Industries outstanding. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Houston Natural Gas closed at 32, down  for the day. On this basis, each share of Pott Industries will be exchanged for stock valued at $43.875.

title: BURNS ASKS INTEREST ON CHECKING ENTRIES IN COMMERCIAL BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, today urged Congress to pass legislation that would permit commercial banks to pay interest on checking accounts on a nationwide basis.

title: U.S. WELFARE TAKEOVER IS URGED UPON CALIFANO
description: WASHINGTON,March 10 (AP)Welfare recipients, administrators and state and local officials urged the Carter Administration today to take welfare financing out of the hands of the states.

title: U.S. ACTS TO ASSURE ISRAELIS AND ARABS ON CARTER REMARKS
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Concerned about possible repercussions in Israel and the Arab countries. Carter Administration officials have taken steps in the last 24 hours to try to convince both sides that President Carter's new Middle East proposals did not mean an end to American evenhandedness in negotiations.

title: Economic Gains in South Linked To Underuse of Taxing Potential
description: ATLANTA, March 10One of the key reasons the South is gaining population and industry faster than other regions is lower taxes.

description: ART(GR 37014) Fri, Sat, Jonah Who Will Be 25 In The Year 2000 3, 7,11; La Salamandre 1, 4:55, 9, Sun, Jonah 1:55, 6,10; Salamandre 3:50, 8.

title: Broadway
description: FREQUENTLY, THE TRICK in theater, the most fickle of all businesses, is to involve yourself in many projects, suffer through them all and then hope that one, maybe even two, will work out. There has never been a time when I haven't had many things going for me, Joshua Logan says, for example. Some die. Some get postponed. You don't work at them all out, full fledged, until you know one will really happen, but you still work. I love work more than anything else in the world.

title: Tentative Manhattan Plaza Accord Reached by Goldin and Developers
description: New York City's Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, said yesterday that an agreement in principle had been reached between his office and the developers and investors involved in the Manhattan Plaza apartment project that would permit most of the apartments to be occupied by entertainmentindustry employoes receiving Federal rent subsidies.
