description: STADLERWaller H. March 11, 1963. Remembered always with love M??????

title: MONEY SUPPLY DROP LIFTS BOND PRICES
description: The credit markets shrugged off news of sharply rising wholesale prices and a February rebound in retail sales yesterday and then apparently were surprised by a decline in the money supply. Bond prices, which showed slight gains throughout the day, climbed more after the Federal Reserve released its money supply data later in the afternoon. The South Central Bell Telephone Company debentures were freed to trade in the secondary market shortly after the Fed figures were released and the bonds inched up to a slight premium.

title: 2 Held on Drug Charges
description: RANDOLPH TOWNSHIP, N. J., March 10 (AP)Henry Neville and William Twigg of New York have been arrested and charged with the manufacture and possession of $300,000 worth of amphetamines at an abandoned farmhouse here, the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration announced yesterday. Arraigned in Newark, the two men were held in lieu of $50,000 and $25,000 bail, respectively.

title: CANCER THERAPY ROLE SEEN FOR MARIJUANA
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 Three Federal agencies plan to conduct a joint study of the usefulness of marijuana in preventing nausea in persons who must take a powerful anticancer drug.

title: Sugar Futures Prices Up Slightly Despite Ban on Use of Saccharin
description: Sugar futures showed only a small rise yesterday while cocoa futures declined sharply, much to the surprise of many market observers.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENMrs. Marion in North Miami Beach, Fla., on March 10. 1977, beloved wife of Mo, devoted sister of Meyer Cohen and Jul?a Schatzman, dear motherinlaw of Lillian Allen, and cherished grandmother of two and greatgrandmother of two. Services Sunday 11 A.M. at The Riverside, North Miami Beach Chapel.

title: Screen: 'Welcome,' A Look at L.A. Life
description: WHEN KEITH CARRADINE and Geraldine Chaplin, the two almost-lovers in "Welcome to L.A.," talk by phone, each looks into a mirror. So does the movie: a very talented effort at very little, a sinewy jaw closing on a noodle, a fashion pose masquerading as a position."City of the One-Night Stands" is the theme song of the film, written and directed by Alan Rudolph and produced by Robert Altman, his mentor. Like "Shampoo," it is about the greed, boredom and decadence of a small, rich and talented cluster of West Coasters. But "Shampoo" said, in effect: These are some lives. "Welcome," with far less vitality and with more style than wit, says: This is life.It doesn't make the case. It is a picture that has the smell of a coterie, of inside allusions and illusions, of private jokes or, ratherbecause there are few jokesof private hangovers. The film is a very rich man in beautiful clothes telling you what a bad night he's had. You are sorry, but it was his night."Welcome" begins with Carroll Barber (Mr. Carradine), after three years of drifting in Europe, returning to Los Angeles. The return is engineered by his father, Carl (Denver Pyle) a self-made millionaire who wants to bring him into his business. The bait is the offer by a pop singer (played by Richard Baskin who, in fact, wrote the film's songs) to record one of Carroll's pieces. It is a phony offer; paid for, in fact, by Carl.Carroll, rich, languid, untouchable, drifts through, drinking Southern Comfort out of a pint bottle, driving an expansive car with one hand, and sleeping with a succession of frantic women.Why are they frantic? Susan Moore, an agent (Viveca Lindfors) is frantic because she is aging and life is all grappling and no grasp. Ann Goode a real-estate woman played with a kind of defeated enthusiasm by Sally Keller-man, is frantic because her husband sleeps around. Karen Hood (Geraldine Chaplin) is frantic because her husband, Ken, a comically ambitious assistant to Carl Barber, is totally wrapped up in himself.The men, incidentally, are equally frantic, but have a little more breathing space. They need to score instant successeswith sex, work, lifestyleand flee intimacy. Thy love their wives, but play around on Christmas Eve.We see these things in episodes, sometimes clever, usually well-acted, but excessively contrived. Harvey Keitel as a man twisted out of all shape by the need to succeedhe bounces like Silly Puttyis funny and grotesque, but never touching. Sissy Spacek has a perfectly polished role as a live-in maid who does her vacuuming topless, and entertains clients when Carroll Barber goes out. She adds a corrosive kind of humor to the movie, but no life.The only figure that does have lifein other words, she is not defined completely at her first appearance, but goes on changing  is Karen Hood, played by Miss Chaplin. She rides around in taxis, talking to herself: cultivates an interesting cough, and rather endearingly attributes to Benjamin Franklin, not Goya, the phrase about the sleep of reason producing monsters.The role, as written, is more winsome than moving, but Miss Chaplin gives it a genuine wildness, and a rhythm that sounds like static and feels like electricity. In her absurdly miscalculated relationship with Mr. Carradine she is far better than anything else in the movie.And Mr. Carradine is worse. Perhaps it is the director's fault more than his, but he sinks the film. We see interminable shots of him staring out windows, drooping around, driving. He is sullen and laconic, and we get dreadfully tired of him. He is the equivalent of the Poor Little Rich Girl. His deadness is supposed to be the film's judgment upon the hyperactive life of its characters. But except for Miss Chaplin, the characters are neither alive nor interesting. Mr. Rudolph is mowing down lead soldiers.The songs are a particular torment. The music whines, the lyrics complain, and Mr. Carradine sings them with a kind of hushed writhing, like a worm dying at the bottom of a barrel.

title: U.S., WEST GERMANY MAKE NO PROGRESS IN ATALKS
description: BONN, Friday, March 11(AP)United States and West German officials ended a second round of talks today on halting the spread of nuclearweapons technology with no sign of easing their disagreement over a GermanBrazilian atomic sales agreement.

title: Car Emissions Compromise Is Endorsed by Big Three
description: DETROIT, March 10 (UPI)The nation's big three automobile makers yesterday endorsed a compromise clean air measure and urged Congress to adopt the legislation.

title: Beethoven Songs, Feld Dances
description: Early in the 19th century, Ludwig von Beethoven, of all people, orchestrated 170 songs from Britain and Ireland. Tomorrow night at the City Center 55th Street Theater, 18 members of the Eliot Feld Ballet will trip lightly to these tunes at the premiere of Mr. Feld's most recent work, A Footstep of Air.

title: Zaire Says Angola Mercenaries Cross Border, Seize Three Cities
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 10(AP)Mercenaries from Angola have invaded southern Zaire and occupied three important mining and communications centers, the Zaire Government said today.

title: Art People
description: WHY SHOULDN'T our city, not exactly a cultural backwater, have an arts exposition like other world capitals? Martin E. Segal, chairman of the city's Advisory Commission for Cultural Affairs, has been pondering the question for quite some time. And so it was that last week Mayor Beame, in his State of the City Message, announced that he had asked the ebullient chairman to begin work immediately on a major new event. The Mayor said, The goal is for the City of New York to host the nation's first international exposition of the arts.

title: LISTING SACCHARIN AS DRUG CONSIDERED
description: The Federal Food and Drug Administration plans to consider classifying saccharin as a drug, instead of a food additive so that doctors could prescribe the noncaloric artificial sweetener among overweight Americans and the millions of patients with diabetes and other disorders for which weight control plays a crucial role.

title: Jury Deadlocks in Trial On Threat to Rockefeller
description: CAMDEN, N.J., March 10(UPI)A mistrial was declared today after a jury failed to reach a verdict in the trial of a man charged with threatening to assassinate former Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller with a cyanide bullet.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TONES AROUND TOWN Indoor music and outdoor strolling can be enjoyed tomorrow at the New York Botanical Garden, Fordham Road and Southern Boulevard, which is open daily from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. with no admission charge; if you drive in, there's a parking tab of $1.50. There's also a tab for the Sunday concerts held in the garden auditorium  $4 for adults, and halfprice for children and the elderly. At 2:30, the Bronx Arts Ensemble will be playing Mozart, Mendelssohn and Tchaikovsky.

title: Retail Store Sales Rise 7%
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Total retail store sales last week were about $12.931 billion. up 7 percent from last year's $12.124 billion, the Department of Commerce reported today. Department store sales were an estimated $1.119 billion, up 14 percent from the yearearlier $985 million.

title: Club's Sylvan Elegance a Memory
description: From the 1930's on, the women residing at the exclusive York Club seeking relief from urban surroundings could walk through the graceful arched doorways to the terrace, where they could gaze out on the 20foottall silver birch trees planted around the adjoining Dodge Mansion.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: PRISON SENTENCES PRONOUNCED FOR 4 AT STIRLING HOMEX
description: David Stirling Jr., 43yearold former chairman of the Stirling Homex Corporation, received a oneyear prison sentence yesterday for a stockfraud scheme that allegedly cost investors almost $40 million.

title: 12 MOSLEMS FACING KIDNAPPING CHARGES AFTER END OF SIEGE
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Twelve Hanafi Moslem gunmen were tentatively charged today with armed kidnapping after their negotiated surrender brought a sudden, peaceful end to the violent siege at three sites in downtown Washington.

title: Notes on People
description: The Board of Regents of the 27campus University of Wisconsin system yesterday chose Edwin Young as chancellor of the university. The 59yearold Mr. Young. a labor economist who received a doctorate from Wisconsin in 1950. is now chancellor of the University of WisconsinMadison campus and served as president of the University of Maine from 1965 to 1968. He will succeed John C. Weaver, who steps down from the $55,000ayear presidency June 30.

title: CARTER SENDS A LETTER TO FREI ON C.I.A. ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, March 11President Carter has expressed his personal regret to former President Eduardo Frei Montalva of Chile over press reports that Mr. Frei had received funds from the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Moody's Rating Kept On Bonds of Quebec
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it was maintaining its Aa ratings on bonds of the Province of Quebec and of Hydro Quebec. The rating service had begun a review of Quebec securities after the victory last November of the Quebec Party, which aims to separate the province from the rest of Canada.

title: Manhattanville, Lehigh Gain
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., March 11Manhattanville College and Lehigh University will meet for the consolation championship of the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women invitation basketball tournament tomorrow at Manhattanville College. Manhattanville defeated Bentley, 4645. and Lehigh topped St. Francis College, of New York, 6662, today.

title: Philharmonic's Rodney Friend Handles Violin Solo Expertly
description: One of the valuable traditions of the symphony orchestra is the practice of engaging its own principal players as soloists in the standard concerto literature. There is extra pay in it for these intramural stars, of course, but, also, inestimable value in encouraging them to keep their skills at the solo level. Ideally, many more orchestra players than now should be allowedor forcedto stand up and be tested.

title: Disaster Relief Funds Voted
description: WASHINGTON,March 11 (AP)The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill appropriating $200 million more for disaster relief. The money is to be used in droughtstricken regions of the West and Great Plains and in eastern states plagued by severe winter snows.

title: RADIO BOARD CHOICE STIRS CONTROVERSY
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The White House has asked Professor William E. Griffith of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to become a member of the Board for International Broadcastinga choice that is already causing controversy because of his role in the Hungarian uprising of 1956.

title: Bologna Student Killed In Clash With Police
description: BOLOGNA, Italy. March 11 (AP)Policemen clashed today with nearly 1,000 leftist students who hurled fire bombs and set up barricades near the University of Bologna. One student was killed and scores were injured, officials said.

title: Harrah's 2 Homers Sink Yanks, 43
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 11Reggie Jackson, the man the Yankees wanted this winter and got, made his debut today, but Toby Harrah, the man the Yankees wanted and did not get, overshadowed him.

title: Four Ruffiansa Charming Opera
description: It was about 25 years ago that the New York City Opera staged I Quattro Rusteghi by Ermanno WolfFerrari. For some reason it did not stay in the repertory, and more's the pity. Thursday night, however, the Manhattan School of Music plugged this particular gap in the repertory with a charming little production of the opera.

title: 2 Brooklyn Youths Charged in Attacks On Elderly Couple
description: Two youths were arrested yesterday and charged with beating an 84yearold Brooklyn man and returning the next day to assault his 80yearold wife.

title: Toulon Mayoralty Race Reflects Many National Trends
description: TOULON, France, March 7Of the 36,000 French cities, towns and villages preparing to elect mayors over the next two weekends, only the people of this Mediterranean naval base have a selection of candidates including a dismissed admiral running as a Socialist, an incumbent Mayor who refuses to campaign, and a bibulous yachtsman who promises that pink wine will flow from household faucets if he is elected.

title: Approval of Access Plan By Exchange Is Reported
description: Directors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to approve a controversial committee report to broaden access to membership, sources said yesterday.

title: U.S. GENERAL TO JOIN ARMS TALK IN SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, March 11President Carter, in an apparent gesture to the military and his Senate critics, has named a representative of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to the American delegation that will discuss arms control matters in Moscow later this month.

title: Archibald Out for Season
description: The Nets learned before the game that Nate (Tiny) Archibald would not return for the remainder of the season. He is back from El Paso, where he was working out after a cast had been removed from his left foot has been earlier in the season. In Texas, however he injured the foot, and it has been placed in another cast.

title: Student Lobbyists Make Albany Grade
description: ALBANY, March 11Barry Fleishman fully expects  hopes, In fact to be over the hill within two years or so.

title: Disarmed, Disowned Hanafi Band Is Facing Threats to Its Survival
description: WASHINGTON. March 11The handful of Hanafi Moslems who terrorized this city for two days were in jeopardy today, both from neighbors and from prison terms they face, which could mean the end of their sect in Washington.

title: Blue Jays Top Mets In Debut, 31
description: DUNEDIN, Fla., March 11Baseball pushed its frontier deeper into Canada today when the Toronto Blue Jays took the field for the first time, scored two runs in the eighth inning and defeated the New York Mets, 31.

title: Middle East Hop, Step and Jump
description: The diplomacy of the Middle East has been frozen for a decade around a procedural issue of great consequence. The Arabs have said that they can never end the state of war with Israel as long as their territory remained in enemy hands. The Israelis have said that they cannot contemplate withdrawal without the sure promise of peace. The Arabs have refused to speak of peace because in granting it they would lose their only bargaining chip. The Israelis have refused phased withdrawals because they saw no way that they could be paid in phased peace.

title: Japan, to Spur Economy, Is Paring Discount Rate to 6% From 6%
description: TOKYO, March 11In an economic move weighted more by psychology than substance, the Bank of Japan announced today a reduction in its official discount rate to 6 percent from 6 percent.

title: Bridge
description: The eight surviving teams in the grand national knockout teams resume play at 1 P.M. today at the East Winds Club. 1555 First Avenue.

title: Marchuk, Soviet Skater, Sets World Mark at 3,000
description: MOSCOW (UPI)Sergei Marchuk of the Soviet Union smashed the fourminute barrier today in the 3,000meter speed skating event to lead four Soviet skaters, who also broke the world record time for the distance.

title: EDUCATOR ASSAILS MONTCLAIR PROPOSAL
description: MORRIS PLAINS, March 11A specialist in educational sociology and school integration said today that the plan proposed for the Montclair schools next September did not represent an integrated program.

title: Miami Bank and F.B.I. Seek Missing $1 Million
description: MIAMI,March 11 (UPI)Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and auditors examined stacks of records and ledgers today, trying to learn how $1.1 million vanished over three to four years from the Southeast First National Bank of Miami, Florida's largest bank.

title: Moslem Groups in Jersey Prisons Are Kept Apart to Avoid Clashes
description: TRENTON, March 11State prison officials described today, in the wake of the two days of Moslem terrorism in Washington, how they have managed to keep opposing factions among 500 Black Moslem inmates separated and thus avoiding trouble.

title: Adamant White Rhodesians
description: Mood Among the Minority Is Shifting to Rule Out Any Concessions to Those Blacks Seen as Radicals

title: Byrd Tells Carter Senate Is Angered By Unilateral Acts
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The uneasy relationship between Congress and the White House took some new turns today, with the Senate majority leader advising President Carter of his colleagues anger and frustration and the Administration attempting to pacify an alienated committee chairman in the House.

title: And Now for an Encore: It's Son of Operation Sail
description: What can the city possibly do for a Fourth of July encore that would be worthy of last year's fabulous Operation Sail? Well, how about another OpSail?

title: Nearby Soybeans Futures Prices Decline Slightly in Light Trading
description: In light, preweekend trading yesterday. soybean futures inched down in the nearby months, which call for delivery of old crop beans. May closed at $8.20 a bushel, down from $8.23. The new crop months of November, January and later showed gains.

title: Student Lobbyists Make Albany Grade
description: ALBANY, March 11Barry Fleishman fully expects  hopes, in fact  to be over the hill within two years or so.

title: Lobsters Sign Roche
description: BOSTON, March 11 (UPI)Tony Roche of Australia, a mixed doubles champion last year at Wimbledon, signed a multiyear contract today to play for the Boston Lobsters of World Team Tennis. To obtain the 32yearold lefthander, the Lobsters traded John Alexander of Australia to Phoenix for the rights to Roche's contract.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Dec. 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Drivers Called Loath to Use Kneeling Buses
description: Remember the kneeling buses? Well, most of them haven't been.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONA replacement heart valve invented in research at Union College, Schnectady, N.Y.. uses mechanical means to mimic the action of a natural valve.

title: Closed End Funds
description: Week coding March 11, 1977

title: Canadians Find Florida Sun Costlier as Currency Falls
description: OTTAWA, March 11The hordes of Canadians who flock to the United States southland for winter vacations more than a million to Florida alone, according to travel industry figureshave discovered that their holidays in the sun are costing them substantially more this year.

title: About NewYork
description: There are these two women housepainters hired to paint a Brooklyn brownstone after the male painter originally sought balked at working in anything but latex. Being a man, he didn't get emotional about it. but. oilbased paints were simply too messy to be worth his while.

title: L.I. Woman, 49, Drowns in Pool While Failing to Save Her Child
description: SELDEN. L. I.. March 11 (UPI)A 49yearold woman drowned this afternoon in a backyard pool here while attempting to rescue her 2yearold foster child, who also died.

title: Judge Accepts 2d Phase Of Milwaukee Integration
description: MILWAUKEE, March 11The second phase of Milwaukee's public school integration plan will combine voluntary and involuntary assignment of pupils, a Federal judge decided today.

title: N.Y. U. Leads Penn for Fencing Crown
description: Although it failed to capture either the epee or foil team title. New York University yesterday emerged from the first day of the twoday Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships at Columbia's Levien Gym with a threebout lead over secondplace Pennsylvania.

title: 12 MOSLEMS FACING KIDNAPPING CHARGES AFTER END OF SIEGE
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Twelve Hanafi Moslem gunmen were tentatively charged today with armed kidnapping after their negotiated surrender brought a sudden, peaceful end to the violent siege at three sites in downtown Washington.

title: Hasidim Hail a Divorce Ruling
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn was praised by members of a Hasidic sect yesterday as having the wisdom of a Solomon after he arranged the terms of a divorce involving the 22yearold leader of the sect and his 19yearold wife.

title: Concordat On Concorde
description: PARISThe transAtlantic argument over Concorde is now marked by savage and bewildering bitterness. Here it must be interjected that of the two proud European progenitors of this supersonic jet, the British have displayed more calm reason and less emotion than the French. Prime Minister Callaghan behaved with restraint during his Washington visit, although he defended his case.

title: Banking Health in U.S. Improves; Fewer Borderline Cases Are Cited
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (Reuters)The health of the United States banking system has improved over the last two years. banking officials said today.

title: Behind the KuhnCuba Tangle
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 11Negotiations between Commissioner Bowie Kuhn and Cuban officials for baseball games in Cuba are at stalemate. The result: It is a virtual certainty that no team from the major leagues, allstar or Yankee, will play in Cuba this spring.

title: Pennsylvania Hospital Releases Miner Who Was Trapped 5 Days
description: POTTSVILLE, Pa., March 11 (AP)Ronald Adley, who was trapped in a coal mine for five days, was released from Pottsville Hospital Wednesday, it became known today.

title: Buddy Greco at Rainbow Room
description: If it were not a matter of record that Buddy Greco was playing piano and singing with Benny Goodman's orchestra 28 years ago and, after a threeyear stretch with Mr. Goodman, has been performing on his own ever since, one might get the impression from his current appearance at the Rainbow Grill that he is a promising, if somewhat overconfident, novice.

title: An Uncommonly Bad Bill
description: The common situs picketing bill is back again in Congress, not as an Administration bill this year but with strong support from the A.F.L.C.1.O. leadership and, not surprisingly, from legislators with ties to organized labor. Though altered in committee to provide certain moderating exemptions, the present bill, like the one President Ford vetoed in 1976. would permit the employees of one contractor on a building project to set up picket lines to keep members of other unions from working anywhere on the site.

title: Spies Held in Egypt Say Libya Sent Them
description: CAIRO, March 11 (Reuters)Five persons arrested by the Egyptian police have confessed to being Libyan agents sent to Cairo to carry out acts of sabotage during the meeting here of Arab and black African leaders, Egypt's official Middle East News Agency said today.

title: Mrs. Trudeau Says She Intends To Cut Down on Official Duties
description: Margaret Trudeau, wife of the Canadian Prime Minister, said here yesterday that she planned to spend more time with my photography and less time with my official functions.

title: Contributions of a Koran Scholar
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP)When Iran's Abassador, Ardeshir Zahedi, learned that he would negotiate facetoface with the leader of a band of Moslems holding 134 hostages, he turned to a man of religion for help.

title: New Yorkers Hasten to Stock Up On Sweetener and Diet Products
description: News of the Food and Drug Administration's plan to ban saccharin sent scores of sweettoothed and dietcon?cious New Yorkers to the nearest market. yesterday to stock up on products that contain the artificial sweetener.

title: 20,366 at Golden Gloves; Biggest Crowd Since 68
description: The place for a boxing fan to be last night was Madison Square Garden for the finals of the 51st Golden Gloves boxing tournament.

title: Toyota Reports Record Exports
description: TOKYO, March 11 (Reuters)Toyota, Japan's biggest automaker, announced today that it exported a monthly record of 110,400 vehicles in February.

title: PLASTIC BOTTLE CURB STAYED BY U.S. COURT
description: WASHINGTON. March 11(AP)A Federal court temporarily stayed today a Food and Drug Administration order suspending its approval of plastic beverage bottles made of acr?lonitrile.

title: Funds for Helium Rescinded
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) President Carter today rescinded $47.5 million from the Federal budget for the purchase of helium by the Interior Department. The White House said that government purchases of helium were terminated in 1973 because an estimated 120year supply of the gas was already in storage or available in proven, nondepleting reserves.

title: Women's Advocate Now Fights Houston Council to Keep Her Job
description: HOUSTON March 11When the Government of Taiwan presented the city of Houston with a statue of Confucius a few months back, it was Nikki Van Hightower, the city's official Advocate for Women's Rights, who spotted the inscription on the base and quickly branded the Chinese sage the sexist of his time.

title: Lowenstein Calls U.N. Rights Session Balanced
description: GENEVA. March 11Allard K. Lowenstein, the American delegate. said today that the annual session of the United Nations Human Rights Commission that ended today had been far more balanced beCatise the United States had Managed to get the group to discuss the issue of Soviet dissidents.

title: Canned  Food Weight Subject of U.S. Study
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Food and Drug Administration has agreed to consider an industrysupported proposal requiring manufacturers to list on cans of vegetables and fruits the weight of the contents before water is added and the food is cooked.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLUTTMANHoward, 19511977, In Inving and everlasting memory of a beloved son and brother. Mom, Dad and Herbert.

title: A Woman's Body Found, Operator of GarmentArea Elevator Is Held
description: The body of a young Brooklyn woman who was eight months pregnant was discovered yesterday in a cardboard box on a sidewalk in the garment center. Ten hours later the police took into custoy a parttime elevator operator in a building she had visited.

title: People in Business
description: Bert Lance, newly installed director of the Office of Management and Budget in President Carter's Administration, has come upon a sympathetic fellow man and a public apology in Steel City, U.S.A. In an editorial prepared for today's editions of The Pittsburgh PostGazette, William Block, president and publisher, addresses an open letter to Mr. Lance apologizing for the lack of time he was given at a recent Chamber of Commerce dinner appearance.

title: Wife of British Foreign Secretary Remains American
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Deborah Schabert Owen has lived in England long enough for her speech to have acquired a crispness closer to London than to Long Island, but as an American married to an Englishmanin her case to Britain's new Foreign Secretary she says: You will always be outside, always he an alien.

title: Waiting for the P.L.O.
description: JERUSALEMThere can be little doubt that the Palestine Liberation Organization has finally decided to announce its new position on how the IsraeliPalestinian conflict can be resolved. After almost two years of cautious and somewhat hesitant announcements, we finally hear that a twostate solution of the conflict has in fact been adopted by the P.L.O.

title: New York Seeks Employee Residency Requirement
description: Members of the City Council and the Beame administration renewed their drive yesterday for legislation requiring future municipal employees to live in New York City.

title: Brazil Cancels Military Aid Treaty Over U.S. Report on Human Rights
description: By The Associated Press

title: Need of U.S. Flu Vaccine Subsidy Stressed by Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Without some kind of Federal subsidy, there will not be enough influenza vaccine for the country's needs next winter, a special advisory panel to Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. decided today.

title: Moses Urges Westchester to Back Inevitable Bridge Across Sound
description: WHITE PLAINS,March 11 Robert Moses, who years ago conceived the idea of a bridge across Long Island Sound from Rye, N.Y., to Oyster Bay, L.I., insisted here today that such a bridge was inevitable, and he appealed for Westchester County support for it.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Yugoslav Hints Atom Arm Goal
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 11A senior Yugoslav military commander said in an interview published today that world conditions would shape his country's decision whether to develop nuclear weapons.

title: N.Y. Savings Bank Inflows Up Despite High Winter Spending
description: The savings banks of the State of New York had a net deposit flow of $269 million in February, up from $246 million in January, the Saving Bank Association of New York State reported yesterday.

title: Venezuela Accelerates $1.5 Billion Caracas Metro Project
description: CARACAS, Venezuela. March 11 After years of indecision and burgeoning traffic in Venezuela's capital, the Government is now moving ahead steadily on construction of the Caracas Metro, a rapid transit system expected to cost more than $1.5 billion.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises 8.8%
description: WASHINGTON. March 11The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.4 billion tonmiles, a high for the year and 8.8 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings during the same period totaled 464,855 cars, 5.2 percent above last year.

title: Rise in Pound Suggested
description: BRUSSELS. March 11 (AP)The European Commission  the Common Market executive bodysays the British Government should consider the possibility of allowing the pound to rise in value.

title: Music: Kirchner
description: Taking opportune advantage of Leon Kirchner's presence in town and of the interest in his work whetted by the imminent premiere by the New York City Opera (on April 14) of his opera Lily, the Performers Committee for 20thCentury Music staged a Kirchner retrospective Wednesday night at Columbia University's McMillin Theater.

title: Brutal Melee in a Jersey Tavern Involves Policemen and Patrons
description: ROEBLING, N.J., March 11  Last Saturday evening, 300 young men and women were in the Village Tavern here, drinking, dancing or listening to a sixpiece Pennsylvania musical group known as Black Rose.

title: Shaken Hostages Tell of Days of Terror
description: WASHINGTON,March 11I was waiting my turn to go to the men's room, and all of a sudden the two terrorists on guard faded away. I heard a noise, and then there was a beautiful sight:the Metropolitan police.

title: A Man of Parts: Student . . . Politician . . .Busboy
description: AVALON, March 11When the manager of the Rock'n Chair Tavern here wants a table cleared of dirty dishes, chances are he will call upon the Democratic chairman of Cape May County.

title: Cosmos Win Exhibition
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 11Giorgio Chinaglia scored all four goals tonight to lead the Cosmos to a 40 exhibitiongame victory over Bermuda's under23 national team. The game ended with five minutes to play because of torrential rain.

title: Legislators Look at the StripMine Problem
description: HUGHESTON, W. Va., March 9The steep mountainside was obviously not virgin land, but neither did it have the ravaged, moonscape look that is characteristic of strip mines.

title: Woman's Body Found on 39th St.; Elevator Operator Held in Slaying
description: The body of a young Brooklyn woman who was eight months pregnant was discovered yesterday in a cardboard box on a sidewalk in the garment center. Ten hours later the police took into custody a parttime elevator operator in a building she had visited.

description: GOLDEN GLOVES FINALS

description: Article 4  No Title

title: 3 Incendiary Devices Ignite Inside Letters At Church St. Post Office
description: Three letters containing lowpowered incendiary devices ignited at a post office in lower Manhattan last night and early today, according to the police.

title: New Madrid Amnesty Expected to Free Many of 170 Political Prisoners
description: MADRID, March 11The Government tonight proclaimed a new amesty that is expected to free a large number of the approximately 170 political prisoners accused or tried under the Franco regime who are still in jail.

title: Strauss Nominated as Trade Aide
description: President Carter yesterday nominated former Democratic National Chairman, Robert S. Strauss, to be his Special Representative for Trade Negotiationsone of the most politically sensitive posts in the new Administration.

title: N.B.A. Draft on June 10
description: The National Basketball Association announced yesterday it would hold its draft of college players June 10. The draft will be conducted by a telephone conference call among representatives of the 22 N.B.A. teams and the N.B.A. officials.

title: Wanted: A Red Light for Scofflaws
description: New York City issues more than eight million parking tickets a year and collects on less than half of them. The list of excuses for this miserable record, as we have been reading it for years, is almost as long as the list of violators. Thus more than $300 million have slipped through the city's hands, to be made up by the taxpayers. Moreover, for every ticket unpaid with impunity, yet another offending motorist is no doubt encouraged not to pay next time. And for every fine uncollected, how many more are encouraged to take their chances and try violating the parking regulations?

title: RUMANIA MAKES LIST FOR EARTHQUAKE AID
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 11A series of specific requests by Bucharest for aid to overcome the damages caused by the severe earthquake that struck the country a week ago was forwarded to Washington today.

title: Byrd Tells Carter Senate Is Angered By Unilateral Acts
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The uneasy relationship between Congress and the White House took some new turns today, with the Senate majority leader advising President Carter of his colleagues anger and frustration and the Administration attempting to pacify an alienated committee chairman in the House.

title: Swiss Vote on Proposal To Set Limit on Foreigners
description: GENEVA, March 11 (UPI)The Swiss voted today for the third time in less than three years on whether to force out of the country hundreds of thousands of foreigners who do much of the nation's menial work.

title: Velasquez, Aboard Swift's Choice Today, Will Step Up Riding Activity at Aqueduct
description: Move over, Steve Cauthen. The champion is ready to defend his title.

title: Personal Investing
description: The managers of the nation's 50 or so closedend investment companies seem to be caught in a paradox that has been sharpened by a shift in investors judgments.

title: Viking Within 185 Miles of Mars For Real Closeup Photographs
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 11 (AP)Viking 1 cameras began looking down the gunbarrel at Mars today as its orbiter moved to within 185 miles of the planet for closeup photographs, a mission spokesman said.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB ? s??ng FIRST$7,000, cl., 3YO and up. 1m. and 70yds.

title: 70 Arrested in an AfterHours Club on West Side
description: Cries of Police! Freeze! stunned patrons into instant silence on the first floor of a lavish New York City afterhours club at 6:30 yesterday morning. In fact, all was so quiet that dancers, gamblers and other customers on the second floor did not know there was a bust until they saw the police who had hounded up the carpeted stairway to yell Police! Freeze! at them.

title: Zaire Asserts It Has Recaptured 2 Towns From Foreign Invaders
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 11 (AP)Government officials said today that Zaire's forces had recaptured two towns in a southern province from invaders who had entered the country several days ago. Government troops were said to be moving toward three other occupied communities.

title: Talks on Seabed Mining Said to Have Advanced Prospect for Agreement
description: GENEVA, March 11More than 80 nations concluded informal consultations here today that have opened prospects of an important advance at the next session of the long deadlocked Law of the Sea Conference.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Sports of The Times

title: DR. SANFORD MEYEROWITZ
description: Dr. Sanford Meyerowitz, a psychiatrist and associate dean of the University of Rochester's School of Medicine and Dentistry. died of cancer yesterday at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 50 years old and a resident of Rochester.

title: Wonderful Town Revival Sparkles At Equity Theater
description: One prefers, in appraising a performance to cultivate a lean, objective demeanor of approval or disdain, but what do you do when you hit a wonderful gusher such as Wonderful Town, the revival of the 1953 hit musical (based on the even earlier My Sister Eileen)? You gush.

title: Gillman Named Head Coach
description: GREENVILLE. N.C., March 11 (UPI) East Carolina University named Larry Gillman. an assistant coach at San Francisco. as its head basketball coach today. The 28yearold Gillman replaces Dave Patton. who resigned after compiling a 4042 wonlost record in three years at the school. Gillman has also served as an assistant at Houston and Minnesota. He will join the Pirates as soon as San Francisco, finishes in the National Collegiate playoffs.

title: 3 Ambassadors Who Negotiated An End to Siege
description: Egyptian Ambassador to the United States since December 1973. . . Member of aristocratic. Egyptian family, son of Supreme Court justice . . . Born May 1925, in Alexandria . . . Graduated from Cairo University with honors, earned scholarship to Harvard where he received M.A. In 1948 and Ph.D. in political science in 1949 . . . Entered diplomatic service in 1945, serving first in the United Nations Human Rights Division, later in the Egyptian United Nations Mission . . . Held subsequent posts in Paris and London, leaving London upon the Sinai invasion in 1956 . . . Served at embassies in Geneva and Ottawa . . . In January 1968 was assigned as chief of the Egyptian interests section at the Indian Embassy in the United States to oversee EgyptianAmerican relations during a break in formal relations between the two countries . . . Returned to Cairo in July 1972 to become assistant adviser to President Anwar elSadat for national security affairs . . . Became press adviser to Sadat in 1973 . . . Married with two children.

title: 12 Are Sent to Jail Because of Protest Over a Power Line
description: MALONE. N.Y., March 11 (AP)Twelve persons who have been attempting to stop construction of upstate New York's first 765,000volt power line were jailed today after being found guilty of contempt of court.

title: Court Tells G.M. to Verify Engines
description: CHICAGO, March 11 (AP)An Illinois Circuit Court judge today ordered General Motors to tell past and future purchasers of Oldsmobiles throughout the nation if their cars contain anything other than Oldsmobile engines.

title: Commodity Price Index Rises 1.8 From WeekEarlier Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 217.3 from 215.5 last week.

title: Powell Trips Up in Aiming a Gibe At Udall Over Unmade Phone Call
description: WASHINGTON. March 11Like pretty girls and haunting refrains, the remembrance of campaigns past came bubbling up at the White House today.

title: U.S. to Negotiate On Pooled Fund For Commodities
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Carter Administration is willing to discuss how to create and pay for huge stockpiles of major commodities that could be tapped to stabilize global commodity prices. The Administration's decision to enter international negotiations is considered a major concession to developing nations.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Concert: Disciplined North Carolina Symphony Comes to Town
description: The North Carolina Symphony came to town for the first time Wednesday night, and it was quite an event. Playing in Carnegie Hall, the orchestra drew a virtually capacity audience. In it were a large delegation from the Southern state, including its new Governor, James B. Hunt Jr.; former North Carolinians and Duke University alumni, who were enjoying a reunion, and people in the music business. There were even pickets outside the hall, urging Governor Hunt to free the Wilmington 10 and the Charlotte Three.

description: Article 1  No Title

title: Israelis Find Beauty, Few Comforts in Sinai
description: OPHIRA, Israelioccupied SinaiThe first lusty organized Bronx cheer  a singularly irreverent raspberry directed at an Israeli official who, as officials are wont to do, was urging patience has been sounded in this remote set??tlement in the southern tip of the Sinai Desert.

title: Paramus to Enforce Sunday Ban On Sales Despite Court Decision
description: PARAMUS, March 11Officials of this Bergen County community, the home of four heavily patronized shopping centers, asserted today that they would strictly enforce this Sunday a local blue law that bans a wide range of commercial activity.

title: Cunningham's Dancers Switch Series to Barnard
description: Merce Cunningham and Dance Company. originally scheduled to appear at the Roundabout Theater, will now perform in the Barnard College gymnasium, next Tuesday through March 20. All tickets purchased for the Dance Umbrella series, which was canceled at the Roundabout this week, will be honored. Other tickets are available at the box office on performance days, 6:30 to 9 P.M., or by calling 6913500.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The medieval and early Renaissance music festival at Christ Church, Park Avenue and 60th Street, will take place at. 8 O'clock tonight, not earlier, as incorrectly listed in The Times yesterday.

title: Stocks Display Small Changes; Dow Is Up 0.99
description: Leading softdrink issues continued to gain yesterday, while the stock market generally showed narrow changes in slow trading.

title: E. Power Biggs, the Organist, Is Dead in Boston at 70
description: E. Power Biggs, noted organist, died on Thursday afternoon in Deaconess Hospital, Boston, following an operation for bleeding ulcers. He was 70 years old.

title: Opposition Strike Disrupts Main Cities of Pakisran
description: KARACHI, March 11An opposition strike call today disrupted life in Pakistan's main cities and brought army tanks into the streets of Karachi to contain widespread violence.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The medieval and early Renaissance music festival at Christ Church, Park Avenue and 60th Street, will take place at 8 o'clock tonight, not earlier, as incorrectly listed in The Times yesterday.

title: Mercury Reaches 73, Record High for Day
description: The temperature reached a record high of 73 degrees yesterday, suggesting that spring had indeed arrived well ahead of schedule. The previous record for the day was 72, set in 1967.

description: SAILING TODAY

description: MINEOLA. L.L. March 11In turnabout of President Carter's telephone callin program, a Republican Representative started a program here today of calling his constituents.

description: BELMONTFrances A. On March 10, 1977 Loves cousin or ???en R????y. Funeral private.

title: Bill to Restrain the Press Raises Storm in South Africa Parliament
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa. March 11Amid opposition cries of Nazi! and Sieg heil! the South African Government today presented Parliament with a bill placing sharp new restraints on the country's newspapers, including the power to stop publication.

title: Connors, Gottfried Win, Giving U. S. a 30 Advantage
description: HARTFORD, March 11'No chance of Australia winning this World Cup, said Jimmy Connors tonight, and then the world's No. 1ranked tennis player went out and routed John Alexander of Australia, 61, 64.

title: Court Coaches Grumble About N.C.A.A. Schedule
description: Four of the East's best college basketball teams headed south and west yesterday to play in the first round of the 39th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association championship this weekend at such distant places as Tucson, Ariz.; Baton Rouge, La.; Norman, Okla., and Bloomington, Ind. However, two of them, Princeton and Hofstra, had to travel only to Philadelphia.

title: Belger Wins 880 Title Of N.C.A.A.
description: DETROIT, March 11 Mark Belger did something different tonight. He won a race from the front, leading from start to finish. And it hurt.

title: Banks Set Up $500 Million Loan For Brazilian Steel Producers
description: LONDON, March 11 (AP)A group or international banks has completed arrangements for a $500 million loan to finance development in the Brazilian Gov ernment steel industry. the Chase Manhattan Bank said today.

title: LEYLAND STRIKERS REFUSE PLEAS TO RETURN TO WORK
description: LONDON, March 11Striking toolworkers of Britains biggest automobile maker, Leyland, refused today to return to work. With shouts and insults they dismissed the pleas of Hugh Scanlon, president of their union, to end their threeweek stoppage and reconsider the enormity of their rafusel.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state police will conduct walkin written examinations on March 26 and April 2 for persons interested in becoming state troopers. No prior application is required. Col. Clinton L. Pagano, Superintendent of the state police, said the examinations would be given March 26 at Essex County Community College in Newark, Mercer County Community College in West Windsor and the RutgersCamden campus. Tests also will be given April 2 at the Essex and Mercer campuses and at Atlantic City High School. The minimum requirements for becoming a trooper include United States citizenship, a high school diploma or equivalent, being between the ages of 18 and 35 and being in good health.

title: DeBusschere Files Suit Against the Nets and Boe
description: Dave DeBusschere, former general manager of the New York Nets, sued the team and its principal owner, Roy L. M. Boe yesterday for $400,000 he claims the Nets owe him. DeBusschore, who served in the Nets front office for a year between his playing career and his brief tenure as commissioner of the defunct American Basketball Association, filed papers for his suit in State Supreme Court in Mineola, L.I.

title: Television
description: 6:00 (4)Agriculture. U.S.A.

title: NBC News Signs Betty Ford to Pact For Two Specials
description: NBC News, which recently signed exclusive agreements with Gerald R. Ford and Henry A. Kissinger for periodic television appearances, yesterday added to the roster the former President's wife, Betty Ford.

title: Counterclaim on Indians Filed by Cape Cod Town
description: BOSTON. March 11(UPI)Residents of Mashpee say that if the Wampanoag Indians win a lawsuit to regain 16,000 acres of that Cape Cod resort town, the tribal council will owe the community $200 million for improvements made over the past three centuries.

title: C'est la Guerre
description: There was no doubt what France's response would be to New York City's refusal to let the Concorde land at Kennedy Airport. The French had delivered their ultimatum to Mayor Beame. It spoke of an insult to the honor of French aerodynamics. At dawn France would be at war with the City of New York.

title: Banker Pleads Guilty On Agnew Contribution
description: BALTIMORE, March 11(AP)A Maryland banker has pleaded guilty to soliciting an illegal campaign contribution from the Singer Corporation for former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew.

title: DNA and the Public Interest
description: Few 20thcentury developments in basic science have stirred more public controversy than the novel recombinant DNA (for deoxyribonucleic acid) techniques, which modify the nucleicacid molecules that serve as the basic genetic material of organisms, and so change their biological character.

title: 3 Islamic Diplomats Bridge Gap to Gunmen
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The tedious negotiations that led to the peaceful release of 134 hostages from their Hanafi Moslem captors early today were conducted jointly by the Washington police, the Ambassadors of three Islamic countries and State Department officials who specialize in dealing with terrorists.

title: Airmanship Award Presented
description: BELLEVUE, Neb., March 11 (AP)Capt. James A. Yule, 30 years old, of Cooperstown, N. Y., was honored yesterday at Strategic Air Command headquarters for preventing the crash of a B52 Bomber. Captain Yule received the first Alfred F. Kalberer Award for Outstanding Airmanship.

title: Books of The Times
description: A quarter of a century ago, a group of Lincoln scholars in Illinois decided that there was nothing basically new to say about the 16th President after so many books, articles, plays and poems. In a sense, they were right. The major biographies have been written in multivolumes by James G. Randall and Carl Sandburg and the histories of the Civil War era by Allan Nevins and Bruce Catton.

title: CONTINENTAL BANK ENDS PLAN FOR FUND TO INVEST IN FARMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI)Bowing to bitter protests, the Continental Illinois National Bank of Chicago today dropped a proposed $50 million plan to invest taxexempt pension funds in farm land.

title: Woman Gets Conservative's Vote And California Chief Justice Post
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 11Attorney General Evelle J. Younger voted this afternoon to confirm Rose Bird as the new Chief Justice of the California Supreme Court.

title: Order on Olds Engine Given
description: CHICAGO, March 11 (UPI)  Cook County Judge Raymond K. Berg ordered the General Motors Corporation yesterday to notify Oldsmobile owners throughout the United States if their cars had engines other than those built for Oldsmobile. G.D.I. disclosed last week it had installed Chevrolet engines in about 43.000 Oldsmobile Delta 88's this year because of a shortage of Olds engines.

title: Bean Widens Lead to Two With a 67134
description: MIAMI, March 11Perhaps it was appropriate that Andy Bean was cocaptain of the University of Florida golf team, which was nicknamed the Gators. As a boy on Jekyll Island in Georgia, he had a few alligators that were much like pets, and as recently as 1975 he startled the golf establishment by playfully manhandling a sixfoot alligator during a competition round.

title: Charles B. Gardner, ExOwner Of Collection of American Bottles
description: NEW LONDON. Conn., March 11Charles B. Gardner, whose collection of American bottles was considered among the most extensive in the world, died today in a convalescent home here. He was 86 years old and lived at 560 Montauk Avenue here.

title: Gold Drops by $1 an Ounce In Both London and Zurich; Dollar Is Narrowly Mixed
description: LONDON. March 11 (AP)The price of gold dropped $1 an ounce today in both London and Zurich. The dollar closed narrowly mixed.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Westehester County established a women's center in White Plains and draw a cheer from an openhouse gathering by announcing that the name of the county's Office of Manpower Training had been changed to the Employment and Training Office.

title: New York Stages a Blitz in Washington for Conventions
description: WASHINGTON. March 11This the year of a New Shine on the Big Apple.

title: Carter and Callaghan Praise Talks
description: WASHINGTON. March 11President Carter and Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain concluded two days of discussions today, evidently confident that they had forged a close friendship and made progress on a wide range of international problems.

title: Brutal Melee in a Tavern Involves Police and Patrons
description: ROEBLING, March 11Last Saturday evening, 300 young men and women were In the Village Tavern here, drinking, dancing or listening to a sixpiece Pennsylvania musical group known as Black Rose.

title: Cabaret: Helen Schneider Sings
description: After knocking around New England bars and clubs for six years and polishing her vocal technique in New York for two more, Helen Schneider has arrived at Tramp's, 125 East 15th Street, as a rounded, colorful and often electrifying singer.

title: Preserve Lives, Not Precedent
description: That was the reaction of Carmi Deleonardis, a Chicago bartenderand of many othersto the release, pending trial, of the leader of the Hanafi Moslem terrorists in Washington. An understandable reaction, based on the not unreasonable fear that the seeming leniency might set an inviting precedent for future gunmen. But wrong.

title: Showings to Resume On Mohammad Film
description: Showings of Mohammad. Messenger of God. which had been stopped simultaneously at two movie houses in Manhattan, one on Long Island, and one in Montclair, N.J.. on Wednesday because of protests against it by Hanafi Moslems, will be resumed at 2 P.M. today at the four United Artists theaters.

description: Horses listed In order or post positions

title: Randall M. Dubois Is Dead at 61, Consulting Transport Engineer
description: Randall M. Dubois, a consulting engineer specializing in transportation, died Thursday in Glen Cove (L.I.) Community Hospital, after a short illness. He lived at Wolver Hollow Road, Oyster Bay, L.I., and was 61 years old.

title: Convicted ExDacca Chief Cleared of 2d Charge
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 11 (AP)Former President Khandaker Moshtaque Ahmed, sentenced to five years in prison last month after having been convicted of misusing $64,000 in public funds, has been acquitted of a second corruption charge.

description: Article 1  No Title

title: Shaken Hostages Tell of Days of Terror
description: WASHINGTON, March 11I was waiting my turn to go to the men's room, and all of a sudden the two terrorists on guard faded away. I heard a noise, and then there was a beautiful sight: the Metropolitan police.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 12, 1977

title: Willem Schermerhorn Dies at 82; Netherlands First Postwar Premier
description: HAARLEM, the Netherlands, March 11 (AP)Willem Schermerhorn, the Netherlands' first Prime Minister after World War 11, died last night. He was 82 years old.

title: Federal Center Reports Outbreak of Syndrome
description: ATLANTA, March 11(UPI)The Federal Center for Disease Control said today that 152 suspected cases of Reye's syndrome and 18 deaths have been reported since Jan. 1, but that earlier diagnosis of the usually severe disease may be reducing the number of fatalities.

title: New Choreography By Trisha Brown At Brooklyn House
description: There are two ways at looking at Trisha Brown's choreography. One is to look at the movement in terms of itself. The other is to be aware of how the sequences of the same movement are organized.

title: British Rail Ending Ladies Only Sections
description: LONDON, March 11Britain's nationalized railroad system has abandoned the 100yearold custom of Ladies Only compartments on trains

title: Princess Anne to Visit Ulster
description: LONDON. March 11 (AP)Princess Anne, fourth in line to the British throne, will spend a day in Northern Ireland later this month. Buckingham Palace announced today. The princess, who is president of the Save the Children Fund in Britain, will fly to the province March 23 for the spring meeting of the Fund of Northern Ireland.

title: Nets, Led by Bantom, Defeat Suns, 8273
description: UNIONDALE. L.I., March 11 (AP)Mike Bantom scored 6 points and pulled down 10 rebounds in the third quarter to spark the New York Nets to an 8273 victory over the Phoenix Suns in the National Basketball Association tonight.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY. MARCH 11. 1977

title: U.S. GIVES NEW YORK A $255 MILLION LOAN UNTIL 30TH OF JUNE
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal today approved New York City's request for a $255 million shortterm Federal loan as a key part of the plan to tide the city over the shoals of threatened bankruptcy.

title: Socialist Candidate in India Goes on Hunger Strike
description: NEW DELHI, India, March 11 (UPI)The Socialist Party leader, George Fernandes, began a hunger strike today to protest Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's refusal to let him out of prison so he can campaign for next week's election.

title: U.S. to Negotiate On Pooled Fund For Commodities
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Carter Administration is willing to discuss how to create and pay for huge stockpiles of major commodities that could be tapped to stabilize global commodity prices. The Administration's decision to enter international negotiations is considered a major concession to developing nations.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: L O. SCHWARTZ SEEKS UNSEATING OF GOLDIN
description: Charging that Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin not only had failed to be forthright about New York City's failing finances but had also misused political contributions. Louis O. Schwartz. a former campaign aide to Senator Daniel P. Moynihan. announced his candidacy for Mr. Goldin's job.

title: Brazil Cancels Military Aid Treaty Over U.S. Report on Human Rights
description: BRASILIA, March 11  Brazil canceled its 25yearold military assistance treaty with the United States today over a State Department report criticizing its human rights practices.

title: Daughter of Judge Killed
description: SMITHFIELD, R. I., March 11 (AP)Mary Bevilacqua, the 22yearold daughter of Chief Justice Joseph A. Bevilacqua of the Rhode Island Supreme Court, was killed in a car accident last night. Three other persons were injured.

title: Salt Contamination of Water in Oklahoma Is Linked to Oil Producers
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 11Federal water experts have found evidence of widespread salt water contamination in Oklahoma's third largest underground fresh water basin and they believe massive operations by oil producers to inject salt water are responsible.

title: Eder Named Times Drama Critic
description: The appointment of Richard Eder as drama critic of The New York Times, starting next September, was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor of the newspaper.

title: Money
description: Friday, March 11, 1977

title: MARSHALL CHARGES SAFETY LAW FLOUTED
description: WASHINGTON, March l1Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall said today that his department's occupational safety and health program had been sabotaged from the beginning by the Nixon and Ford Administrations and was now in a state of chaos.

title: 2 Kinds of Pursuits in Films
description: There's a bit of real humor in the reverse sexism rampant in "The Great Texas Dynamite Chase" about two pretty, smalltown Texas girls, one an escaped con and the other a former, very rude bank teller, who join forces to rob banks, outwit the cops and ravish the men of their choosing. The film, directed by Michael Pressman and written by David Kirkpatrick and Mark Rosin, opened yesterday at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters on a bill with "New Girl in Town.""The Great Texas Dynamite Chase" stars Claudia Jennings and Jocelyn Jones as the two young women who successfully manage their heists without anyone's being seriously injured until near the end. An ironic end-credit card attempts to recoup the film's earlier, lighthearted cynicism and almost succeeds.Like every other low-budget, regional melodrama of this kind, the movie is virtually constructed of automobile chases in which every shot of the lead car turning a corner, hitting a bump or swerving to avoid a truck must be repeated by a shot of the pursuing car dealing with the same set of circumstances. Instead,??? of increasing suspense, this sort of duplication cuts suspense in half. Why don't movie makers learn?"New Girl in Town" is set largely in Nashville, where it was apparently made, and tells the sad story of a once-sweet little farm girl named Jamie Barker (Monica Gayle)???, who climbs to the top of the country-and-western ladder by sleeping with or being raped by the right people.When she reaches her goal, Jamie realizes such success is just a sham. She has paid too high a price for the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow and the blue bird of happiness should have listened to the handwriting on the wall. It's that kind of film.

title: Monroe Is Cleared In Inquiry by N.B.A.
description: After a whirlwind inquiry yesterday, the National Basketball Association concluded that there was nothing untoward about Earl Monroe's lastsecond basket for the other team in the Knicks 108104 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers on Thursday night.

title: SACCHARIN BAN STIRS DEMAND TO CURB F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON,March 11The Food and Drug Administration's decision to ban the use of saccharin in foods and beverages prompted a Congressional challenge today and demands to curb the powers of the agency.

title: U.S. GENERAL TO JOIN ARMS TALK IN SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, March 11President Carter, in an apparent gesture to the military and his Senate critics, has named a representative of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to the American delegation that will discuss arms control matters in Moscow later this month.

title: India's BirthControl Program May Be Casualty of Election Campaign
description: NEW DELHI, March 8Doctors and familyplanning workers around India are concerned that one of the principal casualties of the current election campaign will be the country's birthcontrol program.

description: WASHINGTON, March 11Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal today approved New York City's request for a $255 million shortterm Federal loan as a key part of the plan to tide the city over the shoals of threatened bankruptcy.

description: What can city possibly do for a Fourth of July encore that would be worthy of last year's fabulous Operation Sail? Well, how about another OpSail?
