description: AT COLUMBIA

title: P.B.A. CONTRACT DISPUTE IS GOING TO ARBITRATION
description: Representatives of New York City and the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association will meet tomorrow afternoon with Arvid Anderson, chairman of the Office of Collective Bargaining, to discuss procedures for binding arbitration of their long contract dispute.

title: Diane Ellen Klein Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Klein of Highland Park, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Diane Ellen Klein, to Bruce Zachary Morgenstern son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Morgenstern of Plainview, L. I. An August wedding is planned. Miss Klein is a senior at Pennsylvania State University. Her fianc, who graduated from Pennsylvania State University, is a thirdyear student at Jefferson Medical College.

title: Memorial Services
description: THALHEIMERDr. Ross. There will be a memorial service far Dr. Ross Thalheimer on Monday Mar. 14 at 4 P.M. at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 E. 79 St.

title: It's Full Speed Ahead for Antique Boats
description: You won't find them among the Tiffany daffodil lamps or the Sung porcelain or the oak rolltop desks. In fact, you'll have a hard time finding them at all these days. Antique boats are in demand. And that old wreck that has been sitting in the corner of your local boatyard for years could be a classic.

title: A Way of Life Dies
description: SEVERAL years ago, a newcomer to the state drove in a desultory way for a couple of days through that northwestern part of New Jersey where Sussex meets Pennsylvania, the area near the Delaware Water Gap. It was a place of many trees, rocks, creeks and small deltas, of farms, rural villages, R.F.D. post offices and rusting harvesters, country that appeared to have been forgotten by the present.

title: Law
description: No Supreme Court case in recent years has stirred more passion than Regents of California v. Bakke. The question it presents is whether state universities may set aside a number of places for minority students and fill them by a special admissions program. The California Supreme Court said no. It held preferential admissions unconstitutionala denial to white applicants of the equal protection of the laws guaranteed by the 14th Amendment.

title: 2d Woman Slain With a .44 Pistol Is Buried as the Police Seek Killer
description: The 20yearold Columbia University student who was shot to death last Tuesday night near her home in Forest Hills, Queens, was buried yesterday in Maple Grove Cemetery, Kew Gardens, Several hundred people attended the mass for Virginia Voskerichian in the Edward D. Jamie Funeral Chapel at 14126 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, Queens.

title: Of Arms and a Man;
description: There will be no significant limitation or reduction of nuclear arms in the world unless a broad majority of Americans accepts the proposition that superiority in strategic weaponry is a mirage. If the Soviet leaders do not accept that doctrine, the superpowers will be doomed to a costly and unending arms race in which neither will achieve significant security or advantage. But we shall never know whether the Russians accept it unless Americans do, and proceed to test them in arms control negotiations.

title: Spinning Disks and Studying Law
description: SHE is a timeclock with a personality. She is a machine that smiles, thinks, talks and has ambition. She is Miss Miller, she is Carol Miller. The Carol Miller.

title: Indonesia Charged With Atrocities
description: WASHINGTON, March 12A report circulating on Capitol Hill says that Indonesia may have committed the most serious case of contravention of human rights facing the world at this time in the alleged killing of thousands of civilians in East Timor over the past year.

title: MOVIES
description: ELMONT39 Steps, Robert Donat and Madeleine Carroll in the thriller; Wednesday 7:30 P.M.; Public Library, 1735 Hempstead Tpke. Free.

title: CONNECTICUT TOWNS TRAINDEPOT RIVALS
description: Stamford and Bridgeport are emerging as rivals in an apparent contest to determine which of the two shall be the only highspeed rail stop in Fairfield County, Conn.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Both of New York's opera houses have staged Alban Berg's Wozzeck, but his last, unfinished opera, Lulu, has been avoided. Lulu is considered by many a masterpiece, even if it was not particularly admired by the Young Turks of the 1950's. Andr Hodeir called it uneven and occasionally quite lurid, with a basic contradiction between theatrical imperatives and the tonerow technique. Pierre Boulez feared that Lulu is too clearly stamped with the expressionistic esthetic of 1920, and that it will become dated rather than marking a date.

title: Eve Auchincloss Is Married
description: St. Albans Episcopal Church in Washington was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Eve La Grange Auchindoss, daughter of Reginald L. Auphindoss Jr. of New York and Mrs. Carleton Putnam of McLean, Va., to William Lilley 3d, a visiting professor of government at the University of Virginia. He is a son of the late Mr. Lilley Jr. of Philadelphia and the late Mrs. James K. Wark of Marion, Pa.

title: Gail McDonald Bride Of Jeffrey J. Murphy
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Gail McDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Mitchell McDonald of Stratford, Conn., to Jeffrey John Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Francis Murphy of Poway, Calif. The Rev. Gerard Di Senso performed the ceremony.

title: Flames Break Away in Key Game, 63
description: ATLANTA, March 12Scoring three goals in the final period, two off Ranger skates and one that climbed crazily up the arm of John Davidson, the goalie, the Atlanta Flames beat the New York Rangers tonight, 63. Bill Clement, the intrepid worker, had three goals for Atlanta.

title: Pollini   The Prodigy Has Reached Maturity
description: Maurizio Pollini, the Italian pianist who will give a recital Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, has had an unusual careerand an instructive one. He was born in 1942 in Milan, the son of an architect whose bestknown project was the Olivetti factory near Milan.

title: CHESS
description: Aprominent factor in Mark Diesen's brilliant success in winning the World Junior championship in Groningen, the Netherlands, was his solid, practical opening repertoire. The 19year* old international master from Potomac, Md., has a natural style that tends strongly toward conservative, positional play, and he worked outwith the help of his very capable coach, Grandmaster Lubomir Kavalek of Reston, Va.variations that gave him consonant middle games.

title: Notes: Resorts Cool To Student Invasion
description: Vacationing college students will begin heading south this week on their annual ritesofspring migration to beach resorts in Florida, Bermuda and the Caribbean. But judging from reports trickling north, many of them will receive a lessthanwarm welcome.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: I'M NOT the bestliked guy in the Jersey delegation in any vote of my colleagues. . . The words come in a torrent from the lips of Representative Andrew Maguire, the fiery Ph.D. and maverick liberal Democrat now serving his second term in Congress.

title: Israel Police Break Up Protests By Arab Students on West Bank
description: TEL AVIV, March 12 (Reuters)Israeli border policemen swinging nightsticks and firing teargas grenades today broke up demonstrations by Arab students in Nablus and Ramallah in the occupied West Bank, miliary government sources said.

title: How to Commute in 2 or More Seats
description: IT'S five minutes before the 6:17 leaves Hoboken, and the vacant seats are beginning to fill rapidly with homewardbound commuters. To the uninitiated, it may appear that these oncoming passengers have a free choice of the vacant seats  that they can sit anywhere.

title: Black Coats and Scarlet Epaulets
description: Robins and crocuses are urban signs of spring, but country folk look for pussy willows and redwing blackbirds. The redwings, those blackbirds that wear red epaulets, usually arrive just ahead of the robins, and their loud okallee from the bogside trees and bushes is as clear a spring summons as anyone could ask. The redwings know when the deep ice begins to melt in the swamps and they usually are here to see it happen.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in last Sunday's Times inadvertently attributed a remark describing a former Soviet general, Pyotr Grigorenko, as a communist with small e, to the general's son, Andrei P. Grigorenko. In the same article, the transposition of a phrase erroneously indicated that Michael Harrington, the writer, had said Marx and Lenin were advocates of human rights.

title: Study Shows The Courage Of Chickadees
description: Chickadees may be tiny and friendly birds, but when nesting time comes they will often harass and even attack large predators such as hawks and owls.

title: LETTER FROM MAMARONECK HIGH SCHOOL
description: IN just one year the attitude of the students at Mamaroneck High School has been transformed. The students of last year were lethargic and cynical. This year's students analyze less, achieve more.

title: Barbara Neff Smith, 69, Art Patron Active in New York and Chicago
description: Barbara Neff Smith, a lifelong patron of the arts in Chicago and New York, died Friday at RushPresbyterian St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago. She was 69 years old and lived in Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Long Island man has been arrested on grand larceny charges and accused of faking his own kidnapping in an effort to extract a ransom payment from his wife.

title: LECTURES
description: BRIARCLIFF MANORJohn Leak, poet. Tuesday at 10:50 A.M. Squire Hall, The King's College. 9417200.

title: Plans for an Indoor Season Weighed By North American Soccer League
description: A recommendation for a 12game indoor season was the most significant development at the North American Soccer League meeting in Tampa, Fla., last Thursday and Friday. Of the 18 clubs, according to Commissioner Phil

title: 3 Works Performed By Lyric Arts Trio
description: The New York Lyric Arts Trio, an ensemble of Juilliard graduates that made its local debut last season, performed a concert Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall that ended much better than it started.

title: Election Calendar
description: THE state's busy election season begins officially this month with schoolboard balloting, followed in short order by campaigning for Governor and the Legislature. Between now and the end of the year, there are at least 23 significant days when politically active New Jarseyans may have an extra interest.

title: Student Wins Battle With State Computer
description: ALBANY, March 12 (AP)A western New York student who battled with a stubborn computer to obtain the Regents scholarship he won now has two scholarships:

title: A Wee Drop of the Dew
description: 'Tis the season to be Irishat least In spirits.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: In This Issue

title: Moon Church Among Issues
description: VOTERS go to the polls in Westchester County on Tuesday to decide a series of local skirmishes, but it is doubtful that the results will signal any clearcut shift in the increasingly vigorous struggle for power between the Democrats and Republicans. One of the most controversial issues centers on efforts by the Unification Church, which is headed by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, to develop a university in Tarrytown.

title: Taking the sixties seriously
description: A combination of literary criticism, cultural history, politics, and personal reminiscence, Morris Dickstein's interpretation of the 1960's rests on the cultural achievements of the period it describes. Without the sixties, Dickstein writes, such a combination would have seemed less imaginable, more illegitimate. His book helps to explain the reasons for this important change in sensibility.

title: A Health Bill For Consumers
description: STAGGERING annual increases in the nation's health bill have become a sad fixture in society. However, evidence from several years of hospital ratesetting activity in New Jersey has shown that cost controls based on reasonableness criteria are possible without giving up a high quality of health care.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: OVER the years, I have noticed that a number of people I know have been doing more and more of their work at home. Many years ago few people worked at home unless they took in washing, but in our times it has become something of a symbol of independence, a mark that one is not slaving over machines but is earning a living, or part of one, by dint of art or cerebration.

title: A Bit of Dublin for St. Patrick's Day
description: A thousand years ago the Danes created Dublin as a naval base and stamped it with the culture and speech of the Ostmen. Later the Normans reshaped it and made Norman French the official tongue. When Cromwell took over Ireland, and did his damnedest to bend Irish character to his will, Dublin seethed helplessly. Only a bit more than 50 years ago did it become the chief city of an independent nation.

title: Poor Find Friends At Fuel Banks
description: THE Rev, Thomas J. Lynch, an official of the Hartford Archdiocese, likes to boast about the way the people of Connecticut have responded in recent months to the needs of those citizens without the funds to keep warm during this extraordinarily harsh winter, New England provincialism got nailed to the wall this winter, he exclaimed.

title: Peter Gibson Fiance Of Susan C. Latimer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Latimer of Copenhagen and Stuart, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan C. Latimer, to Peter M. Gibson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Garnet L. Gibson Jr. of Salem, Mass. The couple plan to be married. in Marblehead. Mass., on May 28.

title: Dale Meryl Greenfeld Plans To Wed Marc David Kaplan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Aaron L. Greenfeld of New York and White Meadow Lake, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dale Meryl Greenfeld, to Marc David Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Kaplan of South Orange, N.J. The wedding is planned for June.

title: MUSIC
description: TAKE a New Yorkbased director and conductor, add solo singers from the Metropolitan and New York City Opera companies, fortify with a chorus of New York professionals, stir well, and what do you have? An unusually vibrant and successful Connecticut opera company. It is called State Opera Inc., and under the watchful tutelage of local residents it has produced 23 operas over the last eight years. No. 24 will be Verdi's Rigoletto, this Saturday night at 8:15, in the Hartman Theatre on Atlantic Street in downtown Stamford.

title: Clinton's Shuttle Downs McKee in P.SA.L. Final
description: McKee must have thought Clinton had 10 men on the court during yesterday's Public Schools Athletic League basketball final at St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens. The Governors played with only five at a time, hut got big contributions from 10 as they defeated McKee, 7367. It was the 19th P.S.A.L. title for the Bronx school.

title: Must Do, but When?
description: QUITE a few things have happened in our state in recent months, and a couple of others like the St. Patrick's Day parade in Jersey City and a meeting of the Livingston Bottle Clubare scheduled for today. I must admit that I have been neglectful of many of them.

title: BRIDGE
description: THE most prestigious event in the Westchester contractbridge calendar now has a winner who is not a winner. A sextet of young expertsKen Arnold of Irvington, Jeff Rubens and Jim Rosenbloom of Scarsdale, Chuck Lamprey and Marty Begen of White Plains and Monroe Ingberman of Hartsdaleare the only undefeated team in the knockout team championship, but they have not won the eventyet.

title: Miss Groves Sets Nuptials
description: Philippa Caroline Wilson Groves, who is with Charles Hammond Ltd., interior designers in London, and Ira Stuart Outerbridge 3d, who is studying law at the Middle Temple in London, will be married June 25 in New York.

title: A Profits Jackpot In Slot Machines
description: CHICAGOUnlike the usual employee recreation room with its rows of vending machines and a pingpong table, at the Bally Manufacturing Corporation here three walls are jammed with klanging, cartoonfaced pinball machines and the fourth is lined with the latest models in slot machineseverything from standard 5centers to threeplay, doubleornothing monsters that take only silver dollars.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Being no more or less schizoid than most critics, I submitted to the following interview with myself last week in the hopes of picking up a number of loose ends. It's not as adventurous as facing the tape recorder of a stranger though it does have its risks. If things go badly one can only blame oneself, which is not pleasant and never practical.

title: Russia and Cuba Reported Trying to End African Role of U.S. and China
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 12A number of Western and Middle Eastern diplomats say that the Soviet Union and Cuba appear to have begun an attempt to eject American and Chinese influence from Africa, particularly the eastern part of the continent.

title: Portisch Gains 2Point Advantage In Chess Contest Against Larsen
description: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 12 (AP)  Lajos Portisch of Hungary drew one adjourned game and won another to gain a 2point lead at the halfway mark of his quarterfinal candidates chess match against Bent Larsen of Denmark.

title: Alexandra McKenna to Be Bride May 25
description: Alexandra Veronica McKenna, a singer with the Blue Hill Troupe, plans to be married May 25 to Ralph Irwin King 2d, who is in commercial sales with Cushman & Wakefield Inc., New York realestate concern.

title: Boe Denies Criticism, Voices Optimism, But Echo of Nets' Lost Glory Resounds
description: Ten months ago, after the New York Nets won the last championship of the American Basketball Association, Roy Lars Magnus Boe wandered around the raucous dressing room, his buttondown shirt open and his hair matted with champagne.

title: S.E.C. vs. Corporate Crime
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, to prove that there is no soft spot in its hardnosed attitude toward corporate delinquents, announced last week that it was now going to get even tougher with companies involved in illicit payments.

title: Diplomats Had Decided Money Offered to Khaalis Would Have Angered Him
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)The three Moslem Ambassadors who helped end the siege of three Washington buildings and gain the freedom of 134 hostages yesterday said that they had considered offering money to the Hanafi Moslem leader if he would agree to release the hostages but had decided that the offer would only anger him.

title: Send the Farmlands Your Sludge
description: TO a suburban housewife pondering supermarket prices, it might seem farfetched that decisions by the county government on waste disposal could have any impact on future food supplies and costs. There is, however, a relationship between waste management and food production that is becoming increasingly evident as we face up to the fact that agriculture as well as almost every other industry is having to make adjustments to changing conditions of modern life, including the growing and permanent energy shortage.

title: A Sizzling Battle in the Burger Business
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla.The sizzling question in the fastfood league this winter has been whether Whopper College, having hired away the team captain of Hamburger University, will now mount a major bid for the championship.

title: Champion Mare Dies During Jersey Pace
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., March 12 Tarport Hap, a 5yearold world champion pacing mare who had earned $688,664 in her career, collapsed and died tonight during the sixth race at the Meadowlands.

title: Marquette and So. Illinois Gain in N.C.A.A. Midwest
description: OMAHA, March 12 (AP)Jerome Whitehead and Bo Ellis rallied Marquette to a 6651 victory over Cincinnati in the first round of the National Collegate Midwest regional basketball tournament today.

title: Is Anyone Protecting The Consumer?
description: FOR more than a year, Westchester County's Consumer Protection Unit has been operating without guidance from a threemember policymaking board that was supposed to appoint officers to preside at hearings on violations of the consumer code. The situation has led to increased criticism that the present system of handling complaints is not living up to its promise.

title: ART
description: BRIDGEPORT  Exhibit of expressionist paintings by Robert Natkin, at U. of Bridgeport. Through March 22, Carlson Gallery of the Bernhard Center, 84 Iranistan Ave.

title: SPORTS
description: HARTFORD  Aetna World Cup Tennis Tournament 2 P.M. today. Civic Center. 5666000.

title: It's the Group I.Q. Tests That Flunk
description: AN elementary school permanent record card is a most challenging document. Besides the grades, attendance figures, health data and assorted comments, there is a plethora of standardized test results. Most are computergraded and the resultant computer printout adds the mark of truth, even infallibility, to these test results.

title: Boutique Baedeker
description: Boutiques for kids are booming. Although prices are higher, the clothes are different from those usually found in department stores. They're more individual in style, and many of them are imports from Europe. India and the Far East. Following is a list of some of the best boutiques around town.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Midtown Mall Proposed

title: Anti  Vandalism Is Its Own Reward
description: WHO in the springtime of life did not chronicle a love affair on the top of a school desk? We were forgiven or we forgot. But today even petty vandalism counts. Because of rising costs, schools across the country spend more money repainting, replacing smashed windows and repairing other damages than they spend on textbooks.

title: Fairfield's Hungarians Remember
description: FAIRFIELD EACH DAY AT NOON in Fairfield, the bells of St. Emery's Roman Catholic church toll in memory of the Hungarian hero John Hunyadi, a Christian crusader who liberated his homeland from the Turks in 1456.

title: Mets, Jets Are at Odds Over Shea Agreement
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12The New York Mets reported today that some misunderstandings had arisen that could jeopardize the agreement recently announced by Mayor Beame to keep the Jets football team from leaving Shea Stadium and moving to New Jersey.

title: Mt. Vernon's Gateway to Higher Education
description: FOR about 10 years after he finished high school, John Harris said that he didn't do much of anything. After serving in the Army, he just floated to this and that.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHEN Riley Regan, the recently appointed director of the State Department of Health's Division on Alcoholism, talks about his job, he does so from the inside and with an evangelist's enthusiasm.

title: Bulldog Captures 8th Best In Field of 2,029 at Suffern
description: SUFFERN, N.Y., March 12Ch. Show Biz Fairy Prince, a 63pound brindleandwhite bulldog, topped a field of 2,029 competitors tonight and won his eighth bestinshow victory at the Rockland County Kennel Club's 31st allbreed show in Rockland Community College.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The National Invitation Tournament, the oldest postseason competition in the country, moves into the quarterfinals at Madison Square Garden with a 7 P.M. doubleheader tomorrow, sending Virginia Tech against Alabama and Ilinois State against Houston. A Tuesday doubleheader at 7 P.M. pits Villanova against Massachusetts and Oregon against St. Bonaventure in the other game. The semifinals are 7 P.M. Thursday and the final at 1 P.M. next Sunday.

title: SAMUEL A. SINN
description: Samuel A. Sinn, past president of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx and a former member of the Real Estate Advisory Commission, Department of Real Estate of New York City, died Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at the Yale Club.

title: The Mystery of Coe Hall
description: IT was, appropriately, a dark and stormy night in late February. For the Island, winter 1977 was yielding to a thaw after so much snow and sleet and ice. A gray dusk was settling in as the four people, a man and his wife, their son and his young woman companion, set out in the car from their South Shore community and headed north.

title: There's a Fight in Nassau
description: Just as many of New York City's problems have spread into its suburbs, so too has its recently chaotic politics. These suburbs, once solidly Republican, are now electing Democrats in increasing numbers and Republican organizations, once monolithic and welldisciplined, are showing signs of increasing dissension.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 13, 1977

title: Assembly Committees Schedule 2 Hearings
description: The following public hearings will be held in the New York Metropolitan area by state legislative committees this week:

title: ART VIEW
description: Museum curators who organize exhibitions, even the major exhibitions that alter the very way we look at the art in question, are seldom known to or remembered by the public. Nor, as a general rule, is there much public appreciation of how much study, thought, travel, discussion, diplomacy and exhausting physical laboroften in the face of the most boring and discouraging obstaclesgo into the making of a major exhibition. In the opera house and the concert hall, the conductor is a highly visible presence, and when his labors are completed, he takes his bow and receives the grateful applause of his listeners. In the museum, his counterpartthe curator of exhibitionsremains an invisible man. It is left to fellowprofessionalsartists, art historians, critics and other museum peopleto honor and esteem his accomplishments, and this professional esteem is seldom given public expression.

title: A Hospice for the Terminally Ill
description: THE FIRST inpatient facility for the terminally ill in the United States is a step closer to reality because of pending Congressional action that is expected to pump $4 billion more into public works employment. Hospice Inc. of New Haven hopes that because of the Congressional action it will receive almost $3 million to build a care facility for the terminally ill in Branford.

title: F.D.A. Is Caught Between Demand For New Goods and Public Safety
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Food and Drug Administration's ability to assure the safety and usefulness of tens of thousands of household products has been torn between unending demands for new consumer goods and vastly more sophisticated methods of detecting potential dangers in those products.

title: Miss Burtchaell Wed To Theodore Ingalls, Gillette Company Aide
description: Donna Margaret Burtchaell daugnter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Edward Burtchaell of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Theodore Smith Ingalls, son of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore Hunt Ingalls of Framingham, Mass.

title: D. G. Morrow to Wed Rev. Sue A. Steffey
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Horner Steffey of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, the Rev. Sue Anne Steffey, to David Galvin Morrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Peter Morrow of Buffalo.

title: Father Rhine, Fallen To Industrial Waste...
description: BONNWhen Julius Caesar's armies pushed to the west bank of Europe's largest river in 51 B.C., local tribes told them it was called Rhenos, a word that may have meant clear. In the 19th century, the salmon that swam the broad and swiftflowing waters of Father Rhine were a delicacy often served with the valley's renowned white wines.

title: Cup Downhill To Walcher; Klammer 5th
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., March 12On a day in which the wind played favorites, gusting for some and subsiding for others, Josef Watcher of Austria registered a surprise victory today, capturing the World Cup men's downhill event at Heavenly Valley over a course considered by racers too easy.

title: State of the State: LowInterest Bonds
description: EACH year, state and local governments go to the money market in the United States for about $50 billion in loans, and some governments, like New York City's, have to go with their hats in hand. How, then, New Jersey? New Jersey fares well. For the most part, the bond houses, which act as middle men in borrowing, beat a path to the doors of the state and many local governments.

title: Rostropovich to Conduct Cello Ensemble In Anniversary Celebration
description: Cellists are chummy with each other. Perhaps because their instrument is so problematic, they have a great mutual sympathy. They go to hear each other play. They form organizations. Here in New York, they have the Violoncello Society, Inc., which was established in 1956. Although it is a bit late, the members are going to celebrate its 20th anniversary a week from Monday, on March 21 to be exact, at the 92d Street YMYWHA. It will be a gala occasion, in which a number of distinguished artists will take part. The eight works to be played will use anywhere from two to 32 cellists. On hand to conduct a couple of the works will be none other than Mstislay Rostropovich, the society's new honorary president.

title: Improving the breed
description: Given his racial and political premisesthat blueeyed, blond Nordics of unblemished pedigree constituted the Master Race whose mission was expressed in NazismHeinrich Himmler, Reichsfhrer of the Schutzstaffel (SS), was a terrifyingly logical man. Persons of racially valuable blood should he multiplied in or out of wedlock.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: ONE of these days, I said to my wife, I'm going to find it. So many talk about it. What's the big secret!

title: HiDiddelyDeeThe Writer's Life for Me!
description: In an interview after winning the Nobel Prize, Saul Bellow contended that most people don't pay any mind to writers, and his assessment struck me as correct.

title: Chilean Junta Bans All Political Parties, Widens Other Curbs
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 12 (AP)President Augusto Pinochet's military Government banned all political parties today in a further crackdown on critics of the fourman junta that has ruled Chile since 1973.

title: Washington State Captures Track Title
description: DETROIT, March 12Kenya won the team title today at the National Collegiate indoor track and field championships. It will not read that way in the official N.C.A.A. record hook, since the Kenyans competed for four different schools. Rut. their cumulative total in the twoday meet at Collo Arena was 33 points, well ahead of Washington State, the official team champion at 25. Texas at El Paso was second with 25 and Villanova third with 21

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: I have read with interest David Hicks's specious call for decreased educational spending [Feb. 27], and want very much to believe this will be consistent with the goal of greater scholastic achievement (measured, of course, by standardized test scores, as in the Briarcliff study).

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: That Antique Trail Is Really Much Longer

title: Linguistic Revisionism
description: Acceptable English, in its American version, is subject to frequent revision, one reason being the existence of a vigorous demotic. The linguistic melding of cultures has given the nation hominy (as in grits) from the Algonquian, coup (as in d'tat) from the French, the suffix nik (as in beatnik) from the Russian via the Yiddish and Mafia (as in Cosa Nostra) from the Italian.

title: A Gardener Reveals Her Special Secret for Early Success
description: Acoldframe is high on my list of primary gardening tools. It hastens spring, forestalls winter and serves me in all seasons. In late winter and early spring flower and vegetable seeds are started weeks earlier than possible in the open garden. Quick vegetables such as radish, green onions and lettuce can be grown to maturity right in the frame. Other seedlings of vegetables and flowers which have been started indoors on window sills, under lights or in the greenhouse are hardened off in our frame where they are protected from drying winds and sun, or chilly or rainy days. They are easily watered and fertilized as needed.

title: Others May Follow the Brazilian Lead
description: BUENOS AIRESPresident Carter's human rights campaign, expressed in reduced military aid to South American dictatorships, has provoked such anger in some regimes that a fundamental change seems under way in the relationship between Washington and the Latin capitals.

title: Evaluating The State in $
description: IN THE last couple of years, New Jersey has become a $100 billion state, with nine of its 567 towns billiondollar cities.

title: ART
description: GARDEN CITYAfroAmerican Festival exhibition of photographs by Lawrence Sykes and paintings by Hale Woodruff; through March 30; Sundays through Thursdays 11:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Wednesdays 7 to 9 P.M.; Firehouse Art Gallery, Nassau Community College. Reception today 3 P.M.

title: Steakhouse's Cattle Need Not Fear About Becoming the Main Course
description: OMI, N. Y.Those to whom a hearty steak evokes images of dusty Western plains and Zane Grey cattle drives might he surprised to find that that steak may have originated all the way back East in New York State.

title: New Detroit Center Raises Hopes Of an Aging Industrial Crescent
description: DETROIT, March 12Fabulous! the man said. Its incredible. He had strolled in off the street the other day for his first look at the vast atrium. or lobby, of the new Detroit Plaza Hotel, with its spaceage geometry and halfacre lake, cozy nooks, potted fig trees and broad expanses of skylight.

title: College Results
description: MIDWEST REGIONAL

title: The Buyers' Champion
description: Confrontation is not Carole Ginsburg's style. She says that by nature and vocation she usually acts upon her indignation by seeking solutions, compromises on elements upon which people with differing points of view can agree.

title: The Nation
description: The reports that specialinterest groups have filed on contributions they made in 1976 to Congressional campaigns demonstrate once again how carefully such groups pick the legislative targets they want to influence.

title: Anniversary
description: Joan La Pidus

title: Braynard Launching New Ops
description: FRANK O. BRAYNARD, a resident of Sea Cliff and impresario of Op Sail '76 and Operation Sail in 1964, is hard at work planning his next two nautical extravaganzas.

title: A HARROWING START TO B'NAI B'RITH JOB
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  On Wednesday, his 68th day as B'nai B'rith's new executive vice president, Dr. Daniel Thursz had scheduled a meeting to discuss his first major innovation, a reorganization of B'nai B'rith's large headquarters staff.

title: A TV President?
description: How can President Carter be so adept at managing the symbols and images he wants for his Administrationthe walk down Pennsylvania Avenue, the downhome atmosphere the telephone callinand yet be so inept at establishing a decent working relationship with an overwhelmingly Democratic Congress?

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABCAM: Message of Israel. Address by RabbiEmeritus David J. Seligson of the Central Synagogue.

title: Helen Akin Childs Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James H. Childs Jr. of Sewickley. Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Akin Childs of Boston, to Robert Garfield Burns of Cohasset. Mass., son of Mrs. Alfred H. Burns of Weymouth, Mass., and the late Mr. Burns. A summer wedding is planned. The future bridegroom's marriage was terminated by divorce.

title: A Showcase for Artisans Thrives in Cranbury
description: THE HOBBY BARN, a cheerful red shop, houses an unusual enterprise in the quaint, rural Middlesex County town of Cranbury. Run by four womenall are of European extractionit is a showcase for more than 100 artisans in the area who bring their handiwork to the tiny shop to sell on a consignment basis.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Practically the first thing we come across in the delectable cabaretstyle revue that's been made of some Jules Feiffer cartoons and called Hold Me! is a grownup. Well, no, he's not the first thing. We've already become acquainted with a young fellow who looks rather like a hedgehogmasses of spiky hair, enormous hornrims, pouting lower lipand who is very, very depressed because he knows that deep down inside he's rotten. Actually, he's tried to get over his rottenness by being nice to people, but this has backfired because it's worked. The nicer he is to people, the more popular he becomes socially, but being popular socially hasn't diminished his rottenness in the least, which means that he feels guilty as well as rotten because, after all, he's added hypocrisy to his list of poor characteristics.

title: The Sugar Blues
description: Will the moves by Washington and Ottawa to ban the sale of saccharin sweeten the price of sugar, the most depressed commodity on the world market?

title: Army Will Eliminate 592 Jobs At Its Rocky Mountain Arsenal
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)  The Army will abolish nearly 600 civilian jobs at the Rocky Mountain Arsenal in Denver after a program for neutralizing chemical warfare emissions has ended.

title: Carl Drake Jr., Insurance Company Head, Weds Charlotte Hannaford Day in St. Paul
description: Charlotte Hannaford Day of Brookside, N.J., was married yesterday afternoon to Carl Bigelow Drake Jr. of St. Paul, son of Mrs. Drake, also of St. Paul, and the late Dr. Drake.

title: BILL IN ALBANY ASKS FLEXIBLE WORK TIME
description: ALBANY, March 12A Unibill has been introduced in the Legislature, and, according to its sponsors, it will increase the availability of services to the public, develop employment opportunities for women, older workers, the handicapped and other overlooked groups, and improve morale throughout the state work force.

title: Heating the Home by Stove
description: Since last December, Dr. Lawrence Lieberman of Glen Rock, N.J., has had the only warm house on his block.

title: Yanks' Wynn, Gullett Star But Klutts's Hand Broken
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 12 The sun was shining today, the temperature was in the high 70's and the Yankees beat the Baltimore Orioles, 50. Jim Wynn hit a grand slain home run, Don Gullett pitched impressively in his first three innings as a Yankee and Alike Heath, a young catcher, threw out all three Orioles who tried to steal.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: Governor Byrne should veto the recently passed bill that would require a period of solemn meditation in the New Jersey public schools.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Although the large silver coin pictured at right is called a Bryan Dollar in the books, it is actually an antiBryan medal that was issued during the Presidential campaign of 1896 when William J. Bryan (whose birthday is March 19) was running against William McKinley. And since McKinley did win that campaign by a slim margin, this medal may have helped give the McKinley forces their final push to victory against Bryan.

title: Dr. Mary Harris, Intern, Wed to Eric Forsythe
description: Dr. Mary Catherine Harris, an intern at the Children's Hospital Medical Center in Boston, was married yesterday afternoon to Eric Forsythe, managing director of the Tufts University Theater in Medford, Mass. The Rev. Simeon L. Gardner performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Chapel of SS, Faith, Hope and Charity.

title: Exploring the Islands of Greece By Private YachtLuxurious, Independent and Cheap
description: Our every whim was indulged. Mention a wish, any wish. Dolmades for dinner every night? Manoli, our chefsteward, guide and general factotum, would smile and say, Why not? Whatever you like. It's your ship.

description: BRIDGEPORTModelbuilding contest for boys and girls up to 13. Trucks, planes. miscellaneous vehicles and best of show at North End Boys Club, Madison Ave. To register, call 3675812.

title: Pa. Group Backs Bill to Aid Breeders
description: The Pennsylvania Horse Breeders Association currently one of the most powerful state equestrian organizations in the country, was founded in 1945.

title: Technology Is Available For Massive Irrigation From the Great Rivers
description: JERUSALEMThere will be a note of urgency in the discussions at the United Nations Water Conference at Mar del Plata, Argentina, on the exploitation of water resources chiefly by irrigationto solve the world's food needs. According to a 1973 forecast by the Food and Agriculture Organization, it will be necessary to increase the amount of land under cultivation by 75 percent by 1985 to avert serious shortages in global food production and much of that increase will require improved or new uses of water.

title: VOLUNTEERS HELPING YOUTHS ON PROBATION
description: Theresa Norman, a young college student who became acquainted with 15yearold Billy last November, always knew he had run afoul of the law. After all, that was how they had met. But it was not until recently that Billy confided to her that he was on five years' probation for possession of narcotics.

title: Police Failed to Follow a Complaint on Cowan
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.Frederick W. Cowan, the Nazi follower who killed five persons, including a police officer, before he took his own life last month, threatened to kill a white woman neighbor over a racial matter 18 months ago, the woman said in an interview.

title: Meg Glaubinger Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman C. Glaubinger of Westfield, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Meg Glaubinger, to Robert B. Meckelburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Richard Meckelburg bf Needham and New Seabury, Mass. The future bride is a graduate of Syracuse University, from which her fianc was graduated cum laude.

title: Major Foe of Gandhi Puts Some Excitement Into Election Campaign
description: BHIWANI, India, March 8Looking out over the rows of villagers at a big, noisy campaign rally, Jagjivan Ram paused an instant and then, with a nightclub comedian's sense of timing, delivered one of his favorite lines: Under Indira Gandhi, people's government has been replaced by a oneperson ruleor rather, I should say, oneandonehalfperson rule.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONLabormanagement relations in the building and construction industry, traditionally as bloody and bizarre as the political life of ancient Byzantium, had been showing marked improvement.

description: By Forrest Webb. 203 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $6.95.

title: Lincoln with the emotional charge of McKinley
description: On first thought it is hard to understand why anybody should write a new biography of Abraham Lincoln. More books have already been published about Lincoln than about any other American, and many of them are excellent. No other biography is ever likely to supersede Carl Sandburg's engrossing, warmly human portrait of Lincoln. As a shrewdly critical, yet sympathetic, account of his wartime administration, Lincoln the President, by J. G. Randall and Richard N. Current, remains definitive. For readers Who prefer a compact biography, Reinhard Luthin's The Real Lincoln is factfilled and accurate. The standard onevolume biography, however, has long been Benjamin P. Thomas's Abraham Lincoln, a work of exceptional scholarship and literary skill published in 1952. ly human portrait of Lincoln. As a shrewdly critical, yet sympathetic, account of his wartime administration, Lincoln the President, by J. G. Randall and Richard N. Current, remains definitive. For readers Who prefer a compact biography, Reinhard Luthin's The Real Lincoln is factfilled and accurate. The standard onevolume biography, however, has long been Benjamin P. Thomas's Abraham Lincoln, a work of exceptional scholarship and literary skill published in 1952.

title: PAKISTANI OPPOSITION HARDENS ITS DEMANDS
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 12After a day of urban strife yesterday that brought troops out here and in a number of other cities, the opposition today hardened its demands on Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, and the Prime Minister went on television tonight to plead with his foes to keep the peace.

title: It's All There Now For Tenor Placido Domingo
description: When Placido Domingo steps on the Metropolitan Opera stage Wednesday night as Don Alvaro in Verdi's La Forza del Destino. it will be the 1,209th performance of his career, his 34th Alvaro and his 108th appearance at the Met. Let's see, the tenor muses, rapidly leafing through a pocketsized engagement book. My 700th performance was in Traviata at the Met in 1971, 800 was Tosca in Vienna, 900 was Francesca da Rimini in New York, 1,000 was Forza in Hamburg, 1,100 was Chenier in San Francisco, 1,200 was Otello in Barcelona. He pauses, looks up and flashes a boyish grin, I like statistics.

title: Pope Said to be Over the Flu
description: ROME, March 12 (UPI)Tho Vatican said today that Pope Paul VI has recovered from the influenza that struck him Wednesday and has resumed his normal activities. The Pope received a delegation of Belgian bishops and Vatican sources said he would be appearing as usual on Sunday on his balcony overlooking St. Peter's Square.

title: Fifth Avenue Lease
description: With the signing of three new leases, the 111,000squarefoot Rolex Building at 665 Fifth Avenue is almost 90 percent rented.

title: Irish Tunes Offered by Brady and Irvine
description: The Chieftans have singlehandedly initiated a vogue for Irish folk music during the last year with their successful albums and concert tours of North America, and during this time they have been without serious competition. Planxty, which was formed in 1972, could easily have won over the Chieftans' audience, but their records were never widely heard here, and recently the group broke up.

title: Army Plans Nuclear Unit Shifts
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)The Army says it will move field elements of its nuclear agency from Fort Bliss, Tex., to agency headquarters at Fort Belvoir, Va., by late this year. As a result, 26 military personnel and 16 civilian jobs will be transferred. Civil Service employees who decline transfers will receive priority rights to job replacement in other defense agencies, the Army said Thursday.

title: Conservation Planting Includes the Birds;
description: Just a few months ago, gardeners were concerned about local bird populations because their food supply was locked in ice and snow. Many homeowners who never fed birds before, got into the habit.

title: FILMS
description: BRIDGEPORTBugs Bunny, Daffy Duck and Popeye are among the classic cartoons to be shown by the cinema department of U. of Bridgeport, Thursday, 8:30 and 10:30 P.M. Room 807, the Bernhard Center. 75 cents.

title: Barbara Rothenstein Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Rothenstein of Lawrence, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Anne Rothenstein, to Daniel S. Budasoff, son of Dr. and Mrs. Israel Budasoff of Hollywood, Fla.

title: Christian Parley on Africa Urges Immediate Black Rhodesia Rule
description: MARCY, N.Y.. March 11  Eighty Protestant and Roman Catholic church leaders25 of them from countries in southern Africacalled this week for an immediate transfer of power from the white minority to the black majority in Rhodesia. The situation there, they said, had reached a new level of urgency.

title: A Recent Government Report Said, The Tranquility Is Deceptive
description: A Government advisory committee cautioned the Attorney General earlier this month about the resilient nature of terrorism and urban disorder in the United States.

title: Around. the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)1 The Federal Trade Commission is dropping a proposed ban on television advertisements that induce children to buy cereals or other products by offering toys or prizes as comeons.

title: POLITICS
description: IS there is anything worse than losing an election, it is running a campaign that is misunderstood, dismissed as a lark or interpreted as being of someone else's strategy.

title: Thai Government Asking For Large Aid Increases To Finance Development
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 12Thailand has asked the 16 countries that have been its principal sources of foreign aid for huge increases in grants and loans over the next five years to help finance its development projects.

title: A Snag for Margiotta
description: THE bitter struggle for the Republican nomination for Nassau County Executive may already have had a decisive impact on the political career of one of the state's most powerful Republican county leaders, Joseph M. Margiotta.

title: Rome's Jews Expected to Get Their Ancestors' Catacombs
description: ROME, March 12The carved inscriptions speak of the lives of Sabine, Aurelia Flavia, Pegaianos the scribe and Maria Maroni. And the ancient wall paintings depict the religion of these people with menorahs, shofars and scrolls.

title: Editors' Choice
description: FALCONER, by John Cheever. (Knopf, $7.95.) A man in prison, his emergence into a light; a novel of almost liturgical intensity and beauty.

title: Sara Lee Adler Betrothed
description: Sara Lee Adler and Lance Paul Raiffe, who graduated with the class of '76 from Case Western Reserve University, plan to be married in June. Mr. and Mrs. Samuel I. Adler of Miami Beach have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Raiffe of Somerset, N. J. Mr. Adler is president of Southern General Builders Inc. in Hollywood, Fla. Mr. Raiffe's father is president of Gund Inc. of New Jersey, toy manufacturer.

title: And Criticism, Even Muted, Appears to Be Unsettling
description: WASHINGTONA picture of Jimmy Carter as President is beginning to emerge more and more clearly. Much of it will be reassuring to many his fellow citizens. but not all of it is comforting.

title: State Court Removes Lid On Condo Tax Valuation
description: A recent New York State Supreme Court decision may lead to increased tax assessments for condominium owners in the state.

title: Dr. W. M. Levin Fiance Of Susan T. Rosenberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morris J. Teitler of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Teitler Rosenberg, to Dr. Warren M. Levin, son of Clara Weiner of Bala Cynwyd, Pa., and the late Dr. Israel Levin of Philadelphia.

title: Saccharin Tests Followed Accepted Methods
description: If a small proportion of rats develop cancer when fed saccharin in doses hundreds of times larger than people could reasonably consume, does it make sense to consider saccharin a hazard for human beings?

title: Carter Meets Inquiry Commission Going to Hanoi and Laos, and Looks to Normal Relations With Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, March 12With mixed emotions, President Carter today bade farewell to an American commission bound for Vietnam and Laos to continue the search for some 2,500 servicemen and a few civilians still missing in Southeast Asia.

title: Card of Thanks
description: BRESSLERAnne. Mr. Louis Bressier (Lymey) and family of 60 W. 57th St., N. Y. C. sincerly thank their relatives and friends for their kind expressions of sympathy in their recent bereavement.

title: IN CONNECTICUT
description: GREENWICHVladimir Levltski, pianist for the Minneapolis Symphony, at Greenwich Library, 101 West Putnam Ave. Today 4 P.M. $3.50.

title: Three Incendiary Devices Sent Through the Mails Are Under Investigation
description: The police yesterday were investigating the ignition of lowpowered incendiary devices in three letters addressed to the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico at a post office in lower Manhattan Friday night and early yesterday.

title: Penn Fencers Take I.F.A. Team Title
description: Pennsylvania captured the team title yesterday, but did not fare well in the individual competition, however, as seven Quakers qualified for the individual competition, but none won their weapons. Randy Eggleton, the defending Intercollegiate Fencing Association and National Collegiate Athletic Association champion, in epee, posted a 6 and 2 mark in the individual competition, but had to settle for second place behind James Neale of Princeton, who lost only one of his eight bouts.

title: April Is Cancer Control Month
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI) President Carter has proclaimed the month of April Cancer Control Month. saying 385,000 Americans will die this year of the disease. In his proclamation issued Tuesday, Mr. Carter said that efforts to overcome cancer must be aggressive and sustained  the United States has committed itself to the conquest of cancer as a national goal.

title: Caldo Largo
description: A lot of water has flowed through the Florida Straits between the time of Hemingway's To Have and Have Not, when Machado was president of Cuba, and the last days of Batista, the setting for this novel. But enough has remained the same to provide the dynamics for an analogous plot. Like Hemingway's Harry Morgan, Earl Thompson's Johnny Hand is a Gulf fisherman, a shrimper instead of a game fisherman. Like Morgan, he finds it helpful to keep a Thompson submachine gun hidden in the bilges. Like Morgan, he is sucked into ferrying a boatload of revolutionaries to Cuba. Johnny's voyage is almost as disastrous as Harry's, but the violence has an evil twist that is purely contemporary. In both novels, the deckhands are murdered and the circumstances provide a moral contrast.

title: Sumter Hazzard Is Married
description: Sumter Fraser Hazzard daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Wigs Hazzard Jr. of Sewickley, Pa., was married there yesterday in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church to Peter William Adolph, son of Mrs. Dorothy B. Adolph of Bronxville. N. Y., and Dr. William Henry Adolph Jr. of Scarsdale, N. Y. The Rev. John Guest and the Rev. Samuel S. Odom performed the ceremony.

title: Hurry, Hurry Mary Dear
description: It is not easy to make the world go mad in an orderly way. But N. M. Bodecker does, to our delight, in Hurry, Hurry, Mary Dear. Step right up and meet the mother in the flower pot hat, the man with the corkscrew nose, and the jackofalltrades who has been a crocodile's tailor and a bee in a bonnet but who longs for a crown as eloquently as A. A. Milne's King John ever longed for a big, red Indiarubber ball. The king of nonsense, like most monarchs, has his ups and downs, and Bodecker, with pen and ink, pulls the king's portrait from a pack of playing cards:

title: Rizzo to Seek Approval to Run For Governor While Still Mayor
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP)Mayor Frank L. Rizzo will ask voters in November to change the city charter so that he can run for Governor without resigning, his chief adviser, Albert Gaudiosi, says.

title: Morton's Departure Eases Giants' Path to the Future
description: Craig Morton is gone from the football Giants and his tragedy was that he, like Hamlet, was not a winner.

title: A College Acts to Improve Writing
description: In an effort to raise the level of student writing, members of the English department faculty at Brooklyn College voted last week to extend the required freshmen composition course from one semester to two.

title: Mets Have Field Day In 100 Rout
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12A sunny little corner of the baseball world was rededicated here today with a gleaming, modern grandstand and with ancient memories of the days when Babe Ruth hit long ones into the alligator swamps.

title: Can't Sell the House? Blame the Taxes
description: TAXES. Unfortunately, too many people will, on seeing this word, shrug their shoulders and turn to something else. Yet the Island realestate picture is a disgrace, a detriment and hopelessly outdated.

title: Questions/Answers
description: LETTUCE UNDER LIGHTS

title: SPORTS
description: UNIONDALEBasketball: Nets vs. Los Angeles today 1:45 P.M., $3 to $8.50; wrestling: tomorrow 8:30 P.M., $4 to $7; basketball: Nets vs. Cleveland, Friday, 8 P.M., $3 to $8.50; hockey: Islanders vs. Chicago, Saturday, 8 P.M., $7 to $11. Colisuem. 7949100.

title: THEATER
description: BALDWIN PLACE  The Fantasticks. Thursday to Saturday at 8 P.M. Mahopac Farm Playhouse. Route 6. $5.50 and $6.50; discounts, except Saturday for groups, the elderly, students and children. 6281169.

title: Anne E. Hutchinson Bride of William A. Wesp
description: Anne Elizabeth Hutchinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Hutchinson of Wyncote, Pa., was married yesterday to William Arthur Wesp, son of Mrs. Albert A. Young of Sea Cliff, L.I., and the late Arthur A. Wesp Jr. of Manhasset, L.I.

title: CUT IN CIGARETTE TAX IS BACKED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, March 12A bill that would attempt to thwart cigarette bootlegging by lowering New York State's cigarette taxes was given enthusiastic support this week by representatives of the cigarette industry and a newly formed citizens group.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Cinnamon Bay you fly to St. Thomas ($233 round trip from New York), then take a taxi to the Red Hook ferry dock ($5.50 for the first person and 75 cents for each additional person). The 20minute ferry ride to Cruz Bay on the island of St. John costs $1.50 for adults and 75 cents for children. For the fivemile ride from Cruz Bay to Cinnamon Bay the taxi fare is $4 for the first person and 75 cents for each additional person. There also is a regular taxibus charging $1 a person.

title: Two Essentials Are No Longer in Ready Supply: Money and Students
description: Running colleges and universities in the United States used to be relatively simple. In the period of expansion that followed World War II decisions typically involved which new program to establish, and mistakes were easily obliterated in a continual flow of students and funds.

title: Police Captain Leaves Precinct in Chinatown
description: Police Capt. Laurence S. Hill, who was put in charge of the Chinatown precinct early last December because, an official said, the department wanted a tougher cop to deal with rising crime there, retired Friday.

title: BRIDGE
description: ONE OF THE most famous and prestigious of all contract bridge tournaments is the New England knockout team championship, which was played recently in Chicopee, Mass., with 46 teams taking part.

title: 7 Die, 13 Hurt in Jersey City Fire; One Held as Arsonist, 2 Are Sought
description: JERSEY CITY, March 12Seven persons, including six children, were trapped and killed, 13 others were injured and scores more were left homeless late last night when flames ignited by arsonists engulfed a fivestory tenement here.

title: Why Lilco Prefers Nuclear Power
description: AS the Island prepares to step into the nuclear age, I should like to say doomsday is not upon us. The air seems filled with allegations regarding nucleargenerated electrical energy based on inaccurate and misleading information, and as a result many members of the public are led to draw a multitude of unjustified conclusions.

title: Arizona Is Reported Playground for Crime
description: An investigative reporting team from 23 newspapers and broadcasting organizations asserted yesterday that the state of Arizona had become a playground for jetage mobsters, whitecollar criminals and corrupt politicians who work hand in hand to defraud the public.

title: Rosewall Topples Nastase by 63, 63
description: LAKEWAY. Tex., March 12 (AP)Ken Rosewall stunned the favored Ilie Nastase, 63, 63, in the quarterfinals of the $20,00 Tournament of Champions today. The 42yearold Aussie used every shot in his arsnal to frustrate the Rumanian.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Although the spring crop of cookbooks is a mere shadow of the fall output, this year's flowering includes a high percentage of useful and practical offerings. Ruling out all books on cooking from Carter country and the related works on peanut cookery, one is left with much worth adding to a kitchen library.

title: Barbizon, at 49: A Tradition Survives
description: As thousands of young women have done for nearly half a century, Kim Neblett arrived in New York and headed straight for the Barbizon Hotel for Women.

title: Letters
description: While Dorothy Gallagher (Tracing their roots, Feb. 20) observes that both women and slaves have had difficulty tracing their origins, a third group remains rootless. In 47 states, millions of adopted Americans have lost access to their genetic heritage through the irreversible sealing of records.

title: Auditions for Hit Backers
description: WHEN Eugene D. Jones left the Landmark Club in Stamford one recent night, he was trying to decide whether the music he had just heard had the financial ring of Pajama Game, one of Broadway's biggest musical hits of the 1950's.

title: A case for parapsychology
description: The scientific study of parapsychology has been with us for almost a century now, with little in the way of definitive results. One of the major problems in our acceptance of parapsychology, of course, is that we are quite resistant to new information and phenomena which we consider a priori to be impossible. We do not normally pursue scientific inquiry, for instance, into these areas. If I were to propose an experiment in training elephants to become peach trees I do not think much financial support would appear nor could I enlist anyone's enthusiastic help. People simply do not inform themselves about things they do not believe to be possible.

title: Mets' Box Score
description: ETemPlelon, Tyson. LOBMets 9. St. Louis 5. 2BCruz, Trapp, Grote. HRVail. SSeaver. SBTempleton. SFHarreison, Kingman, Strearns.

title: ROUNDUP
description: Although the weather turned balmy over much of the nation and the winter's energy crisis seemed to be receding rapidly into memory, the fallout from the coldest temperatures of the century did not abate last week.

title: Book and Movie TieIns Scenes From a Marriage of Convenience
description: Los ANGELES Peter Guber, who will make his debut as an independent Hollywood producer this summer with the release of the film based on Peter Benchley's novel The Deep, has unusually warm relations with a number of struggling young novelists. The reason is that Guber has providedeither directly to the novelists themselves or indirectly through deals with their New York publishing housesseed money so that nearly a dozen of these writers can finish specific projects.

title: Going Nuts In Brazil
description: If you have read Jack Douglas before, no explanation of his latest work is necessary. If you

title: Susan Thompson Sets Dec. 3 Wedding Date
description: Susan Thompson, who is studying for a master's degree in Christian education at the Princeton Theological Seminary, and the Rev. Robert Legnani, curate of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Cross in North Plainfield, N. J., and vicar of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Plainfield, plan to be married Dec. 3. The ceremony will be at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Haddon Heights, N. J.

title: Bruce Jenner: Apple Pie Hero
description: Knowing that his lunch menu would require an explanation, Bruce Jenner was already blushing before he asked room service for a roast beef sandwich. By the time he finished ordering his milk, his apple pie and his vanilla ice cream, his face was the color of summer sunset. Hanging up the phone, Jenner looked at his visitor, who was thinkingperfect, this is perfect; the allAmerican hero, the 1976 Olympic decathlon gold medalist ordering apple pie and ice cream.

title: Cynthia Exton Engaged to Dr. Paul von Oeyen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Manning Phillips Mason Exton of Southport Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Phillips Exton, to Dr. Paul Timothy von Oeyen, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Roland von Oeyen of Ubly and Harbor Beach, Mich.

title: Leader of a Teamster Local Is Convicted of Extortion
description: Theodore G. Daley, the head of Local 445 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has been convicted on extortion charges involving truckloads of crushed stone used to build a driveway for his house in Windham, N.Y.

title: Paddle TennisNew, Faster, Fun
description: PEOPLE in cages. People in cages running around. People in cages running around, bouncing off wire fences. Sounds bizarre. Perhaps it is. But whatever its appearance, platform tennis or paddle, as it is called, is the rage, a winter passion that has women feverishly rearranging schedules to play five times from Monday through Friday and perhaps in mixed doubles on weekends.

title: Times Square Lease
description: Frederick Atkins Inc., a merchandising and market research firm, has leased four full floors containing more than 100,000 square feet at One Astor Plaza on Times Square for 15 years at an aggregate rent of more than $13 million.

title: DINING OUT
description: MARRYING the best of a pub menu to the roomy comfort of a large restaurant, Parsley has come up a winner. Now at two Connecticut locations 12 miles apart on U.S. 1, Parsley offers almost the identical menu at both and, in fact, prepares the basic foods only at one. Though our sampling was done at the newer of the two, just north of Greenwich, the judgments can presumably be taken as a guide to the level of quality at the original Norwalk.

title: Site Selection Is Delayed For Bowling Hall of Fame
description: AKRON, Ohio (AP)This city will have to wait another year before learnning if it will be chosen as the site for a national bowling hall of fame.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: It is quite simple to be a genius. You just have to be born with genius, be careful and get lucky. But to be a genius who is also a legend is something quite different. A genius can exist in a vacuum; a legend turns the world around him. Rudolf Nureyev is going down in history as one of those emblematic dance namesa Vestris or a Nijinsky, or, in more popular terms, a Pavlova perhaps. People often ask me whether Nureyev is the greatest male dancer I have ever seen and I have no means of possibly answering that question. I have certainly seen men with much more techniquewho jumped higher or moved fasterand I have seen men with more perfection of style, more harmony of classic gesture. Of course. But I have never seen any dancernot my adored Fonteyn, or even Martha Grahamwhose movements have so burned themselves on my mind like a brand. I shall recall Nureyev in a series of unforgettable photographs that only my memory took and my heart filtered.

title: Saved Again
description: Somehow, New York City has solved its large, urgent money problems in a manner that Mayor Beame had called improbable, if not impossible: Taking a bit here and a bit there, the city raised almost a billion dollars with no help at all from the major banks and relatively little from municipal labor unions.

title: Miss Goldstine Will Be Bride Of Marc Simon
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Herman Heine Goldstine of Princeton, N.J., of the engagement of Mr. Goldstine's daughter, Madlen Heine Goldstine, to Marc Neal Simon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward D. Simon of Richmond. A June wedding is planned.

title: Kentucky Advances Notre Dame Sinks Hofstra
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 12Kentucky and Notre Dame won firstround games in the 39th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament tonight by putting out Princeton and Hofstra, respectively.

title: Of Special Interest
description: Two worthy benefit concerts take place this week. Tomorrow evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, pianist Andr Watts will perform in a benefit for the Brooklyn Boys Chorus. For the first half of the program, the Chorus (resident company of BAM for two years) will join Mr. Watts in works by Robert Schumann. Leonard Bernstein (Mass), Schubert and Brahms. For the second half, Mr. Watts will perform Paganini's Grand Etudes, arranged by Liszt for piano.

title: Music in Review
description: The Fresk Quartet, which appeared March 5 at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a Swedish ensemble that is touring the United States for the first time. Its members are skilled instrumentalists who produce a rich, homogeneous sound. Though comparatively youthful, they have been together since 1965, and it showsthere is an admirable giveandtake to their playing, and tempos are subtly modified with ease and unanimity.

title: Food
description: Leftovers, we aver, have virtues all their own and can be an end in themselves. Our enthusiasm is evidenced by the heartily endorsed recipes on this page. One is for leftover chicken or turkey metamorphosed into croquettes, to be served with a fresh mushroom sauce; the other, for leftover ham transmuted into another variety of croquette, this to be served with a simply made tomato sauce. What's more, with a bit of ingenuity other leftover foods may be substituted for the chicken ham.

title: Yachting
description: AT MAMARONECK, N.Y.

title: MISCELLANEOUS
description: BRIDGEPORTJill Robinson, author of Bedtime Stories, guest speaker Tuesday 8 P.M. in Recital Hall of the Bernhard Center, 84 Iranistan Ave. Free.

title: JOHN F. BUSH Sr.
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J., March 12 (AP)Mayor John F. Bush Sr., of Flemington, died today at Hunterdon Medical Center after a long illness. He was 72 years old. Mr. Bush, a former president of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, was elected Mayor of this Hunterdon County community in 1959.

title: Democrats' Man of the Hour
description: GREAT NECK

title: Election Unit Says 3 Failed to File Campaign Data in Georgia Election
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)The Federal Election Commission published today the names of three candidates who failed to file preelection campaign finance reports in the contest to fill the former Congressional seat of the United States representative to the United Nations, Andrew Young.

title: Providence, Arkansas Absorb Regional Defeats
description: NORMAN, Okla., March 12 (AP)Curtis Redding, a freshman from Canarsie High in Brooklyn, pumpedi n 32 points tonight to lead Kansas State to an 8780c ollege basketball victory over Providence in a National Collegiate Midwest Regional game.

title: Xavier Retains Polo Title, Beating CaliforniaDavis
description: SOMERS, Conn., March 12Xavier University of Ohio, with three brothers riding, won its second straight National Collegiate indoor polo championship tonight with a 139 victory over the University of California at Days.

title: Asking Shoppers, Will It Sell?
description: HICKSVILLE THE ancients studied flights of birds and examined the entrails of sacrificial animals. Modern market researches use different methods, but their concern is the same: the future.

title: Session on Gardening
description: Outdoor Gardening will be the subject of a lecture, demonstrations and questionandanswer session on March 22 at 1:30 P.M. at the Mapleton Library in Brooklyn. The branch is at 60th Street and 17th Avenue. Admission is free.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Best Seller List
description: General

title: Kleber Visahis Michelin
description: The Ides of March have meant other things in other times, but in France they now signal the imminent publication of the powerful hotel and restaurant guidebooks that make or break reputations for the coming year.

title: Coping With the New Tax Law
description: Although scarcely simple, the latest versions of Form 1040 and the briefer Form 1040A are, for most people, not drastically different from what they struggled with last year. But the sheer accumulated complexity of the patched and involuted Internal Revenue Code is enough to give Form 1040 an amply deserved bad name.

title: County Weighs Costs Of CUNY Fee Cut
description: IN the long and difficult campaign to boost sagging enrollment, the feeling at Herbert H. Lehman College in the Bronx is that the school has just won a crucial victory. And as a result, administrators of some colleges in Westchester envision a potential loss.

title: Some Typical Tax Errors
description: Taxpayers tend to trip over two sorts of tax provisionsthe rules that have changed since last year and the rules that haven't. With the 1976 Tax Reform Act, an unusually large number of tax provisions affecting 1976 returns were revamped. According to tax accountants and the Internal Revenue Service, many taxpayers among the easily filers are mishandling some of them.

title: Henri Gault & Christian Millau: Les Enfants Terribles
description: Henri Gault and Christian Millau burst upon the unsuspecting French public in 1969 when they launched their irreverent monthly magazine, Le Nouveau Guide, dedicated to deflating the pumpedup reputations of nolonger worthy restaurants, encouraging a new generation of French chefs and educating complacent restaurantgoers. In 1973 they baptized La nouvelle cuisines and set out its Ten Cornmandments.

title: The Legacy Of Malthus
description: Ever since Aristotle divided the human race into natural masters and natural slaves, dominant classes have fed their selfesteem by claiming that they were on top and others on the bottom because such was the natural or Godgiven order of things. But in the past two centuries the champions of inequality have added a new weapon to their arsenal.

title: Cats I have known and loathed
description: For reasons I do not know and have small intention of finding out, the world is afflicted (there is no other word for it) by a tyranny (there is no other word for that, either) of cats: cats themselves; novels and poems about, and yes, ostensibly by cats; things for cats to cat, wear, sit on, sleep on, meditate over and scratch: cat paintings, drawings and cartoons in awful proliferation. On television, there is a catfond commercial featuring a fat, complacent animal speaking in Larchmont Lockjaw, a kind of English in which the lips are barely parted and the teeth slay firmly clenched; I have always disliked Larchmont Lockjaw, even in Katharine Hepburn. And, I often wonder what got into cat people like Eliot, Ramielaire and Kipling, among others. I am, malheureusement, acquainted with a highly competent cat doctor who addresses hills to the cot, care of the owner and makes believe that the bills come from one of his cats. Is it cynical of me to note that the checks are invariably made out to the doctor?

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY manufacturers and dealers who sell wallpaper and vinyl or fabrictype wallcoverings furnish instruction sheets that tell how to hang their products, and many of these modern wall coverings are prepasted and factorytrimmed to make things as simple as possible for the doityourselfer. However, all too often the instructions furnished are not as complete or as clear as they should be.

title: Rosemary Palmieri Plans a May Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gene F. Palmieri of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rosemary Terese Palmieri, to Richard Clinton Bellinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cornelius Bellinger of Cresskill, N.J.

title: Blarney  A Political Definition
description: A FEW years ago, I decided to do an intensive study of the art of blarney. It therefore became necessary for me to move to New Jersey, and I have never regretted it. Blarney has flowered in the Garden State as nowhere else. Along with our marvelous record of topheavy governmental structure and uncertain cervices, we have more frequent public elections than any other state except Virginia. In these areas alone, the case studies are unique.

title: Senators on Rules Panel Declare Staff Members Salaries Are High
description: WASHINGTON. March 12 (AP)Salaries paid Senate staff members are getting out of hand, Rules Committee members say.

title: Extradition Is Growing as Crime Shows Increase in a Mobile Society
description: ALBANY, March 12When a Westchester grand jury handed up murder indictments last Thursday against two fugitives being held in a Connecticut jail, it set in motion the quite common, but frequently misunderstood, process of extradition.

title: Princeton Yields to Progress
description: WHEN scientific progress in the form of a research laboratory collides with a small, but beloved, chunk of local history and architecture in a university community like Princeton, the impact reverberates to the depth of towngown relations and can raise issues that might otherwise lie dormant.

title: Accord on Answers to AutoInsurance Problems Eludes Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J. March 10An allday conference on the high cost and restricted availability of auto insurance failed to yield any consensus among the participants on how rates could be reduced and insurance made more easily available.

title: IN NEARBY WESTCHESTER
description: HARRISONNations In Crisis: the Middle East, China and the Third World, by Dr. Buultjens, chairman of the International Development Forum. Tuesday 9:30 A.M. Jewish Community Center of Harrison, Union Ave. $7.50. (914) 9675238.

title: CAREY ASKS CHANGES IN LABOR PROCEDURES
description: Governor Carey and his labor advisers have proposed major changes in state labor policies and procedures relating to public employees, but there is already evidence of opposition from some of those who would be most directly affected.

title: Dealing with death in the family
description: Only recently, we lit the candle that marked the day that Jack died. As the flame flickered in the traditional memorial glass, I marveled at the span of time. It was three years now and here we sat talking of himmy husband, their fathertenderly, endearingly, hut without tears.

title: Harrisburg Expecting a Record Entry
description: The routes to Harrisburg, Pa., will be loaded with dogs Saturday. The big farm city's kennel club lists a recordbreaking entry of 3,195 for its 42nd allbreed show and obedience trial in the Pennsylvania State Farm Building on Maclay and Cameron Streets. We rank among the four largest benched shows in the East, said Harold G. Fuehrer, club president and chairman of the event. The others are Philadelphia, Boston and Westminster.

title: Design
description: The best residences produced by New York architects in the past four years include an opulent estate in upper Westchester County and lowincome housing in the South Bronx, at least according the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, which cited these two projectsas well as four othersas winners of its 1977 residentialdesign awards.

title: Some Pointers on Choosing and Using Varnishes
description: VARNISH is one of the most widely used, durable and versatile of all clear wood finishes which the doityourselfer can use, but all too often he or she winds up disappointed with the final resultseither because the varnish does not wear as well as it should, or because the finish does not have the smooth, professionallooking luster normally expected of a good varnish.

title: Vance Tells Arabs U. S. Is Not Shifting Stand on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON. March 12Four Arab ambassadors conferred with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance for more than an hour today and said he had satisfied them that there had been no change in the basic United States position on the Middle East.

title: INTERVIEW
