description: FROM HER BERLIN POST as chief Central European correspondent for The Chicago Tribune, she was among the first to warn of the Nazi menace. She was there when. Hermann Goering turned his charm and Nazi propaganda on Charles Lindbergh. During a personal interview at the Kaiserhof in 1932, Hitler fixed her with his magnetic gaze and proclaimed, My will shall be done. While attending one of her dinner parties in Berlin, Goering remarked to her between mouthfuls, You people gorge yourselves while the masses are starving. She was there when Buchenwald was liberated.

title: Canton Wall Posters Report That Teng Is Appointed as Prime Minister
description: HONG KONG, March 12A Hong Kong newspaper reported today that wall posters have appeared in Canton announcing the appointment of Teng Hisiaoping, the former Deputy Prime Minister, as a Deputy Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party and Prime Minister.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT VANCOUVER

title: SHOP TALK
description: YOU don't have to be Irish to enjoy St. Patrick's Day. And you certainly don't have to be Irish to relish the delights of Irish Imports at 143 Jericho Turnpike in Mineola.

title: Dance: By Rose
description: Mitchell Rose obviously likes movement, since he uses all kinds of it in his pieces, but it is an indiscriminate enthusiasm at best. It appears that he has attended a variety of different classes and has appropriated characteristic combinations from each to incorporate into his works, which were shown Friday evening at the American Theater Laboratory.

title: MEN WHO TOOK $867,567 NO LONGER FACE PENALTY
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y. (UPI)Two, or possibly four, men have legally become entitled to $867,567 stolen from an armored truck in 1972. They beat it, said the Monroe County District Attorney, Lawrence Kurlander.

title: Miss Bedford Is the Bride Of Mark Dyer
description: The marriage of Katherine Keith Bedford and Mark Valentine Dyer. 1975 graduates of the University of Maryland, took place yesterday in Baltimore. The Rev. Charles R. Ehrhardt performed the ceremony in the Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY manufacturers and dealers who sell wallpaper and vinyl or fabrictype wallcoverings furnish instruction sheets that tell how to hang their products, and many of these modern wall coverings are prepasted and factorytrimmed to make things as simple as possible for the doityourselfer. However, all too often the instructions furnished are not as complete or as clear as they should be.

title: STAMPS
description: A century of progress in sound recording, harking back to the invention of the talking machine, as its inventor, Thomas Alva Edison, called it, is the theme of a new commemorative being issued by the United States.

title: Engagements
description: FinkelsteinJacobs

title: And Still No Answers in Montreal
description: MONTREALA vast expanse of ice, snow and concrete greets visitors these days to Montreal's Olympic Park on the eastern outskirts of the city.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Face the Nation: Bob Bergland, Secretary of Agriculture.

title: Return of the Northport Trolley  as a Class Project
description: NORTHPORT WHEN students from Northport High School began to look at some of the problems of the future they found one solution in the pastin the trolley cars that once graced the streets of this harbor village.

title: Dr. Steven Barnett to Wed Pamela Peters
description: Pamela E. Peters, a research nurse in hypertension at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, and Dr. Steven Barnett, a surgical intern at the Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N. H., will be married next June.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Stalking Wilson's Snipe
description: CAMDEN, S.C.  Daffodils were blooming in dooryards facing the south and farmers were plowing and harrowing their fields as we made our way to an extensive manmade marsh to hunt Wilson's snipe.

title: Wife of Khaalis Warns of Danger If Film Is Shown
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (Reuters)The wife of the Hanafi Muslim leader Hamaas Abdul Khaalis, warned today that if a film about the life of the Prophet of Islam was shown, despite what she said was a promise to withdraw it. more trouble is coming, worse than before, all over the country.

title: MUSIC & DANCE
description: BELLPORTSouth Country Chorus performs P.D.Q. Hach and Gilbert and Sullivan; Saturday 8 P.M.; Middle School, Kreamer St. Tickets $2.50, children $1.25.

title: INVESTING
description: The Carter Administration on March 1 unveiled its plan to reorganize the Federal energy bureaucracy, and the President is scheduled to disclose on April 20 his energy policy recommendations to the country. At first glance, it appears that the nuclear power industry and the uranium shares may be headed for lean years, but such an appraisal might not be valid for the long term.

title: A Striking Issue for Teachers
description: TEACHER'?? ??RIKES in Greenwich and Waterbury recently, a threatened strike in Windsor as well as contract talks now going on in several communities are setting the stage for what seems certain to be a hotly contested legislative fight over the bargaining procedures for the state's 38,000 public school teachers and administrators.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: OF the 42 American citizens who managed to get through on telephone calls to President Carter last weekend during his historic radioanswer program for the public, exactly half raised questions on economic matters, mostly personal concerns over the high level of various living costs.

title: THEATER
description: HARTFORDWorld premiere of Christopher Durang's new play, A History of the American Film, opens Friday at the Hartford Stage Company, 65 Kingsley St. Tickets, up to $9; students $2.50. 5254258.

title: THEATER
description: DEATH OF A SALESMAN is 28 years old. I mention this because of the curious lethargy it produced in me in the current production by the Hartman Theater Company in Stamford. Has the play aged, was it the uncomfortable heat of an unexpected warm winter's night, or was it Del Tenney's direction that made this production seem interminable and curiously unmoving?

title: Events Today
description: THE RELUCTANT DRAGON: Musical marionette show; 12:30 and 3 P.M., Cottage Marionette Theatre, Swedish Cottage, Central Park at Central Park West near slot street. (Admission tree, but contributions will be accepted. Reservation, 9889093.)

title: The wandering country boy as Wandering Jew
description: If one is speaking only of his fiction, the quintessential Robert Penn Warren sentence, or something very like it, appears in chapter six of his Pulitzer Prizewinning novel All the King's Men (1946). There Warren's narratorprotagonist Jack Burden, a former newspaperman and seeker of truth turned factotum for Gov. Willie Stark, has occasion to visit his boyhood friend Adam Stanton, now a gifted surgeon. Stark wants to make Stanton the director of a new hospital he is building as a mounment to his greatness and a palliative to his betrayed idealism. But it is no deal. Stanton, a prelapsarian purist whom Burden later calls The Man of Idea, will not serve Stark, The Man of Fact. The two friends quarrel about the nature of good and evil in the fallen world and Burden leaves angrily: And with that I slammed his door and was running and stumbling down the dark stairs, for it was the kind of apartment house where the bulb burns out and nobody ever puts a new one in and there is always a kiddie car left on a landing and the carpet is worn to ribbons and the air smells dankly of dogs, diapers, cabbage, old women, burnt grease, and the eternal fate of man.

title: Rainbow Writing
description: It is worrisome that Eve Merriam, usually a good prose writer, can get by with writing and publishing a book of poetry so sloppy in craftsmanship. There arc places were line breaks seem arbitrary and punctuation and capitalization are random throwaround affairs. There are also internal errors such as faulty imagery, dangling symbolism and confusion of unity within lines and within poems. Flow is one supposed to take the lines: Ling Chee's laundry tickets drift in the gutter/moaning with stomach cancer?

title: Flowers Have Their Own Roots
description: Alex Haley's book Roots is moving a nation to reassess its bittersweet heritage in many ways, large and small. It made me start thinking about what else in our lives might have originated in Africa.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Yankee Batboys/Rules of Tennis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WIND EROSION ON PLAINS REPORTED DOWN THIS YEAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)Wind erosion in the Great Plains through February was down 16 percent from a year earlier, despite recent severe windstorms in the area, the Agriculture Department says.

title: Education
description: In the last two years, 162 men and women in New York State have obtained high school diplomas through a new program that allows adults to receive diplomas without having to sit through formal classes and without taking the equivalency examination that is the most common alternative for high school dropouts. The experimental External High School Diploma program has been sponsored by the State Education Department at eight locations from Long Island to Syracuse.

title: John Hawkesworth Champion of the British Serials
description: LONDON If there is one thing I've learned from working with the truly great names, said John Hawkesworth, it's this: always aim at perfection. Always.

title: U.S. Backs Film of a Battling Eve
description: WASHINGTONA 15minute film, How Many Eves, winner of a Bronze Award at the International Film and TV festival in New York last November, has proved a winner with the Federal Government.

title: Sadat Pledges Not to Give Up Arab Territory
description: CAIRO, March 12President Anwar elSadat, flanked by Yasir Arafat and other Palestinian leaders, opened a crucial meeting of the Palestine National Congress here tonight with a pledge that Egypt would not permit a single inch of Arab territory to remain under Israeli occupation.

title: PRESIDENT IS VIEWED AS FIRM ON 19 CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 12It seemed like an easy target, this $432 million project, although it would eventually irrigate nearly 500,000 acres of South Dakota farmland and provide industrial and drinking water for 17 cities and towns.

title: SAN ANDREAS BULGE PUZZLES SCIENTISTS
description: LOS ANGELES, March 12The Palmdale Bulge, a mysterious swelling of the earth astride California's earthquakeprone San Andreas Fault, is turning out to be even more puzzling than scientists first thought. In some places, the bulge has become a dimple.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: There is no doubt of the historic value of the photographs of the Spanish Civil War on public view for the first time at Castelli Graphics, 4 East 77th Street, through March 26. Made in 1936 by Hans Namuth and Georg Reisner, two young German photographers who had gone to Spain to cover the Barcelona Olympics for the French magazine Vu, they must be among the first action pictures ever taken of the kind of civil war in which ordinary civilians find themselves and their homes, shops, offices and factories on the front line of battle.

title: FRANCIS A. WINGATE
description: Dr. Francis A. Wingate, vice president and treasurer of Onondaga Community College in Syracuse, died Monday at State University Hospital, Upstate Medical Center, Syracuse. He was 67 years old and lived at 204 Sherbourne Road, Syracuse.

title: On the Block: A Week in Portugal
description: THERE are auctions like those at Sotheby ParkeBernet or Christie's where the rich quietly vie for highly priced Picassos and Renoirs.

title: THEATER MAILBAG
description: In last week's Theater Mailbag, several readers were critical of the New York Shakespeare Festival production of Anton Chehhov's The Cherry Orchard, currently at the Vivian Beaumont. The following response is by the director of that production, Andrei Serban.Ed.

title: Body Found in Catskills
description: CRAGSMOOR, N. Y., March 12A body that was found near here last night by three hikers has been identified as that of Dean Albert, 19 years old, of Ellenville, the son of Saul and Evelyn Albert, operators of the Albert Bakery in Ellenvitle, Sheriff Thomas Mayone of Ulster County said that the victim had been reported missing on Jan. 6. Sheriff Niayone said that the death was still under investigation by his department, and he did not rule out foul play.

title: How to profit from the new tax laws
FILMS
description: MAIWARONECKThe Bandwagon, starring Fred Astaire and Cyd Charisse, Tuesday at 8 P.M. Sponsored by the LarchmontMamaroneck Film Council. Mamaroneck Playhouse. $2.50, students and the elderly $1. 8347124.

title: GARDENING
description: IN SEEMINGLY neverending winters, such as this one has been, New Jersey landscapes of deciduous trees and shrubs appear to be particularly bleak and cold. But add a coniferous evergreen or two (a pine and a hemlock, maybe), plus a few broadleaved evergreen shubs, and hitherto unnoticed patterns of beauty emerge among the bare branches.

title: The Golf Clinic
description: Television golf ratings are highest at this time of the year, when weekend players in the snow belt are shut in, hunkered in front of our sets, enjoying vicariously and enviously the remotecontrol world of colored grass and birdie putts.

title: Good Jobs, Not Junk Jobs
description: The easy thing to say about the $1.5 billion youth job program President Carter sent to Congress last week is: It's about time. The more important comment is: Go slow. The critical question has not yet been addressed: What kinds of jobs are to be created? Unless that question can be satisfactorily answered, yet another venture in social virtue may be doomed.

title: MEETINGS & TALKS
description: DIX HILLSWhere Are We Going in Health in Nassau and Suffolk? with Bert JabIon; Wednesday 8 P.M.; Half Hollow Pkwy. Free.

title: BRIDGE
description: If the bridge cognoscenti were asked to produce lists of world ranking in three categories  most effective player, most creative theoretician, and most daring and aggressive performer the chances are that the same name would head all three lists. All titles would go to Benito Garozzo of Rome, who will have his 50th birthday this year. He has been a mainstay of the Italian Blue Team since 1961, winning 13 world titles; he originates complex bidding structures for Blue Team, SuperPrecision or Lancia faster than his suffering partners can commit them to memory; and he is a more active bidder than any of his peers.

title: Newark's Pasquale Is an Irish Hero
description: THEY have a new name these days for Capt. Jim Mooney at the headquarters of Rescue Squad 1 in Newark's North Ward. They call him Pasquale, and it's all because he has been named Irishman of the Year.

title: Platform Tennis
description: AT SCARSDALE. N.Y.

title: Maria Kelleher, Peter Rathbone To Wed June 4
description: Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Kelleher of Princeton, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Kelleher, to Peter B. Rathbone, an assistant vice president of Sotheby Parke Bernet Inc. in New York.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT HOUSTON

title: Home Clinic
description: Q: After many washings, the linoleum floor in my kitchen has become very porous. I would like to know if I can apply a polyurethane finish over this to give it a hard finish and make it easier to keep clean.L.H., New Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: Natures Are Passionate Along the Mediterranean
description: ATHENSThere are three kinds of democracy in Europe: AngloSaxon, Scandinavian and Mediterranean, Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis said recently. Of the three, the Mediterranean is the least disciplined and the most difficult to manage, largely because of the passionate nature of the Mediterranean personality. I detest passion in politics. Passion obscures issues and blinds citizens to the truth.

title: Office Building Sold
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has acquired one of Long Island's largest office buildings for $17 million.

title: The Sound of Music Culture in the Carter White House
description: WASHINGTON During the recent Presidential campaign, Jimmy Carter came across to some people as a man whose interestsinsofar as he had any real interests apart from a consuming desire to be Presidentlay in reshuffling tables of organization. It was said he could perform this mental exercise with ease while tramping through a peanut field. Little was said then of Mr. Carter's cultural orientation. One knew, of course, of his fondness for the songs of Bob Dylan and for the Allman Brothers band, a hardrock group which had subsidized his Presidential drive through its infancy by giving fundraising concerts. One was also told that Mr. Carter liked the kind of sad countryandwestern tunes which could be heard all the time on the radio at his brother Billy's filling station in Plains, Ga. When Mr. Carter was elected last fall, the most popular song in southwestern Georgia was a religious ballad entitled Drop Kick Me, Jesus, Through the Goal Posts Life.

title: James Niemants to Wed Cynthia Walters June 25
description: Cynthia Ann Walters and James Simon Niemants, graduates of Drake University in Des Moines, Iowa, plan to be married June 25 in Minnetonka, Minn.

title: DINING OUT
description: Broadmoor, Union Street, Lambertville. (609) 3971199.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY manufacturers and dealers who sell wallpaper and vinyl or fabrictype wallcoverings furnish instruction sheets that tell how to hang their products, and many of these modern wall coverings are prepasted and factorytrimmed to make things as simple as possible for the doityourselfer. However, all too often the instructions furnished are not as complete or as clear as they should be.

title: To Get and to Get Not
description: BOSTONAt Senate confirmation hearings in January, when Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin raised doubts about the ability of the then Secretarydesignate of Housing and Urban Development, Patricia Roberts Harris, to identify with the underprivileged, he struck a chord in the minds of many blacks, particularly the poor.

title: Flower Show Salutes Winners
description: MORE than a dozen major trophies and other awards, including cash prizes, were presented to exhibitors at the 1977 New Jersey Flower and Garden Show at the National Guard Armory in Morristown. The show closes today.

title: The Standings
description: LAST NIGHTS'S GAMES

title: MISCELLANEOUS
description: GARDEN CITYFourth Annual Nassau County Junior High School Wrestling Tournament; today 12 noon; Bldg. J, Nassau Community College. Free.

title: DRAMA PROGRAM AIDS STUDENTS IN DETROIT
description: DETROIT, March 12After gangs of young toughs went on a crime spree last summer that culminated in a near riot at Coho Hall, Detroit's riverfront convention center, many residents hoped that the coming of the school year would bring a partial cure.

title: The Cuisine Of the Sun By Miredle Johnston. Random House. $12.95.
description: If I were forced by some unimaginable set of circumstances to confine my eating to one corner of the world, that corner would be Provence, the southern region of France where French restraint and balance blends with the sensuous, robust flavors of Italy. While no one can quite come up to the English cookbook author, Elizabeth David, in describing the food of this region, two very good books dealing with it have just been published. The Cuisine of the Sun, by Mireille Johnston stays within the boundaries of Provence, concentrating on the author's native city, Nice. It is a beautifully designed book with handsome jacket, end papers and pages, and the title captures that special feeling of warmth and color that pervades this regional cuisine.

title: Con Edison States Its Case
description: FOR more than 90 years, Con Edison and its corporate predecessors have supplied electric service to the people of Westchester. This service is the most reliable in the state and probably the most reliable in the nation. And has been supplied with everincreasing efficiency.

title: Tennessee Williams Is a Reluctant Performer for an Audience of High School Students
description: Tennessee Williams strolled on the stage of the Winter Garden Theater the other afternoon, pulled a small bottle of vermouth out of his pocket, took a swig and then turned to face his audience800 spirited New York City high school students.

title: G.O.P. Drive to Woo Blacks, Intellectuals
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (UPI)The Republican Party's executive committee announced today new efforts to strengthen its appeal to blacks and to bring more intellectuals into the party.

title: GARDENING
description: RESEARCH entomologists from Cornell University and the Nassau County Cooperative Extension Association have discovered and identified a new tree pest on the Island. The insect, Xyleborus Validus, a beetle that bores deeply into tree trunks and branches, was discovered on European beech trees at Old Westbury Gardens. This is the first time that the insect, which is native to Japan and is a serious pest of woody ornamentals there, has been reported in this country.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodaySaw Mill River K.C. 37th allbreed show and obedience trial, Westchester County Center, Bronx River Parkway. White Plains; 1,040 dogs; 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Resignation of Mayor After Montgomery Police Scandal Prompts an Outcry Against Newspapers
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 12A day after Mayor James Robinson of Montgomery resigned in the aftermath of a police department scandal, a 65yearold retired telephone repairman named Charlie Cunningham went to the City Hall to speak up for Mr. Robinson and support his attack on the city's daily newspapers.

title: Rout of Barons Cuis Flyer Edge to 3
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 12With a relentless body attack that finally wore down the fast, young but leaderless Cleveland Barons, the Islanders tonight crept to within 3 points of the Broad Street Bullies on an 83 victory.

title: Here Come the Marathon Runners
description: GARDEN CITY THIS being the year of the marathon manand womanit is expected that between 800 and 1,000 of them will converge here next Sunday for the Nassau County Marathon. Although these marathoners will not be running from crazed Nazi dentists, as Dustin Hoffman did, all of their skills, endurance, stamina and determination will be necessary to finish the 26mile, 385yard course from Nassau Community College through two Icons in Eisenhower Park and back to the college.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE pumpernickel at this popular German restaurant in Northport is quite beside the point. A few dark spongy rolls nestle in the basket along with some sliced packaged rye. In fact, it is not until the main course that Pumpernickel's shines; choices from the roster of German and Austrian specialties are quite good.

title: CHILDREN
description: GREENBURGHThe American Chestnut Story, a film, followed by a chestnut roast. Today at 1 P.M. Greenburgh Nature Center. Dromore Rd., Scarsdale. Suggested donation: adults 50 cents, children 25 cents. 7233470.

title: CHILDREN
description: BROOKHAVENArts and crafts workshops for children 6 to 13; Saturdays 1 P.M; Bay Community School, 287 S. Country Rd. Fee $3 a session. 2868026.

title: Guadeloupe's Friendly Volcano Turns Angry
description: Last summer, as never before, Guadeloupe was ready for the tourist invasion. Four new hotels had risen on the butterflyshaped French island in the Caribbean; another had been completely refurbished. Some 2.600 hotel and motel rooms were available, a 60 percent increase over 1975, for the tourists who would luxuriate in the tropical sun under beneficent La Soufrire, the 4,000foot volcanic mountain that is the island's trademark. Then La Soufrire turned angry. The result, as I discovered on a tour of the island:: a financial setback for Guadeloupe and a case study of the fragility of the tourist trade in general.

title: Hunch Wins Swift Stakes by 4 Lengths
description: If Seattle Slew loses any sleep tonight, it won't be because of anything that happened in yesterday's $53,850 Swift Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: SOUTH AFRICA DELAY ON PRESS CURB SEEN
description: CAPE TOWN, March 12A strong possibility that the South African Government may defer approval of a new bill restraining press freedom arose today when an organization representing newspaper owners declared its willingness to enter into fresh talks on the issue with the administration of Prime Minister John Vorster.

title: U.S. SAYS MOST LANDS RECEIVING ARMS AID ARE ABUSING RIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The State Department, in reports made public today, has informed Congress that, with the exception of Western European nations and a few others, human rights are being violated in varying degrees by most of the 82 countries that receive security assistance.

title: Geraldine Galligan Fiancee
description: Cornelius A. Galligan Jr. of Flushing, Queens, has announced the engagement of his daughter, Geraldine Claire Galligan, to James J. Morley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Morley of Tappan, N. Y. A wedding in October is planned. Miss Galligan, daughter also of the late Mrs. Galligan, is a teacher at SS. Joachim and Anne School in Queens Village, Queens. She holds a bachelor's degree from Queens College. Her fianc graduated in 1973 from Fordham University, where he also received a master's degree and is a candidate for a Ph.D. He and his father are with Harry M. Stevens Inc., caterers.

title: U.S. Women Gym Meet's Top Stars
description: Lyudmila Tourischeva was not there to lend her quiet charm to the competition, nor was the magnetic Olga Korbut. Nellie Kim, the Soviet Union's rising star, was also among the missing, as was the icy Nadia Comaneci of Rumania, the multimedalist at the Olympic Games in Montreal.

title: Going to School For Antiques
description: COLLECTORS of sophisticated European furniture and bibelots once shunned the suburbs, calling areas outside Manhattan the land of the butter churn and the lazy susan. Now, however, devotees of the old and the rare beat knowledgable paths to the doors of antique stores in Westchester and Putnam Counties.

title: COUNCIL REPORT FINDS NEW YORK CAN STAND MORE BUDGET TRIMS
description: The New York City Council, in a report mandated by the new City Charter, said yesterday that some municipal agencies that had already suffered severe cuts because of the city's fiscal crisis could absorb even further budgetary and personnel reductions without impairing their delivery of services.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Swans' Way
description: Our 10foot scarecrow commands a garden of melting snow. Under the snow, and snug in straw laid down last fall, lie perhaps 60 leeksall that's left of last year's planting of 500 or 600. Any day now, the ground will thaw a bit and we'll have fresh leeks for supper. Tart, fresh, hardy leeks, cousin of the onion, chives and garlicwhat a spur their taste is to setting out a new garden!

title: FOOD
description: THE iconography of the various holidays involves colors, symbols and foods. As February is punctuated by red hearts and chocolates, in Marth we can look forward to green shamrocks and a list of edibles from Erin: soda bread, corned beef and cabbage, Irish stew and Irish coffee, to say nothing of green beer. Thus do we honor the patron saint of the Emerald Isle.

title: U.S. Clinches World Cup As Connors Tops Roche
description: HARTFORD, March 12  Australia proved no match for the United States in the Aetna World Cup tennis competition, as Jimmy Connors clinched the Americans' victory today.

title: Hugh Merrill Weds Melissa G. Muendel
description: Melissa Grace Muendel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold John Muendel of Basking Ridge, N. J., was married yesterday noon to Hugh Brakeley Merrill, a partner of Stokes, Hoyt & Company, a New York Stock Exchange specialist firm.

title: Sacred Heart Moves Up
description: NEW HAVEN, March 12 (AP)Carl Winfree scored 33 points, including both ends of a oneandone, foulshot situation with six seconds left, and led Sacred Heart to an 8582 victory over Towson State tonight in a quarterfinal game of the N.C.A.A. Division II tournament.

title: Put a Life Back Together'
description: On the other hand, some alcoholabuse patients experience few physicaldamaging repercussions. But alcoholism is not determined or defined by the extent of damage done to the body. It is a sociopathic illness with secondary medical implications.

title: Barr Puts His Stamp on Hackley
description: DONALD BARR, who ran a private school in the cramped confines of Manhattan before becoming headmaster of the Hackley School on an 83acre campus in Tarrytown, still is amused at the idea of having to worry about the cover on the swimming pool and the surface on the tennis court.

title: If Belief Is Eroding, So May Churches' Role in the Larger Society
description: A recent survey of Catholic life in the Yorkville section of New York City's Upper East Side traced declines in Catholic worship to a loss of faith in the church's central mysteries, and thus contronted Catholicism with the possibility that belief may be eroding among a sizable segment of American Catholics.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball
description: MIDWEST REGIONALS Marquette 66, Cincinnati 51 Southern Illinois 81, Arizona 77. Kansas St, 87, Providence 80 Wake Forest 86, Arkansas 80

title: Coopman Stops Urtain For European Ring Crown
description: ANTWERP, Belgium, March 12 (UPI) JeanPierre Coopman of Belgium won the vacant European heavyweight boxing title tonight by knocking out Jose Urtain of Spain in the fourth round.

title: MUSIC
description: TAKE a New Yorkbased director and conductor, add solo singers from the Metropolitan and New York City Opera companies, fortify with a chorus of New York professionals, stir well, and what do you have? An unusually vibrant and successful Connecticut opera company. It is called State Opera Inc., and under the watchful tutelage of local residents it has produced 23 operas over the last eight years. No. 24 will be Verdi's Rigoletto, this Saturday night at 8:15, in the Hartman Theatre on Atlantic Street in downtown Stamford.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHEN Henry G. Wenzel 3d, the former Suffolk County District Attorney, took on a new job recently, some of his friends tried to present him with a pair of epaulets, and they reminded him that Danny Kaye once starred in a very funny movie called The Inspector General.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 12The authorities have relaxed censorship on the press, radio and television.

title: Key to Security: The Lobby
description: An elderly couple are murdered during a breakin at their East 'Sixties apartment and fearful neighbors tell of strangers wandering through the building, seemingly at will. Less than a mile to the south, a luxury highrise is hit by four burglaries in as many days, even as tenants, some of whom are paying rents in excess of $2,000 a month, move to force their landlord to restore curtailed security services.

title: MUSIC & DANCE
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR  Concert by John Wummer, flutist, and Joseph Wolman, pianist. Program Includes selections from Bach, Honegger and SaintSans and Widor. Benefit for Briarcliff Performing Arts scholarships. Today at 2:30 P.M. Briarcliff College. $3.50. 9116400 or 271 5644.

title: The $300 Beauty
description: The reason people with stars in their eyes, or maybe dollar signs, keep buying cheap horses is that racing literature is wormy with tales of the meek inheriting the earth. Current examples are Bold Forbes, a $15,200 yearling who finished 1976 as the 3yearold champion with a bankroll of $501,536, and Seattle Slew, the $17,500 investment who consolidated his position as Kentucky Derby favorite the other day by breaking every stopwatch in Florida. In the first three races of his life, this colt collected $94,350.

title: Some Advice On Apartment Safety
description: The doorman should regard himself as the bodyguard of the tenants, admonishes a fourpage listing of instructions to doormen and hallmen given new employees by SulzbergerRolfe.

title: Action at Maho Bay
description: A new camping resort has recently been opened on St. John in the Virgin Islands, and the facilities are expected to take some of the pressure off the Cinnamon Bay Campground, where waiting lists for tent space have been growing longer each year.

title: Births
description: Beynon

title: Skiing
description: AT HEAVENLY VALLEY, NEV.

title: A New Marshall Plan?
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Carter Administration is now beginning a really serious reappraisal of United States immigration policy, with special attention on how to handle the illegal aliens who now outnumber the unemployed in this country.

title: Anne Lawrence Is Affianced To Christopher Alden Wray
description: Anne Evelyn Lawrence, a junior at Boston University, and Christopher Alden Wray, an aeronautical mechanic with Wiggins Airways in Norwood, Mass., plan to be married in June at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul in St. Thomas, V.I.

title: OpenSessions Law For U.S. Agencies Takes Effect Today
description: WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP)Starting today, most Federal regulatory agencies and scores of other Boards and commissions are required to admit the public to meetings at which decisions are made.

title: THEATER
description: DEATH OF A SALESMAN; is 28 years old. I mention; this because of the curious lethargy it produced in me in the current production by the Hartman Theater Company in Stamford. Has the play aged, was it the uncomfortable heat of an unexpected warm winter's night, or was it Del Tenney's direction that made this production seem interminable and curiously unmoving?

title: The Delectable Mountains
description: Devin Donahue, just out of Harvard spends the summer of 1968 recovering from a broken heart and designing sets for a little theater in Colorado. It is a good counterirritant. The folks in the immediate radius of the Red Lagoon Theatre are crazy enough to make Devin forget his melancholy. The producer, an old flame named Leila, is having it off with a deranged hippie who makes sculpture out of human excrement. Leila's mother, Amanda, has a rich inheritance of peculiarity, Leila's husband, an affluent melancholic named Mittie, is being driven right over the brink by his family life. Devin collects experiences, including a black eye and a case of crabs, as the theater concludes its final season with a fatality or

title: Type of Germ Army Used in Test Caused Infection Four Days Later
description: In 1950, four days after the Army secretly released near San Francisco what then were considered harmless bacteria called Serratia marcescens, a 50yearold kidney disease patient at Stanford Hospital developed a urinary tract infection that was found to have been produced by Serratia marcescens.

title: ART
description: THE American Surrealist art show at the Rutgers University Art Gallery is a blockbuster collection of pictures and a major feat as an historical study addressing itself to a muchneglected area of exciting paintings, drawings, photographs and sculpture.

title: Loss of Power By Cunningham Seen Increased
description: Although he was the state's most powerful Democratic party leader 18 months ago, the political power of the Bronx Democratic chairman, Patrick J. Cunningham, is being siphoned away by his organization's continued loss of public offices. The latest was the unprecedented loss of the Assembly seat in a special election in the overwhelmingly Democratic Coop City area to an antiCunningham Democratic district leader, Eliot Engel, who ran on the Liberal line.

title: Madness In the Method?
description: PARIS  There seems to be a certain joyful, disorderly confusion in the Carter Administration's incipient diplomacy, and we cannot exactly blame our foreign friends and adversaries if they are bewildered by some things the United States says and does.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY manufacturers and dealers who sell wallpaper and vinyl or fabrictype wallcoverings furnish instruction sheets that tell how to hang their products, and many of these modern wall coverings are prepasted and factorytrimmed to make things as simple as possible for the doityourselfer. However, all too often the instructions furnished arc not as complete or as clear as they should be.

title: GARDENING
description: THE planting season is nigh. Lest gardeners rush ahead without considering the basics, a word or two on soil. For as any planter knows, the end results are only as good as the foundation.

title: MUSIC & DANCE
description: BRIDGEPORTChamber music by Connecticut String Quartet, Monday, 8 P.M., Recital Hall of Bernhard Center, University of Bridgeport, 84 Iranistan Ave. Free.

title: Carey Given Petitions By Concorde Backers
description: Five mailbags said to contain 125,000 petitions urging that the Concorde be allowed into New York were delivered Friday to Governor Carey's Manhattan office by a fourmember delegation from the Concorde Support Committee in France.

title: Joan Little Gets Job Outside Jail
description: RALEIGH, N.C., March 12I don't really regret being in prison or going through the hell I went through, says Joan Little, as she prepares to begin a daily workrelease program. I see it as a learning experience.

title: I Am a Cookbook
description: Children who can read and are interested in cooking, should enjoy I Am a Cookbook by Em Riggs and Barbara Darpinian. The cartoonstrip technique is used to illustrate recipes, operation by operation, and each recipe covers utensils needed, cautions and reminders to wash hands and clean up.

title: ART
description: BEDFORD VILLAGEPrint Portfo??o by members of A.I.R. Gallery, (through April 2). Tuesday to Saturday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Webb & Parsons. BE 49526.

title: POLL SHOWS 71% APPROVE THE WAY CARTER GOVERNS
description: Seventyone percent of the American public approves of the way President Carter is governing the nation and are particularly impressed with his leadership qualities, his solutions to national problems and the way he sides with the average citizen, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Astronomers Announce Satellites Discovered Around Planet Uranus
description: PERTH, Australia. March 12 (AP)Two American astronomers announced yesterday that they had discovered a swarm of satellites around the planet Uranus in what they said was an astronomical find of major importance.

title: Irish Moonshine Tries to Go Legit
description: GALWAY, IrelandA serious attempt is being made in Ireland to produce and market a new beverage with an old history. There is nothing odd about it, except that the product is already made and marketedillegally. It's the mountain dew, or moonshine, that the Irish usually call poteen, or a wee drop of the hard stuff.

title: Charles B. Gardner, ExOwner Of Collection of American Bottles
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., March 12Charles B. Gardner, whose collection of American bottles was considered among the most extensive in the world, died yesterday in a convalescent home here. He was 86 years old and livd at 560 Montauk Avenue here.

title: Daycare for Elderly
description: UNTIL the early 1970's, the only solution to longterm care for the elderly was the nursing home. Recently the concept of daycare centers for the elderly has emerged as another service, designed for that part of the older population designated as the frail elderly, those who need more supervision than can be found at the usual center, but who do not require skilled nursing.

title: A New Theater Company Grows In Brooklyn
description: Frank Dunlop is a burly teddy bear of a man with an adventurous idea: he wants to find a way of doing plays so that people don't have to spend a fortune going to the theater. With that goal in mind, Dunlop, the British director whose productions of Scapino and Sherlock Holmes were substantial successes on Broadway several seasons back, has joined forces with the Brooklyn Academy of Music in founding a back to basics theater company. The accent, he says, will be on good actors doing good plays.

title: PANEL OF CONGRESS ASKS MORE STIMULUS
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Joint Economic Committee of the Congress, contending that President Carter's economic stimulus program fur 1975 would not reduce unemployment fast enough, today recommended new tax reductions and jobcreating programs that would add $11 billion to the projected deficit.

title: West German Soccer
description: Federal Division

title: Yesterday's Shoes In Museum Spotlight
description: FOOT LOOSE, an exhibit of shoes from the 18th century through today, is scheduled to open a fivemonth run at the Newark Museum on Wednesday.

title: The Regrets of a player's Wife
description: The first time I ever saw Julius Erving play was in Greensboro, N.C. He was on the pro team that played the United States Olympic team. I went with a guy who was really crazy over Julius. He had been telling me about this Dr. J for days.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton County Sheriff Nominated
description: ALBANY, March 12 (AP)  Governor Carey has nominated a state police sergeant, Russell J. Trombly of Chazy, to be the sheriff of Clinton County. If confirmed by the State Senate, he would replace Paul Guay, who resigned. Mr. Guay was indicted for allegedly charging personal expenses to the county, but the charges were dismissed during his trial. Mr. Trombly, a 29year veteran of the state police, was nominated for a term ending Dec. 31. An election for a fullterm sheriff will be held this November.

title: The World
description: Latin nations have from the start smarted over President Carter's persistence with his human rights policy, and now Brazil has canceled a 25yearold military assistance treaty with the United States. The immediate reason: a State Department report on human rights that the Brazilians said was an intolerable interference in their country's internal affairs. Other factors, including nuclear sales and nationalism, apparently also played a part.

title: For Marge Grossberger, Sports Are a Way of Life
description: In appointing her to the State Commission on Sports and the 1980 Winter Olympics, Governor Carey continued what has become something of a tradition in Margaret Grossberger's life. Mrs. Grossberger was the only woman named to the commission, a distinction she has held many times during the more than 25 years she has been associated with sports.

title: Book Ends
description: Big Money. For a sum almost equal to( what the Literature Program of the National Endowment for the Arts spends annually to assist writers, Avon Books has purchased the paperback rights to The Thorn Birds, a novel by 38yearold, Australianborn Colleen McCullough which Harper & Row will publish this May. Avon's successful hid of $1.9 million shaded the previous record of $1.85 million paid by Bantam for E. L. Doctorow's Ragtime.

title: Sunday Observer
description: The Mafia needs a new godfather and the papers say it looks like Carmine Galante will get the job. Let him have it, I say. That's what I said, in fact, when a Mafia headhunter interviewed me about taking the job. if you don't take it, he said, it will go to one of the oldtimers like Galante. Let Galante have it, I said.

title: GOLDEN CLAN
description: CONTENTS: PAGE 7

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE HOUSE PASSED President Carter's tax bill to give a $50 rebate to every taxpayer whose taxable Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve income is less than $25,000, but rejected a program

title: INTERVIEW
description: THE hour grew late and fourfifths of the Greenburgh Town Board listened with stony impatience to a resident's lengthy complaint. At the end of the dais, however, one person looked straight at the speaker. The face of Lois Bronz, who took office last year pledging to bring Town Hall to the people, showed concerted interest. She approves of citizens who speak out, having herself been what she calls a complainant during many years in community work.

title: Albany's Mayor Corning Facing Primary Fight With State Senator
description: ALBANY, March 12A week after the death of Daniel P. O'Connell, Albany's almost legendary Democratic boss, the Democratic machine here received its first challenge in decades when State Senator Howard C. Nolan Jr. announced that he would enter a primary. against Mayor Erastus Corning 2d, the incumbent for 36 years and Mr. O'Connell's heir as county leader.

title: Joanne Doriss Plans To Be Bride in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John B. Doriss of Belvedere, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Doriss, to Seth Allen Lefferts, son of Mr. and Mrs. Farnham Lefferts of Darien, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: GOLDEN CLAN
description: The precise moment when the Irish Catholics passed truly into society is unclear, but it is almost certain that the place where it happened was Southampton. True, there were Irish living in the marbled sepulchers of Newport, but Newport was full of the gaudy rich, meat packers, steel barons and oilmen, who looked for something they could not find in Cleveland, say, or Detroit, and who went to Newport to be snubbed and to indulge themselves in the innocent vulgarity that only the seriously rich afford. The members of the 400 had gone to Newport first, causing a colony of artists and writers to flee in some horror, and while there were Catholics among the 400, there were no identifiable Irish Catholics, the first Irish Catholic of great prominence in Newport being Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs, the daughter of James Fair of the Comstock fortune. Theresa, or Tessie, Oelrichs followed an honorable tradition among the great ladies of Newport: She went mad. Mrs. William Backhouse Astor, the Mrs. Astor, who for years presided over Newport in diamond stomachers and solitary majesty, died in 1908, and in her last summers there she stood alone in the drawing room of her mansion, exchanging pleasantries with people who had long since passed on.

title: Judith House Is Bride of George M. McElroy
description: Judith Ann House, daughter of Mrs. James D. House of Bay City, Mich., and the late Mr. House, was married yesterday afternoon to George Michael McElroy, son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. McElroy of Flushing, Queens, and Sag Harbor, L.I.

title: Bertolt Brecht's Only True Comedy Is Exuberantly Staged at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN Mister Puntila and His Chauffeur Matti (at the Yale Repertory Theater) has been called Brecht's only true comedy. It is more overtly comic, more affectionate in its humor and less didactic than other Brecht plays. There are arguments and threats, but no yiolenceno deaths, coups or wars. Both Puntila and The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui date from the author's Finnish period, when he had left Nazi Germany and was on his way to America. Puntila, written in 1940, was drawn from folk tales and an unfinished play by Hells Wuolijoki, a Finnish writer with whom Brecht stayed during his exile.

title: Braveries, vanities, passions
description: Neruda must have written these marvelous, exasperating memoirs fitfully during the last decade of his life, when he was not writing his poetry or reading it to enormous gatherings in many parts of the world, nor dutifully attending congresses or engaging in political activity which the Chilean Communist Party asked of him, nor magisterially accepting honors, like a degree from Oxford and the Nobel Prize (in 1971). Neither his publishers nor his editors say so, but it would he one explanation for their discontinuity and unevenness. They do not hat e a narrative line: whole periods of his lifefor example, his first two marriagesare scarcely mentioned; and an exquisite evocation about the Chilean seaport. Valparaiso, where he lived in his youth, carries more weight and feeling than, say, his joining the Communist Party. Another explanation may he that these are, after all, memoirs: the reader must be thankful for whatever the writer is pleased to remember. But the most persuasive explanation, whatever the manner in which they were written, is that Neruda could not have performed differentlya poetic genius trying in an unaccustomed medium to fit the prose of his life to the persona he created in more than 60 volumes of poetry.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Canaan's Locked Doors
description: MARIE Hewins still keeps her door locked. Fred Krause still talks about the clue he found. And Susan Shores still has a donations jar on the counter of her grocery store, labeled: Please help Peter Reilly.

title: Priest and Rabbi Patch Up Dispute Over a Charge of AntiCatholicism
description: Two wellknown clergymen, the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley, a Roman Catholic sociologist and columnist, and Rabbi Marc H. Tanenbaum of the American Jewish Committee, have apparently patched up their differences after publicly charging each other last year with irresponsibility in a dis?? over alleged antiCatholicism among Jews.

title: Bonn's Foreign Minister Making Sudden Trip to See Carter Amid Climate of Concern Over U.S. Relations
description: BONN, March 12In a climate of unusual concern about the state of West GermanAmerican relations, Chancellor Helmu?? Schmidt is dispatching his Foreign Minister, HansDietrich Genscher, to Washington tomorrow to see President Carter.

title: Jersey Buses Ordered to Keep Free Rides for Small Children
description: NEWARK, March 12 (UPI)A hearing examiner has ruled that the Hudson County Independent Bus Owners Association cannot eliminate free rides for children shorter than three feet.

title: Music: 4S, A1
description: The fourS program  Stravinksy, SaintSatins, Schubert, Schumannpresented by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in Alice Tully Hall on Friday night was ona of its most atractive of the season. It ran the gamut from brilliant fluff to rich emotionalism, and, as tired as one gets of saying so about the ensemble, it was superbly played.

title: Lillian Carter Letters Are Being Published
description: If I had one wish, I would wish for some clean rags, and if I had two wishes, I'd want some cheddar cheese! I'd rather have a chunk of cheese than diamonds.

title: Caviar Cruise
description: Shiphijacking novels do not come along as frequently as planehijacking novelswhich reflects the decline in ocean travel as well as the greater complexity involved in making off with an ocean liner. (If you have further interest in this exotic felony, you should read Desmond Lowden's 1969 novel, Bandersnatch.) First Mate Don Howard of the luxury liner Naiad has given much thought to the problem and has come up with a nearly perfect solution, as his ship cruises the Mediterranean with a boatload of the overprivileged.

title: MISCELLANEOUS
description: NEW ROCHELLEThe Wizard of Math, an exhibition on the metric system, geometric patterns, statistics and probabilities. Computers and calculators will be on hand for experimentation. Every day, except Friday, 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. (through June 30). Wildcliff Museum, Wildcliff Rd. 6362108.

title: 100 Years of Living, 20 Years of Painting
description: THE WAY Harry Lieberman figures it, an old man needs a reason to get out of bed in the morning, and the older he gets, the better the reason needs to be.

title: Jay E. Phipps Is the Fiancee Of James Heick
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. L. Arthur St. Phillip of Easthampton, L.I., of the engagement of Mrs. St. Phillip's daughter, Jay Eugenie Phipps of Hilo, Hawaii, to James T. Heick, also of Hilo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael G. Heick of Birmingham, Mich.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: Kafka in Yiddish

title: Prison Death House Now Gives Life
description: EACH weekday morning, Alfred Wilson boards the 6:04 A.M. out of Ossining and, like most other New York City commuters, is on his way to work. At night, he returns home, not to a log fire or a cigar and a martini, but to a dormitory block at the Ossining Correctional Facility.

title: Vintage Ford Autos With Jaguar Suspension
description: DO YOU YEARN to dance the Charleston and carry a hip flask? Feel like flipping for bobhaired flappers and those campus cutups in raccoon coats? Do your jaded old peepers grow misty with nostalgia for that golden decade of the 1920's sometimes known as the era of wonderful nonsense?

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Inflation jitters rattled the stock market last week, but sugarrelated issues managed to experience a burst of buying after the Government proposed a ban on the use of saccharin in foods and beverages. These stocks had declined in anticipation of the Government's action and then rebounded when the news was disseminated.

title: Fairy tale with a dark ending
description: Gayatri Devi, former Maharani of Jaipur, appears twice in The Guinness Book of Records; once indirectly, for partaking in the most expensive wedding in the world (that of her husband's eldest daughter), and the second time for winning the largest majority (175,000 votes) of any candidate running for any election in any democratic country in the world. These two events give you some idea of the astonishing range of the woman's life.

title: Star Ball, $14.20, Wins Stakes at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif. March 12 (AP)Star Ball made a sharp left turn as she headed for home, grabbed the rail and rallied boldly to win the $57,650 Santa Gertrudes Handicap at Santa Anita today, thrilling a crowd of 33,272 with a $14.20 win payoff.

title: LongSought Credibility for New York Said to Suffer From Maneuvers Designed to Avoid Fiscal Collapse
description: Top officials said yesterday that despite New York City's rescue from fiscal collapse last week the maneuvering was setback in the drive to strengthen the city's finances and regain the confidence of the nation's investment community.

title: A German Affair
description: Private Billy Kohl, on the lowest rung of the ladder in the military government of Stuttgart in 052, finds that he is almost top dog among the civilian population. Civilians scramble for cigarette butts, which are more negotiable than the paper currency. And the basic rate for prostitutes is 20 marks, or five dollars. His comparative affluence allows Billy to float freely through the beer halls and redlight district of the city, collecting sordid experiences and learning something about himself. His German affair is a brief encounter with Ursula, a warmhearted seamstress of 40, with whom he has a perishable relationship. At 18, Hilly is better suited to take than to give.

title: Walking Around
description: Translated by Robert sly. From Neruda and Vallejo: Selected Poems, Beacon Press.

title: Hundreds Stranded by a Blizzard in Central Plains
description: A blizzard howled across the Central Plains today, burying towns, blocking passenger trains and stranding hundreds of travelers in five states.

title: John Evelyn du Pont Irving Jr. Marries Pandora Duke Biddle
description: Pandora Duke Biddle and John. Evelyn du Pont Irving Jr. were married yesterday afternoon at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Hays Rockwell.

title: Leslie Rotkoff Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rotkoff of CrotononHudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Rotkoff, to Cadet Paul Boyd Neal 3d, a first classman at the United States Military Academy, son of Roberta Neal of Lancaster, Calif., and Mr. Neal 2d of San Antonio, Tex. The future bride attends the United States Military Academy Preparatory School at Fort Monmouth N.J.

title: Oregon Takes Title
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 12 (UPI)Oregon broke California's hold on the Pac8 gymnastics title and won its first conference championship last night. California finished second.

title: Sex for Aged Issue in Arkansas
description: ARKADELPHIA, Ark., March 12Sex among the residents of homes for the aged has become a heated issue in Arkansas since the subject came up at a federally funded workshop for nursing home operators.

title: TIMES BOOK REVIEW WILL BE EXPANDED
description: Extensive changes in the content and format of The New York Times Book Review will be made beginning with the April 3 issue of the Sunday supplement, published as a separate section of the newspaper since 1922.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: THE old man and the young boy sat on a stoop next to the tavern, sharing the last of a fifth of cheap chemical wine. They had the same hooded, supercilious look in their eyesthe ghetto defense that made social workers resent them, politicians ignore them and policemen attack them. Smug, cornplacent looks. Lords of the world. As if they were in control of their lives, in tune with their environs.

title: It's Hard to Leave While the Music's Playing
description: The fine line between mercy killing and death of natural causes is the theme of this trendy novel by a neurosurgeon. It's a line made indistinct, as recent events have shown. by the development of intensivecare technology. Dr. Cooper's hero is Dan Carter, a kidney specialist who finds himself on trial for murder after acceding to the wishes of a friend dying of a debilitating disease. Dr. Carter disconnects the man's respirator and is straightaway in the thick of professional, ethical and legal battles. He loses the first to his professional enemies, wins the last in court and is in a quandary about the ethics of his actions as the curtain comes down.

title: French Watch Local Elections TodayEspecially Paris Mayoraltyfor Indications of National Trend
description: PARIS, March 12France's political state of mind is expected to become clearer tomorrow in the first round of the most significant nationwide municipal elections in the 19year history of the Fifth Republic.

title: 6,500 G. M. Workers Walk Out At Assembly Plant in Wisconsin
description: DETROIT, March 12 (UPI)About 6,500 employees at a key General Motors Corporation assembly plant in Wisconsin walked off their jobs early today, joining 1,200 G.M. workers in Ohio in strikes over local contract issues.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Reform Judaism has issued a new book for home prayer that is both more modern and more traditional than the 25yearold volume it replaces.

title: POLITICS
description: PERHAPS the long, bitter winter and the fitful approach of spring brought them prematurely out of their dark hiding places, or perhaps it was the familiar, reassuring sound of Democrats fighting among themselves, but the Republicans who think they would like to run for Governor next year are already moving cautiously into the open in Connecticut, like a bevy of lovely but insecure stepmothers gliding regally through the halls of their fairy castle, frowning only slightly at one another, stopping occasionally to study their own reflections uncertainly, as if to ask:

title: Blueberries Lavender
description: As a child I disliked nature poetry. I felt cheated: Too often the poet cared more for his metaphor than for his meadow. And why not rejoice in a real meadow instead of the pale memory of one?

title: L. A. Heneveld Jr. To Wed Julia Ryan
description: Mr. and Mrs. John T. Ryan Jr. of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julia Elizabeth Ryan, to L. Allen Heneveld Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd A. Heneveld of Grand Rapids, Mich. The wedding is planned for Aug. 27.

title: Zaire Says It Is Repelling Invaders
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 12 (AP)The Zaire radio said today that Government troops were crushing the invading forces that crossed from Angola earlier in the week and occupied three towns in copperproducing Shaba province.

title: What's Doing on the MISSISSIPPI COAST
description: AMBIENCEMississippi's subtropical Gulf Coast has, from 1699 on, attracted a polyglot group: European explorers, pirates and remittance men and proper members of New Orleans society who, every summer before airconditioning, moved their householdschildren and cooksto their country houses along the Mississippi Sound. More recently discovered by Midwestern and Northern tourists and golfers, the Coast has, despite devastation by hurricanes and the proliferation of hotels and motels, maintained its appealing ambience its 26milelong stretch of beaches, huge old oak trees, yearround golf and tennis, interesting architecture and historic landmarks. And its waters yield vast quantities of fish, shrimp and oysters. Unlike many parts of the country, where property owners have closed off beaches for their own private use, the Mississippi Gulf Coast has democratically kept its waterfront land open to the public, for strolling, picnicking or launching a boat. It's possible to swim, too, if one doesn't mind warm, calm water and wading out beyond the shallows. The main towns are Pass Christian, noted for its Southern beachfront homes; Gulfport, a busy port town; Biloxi, with a concentration of hotels; Ocean Springs, a village reminiscent of some New England coastal villages, and Pascagoula, an industrial and fishing center.

title: American Matador in Nogales
description: NOGALES, Mexico  Across the valley, small round trees resembled soft green polka dots on the beige hills. In the afternoon sun, autos and vans turned slowly into the dirt parking lot from the narrow gray asphalt road leading out of this dusty Mexican border town. Most of the 1,500 aficionados had driven 65 miles from Tucson, Ariz., to see Diego O'Bolger, the American of matador. From the top row of the Plaza de Toros Guadalupe, a small minor league hull ring of white cement blocks notched into the side of another hill, the lead trumpeter in the Nogales Brass, no relation to Herb Alpert either by blood or tone, entertained the early arrivals. Even those who thought they would be late were early arrivals.

title: TV VIEW
description: The following story, worthy of a tacky madeforTV production of its own, could be called The Deadly Awards Game, and subtitled Why I Withdrew from the TV Critics Circle Adventure. To begin with, the Circle is an uneasy conglomeration that was hastily concocted for what seems to be the benefit of a twohour CBS special, The TV Critics Circle Awards, scheduled for April 11. The original idea, drenched in presumably good intentions, resulted from trouble within the Emmy Awards camp over the past year. A battle between the New York and Hollywood chapters of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences has left the organization splintered, and plans to proceed with this year's annual Emmy Awards show on May 15 appear at the moment to be more wishful than practical.

title: Letters: Readers Rise To Defense of Cancun
description: To the Editor:

title: ...But Humans Pollute As Well, and Suffer
description: RECIFE, BrazilWater pollution does not always result from industrial callousness; in this northeastern region of Brazil, 4 million impoverished peasants are affected by schistosomiasis, a deadly disease carried by infected snails that live in streams and ponds polluted by human waste.

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote to confirm the nomination of Paul C. Warnke for the rank of Ambassador for SALT negotiations, which passed, 58 to 40, March 9.

title: New Ivy League Magazine Will Be Published Soon By Students at Columbia
description: Student journalists at Columbia University plan to publish soon a monthly news magazine aimed at the eight Ivy League academic communities.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: PERHAPS the cancellation of the plays of the Bard at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford for this season didn't have to happen, as Ina Bradley wrote recently in this space. But as a Stratford native, and the one who introduced Lawrence Langner to our town, I feel the cancellation might be the best thing that could have happened to the theater, the town, the arts of Connecticut and William Shakespeare.

title: The Greening of New Haven
description: SELF  EFFACING PEOPLE, the Irish waited 207 years before asserting their right to march around New Haven on St. Patrick's Day.

title: The Conrail Trek Out of Danbury
description: FOR MOST people, four hours is half a day's work. For people who live in the Danbury area and travel by train to work in New York City, four hours is the commuting time alone.

title: Asian Dance Is It Ethnic Or Classical?
description: Normally, most of us would have no trouble distinguishing Kentucky's square dances from the solos danced by Rudolf Nureyev. The folk dances of the first type could be called ethnic dance from the United States. The second kind of dancing is classical ballet.

title: Bergen Quandary: What to
description: DECLINING school enrollments are challenging Boards of Education In Bergen County to come up with answers to what should be done with school buildings that are no longer needed for educational purposes.

title: On the Dole In the Best Of Times
description: FOR THE arts in Connecticut, it is the best of times and the worst of times.In the last five years, 10 million people have viewed performances and exhibitions at Connecticut's major cultural centers. The audience for the arts in the state is said to be growing by 125,000 people a year.

title: Diving
description: AT CLEVELAND

title: A talk with Castro
description: An American President confided to a friend: Just at the moment, I am so angry at that infernal little Cuban republic that I would like to wipe its people off the face of the earth. . . They have started an utterly unjustifiable and pointless revolution and may get things into such a snarl that we have no alternative save to intervene. . . .

title: Already, Questions in Lake Placid...
description: The 1980 Winter Olympics are nearly three years away, but the prospect is already affecting land values and development plans in Lake Placid, N. Y. A surge of construction that includes major motels, a shopping center and two sizable residential subdivisions has begun, some of it directly related to the expectation of rising tourism.

title: Dog Shows
description: AT SUFFERN, N.Y.

title: U. S. Aid Asked in Coast Drought
description: YAKIMA, Wash., March 12 (AP)Gov. Dixy Lee Ray has asked President Carter to declare a Federal drought emergency in the Yakima Valley.

title: Medical Center: It's Ready to Go
description: THE County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, had nearly completed a walk through the new Medical Center recently, past colorcoded signs, in color coordinated corridors, into two patient rooms with pastel draperies and electrically controlled beds, around stations for nurses equipped with computerlike consoles and through a modern boiler room that would do nicely in the QE2.

title: Divers From Big Ten Sweep Qualifying Event
description: CLEVELAND, March 12 (AP)Big Ten divers took all 15 qualifying spots today in the threemeter zone competion at Cleveland State University, earning berths in the National Collegiate Division I swimming and diving championships here, March 2426.

title: Soviet Honors Newspaper
description: MOSCOW, March 32 (Reuters)The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia has been awarded the Order of the October Revolution, one of the country's top honors, for its services in the Communist education of the people, it was announced today. Izvestia, which prints nine million copies daily, was given the award to mark its 60th anniversary.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: The right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness for a woman begins with her right to determine her reproductive future, and when, whether and under what circumstances she wishes to bear a child.

title: From the right came voices
description: Things are not what they seem. This is the great message of all art and science, indeed of all thought worth the name. But what if thought itself is not what it seems? This is Julian Jaynes's point of departure in a book that will enlighten and Infuriate any reader who gets past the forbidding (hut characteristically precise) title and meets the author halfway.

title: The Region
description: A decision on whether to permit the supersonic Concorde airliner to land in New York City has been put off again by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, largely out of concern for the residents around Kennedy Airport, and the question may now be decided in court.

title: EAST BLOC EXPECTING RIGHTS DRIVE TO FADE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 12Communist leaders in Eastern Europe feel there is reason to hope that the commotion caused by appeals for human rights in recent months is about played out.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: The crocus made it through the winter. Surely no one doubted they would. Right on schedule spears of foliage pushed up through the muddy soil, and just a few sunny afternoons spread the yellow, purple and white petals.

title: The Big Top Without the Tent
description: SPRING is just around the corner, and so is circus season. In fact, a circus came to town just the other day. But there was no parade dawn Main Street. the acrobats, clowns, musicians and animals didn't arrive in red and gold wagons, and they didn't come with a cadre of roustabouts to pitch the tent, because there are no tents for this circus.

title: America B.C.
description: The great and justifiable increase in the popularity of archeology in the last 20 years has, understandably and regrettably, increased the number of rubbish hooks that are publishedthose offarcheology books that lie unhappily on bookstore shelves, the book sellers who have arranged them there vaguely wondering whether they ought not to be in folklore and mythology. No bookseller yet known to me from Brentano to Blackwell has had the courage to label a series of shelves formally The Maniacal Fringes of Archeology. If he did he would, alas, find it a bestselling corner of his store.

title: Democratic Legislative Study Group Criticizes Antipoverty Programs
description: A Democratic state legislative group has charged that New York City's S40 million antipoverty program is inadequate, mismanaged, undersupervised and in need of an overhaul.

title: The Urge to Merge
description: Aidied and sbe??ed by relatively easy borrowing rates and stock market, prices, corporate ma??ng ??es continued apace last week. Among the widely known couples were:

title: DINING OUT
description: MARRYING the best of a pub menu to the roomy comfort of a large restaurant, Parsley has come up a winner. Now at two Connecticut locations 12 miles apart on U.S. 1, Parsley offers almost the identical menu at both and, in fact, prepares the basic foods only at one. Though our sampling was done at the newer of the two, just north of Greenwich, the judgments can presumably be taken as a guide to the level of quality at the original Norwalk.

title: Glen Cove's Way of Helping Alcoholics
description: GLEN COVE IN 1973, a study by William Collins, a social worker, brought to light a disturbing fact about Glen Covethat as a community, its level of alcohol abuse was uncommonly high.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: Professionally speaking, women architects have yet to get out of the kitchen. They are chained, tied and condemned to the houseto house design and house interiors in the name design efficiency, gemtlichkeit and the family. They are supposed to know more than anyone else about kitchens and related matters, practically and symbolically, through intimate familiarity and natural concern, and they have vacillated between treating the affinity as an advantage or as a curse.

title: GARDENING
description: THE PLANTING season is high. Lest gardeners rush ahead without considering the basics, a word or two on soil. As any planter knows, the end results are only as mod as the foundation.

title: Miss McKegney To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Osborne A. McKegney of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Westhampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann McKegney, to Philip Campbell Dunn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. Franklyn Dunn of Middletown, Conn.

title: Neruda In New York
description: On a rainy April morning in 1972 we stood waiting for Pablo Neruda to arrive at Kennedy Airport. The usual airport anxiety was heightened because Neruda had almost decided not to come. A dawn telephone call from the embassy in Paris: he had a toothache, was canceling the trip. But after some aspirin he changed his mind, and so we were standing around, talking about dentists. Then suddenly he was there, the familiar walrus face moving through the crowd. Handshakes, abrazos, everyone wanting to greet him as we slowly made our way out to the waiting car.

title: Donald Alan Buser, Real Estate Broker, Weds Joanne Egan
description: Joanne Barrett Egan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Egan of Mountainside, N. J., was married yesterday in Summit, N. J., to Douglas Alan Buser, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald James Buser of Estes Park, Colo.

title: VISITORS TO VIETNAM REPORT FARMING GAIN
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 12Westerners who visited Vietnam almost two years after the end of the war report that agricultural recovery is progressing although rice rationing continues in both North and South.

title: Bean Cards 71 for 205, Widens Lead to 3 Shots
description: MIAMI, March 12On a statistical basis, Andy Bean is in a good position to give himself a fine present for his 24th birthday tomorrow. He built a threestroke lead today in the third round of the DoralEastern open and. as it happens, the thirdround leader has won each of the nine tournaments that have been played this season on the progolf tour.

title: Collision Kills 15 Turks
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 12 (UPI)A bus and a truck collided in a dense fog, today bursting into flames and burning 15 persons to death, the police said. The dead included the bus driver and 14 of the 35 passengers. Eight other passengers were hospitalized. The police did not report the condition of the truck driver.

title: IMSA Gets New Sponsor for One of Its Programs
description: While one of this country's two road racing sanctioning bodies fl??unders the other one thrives.

title: Selling America the avantgarde
description: In 1927 when Julien Levy left Harvard he was an exceptionally handsome young man, perhaps something of a dandy, certainly a little bored by what he calls his so commonsensical . . . country of pragmatism. Within the year, frustrated by his father's refusal to invest in a career making experimental films, he had gone to Paris in the company of Marcel Duchamp to work with his idol Man Ray, had met the circle of expatriate American celebrities and had married Joella Loy daughter of the famous Mina, the onetime wife of the protoDada boxerpoet Arthur Cravan, himself the nephew of Oscar Wildeexcellent credentials with which to begin a career as host to the European avant  garde in America.

title: Isley Brothers: A Family Affair
description: WHEN Sallye Isley moved her brood of children from Cincinnati to Englewood in the summer of 1959, she was participating in a showbusiness phenomenon. Success had just come suddenly. Her eldest sons had just recorded a smash hit, Shout, that turned rockandroll upside down.

title: Monroe Scores 34 to Little Avail
description: Executing poorly in all phases of play, the Knicks played just a bit worse than the Seattle SuperSonics at Madison Square Garden last night and suffered a 9188 loss that made their slim hopes for a berth in the National Basketball Association playoffs virtually disappear.

title: Legislature Cool To Tuition Plan
description: ACONTROVERSIAL proposal that would change the way in which state funds are channeled into higher education in New Jersey apparently is an idea whose time has not come.

title: BLAST IN MASSACHUSETTS IS LINKED TO CARTER VISIT
description: MARLBORO, Mass., March 12 (UPI)A bomb exploded at an unoccupied factory tonight, doing extensive damage, the police said. Responsibility for the explosion was assumed by a radical group that has previously declared that it bombed other buildings.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: After the rape of two women students and the beating of a third by a robberall within four monthsYale University in early 1976 barricaded Phelps Gate, the archway facing the New Haven Town Green. The Yale Daily News called for more locked gates on campus and the hiring of special guards.

title: ART
description: GARDEN CITY

title: Marchers Mark Day for Women, Ask More Gains
description: In keeping with a 68yearold tradition, hundreds of women from nearly 40 Women's groups marched through the streets of New York yesterday to celebrate International Women's Day.

title: The Standings
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: THE House of Representatives' new code of ethics may have sailed through that chamber earlier this month, but it didn't go over too well with the Island's Congressional delegation.

title: Freed Hostages Recite Blessing At Temple Rites
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Sabbath is a day of quiet joy for Jews, but today the words of the morning serviceThou didst redeem us, O Lord our God: and from the house of bondage thou didst deliver usheld an even deeper sweetness within the sanctuary of Temple Adas Israel.

title: U.S. to Retry Jerseyan on Charge He Threatened Rockefeller's Life
description: ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 12 (AP) The Government plans to retry Robert F. Dufala on a charge that he had threatened to kill Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller with a cyanide bullet last July 4th weekend, Jonathon L. Goldstein, a United States Attorney said Friday.

title: WESTERNERS CHAFED BY U.S. LAND HOLDINGS
description: The Federal Government owns 762 million of the nation's 2.3 billion acres, or onethird of the gross land area of the United States.

title: Delay Granted in Airwest Case
description: RENO, March 12 (UPI)A onemonth delay has been ordered in the trial of three former associates of the late Howard R. Hughes who are charged with stock manipulation involving the takeover of Airwest Airlines. The trial, scheduled to begin Monday, was reset for April 18. Federal District Judge Bruce Thompson granted the delay yesterday to give the prosecution additional time to find a missing witness.

title: La Technique
description: One of the most ambitious and helpful cookbooks of the season is La Technique by the chef and food columnist, Jacques Pepin. It is, as its subtitle promises, an illustrated guide to the fundamental techniques of cooking. All basic techniques and recipes are illustrated with step by step photographic close  ups of operations in progress, and though the pictures themselves are lacklustre, they are minutely explicit.

title: Mr. Beanie Has Sensed Doomsday Before
description: New York City is in crisis and ton few people believe it.

title: THEATER
description: HEMPSTEADRomeo and Juliet, presented by Hofstra University Shakespeare Festival; today and next Sunday 3 P.M.; Friday, Saturday 8:30 P.M.; John Cranford Adams Theater, University Campus. Tickets $2.50 to $3.50. 5603283.

title: The Royal Road Of the Incas
