description: Popular archeology is a puzzle. Why should piles of potsherds or unreadable hieroglyphs fascinate great multitudes of lay tourists and readers? The appeal of actual ancient art objects, of mummies and sphinxes and partherons is easy to grasp. But the power behind the spell cast over the contemporary popular mind even by nondescript ruins, mere ancient rubble, is an enigma best left to the popular archeologists of a future time. Yet there can be no doubt that prehistory, even without the gold of Tutankhamen, or his curse, to jazz it up, is a crowd pleaser. And here are two new contenders for the attention of us buffs.

title: Students in Italy Protest a Killing
description: ROME (AP)Thousands of leftwing youths battled police officers in Italian cities from Milan to Palermo Saturday, protesting the killing of a student leader in Communistrun Bologna.

title: A Taste of The Cultural Vitality Of Berlin
description: Berlin Now is the name of a festival of drama, cinema, art, music and literature which began in New York City yesterday and goes on through April 19. As its title indicates, it is primarily concerned with what has happened in Berlin during the last 10 years or so. Berlin Then would be a great subject for a festival, but it is not the subject of this one.

title: Feld Dances in Real McCoy and Soldier's Tale
description: It is odd but one suspects that one will never know quite how good a choreographer Eliot Feld is, until you realize quite how good a dancer he is. Almost every major choreographer of our century has been a fairly strong technical danceraccepting that Sir Frederick Ashton was merely perverse but proficient, Antony Tudor must remain as the only exceptionand Mr. Feld is a fine dancer indeed. A dancer very much of the Jerome Robbins mold.

title: Camping on Cinnamon Bay, The Caribbean a Tent Flap Away
description: Normally I don't mind the snow, espe cially when I'm boarding a plane headed for the Caribbean. Not this time. Our 727 had been delayed on the strip at Kennedy, waiting for the plows to clear the runway. We were heading for a camping vacation in the Virgin Islands, and the longer we were held up, the greater the chance we would have to grope our way through a dark unfamiliar campsite trying to find our tent.

title: In Memoriam
description: CULLIGANCharles R. 9th Happy Shilday in Heaven Cully, ever with me.

title: Westport's Overexposure
description: SOME SORT OF solution really must be found for Wesport. The problem, actually, is that too much has been said and continues to be said about the place. This supposedly archetypal exurb appears with such regularity in the media that a moratorium is clearly called for.

title: Questions and Answers on Tax Shelters
description: Tax shelter. No phrase in the tax lexicon is more controversial or less precise. It is a term loosely applied to any investment that gives the investor an immediate, substantial tax deduction, often much greater than the cash he puts up. The deductions shelter his income from other sources by offsetting taxes he would otherwise pay.

title: 20 Years Before the Rails
description: I AM the wife of a commuter. I am also the daughter and granddaughter of commuters. As a matter of fact, my grandfather was one of the first international corporate transfers. He was brought over from England by the Dromedary Date Company to work in its New York office before the turn of the century.

title: Federal Housing Department Changes Policy, Backs LowIncome Project in Philadelphia
description: WASHINGTON, March 12The Department of Housing and Urban Development, in a change of policy, has decided to support an effort by lowincome Philadelphia residents to compel the city to build a controversial housing project in the middleclass Whitman Park district,

title: Behind the Flynn Decision
description: THE unmaking of a candidate in 1977 in Westchester can be a slow and painful process. Actually John E. Flynn, who is in his sixth term as State Senator after three terms as Mayor of Yonkers, was never a declared candidate for County Executive, but Republican leaders tried for months to persuade him to run, and he came close, very close.

title: The Law and Citizens' Rights
description: THERE are more than 500 local governing bodies in New Jersey and thousands of citizens take public office each year as mayors and councilmen. Because most are neither lawyers nor in any way trained in the law, the constitutionality of local legislation is a question that often arises.

title: BOOKS
description: If the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers were to write a book, would Count Dracula or Fear of Flying be a more likely prototype? Absurd question?

title: Cuevas Retains Title
description: MEXICO CITY, March 12 (AP)The World Boxing Association welterweight champion, Jose (Pipino) Cuevas, retained his crown by knocking out Argentina's Miguel Angel Campanino in the second round of a scheduled 15round fight tonight.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Purchase by Hospital
description: The Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center has acquired the threestory office building at 400 Lakeville Road in Lake Success, L. I., from Levitt & Sons for about $2.5 million.

title: Ritger Captures Final, Ending Bowling Slump
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 12Dick Ritger of River Falls, Wisc., a 38yearold who Is on the verge of semiretirement from the Professional Bowlers Association tour, won the $100,000 A.M.F. Pro Classic today at the Garden City Bowl. He earned a firstprize check of $14,000.

title: The Water Conference at Mar del Plata Will Try to Figure Out What to Do About Pollution, Overpopulation, Waste
The watery World of Florida's Pennekamp State Park
description: The entrance to John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park in the Florida Keys is halfway between Mile Markers 104 and 105 on the Overseas Highway (U.S. 1) just north of Key Largo, about 55 miles south of Miami. The park was established in 1960 to preserve approximately a 20mile stretch of the 125milelong reef that runs along the Keys, the only living coral reef in the continental United States. The park covers about 100 square miles, threefourths under the clear blue waters of the Atlantic Ocean. Its attractions: swimming, snorkeling, scuba diving, sailing, fishing, a glassbottom boat, nature hikes, camping and picnicking by a tropical sea.

title: A Plea For Just Funding Of Towns
description: CONNECTICUT is the wealthiest state in the country, but few state governments treat their cities and towns more poorly than Hartford does. For instance, only 21 percent of localgovernment expenditures in Connecticut in 1975 were financed from state aid, compared with 35 percent for local governments in the United States as a whole. This puts Connecticut 47th in the country in state aid to municipalities, one place worse than the year before.

title: Redmen Bow, 7268, in N.C.A.A.Dons Routed by Nevada
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 12St. John's was nudged and San Francisco was blasted out of the National Collegiate basketball tournament today. Utah's outside shooting beat the New Yorkers, 7268, and the speed and rapacious defense of NevadaLas Vegas routed the Dons, 12195.

title: Headliners
description: The Captain Takes Over

title: RICHARD GUGGENHEIMER, AN ARTIST AND EDUCATOR
description: Richard H. Guggenheimer, artist, writer and for 30 years chairman of the art department at Briarcliff College, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 784 Park Avenue.

title: A Grieving Mother Finds Hope in Art.
description: ANNE LOCKE PACKARD, a 43yearold housewife and freelance artist from Hopewell, can still see them clearlyher eon Stephen, 18 years old, and his girl, Linda Lovellthe morning they left to hitchhike to the Pacific Coast:

title: A New Index on the Quality of Life
description: For years economists have been concerned that traditional measures have failed to take into account the impact of economic growth on the lives of people.

title: A Real Rats' Nest
description: WANTAGH JUDITH JACOBS, president of the South Woodbury Taxpayers Association, has set a goal for herself that might ultimately earn her the uncontested title of Pied Piper of Nassau County. She is determined to rid Nassau of its multiplying rats.

title: Ford's Man of the World
description: The family was sitting around a dinner table in Moscow in 1970 when the American executive decided to break the news to the children. Hours before they left Detroit for a Russian vacation, his boss at the Ford Motor Company offered him a new assignment: running the Philco subsidiary in Philadelphia.

title: Weddings
description: ArnoneLombardi

title: $20 Million Went to Members of Congress in 1976For Something
description: WASHINGTONThere is a natural concern about the propriety of the transaction when private groups with high stakes in legislation give more than $20 million to the men and women who write that legislation in a year when almost all of them need money badly. That is essentially what happened in 1976, when political committees sponsored by labor unions, corporations and other interest groups legally contributed money in record amounts to the campaigns of hundreds of Senators and Representatives and. to a lesser extent, to challengers seeking to unseat them.

title: The Future of Tennis: Order Is Needed
description: With all of it_s popularity and prosperity, its politics and its potential, what is tennis's future? In the coming five or 10 years, what will become of the W.C.T., the W.T.T., the A.T.P., the I.L.T.F., the Virginia Slims, the W.T.A., the'challenge matches? And what of the forces, the personalities who have stamped and splintered the game: Jack Kramer, Donald Dell, Bill Riordan, Billie Jean and Larry King, Lamar Hunt, Mike Davies, Bob Briner, Arthur Ashe, Jimmy Connors, Sol Berg? Are there answers applicable to a world of dynamic, dugin men whose priorities seldom seem to he tennis, but rather their own fractions of it?

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: The widely recognized movement towards smaller, lighter, and more automated cameras seems to have triggered a counter movement in the direction of larger, heavier, and nonautomated 4x5 view cameras. Recent interviews with photographers, manufacturers, and dealers have brought to light some intriguing reasons for this trend.

title: Future of Law Regulating Apartment Conversions to Condominiums and Cooperatives Debated at Hearing
Simple French Food
description: The paperback version of Simple French Food, is devoted to the cuisine bourgeoise rather the haute cuisine, presenting all of the economical, savory and hearty specialties of the French home kitchen. There are excellent vegetable dishes here, by the way, such as onion pudding, au gratin of eggplant and a whole cabbage stuffed with pork and braised with tomatoes. Most of them are economical as well as simple to prepare.

title: Banishing the Press, The President Views Tutankhamen Relics
description: WASHINGTON, March 12After a photographer on his own staff tripped and fell over a statue today, President Carter ordered a small press contingent out of the National Gallery of Art, where he and his wife were touring the popular exhibition of relics from the tomb of King Tutankhamen.

title: High School Athletes Need Fewer Limits on When to Compete
description: If the president's Commission on Olympic Sports accomplishes nothing else, it has at least awakened the American public to the sins committed in its name in the infringement of athletes' rights.

title: Working in the Roots Field
description: ROSLYN ROOTS may be the most vivid thing to hit the mass conscience in decades, but a year before that phenomenon appeared, a modest attempt to explore the history and culture of American blacks had already begun at the Nassau County Center for Fine Arts here.

title: Perhaps Too Big: Dr. Burns and Mr. Carter Are on Collision Course
description: In the coming months, President Carter's economic stimulus package could bring to a head a long dispute about the independentand consistently conservativerole that the Federal Reserve Board traditionally has played in making American economic policy.

title: Rangers' Scoring
description: FIRST PERIOD1, Atlanta, Lysiak (22) (Gould, Manery) 3:40. 2, Atlanta, Clement 14 ?? Kea) 7:17. PenaltiesHouston. 0:23; ?? Mulhern, majorminor, (minor served by ?? chych), 4:11, Bennett, 6:53. Fot u, 9:51; ?? 9:51, Vadnais, 12:35. Romanchych, 18:17.

title: Water Crisis Caused by Man and Nature to Be Explored at U.N. Conference
description: Droughtstricken or snowbound, inundated by rampaging floods or sickened by contaminated reservoirs, people in almost every region of the world have long struggled against the caprices and crises of water.

title: Deaths
description: ABERNETHYSamuel, of Tryon, N.C and formerly of New Canaan, Conn. on March 10, 1977, beloved husband of Jane Dunn. father of Joan Wright and Samuel, grandfather of Eden Wright. Services Tuesday, March 15 4 P.M. at Church of the Holy Cross. Tryon, N.C, and memorial service St. Mark's Episcopal Church at P.M., March 26, New Canaan, Conn. In lleu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to St. Luke's Hospital, Tryon, N.C. 28782.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: Endorsed Democrat Apparently Holds Edge in Pittsburgh Mayoral Race
description: PITTSBURGH, March 12The nomination of Mayor Peter F. Flaherty to be Deputy United States Attorney General apparently has given a commanding edge to Thomas J. Foerster in this year's mayoral race.

title: 2 in Row for Miss Barker
description: DALLAS, March 13 (AP)  Sue Barker, Britain's 20yearold tennis star, scored with a topspin forehand and an unerring backhand in defeating Terry Holladay, 61, 76, and capturing her second straight Virginia Slims tennis tournament today.

title: Weekend College Results
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL

title: Rabin Says Carter Asked Too Much On Frontier Issue
description: WASHINGTON. March 13Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel says that he rejects President Carter's view that as part of a final Middle East settlement Israel should give up virtually all territory captured from the Arabs in the 1967 war, allowing for only minor adjustments in the prewar frontiers.

title: SENATE TO CONSIDER TOUGH ETHICS CODE
description: WASHINGTON, March 13A proposed code of ethics that would go beyond the provisions of the code approved recently by the House of Representatives is scheduled to reach the Senate floor Wednesday. Its backers hope the code will bolster public confidence in the Senate.

title: China to Increase 2Way Group Visits Under U.S. Accord
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 13China has agreed to an increase in exchange visits with the United States in a move seen by some as a possible overture to the Carter Administration.

title: Theater: Gemini Is Exceptional
description: When Albert Innaurato's Gemini was first presented in December at Playwrights Horizon, it seemed to be a grand, comic soap opera. In the play's latest and, presumably, definitive version, which opened last night at the Circle Repertory Company, we not only see the rambunctious and bizarre comic vision, but we also feel the heartbeat.

title: Survivors Recall Cracow Ghetto in Memorial to Those Who Died
description: LAKE SUCCESS, L.I., March 13The survivors of the Jewish community of Cracow, Poland, gathered here today to remember. But they found that the candles and the hymns and the speeches and the murals were inadequate memorials to that clayMarch 13, 1943when hundreds ofJews were murdered by nazis in the Cracow ghetto and thousands more were loaded into trucks bound for the death camps.

title: Music: Much Improved Orchestra
description: The Symphony of the New World is a mightily improved orchestra nowadays, judging from the concert it put on yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall under its music director, Everett Lee. The group, now in its 12th season as a racially integrated organization, has had its ups and downs over the years but to a listener who had not heard it for some time the performances were surprising in their technical security.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Maze Of Activity in Fiscal Crisis
description: It started last November when Mayor Beame was in Israel on his first trip abroad. An overseas telephone call from New York's City Hall to Tel Aviv notified the Mayor that the legislatively imposed moratorium on nearly $1 billion in city debts had just been struck down by the State Court of Appeals.

title: Boys in West Germany Die in Grenade Mishap
description: WILDFLECKEN, West Germany, March 13 (UPI)Three sons of American soldiers were killed yesterday in the accidental explosion of a United States Army grenade they had been using as a toy in the cellar of their apartment building, the West German police said today.

title: Michigan Bans Chemical In Cattle Contamination
description: LANSING, Mich., March 13 (AP)Michigan's agriculture director says he will issue an order tomorrow temporarily banning the sale of the chemical PCP, a pesticide and wood preservative, until new standards can be drafted to govern its use.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNCN. Valse Scherzo, Tchaikovsky; Polonaise, Scherwenka; Symphony in D (K. 81), Mozart; Tsar's Bride Overture, RimskyKorsakov; Sinfonia, Vitali; Danse Slave, Chabrier.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: Grete Meilman Bride of Hanno Mott, Lawyer
description: Grete Meilman and Hanno D. Mott were married yesterday morning in Kings Point, L.I., at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Edward Meilman. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Jacques Lipchitz of New York and of Fred S. Mott of Cincinnati. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson of Great Neck, LI., and Rabbi Manfred Rubenstein of Cincinnati officiated.

title: GOTBAUM OPPOSES BEAME'S REELECTION
description: The head of New York City's biggest public employee union urged yesterday that Mayor Beame not seek reelection, but that he unplug the political process and let some young people in.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW March 15th LEONARDO DA VINCI (Italian). Left St. Thomas March 12; due 3 P.M. at W. 55th St.

title: 8 Temples Begin Program to Fight Crime in Brooklyn
description: Eight Reform temples in Brooklyn began a program yesterday aimed at reversing neighborhood deterioration and stemminng the tide of flight, by Jews and nonJews, from the borough.

title: Baker Takes Daytona Race
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 13 (UPI)Steve Baker started his Yamaha on the pole position today and outran Nen Roberts for victory in the rainshortened $102,800 Daytona 200motorcycle road race. Officials had planned to run two 100mile legs, separated by an hour. because of tire safety problems. But a heavy rain began falling shortly after Baker won the first leg and the second segment was canceled. Baker was declared the official winner.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: PUBLIC FUNDS SOUGHT FOR CONGRESS RACES
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Some members of Congress, arguing that the 1976 Presidential election established the value of publicly financed campaigns, are pressing for establishment of Federal subsidies for Congressional candidates next year.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball
description: MIDEAST REGIONALS

title: National
description: Under pressure from the Labor Department, the trustees of the teamsters union's Central States pension fund have agreed to give up control of the scandalridden fund to independent investment managers, then resign as trustees. The Labor Department has been threatening to go to court to force Frank E. Fitzsimmons, the union's president, and other trustees to surrender control of the fund. The Secretary of Labor, Ray Marshall, said it now appears possible that we can avoid litigation, assuming that the fund trustees make good progress in following up on their commitments. [1:6.]

title: RIGHTS LEADER DIES IN A PRAGUE HOSPITAL
description: VIENNA, March 13Jan Patocka, one of the three spokesmen of the Charter 77 human rights group, died in a Prague hospital this morning, according to information telephoned from the Czechoslovak capital.

title: 2 Families Battle in Court to Keep 22MonthOld Girl
description: NEW HAVEN, March 13Nancy Santacroce does not cry. Her voice remains steady and strong as she talks about Tina, her 22monthold foster child. She says the state took Tina away, and she wants her back.

title: BONN CAUTION SEEN AS BAR TO MESHING STRONG ECONOMIES
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Western economic strategy premised upon a coordinated expansion of the strong economies of the United States, West Germany and Japan is probably mistaken, a Senate staff report said today.

title: ExAides of Penn Central Freed in Misuse of Funds
description: A Federal judge in Philadelphia has dismissed all charges against two former top Penn Central Transportation Company officials accused of siphoning $4 million from the nowdefunct railroad, The Associated Press reported over the weekend.

title: ENERGY USE IN U.S. ROSE 4.8% IN 76, ENDING DROP
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)Energy use in the United States increased 4.S percent last year, partly because of the cold winter, and reversed a twoyear decline in consumption, the Government reported today.

title: Justice Stevens, New York's Top Black Judge, Will Retire Next Week
description: Harold A. Stevens, the highest ranking black judge in New York State's history, will retire from the bench at the end of next week.

title: Going out Guide
description: SCREEN SHAPES Workers and visitors in the midtown area near the New York Public Library's Donnell Center, 20 West 53d Street, might care to linger tonight for an earlyevening refresher hour or so on two major artists of modern sculpture. Starting at 7, there will be free screenings of Arnold Eagle's Noguchi: A Sculptor's World and the Paul FalkenbergHans Namuth Brancusi Retrospective Exhibition at the Guggenheim.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of Post Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Red Smith
description: Dave Kingman has committed an unforgivable sin, and if he goes to hell, M. Donald Grant will be saddened but not surprised. Not only does the most prolific hitter of home runs ever employed by the New York Mets want to be paid twice as much money as his employers wish to spend; he has compounded the sin by taking his case to the press.

title: U.S. Would Pursue Potash Price Case On Past Evidence
description: CHICAGO, March 12 (UPI)The Justice Department and defense attorneys for five potash producers have asked Federal District Court Judge Prentice Marshall to rule on their price fixing case using evidence presented at the first trial.

title: Market Place
description: AlbertoCulver Company shares sprang to life in trading on the New York Stock Exchange last Friday after the company announced that its Sugar Twin sugar substitute had been reformulated recently without saccharin.

title: International
description: Jacques Chirac, the former Prime Minister of France, apparently won the first round of his election campaign to become Mayor of Paris over a candidate handpicked by President Valry Giscard d'Estaing. He will now run against a SocialistCommunist electoral bloc in a secondround election next Sunday. If he wins, Mr. Chirac will have made a major advance in his apparent campaign to replace President Giscard d'Estaing as the leader of the nonleftist parties in the next elections for the National Assembly. Municipal elections were nationwide and showed that the leftist opposition was making considerable gains. [Page 1, Column 3.]

title: Give to UNESCO
description: In the fall of 1974, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization voted, in effect, exclude Israel from its activities. This action transformed the basic nature of UNESCO, substituting political for humanitarian considerations in its choices of activities. To protest this politicization, and to force a reversal of its stance on Israel, Congress voted to suspend America's contributions to UNESCO's budget. The United States is now nearly three yearsor $70 millionin arrears, and UNESCO, deprived of 25 percent of its annual budget, faces a major financial crisis.

title: DEMORALIZED F.D.A. STRUGGLES TO COPE
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  In just a decade the Food and Drug Administration has evolved from amorphous obscurity deep within the capital bureaucracy into both the world's paramount regulator of consumer goods and the Federal Government's most criticized, demoralized and fractionalized agency.

title: Red Skelton: Gee, He Looks Good
description: It certainly took more than practice, practice, but Red Skelton, who has not performed in the flesh in New York for 40 years or so, finally got to Carnegie Hall Saturday night and did two shows.

title: An Aura of Awe About Chairman Burns
description: WASHINGTON, March 13In the highceilinged committee chamber he sits alone at a big table, briefcase filled with charts and graphs to one side, pipe and paraphernalia to the other. His dark blue, ultraconservative suit brings out the salt and pepper shades of his neatly cropped gray hair. And, as Arthur F. Burns speaks, the words slide out in scratchy nasal tones slowly, precisely, with a sharp cutting edge.

title: Massapequa, N. Babylon Gain L.I. Court Titles
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.,March 13Tom Murphy's field goal with 6 seconds left gave Massapequa a 7675 victory over Freeport tonight for the Nassau County scholastic backetball championship at the Nassau Coliseum. In the opener of a doubleheader, North Babylon defeated Sachem, 6457, and won the Suffolk title

title: Why New York State Aids Israeli Medical School
description: ALBANY, March 13Next fall, 40 fortunate young New Yorkers will enroll at the Sackler School of Medicine in Tel Aviv for an unusual venture in foreign medical education.

title: PRAVDA CAUTIONS U.S. ON RIGHTS CRITICISM
description: MOSCOW, March 13The Communist Party newspaper Pravda warned today that President Carter's outspokenness on human rights could damage the atmosphere in which a strategic arms agreement must be negotiated.

title: Aqueduct Clerks Protest Scab Trainees
description: While 500 unionized parimutuel clerks demonstrated in the rain outside the track, 300 nonunion recruits using play money practiced selling and cashing tickets yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: OverCounter Supplementary Listings
description: Week ended Feb. 25, 1977

title: Wrong Way on Amnesty
description: When a caller from Cudahy, Wis., complimented the President during last week's radio callin on his humane approach to amnesty, Mr. Carter first made several unassailable observations. He quite properly took credit for his courageous speech in support of amnesty before a highly critical American Legion audience in the early weeks of the election campaign. He accurately concluded from the public opinion polls that there's no way to suit people  meaning all the people or even a clear majority of them  in this controversial matter. And he said that it's time for us to get over the Vietnam War as soon as we can.

title: Syracuse Upsets Tennessee in Overtime
description: BATON ROUGE, Mar 13Syracuse University, which was the surprise of the 1975 National Collegiate basketball tournament by reaching the semifinals, gave indications of repeating that act today when the Orange upset Tennessee, 9388, in overtime during the first round of the 39th N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 13  Governor Byrne, according to his associates. has decided to announce his political plans early next month, and there is every indication that he will say that he wants a second term.

title: Lancelot Is Best Huskie Of 88 at Saw Mill K.C. Show
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 13Ch. Iriocon's Sir Lancelot, a coppercolored and white Siberian huskie, topped the largest entry of SS today at the Saw Mill River Kennel Club's 37th dog show in the Westchester County Center. This show featured 107 bestofbreed winners with no group or bestinshow iudging.

title: The Carters See N.Y.C. Ballet
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)President Carter and his wife Rosalynn attended the New York City Ballet's production of A Midsummer Night's Dream tonight at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Officials at the center said that it was the first time they could recall a President attending a ballet since the center opened five years ago, Hamilton Jordan, the President's closest aide, and his wife accompanied the Carters.

title: 10 Biggest Agencies Listed by Revenues
description: After 32 years of annually ranking ad agencies according to their billings, Advertising Age has decided to change to revenues as a more realistic figure.

title: Why New York State Aids Israeli Medical'School
description: ALBANY, March 13Next fall, 40 fortunate young New Yorkers will enroll at the Sackler School of Medicine in Tel Aviv for an unusual venture in foreign medical education.

title: G.N.P. Rate Lifted By Paper Industry
description: The American Paper Institute has revised upward its 1976 yearend forecast for growth in the 1977 gross national product to 5 to 5.5 percent from earlier projections of a real term improvement of 4.5 to 5 percent.

title: Moscow to Give Rumania $22 Million in Quake Aid
description: BUCHAREST, March 13 (Reuters)The Soviet Union today announced a gift of equipment and material to help Rumania rebuild its economy, which was damaged by an earthquake nine days ago.

title: Hofstra's Pride Is intact in Defeat by Irish
description: PHILADELPHIA. March 13They didn't leave the arena until after midnight, when the fog had settled on the city and wrapped itself around the buildings and trees like a veil of tears. But the Hofstra basketball players, though beaten, their season over, needed no cover from the weather. They walked with their heads up and their eyes dry. That wasn't any turkey team that had beaten them, that was Notre Dame. And that was ball, man, that was ball.

title: Postal System, Beset by Problems, Faces Challenges to Independence
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The United States Postal Service, freed from Government control six years ago in hopes that it would deliver the mail more effectively, is now threatened with loss of its independence because of intensifying troubles.

title: Yesterday's Preseason Baseball
description: Batteries Cleveland, Aussie (5), Stanley

title: George Stevens, 64; Was Key Executive With Radio Station
description: GREENWICH, Conn., March 13 George Cooke Stevens, the president of the Greenwich Broadcasting Corporation and general manager of radio station WGCH here, died last night at Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 459 Indian Field Road in Greenwich

title: Meany Urges Boycott of Circus Over Musicians Contract Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI)George Meany, president of the A.F.LC.I.O., asked union members yestarday to boycott the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Baley Circis.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: Dividend Meetings

title: French Police Arrest Accomplice In Escape of Nice Bank Robber
description: NICE, France, March 13 (UPI)The police arrested Gerard Rang today, as a suspect in the spectacular escape by Albert Spaggiari Thursday from police custody here.

title: ROBERT SCHLEUSSNER JR., CORPORATION EXECUTIVE
description: Robert C. Schleussner Jr., the director of corporate development for the Thiokol Corporation of Newton, Pa., died yesterday in St. Mary's Hospital at Langhorne, Pa., of heart disease. He was 49 years old.

title: Fayvelle Mermey, 61, First Woman To Head Her Synagogue, Is Dead
description: Fayvelle Mermey, the first woman to serve as president of a synagogue in the New York City area, died of a heart attack Saturday at her home in Larchmont, N.Y. She was 61 years old.

title: 2 NURSES WILL SEEK DISMISSAL OF TRIAL
description: DETROIT, March 13 (UPI)An attorney for two Filipino nurses, accused of murdering two patients at a Veterans Administration hospital and attempting to kill seven others, said today that the defense would file another motion to dismiss the case because of reports that another woman confessed the crimes.

title: International
description: Jacques Chirac, the former Prime Minister of France, apparently won the first round of his election campaign to become Mayor of Paris over a candidate handpicked by President Valry Giscard d'Estaing. He will now run against a SocialistCommunist electoral bloc in a secondround election next Sunday. If he wins, Mr. Chirac will have made a major advance in his apparent campaign to replace President Giscard d'Estaing as the leader of the nonleftist parties in the next elections for the National Assembly. Municipal elections were nationwide and showed that the leftist opposition was making considerable gains. [Page 1, Column 3.]

title: SON OF MRS. GANDHI PLEADS FOR SUPPORT
description: AMETHI, India, March 11Across the flat scrubby wheatiands here on the north bank of the Ganges River, Sanjay Gandhi is fighting a tough campaign for his political life.

title: Nets Box Score
description: LOS ANGELES (84)

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Some weeks ago, under the headline Sweet and Rich, a recipe was printed in this column for chocolate truffles. It elicitedand continues to elicitnumerous letters from readers asking if the recipe is correct.

title: Petty Takes Carolina 500 As Crashes Slow Action
description: ROCKINGHAM, N.C., March 13 (AP) Richard Petty, who must wish every Grand National stockcar race was run at North Carolina Motor Speedway, won another one todaythe 12th annual Carolina 500.

title: U.S. Sweeps Australia
description: HARTFORD, March 13 (AP)The United States completed today the first shutout in the eightyearold World Cup tennis competition with Australia. The winning team received $70,000 and the losers $30,000.

title: Books of The Times
description: According to Victor Hugo, Paris is nothing but an immense hospitality. According to J. K. Huysmans, it was. at least in 1884, a sinister Chicago. According to Irwin Shaw. well, when an interviewer once asked him why he lived in Paris, he replied, Had Garbo asked you to dinner when you were young, wouldn't you have gone? Mr. Shaw wentfirst as a soldier, on liberation day, Aug. 25, 1944, and later, in 1951, as a civilian, husband, father, novelist and playwright. He stayed for the hest part of a quarter Of a century.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Horses listed in order 0 post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Topics
description: For most of her career, Anita Bryant has done nothing more controversial than deliver singing commercials for Florida oranges. A few weeks ago, however, she became the center of a juicy controversy in Miami, when she joined with some local religious leaders to oppose a new city ordinance granting equality to homosexuals. Organized Miami homosexualdom responded by calling for a boycott of Miss Bryant, and for a while it looked as if she were going to lose a television talkshow contract because of the extensive national publicity arising from the controversial political activities.

title: Cliffside Park Protesters Fight FastFood Store Site
description: CLIFFSIDE PARK, March 13The battle of the burger was joined yesterday as a group of local residents opposed to a fastfood restaurant in their community demonstrated in front of a proposed site for a McDonald's Restaurant here.

title: Miss Morerod Clinches Women's World Cup in Skiing
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., March 13Under conditions considered even impossible by weather hardened ski internationalists, 20  year  old UseMarie Morerod of Austria clinched the World Cup, her first, today without even stepping into her ski bindings.

title: Braking the Commodity Roller Coaster
description: The other day commodity dealers paid about $2.15 a pound for cocoa. One year ago a pound cost 75 cents. In November 1974, refiners frantically snapped up scarce raw sugar for 57 cents a pound. Today those refiners can buy all they want for 11 cents a pound.

title: Soviet Window Broken
description: Eight young men and women identified as members of the Jewish Defense League were arrested on a variety of charges arising from the breaking of a window at the Soviet Intourist travel agency. Calls to the news services said the Jewish Defense League was responsible for the incident, the latest of a number against various Soviet commercial or diplomatic installations in New York City.

title: Miss Johnson,17,Keeps Throng Roaring in Gymnastics Triumph
description: With a sustained demonstration of strength, agility and grace, 17yearold Kathy Johnson kept a crowd of 15,944 in a roar at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon as she won the women's allround competition in the second annual international gymnastics American Cup.

title: TV: Irreverent Look at Oscars
description: Can you hare your glamorous chic and goof on it, too? That is the question suggested, no doubt inadvertently, by TV TV Looks at the Oscars, an hourlong documentary on Channel 13 at 11:30 tonight. Produced in association with Los Angeles station KCET, the program examines last year's Academy Award rituals through the portable cameras of a video group that has attained national prominence With subjects as diverse as the annual football Super Bowl and the national political conventions. The tone is counterculture but, increasingly, the content is safely Establishment. it becomes more and more difficult to distinguish the deadpan satire from a pedestrian preciccupation with celebrity.

title: In Diois (Pop. 0), It's Easy to Win Seat on Council
description: PARIS, March 13A hamlet with zero population elected a City Council anyway.

title: Supporters of the Arts Organize Lobbying Effort
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)Supporters of the arts gathered here over the weekend to organize a lobbying effort in behalf of legislation which would allow taxpayers to make direct contributions to cultural activities.

title: NEW EFFORT IS MADE ON COUNCIL DISTRICTS
description: Responding to criticism that the new lines it recently adopted for New York City's 33 Council Districts were cosmetic and were pushed through hastily, the City Council has begun a new effort to redistrict Council seats to better reflect natural neighborhood lines. The move is also aimed at satisfying more fully the mandate of the new City Charter, which had called for the redistricting.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: TRUDEAUS SPEND WEEKEND AT RETREAT NEAR OTTAWA
description: OTTAWA, March 13 (Reuters)Margaret Trudeau was out of sight today after a week of highly publicized social activities in Toronto and New York.

title: Business/Finance
description: Charges of fraud against two former top officials of the defunct Penn Central Transportation Company were dismissed by a Federal judge in Philadelphia. David C. Bevan, 70 years old. and William R. Gerstnecker, 64, had been charged with transferring $4 million of Penn Central funds in 1969 to a corporation in Europe. allegedly controlled by a cohort. The trial of two lawyers. Francis N. Rosenbaum and Joseph H. Rosenbaum, who are brothers, on charges related to the alleged swindle, will continue. [43:45.]

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high lide at Asbiifv Park and Belmar, deduct 34 min. from Sandy Hook time.

title: Gotbaum Opposes Beame's Reelection
description: The head of New York City's biggest public employee union urged yesterday that Mayor Beame not seek reelection, but that he unplug the political process and let some young people in.

title: TEAMSTER PRESIDENT AND 3 OTHERS TO QUIT PENSION FUND POSTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Trustees of the teamsters union's principal pension fund have agreed to cede control of the scandalridden fund to independent investment managers, then resign as trustees, the Labor Department announced today.

title: Fire in Jersey City That Killed 7 Described As Like an Inferno in Less Than 2 Minutes
description: It was like an inferno in less than two minutes. The whole place went up like dynamite.

title: Palestinian Militants Lose Vote at Cairso Parley, But Show Strength
description: CAIRO, March 13  Although they showed considerable strength, Palestinian hardliners lost their first test at the Palestine National Congress here today when Khaled Fahoum, a proSyrian moderate, was reelected president of the organization.

title: A BALANCED TRADE IN BONDS EXPECTED
description: The credit markets last week held remarkably steady in a stalmate that many analysts and portfolio managers Friday said they expected to continue for a while. To some, the market's stability resulted from a balance of forces there was an ample supply of funds for investment, to be sure, but most investors seemed to believe that interest rates were headed higher later this year and that there was no need to hurry to buy bonds now, To others, the market was simply confusing.

title: Traditional Idioms of Folk Mixed By the New Lost City Ramblers
description: The New Lost City Ramblers have been performing oldtime country music for almost 20 years now. They were among the earliest folkies, recreating a style of music that was already dated when bluegrass came along to supersede it, and there is still a folkie aura to their work. They tend to pay scrupulous attention to historical accuracy in their arrangements, and in timehonored folkie fashion, they are better at playing their many instruments than they are at singing.

title: Rosewall Beats Dibbs
description: LAKEWAY, Tex., March 13 (AP)Ken Rosewall hitting crosscourt volleys and offensive lobs, continued his sharp play today in a 62. 62 victory over Eddie Dibbs in the $200,000 Tournament of Champions. Dibbs ranks second in America behind Jimmy Connors.

title: A Share For Girls In Jewish Birthright
description: David and Sandra Bergman stood before the family and friends assembled in their West Side apartment on a recent Sunday afternoon and ushered their 6weekold daughter, Elana Miriam, into the covenant of the Jewish people with God. They recited traditional prayers from biblical and rabbinical sources, they knelt and blessed Elena, they read from Khalil Gibran's The Prophet, and they made personal remarks on the meaning of the ceremony they called simchat bat or rejoicing for a daughter.

title: U.S. Inquiry Group Leaves For Vietnam and Laos
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)A special Government commission left today for Vietnam and Laos to try to determine the fate of Americans still listed as missing in action in the Vietnam war, but the chairman warned against unrealistic expectations.

title: Demoralization Plaguing F.D.A.; Some Top Jobs Remain Unfilled
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  In just decade the Food and Drug Administration has evolved from amorphous obscurity deep within the capital bureaucracy into ?oth the world's paramount regulator of consumer goods and the Federal GoVernment's most criticized, demoralized and ?ractionalized agency.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT SAN ANTONIO

title: DEATH OF GIANT STAR COULD CREATE OTHERS
description: Strong evidence has been discovered in the vicinity of Sirius, the dog star, to support the hypothesis that the explosive death of one giant star gives birth to many new ones and that this may be how most new stars and planetary systems are formed.

title: Proposal to Increase Pay For 50 White House Jobs To Be Given to President
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Pay increases for about 50 White House aides will be proposed in a report to President Carter by the end of the week, according to Robert J. Lipshutz, counsel to the President.

title: City Records Saved
description: John T. Carroll, the Municipal Service Administrator, reported that a Federal grant of $59,500 had made it possible to salvage nearly a century of New York City records. The records, covering 1800 to 1898, were recently uncovered in the subbasement of the Municipal Building. The Federal grant will pay for classifying and categorizing budgets, financing plans, leases, contracts, payrolls and other items.

title: DeMarco Case Is Called Indicative Of Crackdown on State's Doctors
description: NEWARK. March 13The trial of Dr. Peter T. DeMarco here on state charges of gross malpractice is only one of many cases involved in a crackdown by the New Jersey Board of Medical Examiners against alleged wrongdoing by physicians.

title: Mr. David's UnHairdressered Look
description: After being chintzy and gardenlike in the 60's, cut up into mini salons in the 70's, the dcor at Bendel's beauty salon is now white walls, wooden floors and canvas director's chairs. More important, there's a new name on the door.

title: Separate Department of Education Is Sought in Measure by Ribicoff
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, who is chairman of the Government Operations Committee, said today that he would introduce tomorrow a bill to create a separate department of education. Most education programs are under the Department of Health, Education and Welfare and are included in a $9 billion budget.

title: Chess:
description: The question is what pieces to allow to he exchangedand whenwhile building up an attack. And the answer requires, in general, subtle answers.

title: TEAMSTER PRESIDENT AND 3 OTHERS TO QUIT PENSION FUND POSTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Trustees of the teamsters union's principal pension fund have agreed to cede control of the scandalridden fund to independent investment managers, then resign as trustees, the Labor Department announced today.

title: Officials Say Hanafi Posed Arson Threat Near End of Siege
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Officials involved in the negotiations last Thursday to free 134 hostages held by Hanafi Moslems said tonight that after the negotiations involving three Islamic ambassadors ended in seeming success, members of the sect apparently prepared to set fire to the B'nai B'rith headquarters, where most of the hostages were being held.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Student Violence Continues in Italy
description: ROME, March 13 (Reuters)Demonstrators and the police clashed again tonight in Bologna, where the killing Friday of a leftwing student leader touched off a weekend of violence across Italy.

title: Tax Hotline Opens
description: A special hotline has been set up to help taxpayers who feel they have not received prompt help from the Internal Revenue Service in solving their tax problems, the I.R.S. has announced, Clare Shy, acting I.R.S. director in New Jersey, said taxpayers who felt they, had not received the proper help through normal channels could contact the problem resolution office at 8002426750 or???visit their nearest I.R.S. office,

title: Spanish Police Arrest 6 in the Massacre of 5 Reds
description: MADRID, March 13The police announced tonight that they had arrested five men and a woman in the murders in January of four Communist lawyers and a receptionist in a Madrid labor office.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT DETROIT

title: Metropolitan
description: Mayor Beame was urged by one of New York City's principal labor leaders not. to seek reelection. Victor Gotbaum, executive director of District Council 37, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, asked the 72yearold Mayor to unplug the political process and let some young people in. He said his union would not support Mr. Beame at this time. [1:2.]

title: Boat Adrift With 24 Aboard
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 13 (UPI)Two Coast Guard aircraft searched the Pacific Ocean off Baja California today for a Mexican fishing vessel reported adrift with 24 persons aboard. The 60foot Noreste reported she was disabled with fuel pump failure and adrift 30 miles west of Ensenada. The officials said the crew members and passengers, including several women and children, did not appear to be in immediate danger.

title: Mets Get Another Spring Shutout, 30
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13Nothing counts until April 7, as they say, but the New York Mets shut out the St. Louis Cardinals for the second straight time today and the Big Three of the pitching staff completed its spring debut with nearly flawless work for the third straight time.

title: They Have Something in Common: Clay
description: There aren't very many things that parents and children can do and enjoy at the same level of competencywhich is one of the things that works so well about the parentandchild clay workshop at Greenwich House Pottery. The participants are all learning as they go, with clay as the great equalizer.

title: 3 Sought in Wrigley Burglary
description: CHICAGO, March 13 (AP)The police yesterday were seeking three men believed involved in a burglary at a, 40room North Side mansion owned by Philip K. Wrigley, the chewing gum magnate and owner of the Chicago Cubs baseball team. The police said an oil painting, a grandfather clock and a collection of National Geographic magazines were among the items taken late Thursday from the house that the Wrigley family has not occupied since 1933.

title: National
description: Under pressure from the Labor Department, the trustees of the teamsters union's Central States pension fund have agreed to give up control of the scandalridden fund to independent investment managers, then resign as trustees. The Labor Department has been threatening to go to court to force Frank E. Fitzsimmons, the union's president, and other trustees to surrender control of the fund. The Secretary of Labor, Ray Marshall, said it now appears possible that we can avoid litigation, assuming that the fund trustees make good progress in following up on their commitments. [1:6.]

title: Columbia Is Trying to Reach Coast Property Settlement
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.Columbia University this month may finally extricate itself from a land deal that for five years has brought accusations that the university's portfolio managers disregarded local environmental concerns in the pursuit of Profits.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Suit Attacks Prison
description: A suit filed in Federal Court in Trenton charges that 70 inmates had been living in inhumane conditions since they were transferred from the Leesburg State Farm to Trenton State Prison after a daylong work stoppage. The suit was filed last week by the American Civil Liberties Union and the Camden County Regional Services Agency.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order of Post Positions

title: Inmate a Suicide
description: An inmate at Rahway State Prison committed suicide by hanging himself from his cell door, officials said. Prison officials said Ronald Carhardt, 31 years old, of Long Branch, was pronounced dead at the scene. His body was taken to the Middlesex County Medical Examiner's office.

title: MAN WITH A GUN IS KILLED BY POLICE ON GOLF COURSE
description: LAWRENCE, L.L, March 13A man who allegedly threatened three police officers with a revolver was shot and killed by them last night on the Lawrence Golf Course, the Nassau County police reported.

title: WOMAN, 80, BEATEN BY ROBBERS, IS DEAD
description: An 80yearold Brooklyn woman who, like her 84yearold husband, was severely beaten in a robbery early this month died yesterday afternoon at Brooklyn Hospital. Her husband remained in critical condition at the same hospital.

title: EX PREMIER LEADS GISCARD'S CANDIDATE FOR MAYOR OF PARIS
description: PARIS, March 13  Former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac apparently won the first round of his campaign to become Mayor of Paris today with a preliminary election victory over a candidate handpicked by President Valry Giscard d'Estaing.

title: Texas Hunters Capture 6,100 Pounds of Snakes
description: SWEETWATER, Tex., March 13 (UPI) More than 300 hunters poked in holes and peered under rocks in the cactuscovered hills near this west Texas city today, looking for diamondback rattlesnakes.

title: Foes of Pakistani Premier Planning Protests Today in Defiance of Ban
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 13Leaders of the opposition to Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto laid plans today for a series of protest marches beginning tomorrow to defy the Government's ban on public meetings.

title: Gillies's Goal Is Last of 6 in the Final Period
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 13Youth must be served, the Islanders learned tonight.

title: Metropolitan
description: Mayor Beame was urged by one of New York City's principal labor leaders not to seek reelection. Victor Gotbaum, executive director of District Council 37, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, asked the 72yearold Mayor to unplug the political process and let some young people in. He said his union would not support Mr. Beame at this time. [30:1.]

title: Record Argentine Harvest
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentina's agricultural campaign to recover the place it once had in the first rank of cereal and meat exporters has paid off this year in a record grain crop. A wheat harvest of 11 million metric tons is straining the storage capacity of farm silos on the Pampas and elevators at the port terminal, where ships load wheat for nearby Brazil and faroff mainland China. About 15 million tons of corn and sorghum, which will be sold to the Soviet Union, Japan and other feed grain importers, are being reaped by combines in the muggy heat of late summer along the Paran River delta.

title: Trying to Accept The Suicide Of a Brother
description: On Feb. 25, my brother took his own life.

title: Figure in Rothko Case Lives Discreetly in Bahamas
description: PARADISE ISLAND, the Bahamas, March 12Frank Lloyd, founder and head of the multinational group of Marlborough Galleries, has managed at times in his long and flamboyant career to hit it off with Pope Paul VI, Queen Elizabeth and the Emperor of Japan.

title: EXPREMIER LEADS GISCARD'S CANDIDATE FOR MAYOR OF PARIS
description: PARIS, March 13  Former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac apparently won the first round of his campaign to become Mayor of Paris today with a preliminary election victory over a candidate handpicked by President Valry Giscard d'Estaing:

title: Redevelopment Could End Free Ride in Houseboats
description: RICHARDSON BAY, Calif., March 13 The sunlight struck stainedglassed windows and colorful iron works and reflected prismatically on the barefoot babies, bearded men, long  haired women and scruffy dogs navigating gangplanks here in this eclectic houseboat community just north of Sausilito.

title: Michigan Gains With Charlotte
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 13 (AP) The topranked University of Michigan, led by Rickey Green's 35 points and 16 apiece by Phil Hubbard and John Robinson, beat Holy Cross College today, 9281, in the first game of an N.C.A.A. Mideast Regional basketball doubleheader at Indiana University's Assembly Hall.

title: Fire That Killed 7 in Jersey City 'An Inferno' Within 2 Minutes
description: It was like an inferno in less than two minutes. The whole place went up like dynamite.

title: City Bar Opposing A U.S. Law to Ban Payments Abroad
description: In a lengthy legal study of corporate bribery abroad, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York has come out strongly against Congressional efforts to make such payments a crime.

title: The Cast
description: GEMINI by Albert Innaurato. Directed by Peter Mark Schiffer; setting by Christopher Nowak; costumes by Ernest Allen Smith; lighting by Larry Grimmlns; Production stage manager, Fred Reinglas. Presented by Circle Repertory Company, in association with PAF Playhouse. At the Circle In the Square, 99 Seventh Avenue South.

title: Irwin Freundlich, at 66; Piano Teacher 40 Years At the Juilliard School
description: Irwin Freundlich, who taught piano at the Juilliard School for 40 years, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital in New York City. He was 66 years old and lived at 311 West 105th Street.

title: The Face Is Familiar, but the Uniform Isn't
description: The new policeman who turned up at seven Central Harlem churches yesterday looked familiar. In fact, he was instantly greeted by nearly everyonewhich somewhat surprised Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan, who was serving his first Sunday on patrol as a member of the Auxiliary Police Force.

title: A Garland of Honor for Alice Tully, Grande Dame of the Music World
description: You have seen the face before, and suddenly you remember where: It gazes out at you from those portraits of ancestral ladies that hang on the staircases of baronial houses. The painter has idealized his subject, of course, and she looks unrealistically serene, dignified, and handsome. It is Alice Tully in person, the portrait of a lady come to life, the American heiress stepping out of a Henry James novel.

title: Nigeria Arrests, Then Expels The Times's West Africa Correspondent
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 13The New York Times correspondent for West Africa was arrested and jailed in Lagos, Nigeria, Friday and then expelled from the country yesterday. No official explanation was given for the deportation.

title: Bridge:
description: The topseeded quartet had to fight for its life in the New York semifinal stage of the Grand National Knockout Team. Championship yesterday afternoon at the East Winds Club, 1555 First Avenue, Manhattan.

title: Rabin Says Carter Asked Too Much On Frontier Issue
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel says that he rejects President Carter's view that as part of a final Middle East settlement Israel should give up virtually all territory captured from the Arabs in the 1967 war, allowing for only minor adjustments in the prewar frontiers.

title: Bean Scores Stroke Victory In Doral Golf
description: MIAMI, March 13Happy birthday, Andy!

title: Murder Suspect to Go to Indiana
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 13 (UPI)The state police said today that detectives would be sent to Santa Clara, Calif., tomorrow to return to Indiana a second suspect in the Valentine's Day slayings of four brothers in the western Indiana town of Hollandsburg. The authorities said that Michael W. Wright, 21, Crawfordsville, was captured in San Jose. Calif., and agreed to return to Indiana to face prosecution.

title: Beame Hails Israeli Labor Group
description: Mayor Beanie praised the accomplishments of Israeli's labor federationHistradutat the annual conference of the National Committee for Labor Israel yesterday at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. The committee wants to raise $5 million to help the health, social welfare and educational programs of the Israeli labor movement.

title: Joan Lichtner Is Bride Of David Solomont on L.I.
description: Joan Lichtner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Lichtner of Lawrence, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to David Solomont of Brookline, Mass., and Palm Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Walter S. Wurzburger at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: An Investigation Is Ordered of an Earlier Death Threat by New Rochelle Slayer of Five
description: The Mayor of New Rochelle, N.Y., said yesterday that an inquiry would be conducted into why the police had failed to investigate a murder threat 18 months ago that could have led to the apprehension of Frederick W. Cowan, the Nazi follower who gunned down five persons In New Rochelle last month.

title: Silk Views City Crisis
description: Leonard Silk compares the banks and the unions perspectives toward the $983 million package that is designed to save the city from bankruptcy. Page 48.

title: U.S. Seeking More Information
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (Reuters)The State Department said today it was looking into a Uganda radio report that said pressure would be put on Americans who were putting out false information about Uganda. Department officials had no direct comment on the matter, but said they were seeking more information about the report.

title: Controversy Over 3Inch Fish Stalls the Mighty T.V.A
description: LENOIR CITY, Tenn., March 11The Tennessee Valley Authority, America's great experiment in governmentrun utilities, has generated almost as much controversy as current down through the years.

title: Lakers Beat Nets, 8481, as AbdulJabbar Stars
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March I3The New York Nets, who specialize in getting other teams to play their waiting game, lulled the Los Angeles Lakers for 47 minutes today at the Nassau Coliseum but could not sustain the lullaby for the requisite 48.

title: Inmates Caught Making Bogus Money Orders
description: BELLE GLADE, Fla., March 13 (UPI)Three inmates at the Glades Correctional System have been producing counterfeit United States postal money orders of excellent quality on the prison's antiquated presses according to officials.

title: 15 Dead in 3 States After Late Winter Blizzard
description: DENVER, March 13 (AP)  The late winter blizzard that swept across the Middle West over the weekend left at least 15 persons dead and hundreds more snowbound.

title: Marijuana Law Saved California Millions
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 13 (UPI) California's more lenient laws cut the number of marijuana arrests in half last year, resulting in savings to police agencies and courts of more than $10 million, a state moon said today.

title: Dr. Charles D. Roberts, 67, Dead; Held Post at Englewood Hospital
description: Dr. Charles D. Roberts, a former chief of medicine at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital, died Wednesday in Boca Raton, Fla., where he was vacationing. Dr. Roberts, who was 67 years old, lived at 131 Walnut Street in Englewood and had practiced medicine in the area for 38 years.

title: Retarded Unit Suing
description: A state court suit will he filed today to force the upgrading of education programs for 2,400 school age residents of New Jersey's schools for the retarded. The action will charge grossly inadequate programs at these institutions violates a court order to provide thorough and efficient education for all children.

title: Catholic Drive Opens
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke started a $3 million fundraising drive yesterday for the 1977 Catholic Charities and Education Appeal. He said the amount represented 1 percent of the $300 million spent annually by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York for health. education and social services in its 10 downstate counties. The rest of the money comes from Government agencies, tuition, foundations and benefactors.

title: Footstep of Air Wafts In As New Feld Masterpiece
description: So at last something wonderful has happened to brighten up what has been so generally dull a dance season. The event was the world premiere of Eliot Feld's A Footstep of Air, which made its graceful bow with the Eliot Feld Ballet at the City Center 55th Street Theater on Saturday night.

title: Yanks, Rich Elsewhere, Need Help in the Infield
description: MIAMI, March 13What if the Yankees held a meeting for their infielders, and nobody came because there were no infielders?

title: The Swiss Voters Reject Power to Veto Treaties
description: GENEVA, March 13The Swiss in a national referendum today rejected a rightwing proposal that would have given them the veto over all treaties entered into by the Government.

title: Threat of New Violence Follows Plant Bombing
description: MARLBORO, Mass., March 13 (AP)Radicals who purportedly bombed a factory last night to protest President'Carter's plan to visit a Massachusetts mill town are threatening more violence, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: AMNESTY PLEA TO CUBA BY UNITED STATES URGED
description: Asserting that President Fidel Castro's own estimate of 5,000 political prisoners in Cuba indicates a proportion in terms of population greater than in the Soviet Union, the International Rescue Committee is urging that new efforts to normalize CubanAmerican relations should include a call for amnesty.

title: Laos Is Said to Jail ExKing and Family As Focus for Right
description: BANGKOK Thailand, Monday March 14 (UPI)Laotian authorities have arrested former King Savang Vatthana, reportedly because rightist soldiers continue to fight the Communists in his name, diplomatic sources in Vientiane said today.

title: Dr. Susan Spear Wed To Ronald H. Janis
description: Dr. Susan Spear and Ronald H. Janis were married yesterday afternoon In Manhasset, L. I., at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Paul Spear. Rabbi Daniel Kerman of Buffalo performed the ceremony.

title: N.I.T. Resumes at Garden After Good Road Show
description: The National Invitation Tournament, which resumes tonight with a Madison Square Garden doubleheader, had a good firstround road show. A crowd of 16,754 watched Alabama defeat Memphis State at Birmingham, Ala. There were also good crowds at the seven other qualifying games, all played in areas close to one of the competing basketball teams.

title: Politics Unlikely at Water Parley
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 13Politics are expected to be muted at the United Nations Water Conference opening tomorrow at the Argentine resort city of Mar del Plata, which will bring 2,000 participants from at least 140 countries.

title: PRAVDA CAUTIONS U.S. ON RIGHTS CRITICISM
description: MOSCOW, March 13The Communist Party newspaper Pravda warned today that President Carter's outspokenness on human rights could damage the atmosphere in which a strategic arms agreement must be negotiated.

title: Mayer Conquers Smith in 5Set Final
description: HAMPTON, Va., March 13 (AP)Sandy Mayer won his second tournament of the year today by beating Stan Smith, 46, 63, 62, 16, 63, in the fial of the $50,000 Grand Prix event at the Hamton Coliseum.

title: A Victory For Reform
description: BOSTON, March 13Senators John McClellan of Arkansas and Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts have agreed on a new version of the longdisputed legislation to reform and codify Federal criminal laws. They expect to introduce a joint bill within the next two or three weeks.

title: The Newest Japan
description: TOKYO  When Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda makes a state visit to Washington next week, the public talk will be of economics (most Japanese want to spend their way out of their protracted pause but most Americans worry about world inflation); of defense (the American troops in Korea that Mr. Carter talks of bringing home are seen here to be defending Japan); and of human rights (the Japanese say they're for rights, personally, but for them to preach at China, Korea and Taiwan would be bad for business, which is bad enough).

title: Larry Gatlin Plays Country Music With Flair
description: Larry Gatlin, who recently won a Grammy for best country song of the year with his Broken Lady, performed over the weekend at the new Lone Star Cafe, Fifth Avenue at 13th Street. His songs were straightforward country and western material with some interesting and unusual twists and turns. His singing, which made liberal use of a Roy Orbisonlike falsetto, was affecting, and his band was excellent. But the real drama of the evening was in Mr. Gatlin's interaction with his audience.

title: Atlanta, 53 Victor, Gains WeekendSeries Sweep
description: Angry fans threw garbage onto the ice, fights broke out in the stands, and an enraged Ranger player cursed and hurled a couple of buckets of ice against the dressing room wall last night after the New Yorkers had lost, 53 to the Atlanta Flames at Madison Square Garden.

title: Brueggen Plays the Recorder Unaccompanied
description: Frans Brueggen, who must be the world's most famous recorder player, performed an entirely unaccompanied program Saturday night at Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium. The dividends may have been a bit slender musically, but Mr. Brueggen's formidable artistry held the stage with ease and raised an interesting issue along the way.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Business/Finance
description: Charges of fraud against two former top officials of the defunct Penn Central Transportation Company were dismissed by a Federal judge in Philadelphia. David C. Bevan. 70 year old. and William R. Gerstnecker, 64. had been charged with transferring $4 million of Penn Central funds in 1969 to a corporation in Europe, allegedly controlled by a cohort. The trial of two lawyers. Francis N. Rosenbaum and Joseph H. Rosenbaum, who are brothers. on charges related to the alleged swindle, will continue. [43:45.]

title: Figure in Rothko Case Lives Discreetly in Bahamas
description: PARADISE ISLAND, the Bahamas, March 12Frank Lloyd, founder and head of the multinational group of Marlborough Galleries, has managed at times in his long and flamboyant career to hit it off with Pope Paul VI, Queen Elizabeth and the Emperor of Japan.

title: Zaire Calling Up Reserves To Fight Invaders
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 13 (AP)Zaire is sending heavy weapons to its southern province of Shaba and is calling up former soldiers for a major new military operation against invaders, official sourer said today.

title: Beth Sandra Lieb Is Married To Dr. Steven Schnell, Intern
description: Beth Sandra Lieb, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Lieb of Short Hills, N. J., and Hallandale, Fla., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Steven L. Schnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Schnell of Franklin Square. L.I

title: Civil Guard Murdered as Unrest Continues in Basque Country
description: A month ago, the police announced that they had liberated General Villaescusa and a powerful former Justice Minister and destroyed the First of October group, but the Government maintained a news blackout on the assassinations of the Communists.

title: Bernard Trencher, 80, Is Dead; A Former Bar Group Official
description: Bernard Trencher, former chairman of the judiciary committee of the Bronx County Bar Association, died Saturday at New York Hospital after a short illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 196 East 75th Street.

title: Suspect in Holdup Killed as 2 Escape In Thruway Crash
description: A roberry suspect was shot dead and two others escaped yesterday after a gunshotpunctuated, highspeed chase on the New England Thruway in Westchester County that began with a service station holdup in New Rochelle and ended when the bandits car crashed in Pelham Manor.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 14, 1977

title: Leonard Silk
description: The latest chapter in New York City's ongoing fiscal crisis has ended. This episode has been billed by the banks as Armageddon  the great final battle between them and the Mayor and the unions over how to rescue the city from bankruptcy. But Armageddon ended not with a bang but a whimper. Mayor Beame has put together a package of $983 million that is so complicated and trickysuch a mixture of found cash, merchandizable assets, postponed payments and income borrowed from the futurethat one bank executive said it would warm the heart of Jim Cavanaugh. Mr. Cavanaugh was the First Deputy Mayor, famed for his fiscal ingenuity, who was forced from office as a result of pressures from the state's Emergency Financial Control Board and the bankers.

title: Uganda Issues Warning To Americans and British Who Tell Lies About It
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 13 (AP)The Uganda radio said today that all Americans and British living in the east African country faced pressure from the Government of President Idi Amin if they were found to be telling lies about Uganda.

title: Advertising
description: Should you be driven by the spirit of adventure or an undeniable thirst for Canadian Club to seek the case of that whisky that a current ad says is hidden deep in Big Foot country, be warnedit's already been found.

title: Commodities: China Grain Buying Watched
description: Despite all the talk about poor crop conditions in the Grain Belt this winter, the biggest question facing wheat and corn traders is whether or not China will once again go on a buying s?ree for basic foodstuffs.

title: Newark Jet Snag Cited
description: Test flights of the supersonic Concorde could not begin at Newark International Airport within the 16 month experimental period established by the Federal Government, a Port Authority of New York and New Jersey spokesman said. Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark has contacted Port Authority members to explore the possibility of establishing test flights of the supersonic jet between the New Jersey airport and Paris and London.

title: Leaking Tanker at Maine Port Is Ordered Out by Coast Guard
description: SOUTH PORTLAND, Maine, March 13 (UPI)A Liberian tanker, the Anco Elias. was ordered out to see today because she had leaks in several cargo oil tanks, Coast Guard officials said.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Like spring training in baseball, the annual confrontation over rent control in New York is once more under way a perennial part of each year's session of the State Legislature.

title: Taxes & Accounting Master Recordings as Shelters
description: Not long ago, the words nonrecourse loan were enough to make the wealthy smile when they discussed ways to invest money to shelter it from the tax collector.

title: Nassau Police Feel Drugs Incited Man Killed by Fusillade
description: The Nassau County police said yesterday that a 27yearold Queens man, who won high decorations in the Vietnam war, might have been under the influence of drugs when he died in a barrage of police fire Saturday night on the Lawrence, L. I., Golf Course.

title: Dance: Cardyn Lord as Romantic
description: Expressionist solo dancing to lushly Romantic music seems so much a part of the past that it was pleasantly surprising to see how Cardyn Lord effectively carried it off at the Cunningham studio Sunday evening. She selected two pieces of music, the Liszt piano Sonata in B minor, and Brahms Variations and Fugue on a Theme of Handel, played by Van Zandt Ellis.

title: Bridge
description: The topranked New York team survived the semifinal stage of the district grand national team contest here Sunday, but only after a bitter battle in which defeat seemed in the cards.

title: F.D.A. May Be Ultimate Challenge to Carter's Pledge on Reorganization and Consumer Aid
description: WASHINGTON. March 14For the Carter Administration, whose leader and top aides say that governmental reorganization and consumer protection are paramount among their priorities, the Food and Drug Administration may be the ultimate challenge.

title: Son of Mrs. Gandhi Is Reported Unhurt In Shooting Attach
description: NEW DELHI, Tuesday, March 15Sanjay Gandhi, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's 33yearold son, escaped injury last night when shots were fired at his jeep during a campaign tour, the Governmentcontrolled news agency here reported this morning.

title: Annenberg Threatening to Cancel $40 Million Arts Center at the Met
description: Walter H. Annenberg threatened yesterday to withdraw his $40 million pledge to establish and maintain a finearts center at the Metropolitan Museum of Art because of mounting controversy over the project.

title: RESULTS
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State ??)

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Stage: Movie Buff Looks Back
description: There seemed to be two shows going on at the Actors Playhouse last night, and two for the price of one is not always good. Especially when the dichotomy appears like a chasm separating the book on the one side and the music and lyrics on the other. For the show was that now rare bird, and clearly endangered species, an Off Broadway musical. Sort of. It was called Movie Buff.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball
description: (Thursday Semifinals)

title: Dave Anderson
description: TEMPE, Ariz.Here they are, the Seattle Mariners, with King Neptune's pitchfork forming a gold trident M on their blue caps, an expansion team dedicated to the Puget Sound tides. But somewhat symbolically, the good ship Mariner, as the club has referred to itself, is being launched in the Arizona desert, the ultimate dry dock. And the Mariners' immediate future in the American League is equally dry. There are no baseball millionaires in this training camp, no baseball players who could be released on their own recognizance. One of Darrell Johnson's coaches, Vada Pinson, accumulated 2,757 majorleague hits529 more than the total of all the batters on the Mariners' roster. Except for Diego Segui, the 38yearold Cuban, who was in the minors last season, the pitchers on the roster have put together only 78 career victories. The leading career winner among the candidates for the starting rotation is Mike Kekich with 43 major league triumphs, although the slender 31yearold lefthander is not officially on the Mariners' roster. Mike Kekichisn't that the guy who ...? Yes, that's the guy.

title: American Distilling Adds $74 Million to Its Offer For Schenley Industries
description: The American Distilling Company disclosed yesterday that it had raised the amount of its offer for Schenley Industries by $74 million to $429 million in cash and securities.

title: Tariff Is Urged For TV Imports By Trade Body
description: The United States International Trade Commission recommended yesterday that President Carter impose a new tariff on imported color television sets that would raise the average price of a foreignmade set by $56.

title: Tariff Is Urged For TV Imports By Trade Body
description: The United States International Trade Commission recommended yesterday that President Carter impose a new tariff on imported color television sets that would raise the average price of a foreignmade set by $56.

title: Yankees' Box Score
description: ESherrill 2. 20Henderson, 2 Campaneris. LOBTexas 7 Yankees 9. White 2, Jackson, Blair, Zeber. SBCampaneris.

title: Carter Asks Congress to Decriminalize Marijuana Possession
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP)The Carter Administration asked Congress today to decriminalize marijuana possession and said it was carefully reexamining its position on penalties for possessing cocaine.

title: Civic Garlands, Wine and Quiche
description: Scarcely a week goes by in New York that somebody is not being honored for something, and ordinarily few New Yorkers outside the immediate family are moved to take note of the ceremony. But this week is an exception. Tonight a Musical Garland for Alice Tully will be held in the concert hall named for the city's preeminent patroness of the arts. It is to Miss Tully that concertgoers owe not only the hall but the ample space between its rows; she is 5 feet 8 inches tall and has long legs. So New Yorkers can pay her their respects this evening in comfort.

title: World Cup Soccer
description: WEEKEND QUALIFYING MATCHES Brazil 1, Paraguay 0. Bolivia 2, Venezuela 0. Peru 4, Ecuador 0.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 15, 1977

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NOW SOUNDS One of the cultural bonanzas of the Upper West Side regularly occurs at Christ and St. Stephen's Church, with its evenings of music, movies, poetry and other events at 120 West 69th Street (between Broadway and Columbus Avenue), The lineup starting this week seems promising, indeed.
