title: G.M. Workers in Louisiana Ratify First Contract
description: DETROIT, March 14 (UPI)The United Automobile Workers announced today that the 700 workers at the General Motors guide lamp division plant in Monroe La., the first Southern plant organized after the auto company signed a noninterference pledge, had ratified their first local contract.

title: Had Fought With Soldiers
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, March 15 (AP)  Officials said that Mr. Porcari, who had worked as an auto mechanic in Abidjan, was expeled from the Ivory Coast after he had engaged soldiers in a gunfight at the airport three years ago.

title: Hamlet Near Dulles DoesnA't Mind
description: CHANTILLY, Va., March 14The people of this hamlet have lived for nearly 10 months in the path of the Concorde landings at Dulles International Airport, four miles north of here. They seem to have settled into an amiable if not enthusiastic accommodation with the noisy supersonic airliner.

title: Women's Star Fives to Meet
description: The burgeoning sport of women's basketball will have its first allstar game in the metropolitan area on March 31. Organizers of the Big Apple AllAmerican Basketball Classic, on annual event for male college seniors, announced yesterday that teams of women collegians from New York and New Jersey would compete in a preliminary game. The contests begin at 6 P.M. at the St. John's gymnasium in Queens.

title: Tennis
description: AT JOHANNESBURG $150,000 OPEN

title: Hunter Pitches, Then Says: It Just Didn't Feel Natural
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 14 No matter what happens to his $3.5 million right arm. Catfish Hunter is prepared to complete his fiveyear obligation to the Yankees.

title: Riots Across Italy Shake Government And Communists
description: ROME, March 14The weekend riots by students in several Italian cities have deeply shaken the governing Christian Democrats and the Communists and have left politicians worried about the stability of Italy.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Saint Laurent's explosion of pretty peasant dresses last summer is still reverberating around the fashion world. It's reflected in ruffled tops and dirndl skirts at the discountcounter level and in embroidered organdy bouffant dresses at the couture level.

title: Dollar Up Against Lira but Off Elsewhere
description: LONDON, March 14 (AP)The dollar rose against a sharply weakened Italian lira today but drifted lower on other European currency markets. Gold was also lower.

title: Carter Says Coverage of Sieges Is a Problem for the News Media
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 A spokesman for the President said today that Mr. Carter had no desire to impose any change on the way news organizations cover terrorist sieges but that he saw the problem as one that should be addressed by the organizations themselves.

title: Athletes in Action Spreading Gospel Efficiently
description: They call themselves Athletes In Action, dedicated to spreading the message of Jesus Christ to the sports world and to contribute to the further excellence of athletic competition. And they simply turn the other ear to occasionally derisive remarks like Jocks For Jesus.

title: The LowFloor Bus
description: New York City's kneeling buses aren't kneeling, which gives added point to hearings being held tomorrow by Secretary of Transportation Brock Adams on one of the most ignored mandates of Congress. Beginning with the urban mass transit act of 1964, and five other times since 1970, Congress has directed Mr. Adams's department to make urban transit fully available to the mobile elderly and the disabled. Nothing has happened.

title: 10.64 GAIN IN THE DOW, TO A CLOSE OF 958.36, IS BEST FOR 3 MONTHS
description: The recently depressed bluechip and glamour stocks spearheaded a broadbased stock market advance yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing by 10.64 points to register its best gain in three months.

title: Canadiens Blank Kings; Lafleur Nears a Record
description: MONTREAL, March 14 (AP)Goals by Jacques Lemaire, Guy Lafleur and Guy Lapointe carried the Montreal Canadiens to a 30 victory over the Los Angeles Kings in the National Hockey League tonight.

title: U.S, WEIGHS REQUEST BY ZAIRE FOR HELP
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Carter Administration officials said today that they were seriously concerned about the reported capture of border towns in Zaire by forces crossing from Angola. They said the Administration was considering an urgent request from Zaire for spare parts and other military equipment to help repel the invaders.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHTS GAME

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 15, 1977

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CAMDEN, S.C.My hunting companionsFred Myers and Hugh Grenade, both of Camdenhad warned me that we might have difficulty finding quail so late in the season, and after three hours of steady walking, during which the temperature climbed into the low 80's, their prophesy became reality.

title: Carter's Diplomacy in Public Causing Questions and Complications
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The public style of diplomacy that President Carter has made one hallmark of his early weeks in office is already stirring controversy here.

title: Finley: Kuhn Wants to Move A's to Capital
description: CHICAGO, March 14 (UPI)Organized baseball wants to buy the Oakland A's and move the team to Washington, Charles O. Finley, the team's owner, said today.

title: Price Range for '77 to Date
description: Starting in today's New York Times, the stock tables for issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange will reflect the highlow price range for 1977 to date.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Suspect's Wife Bitter Over the Murder of L.I. Girl, 10
description: PINELAWN, L.I. March 14At the fresh gravesite of 10yearold Lisamarie Merritt here today, Rose Waggoner said she hoped her husband would be sentenced to death if he was convicted of the girl's murder.

title: Search of Nevada Desert Fails to Find Union Chief
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 14 (UPI) The search for Al Bramlet, the labor leader who led a strike last spring that closed most of the hotel  casinos on the Las Vegas Strip, was called off today after a week of scouring the Nevada desert.

title: Alabama and Houston Gain in N.I.T.
description: Otis Birdsong, the main attraction last night at Madison Square Garden for scouts from 16 teams of the National Basketball Association, put the University of Houston into the semifinal round of the 40th annual National Invitation Tournament.

title: Paris Troupe Coming With Tiger at Gates
description: The Theater de la Ville, the official theater of Paris, will make its first American appearance April 20 with Jean Giraudoux's La Guerre de Troie n'Aura Pas Lieu (Tiger at the Gates) at the New York City Center55th Street Theater.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article from South Lake Tahoe, Calif., in yesterday's Times concerning the World Cup skiing championships erroneously reported that LiseMarie Morerod, winner of the women's title, was Austrian. Miss Morerod is Swiss.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Aide to Energy Agency Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)John O'Leary, the Federal Energy Administrator, announced the appointment today of James Bishop, former assistant Washington bureau chief of Newsweek magazine, as director of communications and public affairs for the agency. Mr. Bishop will hold the post until the creation of the proposed Department of Energy, when he is expected to become chief spokesman for all Government energy programs, Administration sources said.

title: U.S. WEIGHS REQUEST BY ZAIRE FOR HELP
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Carter Administration officials said today that they were seriously concerned about the reported capture of border towns in Zaire by forces crossing from Angola. They said the Administration was considering an urgent request from Zaire for spare parts and other military equipment to help repel the invaders.

title: Plett Dims Ranger Hopes And Bolsters Rookie Bid
description: While his team was battling the New York Rangers for a better position in the competition for a playoff berth Sunday night, Willi Plett of the Atlanta Flames was fighting for recognition as a top candidate for rookie of the year in the National Hockey League. By scoring three goals for the first time in his professional career, the right wing made a strong case for consideration in the Calder Trophy voting as Atlanta posted a 53 victory over the lastplace Rangers. Plett had scored the deciding goal in Saturday's triumph over New York and yesterday he was voted N.H.L. player of the week by the Professional Hockey Writers Association.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: Aussies Widen Cricket Lead
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, March 14 (AP)Australia had consolidated its position at lunch on the third day of the centenary test cricket match against England today at the Melbourne Cricket Ground. With the loss of only one wicket, the Australians added 82 runs in the morning session to be four wickets for 186, a lead of 223.

title: Christians Assault A Lebanese Village Held by Guerrillas
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 14 (AP)Rightwing Christian militiamen attacked a leftistheld village near the Israeli border today. Military sources reported that 12 persons had been killed in housetohouse fighting.

title: At New Orleans
description: The Fair Grounds said it had lost about $12,000 to counterfeiters who had printed fake win tickets on one race. It seems to be the same thing that happened in Hot Springs [Ark.] about a month ago, said the manager, Carroll DeLatte. One man has been arrested

title: STEEL PRODUCTION GAINS FOR 5TH STRAIGHT WEEK
description: For the fifth consecutive week, domestic steel production posted a gain rising to this year's high weekly output of 2.37 million tons in the week ended March 12. The American Iron and Steel Institute, which released the weekly figures yesterday, said this was a gain of 0.4 percent over the preceding week when 2.36 million tons were poured. The latest production level meant that the industry was putting to use 77.1 percent of its total available capability against 76.8 percent a week earlier.

title: Son of Mrs. Gandhi Is Reported Unhurt In Shooting Attack
description: NEW DELHI, Tuesday, March.15Sanjay Gandh., Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's 30yearold son, escaped injury last night when shots were fired at his jeep during a campaign tour, the Governmentcontrolled news agency here reported this morning.

title: Memorial Services
description: PATTERSONIsabel W. Service will be held Tuesday, March 15th at 4 P.M. al the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church In Phillips Chanel on East 73rd St., near Madison Ave.

title: Canadian Dollar Declines
description: TORONTO, March 14 (Reuters)The Canadian dollar fell below 95 cents today after rallying on Friday on Moody's investors service's unchanged bond rating for Quebec, dealers said.

title: BUILDING OF ATOM PLANTS HALTED IN WEST GERMANY
description: BONN, March 14 (UPI)Opponents of nuclear power won a court fight today that appeared to indefinitely halt the construction of atomic power plants in West Germany.

title: Fear and Loathing on Long Island
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., March 14  When the big jets on their approach to Kennedy International Airport fly over this community, conversations stop. Teachers pause in their lessons, clergymen halt their sermons and the old men on the park benches in front of the village hall fall silent until the planes pass.

title: School Results
description: BOYS' HOCKEY

title: READING AND MATH PROVE TOUGH IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: TRENTON, March 14 (UPI)Many New Jersey publicschool pupils do not understand what they read and have serious difficulties with mathematical skills, according to the latest statewide tests.

title: Court Changes Blocked in Albany by Senate, 41 to 16
description: ALBANY, March 14The New York State Senate, in almost complete disarray, voted down today but did not finally kill a package of constitutional amendments aimed at changing the state's court system.

title: Lily Tomlin to Play Solo at Biltmore
description: Lily Tomlin, who costars with Art Carney in the movie The Late Show, will begin a fourweek solo engagement on stage at the Biltmore Theater on March 24. The comedienne will appear in a program of songs and characterizations under the aegis of Ron Delsener. Previews will be held next Tuesday and Wednesday. Performances will be at 8 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays, 7 and 10 P.M. on Saturdays, and 3 and 7:30 P.M. on Sundays.

title: Advertising
description: Esquire magazine, working with a Houston shopping mall, is launching next week a weeklong super merchandising extravaganza that is expected to be the first of a series of similar activities put on by the men's magazine at malls throughout the country.

title: The Cast
description: MOVIE BUFF, book by Hiram Taylor, music by John Raniello; lyrics by Mr. Raniello and Mr. Taylor; musical direction and arrangements by Don Jones; musical numbers staged by Jack Dyville; setting by Jimmy Cuomo; costumes by Carol Wenz; lighting by Jo Mayer; directed by Jim Payne; stage manager, Jessie Frank. Presented by Free Space Ltd. At the Actors Playhouse, 100 Seventh Avenue South.

title: Upgrading of Rail Service to Begin
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The Federal Railroad Administration assured a skeptical Senate Appropriations Subcommittee today that construction work on the longdelayed upgrading of the WashingtonNew YorkBoston passenger rail lines would start on April 1.

title: Terrorism and Fit News
description: Ambassador Andrew Young voiced some thoughts this weekend about the media and terrorism that seem to us hasty and pernicious. He is concerned about the contagious effect of news coverage of such crimes as the Hanafi Moslem hostage episode in Washington. It is, he said, tantamount to advertising to neurotic people who are inspired to attempt suicidal and ridiculous acts. His solution: to restrict the press by law in its coverage of violent crimes.

title: WagePrice Council Asks Cut in Milk Support Level
description: WASHINGTON. March 14The Administration's Council on Wage and Price Stability has recommended reduction of the Agriculture Department's support price for milk.

title: TAXI PANEL PREPARED TO APPROVE 13% RISE IN FARES IN NEW YORK
description: New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission is prepared to increase taxi fares by as much as 13 percent when it meets tomorrow to vote on the industrysought increase, commission members said yesterday. However, a minority was pressing yesterday for a smaller increase.

title: French Government Bid Halts Test In Court Over Ban on the Concorde
description: Today's scheduled court test of the ban on Concorde operations in New York was postponed again yesterday, primarily at the insistence of the French Government, which faces national municipal runoff elections Sunday.

title: MidOhio Track Accepts S.C.C.A. CanAm Event
description: LEXINGTON, Ohio, March 14 (AP)MidOhio officials have ironed out there differences with the Sports Car Club of America and the track will be the site of one of the CanadianAmerican road racing events this summer.

title: AMIN PLANNING A MEETING WITH BRITONS, AMERICANS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 14 (Reuters)President Idi Amin plans to address Americans and Britons living in Uganda, the Uganda radio reported today.

title: Teamster Pension Chief Asserts Commitments Exceed the Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The executive director of the teamsters' union's major pension fund told a Congressional hearing here today that the fund did not have enough money to meet all of its pension commitments.

title: Folger Raises Coffee 50c to $4.18 a Pound
description: CINCINNATI, March 14 (UPI) The Folger Coffee Company, the nation's second largest coffee roaster, topped the $4 a pound barrier today and raised its wholesale prices for ground coffee by 50 cents to a record of $4.18 a pound in a move that should be reflected on supermarket shelves in two months.

title: Annenberg Threatening to Cancel $40 Million Arts Center at the Met
description: Walter H. Annenberg threatened yesterday to withdraw his $40 million pledge to establish and maintain a finearts center at the Metropolitan Museum of Art because of mounting controversy over the project.

title: Energy and Trade To Be Key Topics Of London Summit
description: WASHINGTON, March 14American officials said today that the international economic conference scheduled for London May 7 and 8 would focus on energy, the NorthSouth dialogue between the rich and poor countries, trade questions and broader economic issues relating to management of the recovery from the world's deepest postwar recession.

title: Greek Gives Up Bulk of His. Art To Take Rest of It Out of Soviet
description: MOSCOW, March 14Most of one of the world's finest private collections of avantgarde Russian painting  works from the early 20th century that have not been officially recognizedwill pass into the hands of the Soviet Government this week and into an uncertain future.

title: Fannie Lou Hamer Dies; Left Farm To Lead Struggle for Civil Rights
description: Fannie Lou Hamer, who became a nationally known advocate of equal rights for blacks during the 1960s, died of cancer yesterday in Mount Bayon Community Hospital in Mississippi, 30 miles north of her home in Ruleville. She was 60 years old.

title: Noise Divides an English Lane
description: LONDON, March 14Some of the 200 or so residents of Green Man Lane consider that they live in the outer London village of Hatton, some say it's Faltham and some Bedfont. It's a nowhere place, really, of disintegrating identity, but it's well known to Government engineers who specialize in studying data about decibels.

title: Saudi Crude Oil Production For February Below Target
description: Saudi Crude Oil Production For February Below Target

title: TAXI PANEL PREPARED TO APPROVE 13% RISE IN FARES IN NEW YORK
description: New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission is prepared to increase taxi fares by as much as 13 percent when it meets tomorrow to vote on the industrysought increase, commission members said yesterday. However, a minority was pressing yesterday for a smaller increase.

title: Atlanta to Conduct House Vote Today; Runoff Is Expected
description: ATLANTA, March 14The 12way contest to select a successor tomorrow to Andrew Young as the representative from Atlanta's racially mixed Fifth Congressional District seems almost certain to end without a clear victor, requiring a second election on April 5 to pick a winner.

title: REP. FLORIO ENTERS DEMOCRATIC PRIMARY
description: TRENTON, March 14Representative James J. Florio of Camden made his long anticipated entry into the Democratio race for Governor today and said he saw no need now for dramatic changes in the state income tax program.

title: Ruptured Blood Vessel Apparently Killed Pacer
description: Tarport Hap, the 5yearold pacer who fell dead during the sixth race at the Meadowlands on Saturday night, was the victim of a ruptured blood vessel, according to an autopsy that has yet to be concluded.

title: Mets Gain A Palatable Victory, 53
description: ST. PETERSBURG. Fla., March 14The New York Mets, who sometimes eat crow in the National League have decided to put a better taste on things by naming a committee of four players to select the food on airline tripsnow that baseball players have become more affluent and their eating habits have changed drastically.

title: Books of The Times
description: It would be nice if it were all as simple as Tony Hiss tries to make it seem. For then we could accept the premise of Laughing Last: Alger Hiss by Tony Hiss, which goes as follows: The only fact here is that Al is a naturally private man, and so his private life has been one piece of the puzzle [of the HissChambers case] that hasn't been available before. . . . So this book will be of interest to anyone who thought there was something missing in anything they have read previously about Al. And this book invites you to make up your own mind about my pop, and presents a life, not a court case. From this point of view the public eventsthe court caseare part of a life, and I think anyone who reads this book through to the end will see that the court case makes quite a different kind of sense.

title: Reds Sign Concepcion To a 5Year Contract
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 14 (AP)Dave Concepcion of the Cincinnati Reds has signed a fiveyear contract, the lengthiest awarded in the team's history.

title: Market Place The Rise and Fall of Olympia Brewing
description: The price of Olympia Brewing Company shares has been cut in half in the last seven trading sessions in the overthecounter market with company officials expressing bafflement at the development.

title: Glancing Back at New Faces
description: For at least the last two years, Leonard Sillman, who produced 13 editions of his New Faces revues between 1934 and 1968, has been preparing a Best of New Faces  for Broadway. According to his present estimates, it may arrive in town next fall.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Arraignments Increase Sharply Despite Cutbacks in Police Force
description: Despite sharp reductions in personnel in the Police Department and a reportedly demoralized force, the number of arraignments in Manhattan Criminal Court almost doubled, from 5.729 in January 1976 to 9,115 in January 1977.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: 2 TELL OF A COVERUP IN KILLING BY OFFICER
description: Two police officers testified yesterday that they had kept quiet or had lied about their knowledge that a white officer accused of planting a by pistol near the body of a black youth he had shot, had owned a toy pistol and played with it at least three weeks earlier.

title: Briton Who Vanquished Deep Throat Battles for TV Morality
description: LONDONWhen the Danish director Jens Jorgen Thorsen announced plans last year to make a movie in England about Jesus Christ's sex life, Mary Whitehouse went to work. She appealed to the Church of England, Members of Parliament and the Prime Mmister. She investigated an 1889 law against blasphemous libel. She called on the Home Secretary to ban Thorsen from Britain. And when Thorsen, carrying the script of his film, was turned away at London's Heathrow Airport early this year, it was one of Mary Whitehouse's finest hours.

title: HOUSE VOTES, 250146, TO BLOCK IMPORTING OF RHODESIA CHROME
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The House today gave President Carter an important foreign policy victory by voting to repeal a law that for more than five years has kept the United States in violation of United Nations sanctions against Rhodesia.

title: Arizona Paper Does Not Publish First Articles Prompted by Slaying of Its Reporter
description: PHOENIX, March 14A 23part investigative series alleging corruption in Arizona, prompted by the murder last June of Don Bolles, a reporter on The Arizona Republic, and compiled by a team of reporters from 23 newspapers and two broadcasters, has begun without appearing in the newspaper for which he worked.

title: MEXICO PLANS BONDS PEGGED TO OIL PRICE
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico, March 14In an attempt to stimulate domestic savings, the Mexican Government today announced plans to issue 2 billion pesosabout $90 millionworth of petrobonds that will have a maturity value pegged to the world price of oil.

title: Yesterday's Preseason Baseball
description: AT TEMPE, ARIZ.

title: 350Foot Crane Makes Its Debut on Broadway
description: A crane with a 350foot boom and a cab the size of a small house took up desidence in 44th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues yesterday for the twoday task of hoisting an 88,000pound airconditioning cooling tower onto the 13thfloor roof of The New York Times Building.

title: South. Africa and a Free Press
description: Two slender threads have kept South Africa attached to the ideals of Western democratic societies. One has been a commitment to law, often honored only in the breach and in the service of racism and suppression, but honored nonetheless as a legitimizing force in politics. The other has been tolerance of an outspoken press, especially the portion that represents the restive Englishspeaking half of the country's white minority.

title: The Seigneur of Sark, an Island of Cheap Whisky, Beckons Tourists
description: In these times of political ambiguity, it is refreshing to find a leader of government to whom promises are not mere rhetoric.

title: Notes on People
description: James Callaghan, the British Prime Minister, has returned to London after visits with President Carter and the Canadian Prime Minister, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, and, the British Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday, he will appear March 24 in a televised Carterstyle telephone callin with viewers. Was the program inspired by Mr. Carter's March 5 radio callin, in which he answered the questions of 42 citizens? Not really, said the BBC, for planning for the program began in midFebruary. Opposition parties, notably Margaret Thatcher's Conservatives, were expected to request equal time to conduct their own callins.

title: Manhattan Plaza Wins Approval To Get Tenants
description: The New York City Board of Estimate voted yesterday to allow the Manhattan Plaza housing development near Times Square to begin accepting tenant applications under a plan that gives preference to members of the performing arts for occupying most of the project's 1,700 apartments.

title: Advertisers Support Challenged Claims
description: Because of the involvement of bigname advertisers in some of the challenged claims tackled in February by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus, perhaps those who could support their claims might be more interesting than those who didn't

title: International Cooperation Stressed as U.N. Water Conference Opens
description: MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, March 14A United Nations conference on the world's water crisis opened today at this seaside resort with delegates from more than 100 countries gathered to consider how to control drought, floods, pollution and disease through better water management.

title: Garden Hoping for Fat Pickings In Slims Tournament Next Week
description: Can a major indoor tennis tournament draw in New York? The question has baffled promoters, players and fans, for in recent years the few such tournaments held here have not sold an impressive number of tickets.

title: Britain's Payments Move Into Surplus
description: LONDON, March 14 (Reuters)Britain's balance of payments moved into surplus in February for the first time in 11 months after a sharp improvement in the country's trading performance.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney reports that John D. deButts, chief executive of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, finds the outlook both for his company and the general economy pretty good. Page 53.

title: Violin Recital, Amram Work Offer Sparkle
description: Folk music is the richest source of material available to any cornposer, but remarkably few have the taste and imagination necessary to take the basic stuff, recycle it and transmute it into something personal and contemporary. Don't most listeners learn to wince at the prospect of hearing, say, Variations on a Barndance Tune? Yes.

title: SULZBERGER ADVISES BEAME NOT TO RUN
description: DETROIT, March 14Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, said here. today that New York City needed a tougher man in charge and that Mayor Beame, very frankly, ought to consider stepping down at the end of his current term.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article from South Lake Tahoe, Calif., in yesterday's Times concerning the Would Cup skiing championships erroneously reported that LiseMarie Morerod, winner of the women's title, was Austrian. Miss Morerod is Swiss.

title: Ulysses S. Grant 4th, Professor, Grandson of Former President
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., March 14 (UPI)Dr. Ulysses S. Grant 4th, grandson of the Civil War general and 18th President of the United States, died of leukemia Friday at St. John's Hospital. He was 83 years old.

title: HOUSE VOTES, 250146, TO BLOCK IMPORTING OF RHODESIA CHROME
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The House today gave President Carter an important foreign policy victory by voting to repeal a law that for more than five years has kept the United States in violation of United Nations sanctions against Rhodesia.

title: 175 Picketing Teachers Arrested
description: RACINE, Wis., March 14 (UPI)Public schoolteachers rejected today a contract offer from the Racine school board and returned to picket lines, and at least 175 were arrested for blocking sidewalks and driveways.

title: MarlboroughBlenheim Acquired By Reese Palley to Set up a Casino
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 14Reese Palley, the widely known flamboyant art dealer, announced today that he and an associate had purchased the MarlboroughBlenheim Hotel and would spend $35 million on renovations to qualify it for a casino gambling license

title: Theft of Historic Letters From New York Library Laid to Autograph Dealer
description: A 31yearold autograph dealer was arrested yesterday and accused of acquiring a remarkable inventory of early American signatures by using a razor blade to remove historic letters from the New York Public Library's document collection.

title: Aluminum Shipments Up 8.7%
description: January shipments of aluminum sheet and plate reached an estimated 440.4 million pounds, a gain of 8.7 percent over the like 1976 month, the Aluminum Association reported yesterday. Foil shipments in the first month at 66.1 million pounds ran 2.6 percent lower than a year ago.

title: Howard Whidden of Business Week
description: Howard P. Whidden, a former vice president of the Committee for Economic Development and a former senior editor of Business Week, died Saturday in Columbia Memorial Hospital in Hudson, N.Y., of cancer after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived in Hillsdale, N.Y.

title: So. Africa Net Final Off
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 14 (AP)The final of the rainplagued $150,000 South African open tennis tournament was called off today because Bjorn Borg of Sweden and Guillermo Vilas of Argentina had to depart for other tournaments. Owen Williams, tournament director said the match might be played in the United States or Europe sometime in the future.

title: Strauss Promises U.S. Won't Give Anything Away in Trade Parleys
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Robert S. Strauss, recently named President Carter's Special Trade Representative, said today the United States had got short shrift in agriculture in previous trade negotiations and served notice that in the current round we're not going to give anything away.

title: Senate Honors Roots Author
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)The Senate passed a resolution today paying tribute to Alexander Haley, for his exceptional achievement in producing Roots. The resolution, introduced by Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, passed by voice vote without dissent.

title: World News Briefs
description: LONDON, March 14 (Reuters)Foreign Secretary David Owen announced today that he will visit southern Africa over Easter to tackle once more the deadlocked problem of bringing black rule to Rhodesia.

title: Minimum Wage Urged As Basis for Welfare
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Mar 14 (UPI)Gov. Robert Straub proposed today a single national welfare system based on the minimum wage and offered Oregon as a test site.

title: Austrian Leader Praises Carter's Stand on Rights; Also Favors Quiet Steps
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria said today that he found the Carter Administration's emphasis on human rights issues very impressive. But he expressed concern that the campaign might damage quieter forms of helping individuals in authoritarian societies.

title: Letters: The Concorde Controversy
description: Your March 9 editorial on the Concorde seems to be a rather simplified account of a complex issue.

title: Beanie Plans Mayoral Race Keyed To Offensive Against Street Crime
description: Following the strategy that the best defense is a good offense, Mayor Beame will make safe streets a major thrust of his administration in the months before the Democratic mayoral primary.

title: Mrs. Carter Sees Role Widening
description: WASHINGTON, March 14About a month ago, when someone asked Rosalynn Carter if she thought she could wield any real power as the honorary head of a Presidential commission, she responded haltingly, hesitantly, a bit uncertain of her words.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: ADVANCE BY LEFTISTS CONCEDED IN FRANCE
description: PARIS, March 14National political leaders of the centerright conceded today that the leftist opposition had made considerable gains in yesterday's nationwide municipal elections.

title: Thailand to Lift Gasoline Prices
description: BANGKOK, March 14 (Reuters)The Thai government tonight announced that prices of gasoline and diesel fuel would rise tomorrow by up to 16.5 percent for the top grade of gasoline. A statement over Radio Thailand said the decision had been made because the country's oil stocks at prices current prior to the last price increase by producer countries last December were running out.

title: About New York
description: It Is risky these days to take a noncrusading view of public life and linger over the distinctions offered by accused people. But that is what friends of Kenneth S. Axelson are doing as they ponder the fall from grace of a man who acquired impressive stature during his oneyear stint as volunteer troubleshooter and deputy mayor during the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Warm Weather Returns To Western Plains
description: DENVER, March 14 (AP)  Warm weather returned today to the Western Plains,melting some of the snow left by a blizzard that paralyzed the area over the weekend and took 16 lives.

title: Greek Gives Up Bulk of His Art To Take Rest of It Out of Soviet
description: MOSCOW, March 14Most of one of the world's finest private collections of avantgarde Russian painting  works from the early 20th century that have not been officially recognizedwill pass into the hands of the Soviet Government this week and into an uncertain future.

title: A Modern Center in Detroit Sets Itself Apart From City
description: DETROITRenaissance Center is certainly in Detroit, but it is hardly of Detroit. The $337 million development, which includes four office towers and a 73story hotel that is due to open today, is one of the largest privately financed real estate projects in history. Its sleek, fresh forms stand out boldly against the dreary skyline of the rest of this sadly deteriorating city. It is a vision, its sponsors hope, of a new Detroit.

title: House Bill Provides Saccharin Warning
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI) Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr., Democrat of Indiana, introduced legislation today that would allow the sale of saccharin in the United States, but each saccharin container would have to carry this label, Warning: The Canadians have determined saccharin is dangerous to your rat's health. Mr. Jacobs sent a letter to all other House members asking them to cosponsor his bill to ban the saccharin ban.

title: BY AMBYN RINCHEN, WRITER ON MONGOL HERITAGE, 72
description: MOSCOW, March 14 (Reuters)Byambyn Rinchen, a Mongolian writer whose outspoken espousal of his country's cultural heritage once got him jailed and another time won him a major prize, died in Ulan Bator on March 6, according to a Mongolian official. He was 72 years old.

title: British Football
description: By The Associated Press ENGLISH LEAGUE First Division

title: DIRECTORS OF BIG BOARD AGREE ON WIDER ACCESS
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday, as expected, that its board of directors approved the report or its access committee to widen access to the exchange with two modifications.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey's Consumer Affairs Division said an order directed at questionable fundraising tactics used by the Congress of Racial Equality would affect solicitation practices by charitable organizations, Virginia Long, director of the division, said the order would protect consumers against questionable practices that might have been used by organizations seeking donations to charitable causes. The state filed suit last August against CORE, charging the group had solicited charity without being registered or filing the required financial records with the state. Last Thursday, Judge Sherwin Lester signed an order in Essex County Superior Court in Newark prohibiting CORE from using words to suggest it was a government agency, continuing to call a person after receiving a refusal to purchase an ad or attempting to collect for an advertisement that has not been authorized.

title: In Memoriam
description: TAYLORWilliam Towson, March 15th 1916. We will love and remember you always. ETHEL, ANN AND LEW

title: 25% of Medicare's Largest Bills Come From New York City Area
description: WASHINGTON, March 14More than one of every four doctors who billed Medicare for $100,000 or more in 1975 are in practice in New York City and its suburbs, according to a Federal list released today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Two youths charged with being designated felons for the murder of an 80yearold woman in her Brooklyn apartment were ordered held yesterday for a hearing on Thursday.

title: Cauthen, On Boy Emperor, Ends Sky Treaty's Streak
description: At the Race Tracks

title: Noise Divides an English Lane
description: LONDON, March 14Some of the 200 or so residents of Green Man Lane consider that they live in the outer London village of Hatton, some say it's Faltham and some Bedfont. It's a nowhere place, really, of disintegrating identity, but it's well known to Government engineers who specialize in studying data about decibels.

title: Bucks, Led by Winters, Subdue Lakers, 110106
description: MILWAUKEE, March 14 (AP)Brian Winters's threepoint play with 50 seconds left gave the Milwaukee Bucks the cushion they needed tonight for a 110106 National Basketball Association victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Fear and Loathing on Long Island
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., March 14  When the big jets on their approach to Kennedy International Airport fly over this community, conversations stop. Teachers pause in their lessons, clergymen halt their sermons and the old men on the park benches in front of the village hall fall silent until the planes pass.

title: EUGENE L. BONDY
description: Eugene L. Bondy, who practiced law in New York City for almost 70 years, died Sunday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 90 years old and had been active in his profession until last year. Mr. Bondy was born in Albany and was a gradute of Columbia College and Columbia Law School, He is survived by his wife, the former Irene Kramer; a son, Eugene L. Jr.; a daughter, Ruth Lowy, and 10 grandchildren.

title: 30 Windows Smashed in School
description: Thirty windows were broken over the weekend at Public School 208 at 4811 Avenue D in the Farragut section of Brooklyn, Norman Desser, the principal, reported yesterday to the police. Beer bottles possibly used as as missiles by the vandals were found outside the school.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 14The Aetna Casualty and Surety Company, which insures 95,000 automobiles in New Jersey, or 2.5 percent of those eligible, scored a breakthrough today in the state's eightmonth freeze on rate increases when State Insurance Commissioner James J. Sheeran announced that the company had been granted a 9 percent rise.

title: President to Stay Overnight With Typical Family
description: WASHINGTON, March 14 (UPI)President Carter will stay at the home of an official of a beer distributing company and his family in Clinton, Mass., after attending a town hall meeting there Wednesday night, the White House said today.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The SherwinWilliams Company, the sole producer of saccharin in the United States, will continue producing the substance for at least another 30 days, the company's vice president and secretary, William P. Inman said yesterday.

title: SPANISH JET HIJACKED AND FLOWN TO AFRICA
description: SEVILLE, Spain, Tuesday, March 15 (UPI)A gunman hijacked an Iberia Airlines jetliner with 36 other persons aboard yesterday and forced it to be flown to the Ivory Coast, where he demanded a $140,000 ransom and the return of his young daughter. He then ordered the Boeing 727 to be flown to Morocco, but it was refused permission to land there and the plane continued instead to Seville.

title: Mrs. Carter Sees Role Widening
description: WASHINGTON, March 14About a month ago, when someone asked Rosalynn Carter if she thought she could wield any real power as the honorary head of a Presidential commission, she responded haltingly, hesitantly, a bit uncertain of her words.

title: Beame Plans to Use Current Funds To Finance City U. for Next Year
description: The Beame administration has quietly devised an unusual proposal to continue for one more year its financing of the senior colleges at City University by shifting the beginning of the university's fiscal year from July 1 to April 1.

title: Palestinian Leaders Propose Conditions For Going to Geneva
description: CAIRO, March 14The leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization today proposed to its national council a set of conditions for its participation in the Geneva conference on the Middle East. The proposal implied a hardening of the Palestinian position on some issues and a slight softening on others.

title: People and Business
description: Charles L. Schultze has relinquished his position as cochairman of the Economic Policy Group, one of three key economic posts he has held under President Carter.

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: $378,613 Pledged to WNET Midway in Fund Drive
description: WNET's fundraising drive, now more than halfway through a 14day special program festival, so far has enlisted 13,208 new members who have pledged $378,613. At that rate, the public television station is likely to raise about as much money as it did last March while signing up fewer members.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: CHANTILLY, Va., March 14The people of this hamlet have lived for nearly 10 months in the path of the Concorde landings at Dulles International Airport, four miles north of here. They seem to have settled into an amiable if not enthusiastic accommodation with the noisy supersonic airliner.

title: People in Sports
description: Bob Beamon, who set the current world record of 29 feet 2 inches in the long jump in the 1968 Olympic Games at Mexico City, was named yesterday to the National Track and Field Hall of Fame with nine other persons.

title: Hamlet Near Dulles Doesn't Mind
description: Hamlet Near Dulles Doesn't Mind

title: Beaux Arts Trio
description: The Beaux Arts Trio joined Frederick Waldman and his Musica Aeterna Orchestra Sunday night in the annual Carnegie Hall benefit concert for Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem. The inevitable outcome was a performance of Beethoven's Triple Concerto (Op. 56)no other work for piano, violin, cello and orchestra is nearly as well known.

title: Basque Man Dies of Injuries Suffered in Clash With Police
description: MADRID, March 14A 20yearold Basque, Jos Luis Aristizabal, died early this morning in the northern town of San Sebastin after being hit in the head yesterday by a rubber bullet fired by riot policemen.

title: Namath Aide, Rams to Talk; Jets, Mets Meet Tomorrow
description: One of New York football's two major issueswhere Joe Namath will play next season and where the rest of the Jets will wind upappeared to move closer to a resolution yesterday.

title: PAULINE R. KOHN, 81; AIDED 250 REFUGEES
description: Pauline Redlich Kohn, who vouched personally for 250 Austrian and German Jewish refugees to come to the United States to escape Nazi rule, died Sunday in Peninsula Hospital Center, Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Soybean Prices Up  Cents a Bushel; Grain Futures Off
description: CHICAGO, March 14 (AP)  Soybean futures advanced 8 cents a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade today, but grain futures prices were mostly lower.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: FIRST$6,500, pace, mile.

title: Saharan Guerrillas Roam Freely In Territory Ceded to Moroccans
description: TIFARITI, Western SaharaThis former trading center is a ghost town, abandoned by its 7,000 residents a year ago under Moroccan bombardment. But the Moroccans have not moved in even though this is part of their twothirds of the Spanish Sahara, which they divided in 1975 with Mauritania.

title: Senate Panel Defers a Vote on Bill To Equalize HospitalPatient Rates
description: TRENTON, March 14The State Senate Health Committee postponed today a vote on a bill that would allow the Commissioner of Health to equalize hospital rates of private patients and those covered by Blue Cross insurance.

title: Men Harder Hit by Recession
description: PARIS, March 14 (Reuters)Women were more successful then men in holding onto their jobs when unemployment hit the major Western industrialized countries during the recent recession, according to an international report.

title: Fed Moves to Spur Money Orders
description: The Federal Reserve Board sought yesterday to stimulate competition in the money order issuing business by making it easier for banks to operate in this market.

title: Mrs. Mondale Is Praised By Nancy Hanks on Arts
description: WASHINGTON, March 14Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts since 1969, told a group of journalists today that she had not given any serious thought to whether President Carter would reappoint her to a third fouryear term next October, when her current term expires, because she was a shortterm, not longterm planner.

title: University Hires Cox in Admissions Suit
description: BERKELEY, Calif., March 14Archibald Cox. former Watergate special prosecutor, was retained by the University of California today to present oral arguments to the Supreme Court in its appeal on the constitutionality of its special admissions programs for minority students

title: Public Health Economist Scores Carey Budget for Day Care Cuts
description: A Columbia School of Public Health economist's study contends that day care cuts in New York City that could result from Governor Carey's proposed budget represent poor planning, poor economics and would drive parents from the working boor on to welfare rolls.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Maybe, He Thought, He'd Wind Up at Entebbe
description: WASHINGTON I thought I was going to die and throughout those 38 hours my mind was a jumble of visions in which I'm telling my wife Dorothy and the family of how I kept thinking I was going to die. That doesn't make sense  or, does it? Is hope really stronger than fear? Is it that you're not alone, that there is comfort in the nearness of more than 100 other anguished captives sharing an imposed camaraderie? Shock. It numbs the emotions, insulating you from the worst of your fears. It keeps your Sanity intact while, your hands bound, you are squirming from flat on your hack to flat on your belly, inching for a more comfortable resting place on the

title: Investors Give Better Reception To Lower Rated Corporate Bonds
description: Corporations with lower ratings from Moody's and Standard & Poor's are getting a heartier reception from investors these days. American Airlines late yesterday afternoon increased an offering of preferred stock with warrants to $125 million from $100 million. Both issues are regarded by the rating agencies as speculative. The success of these offerings is a result of an intensified search for relatively high yields by investors who became used to stratospheric interest rates b'ck in 1974 and 1975 when longterm interest rates climbed to their highest levels in more than a century. To get rates of return as high as those, investors have had to accept more speculative securities.

title: NEW REPORT TANGLES TRIAL OF TWO NURSES
description: DETROIT, March 14  There are some ready to swear that they fought for life more than anyone else. But Federal prosecutors here contend that Filipino Narciso, 30 years old, and Leonora Perez, 32, both highly trained nurses, murdered two patients and attempted to poison seven others at the Veterans Hospital in An Arbor, Mich.

title: Despite Drought Year, 6 Huge Reservoirs On Upper Missouri River Are Nearly Full
description: OMAHA, March 10While many of the great reservoirs that produce hydoelectric power and irrigation water for the Pacific Northwest are now dangerously low, the six huge mainstem reservoirs on the upper Missouri River are filled today close to capacity.

title: RALPH E. LADUE, 87, DIES; EXHEAD OF JOHN DAVID
description: Ralph E. Ladue, former president of John David Inc., men's clothing chain until it was sold to the Hoving Corporation in 1948, died in Florida yesterday. He was 87 years old.

title: Rubinstein Attends Concert

The 90yearold pianist, accompanied by his wife and appearing well, attended a concert given at the Paris Congress Hall by the Orchestre de Paris directed by Zubin Mehta.

title: Private Lives
description: IF YOU are accustomed, especially at airports, to thinking of other people as big trees among which your small children are lost it comes a surprise to see the head of your sonthat shaggy beatitudefloating around at eye level. Did he just come off a rack instead of a plane? Stretched or on stilts of bone, lie ambles into his own future. Somebody watered his ankles, and overnight they elongated. He is only 14, and it is suddenly clear that one day he will reach six feet. You never made six feet, not even on a chinning bar, and it doesn't look as though you ever will without a ladder.

title: Ali Plans Title Bout in Seoul, Sidesteps Garden Pact

title: There's a Knot on Bump's Brow
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 15The Texas Rangers second baseman wore No, 1 on his uniform. He is a compact young man of 24 with a wisp of blond mustache and more than a suggestion of red in his bushy hair. At 177 pounds, he outweighs his father by 10 or 15. He is fast, ran 100 yards in 9.9 seconds in high school, but baseball kept him off the track team and anyway, he is not as fast as his father was. His name is Elliott Wills and he is called Bump. His father is a sports broadcaster named Maury Wills, who Sports of The Times used to steal bases for a living. One summer Maury stole 104 bases, which was more than Ty Cobb ever did in a season, or of Eddie Collins or Honus Wagner. In fact. Maury Wills would rank as baseball's boss burglar if it weren't for larcenous Lou Brock, who stole 118 bases in 1974.

title: Billionaire Hughes's Wealth Put at Only $168,834,615

title: HEAD OF CITY COUNCIL LEADS ATLANTA RACE
description: ATLANTA, March 15John Lewis, the choice'of Atlanta's black leadership to succeed Andrew Young in Congress, assured himself tonight of a place on a runoff ballot next month by showing consistent dominance over his major competitor for black votes and modest but significant strength among whites.

title: About Real Estate

title: Democratic Study Finds Beame Has the Best Chance In the Mayoral Primary
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  Mayor Beame has the best chance of any Democrat of winning this year's New York City primary mayoral election, according to a confidential staff study by the Democratic National Committee.

title: COUNCIL PROPOSES NEW ENERGY OFFICE

description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 15The New York Mets conceded today that other teams had been asking if they would trade their embattled star pitcher. Tom Seaver, and even conceded that they had been replying: What are you offering?

description: Margaret L. Stecker, a retired economist for the Social Security Administration, died Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 92 years old.

title: About French Food, Lore and Customs
description: The fragrant and earthy cooking of Nice and Provence is celebrated in this handsome and enticing cookbook, writ ten by a native of that region who now lives in the United States, In addition to dozens of tantalizing and very complete recipes, it is rich in the lore and customs of that colorful French province, and there is an espe cially fascinating description of the 13 desserts traditionally eaten in Provence on Christmas Eve. Careful descriptions of ingredients and recommended sub stitutes are included in this book, which is especially suitable for spring and summer.

title: McFadden Joins Stingers
description: CINCINNATI, March 15 (AP)The Cincinnati Stingers of the World Hockey Association today named Edgar McFadden as a club vice president. In joining the Stingers, McFadden will head all marketing functions, including promotions and ticket sales. McFadden has previously served as vice president for the Washington Capitals of the National Hockey League.

title: SNOW AND RAIN EASE DROUGHT IN MIDWEST
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  Driving rains and snowstorms have eased, but not ended, the critical drought in some areas of the Northern Plains and added substantial deposits of needed snow in Rocky Mountain regions, according to Government meteorologists.

description: LONDON, March 15 (Reuters)Three thousand strikers who are threatening the future of Britain's stateowned British Leyland Ltd. were told today that they must return to work next Monday or be dismissed.

title: Nobody Loves the F.D.A.
description: Nobody loves the Food and Drug Administration. The brouhaha over saccharin is only the latest such episode; the F.D.A. has been there before with vitamins, cyclamates, tainted cranberries, mercuryladen fish, oral contraceptives, and deceptive cancer cures. Once again it is caught in the crossfire between nervous consumers and powerful industries. It is charged, on the one hand, with admitting harmful additives into the American diet, and on the other, with colossal overregulation.

title: Panel on U.S. Indian Policy Urges Tribes Be Recognized as Sovereign
description: WASHINGTON, March 15A Congressional commission that reviewed the Government's policy toward American Indians will recommend that tribes be recognized as sovereign entities with the right to tax, maintain their own courts and control all resources on their own lands.

title: Peace in the Fields and Vineyards

The agreement not only settles jurisdic tional issues between the two unions; it ends one of the ugliest battles inside organized labor within recent mem ory, and it even does a little something for the tattered image of the teamsters union.

By ordering that public school teachers would have to have a degree in an academic discipline, not just a certificate from a teachers college, the state board of education sparked a feud between the teachers colleges and the liberal arts campuses. title: U.S. and Canada Sign Boeing Inquiry Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)The United States and Canada agreed today to trade information in the investiga tion of alleged payoffs by the Boeing Company in connection with sales of its planes in Canada. It was the first such agreement between the United States and another country involving Boeing. The agreement, signed at the Justice Department, commits law inforcement agencies of each country to exchange information gathered in the investiga tion and to.protect the confidentiality of material until it is used in court.

title: The Rise and Fall of Glenn Turner and His Financial Pyramid
description: IT WOULD BE impossible to write a book about the sales empire of Glenn Turner without invoking H. L. Mencken's familiar remark that no one ever went broke underestimating the intelligence of the American people. Mencken, Mr. Maxa says, would have loved Glenn Turner as one of those colorful rogues who enliven the American scene, a sort of cross between Elmer Gantry and Charles Ponzi, whose name is to financial pyramids what Tutankhamen's is to the original.

title: Blue Law Halt Weighed
description: The State Supreme Court reserved decision on a motion to stay a decision by Judge Sylvia B. Pressler of Superior Court overturning the state's Sunday closing law. Justice Morris Pashman re fused last week to grant the stay, pend ing a conference by the full sevenman court. A decision is expected today. The City of Hackensack and Menswear Retailers of New Jersey, codefendants in the case, had asked that the ruling be held in abeyance until they decided on any appeal.

title: Mauro Named Indiana Aide
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 15 (AP)  Harold Mauro, assistant football coach at Northwestern University the last four years, was named an assistant coach today at Indiana, his alma mater. Mauro, 31 years old, was a center for Indiana's Rose Bowl team of 1968. He will coach centers and guards for the Hoosiers.

title: F. T. C. Moves to Block Tenneco's Taking Over Monroe Auto Equipment
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (Reuters)The Federal Trade Commission today moved to block the $182.5 million ac quisition of the Monroe Auto Equipment Company of Tenneco Inc. on the ground it would cut competition in the market for shock absorbers and ex haust system parts. The agency voted to direct its staff to seek a preliminary injunction against the mer ger, approved in December by the companies, in Federal District court. It also issued a complaint alleging that the merger may violate provisions of the antitrust laws.

description: Parisians are rediscovering soup. In homes, in restaurants, even in the Elysees Palace, soups are gaining prominent place in gastronomic fashion.

title: Navy to Name F18 the Hornet
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)The Navy plans to name its new F18 fighter planes the Hornet. A Navy spokesman announcing the decision yesterday said that the name had been selected because the hornet strikes rapidly and produces a sharp sting.

title: House Panel Votes Limit on Authority In Reorganization
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)A showdown between the Carter Administration and an important House chairman was averted today when a subcommittee agreed to give the President authority to reorganize Government agencies but under strict Congressional review.

title: CASTRO IN ETHIOPIA AFTER SOMALIA VISIT
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 15The arrival in Ethiopia yesterday of President Fidel Castro of Cuba, coupled with new Ethiopian charges of Arab designs on the Red Sea, underscore the jockeying for influence that is intensifying along the horn of Africa.

title: Personal Health
description: A MIDDLEAGED New Yorker who noticed that his hearing was getting progressively worse purchased a hearing aid directly from a retailer. In the next few years, his hearing deteriorated still further. When he finally sought medical attention because he developed pain and discharge from his ear, he was found to have what had become an inoperable cancer affecting his ear.

title: CAREY WOULD LIMIT STRIKE INJUNCTIONS FOR PUBLIC WORKERS
description: ALBANY, March 15Governor Carey today proposed extensive revisions to the state's Taylor Law, urging a mixture of prolabor and promanagement measures that, if accepted by the Legislature, would considerably alter bargaining between public employers and employees.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT SHOWS A SHARP GAIN
description: Production of the nation's factories, mines and utilities snapped back late in February from a slump triggered by January's record cold, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday.

title: TV: The Making of a Hockey Killer
description: ONCE AGAIN, true to infuriating form, television has two outstanding dramatic productions running against each other. Tonight at 9, CBS has The Deadliest Season and PBS ends its fine Childhood series with An Only Child, based on a short story by Frank O'Connor. Each represents a significant artistic achievement for a medium that can use all the significance it can grab in any grven week.

title: Knit to Fit As Spring Slips In
description: ANYBODN here remember the spring coat? A neatly tailored thing was, often in navy blue gabardine, with a white pique collar and perhaps a flower on the lapel. Most had tiny waistlines, circled with black patent leather belts, though some seasons the coat turned with swashbuckling fullness so it could slide over that other concomitant soring the tailored suit.

title: Metropolitml Diary
description: LIFE IN THESE parts is frequently heartening, frequently distressing and always best ap proached with a sense of humor. Gertrude Fowles was at home when one of her neigh bors dropped in to tell about an elderly friend, laden with groceries, who was hesitating to cross Broad way near 84th Street when a passerby offered his help.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: DETROIT. March 15Newcar sales in early March climbed 19.2 percent and broke an 11yearold record, the four do mestic auto makers reported today.

title: To Restrain Arms Transfers
description: As the Carter Administration revises United States armssales policy, it will become evident that any unilateral, selfimposed restraints can be only part of the solution to the problem.

description: Antonino Rocca, a worldfamous barefooted wrestler who claimed the secret of life would enable him to live to 150 years of age, died last night at 49.

description: 1 recipe for pastry dough (see recipe)

title: Yenna Wanna Nyam Avec Moi?
description: Everyone knows that you are what you eat, and most of the time it shows. But where you come from and what your roots are doesn't always show. You just can't tell by looking.

description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Verdl's La Forza del Destine, 8.

title: The Indian Election at a Glance
description: THE ELECTIONAt stake are 540 of the 542 seats in the lower house of Parliament. Two candidates of the governing Congress Party have already been declared elected because they were unopposed. Each Member of Parliament represents about one million people. After the new house is elected, whichever party leader can command a majority of its votes will become the prime minister. The southern state of Kerala is also electing members of its state assembly this week.

title: A DISCOUNT AIR FARE TO COAST APPROVED
description: WASHINGTON, March 15The Civil Aeronautics Board approved today an American Airlines plan to offer supersaver fares between New York and the West Coast that will cost from 35 percent to 45 percent less than standard fares.

title: Ireland Industry Rise Cuts Need to Emigrate
description: GALWAY, IrelandThere is an un mistakable romance about the west of Ireland. In its place names: Gal way, Limerick, Tralee, Tipperary. In the sweet tenor of its voices. In its dry stone walls, which cut the fields into neat rectangles, eternally green no matter how dreary the winter skies.

title: Denver Residents Cut Water Use
description: DENVER, March 15 (UPI)Metropolitan area residents, apparently heeding advice to save water to help Colorado battle the effects of a drought, have ctit their average daily water consumption by', two gallons per day. The Denver Water Board said that its customers used nearly 48.9 million fewer gallons of water duting the first two weeks of March Ulanthey did in the same period a year ago. That represents a savings of 3.41 percent.

title: Grimshaw Out for Season
description: CHICAGO, March 15 (AP)Tony Grimshaw, a Chicago Sting midfielder recently acquired from Manchester United, broke his right leg in the first half of the Sting's opening exhibition soccer victory in Las Vegas Sunday and will be lost for the rest of the year.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST 56.000. Dace, mile.

description: Unaudited net assel values of closedend bond fund Oates, reported he the comnanies as of Friday. March 11. 1977. Also shown Is the closing listed market price or a dealertodealer asked Price of each fund's shares, with Percentage of difference.

title: Maple Leafs 4, Blues 1
description: ST. LOUIS, March 15 (AP)Secondperiod goals by Lanny McDonald and Jim Mckenny sparked the Toronto Maple Leafs to a 41 victory over the St. Louis Blues tonight.

title: James Pollack, 77; Was Former Leader In Baltimore Politics
description: BALTIMORE, March 15 (UPI)James H. Pollack, a wellknown Baltimore political leader for a half a century, died today of cancer at University Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Piccata Pun You Like and Don't Beef
description: Don't be alarmed. The puns in this article about some food peculiarities may make you hot and cross, but other things besides puns lie ahead. And after all, everyone doesn't like the hot cross bun either, but many of them say it is better than muffin.

title: Control Board Director Opposes Beame Deficit Plan as Unrealistic
description: The executive director of the New York State Emergency Financial Control Board has urged Governor Carey and other members of the board to reject what he considers unrealistic recent proposals by Mayor Beanie to close New York City's budget deficit next year.

title: Legion Disease Bacterium Isolated in Pennsylvania
description: HARRISBURG, March 15 (UPI)The Pennsylvania Health Department announced tonight that it had isolated bacterium as the cause of the legionnaires disease, affirming earlier findings by the National Center for Disease Control.

title: Bartender's Long Thirst Ends With a Heady Victory
description: At the Race Tracks Ralph Esposito, who grew up in Belmont Park when he wasn't working in the family saloon across the street, gained his first victory as a trainer on a New York track yesterday after more than 20 years of waiting. Esposito, a 46yearold parttime bartender, saddled Rip's Mick, a 3yearold gelding foaled in a backyard on Montauk, L.I., and owned by its breeder, Charles F. Kenny.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Thousands of pet owners have already discovered a registry called IdentAPet but for the other thousands who haven't it's something be considered. The system is based on an individual number for each pet. which is dermaprinted on the animal's inner flank. The process is painless and provides a permanent method of identification. The number is then fed into the company's computer with the owner's name address and tele phone number. A tollfree telephone number is provided so that if anyone finds the animal after it has been lost or stolen, the owner can be immediate ly found and identified. To date, apparently, the system has a 99 percent rate of recovery. The charge for the process is $20. Some of the dealers where the service can be obtained are the Animal Medical Center and the New York School of Dog Grooming in New York, Animal Hospital of Brooklyn, Riverdale Grooming in the Bronx, Pretty Paws Salon in Queens the Animal Gallery, Yonkers, and Norma Kubrin in White Plains. The Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and many veterinarians are also members of the system, which is nationwide.

title: Police Show Seen Fading As TV Plot
description: AS WITH WESTERNS and other program genres of the past that saturated primetime television for several years and then were seen no more, the lawandJorder shows that have dominated network schedules for most of the 1970's are rapidly thinning in number and many programmers believe these shows are on their way out.

title: Jets to Play First 2 Home Games In Jersey and the 5 Others at Shea
description: The Jets decided yesterday to play their first two home games this season at the Giants Stadium in New Jersey and then return to Shea Stadium for their remaining five.

title: Bridge:
description: Thanks to some efficient organization by the American Contract Bridge League, bridgeplayers now make very substantial contributions to charity. Grants by the league's Charity Foundation in 1976 totaled $250,000, half of which went to the Arthritis Foundation.

title: Books of The Times
description: NO, DESPITE THE SOUND of its title and the look of its prose, Richard Dawkins's The Selfish Gene is not another book about how human behavior is governed by man's evolutionary origins. It only seems so at first because, for one thing, Mr. Dawkins is an ethologisthe teaches animal behavior at Oxfordand the ethologists have done a lot of extrapolating from animal to human behavior in the last decade or so. For another thing, Mr. Dawkins looks as if he is writing about people because for economy's sake he must write about blind phenomenathat is, the way genes survive by producing animal bodies that will behave to the genes advantage as if they were controlled by subjective human will.

title: At Your Service: Caning Your Furniture
description: CAN you give me a quick diagnosis? asked the woman. She was carrying three cane seats that were not in the best of health. A second woman arrived carrying a caneseated Chippendale chair. A third wanted to know about a cane headboard: Which.weive was stronger, the basketweave or the octagonal?

title: Some Officials and Civic Leaders Seek Reversal of Annenberg's Decision on Fine Arts Center
description: While Walter H. Annenberg remained adamant in his decision to cancel his $40million pledge for the Fine Arts Center at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, an effort has begun by city officials and civic leaders to persuade him to change his mind.

title: OfftheRack Furniture for the PutTogether Generation
description: IN A HURRY to own a pillowpadded chair, a status steel and glass table or a walltowall, canesided sofa? Well, waiting for such furniture is now a thing of the past for those willing to wield a wrench and put together a chair, table or room full of furniture on their own, at home.

title: BLUMENTHAL SEES NO USE IN STOCK BILL TO IDENTIFY OWNERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Administration dealt a severe blow today to a measure that would require those who obtain relatively small blocks of a company's stock to disclose their identities.

title: Vietnam Hints at Lucrative Trade for American Business
description: HONG KONG, March 16Vietnam has begun distributing to American businessmen copies of surprisingly liberal new guidelines for foreign investment, setting off hopes among some that there could be a major market for American enterprise if President Carter removes the embargo on United States trade with Hanoi.

title: Atlanta Election Figures Viewed Favorable to White in Runoff
description: ATLANTA, March 16Black leaders and white liberals who hope to see the Fifth District Congressional seat vacated by Andrew Young continue to be occupied by a black drew meager encouragement today from analysis 'f yesterday's balloting.

title: Nets Box Score
description: NETS(86)

title: Connecticut Starts Numbers Game, Expecting $50 Million Bets in Year
description: HARTFORD, March 16Connecticut's legal numbers game went into operation today, with expectations by state authorities that they may take in $50 million or more in bets in the first year.

title: Cleveland Municipal Power Losing Out to Private Utility
description: CLEVELAND, March 16  Publicly owned electric power seems on its last legs here. Cleveland's municipal electric power systema mere shell of its former self but still the provider of electricity to onefifth of the city's people is losing out to the investorowned Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company.

title: A Bit of Old Ireland to Dance Your jig Upon
description: It would be nice to stand upon a piece of the old sod on this Saint Patrick's Day. Failing that, though, how about an Irish Macroom rug from County Cork?

title: Leyland Workers Set To Meet on Strike
description: LONDON, March 16British Leyland said today in a statement that it had agreed with the executive of the Engineers Union to meet representatives of the striking toolmen and withdraw the threat of dismissal providing there was a return to work on Monday. March 11.

title: French Trade Deficit Eases
description: PARIS, March 16 (UPI)France's trade deficit narrowed to $300 million in February from $480 million in January, the Foreign Trade Ministry said today. Seasonally adjusted, imports totaled 5.4 billion and exports were worth $5.1 billion, the Trade Ministry said. The smaller deficit was attributed to a decline of oil imports to $1 billion from $1.16 billion in January, according to the Ministry.

title: Howatt Paces Attack With 3 Goals
description: CHICAGO, March 16The struggling Black Hawks tried to stem a sevengame losing streak tonight by calling up five rookies for their game against the Islanders. All it got them was their eighth straight loss, a shutout by the Islanders goalie, Bill Smith, and five goals scored against them, each coming with one of the rookies on the ice.

title: U S. Mission to Hanoi Begins Talks on the Fate of Missing American Servicemen. After a Warm Welcome
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Thursday, March 17 (UPI)Americans and Vietnamese sitting under a large portrait of Ho Chi Minh began talks today aimed at determining the fale of Americans missing since the Vietnam war.

title: Guests Flee Hotel Fire
description: ROSEMONT III., March 16 (UPI)A fouralarm fire in the eightstory SheratonO'Hare Hotel forced 35 to 50 guests on the top two floors to climb through windows and down aerial ladders to safety early today. Five persons ??? reported to have suffered from smoke inhalation.

title: CHARLES LEE ANDREWS
description: NEWPORT, R.I., March 16Rear Adm. Charles Lee Andrews, retired, a veteran of two world wars, died at his home, Landfall, here last night. He was 80 years old.

title: Senate Speechmakers and CouponClippers
description: If their mail is anything like ours, members of the Senate must know that the recent $12,900 Congressional pay raise is still bard for many citizens to swallow. How, then, can the Senate seriously consideras it will begin doing todaya proposal that must make every member look as though he is trying to cash in even more on his official position?

title: Notes on People
description: ONLY hours after arriving in St. Anthony, Newfoundland, to join a fastgrowing small army of animallovers and conservationists gathering to protest the annual slaughter of baby seals, Brigitte Bardot abruptly flew back to Paris. She proclaimed she was disgusted with the circus atmosphere and indicated unhappiness over the way some protesters were unmindful that many local residents depend on the taking of sealskins for a living. Before leaving, she chatted with some hunters who take part in the hunt on the Arctic ice pack.

title: CLUB OF 10 DEFENDS SOUTH AFRICAN VIEW
description: LONDON, March 16A small group of wealthy South African businessmen is turning to fullpage advertisements in leading Western newspapers to combat criticism of the country and expose what it sees as growing Soviet influence in Africa.

title: Latest in Crafts At 2 New Shows
description: What do you do with a gnarledlooking buffet supported on strange animal feet? Or a table with a macrame top? Over what kind of window do you put a translucent porcelain panel? Where do you hang a weaving that is part fiber and part acrylic?

title: For F.B.I. Men, New York Tops Least Wanted List
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Somewhere out there among the 7,000 or so agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who are working west of the Hudson and south of Perth Amboy, there are, by actual count, four who have expressed a desire to work in New York City.

title: New and Old New Face
description: Leonard Sillman, who produced 13 editions of the revue New Faces between 1934 and 1968, is giving what he brazenly describes as a testimonial to himself in the form of a retrospective sampling of songs from six of his shows at the Ballroom, 458 West Broadway.

title: About New York
description: As the great antipoverty program of the 1960's lay dying, the city's Irish finally got their first piece of it a few months ago. They have just onened three storefront operations and are gradually coaxing the old IrishAmericans left behind in the city to drop in for some conversation and even a bit of help.

title: Explosion Follows Derailment
description: WENDEN, Ariz., March 16 (AP)Eight propane tank cars exploded today after a Santa Fe freight train left the tracks near this desert community 80 miles west of Phoenix, the authorities said. No one was injured as three locomotives and 20 cars of the PhoenixtoLos Angeles train derailed shortly before 7 A.M.

title: H. G. Parks, Sausage Makers, In Sale Agreement With Norin
description: Henry G. Parks, founder and chairman of the board of H. G. Parks Inc. of Baltimore, well known for its radio and television commercial, More Parks sausages, Mom, signed an agreement yesterday to sell the organization to the Norin Corporation.

title: Cemetery Guarded After Funeral
description: VIENNA. March 16 Czechoslovak plaincclothesmen were Ivere reported to have remained on guard at the cemetery after Professor Patocka's funeral.

title: SENATE UNIT REVIVES CARTER PLAN TO SPUR BUSINESS INVESTMENT
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Senate Finance Committee today restored the enlarged business investment credit in President Carter's economic stimulus program after it was knocked out of the proposed legislation that passed the House last week.

title: Moslem Leader In Lebanon Slain, Imperiling Peace
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 16Kamal Jumblat, the Druse chieftain who led the alliance of leftists and Moslems in the Lebanese civil war, was assassinated today on a mountain road near here.

title: Export Prospects Push Up Soybean And Grain Futures
description: Soybean futures soared yesterday as some contracts advanced 27 cents a bushel, just short of the allowable limit for one session, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Carter Opens First Meet the People Tour
description: CLINTON, Mass., March 16On his first meet the people tour, President Carter told a sea of friendly faces here tonight that he wanted to build an Administration that would respond to the ordinary moods of ordinary citizens.

title: Czech Dissident Buried Under Police Restrictions
description: PRAGUE. March 16 (Reuters)lan Patceka the Czechoslovak campaigner for human riphts was buried here today in rites attended by a thousand mourners and a hundred plainclothes policemen.
