title: Cecil WoodhamSmith, Dead, at 80, British Biographer and Historian
description: Cecil WoodhamSmith, a onetime English literary dilettante who parlayed a chance dinnertable conversation into an acclaimed career as a biographer and historian, died on Wednesday at her home in London. She was 80 years old and had been at work on the second volume of a biography of Queen Victoria.

title: Vance Is Expected to Sound Out Soviet on Key Cuts in Strategic Arms
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will go to Moscow late this month prepared to sound out the Kremlin on significant reductions in the Soviet and American strategic arsenals in an attempt to speed arms negotiations, according to authoritative sources.

title: Neurosurgeon's Testimony Backs Mrs. Chesimard
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, March 16  A neurological surgeon, appearing as an expert witness for the defense, testified today that Joanne Chesimard had to have had both hands raised over her head when she was wounded by a state trooper in a shootout on the New Jersey Turnpike on May 2, 1973.

title: Steinbrenner, Paul Going to Cuba
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 16 Although the prospect of a major league team's visit to Havana this spring is dead, baseball relations between the United States and Cuba remained a live topic of debate today.75052278Democrat from West Islip. L.I., asked his fellow Congressmen to join in sending a letter to Bowie Kuhn criticizing the commissioner for having refused to let the Yankees play in Cuba and urging him to reconsider his decision. However, Kuhn said he didn't see any reason for changing his position.

title: Events Today
description: ROMEO AND JULIET, by william Shakesreare; directed by Theodore Mann; starring Paul Rudd and Pamela Playton Wright; presented by Circle In the Square, 50th Street west of Broadway, 6:45.

title: Fashion Goes on Gold Standard
description: The gold rush is on in fashion. The first highly visible sign was the tote bag by Fiorucci that turned up on the arms of Europeans last fall to lend glitter to their blue jean or Rykiel outfits. Often they matched gold cowboy boots.

title: Taxi Fares to Rise 15% on Wednesday; Reforms Promised
description: Tai fares will rise by about 15 percent at 12:01 A.M. Wednesday in New York City as the result of a 4to2 vote yesterday by the City Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Carter Speech at U.N. To Be on TV, Radio
description: President Carter's address tonight, before the United Nations will be telecast live by the three networks and their local stationsChannels 2, 4 and 7starting at 7:30 P.M. On radio, WCBSAM, WINS, WMCA and WNYC AM will provide live coverage.

title: Kenya and Tanzania End Talks
description: KISUMU, Kenya, March 16 (Reuters)Kenyan and Tanzanian officials today ended two days of talks here, with a Tanzanian delegate saying that the meeting was not fully successful in resolving a crisis in relations. Tanzania closed its border with Kenya six weeks ago after the collapse or East African Airways.

title: DublinBorn Jersey Jew to Lead 100 Elderly on Tour of Ireland
description: RIVER EDGE, March 16Manny Steen, who is Jewish, will lead a tour of Ireland May 9 to 24 by 100 persons from this Bergen County borough.

description: PARIS, March 16A British financier today bought into France's leading news magazine, L'Express, for complex financial and political reasons.

title: Investigative Series on Arizona Crime Posing Newspaper Problems
description: After six months of intensive investigation, a highly unusual effort in American journalism involving a team of reporters from competing newspapers has come to a close. The results have been appearing in Newspapers around the country since Sunday.

title: House Backs Pennsylvania Avenue Restoration Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 16A 16yearold proposal to restore Pennsylvania Avenue as a grand, ceremonial corridor was finally given a cautious start today by the House of Representatives.

title: Court Rules F.C. C. Cannot Ban Indecency on Radio
description: WASHINGTON March 16 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that the Federal Communications Commission could not ban indecent language on radio and television, even at certain times of the day to protect children.

description: ATLANTIC CONVEYOR (ACL). Helsinki March 31 and. Leningrad April 3; sails from Pt. Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Archeologists Told of Evidence That Puts Man in America at Least 40,000 Years Ago
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 16Powerful new evidence that early man was in the New World at least 40,000 years agomore than twice the generally accepted ago of man's entry into North Americawas reported today at an archeology conference here.

title: Can't I Take You Home Again, Kathleen?
description: CARMEL, N.Y.  Irish aren't ethnic any more. Study after study tells us that IrishAmericans are now mainstream, socially accepted, and the secondhighestwageearning nationality in this country. The wings of the WASP have carefully unfolded to shelter the IrishAmerican.

title: Pop: SoldOut Eagles
description: THE EAGLES Hotel California, which is rising to the top of the popular music charts as rapidly as most of the band's singles and albums have have risen, begins promisingly. Driving at night on a desert highway, the protagonist is overcome by fatigue and stops at a hotel. There he meets a mysterious woman, hears voices in the night, and finds that he is in a kind of waking nightmare; nothing is what it seems to be. The climactic scene, which leaves the singer scrambling for the door, comes at the end of a series of clever but ominous verses.

title: Rights Group Asks Chile for Accounting of 1,500 Said to Have Vanished
description: Amnesty International asked Chile yesterday for an accounting of what the organization described as the disappearance of 1,500 political prisoners.

title: A Tully Party Chez Alice
description: THEY GAVE A PARTY for Alice Tully in her own house on Tuesday night, and it turned out to be one of the nicest bashes of the music season. The house, of course, was Alice Tully Hall, which Miss Tully helped bring into existence, and the event was a concert called A Musical Garland for Alice Tully, a benefit for one of her fondest projects, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

title: People and Business
description: Edward I. O'Brien, president of the Securities Industry Association, yesterday raised the specter of the development of what he called a Eurostock marketan unregulated market outside the United,States that would deal in shares of American companiesif certain provisions of securities legislation are enacted.

title: Roots Author Sues Doubleday For $5 Million Over Promotion
description: LOS ANGELES, March 16 (AP)Alex Haley, the author of Roots', filed $5 million damage suit today against Doubleday Company, charging that the publisher had not promoted the book.

title: Where's Kelly? Out Making Sure Ski Resort Celebrates in Style
description: Confronted with the possibility of not having St. Patrick's Day weekend observed in what he considers fitting fashion at his Brodie Mountain resort, Jim Kelly, the owner, went to the shovel himself yesterday. Kelly is the News of Skiing energetic ??snman Who anNews nually observes the high holiday at his Berkshire Mountains ski area with all the trimmings.

title: OTTAWA ACTS TO TIGHTEN MERGERCARTEL CONTROL
description: OTTAWA, March 16The Canadian Government introduced legislation in Parlament today designed to expand existing regulatory powers over business mereers and cartels.

title: Variable Bonds Session Focuses On Northwestern Bell Offering
description: The credit markets jockeyed about yesterday, testing some new interest rate levels here and rejecting other yield levels there as prices in the secondary market showed little change. In the major corporate financing of the day, the Northwestern Bentelephone Company sold $130 million of 40year debentures that were priced to yield 8.20 percent, and underwriters reported that the offering was twothirds sold at the end of the afternoon.

title: To Give Is Blest, To Save, Divine
description: IT has become the custom for person to say, upon receiving a present, Oh, but you shouldn't have. Do not believe this. People should give presents, and, do not give enough of them, or give them often enough.

title: Even Castles in the Sky Fail to Fulfill Buffalo's Campus Dream
description: AMHERST, N.Y.Eight miles northeast of downtown Bluffalo, the jigsawed silhouette above the open flatland suggests from a distance a walled medieval city, with a halfdozen 10story castles like giant chess pieces on the skyline.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: A BIT OF THE IRISH: John. McLees, a retired bartender, serving beyr yesterday at a St. Patrick's Day party at the Hebrew Hospital for Chronic Sick in the Bronx. Mr. McLees is a patient at the hospital.

title: House Votes to Bar Funds to Carry Out Carter Pardon Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)The House voted today to amend a new appropriations bill so that the use of funds to carry out President Carter's plan for pardoning draft evaders of the Vietnam period would be barred.

title: U S. Mission to Hanoi Begins Talks on the Fate of Missing American Servicemen. After a Warm Welcome
description: HANOI, Vietnam, Thursday, March 17 (UPI)Americans and Vietnamese sitting under a large portrait of Ho Chi Minh began talks today aimed at determining the fale of Americans missing since the Vietnam war.

title: Charge Lifted Against Principals Barring Ethnic Data
description: New York City school authorities are dropping charges against 67 principals who refused to provide ethnic data about their school staffs despite warnings that the refusal could lead to the loss of millions of dollars in state aid.

title: Melanie and Michael Zwerling's ultimate kitchen
description: The Brooklyn kitchen of Melanie and Michael Zwerling is on a twoyear timetable. We designed the ultimate kitchen. said Mrs. Zwerling (above), and we're executing it in stages. In stage one they installed the tile floor, plumbing, electricity and the basic appliances. Mr. Zwerling, a home furnishings executive with Abraham & Straus, installed the dishwasher in a temporary island he built from plans In Instant Furniture. In stage two an island designed by architect Hal Einhom will have builtin storage and a counter top combining marble and butcher block.

title: Air Force Again Rejects Appeals To FlightTest LowCost Fighter
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)  The Air Force continued today to reject efforts of a Florida aircraft designer to win operational flighttesting of a lowcost fighter bomber designed to support ground troops in combat.

description: Horses listed In order of Post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: DeMarco Used Dirty Needles, Patients Testify
description: NEWARK, March 17In secret testimony given on Monday but released today, two patients of Dr. Peter T. DeMarco said he had given them injections of procaine polyvinylpyrrolidine with needles contaminated from use on other patients.

title: Between Mint Jelly and Imitation Emeralds
description: IF WE ARE to believe that fountain of fancy, Brewer's Dictionary of Phrase and Fable, there are in all 106 different shades of green.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: Manville's highest ranking administrative official and one of its Councilmen have been charged with bribery, fraud, extortion and obstruction of justice by the Somerset County grand jury sitting in Somerville. Francis A. Peltack, Manville's administrator and Borough Clerk, and Councilman Stanley A. Mleczko, the Police Commissioner, have become the latest and most prominent figures to be charged in a continuing county investigation of municipal corruption in the small industrial community. According to the grand jury's report, Mr. Peltack and Mr. Mleczko had for the last five years operated a kickback scheme that netted them a 10 percent payoff on many contracts awarded to companies that did business with Manville.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horses listed in order of post Positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: For Your Cabinet. Here's an Eyeful Of Tricky Dishes
description: Fill out your blue and white willow ware collection with a trompe l'oeil painting from Karl Mann Associates, 232 East 59th Street.

title: BPIEWSTER EXPECTED TO GET LONDON POST
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The White House is planning to name Kingman Brewster Jr., president of Yale University, Ambassador to Britain, according to reliable sources.

title: Labor Mounting Strong Campaign to Unionize South
description: ATLANTA. March 16After decades of sporadic activity and indifferent success in the South, organized labor is in the midst of the most diverse and powerful drive in its history to stamp the union label on the region's rapidly swelling and still largely unorganized work force.

title: Mets Box Score
description: METS (N.)

title: U: S. MID BONN GAINING ON TANK COMPONENTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 16West Germany's Defense Minister, Georg Leber, said tonight that he had reached tentative agreement with the Carter Administration on standardizing four major cornponents of the main battle tanks that are to be produced by the two countries.

title: Zaire at a Glance
description: POPULATIONNearly all of Zaire's roughly 25 million people are blacks with perhaps a few thousand whites, mainly Belgians, who live principally in Kinshasa, the eapit'al, and the other large cities. The blacks are divided among four..main ethnic groups in more than 200 tribes. French is the official language, but Swahili, Lingala, Tshiluba and Kikongo are widely spoken. There are about 9 million Christians, predominantly Roman Catholics.

title: Hers
description: MY FRIEND Pamela confesses she is no longer big on freedom of expression. In fact, when a man in her life recently mentioned, in a dismayed tone, that some misguided judge in Ohio had thrown a man in jail for seven to 25 years, just for publishing a girlie magazine, Pamela smiled one of her most delightful smiles and said softly, Oh, that's wonderful.

title: ROLAND PALMEDO DIES; A PROMOTER OF SKIING
description: Roland Palmedo, one of the early promoters of recreational skiing in the United States, died Tuesday at his sister's home in Williamstown, Mass. He was 81 years old and lived in Princeton, N.J.

title: Secrecy As Usual?
description: BOSTON, March 164s a candidate, Jimmy Carter attacked secrecy in government. As President, he will find it a bureaucratic habit hard to change. Consider, for example, what might be called an endless postscript to the story of the Pentagon Papers.

title: Moscow's Expert on U.S. Asserts Rights Issue May Cloud Arms Talk
description: LONDON, March 16The Soviet Government's top expert on the United States said today that the Carter Administration had overstepped the limits of dtente in supporting Soviet dissidents. Doing so, he said, could impede the next phase of the talks on limitation of strategic arms.

title: Rate of Heart Attacks for Men Found to Drop as Altitude Rises
description: Men living high in the mountains in New Mexico are less likely to die from heart attacks than men who reside closer to sea level, according to results of study being published in a medical journal today.

title: Hijacker Is Seized After 10,000 Miles By Police in Zurich
description: ZURICH, March 16 (UPI)Two policemen disguised as airline pilots today overpowered an armed Italian mechanic to end the world's longest hijacking10,000 miles over two continents.

title: Motorman in Loop Crash Broke Rules,Official Says
description: CHICAGO, March 16The general manager of the Chicago Transit Authority said today that a violation of rules by a 34yearold subway motorman caused the elevated train cras' in Chicago's downtown Loop that killed 11 people and injured 189 others on Feb. 4.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTON  Economists at the Agriculture Department have taken a look at the possible effects of the severely cold and dry winter just ending and come up with these reassuring words.

title: Frazier's Son Wine
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 16 (AP)Marvis Frazier, 16yearold son of Joe Frazier, stopped his opponent in the second round of the state Golden Gloves heavyweight semifinals tonight.

title: Carter Sends Apology to Makarios Over Report on Payments by C.I.A.
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 16 (Reuters)President Carter has apologized to Archbishop Makarios over allegations in the United States press that the Cypriot President had received clandestine Central Intelligence Agency funds, the Information Department here said today.

title: Whitney Show to Depict TurnofCentury U.S.
description: Turnofthecentury America, as seen in paintings, photographs, cartoons, posters, and newspaper and magazine illustrations, is the theme of the Whitney Museum's major summer exhibition, opening June 29. The turbulent findesiecle period, marked by social change and expansion, will be chronicled by some 240 works in a variety of media, by such artists as John Singer Sargent, Thomas Eakins, Mary Cassatt, Winslow Homer, Alfred Stieglitz, Lewis Hine, Jacob Riis, A. B. Frost, Charles Dana Gibson, Howard Pyle and Jessie Wilcox Smith.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The New York Times/Carl T. Gossett MOVING, THE HARD WAY: A onestory brick house was moved yesterday from Williamsbridge Road and Rhinelander Avenue in the Bronx to Pelham Parkway and Tomlinson Avenue, four blocks away. The owner explained that moving his old house would cost hlin less than building a new one.

title: Albany Houses Are Still About a Half Billion Apart With Only 15 Days Left to Pass the State's Budget
description: ALBANY, March 16With only 15 days left for the Legislature to pass next year's budget, the Assembly and the Senate remain far apartabout a half a billion dollars apart in fact.

title: N.C.A.A. Basketball
description: V.M.I. (263) vs. Kentucky (253). Notre Dame (216) vs. North Carolina (254).

title: Lynn Redgrave's New Job It Beats Being in Hellzapoppin
description: IT WOULD BE difficult to picture Barbara Walters playing Lady Macbeth, and it is, similarly, not all that easy to picture Lynn Redgravewho is more accustomed to playing Shakespeare or Shawas a television talk show host. But, at 34, the highly acclaimed film and stage actress who won an Academy Award nomination for Georgy Girl and, more recently, a Tony nomination for Mrs. Warren's Profession, has taken on a new roleas moderator, with Frank Field, of the syndicated Not for Women Only series, seen here daily at 9 A.M. on Channel 4.

title: Slaying of Jumblat Spurs Hard Liners In Palestinian Talk
description: CAIRO, March 16Palestinian leaders, already under pressure from hardliners within their ranks to adopt a tougher position, were spurred to further militancy tonight by the news of the assassination of Kamal lumblat, their foremost Lebanese friend and ally.

title: First Black Newspaper Recalled At 150th Anniversary Ceremonies
description: The first black newspaper to be published in the United States, Freeman's Journal, came off the presses in a building at 5 Varick Street in Manhattan, on March 16, 1827, denouncing slavery and urging New York's free blacks to seek education and practice thrift and industry.

title: News Summary
description: Forces invading Zaire from Angola have been engaged in conflict along routes to the copper mines that are vital to the country's economy, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance told the House International Relations Committee. Mr. Vance said the invaders were believed to be primarily returning members of the former Katanga gendarmerie who fled to Angola a decade ago. He also disclosed that the United States had had its first direct contact with Cuba on opening diplomatic talks. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Reports of Area Skiing Conditions
description: Cortina Valley8to40inch base; variable surface conditions; good spring skiing, limited.

title: Judge Issues Directive on Systerrre TO Be Used to Pay Noteholders
description: In a simple sixpage directive that marks a symbolic turning point in New York City's fiscal crisis, Justice James Gibson of State Supreme Court put into motion yesterday the procedure by which thousands of owners of shortterm city notes can be repaid in the weeks ahead.

title: Open Admissions Ruinous? Let's Look at the Class of 11
description: City College is still reeling from the disastrous effects of the City University crisis. Moreover, the community at large, beset by more than its share of ills, is easy prey to any eloquent preacher of negativism. It is therefore hardly surprising that selffulfilling prophesies of doom aimed at the College have been receiving, more than their share of attention in the news media nowadays.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor I am glad to see Drew Middleton address the important issue of Unionization of the Armed Forces [military analysis, March 4]. Since our armed forces eventually reflect the characteristics of our society as a whole, unionization will require an increasing amount of our attention in the future.

title: Hopes for Expansion of Economy Lift Dow by 2.99 to a 968 Close
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday to round out the first string of five straight advancing sessions in 1977. Hopes for a resumption of economic expansion this spring have provided much of the impetus for the market's recent climb.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation disclosed yesterday that net loan chargeoffs on its $9.2 billion portfolio of international loans amounted to $1.1 million last year. Furthermore, in its 1976 annual report, it said that these chargeoffs averaged under $1 million a year over the last five years.

title: Pirates, A's Swap 9 Players; Garner and Medich Key Men
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 16 (AP)Phil Garner, who has been seeking the financial status several of his former Oakland A's teammates reached last fall as free agents, was sent to the Pittsburgh Pirates today in a nineplayer trade.

title: Virginia Woolf's 'Unforgettable Document'
description: THE VICTORIANS have had their revenge on Bloomsbury, after all. The latter may have succeeded for a time in discrediting the piously researched doubledecker biography upon which the Victorians lavished so much talent, energy and laborthe kind of literary enterprise that Lytton Strachey mockingly dismissed as funereal in his preface to Eminent Victorians, the book that created a taste for something pithier, irreverent and more amusing.

title: 18 Indicted on U.S. Heroin Counts, Among Them a Reputed Top Dealer
description: Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, described as one of the top heroin dealers in New York City, was arrested and charged yesterday with heading a narcotics organization that reaped profits of tens of thousands of dollars a day.

title: Options Seen on U.S.Soviet Arms
description: WASHINGTON, March 16William E. Colby, the former Director of Central Intelligence, told a Senate panel today that the influence of the Soviet Union and the United States on each other's military programs was more significant than the question of superiority.

title: Market Place
description: Shares of the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company fell hard in light trading yesterday after William Wrigley, president, predicted at the company's annual meeting that net income might be off as much as 30 percent in the quarter ending March 31.

title: Meany Sees Police Brutality
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O.. said today that Professor Patocka's death can he categorized only as barbarous and malevolent police brutality at the direction of the Sovietdominated government leadership. He made the statement in a cablegram of condolences to the Patocka family.

title: Gunman on Coast Holds 2 Hostage, Frees Baby After Firing at Police
description: SOUTH SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 (AP)A robbery suspect holed up in an apartment here released one of three hostages, a 18monthold baby boy, to the police late today, but continued to hold a wounded man and his wife.

title: Underworld Figure Refuses to Talk Before a House Assassination Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI)Santo Trafficante Jr., once the overlord of syndicate gambling in Cuba, risked a contempt citation today by refusing to answer any questions from a House cornmittee about the assassination of President Kennedy or plots to kill Premier Fidel Castro ofCuba.

title: For F.B.I. Agents, New York Heads Least Wanted List
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Somewhere out there among the 7,000 or so agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who are working west of the Hudson and south of Perth Amboy, there are, by actual count, four who have expressed a desire to work in New York City.

title: Personal Beauty
description: THE HOUSE cleaning is done and the waxy buildup is off the kitchen floor. But what about the gray look on one's face that's been building up over a long winter? Cleanliness may not equal anything as soullifting as godliness, but it's the indispensable first step to looking one's best. The beauty rites of spring begin with thorough cleansing. But how? Creams, lotions, scrubs, soap?

title: Flyers in 44 Draw on Esposito Tally
description: Playing before a surprisingly supportive Madison Square Garden crowd, the New York Rangers began modest atonement for their lost weekend by tying the Philadelphia Flyers last night, 44. It was the fourth time the teams had tied in five meetings this season, and on this occasion Phil Esposito performed the deed, touching in a shot by Ron Greschner at 5 minutes 57 seconds of the final period.

title: 3 Held on Marijuana
description: SOUTH RIVER, N. J., March 16 (UPI)Three men were arrested Tuesday night by the state police and Federal drug agents when they allegedly tried to sell 700 pounds of marijuana to undercover officers in a trucking firm's parking lot, the state police reported. They identified the suspects as Charles W. Katko, 46, of 494 Metlars Lane, Piscataway, N. J.; Anthony J. Cullari, 41, of 8 Mashalle Place, Middlesex, N. J., and Joseph Mino, 55, of Fort Lee, N. J.

title: Sections of Bill to Change Courts Given Second Passage in Albany
description: ALBANY, March 18The Republicancontrolled State Senate today gave second passage to two sections of a constitutional amendment aimed at changing the state's court system. But, it was forced to withdraw the vote on a third partthat dealing with the appointment, rather than election, of judges to the Court of Appealswhen it appeared to be headed for defeat.

title: The Great Party? Psychology Helps
description: SO, YOU'RE having a party. You've dusted, vacuumed and polished until the place could pass a Marine Corns inspection; invited lots of interesting people with widaly different interests, backgrounds and personalities; moved additional armchairs into the party area so that everyone will have a comfortable seat, and displayed lots of good food and drink in a central location. In short, you've; done everything to ensure a successful party, right? Maybe. Or ???ybe you've just set the stage for a social disaster. At least that's what a number of behavioral scientists might say.

title: Where to Find It
description: The ZOOM chair, disassembled, goes home by subway. The bantamweight wonder (it tips the scale at just under 11 pounds) one of the new KD pieces that have just arrived in town, comes packed in a box measuring 30 inches by 26 inches by 8 inches deep, a carton that has a cutout into which you slide one hand to carry it out of the store.

title: Stevens, Capital Booster
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Roger L. Stevens, chairman of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, told newsmen yesterday New York was a very sick place to take plays and if there can be a national theater, I think it can be in Washington.

title: VANCE SAYS INVADERS IN ZAIRE THREATENI VITAL COPPER MINING
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Secretary of State Cyrus FL Vance, defending the emergency airlift of American supplies to Zaire, said today that the invading forces from Angola had produced a dangerous situation for Zaire's critically important copper industry.

title: AGENCY STUDY WARNS OF 1985 OIL SHORTAGE
description: PARIS, March 16 (Reuters)Studies by the International Energy Agency show there could be a world oil shortage of up to 14 million barrels a day by 1985, Detlev Rohwedder, chairman of the agency, said today.

title: Dig He Must, and a 1600's Coin Turns Up at Bowling Green
description: A Spanish coin of the early 1600's, green from centuries of burial, has been dug out of the Bowling Green park by a young man who, when not working as assistant curator of manuscripts at the NewYork Historical Society, seeks out construction sites in quest of traces of old New York.

title: Using the Sun to Bring Heating Costs Down to Earth
description: The Robert Mocarskys had a double motive for building themselves a solarheated house outside of Hartford. One was the eventual saving in fuel, the other was to use the house as a guihea pig for future projects.

title: In a Typical Village in North India, Electionls a Very, Special Occasion
description: GARHIBOHAR, India, March 16 Sumar Singh, one of the whitehaired elders of this little wheatgrowing village 40 miles west of New Delhi, folded his ballot paper, slid it into the slot of a locked brown metal box and murmured, with selfsatisfied smile: There, I have voted.

title: A.T.&T. Again Has $1 Billion Net
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest utility, reported yesterday that it had earned $1 billion in its latest quarter, the third successive time that it had done so.

title: Dividends
description: Pe Stk. of pay rlod Rats record able

title: New Rochelle Puts ExJudges on Panel For Police Inquiry
description: Three former Westchester County judges agreed yesterday to investigate charges that the New Rochelle police failed 19 months ago to look into a murder threat by Frederick W. Cowan, the Nazi cultist who shot five persons to death, including a police officer, and then killed himself in New Rochelle last month.

title: Those Chairs? Asks White House
description: When Americans watched the TV replay of Ask President Carter last week, their eyes were riveted on the President and Walter Cronkite of CBS Newsand on the apricotcolored wing chairs the two sat in.

title: Soviet to Sell Gold To Finance Trading
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)The Soviet Union is expected to sell about 600 tons of gold on European gold markets in 1977 and 1978, in part to finance its trade deficit with the West, according to the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: CairipaignLiterature Case Brings Federal Court to a PATH Terminal
description: JERSEY CITY, March 16Homewardbound commuters were treated during the rushhour this evening to the unusual sight of the United States District Court convening on the main concourse of the PATH station in Journal Square.

title: Katanga Forces Have Operated Under 3 Flags
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Xatangan gendarmes, identified by Secretary of State Cyrus R, Vance as the main element of the troops allegedly invading Zaire, have been a controversial and often a shadowy force that has fought under three flags in 16 years.

title: St. Patrick's Day Parade Expected to Draw 127,000 In March Up Fifth Avenue
description: An estimated 127,000 people who want to be Irish for at least a day are scheduled to march in New York City's St. Patrick's Day Parade today, with 193 bands and 240 organizations starting up Fifth Avenue at noon from 44th Street.

title: Inside Designer's Own Closets
description: Wouldn't it be nice to get up in the morning and find one's clothes perfectly arranged in beautifully planned and organized closets?

title: Agencies Ask Law to Curb Research on GeneSplicing
description: WASHINGTON. March 16Legislation that would closely regulate a controversial area of genetics experimentation was proposed today by a highlevel committee representing all Federal agencies concerned with the research.

title: Dunne to Toin Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., March 16Francis P. Dunne, who retired last year after 33 years as a steward for the New York Racing Association, has heal appointed steward for the thoroughbred meet at Monmouth Park opening June 1. The 74yearold Dunne has been racing secretary at Hawthorne, Hollywood Park, Tropical Park, Mexico City and Agua Caliente in his long career.

title: Disks: Suddenly, a Spate of lberias'
description: Years can go by without the appearance of a new Iberia in the record catalogues, and suddenly we are presented with three at once. None, let it be said quickly, seriously theater the hegemony of Alicia de Larrocha's definitive version, available on London (CSA2235), in a set that also includes Albeniz's Cantos de Espana and Navarra. But each of the three newcomers has something to offer those who appreciate the ferocious difficulty of this music and the imagination that is required In any idiomatic performance of it.

title: A World At Her Door
description: ALWAYS, THE TOWNHOUSE on East 79th Street was described as exquisite. Ditchley, the estate In Oxfordshire, was never called anything but magnificent, while Heron Bay, the house in Barbados, was thought of warmly, if not objectively, as the most beautiful place in the Caribbean. Marietta Tree was mistress of all these houses, each of which in its way was baronial. Now Mrs. Tree has moved to an apartment on Sutton Place, which, while charming, is hardly baronial. It has not altered her way of life in New York at all. The children had flown the nest, and Ronnie was spending a great deal of time in Barbados. We wanted to sell the house on East 79th Street, and then a friend said, I've always known that you liked this area Sutton Placeand showed us this, Mrs. Tree said. She meant the apartment, and she said that she and her husband, Ronald Tree, had liked it immediately. Soon afterward, however, Mr. Tree died. A month later, Mrs. Tree, by then having disposed of much of the furniture in the townhouse, moved into the apartment.

title: Late Whistle at Shea Stadium
description: New Yorkers are smarting with the sense of having been hit unfairly from the rear after learning that M. Donald Grant, chairman of the board of the New York Mets, has discovered that the oral agreement between him, Mayor Beame and the New York Jets was not a deal after all. The agreement involved a concession by the Mets to allow the Jets to play two regularseason football games at Shea Stadium before the end of the baseball season. In return, the Jets agreed not to move to New Jersey.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS 18 ON HEROIN CHARGES
description: Leroy (Nicky) Barnes, described as one of the top heroin dealers in New Yak. City, was arrested and charged yesterday with heading a narcotics organization that reaped profits of tens of thousands of dollars a day.

title: United Airlines President Backs Proposals for Regulatory Reform
description: The president of United Airlines, Richard J. Ferris, firmly supported yesterday the idea of regulatoryreform legislation that would allow some flexibility in setting fares and permit easier entry into and exit from the market.

title: Air Force Again Rejects Appeals To Flight Test Low Cost Fighter
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)  The Air Force continued today to reject efforts of a Florida aircraft designer to win operational flighttesting of a lowcost fighter bomber designed to support ground troops in combat.

title: SENATE UNIT REVIVES CARTER PLAN TO SPUR BUSINESS INVESTMENT
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Senate Finance Committee today restored the enlarged business investment credit in President Carter's economic stimulus program after it was knocked out of the proposed legislation that passed the House last week.

title: Town Rich in History Is Host to the President
description: CLINTON, Mass., March 16The long, connected humpbacked buildings of the mills twist down the slope of Main Street in this factory town like a grimy, redbrick beast.

title: Design Notebook
description: WHAT COLOR is New York? San Francisco is mostly white, London is more gray than anything else,. Santa Fe is the color of adobe. New York isn't as easily characterized, but at tends toward a silvery graythe color of the limestone of many of its older buildings and the aluminum of many of its newer ones.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: The New York Times/Carl T. Crossett MOVING, THE HARD WAY: A onestory brick house was moved yesterday from Williamsbridge Road and Rhinelander Avenue in the Bronx to Pelham Parkway and Tomlinson Avenue, four blocks away. The owner explained that moving his old house would cost him less than building a new one.

title: Washington & Business
description: Agriculture Department economists have assessed the effects of the harsh winter on food supplies and prices. Supplies continue large, but retail prices are higher. Page D3.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: First Period1. Pittsburgh, Blanchin 23 (Schack), 4:10. 2. Pittsburgh, Chapman 13 (unassisted), 12:37. PenaltiesPlante, StL, 4:26; Corrigan, Pit, 4:26; Kelly, Pit, 7:02; Irvine, StL, 13:10. 8 8

title: Family Money Builders
description: I ATROCITY stories about building contractors are making the rounds of any of the 40 neighborhoods in the New York metropolitan area where the Brownstone RevivalCommittee has members, Benita Korn is usually one of the first to hear them.

title: World News Briefs
description: MAR DELE PLATA, Argentina, March 16The thirdworld countries at the United Nations water conference here lined up today behind a proposal for an international water fund to finance a pure water supply for all the world's people.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: New developments emerged on several fronts in the Cuban situation:

title: Dance: Free Form Soars
description: THE FREEFORM concert of percussion improvisation and dance movement is rarely seen with such effect as when devised by Steve Paxton and the musician David Moss. The sound included traditional tones from conventional drums and exotic metallic rustlings from instruments of Mr. Moss's own creation. Mr. Paxton produced an inventive cluster of movement at St. Marks in the Bouwerie on Tuesday evening.

title: JUDGE RAO CLEARED; HIS SON FACES TRIAL
description: The perjury indictment of Judge Paul P. Rao of United States Customs Court was dismissed yesterday by a New York State Supreme Court justice. At the same time the justice upheld the indictments of Judge Rao's son and another lawyer.

title: SELFRULE BY INDIANS BACKED IN U.S. REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The relationship between the Federal Government and the American Indian, a problem as old as the nation itself, has been brought into, Sharp focus once again with the recommendation of a Congressional report that Indian tribes be given virtually autonomous rule.

title: Growing Orchids? It's Not So Difficult
description: ORCHIDS are at once probably the ugliest and the most beautiful of all house plants. Variously described as a pot of dried onion tops, unkempt whiskers, shoehorns for deer or slightly burned grass, the orchid as a foliage plant is a crowning failure. Ah, but when it blooms, all is forgiven.

title: Religious Group Asks U.S. T o Put Pressure on Soviet Under Helsinki Accords
description: A national religious task force concluded at a meeting here yesterday that, in urging greater religious freedom in the Soviet Union, the United States should focus on emigration, liberalization of religious education and expansion of places of worship.

title: John and Virginia Saladino's leftovers
description: When designer John Saladino (left, in his living room with wife, Virginia and son, Graham) wants to see people he invites them to his office. It's finished. If it were up to him, no one would be invited his apartment (which was once part of a Gould family triplex in an Upper East Side building) until it was finished, too. It's embarrassment to him. According to Mr. Saladino, the 37foot by 23foot by 24foot high living room is furnished by default, not by program, with leftovers from his last apartment. I always say God is the details, and this place is a monument to the collapse of careful detail. Is he afraid of finishing it? No, I'm not afraid of commitmentseeing it through down to the last soap dish. He doesn't say when he'll finish it. Who wouldn't Mr. Saladino want to see this room now? His classmates from Yale, where he studied painting, and his clients. What about his competition? Said Mr. Saladino, I have no competition.

title: BANK OF AMERICA EXPECTS LAG IN ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 16A cold winter in the East and drought conditions in the West will slow the economic growth of the United States from 5.1 percent to 4.7 percent and increase consumer prices by 5.9 percent, the Bank of America said today.

title: Smashing The Gang Around
description: PEKING, March 15Four captivating fiveyearold girls, all with big bows in their hair and wearing brightly colored sweaters, clapped their hands in glee at the appearance of a Western visitor to the factory's daycare center.

title: We're Sorry, Too, But
description: We are honored to accept the accolade of greatness from Mobil in that great corporation's customary Thursday morning lecture on the opposite page. We are also happy to acknowledge at least the possibility of our fallibility, both as reporters and commentators. If factual accuracy is the issue, let us see how serious were The Times transgressions:

title: Housing Starts Up Record 29% in Month
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)Builders logged a record increase last month in the number of new homes started, the Government reported today, providing further evidence that the economy is rapidly shaking off the effects of the severe winter.

title: Leonard Silk
description: There may be a way of seasonally adjusting the robins and crocuses out of the picture, but meanwhile both business and the stock market are feeling the lift of spring. Some of the optimism is also coming from looking back at how severe the winter was not, now that the latest numbers are coming in. Industrial production bounced up a full percentage point in February, more than making up for the 0.8 percent decline in January, when the freezing weather was at its worst.

title: VANCE SAYS INVADERS IN ZAIRE THREATEN VITAL COPPER MINING
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, defending the emergency airlift of American supplies to Zaire, said today that the invading forces from Angola had produced a dangerous situation for Zaire's critically important copper industry.

title: Dave Anderson
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 16Throughout the boxing career of George Foreman, his opponents invariably have climbed into the ring with strategy based primarily on prayer. Stay away from him in the early rounds. Frustrate him. Tire him out. Take the big punch away from him. But its easier planned than done. In his 46 fights, George Foreman has concluded 40 inside five rounds, 37 inside four rounds. 30 inside three rounds, 23 inside two rounds and 11 inside the first round. And the biggest percentage of my fights, George Foreman says, were against boxertypes who I knocked out. Among the few escapees was Muhammad Ali, who dethroned George Foreman as the world heavyweight champion with an eighthround knockout in Zaire nearly three years ago after having absorbed George Foreman's assault. And he was praying, George Foreman says. I could hear him praying. I could feel him praying. Ali's prayers were answered in George Foreman's only loss. But tomorrow night another boxertype, Jimmy Young, will be trying to escape. Jimmy Young is the clever heavyweight out of Philadelphia who, many people thought, outpointed Muhammad Ali last year. Jimmy Young cannot punch even as hard as Muhammad Ali and he cannot talk like him. But he's trying, or possibly just praying out loud.

title: GARDENING: IN AND OUT
description: A particular pleasure for Dr. E. E. Rockey is to have his dinner guests go out to his orchard and pick their own fruit for dessertperhaps a nectarine, a Jonathan apple or a bunch of grapes. For Dr. Rockey's guests a pickyourown dessert course has to be somewhat unexpectedhis orchard is on the 21st floor of an East Side penthouse.

title: Advertising
description: Hertz, Color it yellow. Avis. Color it red. Now, look at your calendar and scratch them both. It's St. Patrick's say, darlin's, and a dandy time to tall about the Big Green Team from National Car Rental.

title: Sunbelt Chic Blossoms in Scottsdale
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz,Scottsdale, Phoenix's adult playground town 20 miles to the east, bills itself as 'the West's most Western town. That's like calling Nantucket a Yankee fishing village. Scottsdale is both the most concentrated resort in southern Arizona as well as a thriving city of some 80,000 residents, an astonishing number of whom seem to have either a tennis court, a swimming pool, a set of golf clubs, or all of the above.

title: Decorating for the Diaper Set
description: ONCE, you could hardly start thinking about the design of a nursery without first answering the big questionpink or blue? Now, you can start way ahead. There are so many considerations to take into account, but the pink versus blue isn't one of them.

title: Sound
description: CHANCES are that you can dramatically improve the sound of your stereo system at no cost at all. All it takes is a moderate exercise of your imagination, the attentive use of your ears, and an hour or so of experimenting with the placement of your loudspeakers.

title: China, in Aagressive Drive, Tops Soviet in Exports to U.S.
description: An aggressive export drive by Peking, sparked by exhibits at the Canton Trade Fair and other sales efforts, has put China squarely ahead of the Soviet Union among Communist suppliers of manufactured goods to the United States.

title: Cherry Trees Safe After Winter
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)This winter's harsh weather apparently did little, if any, damage to the htousands of Japanese cherry trees in the capital, the National Park Service said today. If we don't have any heavy freezes, they'll look pretty good, said Harold brown, a horticulturalist. He said that the trees would bloom about March 23 ?r March 28.

title: White House Stopping All Afternoon Tours
description: WASHINGTON. March 16 (UPI)Rosalynn Carter has banned afternoon tours of the White House so her family can come and go without interference a White House aide said today.

title: Schneider to Conduct British Theater Tour
description: Alan Schneider, the director, will conduct a threeweek study tour of British Theater in Transition to examine the forces, institutions and personalities currently shaping British theater.

title: Letter FromHome
description: IT IS hard to be a walker in our town without being run down by a jogger. For sheer jogger densityand sheer is the worst kindNew Haven has no rival. We have joggers the way other towns have dogs, or, to put it another way other towns have dogs the way we have joggers. I don't think there is still another way to put it.

title: Fantasy by the Roomful
description: Almost everyone has a fantasy room in his or her head, including celebrities Julia Child, Polly Bergen and Naomi Sims. And at Niacy's through the end of the month, shoppers will find sixdesignercreated fantasyrooms created to mirror the lifestyles of specific celebrities.

title: DRIVE TO EASE LAWS ON MARIJUANA AIDED
description: ALBANY, March 16A senior Republican Senator introduced a bill today to remove criminal penalties for the possession of small amounts of marijuana, bill that differs in some details, but not in the basic concept, from one already before the Democraticcontrolled Assembly.

title: JUDGE RAO CLEARED; HIS SON FACES TRIAL
description: The perjury indictment of Judge Paul P. Rao of United States Customs Court was dismissed yesterday by a New York State Supreme Court justice. At the same time the justice upheld the indictments of Judge Rao's son and another lawyer.

title: Tomjanovich, Rockets Vanquish Nets, 10086
description: HOUSTON, March 16 (AP)Rudy Tomjanovich scored 36 points tonight and led the Houston Rockets to a 10086 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets.

title: Winter Gas Heat Cost Up $2.5 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)A Federal Power Commission staff report estimated today that householders paid an extra $1.5 billion in higher natural gas prices this winter plus another $1 billion for additional gas to fight freezing temperatures.

title: And She Doesn't Care Who Knows It
description: IFORESEE a situation developing that had perhaps best be nipped in the bud. Quickly. Heaven knows what complications it may lead to. Have you by any chance read the Playbill biographies for Andrei Serban's production of The Cherry Orchard at the Beaumont? You know, those thumbnail sketches that follow the castofcharacters page in the program and are meant to brush us in on the past works and pomps of the players, the director, the designer, the producer, the electrician and practically everybody except the fellow who pastes up the pretty posters outside. It so happens that I didn't give them any attention myself while I was actually seated in the Beaumont. My attention was much too riveted by the extravagant; and in the upshot, exhilarating things Mr. Serban was doing to and with Chekhov's play.

title: Checking a Boon to Savings Banks
description: Since being permitted to offer personal checking accounts last year, savings banks in New York State have steadily drawn away business from commercial banks, a survey by the Federal Reseve Bank of New York showed yesterday.

title: Suns Trounce Knicks, 12491
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 16  In a performance worthy of the legendary Knicks of the early 1960'swho finished last seven seasons in a rowthe 197677 Knicks were humiliated tonight by the Phoenix Suns, who had lost 12 straight games and were without the services of two strong rebounders, Gar Heard and Curtis Perry. The final score was 12491.

title: Reynolds Metals 77 Outlay
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that it expected its capital spending this year to total $85 million to $100 million. In its annual report, the Richmond based metals producer said 1976 outlays were $77.8 million, 22 percent below the $100 million estimated last October.

title: 5 New York Members of Congress Fight Bridge Tolls
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Five New York members of Congress released preliminary New York State report today to support their charge that tolls on the East River and Harlem River bridgewould cause severe economic and social consequences.

title: Taxi Fares to Rise 15% on Wednesday; Reforms Promised
description: Taxi fares will rise by about 15 percent at 12:01 A.M. Wednesday in New York City as the result of a 4to2 vote yesterday by the City Taxi and Limousine Commission.

title: Three Different apartmentsOne Classic Style
description: HOME is where you hang your hat and your heartanywhere in the: orld except New York. Here, home is the result of Darwinian selection. Life is the survival of the fittest and home is whatever you can find and afford: Mutation of the species is part of the processin my own case, a natural brownstoner became a reluctant Park. Avenue dweller; choice is a delusion even with the luxury of ontions.

title: Loews Net Up 50.6% in 4th Quarter
description: The Loews Corporation reported yesterday profit increases of 50.6 percent for the fourth quarter and 37.5 percent for all of last year. The record annual revenues and earnings reflected a rise in results for the Lorillard tobacco operation, the record results of its hotels division and sharply higher investment gains, Laurence A. Tisch chairman, said.

title: Reds Bomb Mets While Rose Broods
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 16Pete Rose stood alongside a railing down the leftfield line today, troubled by the presence of chips in his right elbow and the absence of a signed contract for 1977.

title: Tarport Hap Is Buried Where She Was Star
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 16 'I wanted to hold the funeral before sunrise, said Alan J. Leavitt as he was driving his Cadillac through the Lincoln Tunnel this morning. I didn't want a lot of people around, turning It into a circus.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: After a visit by State Supreme Court Justice Oliver Sutton to radio station WBAIFM last night, staff members voted to evacuate the station today. They have been occupying it since Feb. 11.

title: One Day in the City Council, an Education
description: Atter hours of shouting ana scansticsloaded debate, the New York City Council voted yesterday to require all city workers who live outside the city to mode back to New York within five years or face the loss of their jobs.

title: Racine, Wis., Teachers To End 7Week Walkout
description: RACINE, Wis., March 16 (AP)Negotiators for striking teachers and the Racine Unified School District reached tentative agreement today on a threeyear contract to end a bitter sevenweek walkout.

title: Edith Flynn's waiting game
description: Newlywed Edith Flynn (below) is a confirmed finisher. Twice widowed, she has lived in eleven houses in the last ten years. She prefers selling off the last scheme and starting from scratch each time. I love the process of decorating, she said, but after six months it should be done. But how do you furnish from scratch when you know you're moving as soon as you find a larger place? She and her husband, Bernard Flynn, a television producer, turned to designer Mara Palmer, who gave them a temporary stage set.

title: O'Neill Backs Public Funding for Congress Races
description: WASHINGTON, March 16Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who had twice voted against public funding of Congressional election campaigns, reversed himself today and said that, like most of his colleagues in the House of Representatives, he now supports such legislation.

Is it advisable to hang another wallpaper over, this, and if the original paper has to be removed what is the best way to do this?E.T., Garden City, L. I.

title: Hughes Estate New Questions
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 16A major mystery was born yesterday when an estate appraisal, filed in Texas and Nevada probate courts contended that when Howard R. Hughes died on April 5 he was worth $168.8 million and not billions of dollars.

title: Think First, Fly Later
description: Zaire is no longer the Congo and the United States is no longer looking for nationbuilding adventures abroad. So the urgent airlift of about $2 million worth of nonlethal military supplies to the regime of President Mobutu is not the beginning of a new Vietnam. Considering the past military aid to Zaire, it isn't even much of an added commitment. But it is a reflex response that should have been checked in recognition of the symbolism that such an action can acquire overseas and at home. The officials who rushed to help Mr. Mobutu deal with a border incursion want his continued gratitude and votes in international councils. But future American policy in Africa will be to seek such support exclusively through economic links with the nations of that continent. It will work best if we desist from military and political maneuvers in their internal affairs. The best way to mark time while defining a new policy is to mark time. The worst way is to imitate past crisis action without justifying the rush.

title: Dance: Cunningham Event Happens
description: THE DANCE UMBRELLA series resumed Tuesday night with Merce Cunningham and Dance Company. A contretemps between the producers of the series and the management of the Roundabout Theater has led to a change of venue, or venues.

title: Moslem Leader In Lebanon Slain, Imperiling Peace
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 16Kamal Jumblat, the Druse chieftain who led the alliance of leftists and Moslems in the Lebanese civil war, was assassinated today on a mountain road near here.

description: SEARING REALISM, it's not, but for the last five years The Waltons has been reminding viewers that there are alternatives to situation comedies and actionadventures in television programming. It is one of those few hit series that may have been saved by critics.

description: AMHERST, N.Y.Eight miles northeast of downtown Bluffalo, the jigsawed silhouette above the open flatland suggests from a distance a walled medieval city, with a halfdoien 10story castles like giant chess pieces on the skyline.

description: WASHINGTON  When you ask Clement E. Conger, the White House curator, to tell you about himself, the first thing you're, apt to find out is that he lives In Alexandria, Va., where his family has held forth for 253 years.

title: Labor Mounting Strong Campaign to Unionize South
description: ATLANTA, March 16After decades of sporadic activity and indifferent success in the South, organized labor Is in the midst of the most diverse and powerful drive in its history to stamp the union label on the region's rapidly swelling and still largely unorganized work force.

title: Carter Opens First Meet the People Tour
description: CLINTON, Mass., March 16On his first meet the people tour, President Carter told a sea of friendly faces here tonight that he wanted to build an Administration that would respond, to the ordinary moods of ordinary citizens.

title: I d Love to Have You Over For Dinner; but the House Isn't Finished
description: These are not good times for home furnishings voyeurs. While everyone seems to be in the throes of decorating and renovating, the good old personally conducted tour of the house has gone the way of the fivecent cup of coffee.

title: NEW &USEFUL
description: A lot of people today are throwing out the Chippendale, tearing down the walls and furnishing their homes with a flow of multilevel platforms and a minimum of furniture, often built in. But how do you get the platforms built? Two young men named George Hollander, and Dan Goldner, a builder and interior designer respectively, asked themselves that question, and a few months ago opened Plateaus, Ltd. The firm specializes in building walltowall, carpetcovered platformswhich can double as storageas well as constructing separate storage units.. They're also ready to work out the color scheme design and build the furniture, install all, the lighting and even come up with a total interior plan. The cost is generally from $15 td $35 a square foot. Plateaus, 340 West 22d Street; telephone 6919838.

title: Cape Cod Battles Pellets of Oil on Beach
description: WELLFLEET, Mass., March 16Every day the crews report at 7 A.M. and move up and down the beach removing the raisinsize pellets of oil. The crewstravel slowly, in groups of 20 or so, picking up the tarballs in makeshift scoops, buckets and plastic bags, which are then emptied into 55gallon drums on pickup trucks.

description: WASHINGTON, March 16Sentiment has been building in the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee for a change in President Carter's energy reorganization plan that would take away from the proposed job of Secretary of Energy the power to set oil and natural gas prices.

description: WASHINGTON, March 16The National Education Association is locked in an angry dispute with the Federal Election Commission over 'hat agency's refusal to condone its practice of raising political campaign funds by automatically deducting a contribution from members oavchecks.

He performs Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 P.M. until 1:30 A.M.; no cover or minimum charge.

Yet the investigations into his proposal to establish a Fine Arts Center of the Annenberg School of Communications at the Metropolitan Museum of Art evidently so offended him that he withdrew his $40 million offer.

title: News Summary
description: Forces invading Zaire from Angola have been engaged in conflict along routes to the copper mines that are vital to the country's economy, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance told the House International Relations Committee. Mr. Vance said the invaders were believed to be primarily returning members of the former Katanga gendarmerie who fled to Angola a decade ago. He also disclosed that the United States had had its first direct contact with Cuba on opening diplomatic talks. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Associated Press

The driver of the car, identiried as Benjamin Reynolds, 20, of Westwood, Mass., got onto the turnpike at Interchange 3 without stopping for a toll ticket. Police gave chase, following for 26 miles at speeds of around 100 miles an hour. Driver was killed and seven injured in the crash.

title: Stage: Complications
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I. ARE WE IN THE MIDST of a neorealist movement in playwriting? Well, one would hardly think it from the Eastern seaboard, although even here the majority of our black playwrights are pretty much concerned with telling a plain tale plainly. And when one moves across the country, or perhaps more specifically down the country, one can discern a new desire to tell it as it really is.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Can the art of the moment be seen at established museums and galleries? A group of artists who feel that it can't, will show their work in SoHo this weekend in the Whitney Counterweight festival. In response to the current Biennial at the Whitney Museum, 90 artists from as far away as California and Puerto Rico will exhibit work that ranges from the fairly traditional to the wildly experimental. Six SoHo galleries all within a city block, will participate. Browsers are advised to start their tour at the James Yu Gallery 393 West Broadway (4317867). There they will receive maps and information on Counterweight readings and performances, which start off with a symposium tonight at the SoHo Center for the Visual Arts, 114 Prince Street, at 9. Patterson Sims, Whitney Biennial curator, will be there. The galleries are open from 11 to 6 today, tomorrow and Sunday. Suggested tour contribution is 75 cents.

description: PROVO, Utah, March 17Idaho State, using a zone defense and a gameend stall, unexpectedly knocked the University of California, Los Angeles, out of the National Collegiate Athletic 'ssociation's basketball championships tonight with a 7675 decision.

title: At the Movies
description: HE'S 63, with a weathered face and a white wilderness of beard. Yet he carries his massiveshouldered bulk youthfully, with the pantherish grace of a Hemingway hero, as agile as the doomed Swede in The Killers, the movie which shot him to stardom more than three decades ago. His voice is majestically husky, his diction precise but punchy, vibrant with echoes of the New York streets he walked so long ago. Halfsmiling, he grips your hand and pierces you with a shaft of blueeyed intensity.

title: Chicago St. Patrick's Day Parade Dominated by Memories of Daley
description: CHICAGO, March 17Richard J. Daley, who died last December, dominated the 26th annual St. Patrick's Day parade today just as he did in the 21 years that he was Mayor.

title: Theater: Romeo And Juliet in Circle
description: WHAT IS Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet about? Love adrift, finally drowned in a sea of tragedy? Yes, in part. Yet it is also a study of Renaissance society, its hierarchy, its rigidity, its aspirations, its perils. At one level Romeo and Juliet are swept up in a personal tragedy, but at another it is a social tragedy. It is also an Italian tragedy. Full of sun and menace, of grandeur and passion.

title: Art: Hannah Hoch, A Mama of Dada
description: AS A FEATURE of the Berlin Now festival, which is bringing a variety of German achievements in the visual, literary and performing arts to New York this month and next. Goethe House has organized an exhibition of the work of Hannah Hoch, one of the last of our living links with the European avantgarde that flourished in the early decades of this century.

title: Calif ano Says Quotas Are Necessary To Reduce Bias in Jobs and Schools
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Employment quotas can find do work in reversing patterns of job discrimination, Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today.

title: Art:. Six Greats At Morgan Library
description: THE QUESTION How much is too much? has yet to be heard at the Morgan Library. In that omnicapacious institution there is no such thing as too much and each one of its departments could be hived off and turned into a museum of a very high class.

title: A 27STORY COMPLEX PLANNED FOR NEWARK

title: The Peasants Can Frolic Along Madison A venue
description: What the chic women who shop regularly in the smart little boutiques gong Madison Avenue will be encouraged to buy this summer is clothes that make them look like peasants. Peasants on a feast day. Peasants parading around the village square before dinner. Marie Antoinette playing milkmaid.

title: The Pop Life
description: PETER GABRIEL'S appearance at the Palladium tomorrow night will be the first for the singersongwriter since leaving Genesis, the highly successful English rock group for which he was lead vocalist, more than a year ago. His departure from the group came when Genesis was just beginning to reap the rewards of almost 10 years of recording and touring, and many observers wondered how the other members would get along without Mr. Gabriel's costumes, theatrical props, mercurial stage presence and manofathousaihdvoices routines. Then the popularity of Genesis skyrocketed, with the drummer Phil Collins filling in for Mr. Gabriel, and people began wondering how Mr. Gabriel would get along without the rest of Genesis.

title: P. L. O. Official Shakes Hands With President
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 17President Carter shook hands with a representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization during a reception tonight following his speech in the General Assembly hall here. However, he later said he had no intention of following up with further contacts until the P.L.O. gave up its platform dedicated to the destruction of Israel.

title: City Opera: Blutende Hollander
description: There are opera performances at which more tension is generated backstage than in view of the sudiende. The spring season's third performance in German of Der Fliegende Hollander, which the New York City Opera presented Wednesday night, proved to be one such event.

title: Kingman Hits 3d Homer as Mets Win
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17The New York Mets made it five out of seven in spring training games today. They scored a 52 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates, a team that had just executed a rare play in baseballa nineman trade with Charlie Finley that was not blocked by Bowie Kuhn.
