description: NEWARK, March 17Plans for a 27story office complex in the heart of downtown Newark, 20 floors of which would provide an enlarged and consolidated headquarters for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, are expected to be announced within the next few weeks.

title: Texaco Told by F.P.C. To Show Cause on Plan For Delivering of Gas
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Federal Power Commission ordered Texaco today to show cause why it should not be prohibited from delivering natural gas to its Port Arthur, Tex. refinery from Federal fields offshore Louisiana.

title: Land Boom in North Hills Vexes Nassau
description: NORTH HILLS, L.I., March 15Somebody once called the Bois de Boulogne the lungs of Paris. By the same reasoning, the village of North Hills has served as the security blanket of Nassau County.

title: 2 Holdup Suspects Are Chased Into Police Arms by Bar Patron
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., March 17 (AP)The police here made two easy arrests when an angry bar patron chased two suspected robbers into the arms of a group of patrolmen.

title: Whitman Drops Football
description: WALLA WALLA, Wash., March 17 (UPI)Football is dead at Whitman College. Whitman trustees made it final this week. They cast their votes approving elimination of the program by telephone. The football program was as old as the 84yearold institution, having begun in 1892. The only previous time the sport was canceled was during the two World Wars. Whitman's wonlosttied record ended at 19132519.

title: BODY FOUND IN THE DESERT MAY BE LEADER OF UNION
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 17 (UPI)The body of a man, possibly of Al Bramlet, the missing leader of a Culinary Workers Union local, was discovered in the desert about 40 miles southwest of here today.

title: Letters
description: City Water: An Unwise OptionTo the Editor New York City enjoys drinking water that is among the purest in the U.S.A. because its source is uncontaminated upstate rainwater. A proposal of the Army Corps of Engineers (news story March 6) would supplement this almost pristine supply with Hudson River water, or, more accurately, with a dilute solution of partially treated sewage and industrial effluents.

title: WALTER M. PERRY
description: Walter M. Perry, a retired executive of Johns Manville, died Monday at his Darien, Conn. home. He was 71 years old. A graduate of Cornell University, he joined the company in 1936 and retired in 1970 as production manager in the international department.

title: Finley Loses Legal Battle As Court Upholds Kuhn
description: CHICAGO, March 17 (AP)Charles 0. Finley, owner of the Oakland A's, has lost his multimilliondollar lawsuit against the baseball commissioner, Bowie Kuhn.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS CARTER REBATE PLAN BY PARTYLINE VOTES
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Senate Finance Committee today in effect approved Presi'ent Carter's $50 tax rebate, the cornerstone of his economic stimulus program this year, by narrowly rejecting two Republican amendments offering permanent tax cuts instead.

title: Bomb Is Found in Pizza Parlor
description: A bomb was discovered last night in a Brooklyn pizza parlor at 1255 Flatbush Avenue. The police said it was defused by the bomb squad after a customer had discovered the ticking package behind counter and had thrown it into a trashcan outside.

title: Carey Bars 5% Rise Now For All in Civil Service
description: ALBANY, March 17Governor Carey today rejected the recommendation of factfinding panel that all of the state's Civil Service employees be given an immediate 5 percent pay raise. The matter now seems certain to go the Legislature for a final decision.

title: In Memorial
description: LEIGHVivIon. In the tenth year Forever lovely, forever loved. She will always Be. C.C.K.

title: GERALD C. M'NAMARA
description: Gerald C. McNamara, a securities broker, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and a resident of Saddle River. N.J.

title: A Philosophical Debate on Welfare Sparked in Legislative Committee
description: TRENTON, March 17A Monmouth County welfare family that makes $1,000 a month in salary and rides around in a 1977 Buick station wagon sparked a philosophical debate today over the purpose of welfare programs at a meeting of the New Jersey Legislature Appropriations Committee.

title: Issue Over the Rosenberg Case Brings Debate on Role of Judges
description: The convictions and sentences of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg were upheld after as much scrutiny by appellate courts as any case in American history. But now, 24 years after thelr were electrocuted as atomicespionage plotters, a different aspect of the case has become the topic of debate among prominent law professors leaders of the bar and civil libertarians.

title: Stocks Lose Drive After 5 Days And Dow Declines 3.16 to 964.841
description: The stock market's strong fiveday recovery ran out of momentum yesterday in a slight pullback. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 3.16 points to 964.84 after running ahead nearly 25 points during the last week.

title: MIAMI BANK SUSPENDS AIDE PENDING FUND STUDY
description: MIAMI, March 17 (AP)A vice president of the Southeast First National Bank of Miami, the largest bank in Florida. has been suspended as bank and Federal officials continued an investigation into the disappearance of $1.1 million, a spokesman said today.

title: North Carolina and Kentucky Win
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md. March 17On St. Patrick's Night, with just two seconds left to play in the game, the Fighting Irish ran out of luck. Phil Ford of North Carolina calmly hit two foul shots to give the Tar Heels a 7977 victory over Notre Dame in the second game of the Eastern Regional doubleheader of the National Collegiate basketball tournament. The victory set up Saturday's regional final against Kentucky, which outran and outshot Virginia Military Institute in the first game. 9378.

title: New Office for Beame Opened
description: Four city employees, on loan to Deputy Mayor Stanley M. Friedman, Mayor Beame's chief political adviser, opened an office at 51 Chambers Street three weeks ago to improve the Mayor's scheduling and coordinate City agencies.

title: Music: Piano Flash From James Tocco
description: IF NOTHING else, the piano recital that James Tocco gave in Tully Hall on Wednesday evening showed why he has won or placed high in major international competitions. Almost always competition winners are spitandpolish technicians, musical literalists (eccentricities bother the jurists) and unexceptionable musicians.

title: Auto Industry Expected To Build 210,000 Cars In Week, Highest Since'73
description: DETROIT, March 17The United States auto industry is expected to build 210,272 cars this week, the highest weekly total since late 1973 when the Arab oil embargo started the industry on a twoyear slump, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

title: India Political Foes Trade Charges; ReVote Ordered at 18 Polling Sites
description: NEW DELHI, March 18 (AP)Prime Minister, Indira Gandhi accused her political enemies and the press today of trying to foment chaos and anarchy. The opposition accused her of seeing phantoms.

title: Personal Income Growth Revives From Winter Lag
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)Record growth in the aggregate size of Americans paychecks last month helped pull personal income out of its weatherinduced stagnation, the Government reported today.

title: Art People
description: BOWING A VIOLIN with a builtin speaker while wearing ice skates embedded in blocks of ice, Laurie Anderson gave several outdoor concerts in Genoa, Italy, in 1975. Between songs I talked to passersby about the parallels between skates and violinplaying: balance; blades over a surface, simultaneity, she writes in her justpublished Notebook, which records several such excursions on the violin.

title: HANAFI SECT TRADES THREATS WITH J.D.L.
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Jewish Defense League threatened today to stage a demonstration by armed, angry Jewish youths outside the headquarters of the Hanafi Moslem sect on Sunday. The Hanafi response was a warning of blood baths against all Zionist Jews if the demonstration was carried out.

title: Deaths
description: AXELRODMorris. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Francine and Penny, cherished grandfather of Ginger and Patrick. Loving brother of Cal and Irene. Services Sunday, 10:00 A.M., The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Energy Quest Extends Ever Deeper Into Ocean
description: LAFAYETTE, La.As the 165foot Coastal Cruiser lay at anchor the other day, about 75 miles off the marshy Louisiana coast, her crew was in the stern, preoccupied with raising and lowering ashiny, white sphere.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: BostonMarvin Hagler, 161 pounds, Brockton, Mass., knocked out Reggie Ford, 158, Guyana, 3 rounds; Hagler retains North American middleweight title.

title: German Sprinter Says Team Uses Drugs
description: BONN, March 17A West German sprinter says that 90 percent of the members of the West German national track and field team are on pills and shots, and acknowledges that he has been taking steroids for years.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: Mary McGrath Is Bride of Teddy F. Walkowicz
description: Mary Lucy McGrath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. McGrath of New York, was married yesterday to Teddy F. Walkowicz, chairman and chief executive officer of the National Aviation and Technology Corporation. Only members of the immediate families attended the civil ceremony, which was at the McGrath home.

title: Call Options Trade In 11 Stocks Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The staff of the National Association of Securities Dealers will present data to its board here tomorrow indicating that a plan for trading call options on 11 overthecounter stocks is economically feasible.

title: Genesco Reveals Its Ouster Terms As Jarman Leaves
description: Franklin M. Jarman, who was ousted as chief executive officer of Genesco Inc.. the country's largest maker and retailer of apparel, but allowed to remain chairman, will resign by Aug. 1. However, he will be paid $431,667 in 28 monthly installments after that date. He will also receive a paid club membership in New York and use of a 1977 Continental automobile.

title: Money Supply Rose $1.5 Billion Week of March 9 After Decline
description: The nation's money supply rose S1.5 billion during the week ended March 9, reversing in part the declines of the previous two weeks, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: Villanova, Alabama Bow at Garden
description: Glenn Hagan is the unheralded member of the St. Bonaventure basketball team. The primary job of the 6foot junior backcourt man is to set up Essie Hollis and Greg Sanders, his high scoring forwards, and to dribble, make steals and stay out of the limelight.

title: Reminiscing With Billy Eckstine
description: When Billy Eckstine joins Count Basie's orchestra on the stage of Carnegie Hall this evening, he will be singing with a band that exists primarily because of him.

title: Dorothy Seiberling Is Named To Post on The Times Magazine
description: Dorothy Seiberling, an executive editor at New York magazine has been named deputy editor of The New York Times Magazine, it was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor of The Times.

title: REORGANIZATION PROPOSAL BACKED BY HOUSE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)The House Government Operations Committee today approved President Carter's requested Government reorganization authority by vote of 39 to 3, clearing the way for final Congressional action by next week.

title: Preseason Baseball
description: BatteriesDeny, Lagrow (5), Harrison (7), and Simmons, Tamargo (7); Barrios, Kucck (5), Martinez (7). Peterson (9), Otten (9) and Nordhagen. Session (7. WHarrison. L. Martinez. HRSt. Louis, Chant.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Associated Press BOYLE RELEASED: W. A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers, leaving prison in Pittsburgh yesterday with his daughter Antoinette. Boyle, who was convicted in 1974 of ordering the murder of union insurgent Joseph Yablonski and his wife and daughter, was granted a new trial by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court last month.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Horses listed In order of post positions Letter designate. OTB listing FIRST$8,000, Cl., 3YO and UP, 6f.

title: A Search for the Proper Path In a World That Is No Longer
description: Unlike others among his contemporaries who have written about the nowdestroyed Jewish communities of Eastern Europe, Chaim Grade is little interested in the interaction between these communities and the hostile environments that surround them or in the encroachment of Western ideas on tradition or the interplay between ancient views and fresh ones blowing in from all sides.

title: Publishing: First Novels
description: SOME 10 PERCENT of new books published are novels. Of these, far fewer than half on any house's list are first novels. Proportions vary from season to season, depending on how you count thrillers, Gothics, historicals, sciencefiction, fictionalized fact and factualized fiction.

title: Dividends
description: Pe Stk. of pay riod Rate record able

title: SEPT. 8 IS SELECTED AS DATE FOR PRIMARY
description: ALBANY, March 17The statewide primary this year will be held on Sept. a, with a runoff election to follow, necessary, in New York City on Sept. 19, according to a new timetable agreed on last night by the leaders of the Legislature.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)  The House Select Committee on Assassinations announced today that it would conduct independent ballistics tests next week on the bullet that killed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: CHROME IMPORTS CURB HELD NO AUTO PROBLEM
description: DETROIT, March 17Action by Congress and the Carter Administration to stop importing Rhodesian chrome will not cause any immediate problems for the auto industry, according to spokesmen for the major auto manufacturers.

title: Bad Spots at Aqueduct Bar Change From Winter Track
description: Unless the main dirt track at Aqueduct shapes up in a hurry, Kentucky Derby candidates in the Bay Shore Stakes may find themselves running six furlongs instead of seven.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AFRICAN METEOR (Farrell). Capetown AorII 2, Be ra; 16; sails from Joralemon St., Brooklyn.

title: A Bedouin Sculptor Breaks a Tribal Taboo
description: IN THE DESERT, IsraeliOccupied SinaiA mile or two inland from the gleaming waters of the Red Sea, at a point were a Crusader ruin sits majestically on a coral island, lives a man who, in his terms, can be said to have invented the art of sculpture.

title: Clinton Back to Normal After Carter's Visit
description: CLINTON, Mass., March 17Everyone on the street here today was wearing a touch of green, from a carnation to a Complete outfit, and by early afternoon the three bartenders on duty at the Old Timer Bar were moving fast to keep up with the growing throng of St. Patrick's Day celebrants. This heavily Irish New England mill town was settling back for normal after a visit by the President of the United States.

title: Transcript of President's Address at U.N.on Peace, Economy and: Human Rights.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 17Following is a transcript of President Carter's address here tonight:

title: How to Get There
description: The Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge is on Cross Bay Boulevard between Howard Beach and Broad Channel. By subway, take the A train to the Broad Channel station and either walk a half mile north to the visitors center or take the Green Line bus on Cross Bay Boulevard from the subway station. From Columbus Circle, the subway ride is one hour.

title: CONTROVERSY MOUNTS OVER MEDICAID BEDS
description: Controversy is mounting among healthcare authorities over a proposed solution to the chronic shortage of Medicaid beds in New Jersey, a monthly backlog that has risen from 1,000 to 1,800 patients in the last year.

title: Retarded Youth Is. Fatally Stabbed
description: A 20yearold retarded youth was fatally stabbed by another youth in a crowded subway corridor at 14th Street and Eighth Avenue late yesterday afternoon.

title: Moving Day For School Prompts a Concert
description: Nothing affects art as much as money. Even foreign exchange rates can determine whether a European soprano is willing to sing at the Metropolitan Opera or a string quartet feels it is worthwhile to tour Japan. Recently, economic leverage caused a music school to move from Switzerland to California.

title: Dr. Chih Chiang Teng Dies at 72; Research Director for EyeBank
description: Dr. Chili Chiang Teng, an ophthalmologist, died Monday at University Hospital. He was 72 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: AN EXADDICT GUNMAN HOLDS TWO HOSTAGE
description: A 27year old former heroin addict, upset over poor living conditions and the removal of his 5yearold daughter by welfare officials, held a 15yearold boy and a television reporter hostage in an East Harlem church for nearly two hours yesterday before being overpowered in a quick lunge by a police captain.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: WASHINGTONAbout a year ago, a lively controversy was raging here between top officials of the United States Treasury and the World Bank over the future scope of the bank's operations. The development institution's mangers wanted to set in motion a substantial enlargement of its financial resources to permit expanded lending down the roadproviding moderate growth and allowing for rising inflation. Those objectives, however, were stoutly resisted by the Ford Government as exces ambitious, premature, risky and politically impractical.

title: Music: Bread Plays
description: Bread, the Los Angelesbased rock group that had a string of AM radio hits between its formation in 1969 and its demise in 1973, was back in action Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. The timing of the appearance made comparison with the Eagles, which performed at Nassau Coliseum on Tuesday and will be at Madison Square Garden for a soldout show on Friday, virtually inescapable. Both are LOS Angeles bands wan Singersongwriters as their principals. Both have made their mark with soft, middleoftheroad rock and, above all, with distinctiVe songs.

title: Judge Rejects Charges of Brainwashing Against Hare Krishna Aides
description: The Hare Krishna movement was called a bona fide religion yesterday by State Supreme Court justice in Queens who threw out two indictments against officials of the movement. The indictments had charged them with illegal imprisonment of two members and attempted extortion from the father of one of the believers.

title: WILLIAM J. FULTON, 70, CHICAGO TRIBUNE REPORTER
description: CHICAGO, March 17William J. Fulton, a reporter for The Chicago Tribune for more than 40 years and its correspondent at the United Nations from 1949 until his retirement five years ago, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital, Sarasota, Fla. He was 70 years old.

title: Only Part of Times Mans Papers Are Returned by Czechoslovakia
description: VIENNA, March 17The Czechoslovak Government has returned the unused writing paper and envelopes that policemen seized from Paul Hofmann of The New York Times when he reached a border station Feb. 12 on his way out of the country, but it kept notebooks and other documents.

title: MOUNTED POLICE CHARGE UNRULY YOUTHS IN PARK
description: Mounted police officers supported by almost 100 foot patrolmen charged into a crowd of some 5.000 rowdy teenagers who had gathered in Central Park yestertay to drink and watch the St. Patrick's Day Parade.

title: Jews Send Thanks To Moslem Envoys For Help in Siege
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The 10th Surah of the Koran says that mankind were only one nation, then they fell into variance. The elusive dream of world unity came a tiny step closer to realization last week when three Moslems ne gotiated the release of 134 hostages, most of them Jews, from their Moslem captors.

title: Third World Hails Tentative Approach On Aid From U.S.
description: GENEVA, March 17Representatives here of thirdworld countries have cautiously welcomed the first statement by the Carter Administration of a new willingness to discuss a common fund that would serve to stabilize world commodity Prices.

title: COURT ORDER HALTS REHIRING OF POLICE
description: A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan enjoined the New York City Police Department late yesterday from rehiring officers laid off in the fiscal crisis until seniority lists were revised to remove the effects of past discrimination against blacks and Hispanic people.

title: Music: De Larrocha With the Toronto
description: THIS HAS BEEN the season of the Beethoven Piano Concerto No. 3, and last night Alicia de Larrocha was the exponent of that popular work. Seems that everybody has been playing it this season. The great Spanish lady was soloist with the Toronto Symphony in Carnegie Hall, with Andrew Davis conducting.

title: People in Sports
description: One of major league baseball's better pitchers, Luis Tiant, has ended a threeweek boycott of spring training and will report to the Boston Red Sox camp in West Palm Beach, Fla., today.

title: Pakistan's Experiment With Democracy Results in Chaos
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 16 Chances are no one will ever know who won Pakistan's elections last week, but there is no doubt that democracy lost.

title: BOND PRICES SHOW A SLIGHT DECLINE
description: Bond prices declined slightly yesterday as most of the new issues marketed this week failed to sell as quickly as investment bankers had hoped. The Federal Reserve, which had temporarily drained reserves from the banking system earlier this week, added some yesterday, and it also reported Credit increases in bank loans and Markets the money supply that were smaller than expected. All these developments failed to stir the credit markets much, however, and the afternoon ended with fixed incomes securities drifting sideways, a little below their Wednesday closing levels.

title: Proposal Renewed to Apply Tolls To More Westchester Parkways,
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 17The East Hudson Parkway Authority, which last year ran into a flood of opposition when it proposed tolls on a number of Westchester County parkways, has quietly resubmitted essentially the same proposal in an attempt to get Governor Carey's support for the necessary legislation.

title: After Prison (in India), and Before (in Rhodesia)
description: BOMBAYWhen some of us were released from Bombay Central Prison on the night of Jan. 25, R. S. Chavan, the prison warden, escorted us outside the massive wooden gate. Chavan is not exactly a kindhearted man. I have seen him dealing with convicted criminals with a strictness bordering on harshness.

title: Demand for Phoenix Crime Report Stirs Run on OutofTown Papers
description: PHOENIX, March 17  The hottest property in Phoenix these days is an outof town newspaper.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (Reuters)The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. George S. Brown, today voiced concern over the longterm effect Of the rejection of United States military aid by Latin American countries angry at criticism of their human rights practices.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney discusses the changing slant of Administration policy toward World Bank thirdworld development operations. The new Administration may endorse the same expensive aid by the bank that was so strongly opposed only a year ago by the Ford Administration. Page D2.

title: Many Marchers and a MillionWatchers Paint Town Green
description: Twas the only day of the year when a dyed green carnation will win out easily over a perfect rose, when the bright white lines on Fifth. Avenue pale beside a center stripe of Kelly and the American flag is outnumbered by the green, white and orange, banner of Irelanda great day, for the Irish, for street vendors, souvenir hawkers and tavern owners.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: SUGGESTED LYRIC for this weekend; So long, it's been good to know you. In fact, it's been absolutely delightful. But at P.M. tomorrow on CBS, in Episode No. 168, The Mary Tyler Moore Show calls it quits, leaving the grind of new shows for the longterm annuities of repeats and international syndication. Created by James L. Brooks and Allan Burns, the series had its premiere on Sept. 19, 1970, and the fictional local newsroom at WJMTV in Minneapolis has achieved the popularity clout of all three network news operations combined.

title: JUIYIBLAT Is BURIED AS KILLINGS MOUNT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 17Kamal Jumblat, the slain leftist and Druse leader, was buried today in his home village southeast of here in the presence of tens of thousands of mourners. There were increasing reports of revenge killings, and his followers brought the Moslem half of Beirut to a halt with a general strike.

title: DR. MARIANO VEIGA
description: Dr. Mariano Veiga, a psychiatrist and psychologist, died Wednesday at Maryland General Hospital in Baltimore. He was 57 years old and a resident of Timonium, Md.

title: TRAIN CRASH HEARING IS TOLD OF MARIJUANA
description: CHICAGO, March 17 (UPI)A doctor said today that Stephen Martin could have been normal or high as a kite from marijuana, when the eleyated train on which he was motorman ran into another train and plunged from the tracks, killing 11 persons and injuring nearly 200.

title: Hanoi Chief Cites New U.S. Spirit
description: HANOI, Vietnam, March 17 (UPI)Prime Minister Pham Van Dong of Vietnam said today that the new spirit of President Carter could solve all problems between Vietnam and the United States. Leonard Woodcock, head of the White House commission on Americans missing in Indochina, praised the Vietnamese as a courageous people.

title: Roosevelt
description: Horsos, listed in order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Tennis
description: Second RoundDianne Fromholtz defeated Mona Guerrant, 64, 61; Kerry Melville Reid defeated Kathy Harter, 63, 64; Betty Stove defeated Lele Faroad. 64, 63; Sue Barker wan be default from Virginia Ruzici; who is suffering from an injured wrist.

title: People and Business
description: Questioning what's in a name, Stanley S. Kresge, 76yearold son of the late Sebastian, who founded the S.S. Kresge Company, has taken exception to a vote of the company's directors approving a change in the company name of K Mart Corporation. I don't think it makes any sense to change from the name of a founder to a name that doesn't relate to n individual, Mr. Kresge said yesterday in Troy, Mich.

title: Charlton J. K. Hinman, 66, Expert On First Editions of Shakespeare
description: Charlton Joseph Kadio Hinman, a Shakespeare scholar and inventor of the Hinman Collating Machine, a device that made possible the comparatively rapid collation of individual pages of Sheakespeare's printed texts, died Wednesday at the Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 66 years old.

title: Interesting Development, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 17State Department officials said today that the North Korean's remarks were an interesting development but were part of mixed signals emanating from Pyongyang.

title: Memorial Srruires
description: ??UOME  Carol Anne. Suecial Masses will be held on Sunday, March 20 at 10:15 A.M., St. Pius X Church, Plainview. N.Y. (Washington Ave.), & on Monday, March 21. at 11:30 A.M. at St. Jean Baptiste Church, 184 E. 26th St. (Lexington Ave.).

title: Charlotte Advances With Michigan
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 17St. Patrick's Day worked its magic in the Mideast Regionals tonight when a basketball team called the Mean Green, from the University of North Carolina, Charlotte, trounced the Orangemen from Syracuse University, 8159.

title: Gertrude Case, 77; Civic Leader Aided New York Charities
description: Gertrude Eldred Case, a prominent civic volunteer, died yesterday in the Caroltown Convalescent Hospital in Fairfield, Conn. She was 77 years old. Mrs. Case, who recently moved to Connecticut from Washington, was active in New York civic causes for many years.

title: Broadway
description: THE GOODSPEED OPERA HOUSE in East Haddarn, Conn., which is to Broadway what good farm club is to the Yankees, will open its new season April 26 with Sweet Adeline, the Jerome KernOscar Hammerstein 2d musical that first knocked them dead in 1929. Sweet Adeline will run until June 18, and then Hit the Deck will come in June 26. This is the show by Vincent Youmans and Herbert Fields that was first around in 1927. It will be at Goodspeed until Aug. 13. Then The Red BlueGrass Western Flyer Show will come in Aug. 16 and stay until at least Oct. 2. Brand new, it has been anywhere else before.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A candidate for the City Council in Jersey City won the right yesterday to distribute campaign literature at the PATH station in Journal Square despite contentions by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that he would disrupt commuter traffic.

title: SECURITY IS STRICT FOR CARTER'S VISIT
description: Paying his first visit to New York City since, taking office two months ago, President Carter was whisked under heavy guard to the United Nations last night, but even the strict security measures could not stifle his craving for contact with the people.

title: Some City Funds Barred At Savings Banks Cited By Beame on Mortgages
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that New York City would henceforth deposit certain special funds, amounting to $10 million a year, only in those savings banks that had committed themselves to more home mortgages for New York City residents.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: Tomianovich 8 7.8 23, Malone 4 78 15, Kunnert 9 0.0 18, Lucas 3 22 8, Murphy 0.0 14, Newlin 3 00 6, Johnson 1 0.0 Jones 0 0.0 0. Kennedy I 0.0 2, Ratleff 0.2 0. Totals 36 16.20 88.

title: DR. ARNOLD S. BREAKEY, OPHTHALMOLOGIST, DIES
description: Dr. Arnold S. Breakey, an ophthalmologist, died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Rumania Admits Its Oilfields Approach Depletion
description: BUCHAREST, RumaniaEnergy experts here say the severt March 4 earthquake apparently has not affected this nation's oilfields, but there has been an official admission that they are ap?? ??

title: About Real Estate
description: When the eye of the beholder belongs to Ted Hilles, beauty lies in old and dilapidated buildings. Restore he must.

title: Bhutto's Opponent Reported Arrested
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, Friday, March 18 (Reuters)Reliable sources here said today that the police had arrested Pakistan's most prominent opposition leader, retired Sir Marshal Heghar Khan.

title: Panama Canal Negotiators Held Secret Talks in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 17Panama's negotiating team flew secretly to Washington last weekend for a daylong discussion with the United States delegation of issues to be resolved for a new Panama Canal treaty.

title: Los Angeles Cleared in Blast
description: LOS ANGELES, March 17 (UPI)The State Court of Appeal says the city is immune from liability for deaths and injuries resulting from a bomb explosion in a locker at Los Angeles International Airport in 1974. Three persons were killed and 36 injured by the explosion. Justice Lynn D. Compton yesterday upheld a Superior Court decision dismissing cases against the city, noting that the law makes public entities immune from liability for failure to provide sufficient police protection.

title: Out of Doors
description: NEW YORK CITY'S greatness rests on man's works and nature's gifts, notably its outstanding harbor, probably the finest in the world. But among the lesserknown natural advantages that bless the city is the fact that it lies directly beneath the Atlantic Flyway, the major route for bird migration in the East.

title: N.F.L. Players Given Extension on Pact Vote
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (UPI)The National Football League Players Association announced today it had extended for one week the balloting deadline for its members on a fiveyear. $107 million contract with pro football owners.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The nation's secondlargest steelmaker, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said yesterday it planned to raise its prices for carbon and alloy tool steel by 8 percent effective April 1. Other specialty steelmakers had no comment on the action. A spokesman for Bethlehem said the increase resulted from higher costs of labor, raw materials and energy and added that the grades involved in the pricing action account for less than one percent of the industry's total shipments.

title: Beanie Will Sue To Bar the Jets In Jersey Move
description: An angry Mayor Beame yesterday directed the city to take four major sports powers to court to prevent the Jets from playing the first two home games of their season in New Jersey.

title: For Children
description: AFRICAN CULTURE WORKSHOPS, after school and weekend programs, free, for children 6 to 12 Years old, at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, and at the James Weldon Johnson Center 120 East 110th Street. Programs include small ??? African mask making, heroes of Africa ??? workshop and others. For information and reservations call TR 31300, extension ??? or 525.

title: Young Floors Foreman in 12th And Wins Unanimous Decision
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 17With a knockdown in the final round, Jimmy Young completed a startling upset of George Foreman by earning a unanimous 12round decision over the former heavyweight champion tonight at the Roberto Clemente Coliseum.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST$7,500, pace, cl., mile.

title: Antiques
description: COLLECTORS of musical instruments and memorabilia are finding lately that the pace is quickening. The first specialty musical instrument auctionstwo in factwere held here last fall, and the sale at Sotheby Parke Bernet resulted in two world records. A Ruckers double virginal fetched $65,000, the highest price paid at public sale for a keyboard instrument. And the events set the record for total sales of this kind$515.160.

title: New Coach in Town
description: The thing I liked about his appointment, Bill Russell was saying a few days ago about the designation Willis Reed as the new Knicks coach, is that nobody said anything about his being black. When I was first appointed they made all this fuss about my being the first black coach and I said then that the time it would become important was when nobody mentioned anymore.

title: PRESIDENT INSISTENT ON ENERGY CUTBACKS
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 17President Carter strongly hinted today that the fuelconservation measures he plans to offer Congress next month may be sufficiently painful to damage him politically.

title: CARTER URGES U.N. TO STEP UP EFFORTS FOR HUMAN RIGHTS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17President Carter brought his campaign for human rights to the United Nations tonight, asserting that the world body had allowed its human rights machinery. to be ignored and sometimes politicized.

title: French Senator Statts China Visit
description: PEKING, March 17 (Agenoe FrancePresse)  Andrd Colin, chairman of the foreign affairs, defense and armed forces committee of the French Senate, arrived here today for a twoweek visit. Senator Colin is the first French political figure to visit China since the purge last October of the four ultraleftists led by the late Chairman Mao Tsetung's widow, Chiang Ching.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Soeclal to The Nev York Times

title: Carter's Rights Lawyer, a Black, Says He'll Limit Demand for Busing
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 AP)The black activist who is the Carter Administration's chief civil rights lawyer says that courts should not order citywide school desegregation to remedy limited instances of illegal racial segregation.

title: Frank White Buffalo Man Is Dead; Was Promoter of Indian Culture
description: MILWAUKIE, Ore., March 17 (AP)Frank White Buffalo Man, a popular promoter of Northwest Indian culture who said that he was a grandson of the Sioux leader Sitting Bull, died yesterday at his home here. He was 73 years old.

title: The New York Times/Fred R. Conrao
description: The New York Times/Fred R. Conrao

title: From Negative to Neutral on Race?
description: A recent Supreme Court decision approving a state plan to redistrict Brooklyn has drawn heated criticism. The strongest objection has been against the Legislature's deliberate use of racial formulas to redraw the districts under the Voting Rights Act of 1965. That, the critics contend, is discrimination just as bald as what the act was intended to stop. They also argue that the state plan encourages bloc voting and discourages dispersal racial minorities. These are honorable views, but they are too narrow. They ignore social history and political reality, which give meaning to the Supreme Court's judgment in this case.

title: PENN CENTRAL PROPOSES PAYING IN STOCK ABROAD
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (AP)Officials of the bankrupt Penn Central Company have announced a plan to give foreign creditors 1.5 million shares of stock in the reorganized Penn Central Transportation Company to settle debts of about $130 million.

title: Texas Railroad Group Orders Full Capacity Oil Production
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 17 (UPI)The Texas Railroad Commission, noting an urgent need for a comprehensive national energy policy, today ordered all oil wells in the state to produce at full capacity in April.

title: Skiing
description: WORLD CUP Men's Giant Slalom.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Committee against Apartheid11 A.M.

title: Prices of Soybeans Rise and Then Fall; Close Is Mostly Off
description: CHICAGO, March 17 (AP)Soybean futures prices bounced around like a rubber ball on the Chicago Board of Trade today, advancing 23 cents, then closing mostly lower under late profit taking.

title: Notes on People
description: Only hours after he warned against a unilateral rush into renewed diplomatic relations with Cuba, Gale W. McGee, former Senator from Wyoming, was unanimously approved by the Senate to be Ambassador to the Organization of American States. Before the voice vote, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee heard Mr. McGee say that I don't think we ought to be racing pell melt toward renewed relations with Cuba. He added: The President has made it clear he is interested in some movement in that direction, some token movement in order to test the waters. There ought to be a blend. It has to involve more than unilateral action. He also noted that Cuba, which has been suspended from the organization, manifests no interest in returning to membership. Mr. McGee's Senate approval came on his 62d birthday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday incorrectly identified a member of the City Taxi and Limousine Commission who criticized its raising taxicab fares. His name is Albert Kreindler.

title: F. B. I. to Use 400 Agents in Effort to Clear Backlog Of Inquiries About Files
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Federal Bureau of Investigation, besieged by thousands of citizens who want to know what the bureau has in its files about them, will summon 400 agents here this summer in an effort to eliminate a backlog of Freedom of Information requests.

title: Aide of Frank B. Hall & Co. Quits After an Investigation on Expenses
description: William A. Baxter, executive vice president of Frank B. Hall & Company, an international insurance brokerage concern, resigned Wednesday following a company investigation that uncovered some $400,00 worth of expanses authorized by Mr. Baxter and others which were incorrectly recorded on a subsidiary's books, the company announced yesterday.

title: AllStar Hockey
description: ForwardsKip Churchill, Union, sophomore; Tom McMullen, American International College, junior; Dave R, st, Army, senior.

title: 2 BOYS FACING TRIAL IN WOMAN'S SLAYING
description: Two boysone 12 years old and the other 15were held yesterday for trial April 12 in the fatal beating of an 80year old Brooklyn woman.

title: U. S. Tariffs, Global Risks
description: The United States International Trade Commission left President Carter with a globalsized headache this week. It recommended a cut in sugar import quotas from million tons a year to fewer than 4? million and a hike in tariffs on color television sets from 5 percent to percent. Last month, in a similar decision, the commission suggested additional tariff protection for the shoe industry. In each case, the President has the choice of accepting the commission's recommendation within 60 days or risk being overridden by majority vote Congress.

title: North Korean Official in Japan Looking to Talks With U.S. on Ties
description: TOKYO, March 17A North Korean official resident in Japan suggested here today that now was a good time for normalization of relations between the United States and North Korea.

title: Leyland's Strike Ends as Workers Faced Dismissal
description: LONDON, March 17A protracted strike against Britain's largest auto maker ended today, after damaging the prestige of the Labor Government, blighting the reputation of the manufacturer and costing its workers millions of dollars in lost wages.

title: Cargill Reports Unusual Payments Made Abroad
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 17 (UPI)Cargill Inc. and its affiliates made unusual payments totaling about $5 million, mostly to foreign countries, from mid1971 through last year, the company said today.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT BOSTON

title: General Walker Free on Bond
description: DALLAS, March 17 (AP)Retired Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker, known as an advocate of conservative causes, was free on $400 bond today after being charged with public lewdness for the second time in less than a year. Officers said that a park policeman, R. H. Bennedict, accused General Walker, 67 years old, of making physical advances to him in a men's restroom Tuesday night at Reverchon Park.

title: Many Marchers and a MillionWatchers Paint Town Green
description: Twas the only day of the year when a dyed green carnation will win out easily over a perfect rose, when the bright white lines on Fifth. Avenue pale beside a center stripe of Kelly and the American flag is outnumbered by the green, white and orange, banner of Irelanda great day for the Irish, for street vendors, souvenir hawkers and tavern owners.

title: Jazz: Drumming Up a Storm
description: PhiIly Joe Jones, the celebrated modern jazz drummer who was with Miles Davis's influential combos of the 1950's and early 60's is making his first New York nightclub appearance in seven years this week at Ali's Alley, 77 Greene Street, in Sollo. Aside from one memorable night at Town Hall last year, with the Collective Black Artists's big band, Mr. Jones has been keeping a low profile in Philadelphia, but his powers have not diminished. Indeed, he seems to be playing With at least as much fire and virtuosity as he_ displayed in the 1950's.

title: Knicks Recover for a Victory Over Nuggets, 115107
description: DENVER, March 17  In Earl Monroe's mind, the Knicks hit rock bottom when they were thrashed in Phoenix. 12491, last night. But with Monroe and Bob McAdoo doing most of the heavy work during a hardfought second half. Tonight, New York scored an impressive 115107 National Basketball Association victory over the Denver Nuggets in McNichols Sports Arena.

title: How Invasion Developed
description: KINSHASA, March 17At this distance from the invaded area, with no telephone connections to a region 1,500 miles away, it is difficult to discern fact from the host of rumors circulating here. But according to Western diplomats who themselves have had no chance at firsthand observation, the invasion began on March 8.

title: McCullough Leads Golf By ???
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., March 17The head hunters are here, working in much the same way their opposite numbers operate at a convention of university professors. In this case the targets are touring golf professionals, and the head hunters are promoters, sponsors and representatives of tournaments who are recruiting players for their events, working hardest on the bigname players such as Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer and Lee TreviThey come from such places as Coal Valley, Ill.; Endicott, N.Y. and Mason, Ohio, and the reason they have descended on this beach resort 25 miles south of Jacksonville is that the fourth Scores on Page A20. won the T.P.C. twice shot a oneoverpar 73 and Al Geiberger, the 1975 winner, carded 77.

title: Pro Transactions
description: NEW YORK (AL)Signed Fred Stanley, shortstop, to threeyear contract.

title: Jews Send Thanks To Moslem Envoys For Help in Siege
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The 10th Surah of the Koran says that mankind were only one nation, then they fell into variance. The elusive dream of world unity came a tiny step closer to realization last week when three Moslems negotiated the release of 134 hostages, most of them Jews, from their Moslem captors.

title: Rustow Study Says Potential of OPEC Lags on Oil Needs
description: By 1935. a thin margin is expected to exist between the industrialized world's thirst for imported oil and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries desire to quench it, according to the latest study on future world supplies.

title: United Press International
description: River yesterday. River traffic is expected to be blocked until the collapsed sections are located and then removed. The bridge is 93 years old.

title: CARTER SENDS LETTER TO SOOTHE CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, March 17President Carter, in a letter to members of Congress, has attempted to assuage resentment generated by his suspension of funds for 19 water resource projects in his 1978 budget.

title: Carter View Disturbs Israelis
description: TEL AVIV, March 17President Carter's statement on a homeland for the Palestinian refugees disturbed Israelis who are dead set against a Palestinian Arab state between Jordan and Israel.

title: A Savory Guide To the Town's Best Brunches
description: THOSE WHO VIEW Sunday morning as the time to lounge at home in bathrobes with endless pots of coffee would have a hard time imagining Manhattan's stylish brunch scene, never livelier than during the spring.

title: Maine's Drinking Age Raised
description: AUGUSTA, Me., March 17 (UPI)Gov. lames B. Longley today signed a bill to raise the drinking age from 18 to 20 in Maine and commended the legislature for coming to grips with the issue of underage drinking.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS CARTER REBATE PLAN BY PARTYLINE VOTES
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Senate Finance Committee today in effect approved President Carter's $50 tax rebate, the cornerstone of his economic stimulus program this year, by narrowly rejecting two Republican amendments offering perManenttax cuts instead.

title: Carter Team to Weigh Economic Impact of New Rules
description: WASHINGTON. March 17The Carter Administration's top economic policy team has agreed to a stringent new program requiring Federal agencies to measure the impact of regulations on the economy before they are imposed.

title: Renoir Cinema Opens Without Illusions
description: The city gets a new movie house this weekendthe Jean Renoir Cinemawhich is a product of unlikely parts an unprepossessing theater space in the East Village, a letter of approval from the 82yearold French film maker, and a partnership composed of a soap opera ingenue, a precocious film aficionado and a female projectionist.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON MORE TRANSIT AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Deliaftment of Transportation and Senators framing new masstransit legislation were in agreement today on most aspects of Senate committee plan to make about $??? billion available for transit capital and operating aid over the next five years.

title: Search to Begin for Legendary New Mexican Treasure
description: LAS CRUCES, N. M., March 17The Lost Dutchman Mine is much more famous and the fabled Seven Cities of Cibola is richer by far. But any day now, barring bad weather or judicial intervention, the treasure of Vittorio Peak may surpass them both as the stuff of which lush and fevered fantasies are spun. Then again it may not.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter, in the General Assembly of the United Nations, asserted that the organization had allowed its human rights machinery to be ignored and sometimes politicized. He said There is much that can be done to strengthen it, and suggested that the United Nations Commission on Human rights meet more often and that it move from Geneva to New York. The President touched on a number of other subjects in his speech, which was also intended to emphasize his Administration's support for the United Nations. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNCN. Grande Valse Brillante, Chopin; Overture to La Fine de Madame Angot, Lecocq Questa Fanciulla, Landini; Symphony in D minor, W.F. Bach Rondo in B flat, Rodriguez; Overture to Richard Coeur de Lion, Gretry; La Campanella. Liszt.

title: Dublin's Parade Has a U.S. Flavor
description: DUBLIN, March 17Most of the Americans arrived yesterday, wearing green pants, green caps, green neckties and warm, green goodwill.

title: Revue: Wine and Laughs for Lunch
description: IN JOHN VON HARTZ's new comedy revue, A Little Wine With Lunch (at the No Smoking Playhouse), lunch is a time for a confrontation and revelation. Eating can be incidental, although the wine never stops flowing. If there is a lesson to he learned from this delectable, vintage entertainment, it is in vino veritas and laughter.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN SOME WAY, Thomas Berger has gone over to the enemy. That is, in Who Is Teddy Villanova? his eighth novelhe seems to have given up on language and intelligence as means of coping with the modern world, especially in New York. He seems also to have given up on Protestantism, considering what happens to Calvin, Knox and Zwingli in these pages. About all he hasn't given up on are the consolations of heterosexuality. Those polymorphous perverts and their tracts on venereal liberation will never get him.

title: Conversation Piece Under the Sun
description: MIAMI, March 17George Bamberger, Orioles pitching coach, whose disciples invariably are blessed with deceptive changeofpace: We want each man to develop four pitchesfastball, curve, slider and change. How do you teach a changeup? Depends on the pitcher. With some you can say, pull down the shade, that is, come over the top with your regular fastball motion but instead of coming through you bring your hand straight down as though you're pulling down a window shade. With others you suggest they hold the ball with these three fingers across the seams and the thumb and forefinger alongside the ball. The main thing though is to bring the ball out front of you. Look at the whip in my wrist at the end of my fastball motion. That imparts the speed. Now turn the palm out a trifle, thumb dawn, and throw. See? The wrist doesn't break. You throw as hard as you can but there's no whip to give it speed.

title: House Votes $15 Million For Preliminary Research Into Development of SST
description: WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP)Almost exactly six years after Congress killed the American supersonic transport, the House voted today to spend $15 million for preliminary research into such a plane. But it stipulated that no money could be spent on designing or developing a new SST prototype without specific Congressional approval.

title: British Petroleum Profits Doubled In Fourth Quarter on Rise in Sales
description: The British Petroleum Company, a major company that operates in all phases of petroleum, reported yesterday that its profits had doubled in the fourth quarter of 1976 and were up 8.5 percent for all of last year, reflecting increased sales and improved prices.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (millions of dollars) Daily Averages for the weeks ended:

title: Beame Will Sue To Bar the Jets In Jersey Move
description: An angry Mayor Beame yesterday directed the city to take four major sports powers to court to prevent the Jets from playing the first two home games of their season in New Jersey.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter, in the General Assembly of the United Nations, asserted that the organization had allowed its human rights machinery to be ignored and sometimes politicized. He said There is much that can be done to strengthen it, and suggested that the United Nations Commission on Human rights meet more often and that move from Geneva to New York. The President touched on a number of other subjects in his speech, which was also intended to emphasize his Administration's support for the United Nations. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Elderly Patients Face Transfer From Home for Being Healthy
description: WOODBURY, L.I.  For 50 years Anna C. Schreiber worked as a saleswoman in a Manhattan department store. She retired on a pension of $48.50 a month and Social Security. She soon realized that inflation had eaten up the value of her only income. So, Miss Schreiber, who was an elder in the United Presbyterian Church, sought refuge in a churchsponsored home. She entered it two years ago thanks to Medicaid.

title: Meat and Potatoes Co. to Offer The Alchemist
description: Ben Janson's The Alchemist will be performed by the Meat and Potatoes Company tonight, tomorrow and Sunday evening at 8 P.M. at 58 West 39th Street. Tickets are $2.50.

title: Market Place
description: Now that interest rates on taxexempt bonds have eased somewhat from record levels, investors are scouring the market for high coupon taxexempts. They do so, in at least one case, at their peril.

title: YankeeRed Sox Rivalry Budding After First Brushback of Spring
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 17 With their latest skirmish already engraved in the lore of their intense rivalry, the New York Yankees and Boston Red Sox both chartered buses out of here this morning, the Yankees heading for Vero Beach and the Red Sox for West Palm Beach.

title: Management
description: What Unites the New Jersey Dental Association, the Wall and Ceiling. Contractors Association and the Georgia Poultry Associationnot to mention New England's Little Wanderers? Their top officials all belong to an association of associations, the American Society of Association Executives, or A.S.A.E.

title: Land Boom in North Hills Vexes Nassau
description: NORTH HILLS, L.I., March 15Somebody once called the Bois de Boulogne the lungs of Paris. By the same reasoning, the village of North Hills has served as the security blanket of Nassau County.

title: New Face
description: When he was a boy, Paul Dooley wanted to be a cartoonist. He also wanted to be a clown. Later, in high school and college, his movie heroes were the great funny men of the silents Chaplin, Keaton, Laurel and Hardyand he spent hours unreeling rented prints of their early films on a friend's projector. He envied the bygone vaudevillians, longed for the shtick and the old shoftshoe.

title: Doctor Testifies on Bullet Scars in Chesimard Trial
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, March 17Dr. David Spain, director of pathology at Brookdale College in Brooklyn, testified today that an examination of Joanne Chesimard's bullet scars and Xray reports supported her version of how she was shot during a gunfight on the New Jersey Turnpike nearly four years aso.

title: Youth Pleads Guilty in Controversial Beating Case
description: Ronald Timmons, a 19yearold Bronx youth who was the cause of a public outcry over the treatment of youthful offenders when he jumped a low bail of $500 that was set despite his long juvenile record, pleaded guilty yesterday to robbing and beating an 82yearold woman in her Bronx apartment.

title: Restaurants
description: OF THE VARIOUS Chinese regional cuisines that have become popular here during the last 10 or 15 years, that of Hunan is perhaps the most subtle and intriguing. Set halfway between Szechwan and Canton, this province offers dishes reminiscent of boththe chili fired specialties every bit as hot as those of Szechwan, along with a complement of dishes as gently and soothingly seasoned as those of Canton.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 17The State Lottery Commission is being sued by an 82yearold Bayonne man who says the commission has refused to pay off on a winning lottery ticket he submitted for payment.

title: Bridge:
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 17Seven major national championships will be decided here during the next 10 days of play at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, and several titles will have a bearing on future international representation.

title: CLARA RUANO
description: Dr. Clara Ruano, an anesthesiologist, died Friday at her sister's home in Miami Beach. She was 63 years old and a resident of Passaic. N.J.

title: SENATE LEADER ASKS STRONG ETHICS CODE
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, made a strong plea today for a stringent code of ethics to restore the public's confidence in the Senate as efforts were made to defeat a proposed limitation on income and honorariums.

title: Business Records
description: THOMAS HAROLD HAM, 13 Dogwood Hills Road, New. burgh. N.Y. Liabilities, $60.111; assets, 524.790.

title: S.E.C. Will Propose Allowing Dual BrokerAdvisory Roles
description: WASHINGTON, March 17The Securities and Exchange Commission decided today to propose a series of rules under which brokers who also act as investment advisers could continue to conduct both businesses.

title: Ready for Kaminsky Kazoos?
description: No matter what, the Kaminsky International Kazoo Quartetfive strongand members of the Fine on Arts Ensemble will take over Alice Tully Hall tonieht at 8.

title: Worstell Helps Maryland In Rout of Princeton
description: PRINCETON, N.J. March 17Pete Worstell, at attack, scored three goals and one assist today to lead the Maryland Lacrosse team to a 13.3 victory over Princeton on Poe Field.

title: Marquette Advances With Wake Forest
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 17 (AP)Butch Lee hit a driving layup with less than a minute to play to give Marquette a 6766 victory tonight over Kansas State in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest regional semifinals. Marquette will play Wake Forest, which beat Southern Illinois, 8681, in the second game. The Warriors were behind by 8 at the half and dropped behind by 10 several times during the second half.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: BROOKINN HEIGHTS had its Walt Whitman, Brownsville, Robers Merrill of the Metropolitan Opera. And Flatbush? Flatbushthe cradle of doctors, teachers, lawyers and certified public accountantsa solid bastion of upward mobility. Well, there was redhaired Sidney Frumpkin. Sidney, the policeman's son, grew up to become Sidney Franklin, the only Americanborn matador of international stature.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Associated Press BOYLE RELEASED: W. A. Boyle, former president of the. United Mine Workers, leaving prison in Pittsburgh yesterday with his daughter Antoinette. Boyle, wile was convicted in 1974 of ordering the murder of union insurgent Joseph Yablonski and his wife and daughter, was granted a new trial by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court last month.

title: SOME CONSUMER CASES TO BE PAID FOR BY F.E.A.
description: WASHINGTON, March 17In what could be a precedent for wider representation of consumers in regulatory proceedings, the Federal Energy Administration agreed today to pay for intervention by Consumers Union in cases involving costs and prices of three major oil refinine companies.

title: How to Save Israel.:
description: WASHINGTON, March 17This city is on the verge of another fundamental debate on the new Carter Administration's policy in the Middle East, and the debate has been building up in an odd and almost offhand way.

title: Palestinians in Cairo Welcome Carter's Stand on Need for Homeland
description: CAIRO, March 17Yasir Arafat and other Palestinian leaders attending the Palestine National Council voiced welcome today for President Carter's statement on the need for a Palestinian homeland. However, many delegates said it did not go far enough and expressed doubt that the United States would seek to have it carried out.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Dec. 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) Overthecounter. 1976 1975

title: JOHN W. HILL, 86, DIES; LED HILL & KNOWLTON
description: John Wiley Hill, a founder of Hill & Knowlton, the world's largest public relations firm and a confidant of corporate mighties, died yesterday of a brain tumor at his home at 50 East 77th Street. He was 86 years old and had been going to his office almost daily until about four weeks ago.

title: European Soccer
description: Dynamo Kiev 2, Bayern Munich 0. Dynamo Dresden 3, Zurich 2. Borrusia Gladbach 1, Bruges 0. Liverpool 3, Saint Etienne 1.

description: Knicks 115, Denver 107. Milwaukee 101 Boston 91. Kansas City 125, Buffalo 104. Houston 88, Cleveland 87.

title: Man's Move Entitles Wife to Jobless Aid
description: SACRAMENTO (AP)  A husband or wife who quits a job to move to another city with a spouse is eligible for unemployment benefits, the California Unemployment Insurance Board has ruled.

title: 11 in House Seek Inquiry On Charges of Pressure By Kissinger on Leaders
description: WASHINGTON. March 17 Eleven representatives, members of the former House Intelligence Committee, asked the Alsace Department today to investigate a suggestion by William Safire, The New York Times columnist, that Henry A. Kissinger, former Secretary of State, might have improperly tried to pressure the House leadership into stopping the investigation of the nation's intelligence aeencies.

description: TOURNAMENT PLAYERS' CHAMPIONSHIP The Leading Scores.

title: CARTER URGES U.N. TO STEP UP EFFORTS FOR HUMAN RIGHTS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17President Carter brought his campaign for human rights to the United Nations tonight, asserting that the world body had allowed its human rights machinery to be ignored and sometimes politicized.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: Children turn every parent into a bit of a scientist. People who slept through undergraduate biology suddenly find themselves intently watching teeth grow. And people who never talked aboutand perhaps tried not to think aboutintestinal functioning find themselves in animated conversation on the subject.

title: Jazz: The Sounds of Zoot Sims
description: Zoot Sims has been such a consistently swinging jazz saxophonist over the years that he is apt to be taken for granted. He is expected to do what he has always done, but, although he conforms in the sense that he almost never disappoints his listeners, he is much too inventive and secure a musician to settle for a preordained formula, no matter how superficially pleasant.

title: New York and Pennsylvania Held Key to a Halt in SludgeDumping
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J., March 17 (UPI)New Jersey's offshore sludgedumping problem can be solved only if New York and Pennsylvania also agree to stop dumping toxic wastes, according to a state official.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S GAME

title: Carter Team to Weigh Economic Impact of New Rules
description: WASHINGTON. March 17The Carter Administration's top economic policy team has agreed to a stringent new program requiring Federal agencies to measure the impact of regulations on the economy before they are imposed.

title: Pork and Water
description: President Carter has now learned, if he did not already know it, that the most thankless action a President can take is to challenge the porkbarrel traditions of Congress. In a daring move last month, Mr. Carter picked out 19 Federal water projects, already approved, for review and reconsideration, and indicated that their funding would be dropped from the 1978 budget if they were found economically wasteful, environmentally harmful, or both.

title: Senators Favor Lowering Taxes For 46 Million
description: WASHINGTON; March 18The Senate Finance Committee voted today for tax bill provisions that would mean lower taxes for 46 million Americans who use standard deductions, higher taxes for two million single persons who take standard deductions and make more than $13,750, and unchanged taxes for all who itemize deductions.

title: Move on School Break Delayed
description: ALBANY, March 18The plan to revise next year's school calendar to include a fiveweek midwinter break is apparently dead for now. Emlyn J. Griffith of Rome, a state Regent and chief proponent of the plan, has written his fellow Regents suggesting that they postpone a decision on the fiveweek break until after it has been studied.

title: Index of Commodity Prices. Rose To 218.7 From 217.3 in the Week
description: The commodity spotmarket price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 218.7 from 217.3 last week.

title: Massive RushHour Train TieUp Under Investigation by L.I.R.R.
description: The Long Island Rail Road began an investigation yesterday into the breakdown that disrupted virtually all of its rushhour service Thursday night, delaying 76,000 riders two to three hours and leaving nearly 15,000 people trapped in tunnels under the East River for two hours or more.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor Prior to completing the process, in which we all appear to be engaged, of eliminating Vietnam from our nation's history, or at least from our collective memory, we should settle, logically and rationally, the amnesty/ pardon question. To do so, it is not necessary to praise or condemn those who might benefit from such a program.

title: Now the Japanese Pinball Industry Is Atilt
description: OSAKA, JapanAs the pachinko ball business goes, so goes Japan. And today the ball business is bad. That's how the ball bounces, you might say.

title: Court Report on Hughes Shows He Toyed With Staff on Will Revision
description: LOS ANGELES. March 18For six months before Howard R. Hughes died ??? April 5, his toplevel employees had urged him to revise a will they thought had signed that named Nuah Dietrich is trustee of the Hughes estate. Mr. Dietrich, a longtime Hughes aide, lied fallen out with the reclusive industrialist and had come to be regarded as a Hughes enemy.

title: Bugging in Homes, Schools and Offices Helps to Catch Burglars in the Act
description: STAMFORD, Conn  The taperecorded soundsfootsteps, the scraping of metal on metal, squeaking door, heavy breathing, drawers being opened were reminiscent of an oldtime radio mystery program.

title: King Wants An Ali Bout In Havana
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 18Don King, the boxing promoter, announced today that Havana was being sought as the site of Muhammad Ali's next world heavyweight title defense sometime in May against Alfio Rhighetti of Italy.

title: DISTRICT IN BROOKLYN REFUSES NEW TESTS
description: A Brooklyn school board said yesterday that it would not give its 21,000 pupils the March 29 citywide reading test, now being received in the schools, because its easy availability could result in cheating and other serious abuses.

title: Met Offers Berg's Symbolic Lulu
description: Alban Berg's Lulu has finally made it to the Metropolitan Opera. This expressionistic torso of a work, left unfinished by the composerthough experts say that a complete version from Berg's own material is entirely feasiblehas been given all over the world in recent years, but the previous regime at the. Metropolitan staunchly resisted it. The present management, more hospitable to experiment, has now given New Yorkers a chance to make up their own minds.

title: Sports Today

title: Bonn Bugging Scandals Shake Schmidt's Coalition
description: BONN, March 18Continuing revelations of extralegal monitoring of conversations by Government agencies have shaken Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's ruling coalition and are raising questions about whether West Germany's secret services are subject to effective legal controls.

title: Books of The Times
description: Centering on two men, Junker and Jew, Prof. Fritz Stern's Gold and Iron chronicles the hitherto slightly known story of Otto von Bismarck, the statesman, and his banker Gerson Bleichrbder, who thirsted for and finally achieved a von to precede his surname, the supreme emblem of acceptance into the German nobility he served. Equally, this book, based on letters and documents previously unused, is the inside story of the founding of the modern German Empire, compounded of the new world of capitalism and an older world of feudal privilege. In addition, the book is an account of a Jewish success that proved utterly delusive, so much so, in fact, that Bismarck omitted to mention his banker's name in his memoirs.

title: NANCY M'CARTEN
description: A memorial service for Nancy McCarten, wife of the late John McCarter', the film and theater critic for The New Yorker magazine, will be held Monday at 10 A.M. in the Church of the Covenant, 310 East 42d Street.

title: Senators Favor LoweringTaxes For 46 Million
description: WASHINGTON, March 18The Senate Finance Committee voted today for tax bill provisions that would mean lower taxes for 46 million Americans who use standard deductions, higher taxes for two million single persons who take standard deductions and make more than S13.750, and unchanged taxes for all who itemize deductions.

title: William Laurence, ExScience Writer For The Times, Dies
description: MAJORCA, Spain, Saturday, March 19 William L. Laurence, a science reporter who was the only journalist to witness the historic nuclear blast at Alamogordo, N. M., in 1945 and later the only newspaperman permitted to fly on the atomicbomb mission over Nagasaki, Japan, died here today of complications from a blood clot in the brain. He was S9 years old.

title: 'Nasty Habits' of Nuns in Politics
description: The nuns at the Abbey of Crewe are in a swivet. The old Abbess Hildegarde has died 30 seconds prematurelybefore putting her signature to a declaration of intent that Sister Alexandra should succeed her. A contested election is in the offing: Sister Alexandra, handsome, aristocratic, obsessed with power and sense of mission ("Unless I fulfill my destiny, my mother's labor pains were pointless"), versus Sister Felicity, who, while carrying on a madcap affair with a Jesuit brother, draws the support of the younger nuns with her promises to turn the convent into a "love-abbey."The furious Alexandra instructs her two most trusted associates, Sister Walburga, the prioress, and Sister Mildred, chief of the novices, to fix upon a planwithout Alexandra's knowledge, of course.That plan is to steal Felicity's love letters and publicize them in order to discredit her. Unfortunately, the two Jesuit seminarians who are commissioned to carry out the theft bungle it. They're caught in the act. At first it's all explained as simple high spirits. Nobody pays much attention. Alexandra wins the election by a landslide.Then, slowly but inexorably, the word of the strange procedures at Crewe begins to leak out. Stories appear in the press. The Abbey, it's reported, is bugged. Rome becomes interested. Felicity leaps over the wall with her Jesuit lover to appear on television to promote her cause with the determination of a pop singer plugging her autobiography. What to do? Late at night, in the Abbess's elegantly cloistered quarters, Alexandra, Walburga and Mildred discuss possible scenarios.Because most of us know the ending of the Watergate scandal, we know the ending of "Nasty Habits," the screen adaptation of Muriel Spark's 1974 satire, "The Abess of Crewe." Thus our attention must be held not by what happens, but how it's done. Approximately half of "Nasty Habits," which opened yesterday at the Cinema 2, is very funny. The other half is anywhere from awful to merely poor, which isn't good enough for a movie like this any more than it would be for a bottle of wine.The most peculiar thing about the film, which was written by Robert J. Enders and directed by Michael Lindsay-Hogg, is that even as it utilizes great chunks of Miss Spark's marvelous dialogue (I like particularly Alexandra's talk to the nuns in which she defines the difference between "a lady" and, with a sneer, "a bourgeoise"), it also calls attention to the fragility of the novella, emphasizing the ways in which Miss Spark's comic conceit is least effective.Take Sister Alexandra as written by Miss Spark and as played by Glenda Jackson (in her best role in years), she's a supremely interesting comic character  witty, clever, quick-minded, erudite, the sort of woman who, because she is the mistress of great traditions, can bend them. The gulf between Alexandra and the Whittier-educated President she's meant to satirize is funny in the book. On screen, it simply serves to make the satire silly.We root for Alexandra. We cheer her brilliantly devious responses to Rome's criticism about the bugging. It's a paradox, she says airily. The Scriptures, she points out, tell us "'to watch and pray,' which itself is a paradox since the two activities cannot effectively be practiced together, except in the paradoxical sense."Miss Jackson as Sister Alexandra is great fun, but the film that contains her moves uneasily between high comedy and conventional low comedy about a bunch of nuns doing things that are supposed to be funny because nuns are doing them. It's as simple-minded as Leo McCarey's "Bells of St. Mary's," updated without sentiment.The film's setting has been switched from England, the setting of the book and where most of the film was shot, to Philadelphia, perhaps to explain the presence of such American actresses as Geraldine Page and Anne Jackson, who play Haldeman and Ehrlichman types and who match Glenda Jackson's stylish performance line by line, gesture by gesture. I also very much liked Anne Meara as the Gerald Ford of Crewe Abbey.Nothing, though, can explain or make palatable the casting of Melina Mercouri as the abbey's Henry Kissinger and Sandy Dennis as a John Dean sort. Miss Mercouri has the touch of a bull elephant tap-dancing on the floor above.Miss Dennis, mugging outrageously and badly, gives the kind of performance that, 40 years ago, would have sent her to bed without her supper. It's rude, show-offy and, worse, it's incompetent. Watching her do a double-take is like watching a small tug trying to work the QE2 into her Hudson River berth in a gale. It's long and boring.Mr. Lindsay-Hogg has allowed Miss Dennis to go for the easy laugh at the expense of undermining the legitimate performances of the other actresses, including Susan Penhaligon, who plays Sister Felicity, and of the actors like Eli Wallach, Rip Torn and Jerry Stiller, who have small roles as church fathers.Apparently afraid that movie audiences would miss the point, the director and Mr. Enders, who was the film's producer as well as writer, have added lines not in the book ("You won't have Sister Alexandra to kick around anymore") that eventually coarsen Miss Spark's work, making it sound less witty than desperate in the manner of an extended television sketch.

title: Two Hanafi Moslems Arraigned; One Accused of Slashing Hostage
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI)  A judge ordered two jailed Hanafi Moslems bound over for grand jury investigation today after testimony that each held hostages at machete point in last week's siege and one slashed a man severely.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 18Critics of the oil and gas industry have often accused the companies of crying wolf to keep unfavorable legislation from passing. For once, at least, the industry feels vindicated.

title: Britten's Cello Symphony Elicits A Top Performance by Munroe
description: Lorne Munroe, the New York Philharmonic's principal cellist, was the soloist in its program on Thursday night in Avery Fisher Hall, and his vehicle was the late Benjamin Britten's Symphony for Cello and Orchestra. Written in 1963, it is one of four works the composer created for his good friend Mstislav Rostropovich, the great Soviet cellist. With Britten as conductor, it was given its premiere in Moscow and the work was later recorded by them.

title: A Diet HauteCuisine Restaurant Gains That 3d Big Michelin Star

description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (Reuter)Harold Brown, Secretary of Defense, said that today he might rule American bases off limits to union organizers if a serious attempt was made to sign up military personnel.

title: Gold Exceeds $150, Highest Since 1975

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A 21yearold New York City man was sentenced in Hackensack to 25 to 30 years in prison for beating and stabbing to death an eldery New Jersey antiques dealer who had refused to pay $30 for a homosexual liaison. The defendant, Theodore Smith, originally from East Brunswick pleaded guilty in January to the July 11 killing of Gerlot Schmidt, 62, whom he met in a Greenwich Village bar.

title: Amex Votes to Admit Foreigners
description: Members of the American Stock Exchange voted yesterday to ratify constitutional amendments to allow foreign membership on the exchange. The proposal, which had been sent to the membership by the Amex board of governors, will now go to the Securities and Exchange Commission for final approval.

title: Houston Policeman Backs Report of Police Brutality
description: HOUSTON, March 16Late last Friday night, Dernas Benoit Jr., a 20yearold carpenter who lives with his parents in a black neighborhood in northeast Houston was stopped by the police after long highspeed chase that began when he allegedly passed a red light and ignored an officer's signal to stop.

description: DETROIT, March 18 (UPI)Negotiators for General Motors and the United Auto Workers reached agreement early today on a new local contract that headed off a strike at the concern's Lakewood, Ga., assembly plant.

title: Ecologists Give Qualified Approval To a CabinetLevel Energy Agency
description: WASHINGTON, March 18Environmentalists endorsed today the idea of unified, cabinetlevel Department of Energy, although they disagreed with the Carter Administration proposal in some particulars.

description: HOUSTON, March 18 (AP)Jennie Bell Morrow Decker, a granddaughter of Texas revolution hero Sam Houston, died yesterday at the age of 106.

title: Beame Wins First Battle In Legal War Over Jets; Restraining Orders Given

description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 18 Unlike Lou Gehrig and Reggie Jackson, Marty Perez doesn't think he's lucky to be a Yankee.
