description: WASHINGTON, March 18Consumer prices surged 1 percent in February, the biggest advance in nearly two and a half years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Occupation at WBAIFM Ended With Arrest of Five for Contempt
description: The occupation at WBAIFM by the radio station's staff and some listener supporters ended yesterday as five persons who refused to comply with a court order to leave were arrested.

title: Atlanta 500 Field Reaches 30
description: HAMPTON, Ga., March 18 (UPI)Bobby Allison sped around the Atlanta International Raceway at 157.847 miles per hour today and gained the 16th starting position for Sunday's $166,790 Atlanta 500 stock car race, Fourteen other drivers also qualified on the second day of trials, raising the field to 30 with 10 other spots to be filled tomorrow.

title: Spring to Bloom at 12:43 P.M. Tomorrow
description: Spring begins tomorrow 43 minutes after midday, according to astronomers at the American MuseumHayden Planetarium. The event is known as the vernal equinox because of the popular belief that it is the time when day and night are of equal length.

title: AREA INFLATION RATE BELOW OTHER CITIES
description: The inflation rate in the last year has been slower for the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area than for any of the 12 other major metropolitan areas in the country, according to Consumer Price Index figures compiled by the Bureau of Labor statistics.

title: MRS. GANDHI WINDS UP REGIME'S VOTE DRIVE
description: NEW DELHI, March 18Prime Minister Indira Gandhi wound up her reelection campaign today by declaring at one rally after another that only her Government could insure stability and development for India.

title: BEANIE PANEL URGES CITY LABOR REVISIONS
description: In an unusually blunt assessment of city labor practices an advisory panel chosen by Mayor Beame called yesterday for an end to unqualified political appointees in city government and for the adoption of sweeping collectivebargaining revisions to strengthen the hand of management.

title: U.N. Diplomats Pleased by Carter's Specific Commitments on Rights
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 18President Carter's proposals for moves to strengthen respect for human rights has evoked favorable response from many diplomats, who said today that they had not expected such specific commitments.

title: U.S. Reports Angola Support
description: WASHINGTON, March 18The State Department said today for the first time that Angola was providing logistic support to the forces that have invaded Zaire from Angola and are Moving toward Kolwezi. The department said that its information was that the invading forces were still 90 to 150 miles from Kolwezi.

title: Marriage in Kiev Not Complete Without a Gala Dinner
description: KIEV. U.S.S.ROne young bride was ascending the staircase, her long white gown daintily hoisted. Another was exchanging vows with her groom and a third, fresh from the ceremony, was descending. A fourth bridal party had just arrived downstairs and was jostling earlier guests in the clockroom. The big of brown wedding palace on Karl Liebknecht Street had 27 weddings on the day's schedule, slow for a Saturday. The more popular season is summer, but a drizzle did not discourage a succession of freshfaced couples from plunging into matrimony.

title: Major Aid to State Expected From U.S. Under Transit Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 18New York and New Jersey transportation officials looked forward today to major benefits from the proposed stretchout of the existing Federal masstransit assistance program through 1982 involving $5.7 billion in new funds.

title: In Memoriam
description: JACOBSONJeanne S. died January 5, 1977. My wonderful, wonderful wile. You and I together with our children and grandchildren would have celebrated our Golden Wedding anniversary, March 19, 1977. God willed it otherwise. I miss you terribly, Not a moment are you out of my mind My darling. I shall love you always and heart. Rest In Peace.

title: News Summary
description: The Zaire Government flew troop reinforcements to Shaba Province in an attempt to halt the advance of invading forces from neighboring Angola before they reached the coppermining center of Kolwezi. The invaders, mostly former Katangan militiamen who fled the mining region into Angola exite in 1963. were estimated to number 2,000 men. [Page 1, Column 1.]

description: WASHINGTON, March 18The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.6 billion tonmiles, 8.6 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 472.488 cars, 5.4 percent above last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage was 7.9 percent above last year.

title: Courteous Drivers Given Tickets
description: BARRINGTON, R.I., March 19 (UPI)The police are looking for the most polite motorists in this affluent suburban community. Patrolmen have issued 33 tickets to good drivers since they started jotting down the license numbers of courteous drivers in January, Chief Stanley Gontarz said.

title: First, Shop Around
description: A coop can save you up to 40 percent on your food bills. But before rushing to join, make sure you know everything that is expected of you as a member. What membership fees are there? How much work will you be required to do? When can you shop, or pick up your food if it is prepaid? Time truly is money here, and the more of the first you spend, the more of the second you'll save.

title: Nebraska Schedules 3 Executions
description: LINCOLN, Neb., March 18 (UPI)The ebraska Supreme Court today set the Elates for the executions of three of the four men on the state's death row, opening the possibility of the first executions in the state's electric chair in 18 years. Erwin Charles Simants, 30 years old, of Sutherland; Richard Dean Holtan, 41, a transient, and John Edward Rust, 25, el Omaha, are to be executed within five days of each other, beginning with Mr. Holtan on June 27, the court said. Mr. Rust's execution was set for June 29, and Mr. Simants was scheduled July 1.

title: A Wild Goose Breaks the Golden Egg
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 18His hair always looks as if it were styled by an electrician. But today his long gray hair appeared higher than usual. Grayer, too, Don King was still in shock from Jimmy Young's upset of George Foreman in a unanimous 12round decision last night. The fox had bearded the lion. But as Don King schemed for a rematch that might restore George Foreman's credibility, he was muttering in a different imagery.

title: and a BelleEpoque House Loses Its Rooster
description: PARIS, March 18Three years ago, the stars stopped shining on L'Escargot Montorgueil. Now, the black rooster has vanished from beside its name.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: For high tide at Asbury Parle and Belmir, deduct 34 min. from Sand/ Hook time. For high tide at Atlantic City (Steel Pier), deduct 26 min. from Sandy Hook time. For hleti tide at Jones Inlet (PI. Lookout), deduct 19 min from Sandy Hook time.

title: Berlin, a Vanguard in Cold War, Now Seems a Casualty of Detente
description: WEST BERLINIn the cold war, this city of two million people was a brave symbol of Western freedom and prosperity 110 miles inside Communist East Germany. Today, in the anguish of urban decline, some Berliners are wondering whether their city has become a casualty of detente.

title: Arrests by Syria's Lebanon Units Follow Killings of 100 Christians
description: BEIRUT, March 18Syrian troops of the Arab peacekeeping force have made a number of arrests in an effort to check a wave of reprisal killings that followed the assassination Wednesday of Kamal Jumblat, the Lebanese leftist and Moslem leader.

title: ForeignInvestment Law Details Disclosed by Chilean Government
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 18 (AP)Thee military Government has disclosed details of a new foreigninvestment law designed to speed the flow of capital into Chile's ailing economy.

title: Bratha
description: AXELRODMorris. Beloved husband of Barbara, devoted father of Francine and Psnny, cherished grandfather of Ginger and Patrick. Loving brother of Cal and Irene. Services Sunday, 10:00 A.M., The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Stuyvesant Town Tenant, 76, Slain In Apparent Mugging in Vestibule
description: A 76yearold man believed to have been returning from filing his incometax returns was stabbed to death during an apparent robbery last night in the vestibule of his apartment building in Stuvvesant Town the police reported.

title: Second Suit Charges Bias In Chicago House Sales
description: CHICAGO, March 18 (UPI)A group of homeowners filed a suit in Federal court today, charging a real estate cooperative and seven other concerns with racial discrimination in the sale of houses in the tense Marquette Park area. The lawsuit, filed by both black and white homeowners, was the second by the Leadership Council for Metropolitan Open Communities.

title: Powerful Rock By Bob Seger And His Band
description: When a rockandroller who has put in a lengthy regional apprenticeship finally achieves national recognition, there is usually cause for rejoicing. Local rock scenes can be limiting, for there is always pressure to copy the work of established groups. But there is also a maturity that comes from nightly interplay with audiences that really cannot be acquired any other way.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Forces Labor Into NoConfidence Test in Commons
description: LONDON, March 187The Conservative opposition to Britain's Labor Government forced Prime Minister James Callaghan into a test of strength today, raising the possibility of a general election at a time when the Tories would be considered heavy favorites.

title: Nets Impress Cavaliers but Still Lose, 10188
description: UNIONDALE, LI., March 18Not that anyone was counting, but the New York Nets were mathematically eliminated from the National Basketball Association playoffs tonight.

title: Snow Halts Suffolk Racing
description: BOSTON, March 18 (AP)  Racing was halted after the fourth race at Suffolk Downs today because of a snowstorm, a spokesman for the thoroughbred track announced.

title: Increased Flows Reported In 5 Biggest U.S. Rivers
description: WASHINGTON, March 18Increased supplies of water are flowing in streams in the West and Middle West, the United States Geological Survey said today, but it warned that the improvement was temporary and drought conditions remain serious in many areas.

title: Michael's Pub Series Closing With Some High, Low Notes
description: Michael's Pub Series Closing WithSomeHigh,Low NotesThe series of programs based on Alec Wilder's book American Popular Song, which has been running at Michael's Pub since the beginning of last month, is winding up with some high notes and some low notes. This week and next, the final fortnight of the series, the singers are Mary Mayo, whose specialty is high, puretoned vocalization, and Johnny Hartman, whose rich, resonant baritone gives his songs an unusually sturdy sound.

title: Met Pitchers Stay Hot, Beat Cards
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 18The New York Mets headed tonight for a fast weekend in the Dominican Republic after nudging the St. Louis Cardinals, 21, in 10 innings, for their sixth victory in eight springtraining starts.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: 1 YOUTH KILLED, 19 INJURED IN UPSTATE BUS ACCIDENT
description: DANSVILLE. N.Y. March 18 (AP)Nineteen persons remained in critical, serious or guarded condition after a bus accident in Steuben County todaythat killed a 17yearold Pennsylvania hockey player.

title: And Now, Another Completely New (Unique) Thesaurus
description: In the harsh soil of contemporary language blooms the verbiferous thesaurus, giving color to thought, fragrance to expression, shade to meaning and poetic license to copywriters.

title: BEAM PANEL URGES CITY LABOR REVISIONS
description: In an unusually blunt assessment of city labor practices, an advisory panel chosen by Mayor Beame called yesterday for an end to unqualified political appointees in city government and for the adoption of sweeping collectivebargaining revisions to strengthen the hand of management.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST$9,000, Pace, cl., mile.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: The [Druse] sect originated in the time of alHakim, the 6th imam of the Fatimid dynasty of Egypt and North Africa, who ruled between 996 and 1021. AlHakim was a strange man, noted both for his generosity and moralizing and for his cruelty. He disappeared in 1021 in mysterious circumstances, presumably having been murdered.

title: Chicago Relief Queen Guilty
description: CHICAGO. March 18 (AP)  A woman known as the welfare queen was convicted last night of welfare fraud and perjury for using two aliases to collect 23 public aid checks worth $8,000.

title: Capitals 50 Victors As Crozier Excels
description: LANDOVER, Md., March IS (AP)Roger Crozier appearing in his second game for Washington, played two brilliant periods as the Capitals rolled to a 50 National Hockey League victory over the Colorado Rockies tonight.

title: PRESIDENT PLEDGES FOREIGN AID CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON. March 18President Carter promised today to root out mismanagement and inefficiency in United States foreign aid programs and to demand from recipients high standards in using the aid and in respecting basic human rights.

title: Personal Investing
description: For the latest two decades or so, coin collectors have had everything their way. In 1965, for example, a United States halfdollar of the 1900 series In mint condition sold for about S50. Today, the same coin goes for around $400.

title: Coaches of Houston, Bonnies View Final With Caution
description: The Houston Cougars gave Coach Guy Lewis his 400th career basketball victory by beating nationally ranked Alabama, 8276, Thursday night.

title: Seiberling Recalls 5,500 Tires
description: BARBERTON, Ohio, March 18 (UPI)The recall of 5,500 Power Trac Lug tires in size 10I5LT, sold in the replacement market, was announced today by the Seiberling Tire and Rubber Company because of insufficient rubber in the tread base area. The tires, used on small pickup trucks and fourwheeldrive vehicles were produced from August 1976 to February 1977.

title: Britain Counters Funds Inflow
description: LONDON, March IS (Reuters)The Bank of England today took action to restrain the fall in shortterm British interest rates and to reduce the flood of overseas funds into London.

title: Roots Has Widespread and Inspiring Influence
description: Kunta Kinte Reid, a 7pound, 11ounce baby boy, was born to John and Nethertiti Reid in Harlem Hospital on Feb. 18.

title: Pakistani Police Wound 20 in Riots Over Arrest of Opposition Leaders
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, March 18 (Reuters)More than 20 persons were wounded here today when the police fired shotguns during riots over the arrest of four opposition leaders, reliable sources said.

title: The Murder of a Gentleman
description: PARISKamal Jumblat, the Lebanese leftist who was murdered by gunmen Wednesday, was both an original personality and a great gentleman. He belonged to a special breed in the Arabized Middle East, which included King Abdul Azziz ibn Saud, who created a country and a dynasty; the Emir Abdullah of Transjordan; Hassanein Pasha, a cultivated explorer who tried unsuccessfully to educate Egypt's last king, Farouk, and Mullah Mustapha Barzani, the brave Kurdish chief.

title: Notes on People
description: In state Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday, Alan Jay Lerner, the play. Wright and lyricist whose Broadway credits include My air Lady, was taken to task by Justice Beatrice Shain. swit for pleading poverty to avoid payment of alimony and child support, Mr. Lerner's claimed condition of poverty could Well be the envy of 99 per cent of our entire population, Jus tice Shainswit wrote in an opinion a case brought by Micheline Lerner, seeking $12,000 in arrears covering threemonth period. Justice Shainswit made the caustic observation that Mr, Lerner's position is that his wife and son must be penalized because in the 11 years since the divorce, he has luxuriated in a lavish life style. She noted that Mr. Lerner did not document his alleged poverty, except for his concurrent confession that his income for 1976 has dwindled to a mere $250,000. She directed that a special referee determine Mr. Lerner's true assets and true income.

title: Russell Patterson Is Dead at 82; Set the Fashions for Flapper Era
description: Russell Patterson, the illustrator, cartoonist and designer whose slick, sophisticated drawings created many of the fashions of the flapper and collegiate eras of the 1920's, died Thursday night at Atlantic City Hospital of heart failure. He was 82 years old.

title: Music: Grosse Fuge Is Heard
description: Beethoven's Grosse Fuge, the contrapuntal edifice that he originally intended as the finale of his String Quartet in B flat (Op. 130), was replaced by him with a more tractable movement and published as a separate work. Some groups nowadays reinstate the great fugue to its place at the end of Op. 130, but because of its length and extraordinary difficulty, most players are glad to pass It by.

title: Walter H. Van Hoesen Dies at 79
description: Walter H. Van Hoesen, who started out as a writer and later turned to freight forwarding, died Thursday at the Ashbrook Nursing Home in Scotch Plains, N.J., at the age of 79. He was a resident of Fanwood. N.J.

title: Spring Will Blossom 12:43 P.M. Tomorrow
description: Spring begins tomorrow 43 minutes after midday, according to astronomers at the American Museum  Hayden Planetarium. The event is known as the vernal equinox because of the popular belief that it is the time when day and night are of equal length.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONWith a new communicatnig system, a utility can read a household meter without interrupting the power it is providing. American Science and Engineering Inc., Cambridge, Mass., received a patent for the method this week.

title: President's Science Adviser
description: There are few men who have known the pulse of the earth so intimately as Frank Pressits tremors, its free oscillations like those of a reverberating bell and all its other movements that tell about the planet's rigid, notsorigid and liquid interior. Because such Knowledge bears on two critical issues of our timeunderground nuclear tests and predicting earthquakesDr. Press has spent enough time in Washington to know not only the forces that have shaped the earth, but also those that shape political and scientific decisions. His nomination yesterday as science adviser to President Carter, therefore, is no surprise, particularly in view of the President's reported declaration that he wanted an earth scientist rather than a physicist for the post.

title: Spring Slips on Snow on Way to Opening
description: The notion that things were looking very much like spring was dashed yesterday by an abrupt replay of winter.

title: Roosevelt
description: Hotses listed in order of cost ??? ??? Letter designates OTB listing.

title: Burke and Newark Officials Meet on School Crisis
description: NEWARK, March 18Dr. Fred G. Burke, the New Jersey Commissioner of Education, met with Newark school authorities today to discuss new plans for dealing with what he called the city's educational crisis.

title: NICHOLAS J. STEHNICKY
description: Nicholas S. Stehnicky, a retired second vice president of the Sheraton Corporation of America, died yesterday at Morristown Memorial Hospital in New Jersey. He was 64 years old and lived in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: Donald Emery, 58; Educator Served Westchester County
description: Donald G. Emery, an educator and assistant superintendent of the Board of Cooperative Educational Service for Southern Westchester County, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital. He was 58 years old and a resident of the Town of Greenburgh.

title: Leyland Announces $119.7 Million Profit
description: LONDON, March 17 (Fleuters)British Leyland announced today a record $119.7 million profit for the last 15 monthsone day after a potentially crippling strike at the comnany ended.

title: Upset of U.C.L.A. a Rarity in National Playoffs
description: LEXINGTON. Ky., March 18For the first time in 11 years and only the second time in 14 years, the University of California, Los Angeles, will not be one of the teams in the semifinal round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship. Even more surprising, the Bruins failed to make the final of the West regional playoff because they were beaten by Idaho State, 7675, in the biggest of many upsets so far in the 39th N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Copper Prices Increased For 2d Time This Month
description: Several major copper companies announced yesterday the second price increase for the metal this month. The conflict in Zaire, a major African copper producer, and coming labor negotiations in the domestic industry spurred the rise.

title: HEAD OF F.P.C. DENIES PENALIZING THE STAFF
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)Richard L. Dunham, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, denied today that he sought to penalize staff attorneys who gave testimony to Congress critical of gas producers or who vocally advocated a public interest.

title: Overall Reserves Of Oil in Mexico Exceed Estimate
description: MEXICO CITY, March 18Mexico's state oil monopoly, Pemex, said today that the country's total oil reserves greatly exceed a recent unofficial estimate of 60 billion barrels. It added that proven reserves stand at 11.1 billion barrels.

title: Slain Union Leader Called Probable Victim for Debt
description: LAS VEGAS Nev. March 18 (UPI)Al Stamlet, the slain culinary workers union leader probably was the victim of men to whom he owed a personal debt and not the target of a professional hit man. District Attorney George Holt said today.

title: Music: Modern
description: Stefan Wolpe's Passacaglia for piano (1936) was the highlight of a stimulating concert Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall by Parnassus, an ensemble of young contemporary music specialists now in its third season.

title: A Man Not in Blue (Or in Any Color) Steals Police Car
description: A blue and white police car sped through Central Park early yesterday morning, headed north. There was nothing unusual about itexcept that the man behind the wheel had no clothes on.

title: Race Is on for Opera's Finale
description: Alban Berg's Lulu is one of the important unfinished operas in the repertory, along with Puccini's Turandot and Busoni's Doktor Faust. Berg started his opera in 1928 and had not completed it by his death in 1535.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Agriculture, U.S.A.

title: Massive RushHour T rain TieUp Under Investigation by L.I.R.R.
description: The Long Island Rail Road began an investigation yesterday into the breakdown that disrupted virtually all of its rushhour service Thursday night, delaying 76,000 riders two to three hours and leaving nearly 15,000 people trapped in tunnels under the East River for two hours or more.

title: Promises, PromisesWell, at Least Some of Carter's
description: The White House has taken measure of the extent and nature of President Carter's campaign promises and in releasing a 111page compilation to the news media last month, shared them with the piablic. The document, prepared by the transition staff before the inauguration, is excerpted here. The public can obtain the document by writing to the White House.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The map with the guide to weekend brunch restaurants in The Times yesterday incorrectly listed the address of the Bijou. It is at 400 East 57th Street.

title: HERMAN D. HILLMAN DIES; EXFEDERAL HOUSING AIDE
description: Herman D. Hillman, a retired Federal housing executive, died Thursday at South Nassau Community Hospital in Oceanside, L. I. He was 65 years old and a resident of Rockville Centre. L.I.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Norris Industries Inc. of Los Angeles said yesterday that it would make an offer to merge McIntosh Corporation of Chicago into Norris in an exchange of stock valued at $47 million.

title: Meter Reading Eased
description: A new communication system pattented this week allows a utility to read a meter without interrupting Power Page 31.

title: Penney Clears Axelson Return As an Executive
description: Kenneth S. Axelson, who last week withdrew his name from nomination as Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Department, was cleared yesterday by the J. C. Penney Company to return to its top executive ranks.

title: MAN, 21, IS ARRESTED IN A SUBWAY MURDER
description: A 21yearold man, said to be retarded, was taken into custody at his Manhattan home early yesterday and charged with fatally stabbing another retarded 20yearold man in a West Side subway corridor, the Transit Authority police said.

title: GOING OUT Guider
description: AWAY THEY GO Spring is indeed upon us with those guided tours of Brooklyn under way again, organized by the enterprising Lou Singer and scouring the borough for interesting sites, history and colorfrom brownstone homes and churches with Tiffany windows to historic landmarks, residential streets and ethnic communities. There are five more Saturday tours of Singer's Brooklyn (skipping April 9), with the group assembling in Manhattan for a bus ride, converging at 10 A.M. at 41st Street and Second Avenue, and returning there at 4 P.M. The tour tab is $10.

title: News Summary
description: The Zaire Government flewtroop reinforcements to Shaba Province in an attempt to halt the advance of invading forces from neighboring Angola before they reached the coppermining center of Koiwezi. The invaders, mostly former Katangan militiamen who fled the mining region into Angola exile in 1963, were estimated to number 2,000 men. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: Dual Purpose Funds
description: Week ended March 18, 1977 Following Is a weekly listing of the unaudited net asset value applicable to the capital shares of dualnureost investment companies at close of business Friday. Also shown are closing listed market prices or best overthe counter dealertodealer asked prices for the capital shares of each company with the percentage difference. (discount or premium) between the net asset value and the asked.

title: H.E.W. Town Meeting on Welfare Attracts Mostly Social Workers
description: HIGHTSTOWN, March 18As part of President Carter's policy to find out what the people are thinking, officials of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare came here today for what had been advertised as a town meeting on welfare.

title: Tunisians See Gains in Economy As Dependent on Political Events
description: TUNISTunisians speak sanguinely of an economic takeoff by 1981 but generally add, Of course everything depends on Bourguiba.

title: MISSING TONIGHT SHOW BRINGS NBC 3,800 CALLS
description: When Johnny Carson and his Tonight Show failed to appear on the home screen of television viewers Thursday night, the National Broadcasting Company got 3,800 telephone calls asking why. Of these inquiriesall emanating from New York City, 3,000 were made hetween 11:30 P.M. and midnight.

title: Letters: On Bridge Toils
description: To the Editor In calling for tolls on the East and Harlem River bridges, The Times states that critics of the tolls should demand that the city come up with alternatives that are workable and effective [editorial March 3].

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: G.A.O. FAULTS MOVES ON ORGANIZED CRIME
description: WASHINGTON, March 18Despite an expenditure of about $80 million over the last decade, the Department of Justice has not developed a national strategy for fighting organized crime and has not even been able to establish a definition of what organized crime is, the General Accounting Office said in a report issued today.

title: Beame Shows a Candidate's Flair Only Doing What a Mayor Must
description: Sounding a lawandorder theme that is certain to recur in his expected reelection campaign, Mayor Beame presided yesterday over the rehiring of 200 police officers and then sped off to Brooklyn for more speeches and handshaking that suggested his campaign might have already begun.

title: Miriam E. Hertz, 72, Former Head Of New York City Women's Clubs
description: Miriam Ehrenreich Hertz, a former president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, died of a heart attack Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital. She was 72 years old and lived at 1035 Fifth Avenue.

title: Americans Now Free To Travel Anywhere
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)For the first time since 1950, Americans are free to travel anywhere in the world without restrictions on the use of their passports.

title: Official of China Says It Condones U.S. Aid to Zaire To Bar Soviet Expansion
description: PEKING, March 18A Chinese Foreign Ministry official says that his Government would have no reason to oppose American aid to Zaire if the United States aim is to aid the African country and to oppose Soviet expansion on the continent.

title: SPRING MARKS TIME AS SNOW BLUSTERS IN
description: The notion that things were looking very much like spring was dashed yesterday by an abrupt replay of winter.

title: Mr. Carter's Middle East Vision
description: Israelis, Arabs and their respective supporters around the world are in a tizzy because of President Carter's recent definitions of the issues that must be faced on the way to Middle East negotiations later this year. There is some evidence that President Carter stumbled into detailed discussion of these ideas sooner than his diplomats had intended, but there is nothing makeshift or accidental about the policy he intends to pursue. It is a wise policy, and whatever its momentary effect on Arab conclaves or Israeli elections or the parade of Middle Eastern visitors to Washington, it ought to be judged on the merits.

title: Palestinians Reject Move For Recognition of Israel And Limit Arafat's Powers
description: CAIRO, March IS (UPI)Palestinian leaders rejected today any move to recognize Israel and also denied Yasir Arafat sweeping powers to negotiate a Mid Ideal East peace settlement.

title: CONSUMER PRICE RISE WAS 1% IN FEBRUARY, LARGEST IN 2 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, March 18Consumer prices surged 1 percent in February, the biggest advance in nearly two and a half years, the Labor Department reported today.

title: U.S. Inquiry Backs Chicago on Finding In Crash of Train
description: CHICAGO, March 18 (UPI)A Federal official said today that no evidence contradicted the Chicago Transit Authority's preliminary finding that human error caused an elevated train crash in which 11 persons were killed and nearly 200 were injured.

title: Worker Killed by Molten Steel
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. March 18 (AP) A foundry accident showered molten steel on employees yesterday, killing one man and injuring 10 others, the police said. Killed at the Rockwell International plant was Thomas Farmer, 34 years old, of nearby Guild.

title: Soybeans Futures Prices Recoup Losses and Gain; Coffee Continues to Rise
description: Rain in the Midwest areas led to some early selling of soybeans yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, cutting prices.

title: Daniel J. Hurley, ExReporter And New York City Detective
description: WATERFORD, Conn., March 18Daniel Joseph Burley, a retired New York City Police Department detective and a former reporter, died Thursday at Lawrence Memorial Hospital in New London, Conn., where he had been admitted Wednesday. He was 68 years old and lived at 22 Wood Street, Waterford.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The map with the guide to weekend brunch restaurants in The Times yesterday incorrectly listed the address of the Bijou. It is at 400 East 57th Street.

title: Hollander, New York School Aide, Is Offered Jersey Chancellorship
description: TRENTON, March 18The New Jersey Board of Higher Education announced today that it had offered the position of Chancellor to Dr. T. Edward Hollander, New York State's deputy commissioner ifor higher and professional education.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 18The New Jercey Board of Higher Education announced today that it had offered the position of Chancellor to Dr. T. Edward Hollander, New York State's deputy commissioner for higher and professional education.

title: Bell Says He Decided On Moslem's Release
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP)Attorney General Griffin B. Bell said today that it had been his decision to authorize the temporary release of the Ilanafi Moslem leader responsible for taking 134 hostages in Washington last week. One person was killed in the siege and another was seriously wounded.

title: Greenlining Instead of Redlining
description: Whether people are complaining about redlining or engaging in greenlining, lots of attention is being focused on the urban investment policies of New York banks. Redlining is the practice of refusing home improvement loans or mortgages in certain neighborhoods. Greenlining is the name that some protesters give to their efforts to increase the availability of home loans in Brooklyn.

title: Marcia Dawkins Is Wed to a Baron
description: Marcia Lannon Dawkins, deputy commissioner and director of Consular Corps Affairs at the New York City Commission for the United Nations and for the Consular Corps, was married at noon yesterday to Baron CarlHenric Nauckhoff, Consul General of Sweden in New York. The Rev, Dr. Stuart Grayson, associate minister of the First Church of Religious Science, performed the ceremony at the Swedish Consul General's residence.

title: Citibank Halts News Letter
description: After three years. Citibank has ceased publication of Money International, its monthly news letter, with the current March issue. A bank spokesman said that management had decided that Citibank had too many publications. The news letter, which was complimentary, had been distributed to about, 17,500 customers of the bank and its parent, Citicorp.

title: POLITICS
description: HOW are the people to know the minds of their elected representatives when they are silent? How are they to know their reasons for voting as they do if the General Assembly gets engaged uneasily and only marginally in debate when it comes to uncomfortable matters like the one called Gay Rights?

title: DINING OUT
description: DOES the fact that an inn claims to have served food regularly for 228 years make the stuffed pheasant taste any better? Of course not. But if the pheasant is a spectacular success, as it was at The Horse and Hound, the sense of history that surrounds this modest inn adds to its enjoyment.

title: Source of the Terror
description: PARISOne reason the ArabIsraeli dispute is so hard to settle is that both sides are philosophically persuaded they are involved in a just confrontation. Jews, persecuted in Europe and the Middle East, who joined their brethren in modern Israel, are convinced they have a right to be there and intend to stay.

description: This World War II fantasy by Harry Patterson (a.k.a. Jack Higgins) has a vintage bouquet that I havent sampled since I devoured The Boy Allies series by flashlight in my cot at summer camp. It features two armoredforce aces. one German. one American. who choose to shoot it out with machine guns in individual combat. (My affairstay out

title: Basie and Eckstine Do the New. and Old
description: Count Basie, who suffered a heart attack last September, came to town with his band for the first time since then on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall to share a concert with Billy Eckstine, the singer.

title: Old. Mosaics, Old Graffiti
description: The discovery of a 2,000yearold mosaic in Kiras Vrysi, Greece serves as a reminder that ancient Greeks were as capable of deliberately destroying artistic landmarks as, say, modern Americans. The mosaic covered the floor in the main hall of a bathhouse that was torn down about A.D. 410 to provide building material for a defense wall across the oncestrategic isthmus connecting northern and southern Greece 50 miles west of Athens.
