description: An increasing number of cultural institutions are offering fundraising travel packages. Special features include entree to private homes, art collections or gardens not generally open to the public and pretrip orientation programs. A partial list of tours available for 1977 follows.

title: Jury Indicts 4 Men in Miami In Theft of 17 Tons of Coffee
description: MIAMI, March 19 (UPI)  A Federal grand jury has indicted four men for stealing 17 tons of coffee last fall. They are believed to have sold it for $16.000.

title: Transit Authority Patrolman Shot By Gunman in 42d Street Station
description: A Transit Authority policeman was shot and critically wounded last night as he was investigating reports of a gunman on the platform of the IND subway at 42d Street and Sixth Avenue.

title: Castro Plans to Visit His Troops in Angola
description: NGORONGORO, Tanzania, March 19 (UPI)President Fidel Castro of Cuba visited the Ngorongoro national park today in the floor of this extinct volcano near Mount Kilimanjaro and announced that he would visit his troops in Aneola as part of his African tour.

title: Samuel Mygatt, Lawyer, Fiance Of Susan Hall
description: Susan Medbury Hall, who is, completing studies at the Boston University Law School. and Samuel Gifford Mygatt, an associate with the New York law firm of Cadwalader. Wickersham & Taft, plan to be married in June.

title: TWO TURKS HIJACK PLANE TO BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. March 19 (AP)Two hijackers armed with pistols commandeered a Turkish jetliner with 181 persons aboard today and forced it to land at Beirut airport. The hijackers later surrendered after releasing the 173 passengers.

title: Poetry In a New Land
description: FOR Anne Marx, flight from Hitler's Europe meant more than a loss of contact with friends, relatives and a medical education. A poet, she had also lost touch with words.

title: Enzo Ferrari Resigns From Auto Company
description: MODENA, Italy, March 19 (AP)Enzo Ferrari said today that he had resigned as president of the automobile company he founded 31 years ago.

Perkins of Villanova, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Foster Perkins, to Richard Campbell Gilbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Gilbert of Greenwich, Conn. description: The Richard Morse Mime Theater. which appeared so succesfully at Town Hall a few months ago, has now settled into a new home at 224 Waverly Place for a series of weekend performances this spring.

title: If Hammett and Chandler were written by Perelman
description: Thomas Berger's fifth novel is mainly a parody of detective thrillers; his wellknown Little Big Man was a parody of Westerns. According to the jacket copy, in Who Is Teddy Villanova? we will recognize the familiar seedy office, downattheheels shamus, procession of sinister, chicane, or merely brutal men and scheming, vicious, but lovely women and a sequence of savage beatings. All this is true. The novel contains much that is conventional in detective thrillers. Still, one needn't know the

title: Opera: Met Offers Berg's Symbolic, Intense Lulu
description: Alban Berg's Lulu has finally made it to the Metropolitan Opera. This Expressionistic torso of a work, left unfinished by the composerthough experts say that a complete version from Berg's own material is entirely feasible has been given all over the world in recent years, but the previous regime at the Metropolitan staunchly resisted it. The present management, more hospitable to experiment, has now given New Yorkers a chance to make up their own minds.

Mr. Boller is a newventure products manager with Imperial Chemicals Industries, United States, in Wilmington, Del., a subsidiary of Imperial Chemical Industries Ltd., London.

description: PITTSBURGH, March 19Belatedly discovering an opportunistic scoring punch and balance by using two energetic checking lines, the New York Rangers defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 52, tonight for the first victory in their last six games.

description: QUINCY, Mass., March 19 (AP)Eastern Nazarene College plans to mark its 60th year here by moving to Pennsylvania.

title: Troops Recapture Village
description: KOLWEZI, Zaire, March 19President Mobutu Sese Seko today flew to this southern coppermining center, situated in the path of an invading column, and was briefed by officers who said Zairian forces had recaptured a village from the invaders.

title: It Is No Longer Clear Where the Public Sector Ends and the Private Begins
description: WASHINGTONWhen the Carter Administration recently proposed an informal and voluntary system jawboning, to be preciseto help restrain wage and price increases, labor, industry and assorted defenders of the free enterprise system responded with cries of defiance against Government intervention in the marketplace. But when the Administration said a few days later that it would support a new price support program for agriculture, including a target price for farm products that would insure many farmers against any production risks, there were few protests. Few can be expected this week when Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland testifies before the Senate subcommittee that is considering the new price levels.

title: The Games Young People Play
description: The best heavyweight of my time was named Danny Goldberg. He was 6 feet 1% inches and 202 pounds and had closecut curly blond hair, steely blue eyes and a smoothly muscled broadshouldered body that tapered to a narrow waist. He had a crisp left hook, a good jab and a dynamite right hand. He was highly intelligent and from the Bronx, and he was known as the Blond Bomber.

title: Learning the Realities

description: The stock market lately has been puzzling, frustrating, disappointing or boring for most investors. They have listened to Wall Street opinions about corporate profits, the frigid winter, the perils of inflation and the uncertainties of a new Administration. Meanwhile, stock prices have meandered.

title: Putting Brakes On Tenure
description: THE issue of tenure for teachers_ is one of the most controversial and complex of all problems en: countered by a school board. Tenure is a doubleedged sword. It guarantees freedom to the teacher to present books, ideas and concepts, and, at the same time, it gives protection to the ineffective teacher.

McGarry of Weston, Mass., and the late Mrs. McGarry, was married yesterday to Bryan Witherspoon Aldridge. son of Mrs. John Vernon Aldridge of Austin. Tex., and the late Mr. Aldridge. The Rev. Larry M. Hill. a Presbyterian minister, of Harvard University per formed the ceremony in the Harvard Memorial Church.

title: Paper Back Talk
description: Osculation. If you were a kid hellbent on becoming a man back in the 1930's, you had a Problem: How should you go about exchanging a few goodnight kisses with your date with all the finesse of a Clark Gable taking on a Joan Crawford? The movies offered you few tips for in those days the Hays office kept the cameras from peering too close. You might, as thousands of other DepressionAge kids did, see an ad in a pulp magazine and write to the Franklin Publishing Co. of Philadelphia for a copy of The Art of Kissing by one Hugh Morris.

description: Rachel Frydman, a sophomore at Brandeis University, and Henry Brem, who is completing his third year at the Harvard Medical School, plan to be married in June.

Then a stockbroker who had never produced a play bought it and made mile of

title: ENCOUNTER
description: The cell door slammed. I was in a primitive jail in Cartagena, Colombia, locked in a bare concrete room, nine feet by 12, furnished with only a stone bench along one wall and a puddle of urine in the corner. A little light came in through a 10inch square opening in the door. When I put my head through the opening to ask if I could make a phone call, the guard slammed a cover over the opening.

title: K. W. Hooper Fiance Of Lisbeth Petterson
description: The engagement of Lisbeth M. Petterson to Kenneth W. Hooper has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. DeWitt R. Petterson of Basking Ridge, N.J. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Hooper of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Port Marks Three Anniversaries
description: Last week was anniversary week along the waterfront. More specifically, the 10th anniversary of the stranding of the Torrey Canyon, which produced the world's largest accidental oil spill; the 20th anniversary of Columbus Line's service in the port; and the 89th annual remembrance of the Blizzard of 88. The tanker Torrey Canyon, which broke up off the coast of Cornwall. England, spilled 29.4 million gallons of crude oil into the Atlantic, or four times as much as the Liberian tanker Argo Merchant, which was wrecked of Nantucket in midDecember.

title: NeoRomantic Music Warms a Public Chilled by the AvantGarde
description: A couple of years ago Isaac Stern played a new violin concerto by the American composer George Rochberg. Now, Rochberg during the 1960's had been a prominent, cardcarrying member of the serial movement. He composed music that to most listeners was abstract, atonal, severe, unmelodic. He was not alone in this, of course. Most of the music composed by the academic avantgarde all over the world had sirnfilar stigmata. So when Stern stepped on stage, one expected still another wellmade piece of musical assemblage that would perhaps jostle the intellect but at the same time would make the emotions yawn.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: THE MILLS of government, like those of the gods, sometimes grind exceedingly slowly, although not necessarily finely in all instances. The fineness of the grind sometimes seems to depend on the politics of the situation.

title: Students Learn To Enjoy Opera By Performing
description: When the curtain went down on the fourth and final act of La Boheme Friday evening, the audience cheered wildly as Mimi and Rodolfo took their final bows. But the actress who played Mimi was a . flushed and smiling Margery Hellmold, just 15 years old. And instead of the Metropolitan Opera's portly Luciano Pavarotti, a lean 17yearold, Christopher Dolin, held her hand.

title: DINING OUT
description: DOES the fact that an inn claims to have served food regularly for 228 years make the stuffed pheasant taste any better? Of course not. But if the pheasant is a spectacular success, as it was at The Horse and Hound, the sense of history that surrounds this modest inn adds to its enjoyment.

title: Dancing for a Cause
description: TAKE a highschool gymnasium, an energetic body of teenagers willing to dance the clock around for a good cause. Add a couple of disk jockeys armed with 200watt speakers and 600 albums and tapes and what do you get? At Mamaroneck High School, the answer could be as much as $10,000, about half of which will go to charity and .half to the coffers of the student government.

title: Wanted: New Way to Pick Supervisors
description: ONCE AGAIN, the biennial search is on in Westchester for candidates for town supervisor in the November election. It is up to the electorate to choose a person, who, under New York State law, holds perhaps the most important position in town government and is the only fulltime elected official responsible for overseeing the operation of the total town government.

title: Laurie Gross Is Married

title: Suit on TV Tower Collapse Ends
description: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, March 19 (UPI) A $2 million outofcourt settlement was reached yesterday in a suit over the collapse of a 2,000foot television tower that killed five ironworkers in 1973. The Cedar Rapids Television Company, which owns KCRGTV and the tower, will receive S1.5 milion and the estates of four of the workers will share about $500,000. A settlement was reached earlier for the estate of the fifth victim. The Iowa Educational Broadcasting Network, now the Iowa Public Broadcasting Network, was a defendant in the suit along with the company that built the tower and the one that was modifying it.

title: Hobbies, Crafts, Antiques Art

title: Trend to Living Alone Brings Economic and Social Change

She lives in a comfortable onebedroom apartment amid mixture of chronic modern and old attic furniture, just a stone's throw from Lake Washington. She shares the place with nobody but her seventoed cat, Alfred, and she likes that just line.

title: QUEENS MAN ACCUSED OF A TAVERN SLAYING

title: French Left Expects More Gains Outside Paris in Election Today
description: PARIS, March 19The French Socialist Party indicated yesterday that it expected to increase its gains in the provinces in the second round of nationwide municipal selections tomorrow. But it seemed much less confident that the leftist alliance would defeat former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac in the Paris mayoral election.

title: Bodybuilders Labor to Develop an Image
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., March 19With a natural rhythm like the waves pounding the nearby beach, the men at Gold's Gym moved through their exercise routines. These men, who come from all over the world to train at Gold's, are bodybuilders. They come here each day to endure the rigors that will bring them closer to their goalthe development of a cleanly and symmetrically defined muscular physique that they will display by posing for judges.

title: Turkish Violence Increases the Pressure for Elections

title: Kuester Key to 7972 Defeat of Kentucky:
description: COLLEGE PARK. Md., March 19What should have been the knockout blow was delivered with 19 minutes and 8 seconds left to play in the game North Carolina won, 7972. It left Phil Ford lying on the ground, holding his injured elbow to make sure it was still attached to his right arm. Ford had just charged into Kentucky's Larry Johnson and picked up his fourth foul. Normally, Dean Smith, the Carolina coach, would have pulled Ford and sat him down until he was desperately needed down the stretch. But when Ford sat down today, there was no chance of him coming back: he couldn't even raise his arm, let alone use it

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Somewhere in back of our century's achievement in the arts there occurs over and over again the notion of an irreversible breakdown. The key examples leap to mind. That final thump in Stravinsky's Rite of Spring leaves us in no doubt that someone lies dead on the ground. The execution machine in Franz Kafka's Penal Colony foreshadows an inhumanity that soon reached pandemic proportions. Samuel Beckett's plays are often very funny, but we know where they lead us. The Waste Land is what its title suggests.

title: Mauna Loa Eruption Predicted
description: VOLCANO, Hawaii, March 19 (AP)Scientists here expect another eruption of the volcano Mauna Loa within 15 months. A 24hour lava flow in July 1975 was its first eruption in 25 years.

title: Rhetoric and Reality
description: It is not President Carter's fault that his wellplanned gesture to the United Nations last weekto rejoin the boycott of Rhodesia until a black government is created was tarnished even before delivery. At the very moment of his address, his Administration was rushing military supplies to help the apparently incompetent if not impotent Government of Zaire repel a few thousand resurgent secessionists. If banning Rhodesian chrome once again was symbolic of support for progressive change in Africa, was not the airlift symbolic of reflexive support for a past policy of military meddling? Yesterday, the President called the boycott  a central element in our African policy. What policy?

title: Millions in Smoke For Tinder Box Inc.

There was no need for panic, however, because the Surgeon General turned out to be the best friend his cigar and pipe business ever had.

title: Two Cities
description: In an interview at his airport office Mr. Kaolian said that Sikorsky was licensed by the Federal Aviation Administration as a certified aircarrier airport. He said that American Airlines relinquished its license to Allegheny Airlines nearly 20 gears ago and that Allegheny suspended service two years ago. Altair, a commuter airline, is leaving the airport this month, and Pilgrim, another shortrun airline, has reduced its service. He suggested that most of this was a result of inadequate runways.

title: JOE MARCUS
description: SYOSSET, L.I., March 19Joe Marcus, a sportswriter for the New York Post, died at 1:15 .P.M. today in Syosset Hospital. He was 43 years old and had worked at the Post for the last 2 3years. He was suffering from cancer.

title: Congo at a Glance
description: GEOGRAPHYAbout half the size of Texas, Congo straddles the Equator on the northern bank of the Congo River and is bordered by Gabon, the Central African Empire, Zaire and Angola. The tropical country is heavily forested and wood products are a major export, but twothirds of the Government revenues come from oil drilled off shore in the Atlantic. Chief agricultural products are palm oil, cocoa, coffee, bananas and peanuts. Potash is also exported.

description: ALBANY, March 19New York State's eight million voters will be asked next Election Day whether to set in motion a fullscale effort to revise the state's 200yearold Constitution.

title: Sunday Observer

A few years ago, when its highest aspiration was to hold the dean for ransom, youth looked as if it might grow up to amount to something. Instead, it wants to be . lawyers.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to Marrakesh, you can fly via Casablanca or direct from London, Paris and other European cities. Driving gives you more freedom and leaves you with a better sense of the countryside, and the roads are good. An Avis rental car costs about $38 a day for unlimited mileage, with gas extra.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: It is now 10 yearsor near enough to make no differencesince Eliot Feld, dancer, set up shop as Eliot Feld, choreographer. In that period he has staged 25 ballets all over the world. It has been a stormy, controversial decade, for Feld is the kind of artist who provokes only extremes of interest.

title: Charting the Genealogy Of Jazz on Disks
description: Despite the recent massive reissue of jazz recordings, along with a trickle of historical records of the folk roots of other aspects of American music, relatively little effort has been made to use recordings as a means of putting this musicjazz, country, blues, folk, ragtime, pop, soul or even rockin perspective. Most reissues concentrate on a specific artist, skimming the cream of his work or, as in the case of some of the current RCA Bluebird jazz reissues, presenting the complete works of a performer (complete so far as that label is concerned) in chronological recorded order.

title: 9th Century Temple in Java Hid 4 Other Buddhist Shrines
description: BOROBUDUR, IndonesiaA sprawling ninthcentury Buddhist temple on a mountain here in central Java was built atop the remains of at least four previous shrines, according to scientists, engineers and archeologists who have been restoring the structure.

title: Around the Nation

This question is now being examined by Southern Connecticut State College in view of the decision by President Manson Van B. Jennings to allow acceptance of 500 students of lower academic promise next fall.

title: Yugoslavs Foil Jeans Bootleggers
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 19A campaign in Eastern Europe to stem the flow of bootleg blue jeans from the West has achieved another success with the disruption of an Italian connection at the Yurgoslav frontier.

description: The name of the game in strifetorn Zaire may be politics, but a key goal is control of the central African country's vital supply of cobalt, according to metals traders in New York and London who have been closely watching situation unfold.

title: Iggy Pop Meets Rock's Rousseau
description: Iggy Pop, who used to call himself Iggy Stooge, Is the Noble Savage of rock. He crawls around on all fours, twists himself into impossibly contorted positions, and snarls and bites at hands that reach out to him from the audience. The lyrics he writes and sings avoid imagery almost entirely, opting instead for flat statements. His most celebrated song is I Wanna Be Your Dog.

title: Independence and Courageous Will Be Launched for the America's Cup Trials
description: A hero for life. That's how A. Lee Loomis Jr. envisions anyone who would defy the impossible and take the America's Cup away from America. Loomis thinks about such things because he has to. He is head of the

title: Search for Gold Starts on a Peak In New Mexico
description: VICTORIO PEAK, N.M., March 19Jack Hull, his sunburned face shaded by his white cowboy hat, paused at the top of Victorio Peak and pointed to a small outcropping in the rock.

title: To Catch the Eye and Ear
description: ON a weekday afternoon the Student Union Building at the State University Center at Stony Brook is a bustling arcade of specialinterest groups, and the impressionable undergraduate is the prize for whose attention they tirelessly compete.

title: FORD CAUTIOUSLY BACKS CARTER ENERGY PROPOSAL
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 19 (UPI)In his first assessment of President Carter's policies, Gerald R. Ford today cautiously endorsed a Cabinetlevel energy department but warned that the country's survival depended on its being more than lust a public relations gimmick.

title: CHESS
description: The life history of an opening variation often goes something like this: When it first appears, everyone insists that it cannot be sound. But no one really knows what to do about it. In the second stage, there is grudging admission that there is some point to the variation after all, but meanwhile these outwardly tolerant players are itching to try out their secret refutations. The final stage, years later, arrives when some club member with a good memory asks, Whatever happened to the whatchamacallit defense?

title: Harvard Freshmen Vote to End Boycott of Disciplinary Panel Set Up 7 Years Ago After Student Disorder
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 19An enduring symbol of student protest has passed quietly at Harvard as members of the freshman class voted to send a representative to a controversial disciplinary panel that undergraduates have boycotted for the past seven years.

title: Federal Court Backs Right of Press to Publish Corporate Documents
description: An insurance company's request for a court order to prohibit publication of corporate documents has been rejected by a Federal judge, who ruled that the requested prohibition would violate freedom of the Dress.

title: Unveilings
description: KLONSKYShirley ?? (Section) Lot 149.

title: Haggling Over Aid Formulas Is a Tradition In Congress
description: WASHINGTON  When a bill to provide $4 billion in public works jobs came to the Senate floor recently as part of the new Administration's stimulus plan, there was little disagreement about the total but a great deal of disagreement about how to distribute it among the states. Ultimately, although the purpose of the bill was to relieve areas with severe unemployment, in order to muster a majority of Senators the statistical definition of severe had to be relaxed so that more states would qualify for funds, and each state had to be guaranteed a minimum allocation of $30 million whether it needed it or not.

title: EnergyA Woman Pleads State's Case
description: FOR the last three years, a former teacher has put aside her interest in medieval and modern poetry and plunged instead into the heady world of energy and government.

title: CAREY PLAN TO ALTER DEPARTMENT FADES
description: ALBANY, March 19Governor Carey's plan to reorganize the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene appears to have been all but lost for this session, even before it has been drafted into final form.

title: World News Briefs
description: LENINGRAD, March 19 (UPI)A Leningrad court, citing barbarous treatment of state property today sentenced two artists to terms of seven and six years at hard labor for having painted antiSoviet slogans on Leningrad landmarks.

title: SHOP TALK
description: THE sign reads Alter's, and it protrudes from a building imprinted with BAKERY on the crest of its old facade. Inside the shop, an old Seth Thomas clock looks over glistening white walls, a tin ceiling and, as they come up on an ancient dumbwaiter, stacks of hot breads and rolls. Downstairs, a brickonsand oven, unchanged since 1893, burns 24 hours a day. The baking method hasn't changed since the turn of the century, said Irene Schwartz, whose father, Abraham Alter, bought the North Tarrytown bakery during the Depression.

title: Halfway Houses Go Long Way
description: WOODMERE THE seedy, depressing and sometimes unclean living conditions of former mental patients who live in rooming hotels have long been recognized. The owners of these pitiful places, and the nature of their operation, have been exposed and reexposed, and still they persist.

title: What's Doing in MADRID
description: POLITICSThe Government of King Juan Carlos is steering Spain out of 50 years of authoritarianism to new, representative institutions. Some wouldbe visitors seem to be skirting Spain for this reason, put off by the occasional headline suggesting that the nation is in turmoil. But so far, except for a few patches of violence, the transition has been remarkably smooth. The visitor's chance of getting caught in the middle of a demonstrationor wider political upheavalis slim, and one is certainly safer walking the streets of Madrid than those of many an American city. The parliamentary elections scheduled for late May or early June are unlikely to upset the tourist's rhythm; on the contrary, the truly curious visitor may find a trip enhanced by the political activity. For the first time in four decades Spaniards over the age of 21 will be voting, freely and secretly, for their own representatives.

title: Dr. Edward Halperin Fiance of Beth Weingast
description: Dr. and Mrs. David Weingast of Ridgefield, Conn., and Seaview, Fire Island, L. I.. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beth G. Weingast, to Dr. Edward N. Halperin of New York, son of Mrs. Paul Mitchell Of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Isaac Halperin, who was an internist.

title: Taken By the Casbah
description: Back in the dim, distant days of the early seventies, I used to listen to Crosby, Stills and Nash singing about taking the train to Marrakesh. So it was with a certain sense of wonder, and triumph, that I stood recently in the main square of Marrakesh and watched a man dressed in a straw hat, a ski sweater and knickers lead a monkey around on a chain. When he spotted my 6yearold daughter, Rebecca, he brought the pet over and asked her to shake hands.

title: Home Style
description: One of the prettiest springtime sights is the windowbox, brimming over with geraniums, petunias, marigolds, pansies and ivy.

title: The trouble at Sarah Lawrence
description: On the fall night in 1954 when I arrived Sarah Lawrence College, threw my Bermuda shorts and gold circle pin into the wastebasket and changed into my leotard and jeans, my mother called. She was crying. She had been to a cocktail party and met a wellknown columnist who told her there were no virgins on the Sarah Lawrence campus. How times have changed. Recently, the development office received a letter from an alumna in San Francisco who was distressed by the rumor that the campus is now 50 percent homosexual.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Last Monday the stock market succeeded In producing its best daily gain in three months, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose more than 10 points and simultaneously elevated the spirits of investors.

title: Showing of Roots
description: The opening twohour episode of the filmed version of Roots, the dramatic story that evolved from Alex Haley's long search to trace his ancestors, will be presented April 1 at 2:30 P.M. at Brooklyn's Central Library. The episode starts an eightweek series. Tickets for the April I program will be available at the library, at. Grand Army Plaza, beginning March 28.

title: ART
description: THE photographs on exhibit at the Squibb Gallery in Princeton have an exhilarating and devastating effect upon the viewer. These pictures of Connecticut from the middle of the last century until World 71. War I move us with their beauty and Stir us with their nostalgic remembrances.

title: Tarrytown's Cuban Flavor
description: THE men mill about the local gathering place, a small restaurant where they smoke and sip strong coffee while discussing in Spanish the burning issues of the day. Down the road, blue water shimmers under the bright sun.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ART

title: Asbury Park Is Seeking Auto Races on Streets
description: There were sanctioned auto races through city streets in this country before the Long Beach Grand Prix came along, but the California event did something none of the others had done. It brought into sharp focus the fact that such a race can be definite asset to a city. Now everyone wants to get into the act. Asbury Park, N.J., with a population of 16,000 is the latest city to look seriously at legal street racing, and Allan J. Sockol, the man who started the city fathers thinking in that direction, feels it will be a reality this fall.

title: Down on the Berlin Turnpike
description: TONY MANARD is not about to be cast as some leftover relic of the Berlin Turnpike, a stretch of road tied to the end of the Wilbur Cross Parkway and Hartford's back door that was robbed 10 years ago by Interstate 91 of the travelers and trucks bringing money and business.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 20, 1977

description: WHEN Steffi Nossen began her crusade for what she calls dance as education in New Rochelle in 1937, modern dance was an esthetic anomaly to most Americans.

description: Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area Senate

title: Banking After the Fall
description: THEY are being more cautious. They are scrutinizing requests for loans more carefullly. But the two New York City banks that stepped into the vacuum in 1974 and 1975 when two of the Island's biggest banks got into trouble are wooing Long Island developers, builders and businessmen.

title: In Some Countries, Bribes Remain Tax Deductible
description: ROMELast year's disclosures of Lockheed Aircraft Corporation bribes in Europe and Japan brought inquiries, trials and professions of shock, but apart from the few businessmen and politicians prosecuted, little else that might deter others from accepting the use of bribes in their international deals.

title: Summer jobs: Search Begins
description: TODAY is the first day of spring and, although a young man's fancy is supposed to turn to thoughts of love, the fancies of thousands of young men and women are turning, instead, to thoughts of summer jobs. Working during the summer months, instead of just lying in the sun, used to be a kind of luxury, a way to get extra pin money. However, with costs of clothing and of college educations continuing to escalate, waiting on tables, busing dishes and scores of other summer jobs have become necessities.

title: Terrorism Byrne's Advice on Coping
description: ASTUDY of the growth of terrorismin the United States by a national advisory commission lists 95 such incidents in New Jersey from 1965 through the first three months of 1976. The study was part of an effort by the Federal LawEnforcement Assistance Administration to prepare a manual on ways to handle situations such as that which developed in Washington on March 9, when a Muslim sect seized more than 100 hostages.

description: OF SPECIAL INTEREST

title: David B. Gibson Fiance Of Leslie Wood Heiner
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Graham Heiner Jr. of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Wood Heiner, to David Beckwith Gibson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gibson 3d of Glenburn, Pa. The wedding is planned for September.

title: Astronomy
description: What is astronomy?. The subject matter of this science is the disposition of the universe, and its origin and destiny. The astronomer shares his interest in these matters with the theologian; both seek insights, from different points of view, into the ageold questions: What am I? How did I get here? What is my relationship to the rest of the universe?

title: A Rig for RacingOff the Road
description: LAST JUNE, the Baja 500 Internacional became a challenge to. 100 vehicles of every definition and description to race 500 miles to see which could survive a nonstop, offtheroad competition in Lower California. Only one vehicle carne from New York State.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN a piece of wroughtiron furniture or a section of metal railing inside or outside the home breaks most people feel that the only permanent cure is to have it welded professionally. While this may still be advisable, and possibly necessary, in some cases, many repairs of this kind can be easily made at home without special tools or equipmentsimply by using a paste or puttytype epoxy adhesive.

title: Neil Dolgin, a Realty Broker, To Wed Cindy Marsh Aug:13
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Marsh of Livingston, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cindy Ruth Marsh, to Neil Dolgin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Israel Dolgin of Great Neck, L.I. The wedding is planned for Aug. 13.

title: More Parks, Mon

title: From ancient bard to Hovercraft poet
description: About half this book is translation, which can be a pretty dreary prospect: a halfgallon of minor poets dishwater. But not this time, not when the translators are Irish poets reclaiming their heritage, learning English skills from its intricacies:

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Southern Flavor
description: CONWAY, S.C.Flocks of widgeon flared overhead, their white bellies gleaming in the brilliant morning sun, 20 American egrets drifted past to land on a mud flat 300 yards away and the shellcrackers were biting.

title: Three novels of power
description: I don't care what Lord Acton said: Power doesn't corrupt those who possess it nearly so much as it does those who write fiction about those puffy potentates. If power is the ability to exert force in any bloody direction one chooses without having to mop up the resulting mess, then corruption must be the equal and opposite exploitation of that dynamic absolute by cynical novelists who assume a readership fascinated by powerfigures. This assumption seems to preclude the necessity to render these figures dramatically and complexly, to do anything more demanding than give them unhappy marriages, weak bladders, rebellious children, close elections, or bungled embezzlementsjust to reassure the envious reader that it's not all cream puffs and champagne up there in the penthouses. As always, that blessed man Henry James put his delicate finger on the point: What must be granted the artist as given is the subject, the story, the starting pointbut never characterization!

And yet these colorful, imaginative cloth compositions are often worn by Indian women from Central America in their daily dress. It is difficult to believe that art objects that make so much of design, balance and the blending of colors are meant to be admired only as domestic decorations or institutional embellish

title: CARTER'S GEORGIA GURU
description: HAINIBRIDGE, Ga. Since pickup trucks are to southern Georgia what taxis are to Manhattan, nobody paid much attention to the one that rolled out of this little town very early one recent morning loaded to the gunwales with firewood and headed north or. Highway 19. It was driven by a man who seemed to know the road, but kept both hands on the wheel nevertheless, and until he pulled into a Phillips 66 service station a few miles later, anyone who saw the truck pass would just naturally have assumed that its driver was a hardworking farmer getting a head start on a winter chore, or a smalltime logger, perhaps, making his first delivery of the day. When he parked near the orangeandwhite gas pumps, however, and crawled from the cab, it was immediately clear that such judgments would have been faulty. Instead of an opencollar work shirt, he wore a crisp white one with a silk tie; instead of scarred and scruffy hightop brogans, he had on an expensive pair of loafers, polished to a glassy shine; instead of crusty overalls, this fellow was dressed In a $300 suit, expertly tailored to his lanky frame.

title: Additive to Gain Octane Suspected Of Fouling Cars
description: DETROIT, March 19  An additive called MMT, which has gradually been replacing outlawed lead as an octanebooster in gasoline, is suspected by Federal officials of fouling and impairing the operation of the pollutioncontrol system used in most American cars since 1974.

title: A Closeup of the Atomin 3D
description: Aprocedure that produces three. dimensional photographs of minute atoms in chemical molecules has been developed by a research team under the direction of Dr. George W. Stroke at the State University Center at Stony Brook.

title: CAREY BIDS WOMEN ENLARGE PARTY ROLE
description: Governor Carey praised the energy and effectiveness of the women's rights movement yesterday and then exhorted the women of the New York Democratic Party to assume a more vigorous role hi the political and financial problems of the state.

title: BRIDGE
description: The cosmetics industry may make a substantial impact on the bridge scene if new product that has been advertised recently becomes popular. Consider the effect on partners, opponents and tournament committees of a mood crystal nail polish that changes color in reaction to your body chemistry, revealing true emotional involvement and awareness. Imagine a home game between two couples in which the wives are both wearing moody nail polish. We'll call them Mr. and Mrs. Culbertson and Mr. and Mrs. Sims, although their skill does not quite match that of the more famous players of the same name who clashed in a celebrated rubber bridge match more than 40 years ago. The climax of the evening is the diagramed deal, noted in real life by New York expert Murray Schnee.

title: Stout Relics of Brewing's Golden Age
description: Pulling aside a grimy clapboard in the corner of a basement storage room, Leonard Ventura pointed to the worn marble steps that rose oddly to the ceilinga stairway apparently to nowhere.

title: Camping guides
description: 1977 Parents Guide to Accredited Camps, The American Camping Association, New York Section, 225 Park Avenue South, New York, N.Y. 10003. S2.40. The guide comes in four regional editions. The Northeastern edition covers nearly 1,000 camps from Virginia to Maine. Inclusion in the directory means the camp has been inspected by the association within the last five years. For the other regionsSouth, Midwest, Westwrite to the association's headquarters, Bradford Woods, Martinsville, Ind. 46151.

title: Knicks Victors, 107 101, As Hawks
description: The Knicks enjoyed 70 percent shooting in the first half last night, a 20point halftime lead and a 15point advantage after three periods. It was a perfect time for Earl Monroe to have a night off to rest his aching left foot.

title: Invitation to a Vendetta
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has asked the Senate and House Judiciary Committees to investigate private, or ex parte, relations between Federal judges and lawenforcement officials. It is a request that would never have been made were it not for the efforts of a group in the union that wishes to reopen the case of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg via an attack on Judge Irving Kaufman, who presided at their espionage trial.

title: Notes: Tour Buses With a Touch of class
description: From the outside it looks like any other transcontinental bus; inside it's more like the club car of the old Super Chief: individual deeply upholstered chairs that swivel and recline, full carpeting, window curtains, taped music, airconditioning and toilet facilities. Such custom  fitted, luxury  model busesknown as LoungeCruisex or Executive Coachesaccommodate 20 passengers in a space that ordinarily holds 47. And the're starting to go public.

title: Plea by Slain Leader's Son Reduces Danger of New Violence in Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 20The danger of further mass violence receded in Lebanon today as Walid Jumblat, son of Karnal Jumblat, the assassinated Druse lender, toured the villages of the troubled mountain region southeast of Beirut and appealed to members of his sect to refrain from seeking revenge for his father.

title: Test Case on Migrant Labor Pay May Have Severe Impact on State

title: Plan on Product Standards Is Decried by 4 in Congress
description: WASHINGTON. March 20  A farreaching plan to link the Federal Government with 400 professional or commercial groups that set standards for tens of thousands of widely used materials and products has been opposed by four members of Congress who say it would harm consumers and smallbusiness men and stifle technical innovation.

Miss., March 20Andrew Young. the United States delegate to the United Nations, led thousands of mourners, most of them black, in several hours of tribute to the bestknown citizen of this small Mississippi Delta town, Fannie Lou Hamer, the former sharecropper who turned civil rights leader.

title: A Housing Law Nobody Needs
description: The generally desirable conversion of rental housing to tenantowned cooperatives in New York appears have been impeded by a law that ought to be permitted to expire. Known as the GoodmanDeane Bill, it requires 35 percent of the tenants of any property to approve the creation of a coop. Contrary to the impression many tenants, this law provides no protection for opponents of coops that is not already provided in other laws. In the hope that decent but deteriorating rental apartment houses might be saved by converting them into cooperatives, the law should be allowed to lapse on July 1.

Yet in the last year both men have wanted to buy something that is difficult to obtain, expensive, rarely profitable and not really for sale.

title: Sellers in London Hospital
description: LONDON, March 20 (AP)Peter Sellers was taken to a hospital here today after becoming ill on a flight from Nice, France. The 51yearold actor was returning from his honeymoon in the south of France with his fourth wife, Lynne Frederick, 22, British actress. He was given emergency treatment at Heathrow Airport before being taken to Charing Cross Hospital.

description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)The Pentagon is working to improve its ability to wage war with nerve gas.

John Vitale of Rocky Hill, Conn., finished second in 1:36:11 and Don Rincon of College Park, Md., was third in 1:36:17. A total of 510 runners started the race and 416 finished.

title: Rockefeller Tours Egypt
description: CAIRO, March 20  Nelson A. Rockefeller, the former Vice President, went sightseeing in the upper Egyptian cities of Luxor and Aswan today after meeting with Ismail Fahmy, Egypt's Foreign Minister, to discuss the Middle East dispute yesterday. Mr. Rockefeller arrived Friday on a private visit. He will leave Tuesday for Saudi Arabia.

title: TV: Huey Long, Revisionist View
description: The Life and Assassination of the langfish, a twohour factbased television movie on NBC at 9 this evening, gets snarled in its own dramatic machinery as it attempts somewhat revisionist portrait of Huey Long, the Southern populist who was killed in September 1935. The film, shot in Louisiana's Baton Rouge area, opens with the already wounded Long being prepared for an operation in a Catholic hospital. The rest consists of fading out, back and forth, between the hospital and flashbacks offering highly selective snippets of the politician's personal life and extraordinary career.

title: Military Starts Study Of Pilots
description: HONOLULU, March 20Twelve aluminum transfer cases containing the remains of American pilots killed in the Vietnam War were examined today at the military's Central Identification Center in an attempt to positively identify the missing in action.

description: PARIS. March 20The runoffs in nationwide municipal elections today confirmed once again the steady gains of the left in France over much of the last decade.

Louis Blumgarten, Charles Cummings and Jack Stokvis. The TRT Bowling Green or South Ferry stations are closest to the institute.

description: Seventyone years old yesterday, Mayor Beame got a big kiss from the first woman assistant to the President and polite applause from a series of audiences as he hurried through an endofwinter snpw on a busy, candidatelike day.

title: Rivers Fails to Hustle; Will Face Martin Today
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 20 Mickey Rivers: Volume II, Chapter 3. In today's episode of the curious life and troubled times of the enigmatic Yankee center fielder, we see a line drive skip past Mickey and then we see him lazily jog after the ball. A moment later, we see Mickey take a few steps back on a fly ball, nonchalantly stick his glove up for it and drop it.

title: Mark Hayes Triumphs by 2 Shots On Par72 for 289 as Rivals Fade
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., March 20Mark Hayes, a 27yearold pokerfaced golf professional, set two personal records today in two holes: he slammed his wedge after a poor shot in the sand trap on No. 17, and he smiled on the green at No. 18 after scoring a birdie 4 and winning the $60,000 first prize in the Tournament Players Championship.

description: Small explosions knocked out windows in an East Side drug store and Bronx factory building early this morning, according to the police, who said there were no injuries in either blast. They occurred within moments of each other shortly after midnight.

description: When Ron Greschner and Mike McEwen blithely cross the enemy blue line, abandoning their defensive stations, sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't, says Greschner. When it works you look good, when it doesn't you look bad.

title: Lyle Rallies To Conquer Bugner in 12
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 20 (AP)Ron Lyle bloodied Joe Bugner's nose with a righthand punch in the 10th round today and defeated the Briton on a split decision in their 12round heavyweight boxing match.

title: ;Canadian Seal Hunt Gets Under Way Again, Renewing Controversy
description: ST. ANTHONY, Newfoundland, March 16The annual seal hunt is under way along the eastern Labrador coast and in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, and so is the recurrent controversy over a practice of centuries. While blood stains the ice floes in vast subArctic stretches, conservationists and sealers debate and battle in this and other bleak towns of northern Newfoundland that try to make their living from the harsh sea.

title: Tovah Feldshuh Wed to Andrew H. Levy
description: Tovah Feldshuh, the actress, was married yesterday afternoon to Andrew Harris Levy, a partner in the Washington law firm of Arent, Fox, Kintner, Plotlcin & Kahn. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony at the Plaza. Cantor William Wolff assisted.

title: Successful Foe Of Mrs. Gandhi
description: For many years known chiefly for Tas antics in the Indian Parliament, where at times he was asked to leave the chamber because of rowdy behavior. . . There were times when he had to be carried out . . . Image of politician, now 59 years old, changed two years ago when the Allahabad High Court ruled that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had illegally used federal and state officials in her 1971 election campaign against him. The decision, which was later overruled by the Supreme Court, touched off an unusually energetic wave of antiGovernment sentiment . .. He became a national hero, but soon found himself in jail when the Prime Minister declared a state of emergency. ... Head of socialist faction had been jailed many times by the British during the struggle for independence . . . Has consuming passion for politics . . . Rarely speaks about his family but has been known to seek out the company of children and to regale them with tales from Indian mythology. . . Often sports a green cloth wrapped around his head, Arabstyle, and in a culture where headdresses usually signify regional or religious associations, no one has been able to figure

title: Elly Ameling Sings Ravel And Lieder
description: Admirers of Elly Ameling were presented with an unscheduled treat at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. Saturday night when the Dutch soprano gave a recital in place of Judith Blegen, who was indisposed. Miss Ameline has been concentrating on the French and German song literature of late, and on this occasion her choice of repertory fell on Ravel, Schubert and Brahms.

title: Recital: Pollini
description: Maurizio Pollini, a widely admired and popular pianist, drew a full house for his Carnegie Hall recital Saturday night. His several previous appearances here have been uneven, in terms of critical reaction, but having just turned 33, he seems to have turned the corner into maturitythis occasion was almost wholly successful. Certainly the audience loved him.

title: The Jewish Defense League Protests at Hanafi Center
description: WASHINGTON, March 20Watched by more than twice their number of policemen, about 100 members of the Jewish Defense League staged a noisy but nonviolent demonstration in the rain today outside the headquarters of the Fianafi Moslems to protest the sect's 40hour takeover of the B'nai B'rith headquarters here 10 days ago.One person was killed and a number of persons were injured in the siege.

title: Intensive Care Designed for Tiny Patients
description: It was a few minutes after midnight last Monday when the premature infant born 20 hours earlier at St. John's Hospital in Yonkers began to show signs of trouble. His skin had a slightly bluish tinge, and there were spells when his breathing momentarily stormed.

title: Mark Patrick Stumpf, Lawyer And Historian of Irish Society, 67
description: Mark Patrick Stumpr, a lawyer whc was a member of the Cardinal's Committee cf the Laity and historian of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, died Saturday at his home, 541 East 20th Street. He was 67 years old.

description: HAMPTON, Ga., March 20 (AP)Richard Petty, gaining speed as the race progressed, set a record pace today in winning the $170,000 Atlanta 500 Grand National stock car race. It was his second successive Sunday victory.

description: ABERNATHY, Tex., March 17Dan Seale stopped his truck beside a rusting steel pipe in a field where cotton grew a few years ago. Now the land is little more than a playground for tumbleweeds.

Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were going to work full blast on Medicaid and Medicare fraud investigations, until his department's own antifraud office was fully operational.

description: Eileen M. Wallach and Alan M. Ross were married yesterday in Temple Beth David in Lynbrook, LI., by Rabbi Louis Diament.

title: West German Social Democrats lose Elections in Old Stronghold
description: WIESBADEN, West Germany, March 20 (Reuters)  West Germany's governing Social Democratic Party suffered serious defeats today in local elections in Hesse, losing their majority to the Christian Democratic Union in many towns.

title: John F. Meszaros Is Dead at 60; Executive for a Book Distributor
description: John F. Meszaros, a vice president and director of Select Magazines Inc., distributors of magazines and paperback books, died Saturday of a heart attack at his borne on Gray Rock Terrace in IrvingtononHudson, N.Y. He was 60 years old.

description: BORDENTOWN, March 20Shirley Bennett was going to visit her son. Jo Ann and Jacqueline Peoples were heading for a weekly reunion with their brother. Brenda Washington and Frances Snell were eager to see their respective boyfriends.

title: Competition Intense Among Intellectually Gifted 6th Graders for Openings at Hunter College High School
description: In sixth grades throughout the city, 3,354 of the best and the brightest are nervously waiting to hear if they are among the select 300 boys and girls, who are to be admitted next fall to Hunter College High School, a nearly windowless school on Manhattan's upper Park Avenue that looks appropriately like an unbreachable fortress.

title: Louisiana Derby Goes to Clev Er Tell
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 20 (AP)Clew Er Tell, ridden by Ray Broussard, led from the start to upset Run Dusty Run and win the $100,000 Louisiana Derby at the Fair Grounds today. Clew Er Tell took a lead out of the gate and was never headed on the way to tying the track record of 1:48 45 for the 1 18mile distance.

title: History of American Film
description: HARTFORDThe only fair word and it is a word we have been hearing a lot of in the theater lately for Christopher Durang's A History of American Film, which has just appeared at the Hartford Stage Company, is mythic.

title: Nets Produce Goodwill on Lost Weekend
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20The New York Mets landed back here tonight after a 2,000mile round trip to the Dominican Republic, where they created waves of goodwill when Tom Seaver threw a homerun ball to the pinchhitting hero of the island, Manny Mota of the Los Angeles Dodgers.

description: KARACHI. Pakistan, Monday, March 21 (Reuters)The Pakistani Government trying to avert further political violence, has decided to allow four detained opposition leaders to attend a meeting in Lahore today.

title: Connors Defeats Alexander; Chris Evert Captures Final
description: ST. LOUIS, March 20 (AP)Jimmy Ccnnors overcame a slump in concentration during the opening set and mastered Australia's John Alexander, 76, 62, in the final today of the $100,000 St. Louis Classic.

title: An Early Change Seems Unlikely In Credit Markets
description: The stalemate in the credit markets that has kept interest rates unusually stable this month continued last week. Moneymarket economists and bond traders could see little reason Friday for this steadiness to give way very soon. In fact, the strength of the forces keeping the credit markets in balance escalated last week they said.

title: LEFTISTS AGAIN GAIN IN FRENCH ELECTIONS, TAKING 21 BIG CITIES
description: PARIS, March 20The opposition left made considerable gains in nationwide municipal voting today, but it was defeated in Paris as former Prime Minister Jacaues Chirac won the mayoral election.

title: Where Terror Is King
description: BOSTON, March 20Communist Vietnam and Laos welcomed President Carter's commission on Americans missing in Indochina, but the Government of Cambodia would not allow a visit. It was a decision to be expected from the most tightly locked up country in the world, where the bloodiest revolution in history is now taking place.

title: The Trees of Peking
description: PEKINGA columnist given the opportunity to wander about the Forbidden City is tempted to try his hand at reporting.

title: The Minimally Useful Minimum Wage
description: Congress will debate a new minimum wage this spring, but this time there's a twist. Organized labor, drained by the battle to raise the wage floor every few years, pushing for a permanent solution: indexing. This approach, proposed by John Dent, chairman of the House Labor Standards Subcommittee, would raplace thb current $2.30 minimum with an index keyed to the average manufacturing wage. Chairman Dent wants the minimum set at 55 percent of that average wageabout $2.85 an hour this yearand 60 percent in 1978, about $3.30. With such an index, the minimum wage would automatically be tied to the fortunes of industrial workers, eliminating the need for periodic Congressional amendments.

title: Four Teams With Varied Styles Survive in a Tournament of Surprises
description: Jerry Tarkanian, the coach who had to leave Long Beach State because people frowned on his recruiting practices out there, set up shop some miles east and is now taking the apparent favorite, the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, into the semifinals of the 39th N.C.A.A. basketball championship.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: OPPOSITION IS LEADING
description: NEW DELHI, Monday, March 21Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was soundly defeated today for her parliamentary seat in India's sixth national election, and her Congress Party, which has held power ever since the nation gained independence, was trailing.

title: My Father's Country Is the Poor
description: A week before I flew to Cuba began to dream about my father. For several nights he appeared in a pose I recognized but could not place: Standing by the side of a road in front of a filling station, his hat in his hands, watching me as I moved farther and farther away from him.

title: Sabbath Ban on School Activities Arouses a Controversy in Teaneck
description: TEANECK, N.J., March 20This Bergen County community, which has long prided itself on its ability to meet the challenges of social change, is embroiled in a controversy over a school board policy that bans to the maximum feasible extent schoolsponsored activities on the Jewish Sabbath, from sundown Friday to sundown Saturday, and on the Christian Sabbath, on Sunday morning.

title: Bill to Bar Americans
description: WASHINGTON, March 20Controversial and longdelayed legislation that would bar Americans from participating in the Arab boycott of Israel is scheduled to reach the decision stage Tuesday afternoon in the House Foreign Relations Committee.

title: HARDWICK STIRES
description: Hardwick Stires, a retired partner in the investment firm of Scudder Stevens & Clark, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital He was 76 years old and had been living in Cody, Wyo.

title: Market Place
description: World Airways, which has caused nervousness in the airline industry since the company began seeking authority to fly coasttocoast routes at $89 each way, announced last Thursday that it would spend $500 million to buy new McDonnell Douglas DC10s.

title: OVERTHEAIR PAY TV HAS BEGUN IN JERSEY
description: With little fanfare, except among residents of South Orange, N.J., the metropolitan area's first overtheair paytelevision station began its subscription service on March 1.

title: Advertising
description: If there's anything that pleases an ad agency more than getting a new client, it's the return of an old One.

title: LaSalle Gets 26th President
description: PHILADELPHTA, March 20 (AP)Brother Patrick Ellis was inaugurated today as LaSalle College's 26th president. Brother Ellis, 48 years old, is a native of Baltimore and has been a member of the Brothers of the Christian Schools since 1946. He joined the LaSalle staff in 1960 and served as its director of development before being named president.

title: Singer Seeking to Alter impressions in U.S. of Ireland
description: SOUTH ORANGETwo weeks ago, David Hammond left his wife and four children at home in Belfast and came to the United States with his guitar and 10 Irish ballads to teach Americans about the Irish.

title: Excerpts From Schmidt Interview
description: ON RELATIONS WITH THE U.S.: I do not see any kind of a crisis at all. Since President Carter's inauguration and already before that we have again established close personal channels. Jimmy Carter has come to the domestic as well the international scene with fresh energies. . .. He will without any doubt inject fresh judgment into the international dialogue. ON NUCLEAR PROLIFERATION:

title: Artist, 80, and Manager Stave Off Eviction by Outflanking Landlord
description: For the next two years, Mrs. Elsa de Brun, an artist who goes under the Gaelic name of Nualashe turned 80 last Oct. 11and her managercorn. panion, Patric Farrell, who will be 70 next July 22, will be able to keep their sixroom flat at 161 East 81st Street.

title: Neighborhood: Laurelton Group Battling Blight
description: Hardcore pornographic movies are no longer being shown in the Laurelton Theater, in Laurelton, Queens. Stores along Merrick Boulevard, its main stem, that were vacant for many months are now reopening. Youngsters who volunteered to trim overgrown hedges for the elderly have been treated to Broadway shows and majorleague baseball games. Grassy street islands, abandoned by the city, have been brought back to life by the residents.

title: The Primitive Peepers
description: Some years the spring peepers start calling in midMarch, some years not until the first week in April, depending on weather and place. But Whenever it happens, the peeper chorus is the voice of eternal spring. There is nothing else quite like it. Robins sing and maple sap rises, but the peepers in full voice are the ancient and triumphant cry of life enduring. The message is as unmistakable as sunrise.

title: U.S. Skiers Take Relay
description: MORIN HEIGHTS, Quebec, March 20 The United States No. I team, made up of Doug Peterson, Tim Caldwell and Don Nielsen, took first place today in the men's 30kilometer relay race in the North American crosscountry skiing championships. The winning time was 90 minutes 29.12 seconds.

title: Grossman Conducts Mendelssohn Work
description: Mendelssohn's rarely heard Symphony No. 1 in C Minor (Op. 11), performed by Julius Grossman and the Municipal Concerts Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall Saturday night, is actually his 13th. One through 12 were early symphonies for strings alone. Then came five for full Orchestra, of which the C Minor is the first.

title: DISEASE EXPERT SEES THREAT OF GERM WAR
description: The nation's former top civilian epidemiologist, whose job was to protect the public against the sread of communicable diseases, disclosed yesterday that m his Government service he spend onefifth of his working time on problems connected with military biological warfare studies because he regarded biological warfare as a serious threat to the United States.

title: Palestinians Back Peace Parley Role
description: CAIRO, March 20The Palestine National Council adopted a declaration today calling for the establishment of an independent national state on national soil and authorizing Palestinian attendance at an ArabIsraeli peace conference.

title: Stenmark Again Wins World Cup
description: ARE, Sweden, March 20 (AP)Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden captured the World Cup in Alpine skiing today for the second year in a row. He clinched the honor with a smashing victory by 1.59 seconds in the last slalom race of the series.

title: Sabbath Ban on School Activities Arouses a Controversy in Teaneck
description: TEANECK, N.J., March 20This Bergen County community, which has long prided itself on its ability to meet the challenges of social change, is embroiled in a controversy over a school board policy that bans to the maximum feasible extent schoolsponsored activities on the Jewish Sabbath, from sundown Friday to sundown Saturday, and on the Christian Sabbath, on Sunday morning.

title: Amy Carter's Nurse Is Accepted by Church
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (UPI)Mary Fitzpatrick, released from a life murder sentence so she could care for Amy Carter in the White House, was accepted today as a member by the congregation of the First Baptist Church, where the First Family worships.

title: Georgia Execution Postponed
description: ATLANTA, March 20 (AP)Samuel. Gibson 3d, a convicted rapistmurderer who had been scheduled to die in Georgia's electric chair tomorrow, has received a temporary stay of execution, a state official said tonight. William Low, deputy commissioner for the Department of Offender Rehabilitation, said that Mr. Gibson had been granted the stay by the Butts County Superior Court. Mr. Gibson murdered Joan Delight Bryan of Gray,

title: U.S. COMMISSION ENDS ITS VISIT TO INDOCHINA
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 20President Carter's special mission on persons missing in action in Indochina left here for home today after taking the first tentative steps toward improving United States relations with Laos and Vietnam.

title: Court Says Union Can Attach Fees Paid Nursing Homes by Medicaid
description: The union representing most employees of the private nursing hcmes in New York City has won court permission to attach Medicaid payments being received by 42 nursing homes and is seeking judgments against 25 others. The effort is intended to recover $15 million owed to the union's welfare and pension fund.

title: Coast Utilities Test Volt Cuts To Save Energy
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 18Voltage reductions, which a few years ago were as much a part of summer for many New Yorkers as the Good Humor man, are becoming a permanent institution across California. Nearly all of the state's major utilities have agreed to begin testing, circuit by circuit, the effects of a 3 percent, or four volt, cut.

title: Gay
description: Opera's most durable double bill. Nlascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana and Leoncavallo's Pagliacci, joined the New York City Opera's spring repertory Saturday afternoon. Both are violent short stories about vengeful lovers. told convincingly only with full dose of rude Mediterranean passion. On this occasion, Pagliacci convinced, and Cavalleria didn't.

title: Homosexual Named to Rights Panel
description: , The appointment of the first gay activist to serve on the New York City Human Rights Commission was announced yesterday by Mayor Hearne.

title: Issue and Debate
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  The House subcommittee investigation into the Food and Drug Administration's proposal to ban saccharin and the legal basis for the action, the socalled Delaney Clause, is scheduled to open at 10 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Japan's Prime Minister Arrives In Washington to Meet Carter
description: WASHINGTON. March 20 (AP)Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda of Japan arrived here today for an official visit to sound out President Carter on his economic policies and his plans for reducing United States military forces in South Korea.

title: Singer Stresses Irish Image in U.S.
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J.Two weeks ago, David Hammond left his wife and four children at home in Belfast and came to the United States with his guitar and 10 Irish ballads to teach Americans about the Irish.

title: News Summary
description: In India, returns from the sixth national election indicated that. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi was soundly defeated for her parliamentary seat and that her Congress Party was trading the oppositionthe Janata and the Congress for Democracy. But many parts of southern India, where the Congress Party was expected to do better were still to be heard from. Sanjay Gandhi, the Prime Minister's son, was defeated in a rural constituency east of New Delhi. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Red Smith
description: MIAMI, March 20 Four cormorants sat side by side on a channel marker looking on as Al Philpott Sr. steered the good ship Seabiscuit into Biscayne Bay and turned south toward Government Cut. In his 81st year, Philpott pere tougher than a turtle's hind leg, a vestpocket Captain Bligh with the gift of freestyle profanity. Reachine the open sea. he headed down past Key Biscayne toward Forey Rock, one of the lights that warn mariners away from shoals from here to Key West. As owner of the boat, Al Philpott Jr. was permitted to share the duties of mate with his brotherinlaw, Wes Liston. On the way to the Gulf Stream, they rigged six rods, baiting four of them with little pointyllie limes nosed fish called ballao, one with a small, dead mullet and one with a feather jig. Philpott fils, hereinafter known as Al, said a few school dolphin had been showing, although it was still early in the year for those lovely and palatable creatures.

title: Mark Stephen Stimmler Marries Jane D. Kaplan
description: Jane Deborah Kaplan, a marketing planning manager for the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia, and Mark Stephen Stimmler, a marketing officer for the Philadelphia Saving Fund Society, were married yesterday afternoon in Millburn, N.J.

title: Liberation
description: In the swell of opposition to the war in Vietnam during the decade before America's withdrawal, there was always a minority, small but vehement, that looked the Communists as saviors of that unhappy land. They carried Vietcong flags in peace demonstrations, hailed Ho Chi Minh as the George Washington of his country, and invariably spoke of the North Vietnamese as liberators.

title: Clinton, Martin of P.S.A.L. Subdue Top Catholic Fives
description: For one day at least, public school basketball proved superior to the Catholic school style as DeWitt Clinton and August Martin won their games yesterday in the first Metropolitan Conference playoffs at St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens.

title: WESTINGHOUSE CONTRACTS ON F16 RADAR AWARDED
description: PITTSBURGH, March 20The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has awarded four contracts valued at about $55 million to European electronics companies for coproduction of the multimode radar developed by Westinghouse for the F16 singleengine fighter plane.

title: Rabin Says He Was Joint Holder Of U.S. Bank Account With Wife
description: TEL AVIV, March 20Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin acknowledged tonight that a personal bank account maintained illegally in Washington four years after he had concluded his term as Ambassador there had belonged jointly to himself and his wife.

title: Concert by American Symphony
description: The American Symphony Orcnestra was in fine form for the first half of its program in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. It played two works that are admittedly not weighty. Piston's Suite from The Incredible Flutist and Bartok's Dance Suite: in doing justice to them with sensitive performances under the direction of Kazuyoshi Akiyama, it did honor to itself.

title: LONG WARNS CARTER ON WATER PROJECTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 20It was a quiet lunch at the White House: President Carter and Senator Russell B. Long eating sandwiches in the Oval Office, discussing what was described as a wide range of issues.

title: Robin L. Freier Wed to Kenneth Dubensky,BankAide
description: Robin Lori Freier and Kenneth M. Dubensky were married yesterday in the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club. Rabbi Robert Widom of Great Neck, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: Chess:
description: Michael Rohde, a 17yearold International master from South Orange, N.J., won the 11th International Youth Tournament in Schilde,. Belgium, with a 71 score.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: Week ended March 18, 1977

title: Digging for Gold Treasure Begins
description: WHITE SANDS, N.M., March 20Men wielding picks and shovels began excavating here today at a site near the top of Victorio Peak, a limestone mountain where a Florida treasurehunting concern believes it may find a legendary cache of gold bullion.

title: Employees of Utica Forbidden to Speak To News Reporters
description: UTICA, N.Y., March 20Mayor Edward Hanna has ordered all city employees ?? to talk to newsmen covering the city government here. His order is working so well that even he cannot be reached.

title: St. Bonaventure Takes N.I.T. By Defeating Houston, 94 to 91
description: Greg Sanders, a flamboyant lef handed shooter, and Glenn Hagan, little backcourt general, both termed recruiting steals, led St. Bonaventure University to its first National Invitation Tournament crown yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

title: A Question of Deductions
description: Is the System Corrupt?

title: Swiss Beat Cosmos, 31
description: ZURICH, March 20 (Reuters)  Switzerland's European Cup semifinal soccer team, Zurich F.C., defeated the New York Cosmos, 31, tonight before 4,000 fans. Giorgio Chinaglia scored for the Cosmos.

title: E. Ward King, Who Founded Mason and Dixon Truck Lines
description: KINGSPORT, Tenn., March 20, (Reuters) E. Ward King, founder of what is said to be the largest familyowned trucking company in the United States, died yesterday. He was 81 years old.

title: Op Odyssey II
description: The ideas behind Op Odyssey IL a mixedmedia peformance presented at the Theater of the Open Eye Saturday night, were excellent. Why then was there a certain bloodlessness to the event?

title: Nets Try Hard but 76ers Prevail, 111104
description: UNIONDALE, LI., March 20Showing the strength that has already assured them a place in the National Basketball Association playoffs, the Philadelphia 76ers overpowered the New York Nets, 111104, today at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: A Lawyer Is Elected Chairman Of Fund for the City of New York,
description: Seymour Graubard, a lawyer, has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Fund for the City of New York, private foundation dedicated to improving quality of life and government services in New York City.

title: Hunt for Absent Welfare Parents Off to Slow Start
description: A monitoring of the city's federally mandated program to locate absent welfare parents and to get court orders for support payments resulted in a report yesterday that firstyear costs were more than triple the recelpts$18,086,475 spent to collect $5,713,230.

title: Rabin Says He Was Joint Holder Of U.S. Bank Account With Wife
description: TEL AVIV, March 20Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin acknowledged tonight that a personal bank account maintained illegally in Washington four years after he had concluded his term as Ambassador there had belonged jointly to himself and his wife.

title: Kidnappers Free Wealthy Italian
description: BORNAGO, Italy, March 20 (UPDKidnappers released a northern Italian industrialist. Carlo Colombo, last night after 34 days of captivity for a ransom the police estimated at $1.2 million.

title: Yael Margolin Is Married to Dr. David Goldenberg
description: Yael Margolin of New York, a candidate for a Ph.D. degree in clinical psychology at Adelphi University, and Dr. David Goldenberg of Teaneck. N.J., a resident in internal medicine at the Metropolitan Hospital Center in New York, were married at noon yesterday.

title: Lisa J. Farmer, Student, Bride of Eugene Paulen
description: Lisa Joy Farmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Farmer of New York, was married yesterday to Eugene Paulen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Paulen of Wantagh and East Hampton, L.I. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in Temple EmanuEl.

title: Officer and ExConvict in Hospital After Gunfight in 42d Street IND
description: A transit policeman who engaged in a gun battle with a former convict on a midtown subway station was recovering from his wounds yesterday and his assailant was in critical condition at Bellevue Hospital.

title: Auto Workers Strike Ford Plant Over Local Working Conditions
description: ST. LOUIS, March 20 (UPI)About 2,700 auto workers struck the Ford Motor Company assembly plant in suburban Hazelwood over unresolved local grievances.

title: Met Opera Bestows Prizes but No Jobs
description: The disappointment over not winning a contract yesterday with the Metropolitan Opera Company was lifted somewhat for Vinson Cole, Christine Donahue and Elizabeth Parcells by the fact that they were awarded the top three prizes of the national final auditions.

title: 1985 CLEANUP GOALS ON WATER CRITICIZED BY PAPER INDUSTRY
description: The paper industrywhich contends that onefifth of its capital spending is simply to meet regulatory requirements is taking aim at the stiffest provisions of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972.

title: Books of The Times
description: The world of Joan Didion's complex, powerful but flawed third novel, A Book of Common Prayer, is, needless to say, an uncommonly nasty one, though familiar enough in atmosphere from her second novel. Play It as It Lays. In the north of it lies California, where children blow up office buildings and hijack airplanes, while at fundraising parties in Beverly Hills actresses speak of the superior health and beauty of the children in Hanoi, because they aren't raised by their mothers . . . They don't have any of that bourgeois personal crap laid on them. In the south of this world lies the fictional Central American country of Boca Grande, where revolutions come and go, though nothing actually changes; where every time the sun falls on a day . . . that day appears to vanish from memory, to be reinvented but never recalled; and where there is lightThe opaque equatorial light. The bush and the sea do not reflect the light but absorb it, suck it in, then glow morbidly.

title: FRANK L. PERLEY
description: Frank L. Perley, Middle Western sales representative for King Features Syndicate since 1968, died Thursday in Park Ridge, Ill., after a lengthy illness. He was 59 years old and lived in Park Ridge.

title: Honolulu Newspaper Strike Vote
description: HONOLULU, March 20 (UPI) Members of the Hawaii Newspaper Guild today authorized their bargaining committee to call a strike against The Honolulu StarBulletin and Honolulu Advertiser to back contract demands. Phil Mayer, member of the bargaining committee, said that the publisher of the two newspapers had offered a four percent raise, or $15 a weak, for topscale employees.

title: Schmidt Asserts'Irritations'i Will Not Divide U.S. and Bonnl
description: I BONN, March 17  Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, in a guarded mood because of a spate of domestic troubles and policy conflicts with the Carter Administration, says that he is optimistic about developing close relations with the new President Idespite irritations in GermanAmerican relations.

title: Court Says Union Can Attach Fees Paid Nursing Homes by Medicaid
description: The union representing most employees of the private nursing homes in New York City has won court permission to attach Medicaid payments being received by 42 nursing homes and is seeking judgments against 25 others. The effort is intended to recover $15 million owed to the union's welfare and pension fund.

title: Recital by Galina Vishnevskaya Captures The Spirit of Russian Songsand Audience
description: Galina Vishnevskaya's recital at Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon was on the short side but no one could possibly have felt shortchanged. Very few singers today exercise such command over an audience, generate so much intensity and demand such a degree of concentration; her art can be draining experience but a rewarding one in every way.

title: NOW to Demonstrate in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)The National Organization for Women plans to demonstrate in front of the White House Tuesday on the fifth anniversary of the approval by Congress of the equal rights amendment. The organization said that it wanted to praise President Carter for his efforts so far on behalf of the amendment but also to urge him to do more.

title: Erich Segal and Oliver The Second Time Around
description: Erich Segal, the Roman classicist and fourhandkerchief novelist, is llOW working on his next story.

title: End of a Dynasty Is Greeted With Cheers in New Delhi
description: NEW DELHI, Monday, March 21The pair of villas from which Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and her son Sanjay virtually ruled India stood silent through their night of defeat.

title: Television
description: 11:00 A.M. The Petrified Forest (1956) (5)

title: Orders of Durables For February Held At January's Level
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)New orders for factory goods failed to recover in February from the weatherinduced January slowdown, and were unchanged for the month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S. Sees No Change on Key Issue
