title: Personal Health
description: ONE 15YEAROLD girl with acne scrubbed her face six times a day for 10 minutes at a time trying desperately to rid her visage of Those disgusting pussy pimples. A high school boy with acne on his shoulders, back and arms as well as his face felt that no one would want to look at him, so whenever possible he avoided social contacts, made few friends and even fewer dates.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday. March 22. 1977

title: Chess:
description: Not for many years has the United States had as strong a crop of young players as it does now. Although our student team still has far to go to mount a convincing challenge to the world champion Soviet students, the United States juniors monopolized individual competitions this year.

title: Islanders Hit Season High in Romping by 92
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 22The rainy day the Islanders had been saving their goals for arrived tonight. And the goals came as easily as the raindrops, letting the Islanders romp to a 92 triumph over the Colorado Rockies.

title: Honor Student at Vassar Wins Dismissal in Case Over Disorderly Conduct
description: A 21yearold honor student at Vassar College won a court decision yesterday to dismiss charges of disorderly conduct and resisting arrest that grew out of an incident last month at a train station in Manhattan.

title: Advertising
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company, which has taken a leading role among agencies in exploring consumer reaction to televised violence, is currently involved with six advertisers in researching the effects of violent procrams on the commercials they carry.

title: Police Interpreter in Chinatown Says That Officers Harass Her
description: Lily Wu, a receptionist and civilian interpreter for the Fifth Police Precinct in Chinatown, charged yesterday that she was being subjected to obscene language, threats and other harassment by police officers because she had testified against two officers in an alleged police brutality case.

title: Dr. King's Slayer Interviewed In Prison by House Investigators
description: PETROS, Tenn., March 22 (AP)James Earl Ray met today for more than two hours with lawyers for the House Assassinations Committee to give a preliminary interview on his role in the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in April 1968.

title: Utica Mayor, in Feud With Press, Lectures Reporters on Coverage
description: UTICA. N.Y., March 22Edward A. Hanna, the frenetic Mayor of this Oneida County city of 91,000. was his cheery, rambunctious self this morning as he walked into his City Hall office for what had been promised would be a news conference on his latest proolem with the news media, specifically a weekold gag order restricting some city officials from speaking to the press.

title: Dozen Pupils, Some With Bats, Rampage on a Bus in Brooklyn
description: More than a dozen pupils from William E. Grady Vocational High School, some of them armed with bats, rampaged on city bus yesterday morning, the police in Brooklyn reported. One of the students, believed to be the leader of the group, was arrested.

title: Heart Transplant Recipient Dies; Was Longest Living Such Patient
description: MILWAUKEE, March 22Betty Anick of Milwaukee, who survived a heart transplant operation longer than any other patient, died this morning in Florida where she had moved a month ago.

title: Senate G.O.P. Majority in Albany Fighting Carey's SchoolAid Plan
description: ALBANY, March 22The Republican majority in the New York State Senate, as part of the final negotiations on the stata budget, is insisting that no school district get less state aid next year than it got this yearthereby scrapping Governor Carey's plan to assure that districts with declining enrollments would lose their saveharmless guarantees of constant state aid.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: They are nothing but funtiny glass animals with a belly full of ruby sapphire chips or gold dust, showing through, naturally. The menagerie is from collection by Jill Stuart called Please don't feed the animals and each little beastie is on a thin cord to hang around one's neck. Some of the animals pretty hard to figure out, but whether they're mice or pigs or rabbits or elephants, they're cute. The prices go from $28 to $65 and Bloomingdale's jewelry department is housing the collection. Incidentally, the chips and gold dust are supposed to be real.

title: Panel Suggests Oil and Coal Curbs
description: WASHINGTON. March 22 (AP)President Carter's forthcoming environmental message to Congress may propose that offshore petroleum drilling and onshore coal mining on Federal lands be banned in selected marine sanctuaries and valuable farmlands.

title: Around the Nation
description: BOYS TOWN, Neb., March 22 (UPI)Boys Town, the famed home for boys, reported today that the Father Flanagan Endowment Fund was reduced by more than $8 million last year to $185 million to help finance current construction and new youth services programs.

title: A Potage From the Sea
description: Although the chowders of America's East Coast seem as distinctly Yankee as flapjacks and brown bread, the name is of French origin. It is said to have been brought to this country by fishermen who came from the coastal regions of France. The name derives from chaudire or cauldron, in which the fishermen had made their fish soups and stews on native soil. Here is a French chowder, la chaudiere de poisson:

title: Muriel King Dies; Designed Dresses For Films in 30's
description: Muriel Xing, a fashion designer whose dresses were equally popular in high society and in Hollywood, died Monday at Danbury, (Conn.) Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in Bethel. Conn.

title: Best Buys
description: NOW THAT spring is here, can lower food prices be far behind? Yes, says the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Baynard Kendrick, Writer Of Mysteries Featuring Blind Detective's Feats
description: Baynard H. Kendrick, the mystery writer who created the blind sleuth Capt. Duncan Maclain, died yesterday in nursing home in Ocala, Fla., after threemonth illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Head of Oceanic Agency Ouits
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)Robert M. White, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, submitted his resignation effective July 15, it was disclosed today. Mr. White, 54 years old, who has headed the agency since its beginning in 1970, will become chairman of the National Academy of Sciences Climate Research Board.

title: ROSENBAUM IS URGED FOR NEW G.O.P. POST
description: In what is regarded as a prelude to his stepping aside as Republican state chairman, Richard M. Rosenbaum was proposed yesterday as a possible new Republican national committeeman from New York

title: World News Briefs
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo. March 22 (UPI) Former President Alphonse MassambaDdbat has confessed to planning to overthrow President Marion Ngouabi and having contacts with the group that assassinated him on Friday, the Brazzaville radio said today.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IN TRADITIONAL menu planning, a main course, more often than not, is served with a starch such as rice or potatoes, plus a green vegetable. Quite obviously, when planning a meal to be cooked in limited time, if you can combine all these elements in one casseroleand in less time than it takes to prepare each separately5 ou are ahead of the game.

title: Drop in Gold and Soybean Prices Touches Off Widespread Selling
description: A moderate retreat in soybean and gold bullion futures prices early yesterday triggered widespread profit taking in the commodity market.

title: MYSTERY SURROUNDS NURSE IN V.A. DEATHS
description: DETROIT, March 22  The former supervisor of two Filipino nurses on trial here for the murder or attempted murder of nine patients at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor was regarded as an excellent nurse who really cared about patients.

title: Kingman Breaks Nose in Bat Drill
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22The outbreak of injuries afflicting the New York Mets took a bizarre turn today when Dave Kingman, the team's leading homerun hitter, suffered a broken nose in batting practice.

title: Untied Press International
description: LONDON, March 22Prospects of an agreement that would save the life of Britain's Labor Government brightened considerably today as a result of a flurry of backstage conferences, but it appeared unlikely that Prime Minister James Callaghan's fate would be known for sure until a vote of confidence tomorrow night.

title: Dateline 1977: The Philadelphia Story
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.Financial discussions among baseball players are confusing these days, Danny Ozark was saying. When they say one,  he said, you and I think means a dollar. To them it means a million.

title: Careers
description: Courses for private security personnel are proliferating at universities and community colleges around the country, most recently at Hofstra University and New York University.

title: Rebuff to Mrs. King Causes A Split in Women's Tennis
description: A clause that would have allowed Billie Jean King to play in the Virginia Slims championship as a wildcard entry has created bitter feelings and an embarrassing situation among top women tennis players on the eve of the $150,000 event at Madison Square Garden.

title: Children in Accord Over Poison Safety
description: NEWARK, March 22  A tall, bearded Tennessean struck a few chords on his welltraveled guitar today, and sang his way into the hearts of a group of kindergarten youngsters getting their first lesson on poison and drugs.

title: Bayi Heads Meet Field in Jamaica
description: Track stars from 18 nations, including Filbert Bayi of Tanzania, Donald Quarrie of Jamaica. Alberto Juantorena of Cuuba and Dwight Stone of the United States, will take part in a meet in Kingston, Jamaica, on May 14.

description: RESULTS

title: Knicks Top Bucks With Early Drive
description: Don't ask the Knick players to explain. They can't or won't. But suddenly the Knicks have come alive with the National Basketball Association season winding down and their playoff hopes slim.

title: James J. Wilson, Age 80; Sports Enthusiast Had Led The New York Athletic Club
description: James J. Wilson, a sports enthusiast and president of the New York Athletic Club in 1962 and 1963, died Sunday in Columbia Presbyterian Hospital after short illness. He lived in Tenafly, N.J., land was 80 years old.

title: Carter Requests Funds for Big Increase in Broadcasts to Soviet Bloc
description: WASHINGTON, March 22President Carter asked Congress today to provide funds for a large increase in transmitting capacity for United Statessponsored radio broadcasts to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

title: Layton In, Haywood Out
description: Before the games the Knicks placed Haywood on the injured reserve list and reactivated Mo Layton. Haywood, who missed his 40th game last night, must sit out at least four more games.

title: Minimum Wage Bill Is Reported to Divide The Administration
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Carter Administration is sharply divided over what position to take on pending legisla: tion to increase the minimum wage, wellplaced Administration sources said today.

title: Missouri Basin Planner Resigns
description: OMAHA, Neb., March 22 (AP)The director of planning for the 10state Missouri River Basin Commission has resgned because of what the chairman called conflicts with state members that weer not resolvable. The chairman, John W. Neuberger, said that Nicholas L. Barbarossa would be succeeded by Carroll Hamon in the planning job, which has a pay range of $28,600 to $31,800 a year.

title: U.S. Mission Says Hanoi Plans to Return Remains Of C.I.A. Man and Soldier
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)The White House Commission on Missing in Action returned from Southeast Asia today and announced that Hanoi planned to return the remains of a former Central Intelligence Agency employee and a serviceman.

title: Three Symbols of the Seder Service And What They Mean
description: Why did our fathers eat the paschal lamb while the Temple was still in existence? Because the Holy One, blessed be He, passed over our fathers house in Egypt; as it is said: And you shall say: is the Lord's Passover, because He passed over the house of the children of Israel in Egypt, when He smote the firstborn of the Egyptians, and He spared our houses. And the people bowed their heads and worshipped.

title: Steinbrenner Proposes Diluting Kuhn's Povier
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 22 At a time when a Federal judge has reaffirmed Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's omnipotent authority in baseball, George Steinbrenner has called for a restructuring of that power into a brdader base.

title: MAYOR FLAHERTY SCORED FOR OPPOSITION TO BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  Mayor Peter F. Flaherty of Pittsburgh, President Carter's nominee as Deputy Attorney General under Griffin B. Bell, was accused today of openly advocating defiance of a lawful order to use busing to integrate city schools.

title: NIGERIA URGES SANCTIONS AGAINST SOUTH AFRICANS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22Nigeria's Foreign Minister called today in the Security Council for economic sanctions against South Africa and told Western countries that blocking such action could lead to economic reprisals against them.

title: Gold Ends Week's Rise With $2 Drop in Europe; Pound Loses Marginally
description: LONDON, March 22 (AP)The price of gold dropped about $2 in London and Zurich today after rising for more than a week. The dollar gained marginally in Europe.

title: Kennecott Joins in Increasing Price for Its Copper Cathodes
description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation, the nation's largest copper producer, decided yesterday to go along with the 3centapound increase in the price of copper cathodes that was instituted last Saturday by the Anaconda Company, the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company and the Copper Range Company.

title: CHARLES METZGER
description: Charles Metzger, former owner of the Garden Cafeteria at 165 East Broadway. which used to be popular with journalists from the Lower East Side, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach after a short illness. Mr. Metzger, who sold the restaurant a year ago, lived in Hallandale, Fla., and was 81 years old.

title: Justices Limit U.S. Court Intervention in State Laws
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Supreme Court cut back still further today the power of Federal courts to hear lawsuits challenging the constitutionality of state laws or proceedings.

title: 60 Are Killed by Earthquake in Southern Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 22 (Reuters) An earthquake struck southern Iran today and the government radio said 60 persons had been killed in villages near the Persian Gulf city of Bandar Abbas.

title: Hospital Corporation Fiscal Plan Gets BackUp Pledge From City
description: The Beame Administration promised yesterday to bail out the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation in the event the corporation's newly revised financial plan failed to eliminate a $27 million deficit by June 30.

title: Califano Puts Chef on U.S. Payroll
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)While President Carter is campaigning to eliminate Government frills, Secretary Joseph A. Califano Jr. of Health, Education and Welfare has put a chef on the public payroll to prepare his meals.

title: DERAILMENT MAY DELAY 27,000 L.I.R.R. RIDERS
description: An estimated 27.000 Long Island Rail Road commuters faced delays of up to 40 minutes this morning on trains to New York City because of the derailment last night of five cars of a sevencar freight train in Queens, according to a railroad spokesman.

title: SENATE VOTES LIMIT OF $8,625 A MEMBER ON OUTSIDE EARNINGS
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Senate approved tonight an $8,625 limitation on its members earned outside income on an unusually acrimonious threeday debate.

title: Three Blocks Front Home, He's a Stranger
description: During the first year or so of my residence in Manhattan, people would say, Heh, heh! You've got to be little crazy to live in New York, and I would mutter. Brother, you've got to be nuts. But I don't feel that way now. I have changed. And the change was brought about by the realization that New York, in human terms, is not a city at all: It is a collection of fortified hamlets.

description: HOLMBY HILLS, Calif. In Bel Air there is ZsaZsaGaborTonyCurtisJerryLewis . . . and Torn Jones just bought Dean Martin's place.

title: 2 Killings in Pakistan Said to Bring Curfew Toll to
description: KARACHI, March 22 (Reuters)A man and a boy were shot to death today for breaking a curfew in strifetorn Karachi, reliable sources said. This raised to eight the number of people killed since the curfew was imposed Saturday after 30 persons died in daylong riots they said.

There is no increase in'the price of permitsfor adults, $27.50; for those under 18 years of age, $6, and for the elderly swingers (62 and over). $15.

title: Hurting the Poor to Help the Poor
description: Governor Carey has challenged the New York State Legislatureand all New Yorkersto follow him adopting a budget that would turn the state's social policy in a dramatic new direction. The next few weeks, or days, will show whether we are ready to match his daring.

title: Surprise! Bejart Ballet Is Marked by Surprises
description: THE ONLY UNSURPRISING thing about the infrequent invasions of New York City by Maurice Bejart and his Ballet of the 20th Century is that there is always something surprising about them. Now Mr. Bejart is on his fifth visit to New Yorkhe opened last night at the Uris Theater for a twoweek runand this marks his Broadway debut.

title: First 21, Then a B.L.T., and Now. It's Lunch From Home
description: I don't know about., you, but my heart sinks Whenever anyone suggests eating in at the officetheirs or mine. Not because, as one of my colleagues said, if I'm important enough to have lunch with, I'm important enough to take out! No, on the face of things, I find eating in an attractive idea. You avoid the hassle and the expense of going out to a restaurant. If you're eating in by yourself, you can get some work done during a period when the telephone is less likely to ring. And if you're eating with somebody else you can get right down to business without a lot of discussion about whetheer the smoked trout is better than the red snapper, or the timewasting twodrink ritual. Right?

title: Behind the Pantry Doors: A Gastronome's Choice
description: For reasons that are all too obvious, convenience foods categorically have earned a bad name among gastronomes. But in fact, there are dozens Of foodscanned, packaged and bottledthat are not only instant and convenient, but delicious as well.

description: LUBBOCK, Tex., March 21Given President Carter's opposition to huge and expensive water diversion projects in the West, this hardly seems like the time to propose another one. Texas, however, is preparing to do just that.

title: The Sneeze From Moscow
description: If the United States were organized like the Soviet Union, the world would be well accustomed to hearing Jimmy Carter speak alternately as President and leader of the international democratic movement. No one would then be troubled when he celebrated democrats the world over including those languishing in Soviet prisons, sent them birthday greetings and bade them keep up the good fight until the progressive forces had made the world safe for freedom. He could do all this even while, as President Carter, he was offering to collaborate with the Soviet Union in areas of mutual interest, with due respect for Soviet sovereignty. As President, he would refrain from meddling in anyone's internal affairs. As democrat, he would vigorously but peacefully pursue the ideological struggle.

title: People and Business
description: Robert L. Kirk, a vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, yesterday was named president and chief executive officer of the troubled Vought Corporation, wholly owned subsidiary of the LTV Corporation of Dallas. Mr. Kirk, who is 48 years of age, fills a vacancy at Vought that has existed since the Dec. 31 retirement, at age 56. of Sol Love.

title: Outlook for Zaire Appears Difficult As It Requests. Additional U.S:, Aid
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 22Despite optimistic official accounts of significant advances against the invaders who have entered this country from Angola, there are strong indications here that Zaire continues to face fierce and steadfast opposition in its attempt to dislodge Ratangan insurgents.

description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 22 (AP) Boston's Jo Jo White struck for 27 points and the Spurs were able to put in only 2 points during a threeminute, fourthquarter span tonight as the Celtics registered a 108104 victory over San Antonio.

title: Laos Says It Seeks Amity if U. S Ends Hostile
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, March 21We are ready to forget the past, Laos's Deputy Foreign Minister, Nouphan Sipphasay, said today in a rare interview focusing on relations between the United States and Laos.

title: Pittsburgh Priest Says He Doubts Boyle Ordered Union Rival's Death

title: Bodies of Two Kidnapped Women Are Found in Grave in Oklahoma
description: SALLISAW, Okla., March 22 (AP)The bodies of two women kidnapped six days ago in Jenks were found today in a shallow grave in a wooded area near this northeastern Oklahoma town.

title: Mausser Rated Top Choice as Hawaii Goalie

title: Senate Gets Ship Pollution Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI)As part of his program to reduce oil tanker pollution, President Carter sent to the Senate today for ratification the 1973 Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships. The convention, completed in London on Nov. 2, 1973, creates tough standards for the construction and design of ships carrying oil and other pollutants.

title: The Specter of Fragmentation Returns to Haunt Zaire

Large sums have been poured into the battle, and many of our most distinguished senior and promising younger biological scientists have turned to cancer research. They have been influenced not only by the opportunity to apply their disciplines to a problem of social significance but also by the generous support available. Further, the moment has seemed ripe for applying extraordinary recent advances in biological knowledge to human cancer.

title: Travelers

title: Film: Dilemma of Incest
description: Somewhere between Greek tragedy and soap opera is the sodden territory occupied by "Bittersweet Love," a movie that may best be remembered for bringing the name of Lana Turner back to screens in the neighborhoods where it opened yesterday.Apart from serving as a reminder that Miss Turner was never one of our subtler actresses, "Bittersweet Love" is the movie that asks the question, "Can a young, married couple about to become parents recapture love and happiness after discovering they share the same sire?"Yes, it seems that back in 1944 in New London, Conn., a young Navy officer (Robert Lansing) and a young woman he met at a U.S.O. dance (Miss Turner) spent a night in a motel before going their separate ways. She became pregnant, married the man who loved her (Robert Alda) and never told him he wasn't the father of their daughter (Meredith Baxter Birney).The trouble with "Bittersweet Love" is not with the questions raised by the unlikely but innocently incestuous relationship resulting from the marriage of Miss Turner's daughter and Mr. Lansing's son: Should the pregnancy be terminated? Can the marriage continue? Should it?It's simply that despite the earnestness of the cast, inspiration seems to have died with the posing of the problem. Right to the end, the young couple remain two Nice People who have been given a Terrible Problem. What they haven't been given is sufficient depth of character to make anyone care long or profoundly about them.The PG rating seems primarily attributable to the movie's theme: incest.

title: Film: 'Man on Roof'
description: AT about 2 o'clock on a March morning in Stockholm, a hospitalized police inspector named Stig Nyman is slashed to death in his room with a bayonet.So begins "Man on the Roof," a bloody but keen-eyed, unsparing and absorbing, multilayered Swedish film that opened yesterday at the Plaza.Written and directed by Bo Widerberg, who is probably best remembered here for "Elvira Madigan," "Man on the Roof" is based on "The Abominable Man," one of the novels in the highly praised Detective Martin Beck series by the late Per Wahloo and his wife, Maj Sjowall. What elevated these novels beyond the traditions of the genre was a master plan by the authors to use them as the basis for an exploration of society, and director Widerberg remains faithful to that intent.On one level, "Man on the Roof" stands as a simple mystery. Who killed Nyman and why? But to discover the answer, it is first necessary to know who Nyman was. A policeman, of course. But what is a policeman? One man's brute, it seems, is another's estimable protector of society's decent people. And finally, when the killer is revealed and begins one of those familiar killing sprees on a roof that drew spectacle-thirsty crowds and ringmasters in the form of importunate television newsmen and squads of specially trained and equipped police and their helicopters, the film becomes a study in the rationality of response.As mysteries go, "Man on the Roof" is not a difficult puzzle. Straightforward, routine police procedures, carried out in a matter-of-fact way by sometimes weary men, yield the answer.What invests this film with seriousness and a claim on our attention are the characters themselves. They inhabit a real world, and Widerberg sketches them, their environment and their relationships swiftly and deftly. That is true even of some of the few who appear for a matter of seconds, disappear never to be seen again and probably could be dispensed with in the name of brevity.The chief roles are played remarkably: Carl-Gustaf Lindstedt as Beck, with an economy and grandeur reminiscent of Gabin as Maigret: Einer Ronn as his little chief assistant, with a vertical furrow between his brows that speaks volumes; Sven Wollter and Thomas Hellberg as the two younger detectives who mix like oil and water.But behind it all looms Widerberg. "Man on the Roof" may suffer from a slow section in the middle, but over its length, the director displays several varieties of excellencefrom the conjuration of horror by a single eye seen peering through a dark curtain; to the affectionate depiction of a city as background; to the succinct revelation of character; to the concoction of excitement, terror and suspense in the climactic stage. Not the least of his excellences is his willingness, at a time when it seems that technique is everything and coherence nil, to treat his audience to ideas as well.

title: Plant Early, Pick Later
description: If you decide to plant some uncommon apple trees, you'll probably buy them through a mailorder house. And if you do that, there are several basic steps to assure success. First, plant the trees as soon as possible. Count the hours, not the days.

title: William L. Laurence
description: The formal achievements of William L. Laurence have been elaborately recorded, in his lifetime and at his death. He was the first to report on the explosive potential of the atom, in this newspaper. He was the only journalist to witness the first test of an atom bomb and the only one to witness its use in war over Nagasaki. A gnome like but tough figure, he was always first with the news of science, in the ability to convey it to laymen and in a willingness to dispute its meaning with the experts. But he was not merely an ornament of The Times and a winner of prizes. Atomic Billas he was known to avoid confusion with a namesaketransmitted to a whole era not only information and analysis but excitement about the most complex ideas, the kind science had previously earned only from remote, romantic expeditions. It is the thrill of discovery inside the mind that Bill Laurence captured. Science and journalism can dispute which of them reaped the greater reward.

title: Exxon Study Says Oil Consumers Are Dependent on Rising Imports
description: The oil consuming world faces the prospect of increasing oil imports from the exporting countries in order to achieve a precarious balance between supply of, and demand for all types of energy, the Exxon Corporation forecast yesterday.

title: For Multinationals, New Problems From Every Side
description: RYE, N. Y., March 23New problems are pressing in on big international companies from every side these days, said J. Paul Lyet, chairman and chief executive of the Sperry Rand Corporation.

title: ZAIRE SAYS ITS JETS BOMB REBEL POSITION
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 23An official spokesman announced here that two Zairian Mirage jets had today dropped four tons of bombs on the city of Kisengi, which he said had been identified as the military headquarters of the Katangan invaders.

title: People and Business
description: There's a William Nordhaus and there's .a Robert Nordhaus. They are brothers. They both work for the Carter Administration. For a time, there was some confusion about which Nordhaus would be doing what. It is all straightened out now with William, a former professor of economics at Yale University, nominated and confirmed as a member of the Council of Economic Advisers. His brother Robert, a former staff member of the House Commerce Committee, is now a member of Dr. James R. Schlesinger's staff working up details of an energy policy.

title: Slain Man is Identified
description: NEWARK, March 23 (AP)The bulletriddled body of a man found Monday on. a Port Newark street has been identified by the police as Ricardo Quesada, 33 years old, of Nutley, N. J. The police said no motive had been established for the killing.

title: Man, 29, Is Shot Dead in Brooklyn
description: A 29yearold man was fatally shot yesterday near his home at 78 Starr Street, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, according to the police. There was no apparent motive in the slaying of the man, Jose Rodriguez, police officials said. The shooting occurred about 11:15 A.M. and the unidentified assailant fled on footb a witness reported.

title: Toulon, Where Napoleon Met His Destiny, Takes Life Easy
description: TOULON, FranceOn a hill overlooking the harbor here a 24yearold junior artillery captain rallied his volunteer gunners in 1793, chasing the invading English fleet out to sea, holding Toulon as the home of the French Navy and launching the personal career that led him and his nation to glory and power, defeat and disgrace.

title: NeoFunk: Spoof on High Fashion
description: Funky entered the fashion vocabulary as a term of approval in the 1960's. It referred to clothes that had longsince died In neighborhood attics and were resuscitated by the withit young. Their colors had often faded to the point where they reflected a nowilltolive look, according to Diana Vreeland, the keen fashion observer. In some cases, blue jeans and other contemporary attire were rotted, torn, patched and otherwise distressed to achieve the desirable aged appearance.

title: CASTRO ARRIVES IN ANGOLA AND GETS A BIG WELCOME
description: LUANDA, Angola, March 23 (Reuters) President Fidel Castro of Cuba arrived in Angola today for his first visit to this country where thousands of Cuban troops fought in a civil war.

title: Cecchele in Met Tosca
description: The Metropolitan Opera's uninspired Tosca Tuesday night saw the first performance of Cavaradossi with the company by Gianfranco Cecchele. Mr. Cecchele's small, rather dry tenor took an act to warm up. That meant that his big firstact aria was troubled by an excessively wide beat; by the third act's E lucevan le stelle he sang tidily and to the point. His acting was competent; in fact, competent is about the

title: The Power of the Word
description: BOSTON, March 23 There is school of gloom among democratic political thinkers, typified by some comments of Daniel Patrick Moynihan. Democracy on the American model, he wrote two years ago, is on the way to becoming a holdover form of government, one which persists in isolated or peculiar places . . . but which has simply no relevance to the future. It is where the world was, not where it is going.

title: Books: Dean of Printers
description: It was just 500 years ago last year that William Caxton set up the first printing shop in Englanda fact that may have been overlooked a little by our own celebration of an event that occurred just 300 years later. Yet in its own way, Caxton's act was as momentous as the revolt of the Colonies, which was brought about as much by what the printer started as by the political events that preceded it.

title: Deficit in Payments Widens for Quarter
description: WASHINGTON. March 23 (AP)The United States balance of payments on current account slipped more deeply into deficit in the fourth quarter of last year. the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Shock and Fear Grip a Detroit Suburb as 7th Child Is Found Slain
description: BIRMINGHAM, Mich., March 23The children don't come to spend their money anymore at the HunterMaple Pharmacy near the heart of this uppermiddleclass suburb in Oakland County. Nor do they ride their skateboards in the parking lot out back.

title: Topics

title: Hua's Shanghai Gesture

title: Hagar's Children Is Engrossing Drama
description: PRODUCER is a creature of instinct with a certain amount of experience. Joseph Papp of the New York Shakespeare Festival is an extraordinary producer, and his instincts are always quivering. A couple of months ago I found myself by chance sitting next to him in Washington restaurant. As we were notfor that second of eternityoffidaily on speaking terms it could have been embarrassing, But neither of us, by cruel nature, is a silent person, so we started to talk, with the mixture of love, pain and irony that has always characterized our relationship.

title: PRESIDENT. DISCLOSES NEW PLAN TO DISCUSS LINKS WITH VIETNAM
description: WASHINGTON. March 23President Carter said today that he would accept an invitation from Vietnam to begin new round of negotiations in Paris aimed at normalization of relations.

title: Notes on People
description: As SO MANY previous new First Ladies have done before her, Rosalynn Carter came to New York to shop for some spring clothes. Her first stop yesterday was the Seventh Avenue showroom of Jerry Silverman, where she showed a special preference for Ultrasuede.

title: More Water Projects Face Review; Carter Asks Drought Aid for West

description: Herman (Hymie) Shertzer, whose lead alto saxophone gave Benny Goodman's saxophone section much of its smooth, swinging power at the peak of the Goodman band's success in the mid30' s, died Tuesday evening of lung cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 277 West End Avenue.

description: WASHINGTON, March 23Gazing across the den of the placid and elegant Victorian mansion, the eye is jarred by a fleshcolored mass that bears a distressing resemblance to internal anatomy.

description: GAINESVILLE. Fla., March 23 (AP)John Crist of the University of Alabama but competing unattached set firstday record in the Florida Relays decathlon with 4,008 points today. The previous mark of 3,940 was set last year by Craig Brigham of the University of Oregon, who went on to win the event.

title: Sound
description: HE MEANING of power, in audio as elsewhere, is often vaguely defined, poorly understood, and therefore a cause of rampant ambiguity. And because powerexpressed as the number of watts delivered to the loudspeakersis bandied about loosely though prominently, in audio advertisements, it may be a good idea_ to relate this electrical measurement to the performance of music.

title: Elgiti Cancels Homosexual Films After Chelsea Residents Protest
description: The Elgin Theater, which became the target of strong community protest this week when it switched Monday to allmale homosexual films, returned last night to its old policy of showing revivals and classics.

description: WASHINGTON, March,. 23The Supreme Court, in another major decision curbing attempts to broadly interpret Federal securities statutes, ruled today that a transaction permitisid under state law should stand unless it was shown to be fraudulently deceptive.

description: ALBANY (AP)Dr. Harold C. Martin, former president of Union College, has been elected to the board of trustees at Siena College, in suburban Loudonville.

title: ZiffDavis in Accord To Acquire Yachting
description: The ZiffDavis Publishing Company, a 44yearold privately held corporation, has reached agreement in principle to acquire for cash the Yachting Publishing Corporation, whose major magazine carries more advertising pages than any other monthly.

title: Flight Attendants Shift Union
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 23 (AP)Flight attendants with Trans World Airlines have voted to leave the Transport Workers Union and affiliate with the Independent Federation of Flight Attendants Union. The election was supervised by the National Mediation Board and was concluded late yesterday in Washington. Officials said the attendants voted 2,549 to 1,682 to leave T.W.U. 551 and affiliate with the federation.

title: Exertion Found to Ease Heart Risk
description: A regular pattern of hard physical work sharply reduces the risk of dying from heart attacks, researchers reported yesterday on the basis of results of a 22yearlorig study of 3,600 longshoremen in San Francisco.

title: People in Sports
description: Barry Mendelson, the general manager of the New Orleans Jazz, was dismissed yesterday. Larry Hatfield, chairman of the National Basketball Association club's executive committee, said Mendelson had become a controversial figure because of his trade for Gail Goodrich, a 32yearold guard with the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: AUTHOR LOSES AWARD FOR LIBEL ON APPEAL

title: Beame Is Critical of Courts in State
description: Once again sounding the lawandorder theme that is certain to be a highlight of his expected campaign for reelection, Mayor Beame last night criticized the performance of the State Supreme Court as disappointing and suggested that court time could be used more efficiently and effectively.

title: REAR ADM. F. B. GUEST JR., NAVY SEALIFT COMMANDER

title: Blades Win Cup Hockey
description: ERIE, Pa., March 24 (UPI)The Erie Blades defeated Philadelphia, 41, last night to win the Lockhart Cup playoffs in the North American Hockey League. The Blades captured the fourgame series, 3 games to I.

They will sit down in the Junior Museum Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which is fortunately fitted with adult seats, to view an eighthour, nonstop assemblage by Mr. Langlois of film produced in Paris since the infancy of the industry in the 1890's.

Chipman replaces Tom Davis, who was named head coach at Boston College earlier this year.

description: WASHINGTON, March 24Organized labor suffered its second sharp rebuff in two days today when the Carter Administration proposed an increase in the minimum wage substantially less than the unions had been seeking.

title: President Sees Aid for Vietnam H Talks on Ties Are Successful
description: WASHINGTON, March 24President Carter said today that he would respond well on the question of possible American economic aid for Vietnam if the assistance was arranged as part of successful negotiations to open normal diplomatic relations.

The United States, the President said, will give priority to getting Soviet agreement for substantial reduce tions in the number of strategic missiles and bombers agreed to in 1974 by President Ford and Leonid I. Brezhnev. The United States will also seek a Soviet agreement barring outside military interference in African affairs, Mr. Carter said. [Page Al. Column 6.1

title: California Fearful Of Aquatic Weed
description: MARYSVILLE, Calif., March 24 (UPI) State officials expressed alarm that hydrilla, a rapidly growing leafy aquatic weed that is the scourge of lakes and rivers in the southeastern United States, has a toehold in California.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: RERUNS on television tend to be viewed with contempt, which may be thoroughly deserved if the program in question is, say Code R or West Side Medical. But they can be .helpful in giving the viewer more flexibility, chance to catch up with something worthwhile that was missed the first time around..And public television insists on being extraordinarily helpful by repeating most of any given week's major presentations on Saturday and Sunday. Tomorrow night, for instance, the Dance in America production shown last Wednesday can be seen on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock. The subject is the Dance Theater of Harlem, founded in 1969 by Arthur Mitchell, principal dancer with the New York City Ballet. Karel Shook, his teacher, became a codirector.

title: Chinaglia Paces Cosmos
description: ROME, March 24 (UPI)  Giorgio Chinaglia, playing against his former club for the first time, scored a goal today and led the New York Cosmos to a 21 victory over Lazio of Rome in an exhibition soccer game.

title: PowerSaving Flywheels Urged for Subway
description: The Garrett Corporation of Torrance, Calif., proposed yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority begin moves to equip 200 of its New York City subway cars with flywheel energy  recovery systems developed from those tested on two cars in New York last year.

title: Art: New Works By Philip Guston
description: THE PAINTINGS of Philip Guston nowadays confront us with a conundrum. Everything about the way they are paintedthe sensuous quality of the paint itself, the seductive quality of the color (especially the delicious pinks and pearly graysalways the artist's chromatic forte), and the sheer authority of their structurecommends them to the eye. We are never in any doubt that a great deal of pleasure has gone into the painting of these pictures, and pleasure is what they ought to give us. Yet there is somethingwets, something a little silly about them, too. The scale of their Imagery is imperial and monumentalthe scale of romantic ruins, natural wonders and great spacesbut what is actually depicted is shoe leather, a television set, a rug, and so on. Rooms are turned into landscapes, and landscapes into rooms. There are other formsrumpled trouser legs, perhaps, looking like cigarettes a little the worse for being bent and sat onthat are treated with all the solemnity of Stonehenge.

title: AUTO OUTPUT EXPECTED TO EQUAL LAST WEEK'S
description: DETROIT, March 24American auto production is expected to total 202,971 units this week, about the same as last week's 203,101 but 9.8 percent ahead of the 184,932 cars built in the comparable week last year, according to Ward's Automotive Reports.

title: Ehd at Era: Al athath 0 1 ficiallk Permits jets to Make Rain Deal
description: Joe Namath's 12year career as the heralded leader of the Jets came to a close yesterday when his lawyer officially notified the New Yorkers they could trade the quarterback to the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Julius W. Hobson, a Black Activist In Washington for 20 Years, Dies
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Julius W. Hobson, for 20 years the most influential black civil rights activist in this city, who was widely credited with bringing into being many of the political and educational changes that transformed the District of Columbia in the 1960's, died yesterday after a sixyear battle with cancer. He was 54 years old.

title: The Uses Of the Press
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  President Carter has held four press conferences since his inauguration, each of them making less news than the one before. The novelty is wearing off and he knows it, but he will continue to hold one every fortnight, for he has other purposes.

title: Frazier's Son Wins Ring Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 24 (AP)Marvis Frazier, the 16yearold son of Joe Frazier, knocked out Jarrett Smith in the first round tonight and won the  subnovice heavyweight title of the Pennsylvania Golden Gloves Tournament. With his father, the former world heavyweight champion, watching from a corner, young Frazier backed his bigger opponent into the ropes with two stiff jabs and then dropped him for the 10count with a right hook to the temple. The victory, at the Palestra, was Frazier's sixth in six tries.

title: Screen: Scottish Childhood
description: "My Childhood" (55 minutes) and "My Ain Folks" (48 minutes), which opened at the Film Forum yesterday, are, in effect, a single autobiographical feature film in which Bill Douglas, their writer and director, recalls his childhood in a small Scottish mining community after World War II. The films, photographed in black and white, have an intensely naturalistic look, but Mr. Douglas's interest is less in event than in remembered feelings of loneliness and desolation.The principal characters are a little boy named Jamie (Stephen Archibald), the Douglas surrogate, an older boy named Tommy (Tommy Hughie Restorick), who may be either Jamie's half brother or first cousinthe film never bothers to make that clearand the boys' grandmother, who raises them by letting them do pretty much what they please. She's neither cruel nor without love, just old and forgetful.Mr. Douglas's method is as austere as the life he portrays. Jamie, who looks exhausted, with deep circles under his eyes, never cries and seldom smiles. He has already accepted the unfortunate facts of his lifehis illegitimacy, his mother's mental illness and the presence of his father, a weak, not unpleasant sort of man who lives across the street with a dominating mother."My Childhood" and "My Ain Folks" evoke a world of such bleakness that even the sunlight looks chilly. Affection is something that is distantly remembered or found by chance, as in Jamie's friendship with a German P.O.W. The end of the war, which brings peace to everyone else, simply means that Jamie loses his only friend.I can admire Mr. Douglas's discipline. He recalls all this without a bit of sentimentality. Yet after a while the unremitting gloom comes to be a reverse sentimentality, a sort of angry self-pity that is as off-putting as phony melodramatics. Like Jamie, we in the audience long to run away to some place warm, where people talk to each other and, occasionally, even laugh. The film's emotions are as bottled up as Jamie's."My Childhood" and "My Ain Folks" will be shown at the Film Forum tonight through Sunday at 7:30 and at the same time next week, Thursday through Sunday.

title: How to Get There
description: By car from New York City, take the Palisades Interstate Parkway north to Exit 4, continue north on 9W until you reach Broadway, then bear right at the stop light into the center of town. An alternate route is to take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway north to Exit 10, which is just across from the Tappan Zee Bridge. Follow the South Nyack signs to Clinton Avenue, then turn right on Clinton and continue to Broadway.

description: WASHINGTON, March 24President Carter said today that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance would give priority in Moscow next week to seeking Soviet agreement for substantial reductions in the numbers of strategic missiles and bombers allowed to each side.

description: Following Mayor Beame's lead, the Board of Estimate last night abruptly reversed itself and rejected zoning regulations that would have banned socalled massage parlors, adult bookstores and movie theaters, and all other socalled adult uses from every borough except Manhattan.

He said letters should be mailed to him at the State House in Trenton.
