title: Restaurants
description: MOST ITALIAN CITIES have a legendary restaurant that no one should miss. In Verona, it's the 12 Apostoli. In Bologna, it's the Pappagallo. New York has dozens of Italian restaurants in this category and insiders have long known that Nicola Paone is one of them. Reports had been filtering in recently to the effect that vast changes had been wrought upon this attractive little hideaway on the southern slope of Murray. Hillon 34th Street, just east of Third Avenueand a visit seemed in order.

title: Index of Commodity Prices Rose To 221.4 From 218.7 in the Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials

title: For Children
description: Plays

title: 2 Boys, 14, Win Suit Over Arrest
description: Two 14yearold boys were awarded $500 in damages each yesterday by Federal judge in Brooklyn because they had been taken into custody by a suspicious police officer while they were taking a walk in East Hills, L.I., on the night of Sept. 5, 1975.

title: A Man of Piety At India's Helm
description: NEW DELHI, March 24  Morarji Ranchhodji Desai, one of the few Indian leaders who still follow the Gandhian custom of spinning in their spare moments, has had little time for spin

title: Melancholy Korean
description: The shadowy recesses of the La Mama Annex theater will become the battlements and chambers of the haunted castle at Elsinore this weekend. Hamlet at that snug home for avantgarde theater? But this is a Hamlet with a difference.

title: F.B.I. Begins Study Of F.D.I.C. Logo Use
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 24 (AP)The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun studying the use of a Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation logo on Christmas club deposit books issued by the insolvent American Bank and Trust Company.

title: Japan Textile Cartel Sought
description: OSAKA, Japan, March 24 (UPI)Japan's cotton spinning and manmade textile associations, comprising 100 makers, have asked the Japanese Fair Trade Commission for approval of a recession cartel starting April 1. The associations said that they planned to reduce their production voluntarily by an average 25 percent for three months to cope with sluggish business. The associations took a similar step from January to May 1975, following the oil crisis.

title: The Furor Over Saccharin
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Federal proposal to ban saccharin is a classic example of the Government seeking to regulate what its officials perceive to he the greater good for the greater number of Americans without really knowing what the greater good is. Legally the Food and Drug AdminNews istration has little choice Analysis but to ban saccharin, having exhausted all possible means of dodging the issue. But the larger question deals less with the chemical itself than with the attempt by Federal officials to make a riskbenefit analysis of a potential public health problem using incomplete information. Thus, the saccharin dispute is the latest in a series of controversies, including aerosol sprays, DDT and the SST, that pit science against politics, researchers against lawyers, and the public against public officials.

title: New York City Health Dept. Opposes Measure on Sterilization Control
description: A New York City Council measure under which the sterilization of men and women would not be allowed sooner than 30 days after they had consented in writing to such surgery was opposed yesterday by the city's Department of Health and some parenthood organizations.

title: Albany Assembly Reveals Budget
description: ALBANY, March 24The Assembly today released, with considerable selfcongratulatory fanfare, what is supposed to be the most informative budget it has ever put out. The new budget for the operation of the chamber includes a program performancebreakdown that purports to analyze the effectiveness of how it is spending its money.

title: Advertising
description: In all of his years in marketing William Mack Morris has never seen new product success like Bubble Yum bubblegum, which began its national rollout a little over a year ago and is now No. 1 in the fieldand still riot totally national.

title: Department of Slightly Dirty Tricks.
description: Red Smith

title: Dancing to a Bamboo Beat
description: Mention the name of the Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, which performs through this weekend at the Felt Forum, and one image immediately springs to mind. It is that of a dancer swiftly moving among bamboo poles that are clapped shut by other performers.

title: Morgan Is Golf Pro With Foresight
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., March 24Gil Morgan is one of those rarities on the pro golf tour, a player who has a fallback position, the practice of optometry, to protect him if his game sours or if he is injured. He also is one of those travelers who can happily drive 35,000 miles a year with a pet, in this case a red tabby cat named Claude (after Debussy).

title: AIDE TO CARTER GIVES PLAN ON TAX REVISION
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Carter Administration advanced today some of the principles it hopes to apply this fall when it proposes the restructuring and simplification of the nation's tax laws.

title: L.I. Man Guilty of Wife's Murdet; Body of Victim Was Never Found
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 24 (AP)Thomas F. Busacca was found guilty today of killing his wife, in a murder case in which the body of the victim was never found.

title: Lafleur Sets N.H.L. Record
description: MONTREAL, March 24 (AP)  Guy Lafleur, Montreal right wing, broke an N.H.L. record by scoring in his 23d consecutive game, netting his 53d goal of the season tonight as the Canadiens defeated the St. Louis Blues, 61.

title: Cabaret: Ronny Whyte at Piano
description: Ronny Whyte, a pianist and singer, has split his professional career into two parts. In one, he works as half of a singing duo with Travis Hudson, who, besides being a singer, is also an actress. When Miss Hudson is occupied with her theatrical career, as she is at the moment, Mr. Whyte carries on alone:

title: Mr. Carter's Campaign Cows Come Home
description: An extra billion dollars a year for dairy farmers? That is the estimated cost of President Carter's decision to raise price supports for dairy products by 9 percent. Less than half that billion will come from the taxpayer, to buy  up excess produce at a newly increased price. The remainder will come from the consumersupermarkets must match the Government offer and will raise milk prices 6 cents a gallon, butter 10 cents a pound and cheese 5 cents a poundor even more if processors and distributors follow tradition and tack on a few more cents profit for themselves.

title: Newyork About to Get A Unified Management Of City's Fiscal Matters
description: Welcome to the land of I.F.M.S., as in Iffmmuss. It's an unobtrusive world with a private language of mods, codes, flow charts and acronyms like F.I.S.A. (Fih  Sa), F.A.I.S. (Fay  Iss) and N.Y.C.M.I.S. (Nihsmiss). It can be found in few cluttered offices around City Hall, where its population of 150 technicians and specialists labor quietly, surrounded by charts, graphs and timetables.

title: Joe Stydahar Is Dead at 65
description: Joe Stydahar, a former star tackle for the Chicago Bears in the 1930's and 40's and a coach of two National Football League teams, is dead at the agei of 65. Obituary on Page D 14.

title: No Danger: Craftsmen at Play
description: Fantasymuch of it madcap, some of it wryis the theme of four crafts shows that can be seen this weekend. That there should be four such shows running simultaneously is not surprising, however. For, artistcraftsmen love to play.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 25, 1977

title: Books of The Times
description: TWO QUESTIONS seize the reader's mind at the outset of Hank SearIs's nautical thriller, Overboard,his seventh novel. (I confess I've not read any of the previous six.) The first question is: Will Mitch Gordon ever locate his wife, Lindy, who has fallen overboard from their 40foot ketch and is now treading water somewhere in the South Pacific about 70 miles from Tahiti? And the second: Will the author find enough to write about to keep us interested in Mitch's desperate but somewhat static predicament for over 250 pages? After all, when you're lost at sea you're lost; when you're found you're found, and there isn't much room for dramatic maneuver in between.

title: COLLEGE CRITICIZED OVER HARMAN CASE
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 24The attorney for Dr. Sidney Harman charged in court here today that efforts by Friends World College to compel Dr. Harman to answer questions about an unpaid pledge to the college were nothing more than the wild fantasies of irresponsible litigants.

title: Bonds Fall as Funds Rate Rises; Citicorp Sells 350 Million in Notes
description: Bond prices declined yesterday as traders and investors noticed that the Federal funds rate, the basic rate of the shortterm money market, inched up 4 13/16 percent before the Federal Reserve injected some temporary reserves

title: Blowing on the Wind
description: NORMAN, Okla.One morning in the last week of February, residents of much of Oklahoma found the cars in their driveways spattercoated with ugly brown mud, the messy result of a heavy nighttime dust storm accompanied by a light rain.

title: Free Recital at Donnell
description: Alvin Rogers, violinist, Avron Coleman, cellist, and Margaret Birkeland. pianist, will offer a free recital at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow in the New York Public Library's Donnell Library Center. 20 \Vest 53d Street. They will perform Mozart's Sonata in Bflat (K. 454), Berg's Piano Sonata (Op. I) and the Trio in C minor (Op. 101) by Brahms.

title: Chapin and Brealey Parents Protest
description: The specter of a pizza parlor is haunting East End Avenue at the corner of 84th Street, arousing opposition as well as apprehension in a secluded bulge of Manhattan that is long on highrise cooperatives, penthouses and quiet sunrises over the East River.

title: Ordination of Women Is Supported By Federation of Catholic Priests
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 24 (UPI)The national convention of representatives of Roman Catholic priests yesterday urged that women be allowed to become priests and deacons and called for the elimination of sexist language in official prayers Of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Parents Win Custody of 5 Members of Moon's Church
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 24The Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon received a major setback today when a State Superior Court judge ordered five adult members placed in the temporary custody of their parents, who seek to have them deprogrammed from the church.

title: BUILDING PRODUCT PROFITS UP 36% IN 76, STUDY SAYS
description: The building materials industry found strong financial footing last year, according to a survey by the McGrawHill Information Systems Company.

title: TWO ARE DENIED BAIL IN ARSON DEATHS OF 7
description: JERSEY CITY, March 24Two men accused of helping set a fire that killed seven persons in an aging tenement here two weeks ago were ordered held without bail today at their arraignment in Municipal Court.

title: Banjos Dueling at L.I. Shopping Mali
description: The music with which shopping malls have usually been identified is the dreary whine of. Muzak, but once a year, a different sound is offered at the MidIsland Shopping Plaza in Hicksville, L.I., which presents a live, ninehour bluegrass contest whose size could rival some of the major outdoor festivals.

title: Albany Budget Accord Firm Despite G.O.P. Objections
description: ALBANY, March 24  The delicate agreement on a new state budget held firm today, despite strong pressure from dissident Republican legislators who pressed for cuts in welfare grants.

title: Deregulation Splits United and T.W.A.
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The battle over a proposal to relax Government regulation of the airlines continued today before a Senate panel, with United Airlines reaffirming its support of deregulation and Trans World Airlines taking the view more common among airline officials that such legislation could destroy the industry.

title: Common Market, at 20th Birthday, Sees Hopes Dim but Is Still Hopeful
description: ROME, March 24The European Common Market, which celebrates its 20th anniversary here tomorrow, is somewhat like the middleaged man who awakes to the realization that he will never become the president of the company, so he begins to rein in his ambitions and ideals.

title: CALIFORNIA WARNS F.E.A. AND SOHIO ON ALASKAN OIL
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 23 (UPI) California warned today that it intends to shelve examination of a proposed terminal for Alaskan oil at Long Beach unless the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) completes its application for the project within three weeks.

title: World News Briefs
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Friday, March 25 (UPI)A strong earthquake shook eastern Turkey early today, and the government radio reported that at least 20 bodies had been found.

title: Faulty Repairs Cited On Ship in Explosion
description: WILMINGTON, N.C. March 24 (AP) The Panamanian tanker Claude Conway, which broke apart in the Atlantic Ocean after an explosion last Sunday, left New York with improper repairs on two of her cargo tank vents, the Coast Guard said today.

title: A Place to Pick Up New Theater Ideas
description: All the world is not a stage, Erving Goffman, the eminent sociologist, has written, but the crucial ways in which it isn't are not easy to specify.

title: 2 Enter Indy 500 Race
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 24 (AP)Larry Dickson, a veteran, and Rick Mears, the 1976 United States Auto Club rookie of the year were entered today for the May 29 Indianapolis 500mile race.

title: Julian Koenig Is Mute In a TV Commercial
description: Out of a radiant mist on the television screen there strides a tall figure all dressed in white walking toward the camera from a distance. Who is he? A prophet? Seer? Cult leader?

title: Flyers Win, 62
description: BOSTON, March 24 (AP)Don Saleski scored two goals that sparked threeLgoal first period for Philadelphia tonight and the Flyers routed the Boston Biuins, 62. The victory put Philadelphia 4 points aheod of the New York Islanders in the race for the Patrick Division title in the National Hockey League.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Friday
description: The decoration of Eastern eggs, Ukrainian style, is the subject of workshops for adults all weekend at the Ukrainian Museum, 203 Second Avenue. The eggs are decorated batikstyle with layers of colored paper and beeswax manipulated by heated styluses, then coated with a thin glaze. Egg artists may gain inspiration from the museum's current exhibition of colorful, intricately designed Ukrainian eggs on loan from private collections.

title: A Topic on Moscow Agenda
description: WASHINGTON, March 24President Carter said at a news conference today that demilitarization of the Indian Ocean would be among the topics that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance would take up in Moscow during his visit there next week.

title: Management
description: Major companies are seeking to define the role of corporate directors and determine whether they should be given staff support to help increase their knowledge of the company and get data to make decisions. Page D3.

title: Concert: Takemitsu, Tashi and Ozawa
description: IF TORU TAICEMITSU'S avantgarde standing is still intact among his peers, and if his Quatrain represents his present compositional practice fairly, we may have to revise our notions of what constitutes avantgardism in music in the mid1970's.

title: The New York Times/Teresa Zabela
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  Former President Ford came back to Washington today, riding in a sleek black limousine but obgerving at least part of the style of the Carter White House by carrying his own heavy briefcase.

title: Vance Apparently at Odds With. Carter on Boycott Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has suggested changes that significantly weaken antiboycott legislation now before Congress, it was disclosed today, apparently taking a position at odds with the White House.

title: Market Place
description: The Supreme Court's ruling on Wednesday that companies freezing out public shareholders by going private is ordinarily not the business of the Federal Courts will send most of the many cases pending on the subject back to the state courts. That, at least, was the feeling in legal circles yesterday.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: Seldom have the leading analysts of the securities markets been as unanimous as they are now in pinpointing the main reason for the lackluster performance stocks and bonds thus far this year. In their view, the burden dragging down both markets is a deepseated fear of increased inflation  and the tighter monetary

title: Kennedy Performing Arts Center Faces $4.5 Million Repair Project
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  Rugs have disintegrated. Plaster has peeled. Expensive wall coverings have mildewed. Chandelier stems have corroded.

title: BOMB IN AN ULSTER COLLEGE INJURES EXJUDGE, 9 OTHERS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 24 A bomb exploded without warning in a crowded lecture hall at a college north of Belfast today, injuring 10 persons, including the 80yearold former lord chief iustice of Ulster. Lord MacDermott, who is believed by the police to have been the target. The police said that the bombing was apparently the work of the Irish Republican Army.

title: PARENTS /CHILDREN
description: Parents, when they're in trouble with their children, turn this way and that for adviceto friends, relatives, doctors, psychologists. Should I spank or shouldn't I? they might ask, and of course the answer will depend a lot on who's giving it.

title: Broadway
description: ALAN JAY LERNER and Burton Lane are together again, working on their fourth collaboration. Their first two projects were moviesRoyal Wedding and the unproduced Huckleberry Finnand the third was On a Clear Day You Can See Forever. After that they stopped speaking. Now, however, they are collaborating on a musical whose working title is Carmelina. It is loosely based on a movie they did not like and whose title they would rather forget, and so it will not be mentioned here. Nonetheless, it may be said that Carmelina takes place in Italy, and that it is about a woman who took three American lovers, one of whom got her with child. Subsequently, each of them is told that he is the father so that he will support the child. Carmelina is about what happens when they all return to Italy.

title: Ba,seballRejects aRestructuring Now
description: TAMPA, Fla. March. 24Baseball's club owners set the stage today for the return of Washington to the big leagues but in the meantime refused to realign the 26 teams into six divisions and rejected the gimmickry of wider playoffs involving wild card teams as in football.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in yesterday's Market Place column in The Times that investors exchanging New York City notes for Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds must pay broker's fee of $20 per $10,000 bond. The fee is $20 per $1,000, and the M.A.C. pays it.

title: RapidAmerican Reports a Profit For 4th Quarter
description: The RapidAmerican Corporation, which operates the McCrory and Schenley corporations and other subsidiaries, reported yesterday net income of $14.9 million, or $1.81 a share, in the fourth fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31, compared with a net loss of $4 million in the prior year's quarter. Sales rose to $698 million from $674 million.

title: Podgorny, in Zanzibar, Welcomes Parley With U.S. on Indian Ocean
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, March 24 President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union indicated today that his country was willing to open talks with the United States and other concerned nations on the question of declaring the Indian Ocean a zone of peace.

title: Theater: B. Beaver Animation
description: THE MABOU MINES experimental theater company specializes in its adaptations of the work of Samuel Beckett and in original works that the group calls animations. The titles of these works refer to animals, such as Red Horse and Shaggy Dog. B. Beaver Animation is currently being presented at the Public Theater.

title: The New York Times/Carl T. Gossett
S.E.C. Ends Ban on Four Stocks
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that trading suspensions ended at midnight in the securities of Fay's Drug Company, Lawry Food Inc., the Olympia Brewing Company and the Stange Company. The S.E.C. had suspended trading after Swift Henke & Company, a Chicago broker, went into receivership because of heavy dealings in the four stocks.

title: Carter's Cabinet Lunches Range From Fancy to CafeteriaStyle
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)The Secretary of State takes his lunch on a tray at his desk. The Secretary of the Interior sometimes eats in the cafeteria The Transportation  Secretary has been to the dining room named for him only once.

title: DRAFT STUDY ASSAILS U.S. ON SECRECY LAW
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Commission on Federal Paperwork is embroiled in a controversy over whether report on Government secrecy, which asserts that the Government is conspiring to evade the Privacy Act and circumvent the Freedom of Information Act, has itself been suppressed.

title: Job Corps Heartened by Carter's Expansion Plans
description: GREENVILLE, Ky., March 21Back home in Alamogordo, N.M., Mark Phillips, a husky 19yearold, worked as a laborer, when he wasn't in trouble.

title: Chesimard Jury Asks Clarification of Assault Charges
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, March 24During its second day of deliberations, the jury in the trial of Joanne D. Chesimard tonight asked the judge to repeat his instluctions to them concerning the four assault charges against the 29yearold defendant. The charges against Mrs. Chesimard all stem from a gun battle on the New Jersey Turnpike on May 2, 1973, in which two men were killed.

title: Error Found With Returned M.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON. March 24 (AP)The Pentagon today reported another case of mistaken identity among the remains of 12 men handed over by the Vietnamese Government as war casualties.

title: Monumental Legal Battle Shaping Up in Bid to Bar Color TV Recorders
description: LOS ANGELES, March 24In a rapidly growing stack of briefs and affidavits at the Federal courthouse here, a monumental legal battle Is shaping up between the electronics industry and the entertainment industry. The stakes, for both sides, run into billions of dollars.

title: Parole Board Dispute
description: TRENTON, March 24  Despite New Jerseys sunshine law, a state civic committee has attempted to resolve a bitter dispute among members of the State Parole Board at closed meetings. The dispute is one of a number of problems

title: Senate Relaxes Its Disclosure Rule
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)The Senate, in the first significant amendment of its proposed code of ethics, voted today, 93 to 1, to soften a provision that would require members to disclose the financial holdings and income of their immediate families.

title: Mosque Trial Juror Taken to Hospital
description: The jury in the murder trial of Lewis 17X Dupreecharged in State Supreme Court in Manhattan with the 1972 shooting death of a police officeplanned to go into its third day of deliberations today when a juror suddenly became ill last night and was rushed to Beekman Downtown Hospital.

title: Michael Lauro, ExChief Chemist Of New York Produce Exchange
description: Michtael F. Lauro, chief chemist for the New York Produce Exchange for 20 years until his retirement in 1965, died Wednesday in Hackensack (N.J.) General Hospital after a short illness. He lived at 44 Washington Place, Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., and was 84 years old.

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold prices Thursday. London: morning fixing $153.25, no $0.45. afternoon fining $152.75, off S0.05. Paris: afternoon fixing $155.07, up $1.65. Frankfurt: close $152.913, ue S0.41. Zurich: $132.50 hid off, $0.25; $150.25 asked.

title: Topics
description: Making It in the Media

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 25, 1977

title: April Fool
description: With April Fool's Day approaching, the satirists at Columbia University's newspaper, The Spectator, have discovered an unsuspected audiencethe Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Skevin Gives Up His Fight to Ban All Manufacturing of Carcinogens
description: TRENTON, March 24State Senator John M. Skevin, who has played a leading role in writing legislation designed to arrest New Jersey's cancer mortality rate, the highest in the nation, abandoned today his effort to bar the production and use of 16 known cancerproducing chemicals in the state.

title: Feminists Troop to an Old Battleground For Victory Toast on NOW's 10th Year
description: The New York chapter of the National Organization for Women will celebrate its 10th anniversary tonight in a bar that once refused a drink to feminist named Betty Friedan.

title: JOE STYDAHAR DIES; PRO FOOTBALL STAR
description: BECKLEY, W. Va., March 24 (AP)Joe Stydahar, a former star tackle for West Virginia University and the Chicago Bears and a member of the college and pro football Halls of Fame, is dead at the age of 65.

title: Election Commission Says House Member May Accept Cash Gilts. for Personal Use
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI)There is nothing in the election law to prohibit an Idaho Congressman from accepting cash contributions for his own personal use as long as he does not use them in his campaigns, the Federal Election Commission ruled today.

title: Saturday
description: Dance Umbrella is back, and the Manhattan School of Music has it. The series of programs by moderndance choreographers continues its spring festival at the Manhattan School theater on Claremont Avenue, between 122d and 123d Streets. The Kathryn Posin Dance Company opens Saturday night with dances by one of its own, Lance Westergard. On Sunday the Phoebe Neville Dance Company takes over with new and old works by Miss Neville, set to music by such composers as Meredith Monk and Eleanor Hovda. Performances begin at 8. Ticketsat $4.95 and $6.95are available at the door. Reservations and information: 8664514.

title: JAMES T. FLANNERY
description: CLEVELAND, March 24 (AP)Services will be conducted tomorrow morning in Cleveland Heights for James T. Flannery, northeast Ohio editor for Catholic Universe Bulletin, who died Tuesday at the age of 59.

title: WILLIAM B. DeRONDE, 68, OPERATOR OF TUGBOATS
description: William Bennett DeRonde of Venezuela and Boca Raton, Fla., owner and operator of tugboats serving the petroleum industry in Florida, died in a Miami hospital Wednesday following a heart attack. He was 68 years old.

title: Gold Price Moves Uncertainly
description: LONDON, March 23 (AP)The price of gold, steadily rising since the beginning of the year, had an uncertain day on Europes bullion markets today. The dollar, meanwhile, posted small gains against most European currencies.

title: Art That Sings
description: SOME of the finest art that has been made in our lifetime can be seen in the Robert Rauschenberg retrospective which opens at the Museum of Modern Art today and continues through May 17.

title: Jet Case Put In U.S. Court
description: New Jersey's Sports and Exposition Authority succeeded yesterday in getting the New York City lawsuit over the Jets moved from the Manhattan Supreme Court into Federal court, at least temporarily. New Jersey officials sought the transfer because two states were involved in the dispute.

title: Ballet: Mao, Tao And Bejart
description: MAURICE Mart's Ballet of the 20th Century offered two local premieres in its second program Wednesday night at the Uris Theater. Bolero, to the Ravel score, is one of Mr. Bejart's best works. Le Marteau sans Maitre, to the Pierre Boulez score, is something else.

title: U.S. Negotiators And Cuba Open Talks on Fishing
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The United States and Cuba today opened direct negotiations in New York over an agreement to regulate fishing in the waters between the two countries.

title: Twins Rout Holtzman
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 24The Yankee pitching staff, which seemed a stronghold of security, has suddenly become a flurry of questions for Manager Billy Martin.

title: Chris Evert 2Set Victor At Garden
description: It was like opening night on Broadway after nine years on the road. Martina Navratilova paced the dressing room, so nervous I didn't know what to do with myself.

title: East Bloc Puts Increasing Emphasis on Nuclear Power
description: VIENNA March 24Eastern Europe is putting increasing stress on development of nuclear power, due in part to the approaching depletion of oilfields in European Russia.

title: Dance: Tommy Tune in Ichabod
description: You need more than one Tune to make a musical, and as good as Tommy was, he outdistanced his material Wednesday evening at Town Hall. His program was a solo condensation of Washington Irving's familiar tale Ichabod. viewed as a reminiscence by an older, wiser man.

title: Television
description: 11 P.M. (13) Smiles of a Summer Night (1955). Ulla Jacobson, Eva Dahlbeck. Ingmar Bergman's jewel, restrung as Broadway's A Little Night Music.

title: Renoir's The River
description: Two screenings of Jean Renoir's first color film, The River, will be presented in the auditorium of Japan House, 333 East 47th Street, Sunday at 2 and 4:30 P.M. Tickets, available at the door, are $3.50.

title: Antiques
description: ART NOUVEAU enthusiasts have a right to feel starved for information about Antonio Gaudi, the Spanish architect, whose genius transformed stone as well as furniture, grillwork, ceramics, fountains and street lamps into memorable baroque designs in and near Barcelona.

title: Nyack
description: There is, believe it or not, a little bit of small town, U.S.A., not far from the hustle and hassle of the city. It is Nyack, N.Y., just 30 miles up the Hudson from New York City. Nyackstill tied to the riveris indeed accessible by kayak as attested to by the Tom Adair lyrics that gave the town a place tin popular myth. However, since the song was written in 1940 a number of modern highways have made the trip somewhat easier.

title: Management
description: In March 1974, Bryan F. Smith, currently a director of Texas Instruments and formerly a senior vice president and chief financial officer, made a speech before the Harvard Club in Dallas about the role of corporate directors. It caused so much comment that the company's executives and directors labored over the points raised and brought forth a report on the results late that year.

title: CARTER SAYS VANCE, IN SOVIET, WILL SEEK DEEP WEAPONS CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 24President Carter said today that Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance would give priority in Moscow next week to seeking Soviet agreement for substantial reductions in the numbers of strategic missiles and bombers allowed to each side.

title: Smooth Transfer Impresses U.S.
description: WASHINGTON. March 24 (Reuters)Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States was deeply impressed by the democratic process in India and the smooth transfer of power following its election.

title: New Leaders Pay Homage to Gandhi at His Shrine
description: NEW DELHI, March 24The sublime was mingled with the mundane today under the rising sun at modern India's most sacred site.

title: Colorado Gets Solar Energy Unit
description: DENVER, March 24 (AP)The Federal Government's primary solar research installation will be built in Golden, Colo., according to Representative Timothy E. Wirth, who said today he had been informed of the decision by officials of the Energy Research and Development Administration.

title: Delta State Women Advance, 7549
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 24 (AP)Delta State, the defending champion, and Tennessee captured quarterfinal victories in the Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women basketball tournament today.

title: The LaborLiberal Hour in Britain
description: Americans can be grateful that British Prime Minister James Callaghan's pact with the Liberal Party enabled his minority Labor Government to survive a critical vote in the House of Commons Wednesday. The defeat of the Government would have meant a general election within six weeks. Opinion polls suggest that the Conservative opposition would win such an election. Whatever worthwhile changes a new Government might achieve, a political upheaval at this time could hardly have been favorable. A new budget is about to be presented and the

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Rurnstick Road may be seen tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at P.M., and there is also a 10:30 P.M. performance tomorrow. Tickets are 53.50. Reservations: 9663651. The Performing Garage is at 33 Wooster Street and may be reached by taking the BMT's N or RR lines to Canal Street and then walking three blocks west to Wooster Street.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: broadcast to the nation, calling the electoral change that has just taken place here unique.

title: Stage: Lily Captures Broadway
description: SHE HAS the impudent air of rich waif. She grins intimately, knowing that she has already been inside the homes of all her audience. She is a television personality, with all that does and does not imply. But now, at the Biltmore Theater, her personality is naked. A few clothes, a little lighting, two or three chairs. An empty stage. And Lily Tomlin. She opened last night. And, as ever. she illuminated everything.

title: Retail Store Sales Gain 12%

title: Chinese Ensemble to Play

Malone, who has been administering the National Institutes of Health research programs for the last 15 years, yesterday was appointed deputy director of the institutes, a part of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. Joseph A. Califanao Jr., Secretary of H.E.W., said that Dr. Young's promotion from an associate directorship to deputy director made him the first black to be appointed to such a high position in biomedical research.

title: Bridge

March 24There were plenty of shocks at the American ;Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here last night: a physical but ifnaginary bomb that disrupted the mixed pair championship and two metaphorical but substantial bombs that exploded in the Vanderbilt knockout teams.

title: A Year After the Military's Overthrow of Mrs. Peron,Violence and Turmoil Still Mark Argentine Lif6
description: BUENOIS AIRES, March 24Argentina's miliary junta has succeeded during its first year in power in virtually wiping out a potent leftwing insurgency, but it is still a long way from pacifying this turbulent nation.

title: Alcoholics Said to Run High Risk of Birth Defects
description: ELIZABETH, March 24Women who are heavy drinkers, consuming five or more ounces of alcohol a day, run a high risk of giving birth to abnormal children, a psychologist said today at a conference on women and alcohol at the Holiday Inn here.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP 2D STRAIGHT WEEK
description: The nation's money supply increased substantially for the second week in row, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

title: New Races
description: These have been lean times for lovers of the revue, that traditional incubator of theatrical talent. But there is a spot of cheer at 349 West 46th Street, where a tuneful entertainment called Starting Here, Starting Now is holding forth at the Barbarann Theater Restaurant. SHSN is a compendium of music by Richard Maltby Jr. and David Shire, two young songwriters who have written for theater, films and television, and whose songs have been recorded by the likes of Barbia Streisand and Roberta Flack. Weekend visitors who come to the Barbarann to dine or drink and take in the show will encounter three young performers of exceptional style and verve. George Lee Andrews, personable baritone, is the lynchpin of the trio. Flanking Mr. Andrews are Margery Cohen and Loni Ackerman, both of whom give convincing evidence that the revue form is not only alive, but also capable of kicking up a storm of applause.

title: Tho New York Times/Teresa Zabala
description: WASHINGTON, Marc; 24  Former President Ford came back to Washington today, riding in a sleek black limousine but obgerving at least part of the style of the Carter White House by carrying his own heavy briefcase.

title: Cape Verdeans Celebrate Their Own Mayflower
description: The Cape Verdeans are one of Brooklyn's smallest ethnic minorities, but not too small to celebrate their roots in a special exhibition of photographs and paraphernalia relating to the Ernestina, a deepwater sailing ship that brought many of them to these shores from their windy archipelago 370 miles off the coast of West Africa.

title: Big Board and Amex Issue Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued this week their latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of their companies.

title: NEW DELHI SWEARS IN DESAI AS 4TH PREMIER
description: NEW DELHI, March 24Morarji R. Desai, who was a political prisoner here two months ago, was sword in today as India's fourth Prime Minister. He pledged immediately to drive fear out of the society.

title: Zaire and Invaders Dispute Town's Fall And Battle's Course
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 24With diplomatic efforts under way to solve the conflict in southern Zaire, both sides in the fighting today issued conflicting reports of military advances.

title: For the L. I. R. R. Just Another Day And Another Delay
description: Commuters on the Long Island Rail Road spent an evening in stalled trains again and were alternating between anger and hilarity last night over double breakdowns, abandoned passengers and effusive apologies offered over the one reliable train mechanism, the publicaddress system.

title: Books: Folklore Guide
description: The development of portable and relatively inexpensive film and videotape equipment is revolutionizing the study of folklore. During the 19th century, writes William Ferris, who coedited American Folklore Films and Videotapes and is a professor of American Studies at Yale, paper and pencil were basic tools of folklore research. Later, tape recorders and still photography provided a fuller record of folk voices and faces. Today folklorists increasingly use film and videotape to capture traditions with a drama which handwritten and taped interviews cannot convey. The world of sound and motion recorded on film offers an immediate visual statement of what it means to sing the blues, build a basket, or work in an assembly line.

title: People and Business
description: What's going on at the Farah Manufacturing Company? Earlier this week, four of its nine directors resigned, including William C. Leone, who retained his titles of president and chief executive officer. Until yesterday, that is, when the company announced that William J. Conroy, executive vice president, had taken over the two top spots.

title: Film: 'Les Zozos,' Sweet Comedy
description: PASCAL THOMAS, the young French director, makes the kind of films that many criticsincorrectly, I thinkaccuse Franois Truffaut of having made in his Antoine Doinel cycle. Mr. Thomas's films are definitely "pleasant," which means they are so cheerful and engaging that they come dangerously close to being sentimental. They please. They amuse. They appreciate the uses of irony.Yet they never once surprise you with the comic perspective one gets in the Truffaut comedies. Antoine Doinel, the complete outsider, passionately aspires to join the bourgeoisie, whose manners and customs he studies with the dedication of a loony anthropologist. The bourgeoisie, seen through Antoine's admiring eyes, is simultaneously exotic and hugely comic. Mr. Thomas makes films about people who already belong, who have no idea that any other sort of existence is possible. Their view is limited.Such a film is "Les Zozos," Mr. Thomas's first film, a sweet-natured comedy about several months in the lives of some teen-age boys who are neither better nor worse than they should be. Mr. Thomas knows perfectly well that they'll all grow up to be somewhat stuffy and to the right of centerknowledge he seems to accept with a sort of benign shrug."Les Zozos," which was included in the Museum of Modern Art's 1973 New Directors/New Films program, opened yesterday at the Jean Renoir Cinema, and follows by two years the commercial release of the directors second film, "Don't Cry With Your Mouth Full." It's so decent and well-meaning that to criticize it in any way is rather like returning a birthday greeting unopened."Les Zozos" is about two friends, Frederic (Frederic Duru), a would-be ladies' man, and Franois (Edmond Railard), a shy sort who admires Frederic's worldliness as, in the course of the film, he begins to understand Frederic's shortcomings.This insight comes slowly, gently, as the two boys carry out their various romantic maneuvers, first with a couple of pretty girls who live near their boarding school, and then, most hilariously, when they make a trip to Sweden, whose girls, Frederic has been told, are notoriously easy marks. The Swedish excursion is a disaster for both boys. Franois is incapecitated by food poisoning and Frederic by his inability to understand the language. When a pliant young woman invites him home, he thinks she is telling him to go home.All of the performances are attractive in the low-key way of the entire film. Annie Cole, who played the ripe young heroine in "Don't Cry With Your Mouth Full," has a small role of a girl who, for reasons that are never adequately explained, can't get a boy of her own. As was "Don't Cry," "Les Zozos" was photographed mostly in landscapes of such idealized beauty that after a while one longs to see evidence of a little pollution.

title: Rail TonMileage Up 8.8%
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.8 billion tonmiles, 8.8 percent above the corresponding week year ago and the highest since Nov. 9, 1974. Carloadings in the same period totaled 476,946 cars, 5.2 percent above last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage was 8.5 percent above last year.

title: Miss Richards Eliminated
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 24 (UPI) Dr. Renee Richards lost her quarterfinal match to Marcie Louie,57, 76, 63, today, foiling a possible Lionel Cup semifinal showdown between the transsexual player and Billie Jean King.

title: 75 OPERATING REVENUES OF BIG BOARD INCREASED
description: Net operating revenues of the New York Stock Exchange last years rose to $4.1 million from $3.7 million in 1975, the exchange reported yesterday. Gross revenues in 1976 advanced to $85.6 million from $71.6 million.

title: State Will Let Beame Pay Bonuses to Some
description: After months of negotiations, Mayor Beanie has won informal approval from New York City's fiscal overseers to award longawaited $95 costofliving wage bonuses to 74,000 city employees. But the director of the State Emergency Financial Control Board challenges assertions that productivity savings will make the bonus possible.

title: Pakistan Said to Rearrest Leaders Of Opposition in New Crackdown
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Friday, March 25 (Reuters)Pakistan's four provincial governments said today that security forces, on the order of the national Government of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, had began rounding up opposition leaders and had issued a shoottokill order for violent demonstrators continuing to agitate against Mr. Bhutto's regime.

title: Rise Stevens Plays Role of Impresario
description: Rise Stevens's office is relatively small for that of a president, but handsomely appointed and person11011zed by many photographs and souvenirs. On a recent afternoon the unmistakable boom of someone, practicing on the timpani could be heard through the floor. The renowned Metropolitan Opera singer, who is now running the Mannes College of Music, apologized for the racket.

title: $2.50 MINIMUM WAGE PROPOSED BY CARTER INSETBACK TO LABOR
description: WASHINGTON, March 24Organized labor suffered its second sharp rebuff in two days today when the Carter Administration proposed an increase in the minimum wage substantially less than the unions had been seeking.

title: BUTLER B. MILTONBERGER, EXNATIONAL GUARD CHIEF
description: NORTH PLATTE, Neb., March 24 (AP) Maj. Gen. Butler B. Miltonberger, former commander of the United States Army's National Guard Bureau and commander of Nebraska's highly decorated 134th Infantry Regiment in World War II, died yesterday at a hospital here. He was 79 years old.

title: NEW DELHI SWEARS IN DESAI AS 4TH PREMIER
description: NEW DELHI, March 24Morarji R. Desai, who was a political prisoner here two months ago, was sworn in today as India's fourth Prime Minister. He pledged immediately to drive fear out of the society.

title: British Labor Party, Shy of Coalition, Tries Collaboration
description: LONDON, March 24In 1931, with the British economy in ruins as a result of a worldwide depression, Ramsay MacDonald, the first Labor Prime Minister, led his party into a grand coalition dominated by the Conservatives. It took the

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Now that the nation's three top aluminum producersthe Aluminum Company of America, the Reynolds Metals Company and the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporationhave raised their prices for primary unalloyed aluminum ingot to 51 cents pound, many other producers have decided to follow suit. The Anaconda Company's aluminum division, the .Aluminum Company of Canada Ltd., its United States subsidiary, the Alcan Aluminum Corporation, Revere Copper and Brass and the Howmet Aluminum Corporation took similar action yesterterday, raising their prices by 3 cents pound to the new level.

title: Massachusetts Senators Sentenced
description: BOSTON, March 24 (AP)Two Massachusetts legislators were sentenced today to one year in prison and were fined $5,000 each by a Federal judge on extortion convictions. Senator Joseph J.C. DiCarlo of Revere and Senator Ronald C. MacKenzie of Burlington were found guilty last month of shaking down a New York consulting concern for $40,000 in return for a favorable legislative committee report on an investigation into the company. The two men were freed yesterday pending appeals.

title: At the Movies
description: POETS, painters and actors belong to a select, notoriously unbrawny breed. Yet Bernie Casey, a dedicated poet, painter and actor, is a towering 6 feet 4 and weighs a trimly muscular 215. He didn't get that way struggling with iambic pentameter or toiling over a pallet or sweating out Shakespearean soliloquies. Although he failed to make a cinematic touchdown with such film fumbles as Hit Man, Cleopatra Jones, Dr. BlackMr. Hyde and Maurle, Mr. Casey was for eight triumphant years a superstar of the football stadium. rugged figure he hopes will fade forever into the locker room of the past with the opening next Thursday of Brothers, a scantly fictionalized account of the imprisonment and violent killing of Soledad brother George Jackson. Vonetta. McGee costars as the Angela Davislike militant with whom he falls in love.

title: Rickover Asks Congress to Protect Nuclear Fleet Against Carter Administration's CostCutting Effort
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  Adm. Hyman G. Rickover appealed to Congress today to protect the nuclear fleet against efforts of the Carter Administration to eliminate nuclear ships from the budget in costcutting moves.

title: Charter Talks Set for Dominica
description: LONDON, March 24 (AP)A constitutional conference leading to independence for the West Indian island of Dominica will be held in May, the Foreign Office announced today. The 29milelong island 20 miles north of Martinque, with a population of 75,000, is internally selfgoverning.

title: N.Y.U. Leads Advance In N.C.A.A. Fencing
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 24 (AP) New York University, the defending champion, and 10 other teams moved through the round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association fencing today. However, previously undefeated Penn State was one of the teams in the field of 62 that was knocked out.

title: Michigan Gains Hockey Final
description: DETROIT, March 24 (AP)Dave Silks, a Boston University freshman, scored three goals but it was not enough as the Terriers fell to Michigan, 64, tonight in the semifinals of the National Collegiate hockey championships. Michigan advanced to Saturday's final against the winner of tomorrow's semifinal game between Wisconsin and New Hampshire.

title: Flames 3, Red Wings 1
description: ATLANTA (AP)John Gould's two goals paced the Atlanta Flames to 31 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in an N.H.L. game.

title: Mayoral Hopefuls Give Remedies For New York City Ills at Forum
description: Mayoral candidates in New York City both announced and thinking of announcinggathered in the Harvard Club last night to give their prescriptions, simple and complex, for curing the city's ills.

title: LeGrands Are Convicted of Murdering 2 Sisters
description: Deveron LeGrand, the selfstyled bishop of a Brooklyn church, and his 26yearold stepson, Steven Strong LeGrand, were convicted last night in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on charges of murdering two teenaged sisters in October, 1975, and then burning their bodies.

title: CONGO TO COURTMAPTIAL ACCUSED IN 2 KILLINGS
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo, March 24 (UPI) The military junta here announced today that a special courtmartial would try all peope held in the murders of President Marien Ngouabi and Emile Cardinal Biayenda.

description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 24With, the opening of the baseball season just two weeks away, Manager Joe Frazier today began arranging the Mets starting pitching rotation.

title: Will MacArthur Return? Stay Tuned
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.One morning in 1971, Elia Kazan put his head in my door and asked how the new book was coming. Fine, said I. Roosevelt's running against Landon. The election is tomorrow, and I'm pretty sure F.D.R. is going to win. He pulled a face, in that wry way he has, but he nodded as he withdrew, for he knows how I work, and knew that whatever the calendar said, for me it was Monday, Nov. 2, 1936.

title: 2 Leave W.T.T. Nets
description: CLEVELAND, March 24 (AP)Haroon Rahim and Wendy Overton have been released from their contracts, according to Joe Zingale, owner of the World Team Tennis Nets, who are splitting their matches this season between here and Pittsburgh.

title: Tall Women in Armed Services
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)If the armed services accept 78inch men, they should do the same with tall women, Senator John Culver, Democrat of Iowa, said today. Since men up to 6feet6inches in height are acceptable for military service, there is no apparent good reason to discriminate against women who happen to be taller than six feet. Mr. Culver said in urging the Pentagon to end the policy.

title: Parents Win Custody of 5 Members of Moon's Church
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 24The Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon received a major setback today when a State Superior Court judge ordered five adult members placed in the temporary custody of their parents who seek to have them deprogrammed from the church.

title: The Politics of Court Reform
description: Pauline may have faced more perils, but the cause of court reform in the State of New York is fast closing in on her record. In case you came in late, here is a brief recap: A pareddown version of Governor Carey's court reform plan was passed at the last minute of the last session of the Legislature. It called for appointment of judges to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, by the Governor from a group of nominees selected by a Commission on Judicial Nomination, and also for strengthened court administration and better disciplinary procedures.

title: Panel on Cities Hears From Some Cabbies
description: Taxi drivers with obvious skill and experience in telling what's wrong with New York City gave their views and suggestions about the city to a legislative committee yesterday.

title: Miss Morerod Triumphs In Women's Final Cup Ski
description: GRANADA, Spain, March 24 (AP)LiseMprie Morerod of Switzerland, the new women's World Cup winner, completed the year's competition today by winning a giant slalom race.

title: LISLE W. ADKINS
description: Lisle W. Adkins, a retired vice president for the Louisville & Nashville Railroad, died yesterday in Louisville. He was 68 years old and had suffered a long illness.

title: U.S. Negotiators And Cuba Open Talks on Fishing
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The United States and Cuba today opened direct negotiations in New York over an agreement to regulate fishing in the waters between the two countries.

title: Publishing: A New Atlantic Alliance
description: A new era of transAtlantic publishing Is opening that promises to lead to greater and quicker availability of books in the Englishspeaking world.

title: Opera: Boheme With a New Mimi
description: THE METROPOLITAN Opera's La Boheme has been in the news this season, partly because the production, borrowed from the Lyric Opera of Chicago, had not been seen here before, partly because when televised live last week it was seen by millions of people. On Wednesday night, the Puccini work was in the news again. The performance marked the debut of Ileana Cotrubas, a soprano with an international reputation, in the role of Mimi. Renata Scotto, who had preceded her in the part, moved to the role of Musetta, which she had not sung here previously. Jose Carreras, the Rodolfo; Justino Diaz, the Colline, and Paul Franke. the Alcindoro, were singing those roles for the first time this season.

title: Shaw Breaks U.S. Mark in 500Freestyle
description: CLEVELAND, March 24Tim Shaw, Joe Bottom, Scott Spann and relay teams from Indiana and Auburn broke records tonight as the 54th annual National Collegiate swimming championships began with what promised to be a sweep of the record book.

title: Concert: Composers From Rutgers
description: THE THIRD CONCERT in a series of five featuring composers from Rutgers University took place in Carnegie Recital Hall this week. Works by Louie L. White and Michael Smolanoff were performed on this occasion.

title: Califano Hires a Second Assistant As Office Manager and Bodyguard

title: Ethics
description: WASHINGTON, March 24The controversy over Secretary Califano's cook suggests that the hottest subject in this city of politicians is not arms control or human rights or electoral reform but ethics. In the wake of Watergate and Wayne Haysnot to mention the ominously pending scandal of South Korean slush fundsthe instinct here is to be born again In ethical purity, as soon as possible.

title: A 4Borough Pornography Ban Unexpectedly Loses
description: Following Mayor Beame's lead, the Board of Estimate last night abruptly reversed itself and rejected zoning regulations that would have banned socalled massage parlors, adult bookstores and movie theaters, and all other socalled adult uses from every borough except Manhattan.

title: Fees Raised at Hartford College
description: HARTFORD, March 24 (AP)Room and board fees at the Hartford College for Women will increase by $275 for the 197778 school year, but tuition will not change, the trustees said this week. Room and board fees at the twoyear liberal arts college will go from $1,300 a year to $1,575.

title: VICE PRESIDENT BACKS CARTER RIGHTS STAND
description: Walter F. Mondale, making his first visit to New York City as Vice President, last night defended President Carter's criticism of human rights violations in the Soviet Union, saying that to turn our backs on the struggle for human rights elsewhereon torture, on political imprisonment, on terrorism, on restrictions on the freedom to emigratewould be to turn our backs on ourselves.

title: Cabaret: Mandel and Lydon
description: Ellen Mandel and Michael Lydon, who are opening for the Gabis Brothers countryrock band at Gerde's Folk City through Sunday, are better known as photographer and author than as performers. Miss Mandel photographed and Mr. Lydon wrote Rock Folk and Boogie Lightning, two widely admired books about rock.

title: Castro Honors Dead Of the Angolan War
description: LUANDA, Angola, March 24 (Agence FrancePresse)  Fidel Castro today paid personal tribute to the victims of Angola's civil war, which ended a year ago.

title: President Sees Aid for Vietnam If Talks on Ties Are Successful
description: WASHINGTON. March 24President Carter said today that he would respond well on the question of possible American economic aid for Vietnam if the assistance was arranged as part of successful negotiations to open normal diplomatic relations.

title: Protesters Assail Refusal of Saks To Hire Woman After Mastectomy
description: Twenty women cut their Saks Fifth Avenue charge cards into pieces in front of the Fifth Avenue store yesterday to protest the stores recent refusal to hire a woman who had had a cancerous breast removed. The demonstrators also urged shoppers to boycott the store.

description: Maurice H. Nadjari, the former special state anticorruption prosecutor, has been given a not approved rating by the judiciary committee of the Queens County Bar Association, damaging his candidacy for Queens District Attorney.

description: Practice is not always necessary in order to make perfect. The senior allstars of the State University of New York proved that before a standingroomonly crowd of 4.000 at City College's Mahoney Gymnasium last night, scoring a 7673 basketball victory over the City University's allstars in the Legislative Classic.

title: Jury Indicts Youth In Rape and Killing In Garment Center

title: 2 Soviet Satellites Launched
description: MOSCOW, March 25 (UPI)The Soviet Union has launched two satellites within the past 24 hours, Tass, the official press agency, reported today. Tass said another Molnia 1 communications satellite was launched yesterday to relay telephone, telegraph and television domestically. It said Cosmos 899 was sent up today to continue the exploration of outer space.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times reported incorrectly Thursday that a bill passed by the New York State Assembly providing for agencyshop negotiations by public employees would have also reduced strike penalties. The latter provision was not part of the bill.

description: The Dow Chemical company of Midland, Mich., said yesterday that it had reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company and partly owned foreign subsidiaries had made questionable payments totaling more than $3 million over a sixyear period that began in 1971.

title: Thai Group Proclaims a Coup; Takeover Denied by Government
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, March 26 (UPI)The deputy army commander seized official radio stations today and said that he had taken over Thailand's sixmonthold Government, but Adm. Sangad Chaloryu, who led a military coup last October, said the Government still has the situation under control.

title: Wisconsin Six in Final
description: DETROIT, March 25 (AP)Mike Eaees scored an unassisted goal at the 42second mark of suddendeath over time tonight to give Wisconsin a 4.3 victory over New Hampshire in the semifinals of the N.C.A.A. hockey tournament. The Badger victory sets up a title game with Michigan at 8 tomorrow night in a rematch of the Western Collegiae Hockey Association final, won by Wisconsin.

title: Chevrolet Confirms Plan To End Vega Production After 1977 Model Year

title: In Memoriam
description: BLANKDolly. March 26, 1970, Your kindness, sympathy and understanding are missed so much. The tragedy is greater, for there are so few of your kind In this world. DOROTHY and IRVING.

title: A Twin Spotlight for Seattle Slew

title: Vocational Educator Honored After a 48Year Career
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, March 25In 1929, a disappointed Rutgers student, Benjamin Shapiro, was sent to Middlesex County Vocational School here to fulfill his requirement for practice teaching. title: Landowners vs. 765,000Volt Lines ...
description: WINNETKA, Ill.On a misty fall morning in 1971, Norman Seitz started to harvest the fine stand of corn on his farm near Beecher, Ill. He rode his tractor out into the fields where Commonwealth Edison had recently constructed a 765,000volt powertransmission line. The giant towers, as tall as 12story buildings, cast long barred shadows across the acres of ripe corn. Suddenly Mr. Seitz's leg jerked violently and a startling shock passed through his body. The air became alive with a buzzing sound as if invaded by an invisible swarm of angry bees. Commonwealth Edison had energized the line.

So parcels of land were set asidefrom vacant lots to cultivated acreageand the children were given scrap materials with which to build their own spontaneous playgrounds.

title: 'Airport '77,' Starring a Jet, Fails to Maintain High Level
description: In "Airport," based on Arthur Hailey's novel, a Boeing 707 jet proved its durability by surviving the explosion of a bomb with scarcely a wobble of the wings. In the sequel, "Airport '75," a Boeing 747 jumbo jet was brought safely home to base after a collision with small private plane. Now, in the second sequel, "Airport '77," which opened at a number of theaters yesterday, a Boeing 747, converted into what is described as a "prototype executive aircraft" but looking more like a flying Beef 'n Brew, crash-lands at sea, sinks into 100 feet of water and remains almost as airtight as a diving bell and a lot safer than your own living room.But, some wag is sure to ask, can a 747 boil an egg? Probably not. The Boeing genius has its results, though you'd never know it from this series of popular, immensely silly films that look like reclamation projects for elderly actors.Never, of course, does anything happen to these Boeing aircraft that could conceivably be attributed to equipment failure. The lunacy of man is responsible with such consistency that one begins to feel a quasi-religious emotion in the presence of such perfect planes. You sense the world would be a much better place if people retired and put their destinies on automatic pilot.The tiny story of "Airport '77" concerns a rich art collector, played by James Stewart, who invites a planeload of friends, other art collectors and art critics to the opening of his Palm Beach museum. En route from Washington to Florida, thieves attempt to hijack the plane to get its cargo of paintings, but succeed only in crashing everyone into the ocean. Most of the picture is occupied with the passengers' panic, resolution and heroism as Navy divers attempt to raise the plane by huge floats.The characters include the stalwart pilot (Jack Lemmon), his fiance (Brenda Vaccaro), a frisky, pretty art patron (Olivia De Havilland) whose loyal black maid (Maidie Norman) is among the few people killed, an old (very old) flame of Miss De Havilland's (Joseph Cotten), assorted bratty children, an estranged married couple (Lee Grant and Christopher Lee) and a blind musician (Tom Sullivan), who plays cocktail piano and sings "Beauty is in the Eye of the Beholder."The film was directed by Jerry Jameson, most or whose experience has been in television, but "Airport '77" looks less like the work of a director and writers than like a corporate decision."Airport '77," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some mildly bloody sequences involving passengers and furniture they bump into during the plane's crash-landing.

title: Notes on People
description: An audience of teenagers and senators held a telephone interview yesterday with Henry Winkler, the actor who plays the Fonz, the television character, on the subjects of alcohol and other drugs. Calling from a Washington hearing room, Becky Yates, from Mechanic Falls, Me., said, I'm 13 and a lot of people look up to you. Mr. Winkler said the pressures of life and school and career preparation were enough, without adding the problems of drugs and alcohol. You have to be in possession of yourself to realize your dreams, said Mr. Winkler. Euphoria is connected with accomplishment and it gives you a great sense of self. The actor said he does not use alcohol because I don't like the way it feels in my body, because I'm under its control until it lets me go.

title: Conservative Frenchman on the Way Up
description: PARIS, March 25In times of crisis the French have turned to men like Napoleon, Ptain and de Gaulle. An in creasing number of Frenchmen seem to think that another savior is rapidly needed and that his name is Jacques Ren Chirac. Mr. Chirac, a driven man with the open ambition of becoming the leader, is ready. At age 44 he has Napoleon's boundless energy, Petain's selfassurance and de Gaulle's Machiavellian sense of politics. What he lacks is their prestigious military records, for he has not won a war, although he fought in Algeria, where he was wounded, decorated and promoted to captain.

title: Seaver Expects No Trade; Helps Mets Triumph, 21
description: ST. PETERSBERG, Fla., March 25Tom Seaver pitched five nearly perfect innings against the Boston Red Sox today and then, reflecting on the recent outbreak of rumors about his future, said he doubted that the New York Mets would trade him.

title: Bronx Zoo Increases Fees
description: Citing rising Costs and cutbacks in city aid, the Bronx Zoo said yesterday that it would increase its FridaythroughMonday admission fees for adults from $1 to $1.50 and for children from 50 cents to 75 cents, effective April 1. Admission will continue to be free on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. Children under the age of 2 and persons 65 and over will continue to be admitted without charge every day.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HIS OWN THING Many American tourists who visit Barcelona return home haunted by the port city's bizarre, unfinished Sagrada Familia Church, a towering symbol of the works of Antonio Gaudi, who died in 1926. The visionary architect was considered mad in his time. He is now recognized as a seminal genius. Today through May 24, a large retrospective collection of more than 100 drawings by Gaudi, and the first major show in this country on the Catalan architect goes on view at the Drawing Center, 137 Greene Street (between Houston and Prince Streets).

title: 'Eagle Has Landed' on Screens With Lively Splash of Adventure
description: "The Eagle Has Landed," directed by John Sturges, is a good old-fashioned adventure movie that is so stuffed with robust incidents and characters that you can relax and enjoy it without worrying whether it actually happened or even whether it's plausible.The time is late 1943 and the adventure concerns the efforts of some German commandos to kidnap Winston Churchill and carry him back to Berlin, in ordersays the filmto allow Hitler to negotiate peace with the Allies.Michael Caine plays the leader of the raiding party, a German paratroop officer whose credentials as a humanitarian are established early n the film when, en route to Germany from the Russian front, he attempts to save a Polish Jewish woman from mistreatment by Nazi soldiers. With the exception of Heinrich Himmler (Donald Pleasance), all the Germans in the movie are decent felows, the sort who risk their ives to save the world's less fortunate when they aren't kidnapping the world's leaders.These Germans include Anthony Quayle as Adm. Wilhelm Canaris, who has a very funny scene early in the picture, when he describes a strategy meeting with Hitler that sounds a bit like a Darryl Zanuck story conference, and Robert Duvall, as the German officer whose job it is to make a feasibility study for the raid.Most of the film, though, is set on the beautiful Norfolk coast of England, where the German raiders, disguised as Free Polish troops, settle down to await Churchill's arrival on a weekend rest visit. Mr. Caine's chief accomplice is a fast-talking Anglophobic Irish patriot played by Donald Sutherland with great dash and a brogue that seems to rise and fall according to a mysterious inner timetable.Among other characters are a sweet English girl (Jenny Agutter) who falls in love with the Irishman, and an American Army officer (Larry Hagman) who's such a nitwit he almost wins the day for the Germans.Tom Mankiewicz's screenplay, based on a novel by Jack Higgins, is straightforward and efficient and even intentionally funny from time to time. Mr. Sturges ("Bad Day at Black Rock," "Gunfight at the O.K. Corrall" and "The Great Escape") obtains first-rate performances building the tension until the film's climactic sequence, whch, as you might suspect, concludes with a plot twist.With so many failed suspense melodramas turning up these days, it's refreshing to see one made by people who know what they're about and, in that knowledge, have no delusions of grandeur. The film opened yesterday at Columbia Premiere theaters."The Eagle Has Landed," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), ends with an extended battle sequence that might frighten very small children who have never been exposed to prime-time television.

The 82yearold union chief dominated every meeting, his mind nimble, his wit keen, his vitality appar ently inexhaustible.
