description: WASHINGTONAn antitrust era drawing to a close. It began exactly five years ago this month when International Telephone & Telegraph and Dita Beard gave the Justice Department's antitrust division more notoriety than it had ever expected or desired. It will end on June 1, when Donald G. Baker, who has been the assistant attorney general in charge of antitrust since mid1976, will leave his post (unless you know something I don't, he says jokingly).

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: When the Metropolitan Opera televised its Bohme performance last March 15 over Channel 13the show was repeated last Sundayit was not the first time that the Met had brought live opera to national television screens. But this was the first in color, with a stellar cast, and there was more than a satisfactory response. The Nielsen rating was 7.7 for the New York area. That means that about a million and a half sets were tuned to the broadcast. This 7.7 rating might not have caused coffee cups to rattle at the breakfast tables of commercial television executives, but for public broadcasting it was unprecedented. The national returns are not yet in, but P.B.S. officials, extrapolating, think that all records will be broken.

title: On the Frontier With Mr. Audubon
description: Taking an episode from the life of John James Audubon (his travels on the Ohio and the Mississippi in 182021), Barbara Brenner again demonstrates her gift for invention and respect for facts. This is a combination of fiction and fact that works so well it might almost be the thing it imitates.

title: CARTER BACKER HEADS FOR NONPOLITICAL JOB
description: WASHINGTON, March 26A councilman, in suburban Montgomery County, Md. called a little noticed news conference to announce that he was quitting to take a Federal appointment, apparently unaware of any problems he might be creating for himself and his prospective employer.

title: Platform Tennis Title Events Are Taking Over Forest Hills
description: Championship tennis returns to Forest Hills this week, but it isn't the United States Open.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Acting is acting, isn't it? Well, yes and no. Many years ago at an Edinburgh Festival, I sat up late into the night talking with Alan Bates and the director Clive Donner about the film they had just made of Harold Pinter's The Caretaker. As I recall it, Bates contended (and he had appeared in both the play and the film) that the techniques involved were confusingly differentnot only through the scale of the gesture, the insight of the closeup, the special inflection of the voice, but even more through power and the size of the image. A good example of this also taken from Bates, who has obviously studied the subject could be seen in the slight but telling differences in his stage and film appearances in Simon Gray's Butley.

title: STIFF CAMPAIGN LAW TO TAKE EFFECT SOON
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The most comprehensive and stringent code of campaign regulations ever imposed on candidates for Congress and the Presidency is scheduled to become law this week without a murmur of opposition from oncehostile critics in the Senate and House.

title: Roosevelt
description: OTB payoffs subiect to 5% Municipal surtax)

title: IolantaAn Operatic Romance for Today
description: The Mannes College of Music last week added still another to this season's unprecedented list of opera novelties. It brought Tchaikovsky's Iolanta to the stage for the first time in this city exactly a week after its uptown sister, the Manhattan School of Music, had presented WolfFerrari's charming I Quattro Rusteghi. There has never before in New York musical life been such a concentration of Romantic opera revivalsfrom the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera, the music schools and small professional groups and the concertopera organizations.

title: A Flash of Cliffs, A Glimpse of Tiled Roofs: Cinque Terre
description: The waiters on the rapido from Rome to Genoa performed their miracle, dispensing mounds of steaming pasta down the swaying length of the vagone ristorante without a drop of marinara sauce landing out of bounds. Then, about an hour after lunch, the train sliced through the sandy stretches north of Viareggio. Italy's northern seacoast, where the Riviera begins, never looked more inviting.

title: Fort Devon Withdrawn
description: LONDON, March 26 (AP)Americanowned Fort Devon has been pulled out of next Saturday's Grand National at Aintree, the world's most famous steeplechase race, his trainer, Fulke Walwyn, said today. Fort Devon, owned by Charlie Bird of Unionville, Pa., fell in last week's Gold Cup steeplechase but wasn't hurt. Walwyn said the horse needed more experience to run in the Grand National at Aintree.

title: JAMES R. GIULIANO DIES; RETIRED JUDGE IN JERSEY
description: James R. Giuliano, a retired judge of the New Jersey State Superior Court, died Friday in Orange Memorial Hospital in Orange, N.J., of a heart ailment. He was 72 years old and lived in Newark.

title: Films on Gardening Scheduled
description: Two films that deal with Growing Things Naturally will be presented on March 30 at 10:30 A.M. at Brooklyn's Central Library, at Grand Army Plaza.

title: Upward Price Pressure Worrying More Economists
description: The ranks of, economists who are unconcerned about inflation thinned considerably last week as prices for basic foodstuffs and industrial raw materials continued to go up.

title: A HighPowered Offense Is Best Boating Defense
description: After a prolonged strategy session in front of a cozy fireplace, I have devised a new defense against indoor and outdoor boat shows and the various harbingers of a new season on the waterfront. This year I am going to attack.

title: Signals From the Bathtub
description: MY life's ambition until recently was to emulate the tea bag, that lucky object that is allowed to steep in hot water until the very essence of its being is freed. It may surprise some and offend others to learn that, because I live in Bergen County, I have permanently renounced all baths. I abjure, any contact whatever with the tubwith dipping, plunging, sousing, sprinkling, dabbling, dousing.

title: Gilchrist Takes 2 Titles In Eastern, State Tennis
description: Jim Gilchrist won two tennis finals here yesterday. He beat Tony Franco, 62, 62 for the Eastern indoor clay 45's title and Steve Ogilvie, 61, 61 for the New York State indoor clay 55's crown.

title: INDICTMENT DROPPED IN A MEDICAID CASE
description: An acting State Supreme Court justice has dismissed indictments against a Westchester County nursinghome owner and his wife, who were accused of defrauding Medicaid by filing false financial reports.

title: A Different Beat for the Explorers
description: A LISON DEVAUX, a 17yearold senior at Andrew Warde High School in Fairfield, knows the local police pretty well, but not because she Is an item on the blotter. No traffic violations, no criminal arrests, no appearances in court.

title: Performance by Connie Beckley Lies Between Theater and Music
description: Connie Beckley's performances occupy that elusive but powerful nether world between theater and musica form of smallscaled but intense lyric drama that may some day soon blossom into fulldress modern opera.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: The Frontier Dream That Went Flat
description: THE process was as American as Frederick Jackson Turner's frontier theory of history. We are indeed a people who absolutely require a perpetual frontier, a distant boundary to be overcome and mastered, be it the Mississippi River or the Sea of Tranquillity. It may, in fact, be the key to our national temperamenton the one hand, expansive optimism; on the other, biting dissatisfaction.

title: Diane J. Brown, Peter S. Briggs To Wed Aug. 27
description: Mrs. Edward M. Bigler of Greenwich, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla., and M. Barclay Brown Jr., of Hilton Head, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Justine Brown, to Peter Sheffield Briggs. He is a son of Mr. and and Mrs. John L. Briggs of Greenwich. The wedding is planned for Aug 27

title: CHESS
description: Hypermodern defenses are all based, in one form or another, on the plan of relinquishing the center at an early stage of the opening for the sake of creating a counterattack against the opponent's pawns. In using these defenses, two errors must be avoidedplaying listlessly and thus allowing the opponent's center pawns to swamp you, and counterattacking with excessive ferocity that rebounds to wreck your own position.

title: Trout Season Will Open Friday, Except in 3 Upstate Counties
description: New York State's trout season opens Friday in most counties, and generally good water conditions are expected, the snow accumulations of winter having largely disappeared in March.

title: Tennessee published here
description: Once upon an innocence when our libidos merely had to be tickled instead of hustled, The Pulps reigned. The first of them appeared in 1896 when Frank Munsey, the publisher of Argosy, transformed his boy's magazine into an alladult adventure fiction publication. Each issue consisted of 192 pages and roughly 135,000 words uninterrupted by illustrations. The breather in the hotpaced prose was the advertising.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: FOR various reasonspolitical viewpoint, personal situations or lack of understandingsome Americans still believe that the nation's economy is continuing to travel through very troubled waters. Others speak of the recent recession as a current reality. At the same time, however, most private economists have been hailing the completion of the 24th month of the latest recovery move this week and taking a more positive view of the future.

title: Marilyn F. Fitzgerald Wed To Walter J. Bagley, Editor
description: Marilyn F. Fitzgerald, patientcare coordinator at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N. Y., was married yesterday to Walter J. Bagley, an editor for the Reuters news agency in New York

title: DISPUTE ON CABINET EMBARRASSES DESAI
description: NEW DELHI, March 26Just two days after taking office, Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai tonight found himself snarled in an embarrassing dispute over the composition of his Cabinet.

title: One Person, One Vote
description: WASHINGTON, March 25President Carter has sent to Congress the most extensive electoral reform proposals in history, and even the most contraversial of themdirect popular election of Presidentshas a reasonable chance of Congressional approval.

title: F. M. Ballard Fiance Of Cristina Chavss
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jos M. Chaves of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their, daughter. Cristina. Maria Chaves, to F. Michael Ballard, son of Mrs. Edwin W. Roberts and Fred L. Ballard of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The couple plan to be married in June.

title: China Blanks Australia In Title Table Tennis
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, March 26 (UPI)China, the defending champion, beat Australia 50, today and Sweden defeated Denmark, also 50, in the first round of the 34th world table tennis championships. Czechoslovakia was a 50 victor over Indonesia.

title: NEW PRIMARY RULES PRESENT PROBLEMS
description: If Democrats fail to nominate all of their three top New York City candidates the first chance they getwhich is by no means unlikelythey will find the runoff contenders in an unaccustomed spot, on the far right of the machine.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayGaines 1977 United States Dog Obedience Classic. St. Louis Community College, 5600 Oakland Avenue. St. Louis; 156 dogs representing 31 breeds and 26 states.

title: The World
description: HONG KONGTwo years after victorious Communist armies marched into Saigon and Phnom Penh and the Cornmunistled Pathet Lao took over Laos, none of the other south Asian dominos has fallen, but real insurgencies do exist and the question of how to deal with them remains as much in debate as it always was.

title: CORRECTION
description: The engagement announcement of Deborah Schneider and Dr. Victor A. Greenhut in last Sunday's Times, identified the future bride's mother, Mrs. Howard Schneider, as a former treasurer of the board of trustees of Rutgers University instead of the Halsted School.

title: Thai Coup Attempt, Mostly Just a War Of Words, Is Foiled
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 36Thailand's fivemonthold military Government today foiled a coup by a small clique of military officers backed by about 300 soldiers after a day of confrontation in downtown Bangkok.

title: New light on black I.Q.
description: Arthur Jensen was a littleknown scholar at the University of California in Berkeley eight years ago when he reported on studies concluding that blacks have lower I.Q.'s than whites primarily because of their genetic heritage. His name became synonymous with racism in liberal circles. Last month, when Jensen was elected a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, that normally sedate, scholarly group found itself embroiled in a bitter and embarrassing argument. Margaret Mead helped draw up a fivepoint resolution criticizing the psychologist's work, which she termed unspeakable. William D. Wallace, director of Harvard University's healthcareer programs, called his election an endorsement of racism and damaging to the credibility of the A.A.A.S. in its work with minority scientists. Wallace resigned from the association in protest.

title: West German Upset Victor In Cup Slalom
description: SOLYNIEVE, Spain, March 26 (UPI) Christa Zechmeister of West. Germany today upset Switzerland's former double Olympic champion, MariaTheres Nadig, in the final of the parallel slalom, the final women's event in the Sierra Nevada ski meet that winds up the winter's World Cup competition.

title: Watson Takes 4Shot Lead In Heritage Golf on 66200
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., March 26And now the reprise, the one that is so familiar to Tom Watson. Once again he is leading a tournament going into the final round, and once again there is the question: Will he make it?

title: Ideas &Trends
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, according, to a report by the National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences, has been hindered in its purpose of safeguarding the environment by a number of flaws in the way scientific information is gathered and applied for regulatory purposes.

title: Zimmerman Is Figuring To Find Spot With Giants
description: It happens almost every day, usually without fanfare, often without comment: National Football League teams sign players who were not good enough to make other National Football League teams.

title: A Playwright's Hilarious Parody Of Hollywood's Favorite Myths
description: HARTFORD Movies are artifacts of our lives as well as of our dreams. In his iconoclastic travesty. A History of the American Film (a new play in its premiere engagement at the Hartford Stage Company), Christopher Durang asks, if movies were our only record, what would we know about America? Clearly, the celluloid picture of society is gloriously sentimentalized. Gangsters are glamorous. The Depression was a time of screwball comedy. World War II was fought partially in the Stage Door Canteen. And postwar was a period of redemption and triumph through faith and Alcoholics Anonymous.

title: Cadet James Fucillo Fiance Of Frances G. Q. Washburn
description: Col. Walter R. Washburn Jr., U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Washburn of Colorado Springs have announced the engagement of their daughter, Frances Grace Quirke Washburn, to Cadet James Edward Fucillo, a first classman at the United States Air Force Academy.

title: When Officials Are Sued, Who Should Defend Them?
description: WASHINGTONJohn N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, and 60 other present or former public officials are now being sued in civil courts by thousands of private citizens who believe they were subjected to improper surveillance by their Government, and their cases may soon become the subject of a major Congressional debate.

title: Headliners
description: Joanne Chesimard, an alleged leader of the Black Liberation Army, has been convicted of killing a New Jersey state trooper, and has been sentenced to life in prison. The verdict was returned despite Mrs. Chesimard's protestations that at the time of the incident she was unarmed, and despite defense testimony from two medical experts that bullet wounds suffered by Mrs. Chesimard could only have occurred if her hands had been raised when she was shot. The shootings took place when Mrs. Chesimard and two companions were stopped by state troopers on the New Jersey Turnpike in May, 1973. One companion was killed; another was sentenced to life in prison in 1974.

title: Suggested Agenda
description: I have my own list of issues that I think would make an appropriate initial agenda for the Commission on Connecticut's Future. I hope others add theirs. Can we perform research to do the following:

title: Mary W. Nicholas Bride of Eugene L. Eliasoph
description: Mary W. Nicholas, a group counselor and therapist in New Haven, was married there yesterday to Eugene Leon Eliasoph, a codirector of the New Haven Center for Human Relations. The ceremony was performed in the Branford Chapel at Yale University by the Rev. Theresa Hansing of New Haven, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Taking a Walk Into Spring
description: FOR those bent on a spring day with nothing but the sky overhead, the rolling countryside of Westchester, with its valleys running southerly and southwesterly between ridges rising to nearly 600 feet in many places, makes for ideal tramping. Although the elevations are hardly extreme in this region, there are enough vistas to be exciting. In short, the country provides some of the most enjoyable walking in the Northeast.

title: Early Trout Season for Idaho
description: BOISE, Idaho. March 26The Western drought is giving Idaho fishermen an early start on the trout season in some areas because officials fear that reservoirs will be dry by early summer.

title: ECONOMY REBOUNDING FROM COLD'S IMPACT, FEBRUARY DATA SHOW
description: WASHINGTON, March 26The American economy seems to have overcome the adverse consequences of one of the coldest winters of this century and to be moving toward an annual growth rate 5 to 6 percent higher than last year's. By the end of the year, it may be within striking range of a $2 trillion gross national product.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Amateurism Winning
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On a Large Hunting Preserve in the Old South
description: BOSTWICK, Ga.At 4 A.M., the five footlong curtains in my room billowed in neargale gusts of wind, and lightning flared over the fields and woods surrounding the old plantation house in which I slept.

title: A Plea for Unhobbling the Disabled
description: IAM 20 years old and a college graduate with a degree in social work. I am a wife and the mother of a baby girl. Sometimes I work as a counselor at an agency for troubled teenagers. I have been choir director for a large church community since last year. I run my home with only a bit of outside help. Most of my life I have been in a wheelchair but I am and want to go on being an active contributing member of society. So long as my wheelchair and I are not considered in the planning of public and private buildings and their surrounding grounds, I suffer limits to my freedom and so do like me.

title: Fine Prague Chamber Orchestra
description: The Prague Chamber Orchestra returned to Town Hall on Friday night and once again demonstrated that 36 musicians can function as a superlative ensemble unit without the benefit of a conductor. Intensive rehearsals and an unusual sensitivity for internal balances no doubt accounted for the smooth instrumental blend and smart precision, qualities one now expects from this group as a matter of course.

title: Garden Debris, a Burning Issue
description: TIME WAS when one of the joys of living in the suburbs was the anticipation, spring and fall, of the intoxicating smell of burning leaves. The back would bend to the rake in willing labor for the reward of that first acridsweet whiff. But that time has gone, as state after state has prohibited leaf and brush burning. Connecticut is no exception, and some people here are smoldering as a result.

title: Nina Gagarin Fiancee Of Willard Griffin Jr.; June Wedding Is Set
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Peter Serge Gagarin of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Nina Hill Gagarin, to Willard Henry Griffin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Griffin of Chatham, Mass. The wedding is planned for June at the Gagarins' summer home in Chatham.

title: Carter Picks Gronouski to Head Radios Aimed at the Soviet Bloc
description: WASHINGTON, March 26President Carter has nominated John A, Gronouski, a former United States Ambassador to Poland, to be chairman of the Board for International Broadcasting, which oversees Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, White House officials said.

title: Portrait of a political thrill killer
description: This is a truly ugly little book. It tells the story of one Palestinian terrorist campaign in Western Europeeight killings, two mass kidnappings and a bombing over a 30month period. But it is not the crimes that repel so much as the character of the man who carried them out. A typical episode is the shooting of Joseph Edward Sieff, a British Zionist, while he was dressing for dinner one evening in the winter of 1973. Sieff's assailant was Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, a fleshy Venezuelan in his mid20's better known under his nombre de guerra as Carlos Martinez. Carlos simply rang Sieff's bell, pointed his Browning automatic pistol at the Portuguese butler who answered the door and told the butler to take him to Sieff. The terrified butler did as he was told.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (UPI)Both sides in the walkout of city transit workers here are settling in for a long strike, with neither apparently willing to budge after a tentative contract was rejected Thursday.

title: A Trust for Resources
description: Congress should place the nation's exhaustible natural resources in public trust, with the owners as trustees and the public as beneficiary, a new reresearch report asserts. The trusteeswhether government agencies, individuals or corporationswould have clearly defined obligations to protect the environment and individual citizens would have a legal right to sue to enforce those duties.

title: Rent Bill Confronts Albany
description: WESTCHESTER COUNTY landlords consider it as welcome as a plague of termites and would like to see it exterminated. Most Westchester tenants consider it as vital as heat in the winter and want to see it maintained and strengthened.

title: New &Novel
description: By Shulamith Hareven. Translated from the Hebrew by Hillel Halkin. 205 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $7.95.

title: Theodore S. Baran to Marry Sharonah Schlesinger
description: Sharonah Beth Schlesinger and Theodore Saul Baran. graduates of the Teachers Institute of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, plan to be married in August at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I.

title: SHOP TALK
description: WHEN two booklovers meet, conversation often turns to dreams of opening a bookshopa warm and peaceful place with congenial customers.

title: Deborah Merrick Is Affianced
description: Deborah Hulme Merrick, a staff counsel to the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources in Washington, and Myron Lykins Dale,, a lawyer with the Federal Trade Commission in Washington, plan to be married this September in Princeton, N.J.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: The medallion pictured here was created to mark the 50th anniversary of Charles Lindbergh's epic solo flight across the Atlantic Ocean which began on May 20, 1927, in New York and ended 33 hours later in Paris. It shows a bust of Lindbergh with a depiction of his plane, The Spirit of St. Louis, in the background.

title: INTERVIEW
description: AMONG State Senator Bernard Gordon's memorabilia of 24 years in politics is a framed cartoon on the wall of his Peekskill law office that shows a bloodied and bandaged legislator being carried into the State Senate chamber to vote on the nofault automobile insurance bill. On each of the legislator's stilltwisted arms are the cajoling lobbyists for the trial lawyers and the insurance companies.

title: Volunteer Firemen Play an Essential Role in the Suburbs
description: GLEN HEAD, L.I.A house caught fire in North Shore Acres one night recentlya few licks of orange in the midnight sky, a flurry of children in nightclothes, an upstairs bedroom burning persistently.

title: Distance Medley Relay Is Taken By Fordham Prep at Its Meet
description: The local schoolboy indoor track season officially came to a close yesterday under clear skies, with gusty winds and the temperature at 50 degrees. If that doesn't sound like indoor conditions, they weren't.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: THE weather is warmer, now that spring arrived officially last Sunday, and I expect that my friend Eileen will be able to stop sifting flour onto the rafters of her house in Englewood. Soon, she hopes, her squirrelinduced insomnia will be cured and she won't have to spend her normal sleeping hours researching the hibernation habits of flying squirrels.

title: Editors' Choice
description: General

title: ART
description: AREPORT on the subsistence and conservation of an Eskimo life style, published in 1975, asked the question: Does one way of life have to die so that another can live?

title: BRIDGE
description: As bridge columns in this newspaper go, this one is unique. Ever since the late Albert Morehead began writing in the thirties, every main diagram has been intended to have 52 cards, although the fates have intervened on few occasions. But today we show only 26 cards, quite intentionally.

title: Rain, Rain Everywhere, but...
description: IN THE course of a normal year, about six trillion gallons of rain water fall on New Jersey, or about 900,000 gallons for every resident of the state. Since the average New Jerseyan uses only about 36,500 gallons of water a year, there ought to be water to waste, even in periods of drought.

title: Kayaks: Craft of Eskirnos Is Coming Out of the Cold
description: Riddle: What boat design can take an amazing amount of thundering white water? Answer: The ancient Eskimo designed hunting craft, the kayak.

title: The Best of Al McGuire
description: ATLANTA, March 26Sports, said Al McGuire once upon a time, is a coffee break. His coffee break is about over. He will retire as Marquette's basketball coach after the National College. Athletic Association championship game Monday night. He is 48 years old, which means he is retiring on his schedule. Can you imagine being in your 50's, he once said, and still worrying if some cheerleader is pregnant. Or even worrying about winning a basketball game. Winning is only important, he has said, in war and surgery. Long after Al McGuire's success as a coach is forgotten, his philosophy and his phrases will be remembered and repeated. Some of his words deserve to be chiseled on stone tablets or at least carved into the boardwalk at Rockaway Beach, where he grew up

title: Journey Of the Wolf
description: The wolf of Douglas Day's title Sebastian Rosales, dubbed El Lobo for the cunning ferocity with which he fought Franco in the Spanish Civil War. Now, after 34 years of stifling exile in France he is determined to revisit his native town in Andalucia, if only to die.

title: Taking exercise to heart
description: During the 1975 New York Marathon, I met an old friend and asked him about a mutual acquaintance with whom we used to run. He died of a heart attack three weeks ago, he replied. But, he added quickly, he would have died five years earlier he hadn't been a runner.

title: Cornell Trustees Replace Senate With Less Powerful Organization
description: ITHACA, N. Y., March 26One of the nation's most innovative and powerful collegecampus governments was abolished this week at Cornell Universityseven years after thousands of students demanded and won a voice in how the school should be run.

title: Pitching Makes A's a Cinderella Team Despite a HumptyDumpty Appearance
description: MESA, Ariz., March 26The most suddenly dismembered major league baseball team in 45 years, since Connie Mack started selling off his champion Philadelphia Athletics in the early 1930's, is preparing for the 1977 season here under the scrutiny of three former major league managers and Charley Finley's telephone.

title: Taxes and the Feds
description: THERE are only two things for certain in this world, Mark Twain once observed, death and taxes. New Jersey residents can easily attest to the certainty  and oppression  of taxes.

title: L.I. PAVING CONCERN SUES OVER ALLEGED CONSPIRACY
description: A Long Island road paving company has charged that rival companies belonging to the Metropolitan Asphalt Paving Association conspired with New York City's deputy commissioner of highways to monopolize city contracts for street paving.

title: Help for and From the Poor
description: Food stamps are coupons which poor people buy at discount prices and spend for food. For all the sneers about funny money and for all the complaints about welfare chiseling, they work. Welfare reform theories have come and gone in Washington's abstract breezes; food stamps have fed the hungry. Some 27 million Americans will rely on them sometime this year. But there is a problem. Many needy and eligible peopleperhaps two millionare denied food stamps because of a quirk. The new Democratic Administration now has an opportunity to rectify that wrong.

title: Accord on JuvenileFingerprint Bill
description: ALBANY, March 26Agreement on a bill that would require the fingerprinting of juveniles arrested for serious felonies was reached this week by the chairmen of the State Senate Crime Committee and the Assembly Child Care Committee.

title: Rowing
description: AT PELHAM MANOR

title: Food
description: Someone has claimed that snails, those elegant, finetextured delicacies that grow on vine leaves, are merely a good excuse for gastronomes to eat lots of garlic without apology. That may be stretching things a bit, but snails do belong to that category of foods more or less neutral  like macaroni and potatoeswhose character relies on the flavors and seasonings with which they are linked. Snails go marvelously well with walnuts and cheese, for instance, and, of course, with garlic. Three snail recipes are outlined on this pageone  la hourguignonne, with garlic; another with spinach, walnuts and cheese, and the third, brochette, also with walnuts.

title: Events Today
description: BROOKLYN GARDEN CLUBS FLOWER SHOW: 11 A.M. to 4 P.M., Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 WashIngton Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: MUSIC MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: One Woman and a Challenge
description: FOUR years ago Barbara Wells Vroom was a fulltime staff member of The New Yorker, living in a small apartment on the periphery of Greenwich Village. Today she is the caretaker of a 40acre potato farm on the North Forkthe only woman in the area to live by herself in an 11room farmhouse with a coalburning range and no central heating, no nextdoor neighbors, no dog and no gun.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: First Order of Tending for Perennials
description: Spring is an ideal time to plant most perennials especially when tips of new growth are showing. Fall planting and dividing is what the books recommend, but in my own experience unless the work can be done in early September many plants are not sufficiently well established to withstand adverse winter weather conditions.

title: Beer, Not Drugs, Lures Students to Fort Lauderdale
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 26 (AP)Thousands of college students on semester break are beating a path to Florida. But this spring they are more interested in beer and the beach rather than drugs and demonstrations.

title: Dance: Musawwir Injects Sport
description: Musawwir has a promising idea attempting to combine gymnastics and dance but has yet to produce the repertory to justlfy it. The program of nine works presented Friday evening at the Walden School showed glimmers of accomplishment but no single sustained work of imagination.

title: Spring shape up guide
description: It happens every spring, that day when you step outside at noon, squint up at the hot sun, and consign your heavy coat and muffler to storage. As you walk, the sun caresses, easing away the knotty tensions of winter. Before long you're thinking ahead to such summer pleasures as playing tennis outdoors, cycling to the beach and swimming.

title: Some Answers for Pension Funds
description: The results of pension fund investment in North America during the last decade have been disappointing. A survey of 78 bank commingled equity funds showed that only 21 matched or bettered the Standard & Poor's 500stock index during the first half of the 1970's.

title: Pleasantville Theater
description: OLDTIMERS who have followed Pleasantville Music Theater through three decades raise an eyebrow when they hear that the troupe has taken to playing shows like Candide. For years Gilbert and Sullivan reigned supreme: now they have been nudged aside by Leonard Bernstein.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: PROPERLY INSTALLED, goodquality gutters and downspouts should last for many years with little or no maintenance, except for occasional cleaning. However, the past winter's heavy accumulations of snow and ice in this area, coupled with the fact that in many cases gutters tend to get clogged with leaves and other debris, make it advisable for the prudent homeowner to inspect his gutters as soon as possible to see if cleaning and/or repairing is necessary.

title: The Man Who Coached Rocky To Victory
description: Until recently, Frank Capra, who has won three Oscars for best director, complained that the movies were losing their ability to move people deeply. Now nearly 80, the man who specialized in such moving comedydramas as Mr. Deeds Goes to Town, Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, and It's a Wonderful Life, has been maintaining for a decade that the world is hungry for a lift, for quickening examples of how individuals overcome the dreads of their environment, while Hollywood is trying to feed it creephero stuff: glorifications of the minus people or apologies for the brute people. Gone the power of morality, of courage, of beauty, of the great love story.

title: THEATER
description: GEORGE M! the new offering at An Evening Dinner Theater, Elmsford, N.Y., strikes me as better and brighter than the Broadway production nine years ago. I think the reason in part is that the book, which seemed too lightweight for the solidity of a Broadway theater, fits in just fine with the nearnightclub atmosphere of the dinner theater. Furthermore, the dinner theater can only take minimal sets, and in this case that too is an aid to a book that is more an outline of George M. Cohan's life than anything else. All of what can look like skimpiness with the wrong show at a dinner theater turn into valuable plusses this time.

title: The world's first detective
description: He was famous in his day, and even Poe's M. Dupin accorded him some grudging respect: A good guesser and a persevering man. Francois Eugne Vidocq (17751857) has a legitimate claim to fame. Exconvict, womanizer, police spy, gourmet, friend of Hugo, Dumas, Sue, Gautier and other luminaries of intellectual Paris, master of disguise, moving as easily in the underworld as in the haut monde, he was a fabulous character. He was the world's first detective. He founded the Brigade de la Suret, he was the world's first private eye. Long before such matters were customary in police work, he was looking into fingerprinting, ballistics, blood tests and the use of science to fight criminals.

title: Copters Join Midtown Cacophony
description: George B. E. Hambleton was finishing lunch at the Copter Club on the 59th floor of the Pan Am building the other day when a huge shadow suddenly moved across the table. He leaned forward to look out the window and watched as a 30passenger helicopter gingerly took off from the Pan Am heliport, a few feet above the restaurant.

title: Julianna E. Roosevelt Is Bride Of Stephen MacD. Hargrove
description: Julianna Edwards Roosevelt, daughter of Mrs. Marion Hargrove of Santa Monica, Calif., and Curtis Roosevelt of New York, was married yesterday afternoon in Beverly Hills, Calif., to her stepbrother, Stephen MacDonell Hargrove. He is a son of Mr. Hargrove and of Mrs. Oliver Jensen of New York and Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: GARDENING
description: IT'S time once again for New Jersey's vegetable gardeners to sow seeds of tomatoes indoors. At least, according to the calendar it is.

title: Of Things To Come
description: One of the more endearing traits of modern science fiction is the tendency, in novels and short stories, to wrap things up with a bang rather than a whimper. The crudest planethopping adventure tale, the dullest exercise in straightline extrapolation, the thinnest speculative jape will suddenly blossom into apocalypse in the last few sentences  in which the earth is destroyed, or the hero achieves godlike powers or the secret of the universe (perhaps in the form of a fasterthanlight spaceship drive) is revealed. What makes these cosmic punchlines endearing, rather than offputting, is their deadpan manner of delivery. In most cases, the reader is obviously not expected to give any more credence to the final paragraph than the reader of fairy tales gives to the words And they lived happily ever after.

title: The Doctor With a Mission
description: DR. HERBERT G. CAVE settled back in a chair in his office, still wearing the green surgical gown and mask that is the uniform of the day on most Wednesdays at Harlem Hospital. After warning a visitor that he might be interrupted to return to surgery, he began to outline what he hoped to do as the new chairman of the board of the Westchester Community Opportunities Program.

title: Fantastic stories, fastidious poems
description: This collection of tales by Sylvia Townsend Warner is, to say the least, cause for celebration. Issued on the fiftieth anniversary of the publication of her novel Lolly Willowes, the first book ever chosen by the BookoftheMonth Club, it has all the freshness, wit, originality of perception and clarity of insight that have won for her rhythmical prose so many admirers over so long a time. It offers us an unforgettable journey through time and space, a cast of truly fantastic characters and an impressive and seemingly unending display of verbal fireworks.

title: New Book Traces
description: VOLUME I of The Minutes of Lawrence Township, which lists all of the official actions taken by the governing body of that Mercer County community from 1714 through 1869, is now available to New Jersey historians. The 181 pages of the minutes convey some of the spirit of the times, including how to deal with the poor (a problem still not solved) the value of horses to frontier families and the growth of the local power structure.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT MILWAUKEE

title: Ilene Maslow Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Maslow of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ilene Lois Maslow, to Alan Roy Kanton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kanton of Old Brookville, L.I. The wedding is planned for June. Miss Maslow is supervisor of emergency placements at St. Joseph Children's Services in Brooklyn.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: AVONWorkshops Saturday and Sunday, April 2 and 3. Farmington Valley Arts Center, Avon Park North. Soft sculpture, dyeing and design, grisaille and limoges techniques of enameling. Advance registration, 6781867. Fee, $40.

title: Hundreds of Mexican Children Cross Border to Engage in Crime
description: SAN DIEGO, March 26Maria is a slight, flashingeyed Mexican girl of 13, one of six children in a family struggling for survival in a dirtfloor shack in the slums of Tijuana, Mexico.

title: Now Here's the Way to Do It
description: IF YOU had told Joseph M. Margiotta four years ago that he would be watching an intramural battle for the 1977 Republican nomination for County Executive, he would have thought you were crazy. After all, the county's Republican chairman knew his party never had major primary fights. Not until now.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to the Cinque Terre, you can fly from the United States to Milan and then go by plane or rail to Genoa, which is an hour's train ride from the five villages. Renting a car is less advisable since only two roads into the area are completed, to Riomaggiore and Monterosso, and no roads connect the villages to each other. The train, however, does link each village in a matter of minutes. Write to the Italian Government Travel Office, 630 Fifth Avenue, New York 10020, for a list of rates of hotels, inns and pen sions. You can get American plan at most hotels. They aren't deluxe but the ambience hardly calls for gilt plate.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: NEW ORDERS FOR DURABLE GOODS failed to recover in February from the weatherinduced slowdown in January, the Commerce Department said. New factory orders totaled $55 billion in February, the same as in January and 4 percent under the December level. . . . The Carter Administration proposed an increase in the minimum wage from $2.30 an hour to $2.50. Labor was seeking $3. . . Corporate profits in the fourth quarter of 1976 rose $1.8 billion, or 2 percent, to an annual rate of $86.9 billion, the slowest increase in any quarter of last year.

title: Strong mother, weak father, damaged son
description: It is Dr. David Abrahamsen's not inconsiderable achievement in Nixon vs. Nixon: An Emotional Tragedy to make even as inveterate a Nixonhater as myself feel a measure of sympathy for the former President. Now that Richard Nixon is no longer a political menace (as was first said back in 1963) we can consider him as a human being, and the author argues persuasively that Nixon is one of the most screwedup people who ever lived.

title: Concert of Lenten Music
description: The West Side Madrigalists will give a concert next Sunday at 7:30 P.M., at the First Unitarian Church, 50 Monroe Place, Brooklyn Heights. The concert, Lenten Music of the Renaissance, will feature the premiere of Jesus Wept, a sacred cantata for voices and tape by David Earnest with text by Tray Christopher.

title: Marriages Of Convenience
description: PARISEuropean politics rely increasingly on that oldfashioned institution, the marriage of convenience. A marriage of convenience, in personal life, implies one based not upon romance but on common interest. On the whole, it seems to work out quite well, and many successful and even happy families have thrived on this entirely unsentimental basis.

title: Gen. Brown Quoted As Hinting Congress Impedes the Military
description: WASHINGTON, March 26, (AP)Gen. George S. Brown, in a topsecret lecture to highranking military and Government personnel, labeled Congress as meddlesome and irresponsible in its dealings with defense and foreign aid.

title: Laurie Bernstein, Student, Bride of Steven D. Friedel
description: Laurie Jo Bernstein, daughter of Elaine Bernstein of Astoria, Queens, and the late Gerald Bernstein, was married yesterday evening to Steven David Friedel, vice president of the David Allison Company in Woodbury, L. I. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey performed the ceremony in Temple BethEl in Great Neck. L. I.

title: Environmental Study Is Growing Up
description: Johnny Appleseed would have been pleased: Environmental education is on the boom. Across the United States, In thousands of projects and courses that feature everything from hayrides and songfests to emotional discussions of air pollution and oil spills, American schoolchildren and their teachers are being educated in the eternal verities of nature, as well as the equally eternal profligacy of man.

title: Notes: The Dangers Of Forbidden Fruit
description: A salami from Italy or a mango from Mexicoon the face of it, the perfect tourist souvenirs. In fact, they are among the foreign objects American travelers are forbidden to bring back home, the food and plants that the United States Department of Agriculture warns are dangerous to the nation's health. The salami may carry the virus of cattle footandmouth disease, and the mango may be harboring an insect pest.

title: The Barnyard Set
description: MIAMI, March 26Threeyearold Seattle Slew presented his credentials today as 16yearold Steve Cauthen's rival for leadership of barnyard society's youth movement. The occasion was the 48th Flamingo Stakes, the gaudy pink showcase of the Hialeah meeting which is, traditionally, Florida's prime test for horses with de signs on the racing Triple Crown. Seattie Slew went to the post as the Flamingo favorite and also as the colt considered most likely to succeed in the Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Belmont Stakes. This is an unusual role for a horse with only four races behind him, but as a 2yearold last fall and in his only start at 3, Seattle Slew had given the impression that he was an unusual horse.

title: Susan Mills Is Bride Of Richard Feenstra
description: Susan Rhoda Mills daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ivor M. Mills of Gloversville. N.Y. was married yesterday evening to Richard Allen Feenstra, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Feenstra of Pine Brook, N.J. The ceremony was performed by State Supreme Court Justice Hortense Gabel at the Cornell Club in New York.

title: 2 Players Sue Bridge League; Coercion Cited
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 26The victory of a team with two New York stars in the Vanderbilt knockout team championship yesterday at the American Coutract Bridge League's Spring Nationals was overshadowed by a remarkable place of news: Suit has been filed in Los Angeles against the League and others by the two players who withdrew from the Internation Team Trials in Houston two months ago in mysterious circumstances.

title: Value of Constitutional Revisions Discussed at Albany Conference
description: ALBANY, March 26A conference called by civic groups this week to explore the advisability of revising the New York State Constitution turned into a bittersweet postmortem of the last such effortthe illfated 1967 Constitutional Convention, which lasted six months only, to have its sweeping revisions rejected by the voters.

title: Parra Dancers Offer the Flamenco
description: The Mariano Parra Spanish Dance Company, wellknown in New York, presented a program that concentrated on flamenco Friday night at the Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street.

title: Flood Controls
description: EVERY time that New Jersey's rivers and streams overflow their banks, people say that the state and Federal governments should do something about preventing the millions of dollars in flood damage that occurs each year. But now that the two governments are acting, a lot cf people aren't sure they like it.

title: Taking Aim at Hospital Costs
description: WITH A LITTLE help from the Social Security Administration, the Connecticut Commission on Hospitals and Health Care is conducting a oneyear pilot project that is aimed at reducing soaring costs in the state's 35 acutecare hospitals.

title: Music: Mahler Third by Mehta
description: There has been more than enough Mahler in New York this season, but that did not prevent the Los Angeles Philharmonic's performance of the composer's Third Symphony in Carnegie Hall on Friday night from being welcome. Zubin Mehta, the orchestra's conductor, is admired and popular in New York, and he has become a figure of double interest because he is to take over direction of the New York Philharmonic in the fall of next year.

title: Brewster and Yale's Fortunes
description: TOMORROW Yale's 12,000 students and faculty members are to return to campus in full force after a spring break, and it will be a time for some sort of reckoning by the leaders of the university. For more than a week now, since publication of reports from Congressional sources that Yale's president is to be the next ambassador to Great Britain, Kingman Brewster has barricaded himself from the press, refusing all interviews. Without the official announcement from the White House, rumors and confidential conversations were left to flourish last week among the few who remained here through the recess.

title: Cornelia McLoughlin Wed to Stephen Post, Indian Institute Aide
description: The Episcopal Church of the Epiphany in Southbury, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Cornelia Whitehouse McLoughlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Comerford Whitehouse McLoughlin of Southbury, to Stephen Edward Post, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald John Post Jr. of Middlebury, Conn.

title: Common Market Agrees on Position for World Talks
description: ROME, March 26The leaders of the Common Market nations agreed today on a basic position from which to open negotiations with developing countries on stabilizing the prices of raw materials and aiding the world's poorest nations.

title: Briarcliff Faces Hour of Decision
description: BRIARCLIFF COLLEGE has been very generous, Edward Mortola, the president of Pace University, said one day last week, with the aispute over the 75yearold women's college still unsettled. He was referring to the facultystudent ratio and the small classes at the school.

title: Symphony Moves Ahead on High Note
description: THE New Jersey Symphony, which has yet to choose a conductor to replace Henry Lewis, who left after the conclusion of last season, is nevertheless moving ahead with ambitious plans for new ventures.

title: Notre Dame's Rockne: A Monumental Hero In Age of Heroes
description: There was a special magic in Knute Kenneth Rockne, and a kindred magic in his name. Inevitably, certain questions are posed. Did he become a living legend because of the checkered trappings of the fabled 1920's? Was Knute Rockne a product of his times or did he help make the times? Perhaps a little of both?

title: Frig, Gassoff Suspended In N.H.L. Brawls
description: MONTREAL, March 26 (AP)  Len Frig of the Cleveland Barons has been suspended for three games and Bob Gassoff of the St. Louis Blues has been suspended for two. Clarence Campbell, the National Hockey League president, said today, Frig was assessed game and gross misconduct penalties last night in a game in Cleveland against the Vancouver Canucks. The Barons were also hit with an automatic $1,000 fine. Gassoff was assessed a match penalty for deliberately attempting to injure an opponent during a game in New York on March 20 against the Rangers. A statement from the NHL said Gassoff swung his stick at the head of Carol Vadnais, a Ranger defenseman, who was not hit.

title: The Nation
description: President Carter has proposed several important changes in the method of electing Presidents and members of Congress. Most of the proposals, which have varying prospects of being enacted, seek to increase citizens participation in Federal elections as voters, party workers and candidates.

title: Pamela Wiggin Fiancee of Jon Hazelton Barry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rollin Henry Wiggin Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Blue Hill, Me., have announced the engagement of Mr. Wiggin's daughter, Pamela Keller Wiggin, to Jon Hazelton Barry, son of Mrs. William F. Burrow of Dallas, and the late E. Richard Barry Jr. Plans have been made for a June wedding in Darien.

title: POLITICS
description: WITH some obvious concern, the men and women who were elected by the people of Connecticut to make laws for them are looking again at a proposed constitutional amendment that would put lawmaking powers back in the hands of the people.

title: Miss Barker Reaches Final With Chris Evert
description: Sue Barker almost went to college for cooking, loves Mexican food, digs the Electric Light Orchestra and still calls her coach Mister.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BRONXVILLECatherine Rowe, soprano and Jean Wentworth, pianist, will discuss and perform songs by Debussy. Tuesday at 6:30 P.M. Marshall Field Hall, Sarah Lawrence College. Free. 3370700.

title: Miss Reeves Bride in South
description: Margaret Mallory Reeves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edgar Graham Reeves of Georgetown, S.C., was married yesterday to Andrew Simonds Drury Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Drury of Charleston, S.C.

title: The Millions Judge
description: Democracy in India, so endangered by months of autocratic government under emergency decrees imposed by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, endures: She and her Congress Party have been decisively beaten in a general election. India's 600 million people will now be governed by Moraji R. Desai and the Janata Party, a coalition, its leaders like to say, born in the prison cells where Mrs. Gandhi's regime had consigned them.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: THE continental shelf, with all its problems and potentialities as a major new source of oil off the northeast coast, apparently is coming off the Congressional shelf at long last. Legislation seems to be at hand that would have a big effect on New Jersey and other coastal states.

title: School Is Wherever Their Yellow Bus Takes Them
description: TUCSON, March 26They sat or sprawled on Jim Griffith's various sofas and his redtile living room floor, listen ing intently as Mr. Griffith strummed a banjo and sang folk songs.

title: FOOD
description: FOR nine years Werner's Pork Store at 359 Willett Avenue in Port Chester (a village best known for Italian food products) has been like a knoedel afloat in marinara sauce. My customers come from all over Westchester and Connecticut, they know quality and they know where I am, said Werner Heinemann, a heavyset man who originally came from Leipzig.

title: City U.'s Beckoning Hand
description: LAST year, for the first time, the City University of New York was forced by the city's ballooning financial problems to charge tuition for city residents as well as for students coming from outside the city.

title: Preparing for 'Lear' With 'Romeo'
description: CENTERPORT MOSES GOLDBERG thinks there's more to theater for children than meets the eye and ear tuned into puppet shows and musical fairy tales. He sees theater for the young as a means of fostering esthetic development, of developing an arts tradition that becomes another way of knowing our universe.

title: Criminals At Large
description: With the passing of Agatha Christie, reads the jacket copy of Ngaio Marsh's new book, LAST DITCH (Little, Brown, $8.95), Dame Ngaio Marsh stands as the undisputed doyenne of mystery writers. No argument here. Dame Ngaio has been writing traditional mysteries since 1932, and her first Roderick Alleyn book came out in 1934. Now over 75 years old, she has maintained a very high standard. Indeed, she writes better than Christie ever did: she is more civilized, knows something about the arts, and her characterizations have much more life than Christie's cardboard figures ever did.

title: How terrible everything is
description: It used to be called muckraking. More recently the term investigative journalism has taken hold. Whatever it's called, it is undergoing a major reflowering. Apparently there is a real audience out there. Americans like to hear the worst, perhaps because they have tried so hard to believe the best.

title: Life in Cities of Pakistan Slowed By Protest Strike Over Elections
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 26While the deputies elected in the suspect voting of March 7 were sworn in today in Islamabad, urban life throughout Pakistan was seriously slowed by a nationwide protest strike.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: Indispensable Rope: Yachtsman's Friend
description: From the moment that earliest man used pieces of animal hide, vines, or lengths of natural fibers to bundle animal skins or drag his dinner home, rope became one of the necessities for survival. No one really knows exactly when man learned to twist tying materials together, but the art of making rope has been passed down from generation to generation over thousands of years.

title: Smithtown Legends
description: In the early 17th century, the area around the Nissequogue River was the hunting ground of the Montauks, a tribe led by Chief Wyandanch. On a night when Wyandanch's daughter was to be married, the Narragansetts, from the Connecticut side of the Sound, fell upon Wyandanch's village and made off with the young woman. Lion Gardiner, reputedly the first white man to settle in the East End, interceded and paid the invaders a ransom for the chief's daughter. Gratefully, Wyandanch deeded Gardiner the land along the Nissequogue.

title: Bard College Applicants Get SameDay Yes or No Answers
description: ANNANDALE  ON  HUDSON, N.Y., March 26Bard College today began an innovative immediate  decision plan, in which high school seniors received a personal, onthespot rejection or admission to the liberalarts college next fall after a daylong ??valuation.

title: Jane Edwards Fiancee Of Gordon Walker Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Owen Spenser Edwards of London have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Spenser Edwards, to Gordon B. M. Walker Jr. of Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walker of Greenwich, Conn., where the wedding will take place May 21.

title: Donato N. Gabbai Weds Lauray Furie
description: Deborah Ann Furie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Furie of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Donato N. Gabbai of Paris, where he is with the European marketing agents of the Standard Fruit Company

title: Political Science
description: The following article is part of a series of reports on the state of the academic disciplines. The series, to be pubished to The Week. in Review, will discuss in each case the outstanding debates and current questions to which the academic disciplines are addressing themselves.

title: Should Guruism Grounds for Dismissal?
description: Every work day all over the country from an office on the 54th floor of the World Trade center, with its commanding view of the city, to a starkly furnished room on a sleepy street at the edge of Seattlebosses and dismissed workers reenact the situations that led to a parting of the ways.

title: British Skipper Is Held by F.B.I. In California in Theft of Yachts
description: LOS ANGELES, March 26 (UPI)A Brtish sea captain was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday on charges of stealing sailing yachts in Canada and California and escaping from Federal custody in North Carolina.

title: Music in Review
description: In his New York City Opera debut as Don Jose in Carmen last Sunday, afternoon, Moises Parker revealed a pleasant lyric tenor, but little knowedge of what to do with it. Through unforced and on pitch, his singing was consistently bland, and at times inelegant for its carelessly abbreviated phraseendings. He is also a most uncomfortable actor.

title: SPOT CHECK ORDERED. IN SCHOOL TEST LEAK
description: The exposure of many students to next Tuesday's citywide reading test occurred despite elaborate security measures and a second examination will have to be given at randomly selected schools in May to gauge the extent of the leak, according to Anthony J. Polemeni, who heads the Board of Education's testing office.

title: Borg Puts Gorman Out By 76, 75
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., March 26Bjorn Borg reached the semifinals of the $100,000 La Costa international tennis tournament today, but was not sure how he had got there.

title: Young Defends His Candor as Head of Delegation at U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  Two months after taking charge of the United States Mission to the United Nations, Andrew Young is convinced that he has carved out an influential role in shaping foreign policy and that the criticisms leveled against him are the results of his bluntness, his honesty, and his refusal to voice kneejerk diplomatic opinions.

title: The Savage World Of Rainer Werner Fassbinder
description: Rainer Werner Fassbinder lounged aggressively on a genteel English chair at the Algonquin, his black, blunttoed shoes desecrating a neighboring couch. The young West German film director, screenwriter and actor was briefly in New York to relish what is turning out to be the year of the Fassbinder breakthrough. He also was on hand to explain himself to a newly acquired American public not yet wholly in his pocket.

title: GARDENING
description: AHOME without a lawn is difficult to envision, and with reason. Not every landscape is suited to the naturalistic concept, which discourages artificial development of home grounds through the use of native plants or replacement of, duds with more attractive species. And for houses where there is a lot of foot traffic, lawn playing and outdoor activity a lawn is preferable. Property owners with homes under construction have a better opportunity to go all out for the natural plan.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: THEATER

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: As a parent of three children who graduated from the Waldorf School, I was delighted to see the recognition you gave this unusual school [A Rapport With What Is Studied, Jan. 23].

title: U.S. IS SUING LEGISLATOR TO GET $50,000 RETURNED
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)The Federal Government is suing former Representative James F. Hastings, upstate New York Republican, to recover about $50,000 the former Congressman was convicted of receiving in kickpacks from employees.

title: An Extinct Dinosaur Park?
description: GOVERNOR Grasso has designated March as Dinosaur Month, but people who want to visit Dinosaur State Park in Rocky Hill to see the worldrenowned dinosaur tracks there had better not plan on doing it this monthor any time in the near future.

title: Knicks Are Overtaken by Bullets, 9892
description: The Knicks started their smallchange team last night, with their big money forced to stay on the bench.

title: Ox Ridge Show Given Extra Day This Year
description: The Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show one of the leading outdoor events in the Eastwill be lengthened from five days to six this year.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Muslim gunman who took four hostages for five hours was held without bail yesterday for psychiatric examination when he was arraigned on charges of kidnapping and possession. of a dangerous weapon. The gunmanLuquam AbdushShahid, who held his hostages captive in the ninthfloor offices of the Housing and Development Administration at 100 Gold Street near City Hall on Fridaystood in silence during the proceeding in Criminal Court. Judge Daniel Weiss set April 25 for a hearing.

title: Deaths
description: ALPERTFannie, beloved wife of the lale Adolph, mother of Mildred Reuben, Rena Cohen and the late Edith Steinberg, grandmother and greatgrandmother. Services Monday, March 28, 9:45 A.M., at The Riverside. 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Chicago Shipping Season Opens
description: CHICAGO, March 26 (AP)Chicago's 1977 shipping season on the Great Lakes opened yesterday when a ship carrying taconite pellets from Minnesota arrived at the South Works of the United States Steel Corporation.

title: If You Go...
description: . . . on the Black Heritage Trail, a free brochure that serves as an informative and illustrative guide can be obtained from the Museum of AfroAmerican History at 719 Tremont Street, Boston, Mass. Arrangements may be made to have a museum staff member guide groups numbering up to 20 on a tour lasting about twoandahalf hours; the fee is $35. Individuals may get permission to join such groups by telephoning 6174457400. The museum is open every day except Saturday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is 50 cents for adults, 25 cents for children.

title: Card of Thanks
description: GRODINDr. Thomas M. We, EnidBarton and Nanci Fox, in behalf of our immediate family, would like to thank everyone for their warm expressions of sympathy during our time of bereavement.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: PROPERLY INSTALLED, goodquality gutters and downspouts should last for many years with little or no maintenance, except for occasional cleaning. However, the past winter's heavy accumulations of snow and ice in this area, coupled with the fact that in many cases gutters tend to get clogged with leaves and other debris, make it advisable for the prudent homeowner to inspect his gutters as soon as possible to see if cleaning and/or repairing is necessary.

title: City Council Units Set Hearings for the Week
description: The following public hearings will be held this week by City Council committees:

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayThe Hill, Route 124. North Salem. N.Y. Green, amateurowner, local, junior and children's working hunters; open jumpers, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: DID you ever have an old friend drop out of sight?

title: LETTER FROM WESLEYAN
description: ALTHOUGH I've been around for 18 years before this one and don't think I've been sheltered from the world in any way, it shocked me when I first realized what so many of my dorm mates were doing on those nights they were away from our dormitory. It doesn't shock me anymore, but it disturbs and saddens me to think about it.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Inflation anxieties and the possibility of higher interest rates sent the stock market down sharply last week in slower trading. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 32.16 points during the week to finish at 928.86 on Friday. This decline was the largest since the week ended Dec. 5, 1975, when the Dow fell 41.87 points.

title: IN AMERICA
description: CHICAGO. Bitter winds are whistling outside, the truck depots, railway sidings and deserted streets of the 25th Ward. Even by Chicago's standards, its a vicious night, but valorous Hymie Schmidt, the sheriff's bailiff, is there and so are other paladins and precinct captains of the Southwest Side. There's Eddie Press, the bridge tender: Casey Knapczyk, who hoists rocks for the Department et Streets and Sanitation: young Jimmy Pegwizd, a bailiff too, in the chambers of a circuit court judge, and Matt Ropa, a longtime office holder who has come to rest on the Cook County Board of Commissionersloyal vassals all of Alderman Vito Marzullo, a knight himself at the Round Table of Richard J. Daley, whose realm is now berett, bereaved and for grabs.

title: TV's MiniSeriesRefreshing Change, or Just Less of the Same?
description: Until very recently, the viewing habits of much of the television audience rested on the predictable, comfortable presence of the weekly series with its more or less selfcontained plots. The pattern was interrupted only by occasional specials. Now, however, a new form of programming called the miniseries is corning upon the home screen with a vengeance.

title: Amin Charges Christian Churches Are Used by C.I.A. for Subversion
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 26 (AP)President Idi Amin of Uganda accused the United States Central Intelligence Agency today of using Christian denominations as a cover for subversion and said he would bar all foreign aid to churches in his country.

title: Nine steps to fiscal solvency
description: We care. Except for an occasional mossback, holed up in a statehouse or a newspaper office, wethe people who do not live in New York really care what happens to the city. As a former New Yorker, I might be taken as a special case, but it is almost 20 years since I moved to Pennsylvania, and I identify with the outlanders, even those who know New York only from old Rosalind Russell movies on television. Our impatience with the city's financial woes grows out of our distrust of impracticality. It is not simply that the city officials sound a lot like the woman who lives down the block, the one who says she is being beggared by the high cost of living and then goes off to a reducing salon. It is the instinctive turn to the bankers that worries us, for the best that they have to offer is conventional economic wisdom. Let me make a few money  raising suggestions that would seem simple common sense to the girls' clubs in Easton, Md., or Jaycees in Connersville, Ind., or the volunteer firemen in Brandon, Fla.

title: Europe was the ideal
description: Historians are constantly tempted to paint the portrait of an age, to give as complete a picture as possible of all aspects, of social and cultural life in the hope of catching the spirit of a particular moment in history. Europe in the years before 1914 seems at first sight to lend itself very well to this kind of broad treatment. This is partly because we now have the subjective impression that there was a last, opulent, liberal golden agela belle epoquebefore the catastrophe of World War I, and partly because there actually were some features shared by most European countries that made it possible to talk of a common European experience. Above all, it was the last moment at which Europe's predominance in the world was uncontested, and European culture and technological achievements seemed the natural goal of other societies.

title: RALYN M. HILL
description: ABILENE, Kan., March 26 (AP)Ralyn M. Hill, one of only 124 men to win the Congressional Medal of Honor, the nation's highest award for bravery, in World War I, died today at his home here. Mr. Hill, who was 77 years old, received the award for rescuing a French pilot shot down between American and German lines in France in October 1918. He is survived by his widow, three daughters, 10 grandchildren and eight great grandchildren.

title: The CarterCongress. Rift May Just Have Started
description: WASHINGTONAt the height of the Congressional uproar over President Carter's decision to reconsider a number of water control projects, Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland was asked whether the White House consulted him before announcing the review. As a former Representative who may know more than any other top Administration official about the fury of a legislator barred from the pork barrel, Mr. Bergland could well have warned the President of the impending storm. But Mr. Bergland said he was not consulted: he learned of it from the news and was surprised, like almost everyone else.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Performance of Schools In Briarcliff Defended

title: Moscow Shows Caution Concerning Prospects Of Vance Negotiations
description: MOSCOW, March 26The Soviet Union has expressed a cautious attitude about the prospects of the visit by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

title: To Live Next to a Golf Course Is a Pretty Fair Way to Live
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ritzma Perry sometimes worry that a golf ball will careen through the hedge into their garden, and that occasionally happens.

title: Delta State Takes Third Women's Title
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 26 (AP)Delta State captured its third straight Association of Intercollegiate Athletics for Women basketball championship today with a 6855 victory over Louisiana State.

title: Engagements
description: OkunDeitz

title: No rules for Napoleon
description: Military victory has inspired the strategists, historians and biographers to a far greater extent than defeat. To understand why this should be so, one hardly needs the expertise of the professional students of the human psyche. But the causes of defeat are an important subject, and it is for this reason that an investigation into the psychology of military incompetence is welcome. Norman Dixon seems uniquely qualified to cope with this assignment; he was an officer in the British Regular Army for 10 years (nine of which were in bomb disposal) and is now a reader in psychology at the University of London.

title: ART VIEW
description: Alittle more than four months have passed since the stunning proposal to establish a new branch of the Annenberg School of Communications at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was first announced. It was on Nov. 10, 1976, that the first official word about the project was made public, with the news that Walter H. Annenberg, president of Triangle Publications Inc. and a relative newcomer to the museum's councils (he has been a trustee since 1974), had pledged the sum of $20 million for the creation of this communications center at the Met, and that Thomas Hoving would become its director upon his retirement from the directorship of the museum at the end of 1977. Subsequently, it was reported that an additional $20 million had been promised by Mr. Annenberg to cover the cost of the center's operation for a 10year period.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: PROPERLY INSTALLED, goodquality gutters and downspouts should last for many years with little or no maintenance, except for occasional cleaning. However, the past winter's heavy accumulations of snow and ice in this area, coupled with the fact that in many cases gutters tend to get clogged with leaves and other debris, make it advisable for the prudent homeowner to inspect his gutters as soon as possible to see if cleaning and/or repairing is necessary.

title: The Special Victim Is Not New In the Law
description: Whatever the outcome of the debate in the New York Legislature over bills mandating prison terms for those who assault the elderly, the underlying concept reflects a national trend to enact special victim legislation that makes the severity of punishment for violent crimes turn on the characteristics of the victim. A new component has thus been added to the old debate over whether the punishment should fit the crime or the criminal: Now it is also being asked whether the punishment should fit the victim.

title: Compensation Plan a Pandora's Box At Annual Meeting of N.F.L. Owners
description: Do the Washington Redskins owe the New York Jets something because the Redskins acquired last year the Jets' former fullback who had became a free agent, John Riggins? Do the Giants owe the Miami Dolphins something because they acquired Larry Czonka. the fullback who left the Dolphins to play in the late World Football League in 1975? If there is a debt, how are the Redskins going to pay it through draft choices they have traded away all their significant draft selections?

title: Nadia Comaneci Performs First Time This Year
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 26 (AP)Nadia Comaneci, the Rumanian gymnastics star, made her first public appearance of the year last week. She looked fit and made a good impression. but she has put on some weight and grown taller since last year.

title: HighPower Arms Debated by Police
description: THE state police are quietly attempting to persuade local police departments throughout New Jersey to use a standard weapon, preferably the .38caliber revolver issued to state troopers.

title: Homosexual Leaders Meet at White House With Presidential Aide to Discuss Discrimination in Federal Law
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)Leaders of the homosexual rights movement met with a Presidential aide at the White House today to lobby for an end to discrimination against homosexuals in Federal law.

title: Katherine Ivey, P. C. Ward 3d Wed in South
description: Katherine Campbell Ivey and Peirce Colton Ward 3d were married yesterday at the Myers Park Presbyterian Church in Charlotte, N.C., by the Rev. J. Randolph Taylor.

title: To Say Productivity
description: A new debate over a productivity plan for municipal workers put forward by their unions and New York City has once again raised basic questions of what productivity is and how It can be measured in service industries such as government.

title: Do We Really Have So Much to Learn From British TV?
description: Is British television really as good as we've heard? Is Upstairs, Downstairs the typical product of a superior system? Is it true as some American television critics keep telling usthat British television sets the standard we should try to meet?

title: Jazz: George Lewis, Trombonist
description: The trombone, which was an important solo and ensemble instrument in jazz from the music's beginnings, has played a curiously lowkeyed role sice the early 1960's. Roswell Rudd, Grachan Moncur 3d and a few other players made important contributions, but the most spectacular new trombone technicians  Albert Mangelsdorf, Paul Rutherford  were European jazzmen who seemed to stand somewhere outside the main stream of jazz tradition.

title: Eden Estate Valued at $140,500
description: LONDON, March 25 (AP)Former Prime Minister Anthony Eden left an estate after taxes valued at $140,500, according to his will made public today. Mr. Eden, the Earl of Avon, who died on Jan. 14 at the age of 79, left the bulk of his estate to his widow, Clarissa, a niece of Sir Winston Churchill. He was also survived by a son by his first marriage who succeeded to his title.

title: Chamber's View
description: WASHINGTONAs the chief economist of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, Jack W. Carison is required to express opinions on many subjects. Here, in a recent interview, is his response on a topic of absorbing interest to businessmen the minimum wage:

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Once it was a quiet Pacific fishing zone between Iwo Jima and Pajaros Island in the Marianas. In 1974 a Japanese fishing crew noticed an unexplained rise in the sea bottom at one point. Americans found another such spot in 1975. Evidence of undersea volcanos began to multiply after that.

title: The S.R.O. Blight: What's to Blame?
description: It was the last day in the life of the Van Cortlandt Residence Club, a sixstory welfare hotel at 599 West 113th Street. Someone was boarding up the firstfloor windows with old doors while the last tenantsa few squatters, a prostitute and a dogkept warm upstairs.

title: Don King's Bouts Shift To Texas
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 26 (AP) Hangar No. 40 at Randolph Air Force Base is the next stop for the United States boxing championships, which have included quarterfinal matches on an aircraft carrier, the Naval Academy and the Marion Correctional Institute, where Don King, the promoter, served time for manslaughter.

title: Cormorant Scores at Big A For 6th Straight Triumph
description: At the top of the stretch, Danny Wright knew there was nothing to worry about yesterday at Aqueduct But minutes after winning the $54,000 Bay Shore Stakes aboard Charles T. Berry's Cormorant, the jockey saw plenty to Worry about.

title: The Pattern For Dressmakers
description: THE proverbial little dressmaker is still in business. Just how much business, no one knows. But the homey, fabricstrewn shopit leans these days to a renovated family room in a suburban split is still intact, and the completed ordersthey run to tennis dresses and wrapstyle jerseysstill hang on a single rack.

title: Bikes NowPolo Ponies Then
description: IN 1654, three realestate speculators from Oyster Bay conned the Matinecock Indians out of the 3,000acre peninsula on Long Island Sound they called Caumsett (Place of Sharp Rock), now known as Lloyd Neck, in exchange for three coats, three shirts, eight knives, three hatchets, three hoes, two pairs of shoes and stockings, and 12 feet of wampum.

title: The Film Giant With No Studio
