description: LOS ANGELESWhen Hollywood passes out its Oscars tomorrow night, three of the movies vying for Best Picture of the Year will be from one sourcea movie company that has never owned a studio. It has 29 Academy Award nominations, more than any other company, and it grossed $229.5 million by renting films last year, more than any other company. The United Artists Corporation, a subsidiary of the Transamerica Corporation, is riding high these days.

title: FOOD
description: THE 25 guests who will gather for Passover seder at the Plainview home of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Dorfman will be served a wellrehearsed dinner. Judy Dorfman has been practicing her recipes for weeks in connection with the Passover cooking class she has been teaching at Kitchen Time in Plainview.

title: Medical Newsletter Says Many Doctors Opposed Flu Shots
description: The New York County Medical Society, calling the Federal swine influenza immunization program a gag, said that although most of its members opposed the campaign they had not publicly criticized it because of concern about adverse publicity.

title: Flocking to the Birds' Rescue
description: ON Fire Island now, four swans are performing their immemorial courtship rites because in January, when they were starving, Helen Krolikowski of Saltaire phoned in an SOS and a hunter crossed the frozen bay to bring cracked corn. A Dix Hills feeder kept the home fires burning for a thrasher, a cinnamoncolored songbird that failed to migrate with its kind last fall. On the bays, dabbling teal take their natural food after a month of corn and crackers.

title: New feminine talents, new feminine concerns
description: It seems clear by now that the good news of the 1970's in literature is the emergence of a company of highly talented women writers. Margaret Drabble, Gail Godwin, Julia O'Faolain, Ann Beattie, Diane Johnson, Margaret Atwood, Joyce Carol Oatesthe list could go on much longerare just a few of the serious fiction writers who have largely taken over the former men's club. In the Looking Glass is an anthology of stories that show women examining and interpreting the lineaments of Prize Stories 1977: The O. Henry Awards is dominated (by a margin of ten to eight) by women, and The Sea Birds Are Still Alive is a collection by a black woman writer of increasing reputation. Taken together, the three books offer a fairly good scan of new talents and new feminine concerns.

title: Wisconsin Tops Michigan Six in N.C.A.A. Final
description: DETROIT, March 26 (AP)Wisconsin captured the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey championship tonight with a 65 overtime victory over Michigan.

title: SHOP TALK
description: IN THE RECENT bitter winter, commuting men in towns such as New Canaan and Darien found that the icy winds whipping around their unprotected heads as they waited for the 7:40 to Manhattan made them think about buying a hat. For many, it was the first time in their lives such an idea had occurred to them, unless one counts ski caps or tennis hats, and they weren't ready to settle for a Brooks Brothers fedora.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: Podgorny Receives A Cordial Reception In Zambian Capital
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 26Zambia, a country that has had significant disagreements with the Soviet Union over southern Africa, gave Nikolai V. Podgorny a cordial reception today as the Soviet President arrived on the middle stop of his threenation African tour.

title: Court Allows Sale Of WaldorfAstoria To the Hilton Chain
description: The sale of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel to the Hilton Hotels Corporation for $35 million has been approved by a Federal court in Philadelphia that is supervising the reorganization of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company.

title: C. A. Fisher Plans to Wed Missy Edson
description: Mary Amizetta Edson, daughter of Mrs. Edward G. Edson Jr. of Beaumont, Tex., and the late Mr. Edson, and Christopher Alan Fisher plan to be married on May 14 in St. John's Episcopal Cathedral in Denver. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the prospective bride's mother.

title: Grant Renews Criticism of Mets' Stars
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26Mr. Donald Grant, the board chairman of the New York Mets, addressed himself tonight to some of his team's problemsDave Wingman, Tom Seaver and the arrest this morning of Joe McDonald, the Mets' general manager.

title: Realty News
description: Despite widespread distress in the city's real estate market, foreign investors are showing great confidence in its resilience.

title: CARTER WINS APPROVAL OF 70% IN GALLUP POLL
description: Seventy percent of the American people continue to approve of the way President Carter has been doing his job, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Chart of Hialeah's Flamingo
description: 1977, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Growing Up in Smoke
description: IN the vestibule of the Bronxville High School cafeteria, a 16yearold Bronxville Broncos cheerleader took a long strong drag on a cigarette, blew out a mess of smoke, tugged at her jacket until it covered the big B and buckingbronco emblem on her uniform, crossed her feet until her brown and white saddle shoes cuddled each other, and giggled. We're not supposed to smoke in uniform, she said. It's a school rule; it's the school reputation. And if we do, we're supposed to cover up the emblem. We're not supposed to let a teacher see us smoke in uniform and we're not supposed to smoke during a game.

title: Watching Winter Back Off
description: Few of us can outguess the weather, but the seasons have markers that are hard to ignore and it is a safe bet that the worst of winter is past.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: The World
description: The Soviet Union and Cuba, having collaborated successfully in Angola, are intensifying a drive to consolidate their influence in the black states bordering whiteruled southern Africa and in the continent's eastern horn. Given the instability of many of their clients, their success is by no means assured, but the lack of a comprehensive new Western policy in Africa has given them a new diplomatic momentum.

title: POLITICS
description: As the state budget negotiations creep toward the Thursday deadline for passage, the ability of suburban and upstate Democrats within the Assembly majority to influence the outcome will be tested.

title: Feminine to feminist to female
description: Feminists keep announcing that we need rew versions of the past; Elaine Showalter's provocative chapter of literary history shows what they mean and how right they ere. Based on an impressive range of scholarship (the bibliography and the 213 chronologically arranged capsule biographies of British women writers born after 1800 would alone justify the book: but the book offers much more), carefully organi??ed, thoughtfully argued, A Literature of Their Own places the women novelists everyone has heard ofthe Bronts, George Eliot, Virginia Woolf, Doris Lessingin a new setting, considering them in relation to their relatively unknown female contemporaries. The resulting shift of perspective generates fresh social and literary understanding. Showalter adopts a schematic developmental sequence, feminine to feminist to female, but she treats it as convenience rather than dogma. Moreover, she employs her key terms with great flexibility

title: Murder Charged in 5 Fire Deaths
description: DES MOINES, March 26 (UPI) The Polk County grand jury has indicted a Des Moines man on five counts of firstdegree murder in connection with an apartment house fire in which five persons died last month. The indictment returned yesterday named Ronald Veveyka, 42 years old, who was a resident of the Coronado Apartments that burned.

title: Bearcat Coach Wins in Poll
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 26 (AP)Gale Catlett, coach at the University of Cincinnati, has been named the 1977 Ohio college basketball coach of the year. The 36yearold Catlett was selected in a poll by The Columbus Dispatch. Forty basketball coaches throughout the state participated.

title: Fast Servers Should Crank Up Arms
description: Tenhis players, start cranking up your, arms because the national fastserve contest is on hand. If you think you have a boomer, flaunt it.

title: W. G. B. Hill Will Marry Miss Bocci
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Bocci of Buenos Aires have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Bocci, to W. Graham Bowdoin Hill, son of Robert C. Hill, Ambassador to Argentina, and Mrs. Hill of Buenos Aires.

title: Divorced Catholics Attend Conference To Discuss Status
description: Marianne did not attend Sunday mass for nearly two years after her divorce because she assumed the end of her marriage meant the end of her life as a Roman Catholic.

title: Scholars and Dollars
description: A CHANGE of major proportions is at hand at colleges and universities throughout the nation. The consumer age has come to higher education. This age brings with it an awareness of the high price of a traditional liberal arts education and the value of that degree in the shrinking job market.

title: Dead Heat for First Doubles Fan's Pleasure
description: WESTBURY, L.I., March 26Daily double players at Roosevelt Raceway got a break tonight. There were twice as many winners as usual. A dead heat in the second race between Keven Scott and Touch N Bye produced a pair of winning daily double numbers in 12 and 16.

title: Catherine The Great
description: Judged by the standards of Russian history, Catherine II was a great monarch, arguably the best that Russia aver had; judged by any other standard, she was one of the most remarkable women on record. To appreciate both her historic accomplishments and her personality, it is imperative to disabuse oneself at once of the notion that Catherine was nothing but a royal nymphomaniac who indulged her insatiable sexual appetites to the total neglect of her oppressed subjects.

title: New Bridge Bypasses The Baltimore Tunnel
description: BALTIMORE, March 26Motorists on Interstate 95 were provided a bypass around the frequently jammed Baltimore Harbor Tunnel this week with the opening of the $141 million Francis Scott Key Bridge across the Patapsco River near its mouth at Chesapeake Bay.

title: Kids Programs At the Resorts
description: It is 7:45 A.M. Barely conscious, I trek with my daughter, M. J., through a dark empty nightclub to a silent lobby where we halt and wait in front of tightly closed doors. Other blearyeyed parents and wide awake children materialize out of the gloom to surround us.

title: C. N. Eley Jr., Miss Phillips Are Married
description: The marriage of Miriam Olsen Phillips to Charles Neill Eley Jr. took place in San Francisco yesterday. The Rev. Alanson Higbie, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Burlingame, Calif., and godfather of the bride, performed the ceremony at the HaasLilienthal House.

title: Condominium; By John D. MacDonald. 447 pp. Philadelphia and New York: J. B. Lippincott Co. $10.
description: As the old joke goes, if you ask some people the time, they'll tell you how to make a watch. If you ask John D. MacDonald about the real estate situation in Florida, he's liable to write a novel on the subject. Although Condominium purports to be fiction, its apparent intention isn't so much to explore character, plot or theme as it is to compile every conceivable fact about condominiumshow property is assessed and purchased, public officials are bribed; ecological corners are cut, deals are financed, construction standards are ignored and units are merchandized, then managed or mismanaged.

title: Letters: On the Rosenberg Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Storm Warnings Over the Atlantic
description: Americans took almost 8 million trips abroad by airplane last year, but probably not one traveler in a million knows that the basic ground rules, that made those flights possible are currently being reexamined.

title: He Doesn't Merely. Direct New Plays, He Nurtures Them
description: Death may have become fashionable as well as inevitablethey have begun to teach it in school but will it sell on Broadway? It is a question of high practical, as well as artistic, interest to the director Gordon Davidson, and to the producers Ken Marsolais and Leonard Sotoway. The answer will come some time after Thursday when their The Shadow Box opens at the Morosco after a highly praised run at the Long Wharf in New Haven.

title: BOTANICAL GARDEN STARTS MAGAZINE
description: At a time when most of New York City's institutions are cutting staff and seducing expenses, the New York Botanical. Garden has started a new magazine for its members. Called Garden, the 40page bimonthly features articles about plants. It is printed on coated stock with two and fourcolor illustrations.

title: FORD PRODS CARTER TO STEM INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  Former President Gerald R. Ford said today that he was seriously concerned that some of the fiscal decisions of the Carter Administration and Congress would lead to worsening inflation in the next few years.

title: Doctor Elected New President Of New York Lung Association
description: Dr. Anne Logan Davis was elected president of the New York Lung Association yesterday. The group was formerly known as the Tuberculosis and Respiratory Disease Association of New York.

title: READINESS COMMAND KEEPING LOW PROFILE
description: MacDILL AIR FORCE BASE, Fla.if an African dictator threatens American lives or if events force an alert in the Middle East, the Joint Chiefs of Staff call and the alarm bells ring in a modest twostory headquarters here.

title: REBEL AREA GRANTED AUTONOMY BY MANILA
description: MANILA, March 26President Ferdinand E. Marcos today proclaimed autonomous a large area in the southwestern Philippines where Moslems have been in rebellion against the central Government.

title: Found in a Garden: 2 Bernini Statues
description: WHEN Olga Raggio, chief of the Department of Western European Art at the Metropolitan Museum in New York, read an article in a small art journal about the existence, in Morristown, of two statues by Gian Lorenzo Bernini, she decided to go see for herself.

title: RoseMarie Schmitt, 69, Official With General Foods Corporation
description: RoseMarie Schmitt, a former assistant secretary of the General Foods Corporation, died Friday at her home at 120 Randolph Road in White Plains, N.Y. She was 69 years old.

title: Study Finds DrinkingOften to ExcessNow Starts at Earlier Age
description: Eric, who is 14 years old, gets drunk several times a week, but does not think he has a drinking problem. He drinks only beer or fruity wines, considered innocuous in his circle of friends, and his idea of an alcoholic is a bottleclutching bum lying in the gutter.

title: $17.2 Billion Spent in Fiscal '75 On U.S. Criminal Justice Systems
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)Taxpayers paid $17.2 billion in the fiscal year 1975, 16 percent more than in the previous year, for criminal justice systems of Federal, state and local governments, a Census Bureau report showed Thursday.

title: If You Go . . .
description: . . . to a Paris cooking school, try to avoid the summer season, particularly August, when many schools are closed and others are overcrowded.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Betsey Hall Bride of Dr. Donald Lyman
description: Elisabeth Adams Hall, who is with the Medicaid program in the State Department of Social Services in Albany, and Dr. Donald Owen Lyman, director of the Bureau of Disease Control, State Department of Health, Albany, were married yesterday afternoon at the Dwight Memorial Chapel of Yale University.

title: Speculating in 11 Percent Bonds
description: Skyhigh investment yields were commonplace in 1974 and 1975, but many investors missed the boat and didn't buy the highgrade bonds carrying 10 percent or even higher rates of return. Since then, yields on fixedincome investments have come down from the stratosphere, but the craving for high yields lingers.

title: May 1 Designated Loyalty Day
description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (UPI)President Carter has designated May 1 as Loyalty Day to encourage Americans to reaffirm their loyalty to the United States of America. Loyalty, however we may choose to define it, must dwell in our hearts as well as our minds, Mr. Carter said Wednesday.

title: A Job at the Chase for Kissinger
description: It's no secret that Henry A. Kissinger has had a friend at Chase Manhattan for many years. Now Mr. Kissinger is writing his memoirs, which could bring in as much as much as $3 million, and he may need a banker more than ever.

title: It's Annual Report Time at Gulf Oil, and This Year the Grin Is In
description: The happy group above is the board of directors of the Gulf Oil Corporation. Led by chairman Jerry McAfeethe eartoear smile in the middle of the front rowthey scarcely have the looks of a company that, by its own admission, entered 1976 on one of the most traumatic notes in its 75year history. The present mood is no accident.

title: Murder Suspect, 16, Is Booked On Escape Charge After Arrest
description: A 16yearold murder suspect who had escaped March 18 from Manhattan Family Court was booked yesterday on a charge of escape.

title: U.S. and Vietnam Polish the Peace
description: Sixteen years after the United States began fighting in Vietnam an nearly two years after the Vietnamese won the war, Washington and Hanoi have agreed to begin negotiations that will probably lead to the establishment of diplomatic relations. The United States has never had an Ambassador in Hanoi.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, MARCH 27, 1977

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Boston's Black Heritage Trail: Roots of a Proud and Passionate Past
description: We want to let people know that blacks participated in the building of this city, says Byron Rushing. A tall, softspoken political science scholar, Rushing, 33 years old, directs the Boston Museum of AfroAmerican History. He is also in charge of the Black Heritage Trail that winds in and out of the narrow old streets of Beacon Hill, in the shadow of the State House in Boston. Rushing is acutely aware of last year's racial tumult over school integration in his city.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Track and Field
description: AT MOUNT

title: The Brookdale Blues at Bat
description: THEY take their baseball seriously at Brookdale Community College. Based on the outskirts of tiny Lincroft in sprawling Middletown Township, the school's teams have compiled an amazing record in the six years of their existence.

title: Bidding for a Bit of History
description: SMITHTOWN ONCE the church commanded a commons, a sweeping village green that hogs were fond of invading. Ordinances, against and for, letting hogs do as they please pepper the ledgers of Smithtown's records, which cover more than 30 years. They began when Smith's Town raised, fed upon and sold its own bread and meat and vegetables, and was supplied with necessaries not available locally by ships that came down the Nissequogue River from the Sound.

title: Beanie to Study Ending School Unit
description: Mayor Beame will consider this week a proposal to eliminate the Board of Education and to replace it with a 12member policy hoard and a Chancellor appointed by himself, according to City Hall sources.

title: A FourCourse Selection of Paris Cooking Schools
description: Paris can be as much a frustration as a joy for one who loves to cook. There you are, among the bounty of the markets, inspired by the menus of the great restaurants. But how can you come home and whip up a petit homard  la nage, a caneton au cidre, a feuilett aux pommes chaudes? A growing number of Paris cooking schools may provide the answer.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: The Standings
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES Islanders 5, St. Louis 2. Atlanta 2, Colorado 1. Boston 7, Toronto 5. Los Angeles 6, Buffalo 4. Montreal 4, Detroit 0. Chicago 7, Minnesota 2. Philadelphia 9, Vancouver 3.

title: Ruins of 1,000 Years Ago Beneath Kiev Reveal a Life More Advanced Than Expected
description: KIEV, U.S.S.R.A few years ago, construction teams digging an extension for the Kiev subway happened upon an archeological marvela settlement of ancient wooden homes preserved 40 feet under accumulated silt along the Dnieper River.

title: The U.S. Search for A Policy In Africa
description: Mr. Carter Must Build on an Uncertain Foundation

title: Expert on Pollution
description: IN CLEAR, logical and matteroffact testimony, a ranking oceanpollution expert from the United States Department of Commerce has told the combined Energy and Environment Committees of the State Legislature that natural forces at sea, and not ocean dumping, created the disastrous, 120milelong algae mass along the New Jersey coast last summer.

title: SharPei, Rare Chinese Dog, Gets Role at  Bank Show
description: His natural coat is far too large for his body. When he sits, he resembles a 40odd pound mass of wrinkles with worried brow. But he's been In the world for close to 2,200 years, commands a price close to $2,000 and is such an oddity that he collects a crowd wherever he goes. This is the SharPei from China, one of the rarest breed of dogs, which will be on display for the first time in the Metropolitan area, from April 11 through April 15, at the 17th annual exhibition to be conducted by the Manhattan Savings Bank, 47th Street and Madison Avenue, New York.

title: At 83, Her Pen Is Far From Dry
description: POTTERSVILLE IT COULD easily have been a scene straight out of Nancy Drew or the Hardy Boys. A moment of high drama. A climax of climaxes. Even the setting was perfect: a rustic room in an old country housea living room with wideplank floors, antique ceiling beams, a large bay window decorated with neat rows of old bottles. Beyond the window: farm equipment from yesteryear lying ghostlike amid motionless outbuildings and silent hills.

title: In Memoriam
description: DEMARECAUXJacques. 3/24/76. Much too soon, old buddy. Rest in peace??

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE other weekend my wife persuaded me to take our son over to a hospital emergency room had come home with a limp the previous evening, felt great pain overnight and had trouble walking in the morning. My wife is wiser than I am in the way of medicine, and she felt that there could conceivably be a broken bone in the foot and, even if not, it would be better to have it Xrayed.

title: Dawn Anderson Rides Hill Show Hunter Victor
description: NORTH SALEM, N.Y., March 26Upland Puffin, owned and ridden by Dawn Anderson of Dover, N.J., captured the small pony hunter championship today at the opening session of the twoday Hill show.

title: Miss Cullman Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Cullman of Rye, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Victoria Cullman, to Jeffrey Leland Hedges, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Hedges of Chevy Chase, Md., and Lagos, Nigeria, where Mr. Hedges is First Counselor of Embassy for Public Affairs. Miss Cullman's father is president of Philip Morris International. An August wedding is planned.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Face the Nation: Powell, White House press secretary.

title: Carole Warsawer Wed To Dr Donald Greenblatt
description: The marriage of Carole S. Warsawer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold N. Warsawer of Teaneck, N. J., to Dr. Donald W. Greenblatt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Greenblatt, also of Teaneck, took place yesterday at the Warsawer home. Rabbi Stanley Gerstein of Temple Beth Am and Rabbi Judah Washer of the Teaneck Community Center officiated.

title: '35 Hauptmann Letter to Mother, Denying Guilt, Was Suppressed
description: A longsuppressed 5,000word letter in which Bruno Richard Hauptmann wrote his mother a poignant, detailed claim of his innocence in the 1932 kidnappingmurder of the baby Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. became public yesterday.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Governor Carey has proposed major changes in the state's Taylor Law that would drastically revise the procedures and agencies that have governed public employee labor relations for the last 10 years.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1977

title: Four Principal News Personalities Leaving WOR
description: News, talk and information are main items of WOR's broadcast agenda. Consequently, Rick Devlin, vice president and general manager, said the departure of four principal WOR newstalkinformation personalities did not mean a major redirection of format for the city's No. 1 AM outlet.

title: Tennessee Colleges Ordered to Integrate by Merging
description: NASHVILLE, March 25A Federal district judge's recent order here for the merger of two statecontrolled colleges may have a considerable impact on public higher education in places where college desegregation appears to be hampered by the presence of competing public institutions.

title: Deaths
description: ADLEREdward. We, the Officers and Board of Directors of the Jewish Hospital & Renabilltation Center of N.J. are deeply grieved at the loss sustained by our beloved Senior Vice President and his wife Louts and Dora Adler in the untimely death of their son Edward. We pray they have the strength to endure this trial. Funeral services Monday March 28 11 A.M. Philip Apier 8 Son, Springfield Ave., Maplewood, N.J. GEORGE CLOTT, PRESIDENT CHARLOTTE B. SIMON EXEC. VICEPRESIDENT

title: Chess:
description: Mikhail Tal, the Latvian grandmaster who held the world championship in 1960, once observed wisely that when two players went into a game with no heart for a real fight, there would not be one, no matter what measures were taken.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1977

title: Sketches of Major Figures in India's New Cabinet
description: The 74yearold Home Minister is known for high integrity and insatiable quest for power. . . in politics 40 years . . . often responsible for performance of Congress Party In Uttar Pradesh, traditional power base of prime ministers of India . . . born into peasant family. . . conservative in economic outlook . . . opposes collective farming and mechanization . . . graduated, in science and law from Agra University . . . provincial lawyer until joining Congress Party in 1929. . . participated actively in Mohandas K. Gandhi's noncooperation movement against British. . . jailed several times . . . elected to Uttar Pradesh state legislative assembly in 1937. . . became a minister of that state in 1951. . . held key portfolios including agriculture, revenue and home until quitting Congress Party in 1967. . . in 1969 founded Indian Revolutionary Party, later merging it with new Indian People's Party. . . jailed during emergency imposed by Prime Minister Indira Ghandhi. . .after release merged his party with national opposition front, Janata Party. . . reputed to be able administrator. . . known for dislike of women administrators.

title: Blacks and the G.O.P.
description: The Republican Party, stripped of the White House, a minority in the Congress and among state governors, and facing a continued hemorrhaging of supporters, is preoccupied with an internal debate over its future. Unless the party courts black voters and associates itself with their needs and aspirations, that future may be bleak.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ROUND TWO Salome Bey is the latest Broadway player to begin commuting to the club scene after the last curtain. Having won critical praise for her singing role of Mary in the rockgospel hit Your Arms Too Short to Box With God, Miss Bey will perform a oneweek cabaret show of her own at 11:30 P.M., starting tonight at the Grand Finale. 210 West 70th Street.

description: ENTRIES

title: Deadly Rain Imperils 2 Adirondacks Species
description: ALBANYThe brook trout and spotted salamanders of Adirondack Mountaain lakes are becoming vanishing species because of deadly rain and snow containing corrosive acids that kill them.

title: Bridge:
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 27Two major national championships were up for grabs, but there was an air of anticlimax about the proceedings at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here today.

title: Hollander Is Selected For Top College Post
description: TRENTON, March 27 (UPI)T. Edward Hollander, the deputy New York State education commissioner, has accepted the position of Chancellor of Higher Education for New Jersey, officials announced today.

title: Brazil Bitter at U.S. Effort to Impose Nuclear Curb
description: BRASILIAThe attempt by the United States to formulate a policy aimed at preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons among developing nations is meeting its sternest test in Brazil.

title: Republicans Finding Hidden Benefits in Being Out of Power
description: WASHINGTON, March 27Congressional Republicans who were afraid the November elections had doomed them to be only bystanders, onlookers and kibitzers are discovering that they are not as irrelevant as they had feared.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: A short while ago a recipe was printed in this space for an elaborately rich cake dubbed a Rosenkavalier torte. It had been offered by a reader who stated this cake is the creation of the wife of Hugo von Hofmannsthal whoas every operagoer knowswrote the libretto for the opera.

title: Albany's Budget: Something for Everyone
description: ALBANY, March 27If this year's surprisingly quick and painless state budget negotiations proved anything, it was that, even in a time of fiscal crisis and austerity, it is possible to have one's cake and eat it, too. The man who did the most of both was Governor Carey. On the one hand, by presenting a budget balanced on cuts in welfare, school aid and revenuesharing, he was able to sell the state a dramatic and quite convincing message of the need to cut back government on all levels. On the other hand, he was a willing behindthescenes partner to the legislative compromises that restored many of the cutout funds and insured that his budget ultimately would not hurt anybody very much.

title: Seattle's Families Are Pulling Out But the City May Learn to Like It.
description: SEATTLE  This picturesque Northwestern metropolis has begun to think the unthinkable.

title: Brazil Bitter at U.S. Effort to Impose Nuclear Curb
description: BRASILIAThe attempt by the United States to formulate a policy aimed at preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons among developing nations is meeting its sternest test in Brazil.

title: Orders Surge 55.9% For Machine Tools
description: The Machinery Dealers National Association, which reports on used metalworking machines, said its monthly sales index hit a February record high of 173, a gain of 2 points over the February 1976 level. The index is based on average monthly sales in 1972 taken as 100.

title: Podgorny Peers Into Rhodesia and Predicts Freedom for the Blacks
description: LIVINGSTONE, Zambia, March 27President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union came to the banks of the Zambesi today, where black Africa meets whitegoverned Africa, and declared that freedom and equality would soon be on both sides of the river.

title: Rutherford Beats Foyt
description: PHOENIX, March 27 (AP)Johnny Rutherford, despite two unfriendly ontrack car encounters and a postrace fist fight with an old rival, Gordon Johncock, raced to an 18.5second victory over A.J. Foyt today in the Jimmy Bryan 150 for Indianapolis cars.

title: A List of Survivors Of Crash of 747's
description: SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, Monday, March 28 (Agence FrancePresse)Following is a list of survivors of the plane collision in Santa Cruz de Tenerife, with their conditions, as announced by hospital authorities:

title: The Case for a Quick Fix
description: With the Senate about to act on the Carter tax rebate proposal, it's time for another look.

title: Commodities: Wheat Problem Is Now Storage
description: The good news from the winter wheat belt, which produces 75 percent of the nation's bread grain, is that, drought or not, enough green shoots are appearing from Ohio to Washington State to give the nation its biggest wheat surplus in almost two decades.

title: BROAD AUTHORITY SET FOR NEW HEALTH POST BY BEAME AND CAREY
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame agreed yesterday to give the new healthcare administrator, whom they intend to appoint jointly, sweeping powers over the city's municipal hospitals and its private voluntary institutions.

title: Canary Island Separatist Says Group Planted Bomb But Did Not Cause Crash
description: ALGIERS, Monday, March 28 (Agence FrancePresse)Canary Islands separatists here claimed responsibility early today for a bomb explosion at Las Palmas airport, after which two jumbo jets diverted from the airport to Tenerife crashed in the worst accident in aviation history.

title: Music: The Artistry of Bergonzi
description: Carlo Bergonzi's appearance yesterday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall was so pleasing that it was hard to believe that the popular Italian tenor could have waited to his 53d year before offering what was in fact his first recital in this country.

title: The Ballet: Plisetskaya's Bolero
description: Even before World War II Soviet dancers were occasionally permitted to appear as guest artists with foreign ballet companiesthe great Semyonova,, for example, danced at the Paris Opera in the 1930'sbut there seems something distinctly, although pleasantly, odd about Maya Plisetskaya dancing in New York with Maurice Mart's Ballet of the 20th Century. For although the Belgian company might be thought of as radical in political temper, its sexuality is not exactly what one thinks of first with regard to Soviet ballet.

title: Blast Destroys Two Bars
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 27 (UPI)Two popular bars in the city's River Quay entertainment district were destroyed by a powerful explosion early today. There were no casualties. The police said they were investigating to determine if the blast had been the work of gangland bombers. Pat O'Brien's and Judge Roy Bean's were reduced to craters by the blast, which occurred about 2:15 A.M. after the Saturday night crowds had gone home.

title: Defensible Borders For Israel Opposed By Sadatin Interview
description: President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, who will have talks with President Carter in Washington early in April, said in an interview broadcast last night by CBS that he could not agree to Mr. Carter's recent suggestion that Israel be provided with defensible borders.

title: OneofaKind Car Is Physician's Pride and Joy
description: BERKELEY HEIGHTSA New Jersey physician who feels about old cars the way others do about blue chip stocks is attracting attention here with a Jensen P66, the prototype car built for the 1966 Landon auto show but never put into production.

title: Habitony Scores In Coast Derby
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 27Of the 15 starters in today's Santa Anita Derby, the Irishbred Habitony appears to be the only one who could worry Seattle Slew in the Kentucky Derby on May 7.

title: Love Stops Watts in Boxing Quarterfinal
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 27 (AP)David (Sugar) Love, unleashed a barrage of righthand leads and scored a fourthround technical knockout over Bobby (Boogaloo) Watts today in a quarterfinal middleweight bout in the United States boxing championships.

title: Two Held in Playhouse Fire
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., March 27 (AP)Two youths were arrested yesterday in connection with a fire that damaged the famed Provincetown Playhouse and razed a historic building used for storing theatrical props. The police said the youths were taken while stealing gasoline from cars and then were questioned about the fire. The names of the youths were not released because of their age.

title: Borg Routed By Gottfried; Riessen Wins
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., March 27There is reason to think that at this moment Brian Gottfried is the No. 1 tennis player in the world. Gottfried, a 25yearold from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., routed the world's No. 2 player, Bjorn Borg of Sweden, by 61, 61 in 47 minutes today. And if Borg took a dive, Gottfried refused to confirm it.

title: 550 FEARED KILLED ON TWO 747'S IN CANARY ISLANDS RUNWAY CRASH; SOME ON LOS ANGELES  JET SURVIVE
description: Two Boeing 747 jumbo jets collided and burst into flames on a foggy airport runway in the Canary Islands yesterday, and more than 550 of the 643 people aboard the two aircraft were believed to have been killed. It was the worst disaster in aviation history.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: 249 ON DUTCH JET DIE
description: 550 FEARED KILLED ON TWO 747'S IN CANARY ISLANDS RUNWAY CRASH; SOME ON LOS ANGELES JET SURVIVETwo Boeing 747 jumbo jets collided and burst into flames on a foggy airport runway in the Canary Islands yesterday, and more than 550 of the 643 people aboard the two aircraft were believed to have been killed. It was the worst disaster in aviation history.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Triumph but Hopes Fade as Celtics Win
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 27Phil Jackson made a strong case today for his retention as a Knick next season. The 31yearold bearded philosopher, whose contract ends this season, played a key role in a 10995 victory over the Washington Bullets at Capital Centre. The victory snapped the Bullets' fourgame winning streak and a twogame New York losing string.

title: Mothers Organizing To Combat the Guilt Of Caesarean Birth
description: BOSTON  Five years ago when Nancy Cohen and her husband, Paul, went through prepared  childbirth classes, they were looking forward to experiencing the birth of their child. However, after she had gone into induced labor, her doctor decided that a caesarean section was necessary.

title: San Francisco Is Urging Visitors To Practice Water Conservation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 27Since it does not take water to do it, the thousands of travelers arriving at the sprawling San Francisco International Airport are being welcomed these days with a little gentle brainwashing.

title: New Albany Bishop a Street Priest
description: ALBANY, March 27 (AP)The Rev. Howard J. Hubbard, known affectionately in Albany's tough South End as the street priest. said after his ordination today as the youngest Roman Catholic bishop to head a United States diocese that he wanted to become known as a street bishiop.

title: ABORTION FOES URGED TO JOIN NEW CAUSES
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, March 26State Attorney General William F. Hyland told an antiabortion group today that it should widen its concern to include larger social and environmental issues that affect the quality of life.

title: YOUTHJOB PROGRAM ASSAILED IN REPORT
description: Representative Elizabeth Holtzman charged in a new report yesterday that there had been serious abuse in New York City's 1976 summer youthjob program, with some sponsors failing to provide legally required work experience for use in the future. She also charged there had been apparent nosnow jobs, nepotism, kickbacks and use of false Social Security numbers.

description: Only in New York could consenting adult politicians devise a way of voting for the uninhibited spread of pornography establishments while insisting to the citizenry that they are voting against it. title: Leorzcavallo's Earnest Boheme Comes In Second to Puccini's
description: There were two performances of an opera called La Bohme in New York Saturday night, one by Puccini at the Metropolitan and quite a different one by Leoncavallo at the Beacon Theater. Leoncavallo's version received its premiere in 1897, one year after Puccini's setting, and never made much headway in the repertorythis production by the New York Grand Opera was apparently the work's first professional staging in this country.

description: BOSTON, March 27 (AP)The state police said they had dismantled a homemade explosive device found by Boy Scouts cleaning up along the banks of the Mystic River in nearby Arlington yesterday. The device had been made from a lead pipe about the size of a shotgun shell, and had nails in it and an attached fuse, officials said.

description: As the first quarter closes, credit market specialists suggest that the biggest surprise has been the modest amount of new cash raised by the United States Treasury. Municipal borrowing has exceeded earlier estimates and corporate bond offerings have followed forecasts, analysts said last week, but Treasury borrowing has been significantly below expectations.

description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 27 (Reuters)Seven blacks died when a bus they were riding in detonated a land mine laid by black nationalist guerrillas in south cast Rhodesia, a security forces announcement said tonight.

description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 27 (AP) Neville Miller, a mayor of Louisville in the 1930's who later held positions with a United Nations agency and the National Association of Broadcasters, died today in Washington. He was 83 years old.

description: CAIRO, March 27The Arab League today approved a sixmonth extension of the Arab peacekeeping forces in Lebanon, and its members agreed to provide $90 million toward the costs.

description: SEABROOK, N.H.The cranes stand idle here at the construction site of the planned $2 billion Seabrook nuclear generating plant. As the muddy thaw begins, the huge parking lot is nearly empty.

description: Three out of four American physicians are practicing defensive medicine by ordering extra tests for patientsas A protection against potential malpractice suits, according to an American Medical Association poll being published today.

description: BOSTON, March 27 (AP)The old building at Brook Farm, a 19th Century commune of intellectuals in the West Roxbury section, was destroyed by fire today.

title: Red Smith
description: HIALEAH, Fla., March 27When they took Seattle Slew out for his constitutional this morning his friend and companion, Steam, bit him. Steam is a sorrelandwhite piebald pony owned by Billy Turner, Slew's trainer, and although he likes Slew he also resents him a little because Slew gets all the attention around the barn. One day last week when they were out, Steam got loose, ran back to the barn and into the stall where the boss horse lives. He was evicted, of course, so today when they were hackine about the grounds, he nipped the winner of the Flamingo Stakes. Slew kicked at him. That was a good sign, Billy Turner said, a sign he was feeling good. Actually, he only feinted a kick. They're friends, but Slew would have enjoyed kicking him for real. Five times a runner and five times an overwhelming winner. Slew flies for New York this week. Mickey and Karen Taylor, his owners, see to it that he travels first class, unlike some members of the family. Mickey's mother and two brothers, LaVerne and Quirt, drove a camper all the way from Seattle to watch the Flamingo. They planned on a leisurely week of seeing the country but ran into snowstorms everywhere and kept going day, and night.

J., nursing home. He was 75 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs

Noting the rehiring last week of 210 officers and the promotion of five superiors for the first time in nearly two years. Mr. Codd said, I ask you look to the future with optimism.

title: Germans Visit U.S. to Talk as Well as Listen
description: WASHINGTON, March 27For decades it has been axiomatic in the State Department's Office of Central European Affairs that every week is German weekso full is the calendar of official visitors from West Germany and, more recently, from East Germany as well. In the past it was a ritual News for every aspiring West GerAnalysis man politician to be seen at least once a year in Washington, if possible by the President. Troupes of Bonn politicians still make the annual pilgrimage.

title: Statistically, Seattle Is Near Manhattan
description: Statistically speaking, the city of Seattle is becoming more and more like the island of Manhattan, the quintessence of single, unattached and childless culture.

title: Deadly Rain Imperils 2 Adirondacks Species
description: ALBANYThe brook trout and spotted salamanders of Adirondack Mountaain lakes are becoming vanishing species because of deadly rain and snow containing corrosive acids that kill them.

title: 700 in Denver Applaud Abourezk After Senator Criticizes Israeli Lobby
description: DENVER March 27 (AP)  Senator James Abourezk, whose selection as a Democratic dinner speaker had been criticized because of his reported proArab views, won a standing ovation last night after telling an audience of 700 persons that the Israeli lobby wielded extraordinary influence in Washington.

title: Chenier Is Sung At Met
description: It's easy to forgive the often coarse and clumsy music to Andrea Chnier in view of its abundance of good tunes and hokey but effective melodrama. When the chemistry is right and the cast's adrenalin is flowing, the opera can drive an audience to frenzy. The Metropolitan's first performance of it this season on Saturday afternoon did not quite succeed in doing that perhaps, but there was at least enough emotional fervor and fine singing to carry one along most of the way.

title: McDonald Slated for Hearing
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27Joe McDonald, the New York Mets' general manager, is scheduled to appear in Municipal Court tomorrow for an advisory hearing on charges of driving while under the influence alcohol following his involvement in an automobile accident yesterday.

description: TRENTON, March 27 (UPI)T. Edward Hollander, the deputy New York State education commissioner, has accepted the position of Chancellor of Higher Education for New Jersey, officials announced today.

From Ohrbach's at one end of Fifth Avenue to Bergdorf Goodman at the other, for example, stores had sent dozens of representatives including their presidents. The aim is to catch the tall portents and bring them home.

title: BEAME IS REPORTED NEAR A BUDGET PLAN
description: After months of rearranging numbers and conducting hurried negotiations in Washington and Albany, the Beame administration is reported to be very close to a final program that fiscal officials are certain can eliminate New York City's budget deficit for the next fiscal year without a resort to heavy reductions in city services.

description: HAVANA, March 27 (Reuters)Juan Marinello Vidauretta, who was president of the Cuban Communist Party before Fidel Castro came to power, died here early today. He was 78 years old.

title: Agreement Reached On $5 Million More For City U. Budget
description: ALBANY, March 27  Legislative negotiators agreed tonight to restore $5 million of the $15 million Governor Carey had proposed to eliminate from the budget of the City University's senior colleges. But, in an unusual move, the use of the money returned to the City University budget will be removed from the control of the City University chancellor, Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, and will have to be justified in detail by the Board of Education before it is made available to the school.

title: PUBLIC DOUBT FOUND A BAR TO SLUDGE USE
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 27After exchanging favorable reports on the use of sewage products for land reclamation, fertilization, and irrigation, about 250 Federal, state and municipal officials have agreed that widespread use of the techniques still faces one big obstaclepublic opposition.

title: Changes in Chinese Music and Art Reflect Upheavals in Its Politics
description: HONG KONG, March 27To outsiders the signs of change in China over the last five months since the arrest of the four leftist leaders are often imperceptible. But to Chinese, trained to decipher every ideological nuance, they may seem larger. Take the Peking radio for instance. It is still broadcasting shrill political messages and martial music, but now it also airs lilting folk songs and traditional Chinese instrumental music. Before the arrest of the leftists, such music was banned as decadent.

description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Justice Department's investigation into alleged influencebuying activities by agents of the South Korean Government is now focusing on possible tax violations by two former Congressmen, Richard T. Hanna and Cornelius E. Gallagher, sources familiar with the investigation say.

title: Marsh Wins by a Stroke; Watson Loses Lead Again
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., March 27Tom Watson, whose golf career has been plagued by frequent collapses while holding the lead in the final round of a tournament, did it again today. For the second time in two Sundays he dissipated a leadfour strokes this timeand gave away a tournament, in this case the Heritage Golf Classic.

title: New Panes Give Pleasure in Bronx Garden
description: I don't know if you call this thing a building or a structure, but I know it's incredible, said Representative Jonathan B. Bingham yesterday as the Democrat from the Bronx looked up at a few hundred of the 17,000 panes of glass that make up the sprawling greenhouse roof of the Conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The ornate conservatory, considered one of the nation's finest greenhouse structures, was until recently in a state of nearruin, but it is now being thoroughly restored, and yesterday the Botanical Garden opened up its doors to show off the restoration's progress to the public.

title: Yarborough Outdistances Petty And Takes Staley NASCAR 400
description: NORTH WILKESBORO, N.C., March 27 (AP)Cale Yarborough, keeping up a relationship with a track that gave him two NASCAR victories last year, ran away from Richard Petty today and won the 17th annual Gwyn Staley 400 stockcar race.

description: Who's Got the Rights to Rhodesia?, a CBS news documentary, can be seen at 10 this evening. This is in line with a cardinal rule of primetime scheduling: That which has little chance is given, if at all possible, less of a chance.

title: Carter's Dairy Price Rise To Avoid More Increases?
description: WASHINGTON, March 27When President Carter made his decision last week to increase dairy prices, data prepared for him by the Agriculture Department showed that it would cost the public about $925 million to give producers $1 billion in increased income.

title: Leonard Silk
description: The International Monetary Fund, which many financial wisemen left for dead when the Bretton Woods Agreement collapsed six years ago, is rebounding, stronger than ever. Its new mandate is nothing less than rescuing the world monetary systernand with it, the world's commercial banks. The I.M.F.'s managing director, H. Johannes Witteveen, is engaged in secret, worldwide negotiations, trying to devise a fundcalled simply a facility for the time beingthat would lend money to debtor nations no longer welcomed by private lenders.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch in The Times last Wednesday incorrectly stated that President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union had flown to Africa in a Soviet supersonic transport. The plane was actually subsonic.

title: Supplementary OverCounter Listings
description: Week ended March 25, 1977

title: New Energy for Old Cities
description: With all the gaudy news flowing out of Detroit about the opening of the spectacular new Renaissance Center, a smaller, but still significant story from the same city almost got buried. It told how volunteers from Birmingham, an affluent Detroit suburb, came in rescue an innercity junior high school arts program which would otherwise have been lost because of budgetary problems. The little story about collaboration among people of vastly different social and economic circumstances demonstrates again that the nation's older cities need more than costly real estate development to pull through this critical period.

title: Major Air Crashes in Recent Years
description: The collision of two Boeing 747 jumbo airliners on an airport runway yesterday at Santa Cruz de Tenerife in the Canary Islands was the worst disaster involving aircraft. Previous major air disasters include the following:

title: Board of Estimate Will Meet Today On Pornography
description: The New York City Board of Estimate will meet this afternoon in special session to try to muster a majority behind one of the antipornography zoning measures before it.

title: Disease Control Center, Under Fire, Retains Much of Its Reputation for Excellence
description: WASHINGTON, March 27The Center for Disease Control, widely blamed for mishandling the swine flu vaccination program, has been highly regarded by public health experts here and abroad. But there are clouds now on its horizon.

title: Hunt Says Problems Of the Nation Remain
description: E. Howard Hunt, recently released from prison after serving 32 months for his role in the Watergate scandal, is convinced that most of the nation's preWatergate problems remain.

title: Mehta Leads Angelenos In Beethoven
description: The Saturday evening allBeethoven program by the Los Angeles Philharmonic in Carnegie Hall  commemorating to the day the 150th anniversary of the composer's death  was more interesting than most allBeethoven concerts, and not just because of the inclusion of the rarely heard Triple Concerto in C (Op. 56). Since Zubin Mehta is taking over the New York Philharmonic in the fall of 1978, it was instructive to hear him at work at the core of the repertory.

title: Mets Give 65 Victory To Braves
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. March 27 It's the same as last season, Joe Frazier, manager of the Mets, moaned after watching his club hand the Atlantic Braves a 65 victory today on five unearned runs. The Mets first dissipated a 40 lead by allowing the Braves fodr tainted runs in the fourth inning and finally gave the game away in the 10th when Felix Milian threw a grounder into the Atlanta dugout.

title: Posin Dancers In 2 Premieres Full of Images
description: Within the last year, Kathryn Posin's name has become familiar to those who had not previously seen her work. Andrei Serban's current production of The Cherry Orchard uses her choreography. The Eliot Feld Ballet performs Waves, a moderndance piece she originally presented with her own company.

title: Roosevelt
description: ENTRIES

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch in The Times last Wednesday incorrectly stated that President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union had flown to Africa in a Soviet supersonic transport. The plane was actually, subsonic.

title: 14Day Cruise Lured Pan Am Passengers From the West Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, March 27The 364 passengers on the Pan Am charter plane that crashed today in the Canary Islands had been bound for a 14day pleasure cruise to ports of call in the Mediterranear.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Karen Ann Quinlan becomes 23 years old tomorrow, still unconscious at a nursing home almost a year after the State Supreme Court gave her parents the right to allow her to die.

title: The Doors of Justice
description: BOSTON, March 27From the bench of the Supreme Court last week, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger denounced five of his colleagues for what he called a weird, intolerable, bizarre decision. They had set aside an Iowa murder conviction because the police, after promising not to question a suspect until he saw his lawyer, elicited incriminating evidence from him that was used at his trial.

title: Rural DialaRide Service Breaks Isolation of the Poor and Elderly
description: BELVIDERE, N.J., March 24Julia Halvey, a widow in her 80's, lives alone in a green trimmed white house behind a purple gate on Mountain Lake Road in the hills outside this rustic county seat near the Pennsylvania border.

title: New York Idea, a 1906 Comedy, Gets BAM Off to Delightful Start
description: There is cause for real rejoicing in Brooklyn, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music where the new BAM Theater Company officially opened last might with a delicious production of Langdon Mitchell's farcical comedy The New York Idea.

title: L.I. Area to Get HisHer Beaches
description: LONG BEACH, L.I., March 28With the blessings of this city's Orthodox Jewish community, there will be a men's beach and a women's beach here this summer for those who prefer sexually segregated swimming.

title: Carter Backs Bond Vote at Home
description: PLAINS, Ga., March 28'This is Jimmy Carter, the voice begins in that familiar, soft singsong.

title: JUAN MARINELLO
description: MIAMI, March 28 (AP)Juan Marinello, a poet who helped found the Cuban Communist Party more than 50 years ago, died Saturday at age 70, the Havana radio said today. He served as Cuban delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council and became a member of the Council of State, the collective Cuban presidency, under the new Constitution.

title: French Communists Report Influx
description: PARIS, March 28 (Reuters)Some 50,000 people have become members of the French Communist Party in the first three months of 1977, setting a new record for increase in membership, the Communist newspaper, L'Humanit, reported today. The party estimated its total membership at 600,000.

title: Mastase Taking His Act To Hollywood via W .T .T .?
description: Is Hollywood ready for an Academy Awardwinning performer like Ilie Nastase?

title: PROSPERITY SPREADS TO THE RURAL SOUTH
description: ATLANTA, March 28The growth that has made Southern cities the economic envy of the nation is spreading to the region's longneglected rural areas and small towns.

title: Issue and Debate
description: It happens every day at tracks in all but six of the 25 states where parimutuel racing takes place: Horses with sore legs or other ailments, the kind of problems that formerly could be cured only by rest, parade to the post under the influence of onceforbidden drugs.

title: Carey Asks About Concorde's Use Of Stewart Site Near Newburgh
description: ALBANY, March 28Governor Carey who has firmly opposed the landing of the Concorde at Kennedy International Airport, today raised the possibility that the supersonic jet might be able to use the stateowned Stewart Airport, 65 miles north of Manhattan.

title: World News Briefs
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, March 29 (Agence FrancePresse)South Africa's ruling Nationalist Party here has announced that it will hold a congress to decide whether there should be a referendum testing the attitudes of whites on independence.

title: Notes on People
description: Senator Jake Garn of Utah, whose wife was killed in an auto accident last August, will marry 27yearold Kathleen Brewerton Bingham, divorced a year ago from his administrative assistant, Jeffrey Bingham. Before his 1974 election to the Senate, the 44yearold conservative Republican was mayor of Salt Lake City. The marriage will be in the Mormon Temple there sometime next month.

title: Japanese Shipbuilders Report 38.4% Drop in Foreign Orders
description: TOKYO, March 28 (AP)Japanese shipbuilders had foreign orders for 499 ships totaling 6.55 million gross tons in the first 11 months of fiscal 1976, which ends March 31, the Japan Shipbuilders' Association said today. The figure represented a decline of 38.4 percent or 9.65 million gross tons, from the level st the end of fiscal 1975.

title: Hospitals Prepare for Strike
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 28 (AP)Admissions were curtailed today and patients transferred at some facilities of the strikethreatened Appalachian Regional Hospitals Inc. A contract for hospital workers at eight of the chain's facilities in Kentucky, West Virginia and Virginia that is negotiated by the United Steelworkers expires at 12:01 A.M. Friday. We are getting ready, said a hospital spokesman.

title: S.I. Seeking Source Of Carbon Monoxide
description: The New York City Department of Health began an investigation yesterday to find out why as many as 20 members of six Staten island families have been found with neartoxic levels of carbon monoxide in their blood in the last few weeks.

title: VANCE AND BREZHNEV OPEN MOSCOW TALKS
description: MOSCOW, March 28Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance was confronted today by criticism of President Carter's human rights policies and by a reserved attitude toward his arms  reduction proposals as the United States and the Soviet Union began highlevel talks.

title: HELPWANTED AD INDEX UP 1 POINT FOR FEBRUARY
description: The helpwanted advertising index inched up in February to 106 (1967=100), the Conference Board said yesterday. The index rose one point from a revised figure of 105 for January and was 13 points above February, 1976.

title: ACCORD ON BUDGET HITS SNAG IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, March 28The bipartisan agreement on the new state budget hit an unexpected and apparently serious snag today, hours before the budget was to have been presented in final form to the members of the Legislature.

title: Bridge
description: PASADENA, Calif., March 29East Coast and West Coast players shared the final honors in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here last night. Victory in the open pairs championship added substantially to the world's biggest masterpoint collection when Barry Crane, a Hollywood television producer who is the only man with more than 20,000 points, won with Peter Rank of Los Angeles.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: Giacomin Through for Season
description: DETROIT, March 28 (AP)Eddie Giacomin, a Red Wings' goalie who reinjured his left knee in a game with the Montreal Canadiens yesterday, has played his last game of the season. The Detroit club said today it had called up an amateur goaltender, Mike Frawley, from Cambleton, New Brunswick, as backup to Jim Rutherford for the Red Wings' remaining four games.

title: Bhutto Makes Appeal to Opposition
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 28Pakistan's rump Parliament, in which the opposition has refused to take its seats, unanimously, reelected Zulfikar Ali Bhutto Prime Minister today.

title: Justices Hear Death Penalty Issues
description: WASHINGTON, March 28In a long and somber session before a courtroom packed with students on spring vacations, the nine justices of the Supreme Court sought today to deal with some of the fallout of their landmark rulings last July upholding the death penalty for at least some circumstances.

title: HUSTLER CASE IS POSED AS PRICE OF FREE PRESS
description: CARTAGENA. Colombia, March 28 (AP) Pornography may be the price we have to pay for absolute freedom of the press in the United States, Wilbur G. Landrey, former foreign editor of United Press International, told a group of Western Hemisphere editors and publishers here today.

title: High Court to Rule on Right of Public to Nixon's Tapes
description: WASHINGTON, March 28The Supreme Court agreed today to decide when, if ever, the American public could hear the White House tape recordings that were played as evidence at the Watergate coverup trial.

title: Trucking to the Mideast: Rich but Rough Road
description: VIENNA, March 28  Longdistance trucking from Western Europe to the Middle East is a boom industry right now, but it is entangled in red tape woven by a dozen governments and suffering from cutthroat competition

title: Army to Use Russian Equipment
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)Vithin the next year, Russian tanks nay roll across the United States accompanied by soldiers wearing Russianstyle uniforms, carrying Soviet AK47 assault rifles and riding in Russian armored personnel carriers.

title: New Bond Issues
description: UTILITY BONDS

title: Investor Pessimism Pushes Dow To Its Lowest Level Since Nov. 10
description: Weighted down by investor pessimism. stock prices fell for the eighth straight session yesterday to reach new lows for 1977.

title: Carolina Blacks Learn a DialectTheir Own
description: BEAUFORT. S.C., March 19The late Fats Waller, the legendary jazz pianist, is reported to have once observed, One never knows, do one?

title: 49ers'Sale Is Approved By N.F.L.
description: PHOENIX, March 28Owners and officials of the National Football League's 28 clubs had the almost forgotten pleasure of dealing with straight football matters at their annual meeting today, as they approved the sale of the San Francisco 49ers and began exploring the possibilities of new division alignments, a longer schedule and more playoff teams.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: SUNDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Ceausescu Urges Helsinki Followup
description: VIENNA, March 28 (Reuters)President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania today called for a European pact that would include a ban on nuclear weapons and a renunciation of force as a followup to the EastWest agreement reached in 1975 in Helsinki, Finland.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: ATLANTADespite widespread disappointment here among politicians and businessmen over Georgia's failure last week to win a coveted Federal Government contract for a national solar research facility, this bustling, attractive city is fast regaining confidence about economic prospects after the strains of the recent recession. The economic downturn of 197375 was a new experience for this fastpaced city of 1.6 millionthe hub of trade, finance and transportation for the Southeastern United States, which constitutes the sixth Federal Reserve District.

title: 10 New Judges Appointed by Beame
description: Mayor Beame yesterday appointed 10 new judges, six to Criminal Court and four to Family Court, including Jerome Hornblass, the city's 36yearold controversial Addiction Services Commissioner.

title: Preseason Baseball
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Prosecutor Asserts He Will Prove That 2 Nurses Poisoned Patients
description: DETROIT, March 28The prosecution's circumstantial case against two Filipino nurses will prove that they poisoned nine patients, killing two of them, assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Yanko told jurors today as the nurses' murder trial began.

title: Rothko's Executors Lose Court Appeal On Damages, Fines
description: A state appeals court yesterday upheld a ruling by Manhattan Surrogate Millard L. Midonick that assessed damages and fines of $9,252,000 against the executors of the estate of Mark Rothko, the abstract  expressionist painter, and against Frank Lloyd and Mr. Lloyd's Marlboroueh Galleries.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: EASTERN DIVISION

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Feb. 23 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) Americas Stock Exchange and (O) OvertheCounter.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney reports that Atlanta is quickly regaining confidence about economic prospects after the strains of the recent recession. Page 43.

title: Yepes Plays Versatilely on 10String Guitar
description: A distinctive feature of the artistry of Narciso Yepes, the famous Spanish guitarist who performed Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, is his 10stringed instrument. Designed by Mr. Yepes himself, it is more versatile than the normal sixstringed guitar, and, partly owing to additional overtones from the extras strings, more sonorous as well.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that its Defense Communications division would head an industry team that has been awarded a $36 million firstphase contract by the Air Force to design and supply a functional prototype Of a proposed Strategic Air Command information network.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla.  Watching Frank Mather 3d of Quisset, Mass., and Key Biscayne catching groupers and mangrove snappers from a small boat anchored off a jetty in Key Biscayne Bay, I was reminded that a truly dedicated angler is always delighted to take fish, no matter how usual they are.

title: People and Business
description: Norman Hinerfeld, chairman of the executive committee of the KayserRoth Corporation, said yesterday that he had told the board of Genesco Inc. to remove his name from consideration as a candidate for chairman and chief executive of Genesco.

title: Korean Watergate or Washout?
description: When the news broke last year that the Federal Government was investigating the activities of Tongsun Park and other Korean agents in Washington, the political community speculated that this would be the Congressional equivalent of the Watergate scandal. Mr. Park was known to have close relationships with members of Congress in both parties, but especially among the majority Democrats.

title: Women Get New Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)President Carter announced today the appointment of former Representative Bella Abzug of New York and Betty Ford to nonpaying jobs on the National Commission on the Observance of International Women's Year.

title: DIANA HYLAND, STAR OF TV SERIES, 41
description: LOS ANGELES, March 28 (AP)Diana Hyland, who played a mother of eight in the ABCTV series Eight Is Enough, died yesterday at her home here. She was 41 years old.

title: Outcry Greets Carter Plan to Curb OffRoad Vehicles on Public Lands
description: WASHINGTON, March 28A plan by President Carter to crack down on the use of snowmobiles, motorcycles, dune buggies and other offtheroad vehicles on environmentally sensitive public lands has stirred a hornet's nest of protest by users of such vehicles.

title: Oversight: Good News And Bad
description: WASHINGTON  Recent inquiries about the new Senate Intelligence Committee produced, among other perhaps significant responses, the following:

title: Kibbee Assigns a Council Of Top Officials to Polish University's Public Image
description: The City University of New York has established a council of top officials in an effort to improve what university authorities regard as the embattled institution's poor public image.

title: Aqueduct Jockeys
description: * Apprentice

title: Rocky Gets Oscar as Top Film; Finch, Dunaway Win for Acting
description: LOS ANGELES, Mach 28The Academy Award for best actor went tonight to the late British film star Peter Finch, the first time in the history of the Oscars that an acting award was made posthumously.

title: Quotations From General Brown, Again
description: It seems that almost every time the words of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. George Brown, break into print, his supporters must rush to his defense by extolling his sterling record as a professional soldier. That record cannot indefinitely support the muddled political doctrines that seem to swirl in the general's mind.

title: Rangers' Season Marked by Inconsistency
description: John Bowie Ferguson in anger has great style. He paces behind the New York Ranger bench; his hands start to sweat and he rubs them in one of the pale blue towels the trainers keep in plentiful supply. Then when the referee makes the call that pierces Fergy's thin veneer of restraint, up like a geyser shoots the blue towel landing somewhere in the stands and the large, gnarled hands are clapped to a pounding temple. Then Fergy is gesturing wildly, accusing the officials, beseeching the hockey deities, and his mouth starts its work, spewing forth exclamations and insults.

title: Police Halt Edison Traffic in Contract Demonstration
description: EDISON, March 28Policemen snarled traffic at two major intersections for more than three hours this morning to dramatize a contract dispute with the township.

title: CARTER AUTHORIZES PENTAGON TO REVIEW 432,000 DISCHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, March 28President Carter has authorized the review and possible upgrading of the otherthanhonorable discharges of about 432,000 Vietnam war servicemen, the Defense Department announced today.

title: Labor Boycotting Ringling Circus on Music Issue
description: Organized labor has begun a consumer boycott of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, which opens in New York today, and it is urging people not to buy tickets because of alleged unfair labor practices against musicians.

title: Baker Says Rebate May Lose
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (UPI)The Senate Republican leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., said today that there was an excellent chance that the Senate would kill President Carter's proposed $50 per person tax rebate and substitute a permanent tax cut to stimulate the economy.

title: Arthur Kinsolving Is Dead at 77; Rector of St. James' for 22 Years
description: The Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, a retired rector of St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan and a member of a family that has given three bishops and many priests to the Episcopal Church, died of cancer yesterday in Greater Baltimore Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: News Summary
description: The collision of two 747 jumbo jets on an airport runway in Santa Cruz de Tenerife Sunday killed 577 people. There were 60 survivors, 11 of them in serious condition. The Spanish Government ordered a judicial inquiry. One plane was operated by Pan American World Airways, and the other by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. All aboard the KLM plane were killed. [Page 1, Col. 6.]

title: CUSTODY RULE UPHELD FOR MOON DISCIPLES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 28A threejudge State Court of Appeals panel today upheld a lower court ruling placing five young adult members of the Unification Church of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon in the custody of their parents for 30 days.

title: Improved Ties With Washington Seen in New Delhi Political Circles
description: NEW DELHI, March 28In the opinion of many Indians, the change of government here is likely to bring about a noticeable improvement in the often tumultuous relationship between this country and the United States.

title: Gottfried Beats Riessen In La Costa Final, 63,, 62
description: CARLSBAD, Calif., March 28 Brian Gottfried defeated Marty Riessen, 63, 62, in 80 minutes and won the LaCosta International Classic tonight, It was his fourth tournament victory this year and his fifth in six months.

title: Philippine Christians Are Believed Uneasy At Moslem Autonomy
description: MANILA, March 28Widespread uneasiness is reported among Christians in southern Mindanao as a result of the presidential proclamation of last Saturday granting autonomy to areas where Moslems have been in rebellion against the central Government.

title: Maine's Attorney General Denies Validity of Indian Land Claims
description: PORTLAND, Me., March 28 (AP)Attorney General Joseph E. Brennan says the Penobscot and Passamaquoddy Indians were stripped of their lands some 35 years before the signing of the treaties on which their claims to 12.5 million acres are based.

title: I.R.S. Wins SafeDeposit Access Without Hearings for Boxholders
description: The Internal Revenue Service can break open a safedeposit box to look for valuables without giving the boxholder the right to object, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has ruled in New York.

title: Carey's Bid to Negotiate Language Labyrinth Makes Confusion Perfectly Clear
description: ALBANY, March 28Governor Carey, who has been teased by newsmen recently about his tendency to obfuscate, was involved in another minor skirmish today after agreement on an important bill, first promised by the administration last Friday, once again failed to materialize.

title: Newport Jazz Set for 11 Days, June 24July 4
description: The 24th Newport Jazz Festival will play its sixth straight year in New York from June 24 to July 4, 11 days during which the city will thump to the beat of music, hot and cool, made everywhere from Carnegie Hall to the Staten Island Ferry.

title: DEATH TOLL MOUNTS TO 574 IN COLLISION OF 747'S IN CANARIES
description: SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Spain, March 28With the airport here still littered with the charred remains of the two jetliners that collided on the runway yesterday in dense fog, the death toll rose today to 574, and investigators sought to determine how the crash had occurred.

title: CITY COUNCIL IS STUDYING BAN ON OBSCENE MATERIAL
description: Noting a change in public mores as well as the attitude of the courts in pornography cases, a City Council committee began consideration of a bill yesterday that would ban public display of specified obscene material to people under 17 years of age.

title: On Dealing With Spider Eggs
description: The Great Spider Egg Mystery remains unsolved but it may yet have several happy endings. The mystery concerns Bubble Yum, a popular new bubble gum that has, in a year, overtaken such symbols of earlier childhoods as Dubble Bubble and Bazooka. A few weeks ago came toil and trouble: the unexplained spread of lurid rumors among children in the New York area that, gasp!, Bubble Yum contained spider eggs (or, according to haughtier youthful accounts, caused cancer). Stores which had up to then been unable to stock enough to meet demand suddenly saw sales plummet. Last week, the manufacturer, Life Savers, Inc., took out fullpage ads in 30 area newspapers to combat the rumors.

title: Contradictions Veiling Crash
description: Critical unknowns, confusion and contradictions faced investigators yesterday as they set out to reconstruct the events that led to the collision of two jumbo jets on a Canary Islands runway. There seemed to be good prospects that the cause of the catastrophe would emerge from electronic recording devices, interviews with crew members and other survivors from the Pan American World Airways plane, and interrogation of traffic controllers.

title: Cauthen Gets 4 Winners
description: Back where he is smashing the record for most victories in a meeting with every winner he rides, Steve Cauthen booted home four more yesterday at an overcast and showery Aqueduct Race Track.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The state police reported yesterday a 5.4 percent increase in crime in the state in 1076, although violent crimes, particularly murders, showed a decrease. The preliminary uniform crime report for the state for 1976 said 396,427 crimes were reported to police last year.

title: Nominated for Emmy
description: A 5foot5inch, 114pound blonde, Miss Hyland was seen on most of the top television dramatic shows. She was nominated for an Emmy in 1963 for her performance in The Voice of Charlie Pont on the shortlived Premiere series.

title: U.S. Offers Limited Role in Suits For School Integration in 2 Cities
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP)The Justice Department offered today to intervene in a limited way in St. Louis and Cleveland school desegregation cases pending before trial courts.

title: Former Clinton County Sheriff An Apparent Suicide, Police Say
description: PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., March 28 (UPI) Paul E. Guay, former Clinton County sheriff, was found hanged in an apparent suicide in the basement of his home outside Plattsburgh Sunday, the state police reported.

title: Norway, Deutsche Bank Loan Pact
description: FRANKFURT, March 28 (UPI)Norway and the Deutsche Bank signed today a contract on a $83.3 million loan. The loan, which runs for five years, pays an annual 6 percent interest.

title: Ray's Report of Bounty Checked
