title: Woman Guard Attacked by Inmate in Attica
description: One of three women guards at the Attica Correctional Facility, where all the inmates are men, was, attacked Monday by an inmate while she was standing guard in the mess hall.

title: Kings Down Knicks With Early Drive
description: KANSAS CITY, March 29  The Kansas City Kings withstood a furious fourthquarter rally and defeated the New York Knicks, 132126, before 10,744 fans at Kemper Arena tonight. The victory keeps alive the Kings hopes for capturing the sixth and last Western Conference playoff berth.

title: Carter Authorizes $2 Billion in Sales Of Arms Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, March 29President Carter has approved sales of arms and military construction items overseasvalued at slightly more than $2 billionthat were previously authorized by the Ford Administration, the White House said today.

title: American General Insurance Bid For Richmond Corp. Is Improved
description: The $4.7 billion American Insurance Company of Houston sweetened its offer yesterday to buy the multimilliondollar Richmond Corporation of Virginia. Both have major insurance operations. Only a week ago, in an informal proposal, American General said it would offer a new $2.25 convertible preferred stock with a socalled stated value of $30 a share when the preferred stock is liquidated.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article about young people in Seattle and an accompanying photograph that appeared in The Times on Monday. the family name of a couple was given incorrectly. The correct names are David and Christine Williams.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of Post positions

title: Postal Study to Propose Service Cuts, Subsidies And the 22Cent Stamp
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)Your mail will not be delivered on Saturday, more of your tax money will go toward subsidizing the Postal Service and you will have to pay 22 cents for mailing a firstclass letter in 1985.

title: Chess:
description: While the bishop is a much faster piece than the knight and can usually develop in one movethe knight sometimes requiring two or even three moves to develop properlythere still are problems involved in determining where to put a bishop.

title: Carter. Explains Radio Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 29President Carter was reported today to have mini mized the importance of public frictions with the Soviet Union and to have underscored Moscow's interest in the current talks with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance in Moscow.

title: N.F.L. Adds 2 Games For Total of 16 in 78
description: PHOENIX, March 29The National Football League voted today to increase its regularseason schedule to 16 games starting in 1978. It also voted to add two wildcard teams to the playoff pattern so that a total of 10 teams would qualify for the elimination tournament that leads to the Super Bowl.

title: Coal Gasification Tests
description: Tests in Wyoming of underground coal gasification have produced the highest heat levels for that method to date. Page D7.

title: PODGORNY WINDS UP HIS VISIT TO ZAMBIA
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 29President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union ended a fourday visit today amid signs that he had improved relations with Zambia to the highest level in years.

title: HouseSitters Guard Even Petsin Suburbs
description: Sometimes it means waking up in a strange bed and wondering, Where am I? or having a cold war with a suspicious pet or groping in the dark for an unfamiliar fuse box. But despite these moments of uncertainty, housesitting is growing in popularity in the New York suburbs.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Village Brings Italy Into Fight Over Reactors
description: MONTALTO DI CASRTO, ItalyThere were accordions, drums, flutes, guitars, banners and petitions. There were housewives, fishermen, shepherds, farmers, hippies, nobility and businessmen. The local wine and cheese were passed around.

title: Burn Victims of Crash Going to Army Base in Texas
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 29The Army Medical Facility that is awaiting the arrival of some of the victims from the Canary Islands airplane disaster has grown from a frontier dispensary that treated arrow wounds and saddle sores into a center that has gained worldwide renown for its work with burn victims.

title: For Diplomats, a Chili Atmosphere
description: WASHINGTON

title: CONGRESSMAN REPORTEDLY HELPED TO STOCKPILE GUNS
description: ATLANTA. March 29Representative Larry McDonald, a national officer of the John Birch Society who has frequently warned that enactment of gun control laws would leave Americans defenseless against Communist invasion, helped stockpile about 200 guns in his official district residence near Atlanta over the past several years, according to a report in tomorrow's editions of The Atlanta Constitution.

title: Bread So French It Brings Tears to Gallic Eyes
description: The croissants with the almond base are delicious. said Michaeline Cibaud of the French Embassy. Have you tried the petits painsauchocolate? They are not found anywhere else in this country.

title: NADJARI WILL REMAIN IN RACE, HE DECLARES
description: Maurice H. Nadjari declared yesterday that he would remain in the race for Queens District Attorney, and Queens Republicans said he would have the support of the G.O.P. organization despite an unfavorable rating by a committee of the Queens Bar Association.

title: Too Much to Handle
description: In the end, the account by Marc Bloom (on the opposite page) about the eighthgrade class he teaches in a good New York City junior high school is a cry for help. The poverty and the truancy, the reading failures and the recurrent suspensions, the instability of homes without natural parents, the constant movesall these symptoms of the urban school pathology surely entitle Mr. Bloom to his conclusion that it is all too much for us to handle. He is also entitled to be given some answers.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Iirving Lazar had a party the other night. Mr. Lazar, who is often called Swifty, is not necessarily unhappy when he is with only one celebrity, but his happiness mounts when he is with many celebrities, and so for the party he invited almost all that there were around. He asked them to Tavern on The Green to watch the Academy Awards with him on television, and that is why there were not so many celebrities at the ceremonies in Los Angeles, Swifty bad them all in New York.

title: China, S. Korea Women Gain Table Tennis Final
description: BIRMINGHAM. England. March 29 (UPI)China and South Korea fought their way to their third successive women's team final in the world table tennis championships today. They split in the two previous meetings.

title: Oscar A. Silverman, Long on the Faculty Of the U. of Buffalo
description: Oscar A. Silverman, former chairman of the English department at the University of Buffalo and an expert in modern English literature, died Saturday at a Buffalo nursing home. He was 74 years old.

title: Italian Company Puts Watergate Up for Sale
description: ROME, March 29 (Reuters) The. Watergate complex in Washington, scene of the breakin that led to President Nixon's resignation is for sale, the Italian owners said today.

title: Two Members of Moon Church Quit After Talk With Deprogrammers
description: SAN FRANCISCO,March 29 (UPI)Two young adult followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon who were turned over to their parents by a court have quit the evangelist's Unification Church after meeting with friends who have been trained to convince Mr. Moon's followers tochange their beliefs, an attorney for the parents said today.

title: At the Site, Mood Is Businesslike On the Third Day of a Grim Task
description: SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, March 29The wretched objects on the hangar floor were finally sorted and counted. As everyone had known from the start, it was a new world's record.

title: Socal Seeks Amax Stock
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said in its annual report that it planned to buy Amax Inc. stock in the market from time to time to the extent necessary to maintain its 20 percent interest in the divesified minerals and energy company. The oil company said that it bought $16 million of Amax shares last year to maintain its holding.

title: Dollar Is Mixed in Europe And Pound Gains a Bit; Gold Prices Ease Again
description: LONDON, March 29 (AP)The dollar was mixed on currency markets across,: Europe today. Gold prices eased for the second straight day after last Friday's 18month highs.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Books of TheTimes
description: ADEPRESSING REALITY about the legacy of Mahatma Gandhi is that there is no legacy. While he lived, he accomplished. Through dedication, moral strength, selfsacrifice and rigid discipline, he led and prodded millions of Indians in a quest for freedom, equality and the wherewithal of human survival.

title: Triangles, Triangles
description: PARISIn recent columns I have sought to analyze political changes now starting to take place in Europe and North America; but it is in Asia, where the greatest proportion of humanity lives, that altering power balances may prove more significant.

title: Wiley Decries 2 Fairness Rules
description: WASHINGTON

title: No Matter What
description: I teach language arts and creative writing in a New York City junior high school. It is a good school, considering the latest reading test scores and the economic level of the student body. But good is a relative term. Many of the school's 50 classes are similar in background, ability and disposition to the one that is my official class, as described below.

title: Personal Health
description: IN ITINERARY OF A Breakfast published in 1920, Dr. J. H. Kellogg. medical director of the Battle Creek, Mich., Sanitarium and brother of the rounder of the Kellogg Company, described the colon as the source of more disease and physical .suffering than any other organ of the body. To counter the unhealthy state of colonic affairs, he prescribed an antitoxic diet consisting chiefly of fruits, cereals and fresh vegetables.

title: RAVITCH PROPOSALS CRITICIZED BY STEIN
description: Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein, who is seeking the Democratic nomination forManhattan Borough President, touched. off a dispute yesterday with Richard Ravitch, a builder who is thinking of run ning for Mayor of New York City, overproposals by Mr. Ravitch for solving theproblems of the financially troubled MitchellLama housing program.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HERE SHE COMES Anna Russell is back, appearing at 5:45 P.M. today as this week's Interlude guest at Town Hall, 113 West 43d Street. To her legion of longtime fans, the musical satirist is one of a kind, whether impersonating Mrs. Cowbeach, president of the Women's Federation of Art and Culture.Clubs or wryly sabotaging such delicate classical precincts as the French art song and German lieder. Miss Russell's analytical broadsides aimed at Wagner's Ring cycle and Verdi's Nabucco are hilarious, by consensus.

title: Members of Unions At Conrail Threaten To Walk Out Today
description: Members of four railroad craft unions, angered by the furlough last Friday of 1,200 union workers, threatened last night to strike the Consolidated Rail Corporation at 6 o'clock this morning, halting all freight and commuter service, including some in New York City, Westchester County, Connecticut and New Jersey.

title: Tunisia Builds Export Industry to Develop Jobs and Skills
description: TUNIS  Salah Ben Yahmed, like many Tunisians, has worked in Italy, West Germany and France. Now he has come home to live with his family and has found a Job as a chief mechanic for one of the new textile  export companies.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE EAGLES of C. L. Sulzberger's title are the three European royal housesthe Hapsburgs, the Hohenzollerns and the Romanovsthat employed that bird as their symbol. And his book is a chronicle of the decline and collapse of the empires these houses presided over. The decline in each instance was rapid and the collapse ignominious and simultaneous, for the monarchies of Austria, Germany and Russia all were toppled in World War I.

title: Technology
description: Setting controlled fires in a 30footthick coal seam more than 250 feet beneath Wyoming's high, dry plains, United States Government researchers have produced up to 11.5 million cubic feet daily of a gas mixture that would be suitable for running a local electric power plant.

title: A Move for Job Enrichment And Humanization of Work
description: WASHINGTONContrary to popular belief, Michael Maccoby did not spring fullarmored out of the primordial ooze as a stalker of victoryobsessed team captains in corporate executive suites. Long before his book The Gamesman started zooming up the bestseller list, Dr. Maccoby had won renown among social scientists as chief theorist for an experiment in work humanization that has been transforming fundamental attitudes toward work, productivity and industrial democracy at a Tennessee autoparts factory.

title: Carter's Home County Rejects School Bonds
description: AMERICUS, Ga., March. 29 (AP)Voters in Sumter County, which includes President Carter's home town of Plains, rejected today a $2.2 million school bond issue that the President and his wife had actively supported.

title: Burmese Get New Premier
description: RANGOON, Burma, March 29(AP)The Burmese Peoples Assembly today elected former Minister of Mines U Maung Maung Prime Minister, replacing U Sein Win, who resigned after criticism of his Government's economic program. Sein Win announced last month that he would step down, along with several top aides, after critics charged his Government was unable to revive Burma's economy. Later he and such leaders as Finance Minister U Lwin and Home Minister U Ko Ko were dropped from the party's central committee.

title: Putting the Spring Into Energy
description: WASHINGTONFor at least two decades, United States energy pcilicymaking has been dominated by superoptimism and erroneous assumptions. Now a brutal winter has exposed our mistakes and has sent a second warning that our predicament is indeed serious. This is a propitious time to question the old policies and reexamine the old assumptions, for one advantage of any new Administration is that it has a fleeting opportunity to make a fresh start.

title: Behind Haley's Suit Against Doubleday
description: IN THE MIDST of triumph, there is a sudden taste of ashes for Alex. Haley. His phenomenally successful Roots has sold more than 1.5 million hardcover copies at $12.50 each in 175 days, bringing him fame and wealth.

title: Woody Shaw Ensemble
description: In the modern jazz mainstream, an area bounded chronologically by the hard bop of the early 1950's and the Modal playing popularized by Miles Davis and John Coltrane during the early 1960's, Woody Shaw is the reigning trumpet king. Freddie Hubbard is Hubbard stiff competition, but Mr. Hubbard is mining the disco vein, leaving Mr. Shaw to explore a purer vision.

title: David F. Henderson, 57, Sergeant With U.N.'s Security Service
description: Sgt. David F. Henderson of the United Nations Security and Safety Service, a familiar figure at the delegates entrance to the United Nations General Assembly building, died Saturday in his home. He was 57 years old and lived at 2200 Madison Avenue.

title: 28 Lists in Israeli Vote, but All Eyes Are on 3 Parties
description: JERUTJSALEM, March 29Israel's political campaigns are underway here with a crazy quilt of minor parties seeking seats in Parliament and with the governing Labor Party trying to heal its internal divisions and avert a further erosion of its strength in the general election on May 17.

title: SIDES IN MAINE SUIT MEET IN WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, March. 29Maine Indians and elected officials, with their raspective lawyers, met in the White House today but reached no Compromise on the Indians claims to most of the state.

title: 3 More Bodies Found in Mine
description: TOWE RCITY, Pa., March 29(AP)Rescue workers last night recovered the bodies of three of five coal miners missing since March 1 whn a torrent of water rushed through the Porter Tunnel of the Kocher Coal Company mine here. The recovery brought to seven the number of men killed in the cavein.

title: Studies Find Birth Pills Riskier for Smokers Over 30
description: The increased risk of death faced by older women who use oral contraceptives largely results from the combined effects of cigarette smoking and pill use, according to an analysis of British and American studies released yesterday.

title: Goheen Is Reported Choice of President For Envoy to India
description: WASHINGTON, March 29The White. House plans to appoint Robert F. Goheen; the former president of Princeton University, as Ambassador to India, representing the United States during a period of internal change in India that could lead to closer relations between the two nations.

title: Closed End Funds
description: Tuesday, March 29, 1977

title: U.S. Open Golf to Get 7 Hours TV Coverage
description: ABC has scheduled 7 hours of coverage and will televise all 18 holes of the final round of the United States Open golf championship June 17 to 19 at Southern Hills Country Club in Tulsa, Okla.

title: HardRock Nite City
description: You have to give Ray Manzarek credit for trying, but that's about all the credit you can give him. The former keyboard player for the Doors has been looking throughout the 1970's for a new forum for his talents.

title: U.S. and Soviet To Form Panels OnMajor Issues
description: MOSCOW, March 29Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said here today after the second day of wideranging talks that the United States and the Soviet Union had agreed to establish working groups to discuss issues that could be only initially explored during his visit.

title: RUNWAY PROCEDURE: RULES ARE UNIFORM
description: Air safety experts agreed yesterday that there appeared to be nothing abnormal about the radioed instructions from the control tower that put two Boeing 747 jets on the same runway in the prelude to their collision at a Canary Islands airport Sunday.

title: Of Free Speech and Pay TV
description: After two decades of controversy, neither the promise nor the threat of pay television has been realized. But now, a decision by the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia may bring both a bit closer.

title: Black Schools in Jersey Game
description: Like a shortorder cook casually sliding another treat onto the counter. the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority yesterday added a third game to its 1977 college football schedule at Giants Stadium.

title: SENATE UPHOLDS STRAUSS AS U.S. TRADE NEGOTIATOR
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (UPI)The Senate confirmed today by voice vote the appoinment of the former Democratic National chairman, Robert S. Strauss, to be United States trade negotiator with the rank of ambassador.

title: Lively Jazz Quintet Led By Prime Bob Mover
description: Bob Mover, a young alto and soprano saxophonist, is leading a jazz quintet on Monday nights at Sweet Basil, Seventh Avenue at Bleecker Street, that has its roots firmly planted in the bebop era. The primary bopper is Mr. Mover but he also draws his trumpeter, Tom Harrell, into the style quite often.

title: Letters
description: No Punishment

title: Neil Simon Gives His Wife a Gift
description: HOLLYWOOD. MARSHA MASON and Richard Dreyfuss face each other across a kitchen table in the shabby New York apartment her last lover has secretly sublet to Mr. Dreyfuss before abandoning her. Neil Simon stands in a corner watching his wife making movie he has written as his gift to her. He is a tall, tentative man, far too ordinary looking in his hornrimmed glasses, prim navy blue pullover and redandblue checked shirt to be the most successful modern American olavwrieht.

title: PART OF SCHOOL DAY CUT IN NEW YORK CITY WILL BE RESTORED
description: ALBANY, March 29Part of the school day in New York City that was cut out in the settlement of a teachers strike in 1975 will be restored under an agreement among the Legislature, the city and the teachers union about how to spend a $26 million windfall that the city school system is to receive under revised formulas in the state's new budget.

title: DISCOVERIES; MoonJuneTune Courses
description: Much love and heaven above, moon and Juneand anyone can be a song writer. No Sir (Madame?) (Ms?). But if you think you have talent, and ideas, and that you could do as well as most of the tunesmiths raking in the dough, maybe one of the first steps would be to check out an organization called Songwriter Seminars and Workshops. There are several courses in basic and advanced pop songwriting, starting a project for the musical theater and music theory, and they range from five twohour sessions to 11 sessions of twoandhalf hours each. Prices go from $75 to $120 a course and a telephone call to Libby Bush or Ted Lehrman at 2651853 will bring forth more information and literature. The address, if one is writing, is 119 West 57th Street, New York 10019.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Horses listed in order of Post positions Later designates OTB listing FIRST57.000, cl., 3YO, 6f,

title: Best Buys
description: NOT WITHOUT a sense of the fitness of things, the food stores that were featuring corned beef for St. Patrick's Day are not overlooking Passover.

title: Catholics Urge. Parishes to Drop Hymns Criticized as AntiSemitic
description: The staff of the liturgical committee of the United States Catholic Conference, seeking to improve JewishRoman Catholic relations, has appealed to parishes nationwide to substitute alternative hymns for a portion of the Good Friday ritual that some have called antiSemitic.

title: Elizabeth Ames, Creator of Yaddo, Upstate Cultural Haven, Dies at 92
description: Elizabeth Ames, who transformed Yaddo, a philanthropist's vast estate in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., into a retreat that nurtured many of the nation's leading creative artists, died Monday in Saratoga Springs Hospital.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: Front Page 2  No Title

title: Kean Proposes Energy Division To Deal With Matter Efficiently
description: Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean of Livingston called yesterday for a new State Division of Energy in the Department of Law and Public Safety, in the second position paper of his campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor.

title: Offenses Defined for Korea Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, March 29Lawyers for the House ethics committee have taken the first step to outline the scope of the committee's investigation of allegedly illegal or improper receipt of South Korean favors by Congressmen.

title: Teacher Sues the F. B. I. For $600,000 Over Raid On His Home in Brooklyn
description: An earlymorning F.B.I. raid that hit the wrong target has resulted in a $600,000 civil suit against the agency by a former Brooklyn College English teacher, his wife and 4yearold son.

title: Byrne Requests More Funds for Retarded Children
description: TRENTON, March 29In an emotional scene on the State House steps today, Governor Byrne told 2,000 demonstrators that he had asked the Legislature for extra money to upgrade educational opportunities for retarded children in New Jersey.

title: Politics, Legality Make Rocky Road for Smut Ban
description: Mayor Beame said the other clay that he was not too worried about the liberties of people who purvey films showing 9yearold girls forced to perform sex acts with animals, and that there was no doubt every member of the Board of Estimate snared that sentiment. Being against massage parlors and obscene movies is good politics and good policy; no Borough President would disagree that.

title: KLM Message Adds to Mystery Of Plane Crash
description: American aviation officials analyzing the twoplane collision in the Canary Islands Sunday now believe that, though the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines jet began its takeoff without the required clearance, the tragedy might still have been averted if the crew's radioed takeoff message had been clearer.

title: Dr. Harold Kelman, Founder of Institute Of Psychoanalysis
description: Dr. Harold Kelman, neurologist, psychiatrist, psychoanalyst, teacher and author, died early yesterday at his home on East 83d Street at the age of 70. He had been ill for a year as a result of a brain tumor.

title: Events Today
description: THE SHADOW BOX by Michael Cristofer; directed by Gordan Davidson; et The Morosco Theater, 217 West 45th Street, 6:45.

title: Chanel Updated: First ReadytoWear Unveiled in Paris
description: PARIS PARIS, March 30Chanel has been dead for six years now, but the style she launched in the 1920's, which set the tone of fashion through much of the 20th century, remains valid. The House of Chanel, which has continued making custom clothes since her death, introduced its first collection of readytowear today. The clothes work.

title: Unusual Artifacts From West Africa
description: The romance Scott Sanders has with West Africa began several years ago when he served in the Peace Corps. By the time his stint had ended he had become acquainted with a number of villagers from Abomey, the ancient capital of Benin, who showed him their appliqued hangings  full of bright birds and animals and plants and arcane symbols that bespoke the legends of kings.

title: New Band For Radio Proposed
description: WASHINGTON THERE ARE MORE THAN 8,000 radio stations operating in the United States, a number that practically exhausts the available spectrum for AM and FM.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures;
description: Wednesday, March 30, 1977

title: BOILER ADJUSTMENTS URGED TO SAVE FUEL
description: CHERRY HILL, March 30Charles A. Richman, acting administrator of the State Energy Office, said today that New Jersey could save at least 200 million gallons of oil annually by requiring industrial plants to make simple boiler adjustments to increase operating efficiency.

title: MORRIS GITTER
description: Morris Gitter, a wholesale stamp dealer in Manhattan for 34 years, died yesterday at his home at 30 East 62d Street. He was 76 years old. A pioneer Zionist, he interrupted his studies from 1920 to 1922 to help develop the town of RishonLeZion in what was then Palestine.

title: To Catch a Flea
description: HONG KONG, March 30With informal discussions already under way regarding a trip by President Carter to Peking, here is what America's policy planners should keep in mind regarding the Chinese outlook on the world.

title: RCA AND MATSUSHITA SIGN A VIDEO ACCORD
description: The video tape recorder business got a major lift yesterday with the announcement that the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan had signed an agreement to supply the RCA Corporation with video oassette recorderplayers.

title: Conrail Workers Yield to Court Order Banning Strike Adams Cancels Plan
description: A strike against the Consolidated Rail Corporation that would have halted rail service in 16 states yesterday did not occur after workers agreed to honor a Federal court order barring the walkout.

title: Books of The Times
description: TRUE, NOT ALL of the 60 million or so poker players in America necssarily want to get better at the game. A sizable number of them are compulsive gamblers and therefore want to loseor, as Freud and his followers have observed, need to punish themselves for their childhood sexual fantasies by having their money taken away from them. Still, there are plenty of men and women around who see poker as the game of skill it essentially is and genuinely want to improve at it. A constructive and inexpensive way to do so is to read a good book about the game. Which brings us to David Spanier's Total Poker, an entertaining survey of the game and its manners by an economics correspondent for The Times of London.

title: Carter Warns He May Add Arms If Moscow Balks in Further Talks
description: WASHINGTON, March 30President Carter said today that he was not discouraged by the setback in arms control talks in Moscow but that he would be forced to consider acceleration of American weapons developments if the Soviet Union failed to negotiate in good faith at another round of discussions in Geneva in May.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A committee representing the 1,700 prisoners at the Attica Correctional Facility has apologized for an incident in which an inmate slashed a female guard on the face with a razor. The Inmate Liaison Committee submitted an apology to Harold J. Smith, the prison superintendent. The committee said it did not condone such actions by inmates. Herb Richmond, 39 years old, of New York City is being held in isolation after being accused of slashing the guard, Colleen Bolger, 25, also of New York. Another corrections officer, James B. Munger of nearby Warsaw, suffered a broken nose in subduing the prisoner who assaulted Miss Bolger, according to prison authorities.

title: HOUSE BUDGET PANEL REBUFFS PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The House Budget Committee, setting spending targets for the next fiscal year, rebuffed President Carter today on defense spending, cuts in water projects, and on elimination of Federal grants to school systems near Federal installations.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: Sheriff Says He Lied About Transfer Of Mrs. Chesimard to Aid Security
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, NJ., March 30 (AP) Sheriff Joseph DeMarino of Middlesex County said today that he had intentionally lied to the press about when Joanne Chesimard would be transferred to the Clinton State Correctional Institution for security reasons.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)The scientific arm of Congress was authorized today to begin to study immediately the risks and benefits of the artificial sweetener, saccharin.

title: Flying Home, Survivors Tell and Retell of Escape
description: The C141 was about half way across the Atlantic when Lieut, Col. Charles R. Queen realized that the Air Force had lost its battle to save Isabelle Lord's life.

title: Key Peking Meeting Is Believed Completed
description: HONG KONG, March 30A twoweek meeting of Chinese leaders has concluded in, Peking analysts here believe, and it appears to have been the most important since the arrest of four leftist leaders last autumn.

title: End to U. S. Backing of TaxExempts Asked
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The Treasury Department called for an end to Federal backing of taxexempt municipal bonds and for Federal subsidies for student, farm and other fixedrate borrowers.

title: Spain Says Workers May Form Unions After Four Decades
description: MADRID. March 30 (AP)Spanish workers were given the right today to form their own trade unions after nearly four decades of governmentsponsored unions established by the late Francisco Franco.

title: Thais Round Up Rightist Figures After Foiled Coup
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 30Thailand's ruling military junta has begun a roundup of members of its rightwing opposition as a result of the attempted coup by a small group of officers last Saturday.

title: An Investigator Indicted in Killing
description: A rackets investigator with the Brooklyn District Attorney's office was indicted yesterday on a charge of manslaughter, in the death of an unarmed Brooklyn youth last January, and on assault, for wounding a second youth, after stopping them both for questioning about a suspected burglary.

title: Transit Critic and First Woman Are Selected for Posts on M.T.A.
description: The chairman of a citizens transportation committee who is a transit critic and a woman who is a regular rail commuter between Westchester County and Manhattan have been selected by Governor Carey as new members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, state officials disclosed yesterday.

title: Sound
description: EVER SINCE, as a chronically penurious student, I used to go without lunch to save money for my first sound system, I have been keenly aware that the lifelike reproduction of music is not merely a technical challenge, but a financial one. A happy few surmount such challenges with a casual wave of the checkbook, but for most listeners, cost is an important factor in their choice of components.

title: Vladimir Fuka, Artist, 50, Dies; Widely Known Book Illustrator
description: Vladimir Fuka. a Czechoslovakborn artist who was primarily known for his children's book illustrations and other graphic works, died on Tuesday at his home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 50 years old.

title: The AntiCrime Force That Struck Out
description: A General Accounting Office study of the Federal campaign against organized crime has come to a discouraging conclusion: Even with the vaunted interagency strike forces, even after spending $800 million in the last decade, the racketbusting campaign is a bust. It has lacked coherent strategy, clear organization and even a workable definition of its adversary.

title: When the Milkman Broke the Morning Hush
description: Tradesmen. The word sounds quaint now but in the late 1920's, when I was growing up in New York, at least onehalf the family's business was conducted, in cash, with the smallbusiness merchants or salesmen who brought many of our needs directly to the front door.

title: ECONOMISTS STUDY CITES OVERCHARGES BY GROCERY CHAINS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The increasing market power of large grocerystore chains has led to monopoly over charges costing consumers $662 million a year, according to a study by five economists presented at a Congressional hearing today.

title: A Clearing House for Architectural Roots
description: Thanks to the immense popularity of Roots, the best selling book by Alex Haley that also spawned a widely viewed television series, many Americans have a pretty good idea of how to go about researching their genealogy. But most people would be at a loss if asked to trace the origins of a building.

title: VANCE DISAPPOINTED
description: MOSCOW, March 30Talks between Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Leonid I. Brezhnev on a treaty to limit offensive missiles and bombers carrying nuclear warheads broke down today.

title: Reviving Copper, Silver
description: HAS SILVER replating gone the way of chimney sweeping and doortodoor knife grinding? Not as long as Victorian cruets and wedding presents from rich uncles are in use, although the number of craftsmen doing replating has dwindled.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SPRING IS HEAR Some of the freshestsounding seasonal elegance in town comes from two hacktoback baby grands at Peacock Alley, the WaldorfAstoria Hotel's spacious loungerestaurant. The duo pianists are John De Maio and Fred Silver, who are well known locally and on concert tour for their adroit blends of theater melodies and classics. At their new station, they play Tuesday through Saturday from 4:30 to 9:30 P.M.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 31, 1977

title: KLM Message Adds to Mystery Of Plane Crash
description: American aviation officials analyzing the twoplane collision in the Canary Islands Sunday now believe that, though the KLM Royal Dutch Airlines jet began its takeoff without the required clearance, the tragedy might still have been averted if the crew's radioed takeoff message had been clearer.

title: Hostages At Large
description: WASHINGTONIn the weeks since the Hanafi Moslems released three sets of hostages in Washington, some journalists and politicians have scolded the owners of movie houses for rebooking Mohammad, Messenger of God, the movie that enraged the Moslems.

title: Washington Wife A Life in Limbo
description: WASHINGTON BACK IN GEORGIA, she worked hard to get her husband elected. Driving the length and breadth of the biggest Congressional district east of the Mississippi, she made speeches and shook hands at women's clubs, at livestock shows, at barbecues, in cities, towns, hamlets, at crossroads. She picked butterbeans in the fields with prospective voters. She tacked up campaign posters on telephone poles along stretches of rural highways so hot they melted the crepe soles of her shoes.

title: Carter Hawley Reports Slight Drop in Earnings In Fourth Fiscal Quarter
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. reported yesterday a slight drop in profit for its fourth quarter and a slight increase for the year ended Jan. 29.

title: Bugging in Nassau Not Confirmed
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 30The Nassau County District Attorney's office said today that there was no evidence to substantiate allegations that telephone eavesdropping devices had been secreted in the offices of the Nassau County Republican Party and in the private law office of its chairman, Joseph M. Margiotta.

title: Home Beat
description: HERE is a fivebedroom house on the stage of Martinson Hall at the Public Theater, and someone has been sleeping in one of the beds after hours.

title: Killing of Queens Youth Spotlights The Problems of the 2 Ridgewoods
description: Elderly residents of Ridgewood, Queens, sat in the sunshine in the park across from Grover Cleveland High School yesterday, complaining that unbroken benches were scarce because of destructive young people, a lack of policing and a city that pays no attention. few infants in pink or blue snoozed in expensive prams while mothers helped toddlers on the swings.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed In order of post positions

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: AT HARTFORD

title: Robsevelt
description: Horses listed in order of Post positions Letter designates OTB listing

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: F.B.I.Says Killings Dropped Last Year While Thefts Rose
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)Violent crime declined in virtually every part of the country last year, but a surge in thefts in some big cities prevented the overall national crime rate from falling, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Giants Sign McCovey
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 30 (AP)Willie McCovey, who returned to the San Francisco Giants as a free agent on tryout basis this spring, was signed to a oneyear contract today. The 39yearold slugger reportedly has an incentive clause in the agreement.

title: Don't, Wear White to Monsters
description: WE DON'T LEARN, we just don't learn. Take a member of the audience the night I saw Monsters at the Astor Place. Young fellow, seemed very pleasant, obviously dedicated to the theater and its newest playwrights, two of whose shortish works make up the bill. I'm sure, as he made his plans for the evening, he did everything right. Arranged for his seats well ahead obviously, for he'd been able to get two right down in front, second row probably dined at a decent restaurant, for he was rather better dressed than most occasions now demand: spanking clean white jacket, light shirt, I think a bow tie He looked so well. But what can he have been thinking of?

title: 4 Refiners Indicted In PriceFixing Plot On Industrial Sugar
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn indicted four sugar refining companies yesterday on charges of conspiring to fix the price of industrial sugar in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: U.S.Seeks to Force Con Edison to Burn Coal at Three Sites
description: WASHINGTON. March 30The Federal Energy Administration plans to try to compel the Consolidated Edison Company to burn coal instead of oil at three of its New York City generating plants, but the city is expected to fight the order.

title: Stage: Wait No Longer for the Definitive Godot
description: THE DEFINITIVE production of Waiting for Godot, the greatest play of our time, opened Tuesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The only problem for Englishspeaking audiences is that the performance is in Germana production of West Berlin's Schiller Theater. It is definitive because it is staged by the author, Samuel Beckett, who, as a director of his own work, has the same precise lucidity of vision that marks his writing.

title: GARDENING: IN AND OUT
description: THINK SPRING and one of the first thoughts that comes to mind is the color yellow. It could be the crocuses now spending their all on lawns and in terrace tubs. Or the forsythia hedge ready to burst into bloom in the neighbor's yard, or the host of golden daffodils.

title: Esposito Helps Rangers eat Flames, 43
description: Well, said JeanGuy Talbot, the Rangers assistant coach, we finally beat them. It's good to know we could do it.

title: Bergen Freeholders Board Plans To Revive CulturalCenter Study
description: HACKENSACK, March 30The Bergen County Board of Chosen Freeholders has decided to revive a study into the feasibility of building a major cultural and arts center in the county.

title: Senators Hear F.T.C. Nominee; H. M. Williams Named to S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  Michael Pertschuk told Senators considering his nomination to head the Federal Trade Commission today he would seek to replace laborious, seemingly endless litigation of antitrust cases with agencydrafted rules, and he threatened to discharge F.T.C. lawyers who disagreed.

title: I.R.S. Investigating Two Banks On Cash Transaction Reports
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (Reuters)The Internal Revenue Service is investigating two major banks suspected of failing to report large cash transactions as required under the Bank Secrecy Act, Congress was told today.

title: Miss Evert's Clay Streak Goes to 102
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., March 30 (AP)Chris Evert won her opening match routinely in the $110,000 Family Circle tennis tournament today. She scored a 60, 63 victory over Bunny Bruning of La Jolla, Calif., in 45 minutes.

title: Nobel Award in Economics: Should Prize Be Abolished?
description: The award of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science to Prof. Milton Friedman of the University of Chicago last October provoked a storm of criticism over Professor Friedman's rightwing politics, focused particularly on his willingness to give advice to the central bank and the postAllende Government of Chile. This storm has been followed by a blast from an earlier Nobel Laureate, Prof. Gunnar Myrdal of the University of Stockholm, aimed not directly at Professor Friedman but at the very concept of a Nobel Prize in economics.

title: GISCARD ANNOUNCES NEW FRENCH CABINET
description: PARIS, March 30  President Valry Giscard d'Estaing, in a move intended to bring new vigor and unity to his embattled coalition's campaign against the Left, announced a new cabinet today containing one new face and dropping three prominent political leaders.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO KEEP ASSASSINATION PANEL AFTER SPRAGUE QUITS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The House of Representatives voted today to keep its Select Committee on Assassinations in existence through next year. The vote was taken after the committee's chief counsel, Richard A. Sprague, resigned.

title: When the Babe Almost Hit Huggins
description: Frank Lucchesi has a broken cheekbone and Lenny Randle has a lawyer. And by now, each presumably has second thoughts. Frank Lucchesi, the hospitalized manager of the Texas Rangers, will remember to drop the word punk from his vocabulary when addressing a player and Lenny Randle, the suspended utility infielder, will remember to keep his hands in his back pockets when addressing a manager. The threepunch knockdown of a manager by a player may not be unprecedented in the maior leagues. Doors can be closed. But there were no doors near third base where Lenny Randle showed he was a better candidate for the Golden Gloves than for a Golden Glove. Baseball historians can't seem to recall an incident quite like it. Dave Boswell, then with the Minnesota Twins, had a chance to flatten the manager but Billy Martin punched him out on the sidewalk outside a Detroit bar in 1969, after the pitcher had slugged Bob Allison, a teammate. Other managers and players have snarled at one another without swinging. And in 1925 Babe Ruth was supposed to have picked up little Miller Huggins, the Yankees manager, and held him by the heels off the back of a moving train while threatening to drop him onto the tracks. That incident never really happened, according to several Yankee players of that era. But that same year Babe Ruth almost punched Miller Huggins.

title: Soybeans Touch $9 a Ton for the First Time Since 74
description: CHICAGO, March 30 (AP)Soybean futures touched $9 a ton on the Chicago Board of Trade today, then fell back under heavy profittaking and closed on an uneven tone.

title: OTB Opens a Drive to Aid the Compulsive Gambler
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation, which prospers from mass wagering, announced a campaign yesterday to curb compulsive gambling.

title: Many Cities, Like New York, Making Do With Less
description: CHICAGO, March 29This city is going without new traffic signals and is skipping street repairs. Seattle will mow grass in its parks less often. And animals in Atlanta's zoo are having to make do with a less costly diet.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: RETURNING HOME: A flagdraped coffin containing remains of an American flier killed in Vietnam passes in review during ceremony at Travis Air Force Base, Calif. Remains of 11 servicemen were returned after the recent mission to Vietnam. At right is Mrs. Elwyn R. Capling and her daughter, Chris, and a family friend, Mrs. Paul Bergerot, left foreground. Lt. Col. Elwyn Capling was one of the 11 airmen who were identified.

title: Rejuvenated Baltimore Port Running Hard to Stand Still
description: BALTIMOREW. Gregory Halpin, second in command of the Port of Baltimore, still remembers that 1960 trade conference in Antwerp when he had to use an atlas to show the world's assembled trade officials where Baltimore was.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Aftermath of Disaster in Canaries
description: SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, March 30A woman sits on the floor of the telephone room of the Mencey Hotel, waiting for a longdistance call to Los Angeles to come through. For the first time, she is crying.

title: State Budget Raises Aid to Schools
description: ALBANY, March 30Following is a breakdown of what the new state budget, scheduled for passage tomorrow, will mean to school districts in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Glass Is BackPlastic's OutIn Italian Lighting
description: BELATEDLY, but with remarkable intensity, the Venetian glassmakers have joined the Italian Modern movement.

title: Pele Tunes Up With Cosmos and Without Interpreter
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J.,March 30For a 36yearold, he seemed to be fit, Coach Gordon Bradley said about Pele today after the Brazilian reported to camp 43 days later than his socce? teammates.

title: Masked Marvels
description: WITH PERFECTLY mastered gestures, a prodigal inventiveness and the almost frightening innocence of discovery, the three members of the Swiss mime group. Mummenschanz, are back in New York.

title: Labor Dept. Charges Slain Unionist Made Illegal Loans to Hotel Owner
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The Labor Department today accused Al Bramlet, the slain labor leader, and other trustees of a Las Vegas union pension fund of making illegal loans of more than $30 million to Morris Shenker, owner of the Dunes Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: A Judge Calls for Open Courts To Demystify Judicial Process
description: A Federal District Court judge in Brooklyn called on his colleagues yesterday to doff their judicial robes, step down from their lofty benches to the level of the litigants and to open their courts to television and radio to end confusion and ignorance about the judicial process.

title: Black Angola Refugees Reported Fleeing Into SouthWest Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 30 (Reuters) Hundreds of black Angolans, many of them wounded, are crossing the border into SouthWest Africa, also called Namibia, the South African Broadcasting Corporation reported today.

title: Panel Denies Suggesting Shorter Racing Season
description: New York's horse racing's latest erroneous tip appears to be the published report that a legislative panel would recommend cutting the length of the season. It won't. Neither will the sevenmember temporary commission suggest that the basic takeout on regular wagers at New York tracks be reduced from 17 to 14 percent. Both pieces of information were called totally inaccurate yesterday by John Hudacs, the group's executive secretary.

title: Advertising
description: R. J. Reynolds Tobacco knows plenty about menthol cigarettes and the people who smoke them. After all, its Salem brand, introduced in 1956, shot to first place in the category in 18 months and stayed there until Kool knocked it out of the box a couple of years back.

title: Margiotta Loyalist Dismissed by Caso From Nassau Post
description: MINEOLA, L. I., March 30A top Nassau County official who is a strong supporter of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Couney Republican chairman, was removed from his position today by Ralph G. Caso, the County Executive. The official, Francis E. O'Connor, Commissioner of General Services since 1971, declined Mr. Caso's offer of another position that would have mean a $13,000 loss in salary.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO KEEP ASSASSINATION PANEL AFTER SPRAGUE QUITS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The House of Representatives voted today to keep its Select Committee on Assassinations in existence through next year. The vote was taken after the committee's chief counsel, Richard A. Sprague, resigned.

title: U.S. Is Starting To Investigate Kodak Business
description: An investigation into monopolistic aspects of the Eastman Kodak Company's photographic film business has been started, a spokesman for the antitrust division of the Justice Department said yesterday.

title: HELEN KOCH
description: Helen Koch, wife of the late John D. Koch, founder of the Eagle Regalia Company and writer of literary and drama criticism for local Hungarianlanguage publications, died yesterday at the NewtownWellesley Hospital in Wellesley, Mass. She was 87 years old and lived at 280 Riverside Drive. Mrs. Koch oversaw her husband's concern following his death in 1953, until her own retirement at the age of 71. The company manufactured emblematic jewelry and banners as well as uniforms, mostly for fraternal organizations. Mrs. Koch is survived by her son, Sigmond Koch, professor of psychology and philosophy at Boston University.

title: Senate Panel Votes Amendment Easing Clean Air Measure
description: WASHINGTON, March 30A Senate subcommittee adopted today an amendment to the Clean Air Act that environmentalists said would indefinitely postpone deadlines established for lowering pollution to levels considered safe for human health.

title: People and Business
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday created an Office of the Chairman, to function as similar offices do at many major corporationsbroadening the management base and fostering centralized administration. The office, which will contain the Big Board's three top executives, will begin functioning on May 1.

title: Carter, Despite Campaign Attacks, Has Staff 30% Larger Than Ford's
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  A top White House aide acknowledged today that, despit' President's Carter's campaign attacks against the bloated bureaucracy, is Washington, the White House staff s now 30 percent larger than it was under President Ford. But he asserted that this was just a temporary situation.

title: AMPHETAMINE FOUND TO EASE SURGERY PAIN
description: Amphetamine, a drug popularly known as speed and criticized for its widespread abuse, has been found to have a salutary effect when injected with morphine in relieving severe pain after surgery.

title: Mansfield to Be Envoy to Japan; Harvard Man Gets High C.I.A. Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Mike Mansfield, the former Senate majority leader, has been selected to be Ambassador to Japan, Administration officials said today.

title: U. S.Soviet Proposals on Arms Cuts
description: Following are the Soviet and American proposals for limiting the deployment of strategic nuclear arms, in as much detail as is publicly known:

title: Naturals underfoot
description: Capture the natural beauty of outside for any room in your home. Now Macy's has an entirely new area devoted exclusively to the naturals  those exciting new handicrafts straight from nature . . . those tasteful compositions of exotic grasses: sisals, rushes, rice straws, maize or cocoa fibers . . . entwined with fashion and flair. All are meticulously detailed to highlight their natural beauty ... then woven into updated traditional favorites or more sophisticated styles. All reversible for longer wear. Whether you are seasoning your Manhattan apartment ... or decorating a suburban patioyou'll be delighted with one of our naturals underfoot!

title: Damita Jo Is Back
description: TEN YEARS AGO, Damita Jo, an energetic, blackhaired singer who had come to attention as a member of Steve Gibson and the Red Caps, had a bestselling record of the English version of Jacques Brel's Ne Me Quitte Pas, translated as If You Go Away. It was an unusual success for Miss Jo because her background of rhythmandblues and a singing style that borrowed generously from Dinah Washington was about as far from the Bret could get.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: The straight stalk and few petals of a single black flowerlike the minimal lines in Japanese brushstroke paintingis stand alone on stark white porcelain plate. The flower is one of a number of Images, handsome new concept in china from Block. All of them are drawn from nature, against the same shining white: a willowy blue flower; delicately veined leaves in a rust tone; a linear pattern in brown, like stalks of grass or reeds; and a fifth set of four different flowers in black. The serving pieces are in unpatterned white, and the shape of plates, platters and bowls is a squared circle. Patterns were created through various photographic techniques by Naomi Savage, a student of Berenice Abbott and Man Ray. Fivepiece place settings are $30 and $35. The fourflower patternteasel, Queen Anne's lace, dandelion and thistlesold in a 20piece place setting, is $120. Images is available now at Bloomingdale's (except the linear pattern, due the end of April).

title: Babcock Mergerthe Personal Side
description: George G. Zipf, chairman and president of the Babcock & Wilcox Company, looked better in yesterday's down market than Harry J. Gray, chairman, president and chief executive officer of United Technologies Inc.

title: Professor, 65, Who Killed Himself May Have Been Oswald Confidant
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., March 30 (UPI)A Russianborn professor who committed suicide, apparently when he learned that a House investigating committee wanted his testimony concerning President Kennedy's assassination, may once have been an operative for the Central Intelligence Agency and a confidant of Lee Harvey Oswald, sources familiar with the case said today.

title: ARTHUR DUNAIF
description: Arthur Dunaif, a retired New fork City Criminal Court judge, died yesterday at the Coral Gables (Fla.) Nursing Home. He was 82 years old and lived in Florida, although he maintained a home and private law practice here after his retirement from the court in 1964.

title: Nettles Is Returning; Yanks to Discuss Pact
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 30 Graig Nettles is ending his 48hour absence without leave from the Yankees tomorrow morning, after having won a promise from the team that it would discuss extending and revising his contract.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Common Foes Are Stressed In N.F.L. Plan
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., March 30The new schedule pattern adopted by the National Football League, which will start in 1978 with 16 regularseason games and four in the preseason, is one of the most significant changes the league has ever made and perhaps one of the best.

title: Bejart's Theatrical Faust
description: THE CHOREOGRAPHER Maurice Bjart seems obsessed with two things. His taste for pure theatrical spectacle and his concept of the artist as a man alone, a man searching. Perhaps one could push further and suggest that it was a concept of life as an arena and man as a briefly transitory actor.

title: G.N.P. Real Growth Rate Put at Just Under 4%
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 A rebounding economy was foreshadowed today by the Commerce Department's barometer of leading indicators.

title: Books: Sex On the Run In Vegas
description: SARAH KERNOCHAN'S novel Dry Hustle is an excursion through the back alleys of sex. A dry hustle is a form of con game that involves extracting money under promises of sexual favors. In other words, a dry hustler plays with all the skills of a courtesan upon male vanity and lust, promises a meeting later, wheedles upfront money on some story or other, then fails to show up.

title: Excerpts From Secretary Vance's Press Conference on Arms Talks in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, March 30 (AP)Following are excerpts from a transcript of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's news conference today at the residence of the United States Ambassador in Moscow:

title: Donghia at MassMarket Prices
description: THERE'S nothing new or startling about Angelo Donghia's furniture collection for the Kroehler Manufacturing Companyexcept, perhaps, the moderate prices.

title: Dollar Shows Gain; Pound Is Strong
description: BRUSSELS, March 30 (UPI)The United States dollar made gains at the opening of most European money markets today and sterling was strengthened by yesterday's announcement of a British budget designed to help Britain pull out of her economic crisis.

title: Carter Writes to Leader of Brazil
description: WASHINGTON, March 30President Carter has written a personal letter to President Ernesto Geisel of Brazil at a time when relations between the two countries are unusually strained.

title: ISRAEL CONCEDES IT HOLDS 2 GERMANS IN TERROR PLOT
description: TEL AVIV, March 30Israel has acknowledged that it has held for a year and intends to place on trial two West Germans and three Arabs alleged to have planned an attack on an El Al plane in Nairobi, Kenya, in July 1976.

title: Family Money: Checking Out a House
description: THE REPORT ran for almost 20 typewritten pages and was worth every cent of the $800 it cost the tenants who were thinking about cooping two preCivil War brownstones in Greenwich Village.

title: Scottie's Success Provides High Note for Voice Coach
description: Miss Julie of Stonehedge, the popular new star on the Scottish terrier horizon, is officially a champion. The American Kennel Club certificate arrived yesterday at the Manhattan apartment of her owner, Lehmann Byck, who discovered that Julie had the title tucked away even before he knew about it. Through an earlier miscalculation involving one point at the Meadowlands show, Byck thought the Scottie had earned her Ch. prefix at National Capital instead of the day before (March 12) at Rockland.

title: South Dakotans Set Game Plan for Cuba: Patience, Good Will and a Zone Defense
description: The South Dakota collegiate basketball team that will play in Cuba next week is putting its faith in patience, good will and a zone defense.

title: I'm (What?) Radicalized
description: I was reared with a reverential regard for lawful behavior. I accepted our laws and defended questionable Government practices against the onslaught of Marxist rhetoric. The 60's were almost my undoing. I rarely understood and even more rarely sympathized with radical student movements. Every one of my principles of lawful behavior was challenged.

title: Westinghouse to Pay 11.5 Million Default
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation will provide cash, equipment and services worth up to $11.5 million to three Pennsylvania utilities as a consequence of failing to deliver 646,000 pounds of uranium, the companies disclosed in Pittsburgh yesterday.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Industrial MiniParks Are Studied For Cities as a Stimulant for Jobs
description: TRENTON, March 30The state plans to study the possibility of establishing new small industrial parks in all New Jersey cities that have areas of high unemployment, state development officials said today.

title: It's Still a Springtime of Diplomacy
description: Despite yesterday's chill wind from Moscow, this is a springtime in American diplomacy. A new President and a new spirit have produced a thaw in attitudes toward Vietnam, Panama, much of Africa and now Cuba. They have turned thoughts to next steps with China, to new negotiations in the Middle East, to repair of the institutions of international collaboration and, above all, to control of the arms race.

title: BUDGET COMPROMISE IS REACHED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, March 30A latehour agreement on the welfare portion of the state budget broke a threeday legislative deadlock today and paved the way for passage tomorrow of an $11.5 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins Friday.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that discussions on the sale of Random House, the book publisher, to The Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles had been terminated.

title: Doing Away With the Decorating Rules
description: DO WHAT you should never do. Avoid the obvious, and you'll be way ahead of the game, said the interior designer, Robert Denning. That is his formula for taking the hohum out of decorating.

title: VANCE DISAPPOINTED
description: MOSCOW, March 30Talks between Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Leonid I. Brezhnev on a treaty to limit offensive missiles and bombers carrying nuclear warheads broke down today.

title: City's PotholeRepair Crews Find Queens in the Same Old Ruts
description: The huge cement  mixing truck ground through the pond that was supposed to be 31st Avenue, in College Point, Queens, creating halffoothigh waves that washed into heavily traveled College Point Boulevard.

title: Advantages of Starting Plants From Seed
description: WITH POCKETS of March snow still clinging to the shady hollows along our stream, this is nevertheless the weekend I'm going to start my tomatoes and eggplant. Not only is it considerably cheaper to start them from seed than to buy flats of plants later on in the season, but also the selection is greater. And there's definitely an extra ounce of satisfaction in truly starting a garden from scratch.

title: Denver to Join N.A.S.L.
description: The North American Soccer League granted Denver a franchise for the 1978 season yesterday. It will be called the Caribous of Colorado, and will become the 19th franchise in the N.A.S.L.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONThe business community has been increasingly irritated by the success of Ralph Nader and likeminded legal activists in appropriating the term public interest to identify the law firms that have been pressing consumer, environmental and similar causes in the courts.

title: BELL REPORTEDLY URGED TO ASK F.B.I. INDICTMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30, (AP)Attorney General Griffin B. Bell is studying a Justice Department report about surreptitious entries made by employees of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a spokesman said tonight.

title: Music: Mixed Fare
description: YOU'D THINK that after 20 years ofexposure to every kind of contemporary music, New York Philharmonic audiences would be inured to everything. But last night, when Zubin Mehta conducted the New York premiere of Morton Subotnick's Before the Butterfly, there was first restlessness and then some audible protest.

title: CRUDE OIL IMPORTS JUMP; RECORD IS SET FOR WEEK
description: Imports of crude oil into the United States set record last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. The previous mark had been set on Feb. 18.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Wilbur S. Forrest, a retired newspaper executive, that appeared in The Times last Saturday contained several errors on his survivors. Yvonne Hagen is his daughter. Benjamin Forrest is his son. He left eight greatgrandchildren.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Articles Term City In ArizonaOutpost For Crime Figures
description: By The Associated Press

title: To Put a New Airport In the St. Louis Area
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Transportation Secretary Brock Adams today reversed a controversial decision by his Republican predecessor and suspended plans to build a new St. Louis airport across the Mississippi River in Illinois.

title: Penn Central Case Conviction
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 30 (UPI)Francis N. Rosenbaum of McLean, Va., was convicted today as a conspirator in the repair loan scheme that sidetracked $4 million in Penn Central Railroad funds in September, 1969. Mr. Rosenbaum, who is 60, is the lawyer and conducted his own defense.

title: Value of Construction Contracts Up 14% in February From 1976 Month
description: The value of contracts for new construction, sustained by Federal public works spending and residential construction, increased 14 percent in February from the yearearlier level, according to an analysis of the construction market.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 30, 1977

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 30Local school board budgets were approved by voters in, 390 of 485 school districts, or 80 percent of the districts in the state, yesterday the first time since 1967, according to the State Department of Education, that fewer than were rejected.

title: Killingsworth Becomes Coach at Oklahoma State
description: STILLWATER, Okla., March 30Oklahoma State University, spurned by Kansas State's Jack Hartman, hired Jim Killingsworth of Idaho State as basketball coach today.

title: People in Sports
description: Boog Powell's major league baseball career apparently came to an end yesterday after 339 home runs and 16 seasons.

title: Service for Air Crash Victims Held in Canary Islands
description: SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, March 30The Roman Catholic Bishop of Tenerife Island led an ecumenical memorial service tonight for the more than 570 people who died here Sunday in the world's worst air disaster.

title: New Bond Issues
description: New on list.

title: At Your Service: Paints
description: YOU'VE MOVED to a new apartment and you've decided to paint it yourself. Why not? says Neil Janovic. Even East Siders who live in $150,000 coop apartments are doing their own painting these days.

title: P.S.C. Rebuffs Con Ed On Use of Bill Inserts
description: ALBANY, March 30  The Public Service Commission today denied the Consolidated Edison Company's request for at least temporary permission to use bill inserts to express its corporate views on public controversies. The commission had announced earlier this month that utilities would not be allowed to use such inserts, on the ground that their consumers were captive audience. Con Edison is appealing on constitutional and jurisdictional grounds.

title: SENATEAGAINSOFTENS PROPOSED ETHICS CODE
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)With only five members present, the Senate voted yesterday to soften another major restriction on the outside earnings of lawmakers, and then took a break today from debate on its proposed new ethics code.

title: About the Mets..
description: The Mets traded Benny Ayala to the St. Louis Cardinals for Doug Clary, a rookie infielder who will join their Tidewater farm club in the International Leagde. Ayala, a 26yearold outfielder, played part of two seasons with the Mets and now joins the Cardinals farm club at New Orleans in the Southern Association. . . .Dave Kingman, batting .192 this spring, apparently struck out again in his long contract hassle with the Mets. He has called a press conference today to explain his relations with the management. He has 10 hits in 52 times at bat so far, and five of them were home runs He also has 16 strikeouts, and no contract. . . .Bud Harrelson announced three days ago that he would abandon switchhitting for now and swing only from the right side. Since then, he has swung frequently from the left side. How come? All our lefthanded power is hurt, the little shortstop quipped. . . .Leo Foster, fighting for a job as a utility infielder, tore the skin on his right hip sliding into second base in the sixth inning. Not serious, the Mets reported.

title: Carter Links Rights Amendment to Fight for World HumanRights
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Adding a new twist to an old campaign, President Carter said tonight that the nation's delay in passing the equal rights amendment hurts us when we try to set a standard for human rights around the world.

title: U.S. Notes Progress in Cuba Talks
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The State Department today reported substantial progress toward an agreement with Cuba to regulate fishing and fix maritime boundaries between the two countries.

title: Personal Beauty
description: ALL OVER the country, women are flocking to plastic surgeons to trade in their old faces for young, unlined ones. Like the middleaged wife played by Elizabeth Taylor in the movie Ash Wednesday, many women optimistically imagine that a tuck here and a pleat there will wipe out not only wrinkles, but most of the problems in their lives. The fountain of youth is becoming a flood that threatens to overwhelm reason.

title: Events/Sports
description: 8 P.M., WMCA, WGBB: Basketball. Nets vs. Atlanta.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Horses? listed In order of post positions Letter designates OTB listing FIRST$9,000, cl., 3YO, 6f.

title: The Doors Of Justice: II
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  For more than 100 years a Federal statute has allowed anyone deprived of constitutional rights under color of state authority to sue in the Federal courts. The act was originally passed by Congress in 1871, and it remains one of our basic civil rights laws.

title: Letter From Home
description: WHEN WE moved to Connecticut seven years ago I was naturally curious to know why it was called the Nutmeg State. I was sure that the nickname had its origin in one of those picturesque incidents of colonial timesperhaps some demand by an English King (I think they were all named George) for a sum of four nutmegs and 12 peppercorns, payable to his bailiffs and assigns, for fishing rights along the Housatonic.

title: Disks: Haggard Recalls His Roots
description: RIZAHMS. Hungarian Dances for Plano, Four Hands, Nos. 121. Alfons and Aloys Kontarsky. piano. DG2530710.

title: Disks: Woody Herman's Anniversary Bash
description: Woody Herman celebrated his 40th anniversary as a band leader last November by giving a concert at Carnegie Hall at which his current band was joined by such celebrated members of earlier Herman Herds as Stan Getz, Zoot Sims, Ralph Burns, Al Cohn, the Candoli brothers, Pete and Conte. Jimmy Giuffre, Chubby Jackson, Billy Bauer, Jimmy Bowles, Jake Hanna and the singer Mary Ann McCall among others. It was a nostalgic reunion of these veterans with material they had made their early reputations with, as well as a showcase for the current Herd, which provided the background for the oldtimers and showed off some of its own stuff.

title: World News Briefs
description: JOHANNESBURG,March 30  The South African Government, reacting to growing pressures at home and abroad. announced a budget today that was marked by sharp increases in outlays for defense, for the police and for black education.

title: Honolulu's $33 Million Stadium Is Failing to Pay Its Way
description: HONOLULU, March 30Aloha Stadium, a $33 million installation west of here and up the hill from Pearl Harbor, lost about $250,000 in 1976, its first full calendar year of operation, and will not break even until 1978, or perhaps later, its manager said yesterday.

title: Inspector's Guide
description: Clem Labine, editor of the OldHouse Journal, 199 Berkeley Place, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11217, has put together a free fourpage checklist for home hunters interested in doing some preliminary inspection work on their own.

title: Market Place
description: Shares of Walt Disney Productions have dropped dramatically from levels of a year ago, reflecting a slowdown in earnings gains and heavy selling by institutional investors, which had long favored the shares.

title: Philippine Pilot Kills 5 Passengers, Hostess
description: ZAMBOANGA, the Philippines, Friday, March 31 (AP)The captain of Philippine airliner chartered by the military shot and killed five of his passengers and a stewardess here yesterday, officials on this southern island announced.

title: Suit Filed Against Saccharin Ban
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 30 (UPI)Catherine L. Machen, a diabetic, has filed suit in Federal District Court here to block the Food and Drug Administration's proposed ban on saccharin.

title: 14 Arrive at Texas Center
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 30  Doctors at Brooke Army Medical Center issued a very guarded prognoses for two of the 14 airplane crash victims who arrived here this morning.

title: Deaths
description: BELCHEREdwin Saymour, at Deerfield Beach, Fla., March 25, 1977, husband of Alyce B. Belcher, father of Thomas Edwin Belcher, or Me?arie, La., William H. Belcher of Brewster, N. Y. and brother of Mrs. William M. Johnston of West Hartford, Conn. Memorial service at Christ Church, Greenwich, on Friday, at 10:30 A.M. Interment private.

title: Dr. Frederick Craig, Developed a Method To Diagnose Cancer
description: Dr. Frederick S. Craig, an orthopedist who was a pioneer in diagnosing cancer of the spine without resorting to surgery, died Tuesday at Tompkins County Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y., after a short illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Bartow, Fla.

title: Murdoch and Six Others RookieofYear Prospects
description: Who will be the rookie of the year in the National Hockey League? Halfway through the season, there was little doubt in anyone's mind that Don Murdoch of the Rangers had the Calder Trophy wrapped up, so sensational were his scoring statistics.

title: SHIPTON, EXPLORER, MOUNTAIN CLIMBER
description: LONDON, March 30Eric Shipton, who took part in five assaults on Mount Everest, died on Monday at Ansty Manor, near Salisbury. He was 69.

title: All Subway Routes Getting Timetables
description: When will the train come?

title: Companies List Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended Feb. 28 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock Is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) over the counter.

title: New York Scored On Its Procedures Involving Contracts
description: The public officials who perform audits on New York City's operations took the Beame administration to task yesterday for alleged noncompliance with procedures on contracts, costly delays in filing reimbursement claims in child care and failure to keep track of cars used by city officials.

title: SOVIET TO INCREASE USE OF U.S. SHIPS FOR TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP)The Soviet Union has agreed to use more United States ships for some trade between the two nations and to pay an extra $1.5 million this year to United States ships carrying grain, the Commerce Department announced today.

title: Datsun's Marketer Sheds Ad Agency
description: The marketer of Datsun cars and trucks, which last week said there was no truth in the report that it might be splitting with its ad agency, announced yesterday that it was splitting with its ad agency. The account, according to the Nissan Motor Corporation, bills in excess of $35 million. That is a huge account.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A troubled juror has written to a Federal judge calling three days of jury deliberations in a bankfraud case a mockery. The juror, Joan Palzer of Linden, wrote to Judge Herbert J. Stern in Newark after he declared a mistrial last week in the Federal case against Robert Prodan, former president of the State Bank of Bloomfield.

title: Radio
description: 7:309 A.M., WNYCFM. Three Dances from The Danserye, Susato; Concerto for Flute and Oboe, Haydn; Sonata VI in A minor, Biber; Introduction and Allegro, Ravel; My Beloved Spake, Purcell; French Suite No. 3, Bach.

title: Carter's Jobs Measure Is Stalled By a Dispute on ClearWater Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 30President Carter's $4 billion public works employment program, the centerpiece of his economic stimulus package, has been stalled by an elaborate game of Congressional poker between the Senate and the House over water legislation.

title: Excerpts From Remarks by President
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Following are excerpts from the transcript of President Carter's news conference this afternoon on the Moscow arms talks:

title: Decline Is 9th in Last 10 Trading Sessions
description: The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled nearly 11 points yesterday to push the bluechip indicator to its lowest level in more than 14 months.

title: Yount on Harpsichord
description: GIVEN THE WIDE distribution of harpsichordists and their instruments across the country, it must be assumed that Americans almost anywhere can, with a little effort, hear harpsichord literature of quality decently played wherever they live.

title: City's PotholeRepair Crews Find Queens in the Same Old Ruts
description: The huge cement  mixing truck ground through the pond that was supposed to be 31st Avenue, in College Point, Queens, creating halffoothigh waves that washed into heavily traveled College Point Boulevard.

title: REGENTS SHIFT ASKED IN REPORT TO CAREY
description: Governor Carey's commission on postsecondary education will call in its fina report for major changes affecting the New York State Board of Regents, inciud ing the appointment of its members by the Governor instead of, as now, by the Legislature.

title: About New York
description: Twentyfive years after a DC6 airliner crashed in the yard of an orphanage in Elizabeth, N. J., Lee Kreindler can still give a fascinating lecture on how the 1023 screw snapped in the No. 3 propeller, and how as a lawyer he spent a year discovering this and learning enough technology to make this point in court and win record damages.

title: Princess Christens Princess on the Hudson
description: Princess Grace of Monaco shattered a bottle of vintage champagne against the hull of the $60 million cruise ship Cunard Princess yesterday in what was billed as the first christening of a luxury passenger liner in the New York Harbor.

title: Bridge
description: Recent revelations about the remarkable events at the international team trials in Houston in January are sure to arouse considerable interest throughout the bridge world.

title: Background of Negotiations on StrategicArms Limits
description: WASHINGTON, March 30The first talks on limiting strategic arms ended nearly five years ago with the signing in Moscow of two historic agreements for putting limits on the growth of the American and Soviet strategic nuclear arsenals.

title: The Taming of the Snowmobile
description: From the sound and the fury, you might think the President is about to propose banning cars from the interstate highway system. Actually, all he wants more stringent regulation of offtheroad vehicles, like snowmobiles, on public lands, an idea that is reasonable and overdue.
