title: Article 6  No Title
description: Article 6  No Title

title: WOMAN COACH QUITS AT YALE, FILING SUIT
description: NEW HAVEN, March 30Judith Dixon, a champion tennis player and the coach of Yale University's women's tennis team, has resigned, charging the university in a suit with sex discrimination.

title: MOBUTU'S LONG RULE IN ZAIRE THREATENED
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 29President Mobutu. Sese Seko of Zaire appears to be in serious trouble and although he has weathered major storms before in his 11 and a half years of rule, diplomats here are questioning whether he can survive this one.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 31, 1977

title: Paterson Troupe Will Perform Tomorrow
description: PATERSON, March 30The Inner City Ensemble Theater and Dance Company, which recently returned from a triumphant tour in Puerto Rico after performing here before sellout crowds in December, will once again put on its shows at the Genesis Repertory Playhouse.

title: Israeli Arabs Rally In Galilee to Protest Land Expropriation
description: ARRABA, Israel, March 30About 10,000 Israeli Arabs, along with scores of Israeli Jewish supporters, gathered today in this village in northern Galilee to protest the Israeli Government's policy of expropriating Arabowned lands.

title: COURT VOIDS A RULE ON HIRING MINORITIES
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattandeclared invalid yesterday the controversial city requirement that construction contractors on municipal projects, have affirmativeaction programs to make sure they hire enough workers from minority groups.

title: BELL SALE SPARKS STRONG PRICE GAINS
description: The credit markets, cheered by the successful sale of $250 million of Southwestern Bell Telephone Company debentures Tuesday, staged its strongest advance yesterday in two and a half weeks. Corporate bond prices frequently gained a quarterpoint, and the new Bell System bonds rose to a slight premium above their original price after they were permitted to trade in the free market yesterday morning.

title: A Fabric Library at the Brooklyn Museum
description: ONE of the best kept decorating secrets in New York may be the existence of the Textile and Costume Collection at the Brooklyn Museum. Come May, when Bloomingdale's Topkapi Collection of Easterninfluenced fabrics is unveiled, it may not be such a secret, however, for on. the selvages of each line of fabric is printed the legend, Adapted from a work in the collection of the Brooklyn Museum. If a small crowd of designconscious people beats its way to the Textile Collection doors, the curator, Elizabeth Ann Coleman, will take it all in stride, as long as the requests are serious and specific.

title: Kudrov, Classic Mime Innovator
description: SIMON KUDROV, a mime artist who emigrated from the Soviet Union last year, made his debut in New York on Tuesday night at New York University's Loeb Center with a program entitled Characters and Images.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

title: A NoTrump Sniff
description: The two experts who resigned from the international team bridge trials in Houston in January were alleged by officials to be using a Sniff System, according to a statement made in Pasadena, Calif., this week by the nonplaying captain of their team, John Gerber of Houston.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk reports on reactions to a proposal to abolish the Nobel Prize in economics that comes from a winner of the prize, Sweden's Gunnar Myrdal. Page D9.

title: TV: A Sex Comedy By Innuendo
description: THREE'S COMPANY, a new situation comedy occupying ABC's Thursdaysat9:30 slot, is still another series based on a British television production. The trend began in earnest several years ago with All in the Family. It is not significantly enhanced by Three's Company, originally created for Thames TV, a commercial organization.

title: Don't Tinker With the Taylor Law
description: Most citizens feel that their garbage collectors have no right to go on strike, while most garbage collectors feel that citizens have no right to pay them less than they believe they deserve. To reconcile the demand for a strikefree public sector with the melancholy fact that a sense of outrage won't pick up garbage, New York State adopted its Taylor Law ten years ago. The law attempts to promote peaceful settlement of contract disputes by controlling collective bargaining for public employees.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: AT PITTSBURGH

title: Notes on People
description: HE HAS never made any bones about the fact that he likes drinking and cussing, but Billy Carter has now revealed another personal pleasure that may raise more eyebrows in religious circles of his hometown of Plains, Ga. He likes to bet, so much so, in fact, that he won $22,000 on a wager that his brother would be elected President.

title: Carter Warns He May Add Arrns If Moscow Balks in Further Talks
description: WASHINGTON, March 30President Carter said today that he was not discouraged by the setback in arms control talks in Moscow but that he would be forced to consider acceleration of American weapons developments if the Soviet Union failed to negotiate in good faith at another round of discussions in Geneva in May.

title: Uranus Is Encircled by 5 Rings, Scientists Report in Key Finding
description: The planet Uranus, it has been found, is encircled by at least five rings much like those of Saturn. In announcing this discovery yesterday the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said that the rings constituted the first major structures in the solar system to be found since the discovery of the planet Pluto in 1930.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: A Touch of Carolina in Brooklyn...and It's Home
description: SHE's 20 years old, intelligent, beautiful and one of the top black fashion models in New York. She often makes $75 an hour and her success has allowed her into worlds she didn't even know existed. But Peggy Dillard is a farm girl from South Carolina and one need only glimpse her apartment to know that she is still close to her roots.

title: Firefighters Blame Cuts for Toll
description: Leaders of New York City's fire officers and firefighters warned yesterday that firefighting capability had been cut excessively, resulting in a tragic increase in the loss of life and property.

title: Hers
description: KIMBERLEY ANN, 9, has just decided what she wants to be when she grows up: a parttime cocktail waitress with frosted blond streaks. It is probably just a coincidence that Kimberley Ann's mother recently graduated from law school and lopped off her twotone gold ringlets right at the dark roots.

title: YOUTH, 17, INDICTED ON CHARGES OF RAPE
description: A 17yearold Brooklyn youth has been indicted in Manhattan on charges of raping five women in different midtown office buildings and in a hotel in separate incidents in the last few months.

title: And Now,My Own Beauty Secrets...
description: IF YOU'VE SEEN ME lately, you will wonder how I have the nerve to be dispensing beauty secrets. Just remember the old adage: Those who can't, teach. In any case, you may have to learn all the latest beauty tricks from someone like me, who has the time to bone up on the subject. The naturally ravishing are much too busy attending galas or being ravished.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Wilbur S. Forrest, a retired newspaper, executive, that appeared in The Times last Saturday contained several errors on his survivors. Yvonne Hagen is his daughter. Benjamin Forrest is his son. He left eight greatgrandchildren.

title: Post for Woman Roils Houston
description: HOUSTON, March 30Mayor Fred Hofheinz, saying that he championed women's rights, today outraged members of the Houston City Council by appointing Nikki Van Hightower to a job as an affirmative action specialist only minutes after the Council voted to abolish her position as a womens advocate.

title: Tigers Fidrych Out 2 Months With Torn Cartilage in Knee
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 30Mark Fidrych, the legendary Bird of the Detroit Tigers pitching staff and the biggest boxoffice draw in baseball in years, was found today to have torn a cartilage in his left knee. He will undergo surgery tomorrow in Detroit and will be lost to the Tigers and his charmed public for at least two months.

title: Dr. J. Frederick Eagle Jr. Dies; Held Top New York Medical Posts
description: Dr. J. Frederick Eagle Jr., who played important roles in the medical life of the city, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

title: Japan's Color TV Exports Rise
description: TOKYO, March 30, (AP)Japanese manufacturers exported 381,447 color television sets in February, up 32.2 percent from January and 28 percent from the yearearlier month, the Electronics Industries Association of Japan announced today.

title: Many Cities, Like New York, Making Do With Less
description: CHICAGO, March 29This city is going without new traffic signals and is skipping street repairs. Seattle will mow grass in its parks less often. And animals in Atlanta's zoo are having to make do with a less costly diet.

title: DoItYourself Q & A
description: Q: I have a black lacquered Chinesemotif coffee table and want to know if there is any coating or type of finish that I can apply over it to make it impervious to water stains and scratchesP. T., Manhattan.

title: Symphony Off Stride
description: ASSOCIATE AND ASSISTANT conductors are the National Guardsmen of the symphonyorchestra world, paid to be ready in the event of the misfortune that everyone hopes will never happen. William O. Smith, the Philadelphia Orchestra's associate conductor, made his readiness quickly apparent at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night when he took Edo de Waart's place before the Philadelphia Orchestra. Mr. de Waart had canceled his guestconducting appearance because of illness.

title: The U.N.Today
description: March 31, 1977

title: BUDGET COMPROMISE IS REACHED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, March 30A latehour agreement on the welfare portion of the state budget broke a threeday legislative deadlock today and paved the way for passage tomorrow of an $11.5 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins Friday.

title: Design Notebook
description: IT IS NOT really true that New Yorkers will go to great lengths to put down the homes of their friends and acquaintances. They are, it seems to me, more delicate than most in expressing opinions about the quarters others live in. Exquisitely tactful by nature, and not wishing to appear too easily appreciative, to avoid obsequious flattery.
